name: 3/4 Sit-Up
instructions: Lie down on the floor and secure your feet. Your legs should be bent at the knees.
Place your hands behind or to the side of your head. You will begin with your back on the ground. This will be your starting position.
Flex your hips and spine to raise your torso toward your knees.
At the top of the contraction your torso should be perpendicular to the ground. Reverse the motion, going only ¾ of the way down.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal flexion can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion may increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Excessive spinal movement can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Flexion can irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of vertebral fracture due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Stress on the abdominal area should be minimized post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Supine position can reduce blood flow and increase intra-abdominal pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform a crunch, lifting only the shoulders off the ground.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight plate against your chest for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a stability ball to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Keep hands crossed over the chest to reduce neck strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with your hands.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent excessive lumbar flexion.
Engage the core throughout the movement to stabilize the spine.
formCues: Exhale as you lift your torso.
Keep your elbows wide and relaxed.
Focus on using your abdominal muscles rather than momentum.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the torso.
Pulling on the neck with hands.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: 90/90 Hamstring
instructions: Lie on your back, with one leg extended straight out.
With the other leg, bend the hip and knee to 90 degrees. You may brace your leg with your hands if necessary. This will be your starting position.
Extend your leg straight into the air, pausing briefly at the top. Return the leg to the starting position.
Repeat for 10-20 repetitions, and then switch to the other leg.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The supine position and leg movement can increase intra-abdominal pressure, potentially exacerbating disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The stretch may irritate the sciatic nerve, causing discomfort or pain.
contraindicationDetails.hamstring tendinitis: Direct stretching of the hamstrings can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: Post-surgical protocols often restrict hip flexion and extension to protect healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Supine exercises with leg elevation can increase the risk of vertebral compression fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a slight bend in the knee to reduce tension on the hamstrings.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance during leg extension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Place a small pillow under the lower back for support and perform the exercise with a bent knee.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid full extension and maintain a slight bend in the knee throughout the movement.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep the opposite leg flat on the ground to stabilize the pelvis.
Engage the core to maintain stability and prevent arching of the back.
Flex the foot of the working leg to enhance the stretch.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Using momentum to swing the leg instead of controlled movement.
Not maintaining a 90-degree angle at the hip and knee in the starting position.

name: Ab Crunch Machine
instructions: Select a light resistance and sit down on the ab machine placing your feet under the pads provided and grabbing the top handles. Your arms should be bent at a 90 degree angle as you rest the triceps on the pads provided. This will be your starting position.

At the same time, begin to lift the legs up as you crunch your upper torso. Breathe out as you perform this movement. Tip: Be sure to use a slow and controlled motion. Concentrate on using your abs to move the weight while relaxing your legs and feet.
After a second pause, slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the increased intra-abdominal pressure and spinal flexion, which can exacerbate these conditions.

abdominal_surgery.explanation: Recent abdominal surgery patients should avoid this exercise to prevent strain on healing tissues and potential complications.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve lying on the back or excessive abdominal pressure.

osteoporosis.explanation: Those with osteoporosis should be cautious with spinal flexion exercises to avoid vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform a basic floor crunch with no added resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance on the machine or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a standing cable crunch to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a resistance band around the back and perform a standing crunch to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to fit your body size.
Avoid jerking movements to prevent strain on the spine.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement.
Keep movements slow and controlled.
Exhale during the crunch phase and inhale when returning to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Allowing the legs to take over the movement.
Not adjusting the machine to fit personal body dimensions.

name: Ab Roller
instructions: Hold the Ab Roller with both hands and kneel on the floor.
Now place the ab roller on the floor in front of you so that you are on all your hands and knees (as in a kneeling push up position). This will be your starting position.

Slowly roll the ab roller straight forward, stretching your body into a straight position. Tip: Go down as far as you can without touching the floor with your body. Breathe in during this portion of the movement.
After a pause at the stretched position, start pulling yourself back to the starting position as you breathe out. Tip: Go slowly and keep your abs tight at all times.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the significant spinal flexion and extension involved, which can exacerbate these conditions.

joint_issues.details: Those with shoulder or wrist arthritis or tendinitis should modify or avoid this exercise as it places stress on these joints.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before attempting due to the potential for increased intra-abdominal pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to the risk of diastasis recti and increased intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from abdominal or spinal surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid due to the risk of spinal compression fractures.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute back, shoulder, or wrist injuries as the exercise can exacerbate these conditions.

neurological_conditions.details: Those with balance disorders or neuropathy should modify or avoid due to the risk of falling or losing control.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar extension.
Engage the core fully to protect the lower back.
Avoid arching the back or allowing the hips to sag.
formCues: Keep the core tight and engaged throughout the movement.
Roll out slowly and in a controlled manner.
Breathe in as you roll out and exhale as you return.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag, which increases stress on the lower back.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Not engaging the core fully, leading to poor form.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a limited range of motion, rolling out only a short distance and gradually increasing as strength improves.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise from a standing position, starting with the ab roller at your feet and rolling out to a plank position.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise on an incline or use a stability ball to reduce the load on the lower back.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a resistance band attached to a stable surface to assist the roll-out and reduce shoulder strain.

name: Adductor
instructions: Lie face down with one leg on a foam roll.
Rotate the leg so that the foam roll contacts against your inner thigh. Shift as much weight onto the foam roll as can be tolerated.
While trying to relax the muscles if the inner thigh, roll over the foam between your hip and knee, holding points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat with the other leg.

contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Individuals with hip arthritis may experience increased discomfort due to pressure on the joint and should modify or avoid this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.acute groin strain: This exercise can exacerbate symptoms in those with a recent groin strain due to the pressure and movement across the affected area.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The pressure applied during this exercise may increase the risk of fractures in individuals with severe osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: Those recovering from hip surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent disruption of the healing process.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, may find this position uncomfortable and should seek alternative exercises.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with less body weight on the foam roll by supporting more weight on the arms and opposite leg.
modifications.harder: Increase the pressure by lifting the opposite leg off the ground, requiring more balance and core engagement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Place a pillow under the abdomen to reduce lumbar extension and support the lower back.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid rolling too close to the knee joint and focus on the upper thigh area.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly over joints such as the knee and hip.
Do not apply excessive pressure if it causes pain beyond mild discomfort.
Ensure the foam roll is placed securely to prevent slipping.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain spinal alignment.
Breathe deeply to help relax the muscles of the inner thigh.
Move slowly and with control to effectively target tension points.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly, which reduces the effectiveness of the exercise.
Allowing the pelvis to tilt excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Holding the breath, which can increase tension and reduce relaxation.

name: Adductor/Groin
instructions: Lie on your back with your feet raised towards the ceiling.
Have your partner hold your feet or ankles. Abduct your legs as far as you can. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to squeeze your legs together for 10 or more seconds, while your partner prevents you from doing so.

Now, relax the muscles in your legs as your partner pushes your feet apart, stretching as far as is comfortable for you. Be sure to let your partner know when the stretch is adequate to prevent overstretching or injury.

contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Moderate to severe hip arthritis may be exacerbated by the abduction and adduction movements, potentially increasing joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.groin strain: High risk of aggravating an existing groin strain due to the direct involvement of the adductor muscles.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Individuals with lower back pain, especially those with disc issues, may experience discomfort due to the position and forces applied.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: High risk of compromising surgical recovery, particularly if the surgery involved the hip joint or surrounding structures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate risk due to potential discomfort and instability in the supine position, especially in the second and third trimesters.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a partner, using a resistance band around the thighs to control the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance by having the partner apply more force or using ankle weights.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with the knees slightly bent to reduce lower back strain.
injury_friendly.hip_pain: Limit the range of motion and use a resistance band for controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Communicate clearly with your partner to avoid overstretching.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
Ensure the partner applies even pressure to avoid joint torsion.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the pelvis.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Control the movement both during contraction and relaxation phases.
commonMistakes: Overstretching beyond comfortable limits.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Not communicating effectively with the partner.

name: Advanced Kettlebell Windmill
instructions: Clean and press a kettlebell overhead with one arm.

Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, push your butt out in the direction of the locked out kettlebell. Keep the non-working arm behind your back and turn your feet out at a forty-five degree angle from the arm with the kettlebell.
Lower yourself as far as possible.
Pause for a second and reverse the motion back to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: The rotational and bending movements can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_impingement.details: Overhead position may aggravate impingement symptoms; modifications are necessary.

rotator_cuff_tendinitis.details: Overhead stabilization can increase strain on the rotator cuff.

balance_disorders.details: The exercise requires significant balance and stability, posing a risk for falls.

osteoporosis.details: The bending and rotational forces could increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the windmill without a kettlebell or use a lighter weight to focus on form and flexibility.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier kettlebell or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion and focus on core engagement.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter kettlebell or perform the movement with the arm bent at the elbow.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is securely gripped and the wrist is neutral to avoid strain.
Maintain a controlled movement to prevent sudden jerks that could lead to injury.
formCues: Keep the kettlebell arm locked out and stable throughout the movement.
Push the hips back and hinge at the waist, not the lower back.
Engage the core to maintain stability and protect the spine.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round instead of hinging at the hips.
Losing control of the kettlebell, leading to shoulder strain.
Turning the feet excessively, which can destabilize the base.

name: Air Bike
instructions: Lie flat on the floor with your lower back pressed to the ground. For this exercise, you will need to put your hands beside your head. Be careful however to not strain with the neck as you perform it. Now lift your shoulders into the crunch position.
Bring knees up to where they are perpendicular to the floor, with your lower legs parallel to the floor. This will be your starting position.

Now simultaneously, slowly go through a cycle pedal motion kicking forward with the right leg and bringing in the knee of the left leg. Bring your right elbow close to your left knee by crunching to the side, as you breathe out.
Go back to the initial position as you breathe in.
Crunch to the opposite side as you cycle your legs and bring closer your left elbow to your right knee and exhale.
Continue alternating in this manner until all of the recommended repetitions for each side have been completed.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The flexion and rotation involved in the air bike can exacerbate symptoms by increasing intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Lumbar flexion may aggravate symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase lumbar lordosis and shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The movement may irritate the sciatic nerve due to lumbar flexion and rotation.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The flexion and rotation can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Supine position and abdominal pressure may be uncomfortable or unsafe, especially in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Strain on the abdominal area can interfere with healing.

modifications.easier: Perform a basic crunch without the leg movement to reduce complexity and strain.
modifications.harder: Add a resistance band around the feet to increase the load on the abdominals and hip flexors.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a rolled towel or small pillow under the lower back to maintain a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion of the legs to reduce stress on the knee joints.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with your hands to prevent strain.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your elbows wide and avoid pulling on your neck.
Engage your core throughout the movement.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on the contraction of the abdominals.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Pulling on the neck with the hands.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: All Fours Quad Stretch
instructions: Start off on your hands and knees, then lift your leg off the floor and hold the foot with your hand.
Use your hand to hold the foot or ankle, keeping the knee fully flexed, stretching the quadriceps and hip flexors.
Focus on extending your hips, thrusting them towards the floor. Hold for 10-20 seconds and then switch sides.

knee injuries.explanation: The exercise involves significant knee flexion, which can exacerbate conditions like patellar tendinitis or meniscal tears.

lower back pain.explanation: The position may strain the lumbar spine, especially if there is existing disc pathology or instability.

hip impingement.explanation: Deep hip flexion can aggravate femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) symptoms.

balance disorders.explanation: Maintaining balance in this position can be challenging and may lead to falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch lying on your side, pulling the top foot towards the glutes to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Add a slight pelvic tilt forward to increase the stretch intensity on the quadriceps and hip flexors.

injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a towel or strap to hold the foot instead of directly grabbing it, reducing knee flexion.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the stretch near a wall for support, minimizing spinal strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the supporting knee is cushioned to prevent discomfort.
Avoid excessive force when pulling the foot to prevent knee strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Align the hips parallel to the floor to maintain balance.
Focus on a gentle stretch without forcing the range of motion.
commonMistakes: Overarching the lower back, leading to lumbar strain.
Allowing the hips to rotate, reducing the effectiveness of the stretch.
Pulling the foot too aggressively, risking knee injury.

name: Alternate Hammer Curl
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
The palms of the hands should be facing your torso. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the right weight forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Continue the movement until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat the movement with the left hand. This equals one repetition.
Continue alternating in this manner for the recommended amount of repetitions.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive flexion and grip required can exacerbate symptoms.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The exercise may cause discomfort due to the position of the arms and potential shoulder involvement.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, potentially aggravating symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the need for core stabilization and balance.
modifications.harder: Use heavier dumbbells or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use resistance bands instead of dumbbells to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid shoulder discomfort, stopping before any pain occurs.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid unnecessary strain.
Avoid swinging the weights or using momentum to lift the dumbbells.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the curl.
Control the weight on the way down, resisting gravity.
commonMistakes: Using body momentum to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the torso.
Not fully extending the arm at the bottom of the movement.

name: Alternate Heel Touchers
instructions: Lie on the floor with the knees bent and the feet on the floor around 18-24 inches apart. Your arms should be extended by your side. This will be your starting position.
Crunch over your torso forward and up about 3-4 inches to the right side and touch your right heel as you hold the contraction for a second. Exhale while performing this movement.
Now go back slowly to the starting position as you inhale.

Now crunch over your torso forward and up around 3-4 inches to the left side and touch your left heel as you hold the contraction for a second. Exhale while performing this movement and then go back to the starting position as you inhale. Now that both heels have been touched, that is considered 1 repetition.
Continue alternating sides in this manner until all prescribed repetitions are done.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The flexion and rotation involved can exacerbate disc herniation symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. Flexion may increase pressure on the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. Forward flexion can aggravate vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. Flexion and rotation may irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High severity. Spinal flexion increases the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Supine position and abdominal pressure may be uncomfortable or unsafe, especially in the second and third trimesters.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion, focusing on engaging the core without reaching the heels.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight or medicine ball on the chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with knees bent at a 90-degree angle and feet elevated on a bench to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep arms crossed over the chest instead of reaching to the heels to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive neck flexion to prevent strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to reduce the risk of injury.
formCues: Engage the core before starting the movement.
Exhale as you reach towards the heel, inhale as you return to the starting position.
Keep movements controlled and avoid jerking motions.
commonMistakes: Lifting the head too high off the ground, leading to neck strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: Alternate Incline Dumbbell Curl
instructions: Sit down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. Tip: Keep the elbows close to the torso.This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the right weight forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. As you do so, rotate the hand so that the palm is facing up. Continue the movement until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbell back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat the movement with the left hand. This equals one repetition.
Continue alternating in this manner for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive curling motion can exacerbate inflammation in the tendons of the elbow.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position and movement might aggravate the subacromial space, leading to increased pain or injury.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The incline position may place additional stress on the shoulder joint, potentially aggravating existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures increases with weight-bearing exercises, especially if form is compromised.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle or use heavier weights to increase the difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support by adjusting the incline bench to a comfortable angle.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort and reduce weight as needed.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is securely positioned to prevent tipping.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Rotate the wrist smoothly as you curl to engage the biceps fully.
Control the descent to avoid using momentum.
commonMistakes: Swinging the weights or using momentum.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the torso.
Overextending the wrists during the curl.

name: Alternate Leg Diagonal Bound
instructions: Assume a comfortable stance with one foot slightly in front of the other.
Begin by pushing off with the front leg, driving the opposite knee forward and as high as possible before landing. Attempt to cover as much distance to each side with each bound.
It may help to use a line on the ground to guage distance from side to side.
Repeat the sequence with the other leg.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities like bounding can exacerbate joint pain and degeneration in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Bounding places stress on the ankle joint, which can increase the risk of injury in those with instability.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding high-impact exercises to prevent complications and ensure proper healing.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise can pose a fall risk for individuals with balance impairments.
contraindicationDetails.advanced osteoporosis: High-impact exercises can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with significant bone density loss.

modifications.easier: Perform a lateral step instead of a bound, focusing on controlled movements and maintaining balance.
modifications.harder: Increase the distance and height of each bound, or add a weighted vest for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform a low-impact lateral shuffle instead of bounding to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Use a mini-trampoline to perform the exercise, which can reduce impact forces on the ankles.

safetyNotes: Ensure the landing surface is even and non-slip to prevent falls.
Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
Avoid excessive forward lean to maintain balance and reduce the risk of falls.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Drive the knee high during each bound to maximize distance.
Land softly on the balls of your feet to absorb impact and protect the joints.
commonMistakes: Landing with a locked knee, which can increase joint stress.
Failing to maintain a neutral spine, leading to potential back strain.
Not using the arms effectively to aid in propulsion and balance.

name: Alternating Cable Shoulder Press
instructions: Move the cables to the bottom of the tower and select an appropriate weight.
Grasp the cables and hold them at shoulder height, palms facing forward. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your head and chest up, extend through the elbow to press one side directly over head.
After pausing at the top, return to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Pressing overhead can exacerbate symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: Overhead pressing may increase strain on the rotator cuff, worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint loading in the shoulder can increase pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Overhead movements may place additional stress on the cervical spine, aggravating conditions.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Overhead pressing can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band instead of cables to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing on one leg to increase core engagement and balance challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure cables are securely attached and the weight is appropriate for your strength level.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Press the cable directly overhead without leaning back.
Control the movement on the way down to prevent jerking.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Arching the back excessively during the press.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.

name: Alternating Deltoid Raise
instructions: In a standing position, hold a pair of dumbbells at your side.
Keeping your elbows slightly bent, raise the weights directly in front of you to shoulder height, avoiding any swinging or cheating.
Return the weights to your side.
On the next repetition, raise the weights laterally, raising them out to your side to about shoulder height.
Return the weights to the starting position and continue alternating to the front and side.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may increase inflammation and pain in the tendons of the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights and raising arms can strain the neck, especially if there is a history of cervical disc herniation or stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture increases with overhead movements, especially in individuals with compromised bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the need for core stabilization and balance.
modifications.harder: Use a resistance band instead of dumbbells for increased resistance throughout the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, stopping before any pain occurs.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce stress on the elbow joint.
Do not swing the weights; use controlled movements.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a stable torso.
Lift the weights with your shoulders, not your arms.
Ensure your wrists are neutral and not bent.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Raising the weights above shoulder height.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug upwards.

name: Alternating Floor Press
instructions: Lie on the floor with two kettlebells next to your shoulders.
Position one in place on your chest and then the other, gripping the kettlebells on the handle with the palms facing forward.
Extend both arms, so that the kettlebells are being held above your chest. Lower one kettlebell, bringing it to your chest and turn the wrist in the direction of the locked out kettlebell.
Raise the kettlebell and repeat on the opposite side.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The exercise involves shoulder flexion and internal rotation, which can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The stability required can strain the rotator cuff, delaying healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Joint loading may increase pain and inflammation in affected areas.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise may stress healing tissues and should be avoided until cleared by a physician.
contraindicationDetails.chronic wrist pain: Gripping kettlebells can exacerbate wrist discomfort.

modifications.easier: Use lighter kettlebells or perform the exercise with dumbbells for better control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on a bench to increase range of motion and muscle activation.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a floor press with a neutral grip using dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or a neutral grip to alleviate pressure on the wrists.

safetyNotes: Ensure kettlebells are secure and of manageable weight to prevent dropping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid excessive wrist extension to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Press the kettlebell directly above the chest, not the face.
Rotate the wrist of the lowering arm slightly inward to maintain shoulder alignment.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.
Arching the lower back, which can lead to discomfort or injury.
Using momentum to lift the kettlebells instead of controlled muscle engagement.

name: Alternating Hang Clean
instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder and hold on to the other kettlebell in a hanging position. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrist as you do so.
Lower the cleaned kettlebell to a hanging position and clean the alternate kettlebell. Repeat.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal stress.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or tendinitis in the shoulders or knees should modify or avoid this exercise to prevent joint strain.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing this exercise due to the potential for increased cardiovascular load.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance and core stability challenges.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery in the shoulder, back, or lower body requires clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis or severe diabetes complications may require modifications to reduce the risk of injury.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise with any acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to prevent further injury.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications to ensure safety during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform a single-arm kettlebell deadlift instead of a clean to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the clean for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat portion and ensure proper knee alignment over the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the clean portion and perform a deadlift to upright row instead.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before starting the exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent lower back strain.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without compromising form.
formCues: Keep your chest up and eyes forward to maintain a neutral spine.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips explosively to initiate the clean.
Rotate your wrist smoothly as you bring the kettlebell to your shoulder.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift, increasing the risk of spinal injury.
Using too much arm strength instead of driving through the hips.
Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat portion.

name: Alternating Kettlebell Press
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.
Press one directly overhead by extending through the elbow, turning it so the palm faces forward while holding the other kettlebell stationary .
Lower the pressed kettlebell to the starting position and immediately press with your other arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Pressing movements can increase inflammation and pain in the tendons of the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The load on the shoulders and neck during pressing can increase cervical spine pressure, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Overhead lifting can cause a significant increase in blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not yet be strong enough to handle the load and range of motion required for this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press to reduce balance demands and use lighter weights.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm kettlebell press while standing on one leg to increase core stabilization demands.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells and limit the range of motion to avoid pain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the shoulder joints and muscles.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the press to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Press the kettlebell directly overhead, not forward or backward.
Ensure your wrist remains straight and aligned with your forearm.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the back to arch excessively during the press.
Failing to control the descent of the kettlebell.

name: Alternating Kettlebell Row
instructions: Place two kettlebells in front of your feet. Bend your knees slightly and push your butt out as much as possible. As you bend over to get into the starting position grab both kettlebells by the handles.

Pull one kettlebell off of the floor while holding on to the other kettlebell. Retract the shoulder blade of the working side, as you flex the elbow, drawing the kettlebell towards your stomach or rib cage.
Lower the kettlebell in the working arm and repeat with your other arm.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The forward bending position and load on the spine may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high - The bent-over position can increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: moderate - The shoulder movement may aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: moderate - The pulling motion can stress the shoulder tendons.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - The bent-over position may be uncomfortable and affect balance.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high - The exercise places stress on the core and may disrupt healing.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - The forward bending and load can increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter kettlebells or use a single kettlebell to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance and stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with a supported back to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid shoulder discomfort and use lighter weights.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent back injury.
Avoid rounding the shoulders to reduce strain on the upper back and neck.
Ensure proper warm-up before performing the exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Retract your shoulder blades as you pull the kettlebell towards your body.
Bend at the hips, not the waist, to maintain a neutral spine.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which can lead to spinal injury.
Using momentum to lift the kettlebell instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulders to slump forward, reducing effectiveness and increasing injury risk.

name: Alternating Renegade Row
instructions: Place two kettlebells on the floor about shoulder width apart. Position yourself on your toes and your hands as though you were doing a pushup, with the body straight and extended. Use the handles of the kettlebells to support your upper body. You may need to position your feet wide for support.
Push one kettlebell into the floor and row the other kettlebell, retracting the shoulder blade of the working side as you flex the elbow, pulling it to your side.
Then lower the kettlebell to the floor and begin the kettlebell in the opposite hand. Repeat for several reps.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The plank position and rowing motion can exacerbate spinal compression and increase intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to the forward bending and rotational forces involved.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The rowing motion can further irritate the subacromial space, worsening impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The dynamic pulling motion can strain the rotator cuff tendons, increasing inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The prone position and core engagement may be uncomfortable or unsafe, especially in the later stages.
contraindicationDetails.wrist instability: Supporting body weight on kettlebell handles can stress the wrist joints, risking further instability.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The pressure on the wrists may exacerbate symptoms of numbness and tingling in the hands.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with hands on the floor instead of kettlebells to reduce instability and stress on the wrists.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise with feet elevated on a platform.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on an incline bench to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use lighter weights and focus on controlled movements to minimize shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or hex dumbbells to maintain a neutral wrist position.

safetyNotes: Ensure kettlebells are stable and on a non-slip surface to prevent tipping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid excessive lumbar extension or flexion.
Engage the core to stabilize the pelvis and prevent hip rotation.
formCues: Keep shoulders aligned over wrists to maintain balance.
Drive the elbow towards the ceiling, keeping it close to the body.
Squeeze the shoulder blades together at the top of the row.
Avoid rotating the hips; keep them square to the floor.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag or rotate excessively.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Gripping the kettlebell handles too tightly, causing wrist strain.
Not engaging the core, leading to lower back strain.

name: Ankle Circles
instructions: Use a sturdy object like a squat rack to hold yourself.

Lift the right leg in the air (just around 2 inches from the floor) and perform a circular motion with the big toe. Pretend that you are drawing a big circle with it. Tip: One circle equals 1 repetition. Breathe normally as you perform the movement.
When you are done with the right foot, then repeat with the left leg.

ankle sprain.explanation: Performing ankle circles can exacerbate pain and delay healing in individuals with a recent or severe ankle sprain.

Achilles tendinitis.explanation: This exercise may aggravate symptoms in individuals with Achilles tendinitis due to the movement of the ankle joint.

balance disorders.explanation: Individuals with balance disorders may find it challenging to perform this exercise safely without support.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the balance requirement.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing on a balance pad to increase proprioceptive challenge.

injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform ankle dorsiflexion and plantarflexion instead of full circles to reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure you have a stable support to hold onto if needed.
Avoid performing the exercise if you experience sharp pain.
formCues: Keep the movement controlled and smooth.
Focus on drawing a full circle with your big toe.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid leaning excessively.
commonMistakes: Using jerky or rapid movements.
Leaning too far forward or backward.
Not completing a full circle with the toe.

name: Ankle On The Knee
instructions: From a lying position, bend your knees and keep your feet on the floor.
Place your ankle of one foot on your opposite knee.
Grasp the thigh or knee of the bottom leg and pull both of your legs into the chest. Relax your neck and shoulders. Hold for 10-20 seconds and then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The stretch may exacerbate symptoms by placing additional pressure on the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: The position may cause discomfort or pain due to joint compression.
contraindicationDetails.knee injuries: Placing the ankle on the knee can stress the knee joint, potentially aggravating existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: The pulling motion may strain the lower back, hindering recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while seated on a chair, keeping the back straight and gently leaning forward.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds or add a gentle rocking motion to deepen the stretch.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the stretch with the non-stretching leg straight on the floor to reduce lower back strain.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Place a cushion under the knee of the bottom leg to reduce pressure.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling too hard to prevent overstretching.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your neck and shoulders relaxed throughout the stretch.
Ensure the back remains flat on the floor to avoid lower back strain.
Breathe deeply and evenly to facilitate muscle relaxation.
commonMistakes: Pulling the leg too forcefully, leading to overstretching.
Allowing the head and neck to lift off the ground, causing strain.
Rotating the hips excessively, which can lead to joint discomfort.

name: Anterior Tibialis-SMR
instructions: Begin seated on the ground with your legs bent and your feet on the floor.

Using a Muscle Roller or a rolling pin, apply pressure to the muscles on the outside of your shins. Work from just below the knee to above the ankle, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other leg.

contraindicationDetails.shin splints: Applying pressure to the anterior tibialis can exacerbate pain and inflammation associated with shin splints.
contraindicationDetails.acute ankle sprain: Pressure on the lower leg can aggravate an acute sprain by increasing inflammation and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.compartment syndrome: This condition involves increased pressure within the muscles, and applying external pressure can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower leg surgery: Post-surgical areas may be sensitive and at risk for complications with direct pressure.

modifications.easier: Use a softer foam roller or reduce the pressure applied by supporting more weight with your hands.
modifications.harder: Increase pressure by using a firmer roller or by lifting your body slightly off the floor to apply more weight.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with knee pain, perform the exercise with a straight leg to reduce knee flexion stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly over bony prominences.
Discontinue if sharp pain or numbness occurs.
formCues: Maintain a neutral spine while seated.
Apply consistent pressure without bouncing or jerking.
Breathe steadily to help relax the muscle.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly without pausing on tension points.
Applying excessive pressure causing discomfort or pain.
Neglecting to maintain proper posture.

name: Anti-Gravity Press
instructions: Place a bar on the ground behind the head of an incline bench.
Lay on the bench face down. With a pronated grip, pick the barbell up from the floor. Flex the elbows, performing a reverse curl to bring the bar near your chest. This will be your starting position.
To begin, press the barbell out in front of your head by extending your elbows. Keep your arms parallel to the ground throughout the movement.
Return to the starting position and repeat to complete the set.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen existing injuries.

cervical spine issues.explanation: Lying face down and lifting weights can strain the cervical spine, especially in cases of herniated discs or stenosis.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The reverse curl component can aggravate tendinitis due to repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow.

modifications.easier: Use lighter dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a resistance band for added tension throughout the movement.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a standing overhead press with dumbbells to allow for a more natural range of motion.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce strain on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid excessive arching of the back during the press to prevent spinal strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a neutral spine.
Press the barbell in a straight line, keeping your elbows slightly bent at the top of the movement.
Avoid shrugging your shoulders during the press.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.
Not maintaining a neutral neck position, leading to cervical strain.

name: Arm Circles
instructions: Stand up and extend your arms straight out by the sides. The arms should be parallel to the floor and perpendicular (90-degree angle) to your torso. This will be your starting position.
Slowly start to make circles of about 1 foot in diameter with each outstretched arm. Breathe normally as you perform the movement.
Continue the circular motion of the outstretched arms for about ten seconds. Then reverse the movement, going the opposite direction.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Arm circles can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: This exercise may place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: The repetitive motion can aggravate joint pain and inflammation in individuals with severe arthritis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Patients recovering from shoulder surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with smaller circles or while seated to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Increase the diameter of the circles or add light wrist weights for added resistance.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with one arm at a time, keeping the other arm supported or resting.

safetyNotes: Avoid performing arm circles if you experience sharp pain.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid arching the back.
Keep movements controlled to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your shoulders relaxed and down away from your ears.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Move your arms in a smooth, controlled motion.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up towards the ears.
Arching the lower back excessively.

name: Arnold Dumbbell Press
instructions: Sit on an exercise bench with back support and hold two dumbbells in front of you at about upper chest level with your palms facing your body and your elbows bent. Tip: Your arms should be next to your torso. The starting position should look like the contracted portion of a dumbbell curl.
Now to perform the movement, raise the dumbbells as you rotate the palms of your hands until they are facing forward.
Continue lifting the dumbbells until your arms are extended above you in straight arm position. Breathe out as you perform this portion of the movement.

After a second pause at the top, begin to lower the dumbbells to the original position by rotating the palms of your hands towards you. Tip: The left arm will be rotated in a counter clockwise manner while the right one will be rotated clockwise. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The rotational movement and overhead press can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Sitting with a load overhead can increase cervical spine stress, especially if posture is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Overhead pressing can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead pressing can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press without the rotational component to reduce complexity.
modifications.harder: Use heavier dumbbells or perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support on the bench and engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench provides adequate back support to maintain proper posture.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement to stabilize the torso.
Rotate the dumbbells smoothly without jerking to protect the shoulder joint.
Exhale as you press the weights overhead and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the back to arch excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Failing to control the descent of the dumbbells, increasing shoulder joint stress.

name: Around The Worlds
instructions: Lay down on a flat bench holding a dumbbell in each hand with the palms of the hands facing towards the ceiling. Tip: Your arms should be parallel to the floor and next to your thighs. To avoid injury, make sure that you keep your elbows slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now move the dumbbells by creating a semi-circle as you displace them from the initial position to over the head. All of the movement should happen with the arms parallel to the floor at all times. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Reverse the movement to return the weight to the starting position as you exhale.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The overhead motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen existing injuries.

cervical spine issues.explanation: Lying flat with arms overhead can strain the neck, especially if there is pre-existing cervical spine pathology.

osteoporosis.explanation: The risk of fracture increases with the overhead and wide arc motion, especially if bone density is compromised.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a similar motion with a reduced range of motion, keeping elbows closer to the body.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Ensure proper lumbar support by placing a small cushion under the lower back.

safetyNotes: Avoid locking the elbows to reduce joint stress.
Ensure the movement is controlled to prevent shoulder strain.
Do not use excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Keep elbows slightly bent throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid arching the back.
Engage the core to stabilize the body.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing elbows to drop below the level of the bench.
Arching the back excessively during the movement.

name: Atlas Stone Trainer
instructions: This trainer is effective for developing Atlas Stone strength for those who don't have access to stones, and are typically made from bar ends or heavy pipe.
Begin by loading the desired weight onto the bar. Straddle the weight, wrapping your arms around the implement, bending at the hips.

Begin by pulling the weight up past the knees, extending through the hips. As the weight clears the knees, it can be lapped by resting it on your thighs and sitting back, hugging it tightly to your chest.
Finish the movement by extending through your hips and knees to raise the weight as high as possible. The weight can be returned to the lap or to the ground for successive repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The compressive and shear forces on the spine during this exercise can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The forward flexion and load can increase symptoms of spinal stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise can increase anterior shear forces on the spine, worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The exercise may aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to increased spinal load.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: moderate - Joint stress, particularly in the knees and lower back, can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: moderate - The Valsalva maneuver often used in heavy lifting can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - The risk of vertebral fractures is increased due to spinal loading.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with a sandbag to reduce instability.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a partial lift, stopping at the knees to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid the lapping phase and perform a deadlift variation instead.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight is manageable to avoid excessive spinal loading.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent injury.
Avoid using a rounded back when lifting or lowering the weight.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through your heels when extending through the hips.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Not engaging the core, leading to potential back strain.

name: Atlas Stones
instructions: Begin with the atlas stone between your feet. Bend at the hips to wrap your arms vertically around the Atlas Stone, attempting to get your fingers underneath the stone. Many stones will have a small flat portion on the bottom, which will make the stone easier to hold.
Pulling the stone into your torso, drive through the back half of your feet to pull the stone from the ground.
As the stone passes the knees, lap it by sitting backward, pulling the stone on top of your thighs.

Sit low, getting the stone high onto your chest as you change your grip to reach over the stone. Stand, driving through with your hips. Close distance to the loading platform, and lean back, extending the hips to get the stone as high as possible.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The compressive and shear forces on the spine during lifting can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The lumbar flexion and heavy load can increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise can cause further slippage of the vertebrae.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high - The exercise may aggravate nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: moderate - Joint stress can worsen symptoms, especially in the knees and lower back.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: moderate - The Valsalva maneuver and heavy lifting can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.heart disease: moderate - The intense physical demand may not be suitable for those with cardiovascular issues.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - The risk of fractures due to high compressive forces is significant.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high - The intra-abdominal pressure can disrupt healing.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - The exercise requires significant balance and coordination.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter stone or a sandbag to practice form and technique without the full weight.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the stone or perform the lift on an unstable surface to challenge balance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a smaller stone and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the lift.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the squat and use a lighter stone to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the lifting area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Use proper lifting equipment, such as lifting belts and chalk, to enhance grip and support.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting heavy lifts to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep the back straight and core engaged throughout the lift.
Drive through the heels and use the legs to lift, not the back.
Keep the stone close to the body to maintain balance and control.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift, increasing the risk of spinal injury.
Using the arms to lift instead of the legs, leading to inefficient lifting and potential injury.
Failing to secure a firm grip on the stone, which can lead to dropping it.

name: Axle Deadlift
instructions: Approach the bar so that it is centered over your feet. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to protract. Typically, you would use an over/under grip.

With your feet and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and flex the knees until your shins contact the bar. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward.
After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High risk of exacerbating disc herniation due to spinal loading and flexion.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Potential for increased nerve compression with axial loading.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Risk of vertebral slippage due to lumbar stress.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: May aggravate nerve compression and pain.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: Joint stress may exacerbate symptoms, especially in the spine and knees.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Increased fracture risk due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: Healing tissues may be compromised by axial loading.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Straining can elevate blood pressure dangerously.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Risk of falls or improper form due to instability.

modifications.easier: Use a trap bar or dumbbells to reduce lower back strain and improve balance.
modifications.harder: Increase the axle diameter or add resistance bands for greater grip and strength challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform Romanian deadlifts with lighter weight, focusing on hip hinge mechanics.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit knee flexion and focus on hip hinge; consider sumo deadlifts for reduced knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the lower back and hamstrings.
Avoid rounding the lower back to prevent spinal injury.
Use a weightlifting belt if necessary to support the lumbar spine.
formCues: Keep the bar close to the body throughout the lift.
Engage the core and maintain a neutral spine.
Drive through the heels and keep the chest up.
Squeeze the glutes at the top of the lift.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Starting the lift with the hips too high.
Using an excessive amount of weight leading to poor form.
Not engaging the core, leading to instability.

name: Back Flyes - With Bands
instructions: Run a band around a stationary post like that of a squat rack.
Grab the band by the handles and stand back so that the tension in the band rises.

Extend and lift the arms straight in front of you. Tip: Your arms should be straight and parallel to the floor while perpendicular to your torso. Your feet should be firmly planted on the floor spread at shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, move your arms to the sides and back. Keep your arms extended and parallel to the floor. Continue the movement until the arms are extended to your sides.
After a pause, go back to the original position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and lateral movement of the arms can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which may worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The pulling motion and potential for loss of balance could increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the tension and movement required.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands and use a lighter resistance band.
modifications.harder: Use a thicker resistance band or perform the exercise on one leg to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a shorter range of motion, stopping before any pain occurs.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored to prevent it from snapping back.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce joint stress.
Avoid jerky movements to prevent strain on the shoulders.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a stable torso.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on squeezing the shoulder blades together.
Keep your head in a neutral position, aligned with your spine.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle control.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up towards the ears.
Arching the back excessively during the movement.

name: Backward Drag
instructions: Load a sled with the desired weight, attaching a rope or straps to the sled that you can hold onto.
Begin the exercise by moving backwards for a given distance. Leaning back, extend through the legs for short steps to move as quickly as possible.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The backward drag can place stress on the knee joint, potentially exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The leaning back posture and load can aggravate lower back pain.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The movement requires good balance and coordination, which may be challenging for those with balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by the strain and load of this exercise.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter sled or perform the exercise on a smooth surface to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the sled or perform the exercise on a rougher surface to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter load and ensure a neutral spine position.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the load and focus on shorter, controlled steps to minimize knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the surface is even and free of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Use appropriate footwear to prevent slipping.
Do not overload the sled beyond your capability to maintain proper form.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a stable trunk.
Lean slightly back but avoid excessive arching of the lower back.
Take short, quick steps to maintain control and balance.
commonMistakes: Overloading the sled, leading to poor form.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward during the movement.
Leaning too far back, causing excessive lower back strain.

name: Backward Medicine Ball Throw
instructions: This exercise is best done with a partner. If you lack a partner, the ball can be thrown and retrieved or thrown against a wall.
Begin standing a few meters in front of your partner, both facing the same direction. Begin holding the ball between your legs.
Squat down and then forcefully reverse direction, coming to full extension and you toss the ball over your head to your partner.
Your partner can then roll the ball back to you. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The explosive nature and spinal extension involved in this exercise can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: The overhead throwing motion can aggravate shoulder impingement syndromes.

rotator_cuff_tendinitis.explanation: Repeated overhead motions may worsen tendinitis in the rotator cuff.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The dynamic and explosive nature of the exercise may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: Balance and rapid movements may pose a risk, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

osteoporosis.explanation: The risk of falls and high-impact forces can be dangerous for individuals with osteoporosis.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Use a medicine ball that is appropriate for your strength level to avoid excessive strain.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement to protect your lower back.
Keep your feet shoulder-width apart for stability.
Use your legs to generate power, not just your arms.
commonMistakes: Using too heavy a medicine ball, leading to compromised form.
Not engaging the core, resulting in excessive lumbar extension.
Failing to follow through with the arms, reducing the effectiveness of the throw.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter medicine ball or use a stability ball to practice the motion without throwing.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the motion without the ball, focusing on controlled movements to avoid excessive spinal extension.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion and use a lighter ball to reduce strain on the shoulders.

name: Balance Board
instructions: Place a balance board in front of you.
Stand up on it and try to balance yourself.
Hold the balance for as long as desired.

contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Individuals with conditions affecting balance, such as vestibular disorders or severe proprioceptive deficits, may have difficulty safely performing this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.acute ankle sprain: Performing balance exercises on an unstable surface can exacerbate an acute sprain and delay healing.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires stabilization and healing before introducing balance challenges that could risk re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in lower extremities: Joint instability and pain from arthritis can be aggravated by the demands of maintaining balance on an unstable surface.
contraindicationDetails.neuropathy: Reduced sensation in the feet or legs can impair balance and increase the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of falls and fractures is heightened with osteoporosis, making balance exercises potentially hazardous without supervision.

modifications.easier: Use a wider balance board or perform the exercise near a sturdy support like a wall or chair for assistance.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on a narrower balance board or with eyes closed to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a slight bend in the knees to reduce lumbar strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure the knees are slightly bent and avoid locking them to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.ankle instability: Start with a more stable surface, such as a foam pad, before progressing to a balance board.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area around the balance board is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Use a balance board with a non-slip surface to reduce the risk of slipping.
Consider performing the exercise under supervision if new to balance training.
formCues: Stand with feet hip-width apart for better stability.
Engage the core to maintain a neutral spine.
Focus on a fixed point in front of you to help maintain balance.
Keep knees slightly bent to absorb movement and maintain control.
commonMistakes: Locking the knees, which can lead to joint strain and reduced balance.
Leaning too far forward or backward, which can cause loss of balance.
Not engaging the core, leading to poor posture and reduced stability.

name: Ball Leg Curl
instructions: Begin on the floor laying on your back with your feet on top of the ball.
Position the ball so that when your legs are extended your ankles are on top of the ball. This will be your starting position.
Raise your hips off of the ground, keeping your weight on the shoulder blades and your feet.
Flex the knees, pulling the ball as close to you as you can, contracting the hamstrings.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or lower back pain should avoid this exercise or perform it with caution, as the hip lift can exacerbate symptoms.

knee issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis may experience discomfort due to knee flexion and should modify the exercise or consult a professional.

balance disorders.details: Individuals with significant balance disorders should avoid this exercise due to the instability of the exercise ball.
