modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion or use a more stable surface like a bench instead of a ball.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with one leg at a time to increase difficulty and engage stabilizers more intensely.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Keep the hips lower to reduce strain on the lower back.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the exercise ball is properly inflated and stable.
Perform the exercise on a non-slip surface to prevent the ball from moving unexpectedly.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back during the hip lift.
formCues: Engage the core to maintain stability.
Keep the hips level and avoid sagging or twisting.
Control the movement, especially when returning to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to drop during the curl.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Placing the ball too far under the calves, reducing leverage.

name: Band Assisted Pull-Up
instructions: Choke the band around the center of the pullup bar. You can use different bands to provide varying levels of assistance.
Pull the end of the band down, and place one bent knee into the loop, ensuring it won't slip out. Take a medium to wide grip on the bar. This will be your starting position.

Pull yourself upward by contracting the lats as you flex the elbow. The elbow should be driven to your side. Pull to the front, attempting to get your chin over the bar. Avoid swinging or jerking movements.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High shoulder abduction and internal rotation can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Pulling movements can strain the rotator cuff, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive pulling can aggravate tendinitis, especially lateral epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Gripping the bar can exacerbate wrist pain or carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Neck extension and strain can worsen cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (late stages): Balance and core stability may be compromised, increasing fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of pull-ups.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to high axial loading and potential falls.

modifications.easier: Use a thicker band for more assistance or perform inverted rows.
modifications.harder: Use a thinner band or perform unassisted pull-ups.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit range of motion to avoid pain, or perform lat pull-downs with a controlled range.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper core engagement and avoid excessive arching.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist straps or a neutral grip bar to reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely attached to the bar to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive swinging or kipping to reduce joint strain.
Maintain a controlled movement to prevent injury.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Pull your shoulder blades down and back as you lift.
Keep your elbows close to your body throughout the movement.
Drive your chest towards the bar rather than just your chin.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to complete the movement.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.
Neglecting to engage the core, leading to excessive lumbar extension.

name: Band Good Morning
instructions: Using a 41 inch band, stand on one end, spreading your feet a small amount. Bend at the hips to loop the end of the band behind your neck. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your legs straight, extend through the hips to come to a near vertical position.
Ensure that you do not round your back as you go down back to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The forward bending motion can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The exercise can increase pressure on the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise may increase lumbar instability.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - May aggravate symptoms; modifications required.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: moderate - Joint stress may worsen symptoms; modifications required.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - Risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: high - Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band or without a band to focus on form.
modifications.harder: Use a thicker band for increased resistance or perform the exercise on one leg to increase stability demands.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a dowel or broomstick to ensure proper form and reduce load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Slightly bend the knees to reduce tension on the hamstrings and lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored under your feet to prevent slipping.
Avoid rounding the back during the movement to prevent spinal strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Hinge at the hips, not the waist.
Keep the chest up and shoulders back.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Using excessive resistance that compromises form.
Not engaging the core, leading to lower back strain.

name: Band Good Morning (Pull Through)
instructions: Loop the band around a post. Standing a little ways away, loop the opposite end around the neck. Your hands can help hold the band in position.
Begin by bending at the hips, getting your butt back as far as possible. Keep your back flat and bend forward to about 90 degrees. Your knees should be only slightly bent.
Return to the starting position be driving through with the hips to come back to a standing position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward bending motion can exacerbate disc protrusion, increasing pain and risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Extension and flexion of the spine may compress nerves, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase shear forces on the spine, potentially aggravating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The bending motion may irritate the sciatic nerve, leading to increased pain.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Joint stress during the exercise can lead to increased pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The forward bending motion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: Healing tissues are vulnerable to strain, and the exercise may disrupt recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band or without a band to focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance of the band or perform the exercise on one leg for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a shorter range of motion and ensure the spine remains neutral.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Maintain a higher hip position to reduce knee flexion and stress.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent excessive lumbar flexion.
Avoid using excessive resistance that compromises form.
formCues: Keep your back flat and core engaged.
Push your hips back as if closing a door with your glutes.
Drive through your heels to return to standing.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the forward bend.
Using too much resistance, leading to poor form.
Allowing the knees to bend excessively.

name: Band Hip Adductions
instructions: Anchor a band around a solid post or other object.
Stand with your left side to the post, and put your right foot through the band, getting it around the ankle.
Stand up straight and hold onto the post if needed. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the knee straight, raise your right legs out to the side as far as you can.
Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired rep count.
Switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Individuals with hip arthritis may experience increased pain or discomfort due to joint stress during the adduction movement.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: The exercise may exacerbate symptoms of hip bursitis due to friction and pressure on the inflamed bursa.
contraindicationDetails.inguinal hernia: The exercise may increase intra-abdominal pressure, potentially worsening a hernia.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: Post-surgical patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Individuals with balance issues may be at risk of falling during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise lying on your side with the band around the ankles, reducing the need for balance.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance of the band or perform the exercise standing on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise lying on your side to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure the knee remains straight and avoid locking it to minimize joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored to prevent snapping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid unnecessary strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain balance.
Move slowly and with control to maximize muscle engagement.
Avoid rotating the hips; keep them square to the front.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to bend during the movement.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Leaning excessively to the side for balance.

name: Band Pull Apart
instructions: Begin with your arms extended straight out in front of you, holding the band with both hands.
Initiate the movement by performing a reverse fly motion, moving your hands out laterally to your sides.
Keep your elbows extended as you perform the movement, bringing the band to your chest. Ensure that you keep your shoulders back during the exercise.
Pause as you complete the movement, returning to the starting position under control.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The movement may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The pulling motion may increase the risk of fractures in individuals with significantly weakened bones.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the stress and range of motion required for this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.thoracic outlet syndrome: The position and movement may compress neurovascular structures, exacerbating symptoms.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter resistance band or perform the exercise seated to reduce the load on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier resistance band or perform the exercise with a pause at the end of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, stopping before any discomfort occurs.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored to prevent snapping.
Avoid jerky movements to reduce the risk of injury.
formCues: Keep your shoulders down and back throughout the movement.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to protect the joints.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to round forward.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Overextending the elbows, leading to joint strain.

name: Band Skull Crusher
instructions: Secure a band to the base of a rack or the bench. Lay on the bench so that the band is lined up with your head.
Take hold of the band, raising your elbows so that the upper arm is perpendicular to the floor. With the elbow flexed, the band should be above your head. This will be your starting position.
Extend through the elbow to straighten your arm, keeping your upper arm in place. Pause at the top of the motion, and return to the starting position.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive extension of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The position of the arms may lead to shoulder discomfort or impingement if not properly aligned.

cervical spine issues.explanation: Lying on a bench with improper neck support can strain the cervical spine.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter resistance band or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance of the band or perform the exercise on an incline bench.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort and ensure proper shoulder alignment.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored to prevent it from snapping back.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
formCues: Keep your upper arms stationary and perpendicular to the floor.
Engage your core to stabilize your body on the bench.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, which reduces triceps activation.
Using momentum to complete the movement instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.

name: Barbell Ab Rollout
instructions: For this exercise you will need to get into a pushup position, but instead of having your hands of the floor, you will be grabbing on to an Olympic barbell (loaded with 5-10 lbs on each side) instead. This will be your starting position.

While keeping a slight arch on your back, lift your hips and roll the barbell towards your feet as you exhale. Tip: As you perform the movement, your glutes should be coming up, you should be keeping the abs tight and should maintain your back posture at all times. Also your arms should be staying perpendicular to the floor throughout the movement. If you don't, you will work out your shoulders and back more than the abs.
After a second contraction at the top, start to roll the barbell back forward to the starting position slowly as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward flexion and extension of the spine during the rollout can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise places stress on the lumbar spine, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The shoulder joint is under load and may aggravate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The exercise involves core compression and instability, which is not recommended during pregnancy.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: The exercise places significant stress on the abdominal region, hindering recovery.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise involves spinal flexion and load, increasing the risk of vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise using an ab wheel or stability ball, which provides more control and reduces load.
modifications.harder: Perform the rollout from a standing position, increasing the range of motion and core demand.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on your knees instead of toes to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a resistance band anchored in front of you to assist the rollout, reducing shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely loaded to prevent weight plates from shifting.
Avoid excessive arching or rounding of the lower back to prevent spinal injury.
Do not lock the elbows; maintain a slight bend to protect the elbow joint.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement to stabilize the spine.
Keep the arms perpendicular to the floor to focus the effort on the abdominals.
Move slowly and with control, especially when returning to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to sag, increasing the risk of injury.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Overextending the shoulders, which can lead to impingement.

name: Barbell Ab Rollout - On Knees
instructions: Hold an Olympic barbell loaded with 5-10lbs on each side and kneel on the floor.
Now place the barbell on the floor in front of you so that you are on all your hands and knees (as in a kneeling push up position). This will be your starting position.

Slowly roll the barbell straight forward, stretching your body into a straight position. Tip: Go down as far as you can without touching the floor with your body. Breathe in during this portion of the movement.
After a second pause at the stretched position, start pulling yourself back to the starting position as you breathe out. Tip: Go slowly and keep your abs tight at all times.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The exercise places significant stress on the spine, which can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The forward rolling motion can increase lumbar spine instability.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The shoulder joint is heavily involved in stabilization, which can aggravate impingement.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: High severity. The exercise can increase intra-abdominal pressure and stress the lower back.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. The exercise can strain healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Moderate severity. The exercise can exacerbate existing pain due to lumbar strain.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Moderate severity. The exercise requires significant wrist stabilization, which can worsen pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise using an ab wheel instead of a barbell for more control, or perform the rollout from a shorter range of motion.
modifications.harder: Perform the rollout from a standing position or add a resistance band for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a plank or dead bug exercise to engage the core without spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a stability ball rollout to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or perform the exercise on a soft surface to reduce pressure.

safetyNotes: Ensure a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar extension.
Avoid rolling out too far if you cannot maintain core engagement.
Warm up adequately before performing this exercise to prepare the core and shoulder muscles.
formCues: Engage your core before starting the rollout.
Keep your hips aligned with your shoulders and knees.
Roll out slowly and control the movement back to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to sag during the rollout.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Rolling out too quickly and losing form.

name: Barbell Bench Press - Medium Grip
instructions: Lie back on a flat bench. Using a medium width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
From the starting position, breathe in and begin coming down slowly until the bar touches your middle chest.

After a brief pause, push the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out. Focus on pushing the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position at the top of the motion, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: Ideally, lowering the weight should take about twice as long as raising it.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The barbell bench press can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the overhead pressing motion, which may compress the structures within the shoulder joint.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: This exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening existing injuries.

unstable angina.explanation: The exertion and breath-holding associated with heavy lifting can increase cardiovascular strain, posing a risk for those with unstable angina.

recent shoulder surgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding heavy lifting to prevent re-injury or complications.

severe osteoporosis.explanation: The risk of fractures is elevated due to the compressive forces on the bones during the exercise.

safetyNotes: Always use a spotter when lifting heavy weights.
Ensure the barbell is properly secured with collars to prevent weight slippage.
Avoid bouncing the bar off the chest to prevent injury.
formCues: Keep feet flat on the floor for stability.
Maintain a slight arch in the lower back without excessive hyperextension.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Lower the barbell in a controlled manner to the mid-chest.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out excessively, which can increase shoulder stress.
Lifting hips off the bench, which compromises spinal alignment.
Inconsistent breathing patterns, such as holding breath during exertion.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells or on a Smith machine to reduce stabilization demands.
modifications.harder: Use a narrower grip to increase triceps involvement or add resistance bands for variable resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a floor press to limit the range of motion and reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper bench support and use a spotter to assist with unracking and racking the bar.

name: Barbell Curl
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a barbell at a shoulder-width grip. The palm of your hands should be facing forward and the elbows should be close to the torso. This will be your starting position.
While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second and squeeze the biceps hard.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate tendinitis symptoms.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The exercise may cause further compression of the rotator cuff tendons.

wrist pain.explanation: Gripping the barbell can aggravate existing wrist pain or conditions.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The exercise can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: The exercise may place undue stress on the shoulder joint, hindering recovery.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slower tempo or use a thicker bar for grip challenge.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use an EZ curl bar to reduce strain on the elbows.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or perform the exercise with a neutral grip using dumbbells.

safetyNotes: Avoid using momentum to lift the barbell.
Keep the elbows close to the torso to prevent shoulder strain.
Do not hyperextend the back; maintain a neutral spine.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Lift the barbell in a controlled manner, focusing on bicep contraction.
Lower the barbell slowly to maximize eccentric contraction.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Barbell Curls Lying Against An Incline
instructions: Lie against an incline bench, with your arms holding a barbell and hanging down in a horizontal line. This will be your starting position.

While keeping the upper arms stationary, curl the weight up as high as you can while squeezing the biceps. Breathe out as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Only the forearms should move. Do not swing the arms.
After a second contraction, slowly go back to the starting position as you inhale. Tip: Make sure that you go all of the way down.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during curling motion can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Positioning on the incline bench may alter shoulder mechanics, increasing impingement risk.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Gripping the barbell can aggravate existing wrist pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The wrist flexion required can compress the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Stabilizing the shoulder during the curl can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Lying on an incline may not provide adequate support for those with spinal issues.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric contraction while lying down can increase blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slower tempo or add a pause at the top of the curl.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform standing barbell curls to avoid lying on an incline.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use an EZ curl bar to reduce wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and securely positioned.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the elbows and wrists.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep upper arms stationary and close to the body.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the curl.
Lower the barbell slowly and with control.
commonMistakes: Swinging the arms or using momentum to lift the barbell.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Barbell Deadlift
instructions: Stand in front of a loaded barbell.

While keeping the back as straight as possible, bend your knees, bend forward and grasp the bar using a medium (shoulder width) overhand grip. This will be the starting position of the exercise. Tip: If it is difficult to hold on to the bar with this grip, alternate your grip or use wrist straps.

While holding the bar, start the lift by pushing with your legs while simultaneously getting your torso to the upright position as you breathe out. In the upright position, stick your chest out and contract the back by bringing the shoulder blades back. Think of how the soldiers in the military look when they are in standing in attention.

Go back to the starting position by bending at the knees while simultaneously leaning the torso forward at the waist while keeping the back straight. When the weights on the bar touch the floor you are back at the starting position and ready to perform another repetition.
Perform the amount of repetitions prescribed in the program.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The compressive and shear forces on the spine during a deadlift can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The extension and loading of the spine can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The anterior shear forces can aggravate this condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The exercise may increase nerve compression; modifications are necessary.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: moderate - Joint stress can be high; modifications may be needed based on severity.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: moderate - The Valsalva maneuver can increase blood pressure significantly.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - The risk of vertebral fractures is increased with heavy spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: high - Healing tissues are at risk of re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - The risk of falls is increased; modifications or assistance may be required.

modifications.easier: Use a trap bar or perform Romanian deadlifts with lighter weights.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform deficit deadlifts by standing on a platform.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform sumo deadlifts to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion or perform partial deadlifts.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a trap bar to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before starting to lift.
Avoid rounding the back at any point during the lift.
Use a weightlifting belt if lifting near maximum capacity.
formCues: Keep the barbell close to your body throughout the lift.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips fully at the top.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Starting the lift with the hips too high.
Using the arms to lift the weight instead of the legs and back.

name: Barbell Full Squat
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack just above shoulder level. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder-width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times and maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position.

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and sitting back with your hips as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until your hamstrings are on your calves. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel or middle of your foot as you straighten the legs and extend the hips to go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid heavy loading on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Knee arthritis or tendinitis may require modifications to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Hypertension or heart disease patients should avoid heavy lifting and perform the exercise under medical supervision.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid due to balance and core stability changes.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the spine, hips, or knees require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis patients should avoid heavy loading; diabetes complications may require careful monitoring.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications to ensure safety.

modifications.easier: Goblet squat with a dumbbell or bodyweight squat to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Front squat or overhead squat for increased difficulty and core engagement.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a safety squat bar or perform box squats to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit depth to a pain-free range or perform partial squats.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a safety squat bar or a front squat grip to reduce shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Always use a squat rack with safety bars set at an appropriate height.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting heavy lifts.
Avoid excessive forward lean to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep your chest up and back straight throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels and midfoot to initiate the upward phase.
Ensure knees track over toes to prevent valgus collapse.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward (valgus collapse).
Rounding the back or leaning too far forward.
Lifting heels off the ground during the squat.

name: Barbell Glute Bridge
instructions: Begin seated on the ground with a loaded barbell over your legs. Using a fat bar or having a pad on the bar can greatly reduce the discomfort caused by this exercise. Roll the bar so that it is directly above your hips, and lay down flat on the floor.
Begin the movement by driving through with your heels, extending your hips vertically through the bar. Your weight should be supported by your upper back and the heels of your feet.
Extend as far as possible, then reverse the motion to return to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal load and exacerbation of symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Those with hip or knee arthritis or bursitis may experience discomfort and should modify the exercise to reduce range of motion or load.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid supine positions and heavy lifting. Modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

osteoporosis.details: Due to the risk of vertebral fractures, individuals with osteoporosis should avoid heavy loading on the spine.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if recovering from recent trauma or surgery to the lower back, hips, or knees.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a barbell, using only body weight or a resistance band for added support.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise on a single leg to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and ensure proper lumbar support by engaging the core throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on controlled, slow movements to reduce stress on the knees.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is padded to prevent discomfort and potential bruising on the hips.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar extension.
Avoid hyperextending the hips at the top of the movement.
formCues: Engage your core before lifting to stabilize the spine.
Drive through your heels to activate the glutes effectively.
Keep your chin tucked slightly to maintain a neutral neck position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to collapse inward during the lift.
Using momentum rather than controlled muscle activation.
Lifting the toes off the ground, which shifts the focus away from the glutes.

name: Barbell Guillotine Bench Press
instructions: Using a medium width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over your neck with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, bring the bar down slowly until it is about 1 inch from your neck.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The barbell guillotine bench press places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: This exercise can strain the rotator cuff muscles and tendons, potentially worsening existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: The exercise involves holding a heavy weight over the chest, which can increase cardiovascular strain.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that heavily load the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is increased due to the load and position of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The neck position during the exercise can exacerbate cervical spine problems.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard barbell bench press with a reduced range of motion and lighter weight.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a tempo variation, such as a 3-second eccentric phase.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural arm path and reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a spotter is present to assist with the lift-off and re-rack of the barbell.
Avoid lowering the bar too close to the neck to prevent injury.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement throughout the exercise.
formCues: Maintain a neutral spine and keep feet flat on the ground.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Lower the bar with control, keeping elbows slightly tucked.
commonMistakes: Lowering the bar too quickly or too close to the neck.
Arching the back excessively during the lift.
Using too heavy a weight, compromising form.

name: Barbell Hack Squat
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell behind you at arms length and your feet at shoulder width. Tip: A shoulder width grip is best with the palms of your hands facing back. You can use wrist wraps for this exercise for a better grip. This will be your starting position.
While keeping your head and eyes up and back straight, squat until your upper thighs are parallel to the floor. Breathe in as you slowly go down.
Pressing mainly with the heel of the foot and squeezing the thighs, go back up as you breathe out.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The barbell hack squat places significant axial load on the spine, which can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

joint_issues.explanation: Knee and hip arthritis or tendinitis may be aggravated by the deep knee flexion and load.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver often used during heavy lifts can increase blood pressure, posing risks for those with hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise's balance demands and abdominal pressure are not suitable for pregnant individuals.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries, particularly in the lower body or spine, require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.explanation: Conditions like osteoporosis increase fracture risk due to the compressive forces on the spine.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight squats or use a Smith machine for guided movement.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright posture.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep flexion, stopping before discomfort.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the joints and muscles.
Use a spotter or safety bars if lifting heavy.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to maintain tension.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the heels to activate the quadriceps effectively.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent excessive lumbar flexion.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the ascent.
Rounding the back, which can increase spinal stress.
Lifting the heels off the ground, which shifts the load forward.

name: Barbell Hip Thrust
instructions: Begin seated on the ground with a bench directly behind you. Have a loaded barbell over your legs. Using a fat bar or having a pad on the bar can greatly reduce the discomfort caused by this exercise.
Roll the bar so that it is directly above your hips, and lean back against the bench so that your shoulder blades are near the top of it.

Begin the movement by driving through your feet, extending your hips vertically through the bar. Your weight should be supported by your shoulder blades and your feet. Extend as far as possible, then reverse the motion to return to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal loading and exacerbation of symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Those with hip or knee arthritis, or hip impingement, should modify the range of motion and load to avoid joint stress.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid supine positions and heavy lifting. Consult with a healthcare provider for appropriate modifications.

osteoporosis.details: Due to the risk of fractures, individuals with severe osteoporosis should avoid heavy loading exercises like the barbell hip thrust.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent lower body or back injuries to prevent aggravation.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications to ensure stability and safety during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise using a resistance band around the thighs instead of a barbell to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a single-leg variation to increase difficulty and engage stabilizing muscles more intensely.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and ensure proper lumbar support by engaging the core and avoiding hyperextension.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on controlled movements to reduce knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and does not move during the exercise.
Use a barbell pad to reduce discomfort on the hips.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep the chin tucked to maintain a neutral spine.
Drive through the heels to engage the glutes effectively.
Pause at the top of the movement to ensure full hip extension.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the lift.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.
Relying on momentum rather than controlled muscle contraction.

name: Barbell Incline Bench Press - Medium Grip
instructions: Lie back on an incline bench. Using a medium-width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on you upper chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: it should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The incline angle can exacerbate impingement by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which can aggravate existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: Heavy lifting can increase blood pressure and heart rate, posing a risk for those with unstable angina.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to stress, and this exercise can strain healing structures.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The load on the spine and potential for falls or dropping the bar can be dangerous for individuals with fragile bones.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The incline position can place additional stress on the cervical spine, exacerbating existing conditions.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural range of motion and reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle or add resistance bands to increase the difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip using dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support on the bench and reduce the load to minimize spinal stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is set at a safe incline angle (typically 30-45 degrees).
Always use a spotter when lifting heavy weights.
Avoid locking the elbows forcefully at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the ground to maintain stability.
Engage your core to support your lower back.
Lower the bar to the upper chest, not the neck, to avoid undue stress on the shoulders.
commonMistakes: Bouncing the bar off the chest to gain momentum.
Flaring the elbows excessively, which can increase shoulder stress.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.

name: Barbell Incline Shoulder Raise
instructions: Lie back on an Incline Bench. Using a medium width grip (a grip that is slightly wider than shoulder width), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms straight. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the arms straight, lift the bar by protracting your shoulder blades, raising the shoulders from the bench as you breathe out.
Bring back the bar to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which may worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying on an incline bench may strain the cervical spine, especially if the neck is not properly supported.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Holding the barbell can increase strain on the elbow joint, aggravating tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The load on the spine and shoulders could increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to re-injury; this exercise should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load and allow for a more natural range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle or add resistance bands for additional tension at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip using dumbbells to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support by adjusting the bench angle and using a lighter weight.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is securely positioned and at an appropriate incline angle.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form and increases injury risk.
Warm up adequately before performing the exercise to prepare the shoulder joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability throughout the movement.
Avoid shrugging your shoulders; focus on controlled scapular protraction and retraction.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug, which can lead to neck strain.
Failing to maintain a stable core, resulting in lower back arching.

name: Barbell Lunge
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack just below shoulder level. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and step forward with your right leg and squat down through your hips, while keeping the torso upright and maintaining balance. Inhale as you go down. Note: Do not allow your knee to go forward beyond your toes as you come down, as this will put undue stress on the knee joint. li>
Using mainly the heel of your foot, push up and go back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat the movement for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform with the left leg.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the depth and load to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Hypertension or heart disease patients should monitor exertion levels and avoid heavy loads.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid heavy lifting and consider balance and core stability modifications.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the lower body or spine require clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis patients should avoid heavy loading and focus on form and balance.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications to ensure safety.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight lunges or use dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the barbell weight or perform walking lunges for added intensity.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and ensure the knee does not extend beyond the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a front rack position with a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely positioned on the shoulders and not on the neck.
Use a squat rack with safety pins set at an appropriate height.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep the torso upright and core engaged.
Step forward with a controlled motion and avoid letting the knee extend past the toes.
Push through the heel of the front foot to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to extend beyond the toes.
Leaning the torso forward excessively.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Barbell Rear Delt Row
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell using a wide (higher than shoulder width) and overhand (palms facing your body) grip.

Bend knees slightly and bend over as you keep the natural arch of your back. Let the arms hang in front of you as they hold the bar. Once your torso is parallel to the floor, flare the elbows out and away from your body. Tip: Your torso and your arms should resemble the letter "T". Now you are ready to begin the exercise.

While keeping the upper arms perpendicular to the torso, pull the barbell up towards your upper chest as you squeeze the rear delts and you breathe out. Tip: When performed correctly, this exercise should resemble a bench press in reverse. Also, refrain from using your biceps to do the work. Focus on targeting the rear delts; the arms should only act as hooks.
Slowly go back to the initial position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to the overhead and abducted position of the arms which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Moderate risk as the exercise heavily involves the shoulder joint and can strain the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Moderate risk due to the forward bending position which can place stress on the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Low risk but caution is advised as gripping the barbell can aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Moderate risk due to the bent-over position which can increase lumbar spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High risk for individuals with severe osteoporosis due to potential for vertebral fractures from the bent-over position.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise on a single leg to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use resistance bands instead of a barbell to allow for a more controlled range of motion.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Perform the exercise seated on an incline bench to reduce stress on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid jerking movements and focus on controlled, smooth motions.
Ensure proper warm-up of the shoulder and back muscles before performing the exercise.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back to maintain a neutral spine.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back which can lead to spinal injury.
Using momentum instead of muscle contraction to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to drop below shoulder level which reduces effectiveness.

name: Barbell Rollout from Bench
instructions: Place a loaded barbell on the ground, near the end of a bench. Kneel with both legs on the bench, and take a medium to narrow grip on the barbell. This will be your starting position.
To begin, extend through the hips to slowly roll the bar forward. As you roll out, flex the shoulder to roll the bar above your head. Ensure that your arms remain extended throughout the movement.
When the bar has been moved as far forward as possible, return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The spinal flexion and extension involved can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise places stress on the lumbar spine, which can worsen the condition.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The shoulder flexion required may aggravate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: High severity. The exercise involves core compression and balance challenges that are not recommended during pregnancy.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. The exercise can stress healing tissues and should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. The exercise involves spinal loading that may increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Moderate severity. The grip and weight-bearing on the wrists can aggravate tendinitis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise from the floor on your knees, reducing the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise from a standing position, increasing the range of motion and core engagement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use an ab wheel instead of a barbell to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive shoulder flexion.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or a neutral grip bar to reduce strain on the wrists.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure to prevent tipping.
Avoid excessive lumbar extension to protect the lower back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Engage the core before starting the rollout.
Keep arms straight and avoid bending the elbows.
Roll out slowly and control the movement back to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to sag, increasing lumbar stress.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Bending the elbows, reducing core engagement.

name: Barbell Seated Calf Raise
instructions: Place a block about 12 inches in front of a flat bench.
Sit on the bench and place the ball of your feet on the block.
Have someone place a barbell over your upper thighs about 3 inches above your knees and hold it there. This will be your starting position.
Raise up on your toes as high as possible as you squeeze the calves and as you breathe out.
After a second contraction, slowly go back to the starting position. Tip: To get maximum benefit stretch your calves as far as you can.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.achilles tendinitis: High stress on the Achilles tendon during calf raises can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: Pressure on the plantar fascia can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The exercise may increase joint stress, leading to discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: The exercise requires stable ankle support, which may be compromised.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding high-load exercises until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise without a barbell, focusing on bodyweight resistance.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single leg to increase the load on each calf.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a Smith machine to stabilize the barbell and reduce strain on the back.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep dorsiflexion which can stress the knee joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely placed and balanced to prevent slipping.
Use a spotter if needed to help with barbell placement and removal.
Avoid bouncing at the bottom of the movement to prevent tendon strain.
formCues: Keep your back straight and core engaged throughout the exercise.
Focus on a slow, controlled movement to maximize muscle engagement.
Exhale as you lift your heels and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the heels to drop too quickly, which can strain the Achilles tendon.
Not using a full range of motion, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.

name: Barbell Shoulder Press
instructions: Sit on a bench with back support in a squat rack. Position a barbell at a height that is just above your head. Grab the barbell with a pronated grip (palms facing forward).

Once you pick up the barbell with the correct grip width, lift the bar up over your head by locking your arms. Hold at about shoulder level and slightly in front of your head. This is your starting position.
Lower the bar down to the shoulders slowly as you inhale.
Lift the bar back up to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead movement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Overhead pressing can strain the rotator cuff muscles and tendons.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Sitting with a load overhead can increase cervical spine compression.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping and pressing can aggravate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to spinal loading and potential falls.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead lifting can increase blood pressure; monitor closely.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural range of motion.
modifications.harder: Perform standing barbell shoulder presses to engage more stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform seated dumbbell shoulder presses with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a bench with back support and maintain a neutral spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench has adequate back support to prevent hyperextension of the spine.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Use a spotter or safety pins in the squat rack for added safety.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid excessive strain.
Lower the barbell slowly and with control.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Arching the back excessively, which can strain the lumbar spine.
Failing to engage the core, leading to instability.

name: Barbell Shrug
instructions: Stand up straight with your feet at shoulder width as you hold a barbell with both hands in front of you using a pronated grip (palms facing the thighs). Tip: Your hands should be a little wider than shoulder width apart. You can use wrist wraps for this exercise for a better grip. This will be your starting position.
Raise your shoulders up as far as you can go as you breathe out and hold the contraction for a second. Tip: Refrain from trying to lift the barbell by using your biceps.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The upward motion of the shoulders can exacerbate impingement by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Individuals with cervical spine problems may experience increased strain due to the load and motion involved in the shrug.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise can place additional stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.acute neck pain: The exercise may increase tension in the neck muscles, aggravating pain.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural range of motion and reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform shrugs with a resistance band to reduce load and allow for controlled movement.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Focus on scapular retraction exercises like seated rows to strengthen the upper back without direct neck involvement.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the neck and shoulders.
Ensure a controlled motion to minimize risk of injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a stable posture.
Lift your shoulders straight up towards your ears without rolling them.
Maintain a neutral neck position throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight, which reduces effectiveness and increases injury risk.
Rolling the shoulders, which can strain the shoulder joint.
Allowing the head to jut forward, which can strain the neck.

name: Barbell Shrug Behind The Back
instructions: Stand up straight with your feet at shoulder width as you hold a barbell with both hands behind your back using a pronated grip (palms facing back). Tip: Your hands should be a little wider than shoulder width apart. You can use wrist wraps for this exercise for better grip. This will be your starting position.

Raise your shoulders up as far as you can go as you breathe out and hold the contraction for a second. Tip: Refrain from trying to lift the barbell by using your biceps. The arms should remain stretched out at all times.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The behind-the-back position can exacerbate impingement by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The load on the shoulders can increase tension in the neck, aggravating cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise may strain the rotator cuff due to the position of the arms and the load.
contraindicationDetails.acute neck pain: The exercise can increase neck tension, worsening acute pain.
contraindicationDetails.thoracic outlet syndrome: The position of the arms may compress neurovascular structures, exacerbating symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform dumbbell shrugs with arms at the sides to reduce shoulder joint stress.
modifications.harder: Use a Smith machine for added stability and increased load.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use resistance bands instead of a barbell to reduce load and stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Perform seated shrugs to minimize neck involvement.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder and neck strain.
Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare the shoulder girdle and neck muscles.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a neutral spine.
Lift with your shoulders, not your arms, to target the traps effectively.
Avoid jerking the weight; use a controlled motion.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the barbell.
Allowing the head to protrude forward, causing neck strain.
Bending the elbows, which shifts focus away from the traps.

name: Barbell Side Bend
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell placed on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck). Your feet should be shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your back straight and your head up, bend only at the waist to the right as far as possible. Breathe in as you bend to the side. Then hold for a second and come back up to the starting position as you exhale. Tip: Keep the rest of the body stationary.
Now repeat the movement but bending to the left instead. Hold for a second and come back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High risk due to increased spinal flexion and lateral bending, which can exacerbate disc protrusion.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Moderate risk as the exercise may increase shear forces on the vertebrae.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Moderate risk due to potential compression of the spinal canal during lateral flexion.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High risk as bending may irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High risk of vertebral fractures due to lateral bending with load.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate risk, especially in the second and third trimesters, due to changes in balance and core stability.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal or spinal surgery: High risk as healing tissues may be compromised by the movement.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Moderate risk due to the need for stability during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a barbell, using just body weight or a light dumbbell held in one hand.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a resistance band anchored at waist height and perform standing side bends with the band for reduced spinal load.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive lateral flexion to prevent undue stress on the spine.
Keep the movement slow and controlled to reduce risk of injury.
Ensure the barbell is securely placed and balanced on the shoulders.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Keep your shoulders level and avoid twisting your torso.
Bend only at the waist, keeping your hips stationary.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the body instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the barbell to roll onto the neck.
Twisting the torso instead of pure lateral bending.

name: Barbell Side Split Squat
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell placed on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck). Your feet should be placed wide apart with the foot of the lead leg angled out to the side. This will be your starting position.
Lower your body towards the side of your angled foot by bending the knee and hip of your lead leg and while keeping the opposite leg only slightly bent. Breathe in as you lower your body.
Return to the starting position by extending the hip and knee of the lead leg. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
After performing the recommended amount of reps, repeat the movement with the opposite leg.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or hip impingement should modify the range of motion to avoid exacerbating symptoms.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing exercises involving heavy lifting.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve heavy lifting and balance challenges.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the lower body or spine, require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare professional.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a barbell, using body weight or a light dumbbell for balance support.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage stabilizer muscles more intensely.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a Smith machine to provide additional support and reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat and focus on a controlled, slow movement to minimize knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely positioned on the upper back, not the neck.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid locking the knee of the non-working leg to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged.
Push through the heel of the lead leg when returning to the starting position.
Align the knee of the lead leg with the toes to prevent valgus collapse.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to extend beyond the toes, increasing knee joint stress.
Rounding the back, which can lead to spinal injury.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.

name: Barbell Squat
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack to just below shoulder level. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and hips as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid barbell squats due to the axial loading on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis, knee tendinitis, or hip bursitis should modify the depth and load to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Hypertension or heart disease patients should avoid heavy lifting and consult a physician before performing squats.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid barbell squats due to balance and core stability changes.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical patients, particularly those recovering from back or knee surgery, should avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis patients should avoid heavy weights and focus on controlled movements to prevent fractures.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications or alternative exercises to ensure safety.

modifications.easier: Goblet squat with a dumbbell or bodyweight squat to reduce load and improve form.
modifications.harder: Front squat or overhead squat to increase core and upper body engagement.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a Smith machine or perform box squats to limit range of motion and reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit squat depth and use a resistance band around the knees to encourage proper alignment.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a safety squat bar or a front squat grip to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Always use a spotter or safety pins in a squat rack.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting heavy lifts.
Avoid bouncing at the bottom of the squat to prevent knee and back injury.
formCues: Keep the chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the heels to stand up, avoiding shifting weight to the toes.
Ensure knees track over the toes, not collapsing inward.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the ascent.
Rounding the back, especially at the bottom of the squat.
Lifting the heels off the ground.

name: Barbell Squat To A Bench
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first place a flat bench or a box behind you. The flat bench is used to teach you to set your hips back and to hit depth.

Then, set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and sitting your hips back as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until you slightly touch the bench behind you. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs and extend the hips to go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial load on the spine.

joint_issues.explanation: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the depth or avoid the exercise to prevent exacerbating joint pain.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid heavy lifting and consult a physician.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid heavy squats due to balance and intra-abdominal pressure concerns.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery, especially involving the spine or lower extremities, requires complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

osteoporosis.explanation: High risk of fractures due to the axial load on the spine and hips.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent trauma or sprains should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

neurological_conditions.explanation: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls; modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform bodyweight squats to a bench.
modifications.harder: Perform the squat with a pause at the bottom position before returning to the start.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a safety squat bar to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit depth to a partial squat or use a higher bench to reduce knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at an appropriate height to prevent excessive knee flexion.
Use a spotter or safety bars in the squat rack for added safety.
Warm up thoroughly before performing heavy lifts.
formCues: Keep the chest up and back straight throughout the movement.
Engage the core to maintain stability and protect the spine.
Drive through the heels to engage the posterior chain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Rounding the back or leaning too far forward.
Bouncing off the bench instead of using controlled movement.

name: Barbell Step Ups
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a barbell placed on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) and stand upright behind an elevated platform (such as the one used for spotting behind a flat bench). This is your starting position.
