Place the right foot on the elevated platform. Step on the platform by extending the hip and the knee of your right leg. Use the heel mainly to lift the rest of your body up and place the foot of the left leg on the platform as well. Breathe out as you execute the force required to come up.

Step down with the left leg by flexing the hip and knee of the right leg as you inhale. Return to the original standing position by placing the right foot of to next to the left foot on the initial position.
Repeat with the right leg for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform with the left leg.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: Those with knee arthritis, hip impingement, or tendinitis may experience exacerbated symptoms due to the load and movement pattern.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: People with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should be cautious with heavy lifting due to increased cardiovascular demand.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: During pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, balance and core stability are compromised, making this exercise risky.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Individuals recovering from lower limb or spinal surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.neurological_conditions: Conditions affecting balance or proprioception, such as neuropathy, may increase the risk of falls.

modifications.easier: Perform step-ups using body weight only or with dumbbells held at the sides.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the platform or add a pause at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight or hold dumbbells at the sides to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion or use a lower platform to reduce stress on the knees.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a safety squat bar or hold dumbbells to avoid shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the platform is stable and non-slip.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise.
Start with a manageable weight to master the form.
formCues: Keep the chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the heel of the stepping leg to engage the quadriceps effectively.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar flexion or extension.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to cave inward, which can increase stress on the joint.
Using momentum rather than controlled muscle contraction.
Leaning too far forward, which can strain the lower back.

name: Barbell Walking Lunge
instructions: Begin standing with your feet shoulder width apart and a barbell across your upper back.

Step forward with one leg, flexing the knees to drop your hips. Descend until your rear knee nearly touches the ground. Your posture should remain upright, and your front knee should stay above the front foot.
Drive through the heel of your lead foot and extend both knees to raise yourself back up.
Step forward with your rear foot, repeating the lunge on the opposite leg.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and potential for spinal compression.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis may experience exacerbated symptoms due to the dynamic knee flexion and extension.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should be cautious due to the potential for increased blood pressure during the exercise.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise to prevent balance issues and excessive intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical patients, particularly those recovering from lower limb or spinal surgeries, should avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid due to the risk of fractures from axial loading. Diabetic individuals with neuropathy should be cautious of balance issues.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the lower body.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase fall risk, requiring modifications or avoidance.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight walking lunges or use dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform walking lunges on an incline.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a Smith machine to provide more stability and reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion and use a shorter stride.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely positioned across the upper back to avoid neck strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent lower back injury.
Avoid allowing the front knee to extend beyond the toes to minimize knee stress.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back to maintain an upright posture.
Engage your core muscles to stabilize the trunk.
Step forward with a controlled motion and avoid slamming the rear knee into the ground.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to collapse inward (valgus collapse).
Using momentum instead of muscle control to return to standing.
Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the lower back.

name: Battling Ropes
instructions: For this exercise you will need a heavy rope anchored at its center 15-20 feet away. Standing in front of the rope, take an end in each hand with your arms extended at your side. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by rapidly raising one arm to shoulder level as quickly as you can.
As you let that arm drop to the starting position, raise the opposite side.
Continue alternating your left and right arms, whipping the ropes up and down as fast as you can.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The rapid arm movements can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The dynamic nature of the exercise can strain the rotator cuff, worsening existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the ropes tightly can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The high-intensity nature of battling ropes can cause a significant increase in blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which may not be suitable during recovery.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The standing position and dynamic movement can strain the lower back, worsening pain.

modifications.easier: Use lighter ropes or perform the exercise seated to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed of the waves or use thicker, heavier ropes.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion or use a single arm at a time.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated or with a slight forward lean to engage the core more effectively.

safetyNotes: Ensure the ropes are securely anchored to prevent accidents.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees to reduce lower back strain.
Avoid locking the elbows to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive leaning.
Use a smooth, controlled motion to generate waves.
commonMistakes: Using excessive body sway to generate momentum.
Allowing the elbows to lock out during the movement.
Neglecting core engagement, leading to lower back strain.

name: Bear Crawl Sled Drags
instructions: Wearing either a harness or a loose weight belt, attach the chain to the back so that you will be facing away from the sled. Bend down so that your hands are on the ground. Your back should be flat and knees bent. This is your starting position.
Begin by driving with legs, alternating left and right. Use your hands to maintain balance and to help pull. Try to keep your back flat as you move over a given distance.

herniated disc.explanation: The forward-leaning position and load on the spine can exacerbate disc herniation.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The exercise places significant stress on the knees, which can aggravate osteoarthritis.

acute lower back pain.explanation: The exercise requires a stable core and flat back, which may be compromised by acute pain.

balance disorders.explanation: The dynamic movement and coordination required can be challenging for those with balance issues.

recent shoulder surgery.explanation: Weight bearing on the hands can stress the shoulder joint, potentially hindering recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the sled to focus on form and balance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the sled or perform the exercise on an incline.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter sled and focus on maintaining a neutral spine with minimal forward lean.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the sled weight and perform the exercise on a softer surface to reduce impact.

safetyNotes: Ensure the harness or belt is securely fastened to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive forward lean to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep your back flat and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive with your legs and use your hands primarily for balance.
Maintain a steady, controlled pace to ensure proper form.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round, which can increase the risk of injury.
Using the arms too much instead of driving with the legs.
Moving too quickly, which can compromise form and increase injury risk.

name: Behind Head Chest Stretch
instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you.
Place your hands behind your hand, and push your elbows back as far as you can. Your partner should hold your elbows. This will be your starting position.
Gently attempt to pull your elbows forward with your hands still behind your head for 10 or more seconds. Your partner should prevent your elbows from moving.

Now, relax your muscles and have your partner gently pull the elbows back as far as it comfortable for you. Be sure to let your partner know when the stretch is adequate to prevent overstretching or injury.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to the position of the arms and potential for overstretching.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stretch may place undue stress on the rotator cuff, leading to further injury.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The position can strain the neck, especially if there is a history of cervical disc herniation or stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to the potential for excessive force on the spine and ribs.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Hormonal changes increase joint laxity, making overstretching more likely and potentially harmful.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch without a partner, gently pulling the elbows back yourself to control the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the isometric hold to 20 seconds and deepen the stretch gradually.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a standing chest stretch with hands on a wall or doorway to reduce strain on the shoulders.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Avoid placing hands behind the head; instead, clasp hands in front and gently pull elbows back.

safetyNotes: Communicate clearly with your partner to avoid overstretching.
Stop immediately if you feel any sharp pain or discomfort.
Ensure the partner is aware of your limits and any existing conditions.
formCues: Keep your spine neutral and avoid arching your back.
Engage your core to support your posture.
Breathe steadily throughout the stretch.
commonMistakes: Overstretching beyond comfort level.
Arching the back excessively.
Not communicating effectively with the partner.

name: Bench Dips
instructions: For this exercise you will need to place a bench behind your back. With the bench perpendicular to your body, and while looking away from it, hold on to the bench on its edge with the hands fully extended, separated at shoulder width. The legs will be extended forward, bent at the waist and perpendicular to your torso. This will be your starting position.

Slowly lower your body as you inhale by bending at the elbows until you lower yourself far enough to where there is an angle slightly smaller than 90 degrees between the upper arm and the forearm. Tip: Keep the elbows as close as possible throughout the movement. Forearms should always be pointing down.
Using your triceps to bring your torso up again, lift yourself back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Bench dips can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the position of the arms and the stress placed on the shoulder joint.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive extension and flexion of the elbow can aggravate tendinitis.

wrist pain.explanation: The pressure on the wrists during bench dips can worsen existing pain or conditions.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The wrist position can increase compression on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate rotator cuff injuries.

modifications.easier: Perform bench dips with bent knees to reduce the load on the triceps and shoulders.
modifications.harder: Place a weight plate on your lap to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform tricep pushdowns using a cable machine to reduce shoulder involvement.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use parallel bars or dip bars to keep wrists in a neutral position.

safetyNotes: Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to prevent joint stress.
Ensure the bench is stable and secure to prevent accidents.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your body throughout the movement.
Lower your body in a controlled manner to avoid excessive strain on the shoulders.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, which increases shoulder stress.
Dropping too quickly into the dip, which can lead to injury.
Failing to maintain a straight line from shoulders to knees or feet.

name: Bench Jump
instructions: Begin with a box or bench 1-2 feet in front of you. Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Perform a short squat in preparation for the jump; swing your arms behind you.
Rebound out of this position, extending through the hips, knees, and ankles to jump as high as possible. Swing your arms forward and up.
Jump over the bench, landing with the knees bent, absorbing the impact through the legs.
Turn around and face the opposite direction, then jump back over the bench.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high impact and potential for spinal compression.

joint issues.details: Those with arthritis, knee tendinitis, or bursitis should avoid this exercise as it can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.

cardiovascular conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity plyometric exercises.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid high-impact exercises like bench jumps due to balance and joint stability concerns.

surgical recovery.details: Recent surgery on the lower extremities or spine requires clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting high-impact exercises.

chronic conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid high-impact exercises due to increased fracture risk.

acute injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

neurological conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase fall risk during this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform step-ups onto the bench instead of jumping to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the bench or add a weighted vest for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform box squats to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a lower platform and focus on controlled landings to minimize knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and on a non-slip surface.
Wear supportive footwear to absorb impact.
Warm up thoroughly before performing plyometric exercises.
formCues: Engage your core to maintain balance.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Keep your chest up and gaze forward during the jump.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff knees, increasing joint stress.
Allowing knees to cave inward upon landing.
Not using arms to generate momentum.

name: Bench Press - Powerlifting
instructions: Begin by lying on the bench, getting your head beyond the bar if possible. Tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement.
However wide your grip, it should cover the ring on the bar. Pull the bar out of the rack without protracting your shoulders. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart.
Lower the bar to your lower chest or upper stomach. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times.
Pause when the barbell touches your torso, and then drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High stress on the shoulder joint can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The exercise places significant load on the rotator cuff, which can worsen tears.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repeated flexion and extension under load can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The wrist is under constant load, which can exacerbate pain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver commonly used in powerlifting can increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Arching the back can increase spinal compression, worsening stenosis symptoms.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural range of motion and reduce joint stress.
modifications.harder: Add resistance bands or chains to increase resistance at the top of the lift.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a floor press to limit the range of motion and reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a flat back position instead of an arched back to minimize spinal compression.

safetyNotes: Ensure a spotter is present to assist with the lift.
Use collars to secure weight plates on the barbell.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the shoulder joints and muscles.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the ground for stability.
Maintain a slight arch in the lower back without excessive hyperextension.
Retract and depress the shoulder blades throughout the lift.
Keep the elbows at a 45-degree angle to the torso during the descent.
commonMistakes: Bouncing the bar off the chest, which can lead to injury.
Flaring the elbows out excessively, increasing shoulder strain.
Lifting the hips off the bench, which can cause lower back strain.

name: Bench Press - With Bands
instructions: Using a flat bench secure a band under the leg of the bench that is nearest to your head.
Once the band is secure, grab it by both handles and lie down on the bench.
Extend your arms so that you are holding the band handles in front of you at shoulder width.
Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. This will be your starting position.
Bring down the handles slowly until your elbow forms a 90 degree angle. Keep full control at all times.

As you breathe out, bring the handles up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and pressing motion may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The repetitive pressing motion can irritate the tendons further, leading to increased pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during pressing exercises, can spike blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which may not be suitable during the recovery phase.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: The exertion and potential for holding breath can increase cardiac workload, posing a risk for individuals with unstable heart conditions.

modifications.easier: Use lighter resistance bands or perform the exercise with a single band to reduce tension.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance by using thicker bands or adding a second band.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure the lower back is supported by the bench and maintain a slight arch to avoid excessive lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely anchored to prevent slippage.
Maintain control throughout the movement to prevent sudden jerks.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Exhale as you press the bands upward, and inhale as you lower them.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the bands to snap back quickly, losing control.
Flaring elbows too wide, increasing shoulder strain.
Arching the back excessively, leading to potential lumbar stress.

name: Bench Press with Chains
instructions: Adjust the leader chain, shortening it to the desired length.Place the chains on the sleeves of the bar.

Lying on the bench, get your head beyond the bar if possible. Tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement. However wide your grip, it should cover the ring on the bar.

Pull the bar out of the rack without protracting your shoulders. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart. Lower the bar to your lower chest or upper stomach. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times.
Pause when the barbell touches your torso, and then drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and pressing motion can exacerbate shoulder impingement by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate a rotator cuff tear.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and pressing action can worsen symptoms of tendinitis in the elbow.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The weight of the barbell and the gripping motion can increase stress on the wrist joint, aggravating pain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver often used during heavy lifts can increase blood pressure, posing risks for those with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The arching of the back and the load on the spine can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The spinal extension and load can worsen vertebral slippage in spondylolisthesis.

modifications.easier: Perform the bench press with a lighter barbell or use dumbbells to reduce the load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the chain weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip bar to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a flat bench without arching the back excessively.

safetyNotes: Ensure chains are securely attached to avoid instability.
Use a spotter or safety racks to prevent accidents.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the shoulder and elbow joints.
formCues: Keep your shoulder blades retracted and tight against the bench.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid excessive stress.
Drive through your feet to stabilize your body.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder strain.
Bouncing the bar off the chest, which can cause injury.
Losing tension in the upper back, leading to instability.

name: Bench Sprint
instructions: Stand on the ground with one foot resting on a bench or box with your heel close to the edge.
Push off with your foot on top of the bench, extending through the hip and knee.
Land with the opposite foot on top of the box, returning your other foot back to the start position.
Continue alternating from one foot to another to complete the set.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The repetitive impact and load on the knee joint during the exercise may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The dynamic nature of the exercise can increase strain on the lower back, potentially worsening pain.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, which may be challenging and unsafe for individuals with balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding high-impact and dynamic movements to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: The exercise can aggravate the hip joint and surrounding tissues, leading to increased inflammation and pain.

modifications.easier: Perform step-ups on a lower platform or use a stable chair to reduce the height and impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the bench or add ankle weights for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform the exercise on a lower platform and focus on controlled, slow movements to minimize joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Engage the core muscles and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to reduce lower back strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench or box is stable and non-slip to prevent falls.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
Avoid locking the knees during the push-off phase to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance and stability.
Push through the heel of the foot on the bench for optimal muscle activation.
Land softly with a slight bend in the knee to absorb impact.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to cave inward during the push-off phase.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Failing to maintain a neutral spine, leading to excessive lower back arching.

name: Bent-Arm Barbell Pullover
instructions: Lie on a flat bench with a barbell using a shoulder grip width.
Hold the bar straight over your chest with a bend in your arms. This will be your starting position.
While keeping your arms in the bent arm position, lower the weight slowly in an arc behind your head while breathing in until you feel a stretch on the chest.
At that point, bring the barbell back to the starting position using the arc through which the weight was lowered and exhale as you perform this movement.
Hold the weight on the initial position for a second and repeat the motion for the prescribed number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The movement may aggravate inflammation in the rotator cuff due to the overhead and backward motion.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The neck position during the exercise can increase pressure on cervical discs, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The position and load can increase the risk of fractures, especially in the thoracic spine.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which may not be suitable during recovery.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or a dumbbell for better control and reduced load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion and challenge.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with a resistance band to reduce joint stress and allow for a more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid excessive weight to prevent undue stress on the shoulders and spine.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep elbows slightly bent and fixed throughout the movement.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
Focus on a slow and controlled motion, especially during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively.
Using momentum to swing the weight back to the starting position.
Arching the lower back excessively during the movement.

name: Bent-Arm Dumbbell Pullover
instructions: Place a dumbbell standing up on a flat bench.

Ensuring that the dumbbell stays securely placed at the top of the bench, lie perpendicular to the bench (torso across it as in forming a cross) with only your shoulders lying on the surface. Hips should be below the bench and legs bent with feet firmly on the floor. The head will be off the bench as well.

Grasp the dumbbell with both hands and hold it straight over your chest with a bend in your arms. Both palms should be pressing against the underside one of the sides of the dumbbell. This will be your starting position. Caution: Always ensure that the dumbbell used for this exercise is secure. Using a dumbbell with loose plates can result in the dumbbell falling apart and falling on your face.
While keeping your arms locked in the bent arm position, lower the weight slowly in an arc behind your head while breathing in until you feel a stretch on the chest.
At that point, bring the dumbbell back to the starting position using the arc through which the weight was lowered and exhale as you perform this movement.
Hold the weight on the initial position for a second and repeat the motion for the prescribed number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and range of motion can exacerbate symptoms by compressing structures in the shoulder.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The head-off-bench position may strain the neck, potentially aggravating cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise involves a significant load on the upper body and spine, which can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The position and movement can increase intra-abdominal pressure and spinal extension, potentially aggravating disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The hyperextension of the spine during the exercise may exacerbate vertebral slippage.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter dumbbell or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or perform the exercise on a stability ball to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort and use a lighter weight.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on the floor with knees bent to reduce spinal extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the dumbbell is securely assembled to prevent it from coming apart during the exercise.
Maintain a firm grip on the dumbbell throughout the movement.
Avoid hyperextending the spine by keeping the core engaged.
formCues: Keep elbows slightly bent and locked in position throughout the movement.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso and prevent excessive arching of the back.
Move slowly and control the weight, especially during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, which can reduce effectiveness and increase shoulder strain.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Hyperextending the lower back by not engaging the core.

name: Bent-Knee Hip Raise
instructions: Lay flat on the floor with your arms next to your sides.
Now bend your knees at around a 75 degree angle and lift your feet off the floor by around 2 inches.

Using your lower abs, bring your knees in towards you as you maintain the 75 degree angle bend in your legs. Continue this movement until you raise your hips off of the floor by rolling your pelvis backward. Breathe out as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: At the end of the movement your knees will be over your chest.
Squeeze your abs at the top of the movement for a second and then return to the starting position slowly as you breathe in. Tip: Maintain a controlled motion at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The spinal flexion involved can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. Flexion of the spine can increase pressure on the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise can increase lumbar spine instability.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity. The movement may irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Spinal flexion can increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Supine position and abdominal pressure may be uncomfortable or unsafe, especially in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with feet on the floor and only lift the hips slightly.
modifications.harder: Extend the legs fully while lifting the hips to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a small pillow under the lower back for support.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep the knees bent and avoid full extension to reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking movements to prevent unnecessary spinal stress.
Do not use momentum; focus on controlled muscle activation.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you lift the hips and inhale as you lower them.
Keep the movement slow and controlled.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the legs.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Not engaging the core adequately.

name: Bent Over Barbell Row
instructions: Holding a barbell with a pronated grip (palms facing down), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The barbell should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

Now, while keeping the torso stationary, breathe out and lift the barbell to you. Keep the elbows close to the body and only use the forearms to hold the weight. At the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a brief pause.
Then inhale and slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

herniated disc.explanation: The forward bending position can exacerbate disc herniation by increasing intradiscal pressure.

spinal stenosis.explanation: Forward flexion can narrow the spinal canal further, increasing nerve compression.

spondylolisthesis.explanation: The exercise may increase shear forces on the spine, worsening vertebral slippage.

sciatica.explanation: The bent-over position can aggravate sciatic nerve pain; modifications are needed.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The shoulder position during the row can exacerbate impingement symptoms.

hypertension.explanation: The bent-over position may increase blood pressure; monitor closely and modify as needed.

pregnancy.explanation: The forward bending position can be uncomfortable and unsafe due to balance and abdominal pressure.

osteoporosis.explanation: The forward flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a wider grip or add tempo variations to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a supported row using a bench to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to decrease shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent back injury.
Avoid rounding the shoulders to protect the upper back and neck.
Start with a lighter weight to master the form before progressing.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Pull the barbell towards your lower ribcage, not your chest.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which can lead to spinal injury.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, reducing back engagement.

name: Bent Over Dumbbell Rear Delt Raise With Head On Bench
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell in each hand and with an incline bench in front of you.

While keeping your back straight and maintaining the natural arch of your back, lean forward until your forehead touches the bench in front of you. Let the arms hang in front of you perpendicular to the ground. The palms of your hands should be facing each other and your torso should be parallel to the floor. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your torso forward and stationary, and the arms straight with a slight bend at the elbows, lift the dumbbells straight to the side until both arms are parallel to the floor. Exhale as you lift the weights. Caution: avoid swinging the torso or bringing the arms back as opposed to the side.
After a one second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.
Repeat the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms laterally can exacerbate impingement by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The movement may increase inflammation and pain in the tendons of the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Leaning forward with the head supported may place strain on the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The forward-leaning position and weight bearing can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Forward flexion can exacerbate symptoms by increasing disc pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The forward-leaning position may increase lumbar instability.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights to focus on form and muscle activation.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slight pause at the top of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with resistance bands to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without swinging.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Lift the dumbbells to the side, not back, to target the rear deltoids effectively.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce stress on the elbow joint.
commonMistakes: Swinging the torso to lift the weights.
Lifting the weights too high, causing shoulder strain.
Allowing the head to move off the bench, leading to neck strain.

name: Bent Over Low-Pulley Side Lateral
instructions: Select a weight and hold the handle of the low pulley with your right hand.

Bend at the waist until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor. Your legs should be slightly bent with your left hand placed on your lower left thigh. Your right arm should be hanging from your shoulder in front of you and with a slight bend at the elbow. This will be your starting position.
Raise your right arm, elbow slightly bent, to the side until the arm is parallel to the floor and in line with your right ear. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and repeat the movement with the other arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and lateral movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: This exercise may place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening a tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: The movement may increase joint pain and inflammation in individuals with advanced shoulder arthritis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Bending over can strain the neck, especially if there are existing cervical spine problems.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The bent-over position may increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The bent-over position can increase spinal load, aggravating disc herniation symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The forward bend may exacerbate sciatic nerve pain due to increased lumbar pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band instead of a cable to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slight pause at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise in a seated position with back support to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise while seated on an incline bench to maintain a neutral spine.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid jerking or swinging the arm to reduce the risk of shoulder injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbow throughout the movement.
Lift the arm in a controlled manner, focusing on the shoulder muscles.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the back to round, which can lead to spinal strain.
Lifting the arm too high, which can cause shoulder impingement.

name: Bent Over One-Arm Long Bar Row
instructions: Put weight on one of the ends of an Olympic barbell. Make sure that you either place the other end of the barbell in the corner of two walls; or put a heavy object on the ground so the barbell cannot slide backward.
Bend forward until your torso is as close to parallel with the floor as you can and keep your knees slightly bent.
Now grab the bar with one arm just behind the plates on the side where the weight was placed and put your other hand on your knee. This will be your starting position.

Pull the bar straight up with your elbow in (to maximize back stimulation) until the plates touch your lower chest. Squeeze the back muscles as you lift the weight up and hold for a second at the top of the movement. Breathe out as you lift the weight. Tip: Do not allow for any swinging of the torso. Only the arm should move.

Slowly lower the bar to the starting position getting a nice stretch on the lats. Tip: Do not let the plates touch the floor. To ensure the best range of motion, I recommend using small plates (25-lb ones) as opposed to larger plates (like 35-45lb ones).
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and switch arms.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The forward bending position and load on the spine can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The flexed position may increase spinal canal narrowing, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise can increase anterior shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The position may aggravate nerve compression; modifications needed.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: moderate - The movement may exacerbate symptoms; consider modifications.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: moderate - Avoid if pain is present; modifications may be necessary.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: moderate - Exercise may exacerbate symptoms; ensure proper form and consider modifications.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - Risk of vertebral fracture; use lighter weights and ensure proper form.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band for reduced load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a chest-supported row machine to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip and avoid excessive range of motion to minimize shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the non-weighted end of the barbell is secured to prevent movement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to minimize spinal stress.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weight; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support your lower back.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees to stabilize your position.
Pull with your elbow close to your body to target the back muscles effectively.
Avoid rounding your shoulders; keep them retracted and down.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which increases spinal stress.
Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Swinging the torso to lift the weight, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.

name: Bent Over Two-Arm Long Bar Row
instructions: Put weight on one of the ends of an Olympic barbell. Make sure that you either place the other end of the barbell in the corner of two walls; or put a heavy object on the ground so the barbell cannot slide backward.
Bend forward until your torso is as close to parallel with the floor as you can and keep your knees slightly bent.
Now grab the bar with both arms just behind the plates on the side where the weight was placed and put your other hand on your knee. This will be your starting position.

Pull the bar straight up with your elbows in (to maximize back stimulation) until the plates touch your lower chest. Squeeze the back muscles as you lift the weight up and hold for a second at the top of the movement. Breathe out as you lift the weight. Tip: Use a stirrup or double handle cable attachment by hooking it under the end of the bar.

Slowly lower the bar to the starting position getting a nice stretch on the lats. Tip: Do not let the plates touch the floor. To ensure the best range of motion, I recommend using small plates (25-lb ones) as opposed to larger plates (like 35-45lb ones).
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The forward bending position and load on the spine can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. The flexed position may increase spinal canal narrowing, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The forward bend and load can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. The position and load may aggravate sciatic nerve irritation.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The shoulder position during the row may exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Moderate severity. The isometric hold and potential for Valsalva maneuver can elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. The forward bending and load can increase fracture risk in the spine.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a chest-supported row machine to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a higher starting position to reduce knee flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort at the top of the movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely anchored to prevent movement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weight; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support your lower back.
Pull with your elbows, not your hands, to engage the back muscles effectively.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which increases the risk of spinal injury.
Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the bar to touch the floor, reducing tension on the muscles.

name: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row
instructions: With a dumbbell in each hand (palms facing your torso), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward by bending at the waist; as you bend make sure to keep your back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The weights should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the dumbbells to your side (as you breathe out), keeping the elbows close to the body (do not exert any force with the forearm other than holding the weights). On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The forward bending position can exacerbate disc herniation and increase intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. Forward flexion may worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise can increase shear forces on the vertebrae, worsening slippage.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The rowing motion may aggravate shoulder impingement; modifications are necessary.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: Moderate severity. The bent-over position can increase blood pressure; monitor closely.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. The forward bending position can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider due to potential stress on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated with chest support to reduce load on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Use a barbell instead of dumbbells for increased load and stability challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with one arm at a time, using the other hand for support on a bench.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid shoulder discomfort, or use a neutral grip.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weights; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Keep your elbows close to your body during the lift.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which increases the risk of spinal injury.
Using too much weight, leading to poor form and potential injury.
Allowing the head to drop, which can strain the neck.

name: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row With Palms In
instructions: With a dumbbell in each hand (palms facing each other), bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The weights should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the dumbbells to your side as you breathe out, squeezing your shoulder blades together. On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - Bending forward and lifting weights can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - Forward bending can increase pressure on the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - Forward flexion and load can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: moderate - Arm movement may aggravate symptoms; requires careful monitoring.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: moderate - Isometric holds and straining can elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - Forward flexion increases risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - Bent-over position may challenge balance; requires supervision.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with chest support to reduce lower back strain.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm row to increase core engagement and load on each side.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated rows with a resistance band to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit range of motion and use lighter weights to reduce shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid rounding the back to prevent spinal strain.
Use controlled movements to reduce risk of injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support the lower back.
Squeeze shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
Keep elbows close to the body during the lift.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which increases risk of spinal injury.
Using momentum to lift weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing elbows to flare out, reducing effectiveness on target muscles.

name: Bent Press
instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so. This will be your starting position.

Begin my leaning to the side opposite the kettlebell, continuing until you are able to touch the ground with your free hand, keeping your eyes on the kettlebell. As you do so, press the weight vertically be extending through the elbow, keeping your arm perpendicular to the ground.
Return to an upright position, with the kettlebell above your head. Return the kettlebell to the shoulder and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The bent press involves significant spinal flexion and rotation, which can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: The overhead pressing motion can aggravate impingement symptoms, especially if form is compromised.

rotator_cuff_tendinitis.explanation: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which can worsen tendinitis symptoms.

balance_disorders.explanation: The unilateral nature and leaning motion require good balance, posing a risk for those with balance issues.

osteoporosis.explanation: The exercise involves spinal flexion and rotation, increasing fracture risk in individuals with osteoporosis.

hypertension.explanation: The overhead position and isometric contraction can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform a standing side press with a lighter kettlebell, avoiding the full lean to the ground.
modifications.harder: Increase the kettlebell weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight and limit the range of motion to reduce spinal stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter kettlebell and focus on a controlled press without full extension if pain occurs.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up focusing on shoulder and thoracic mobility.
Use a spotter if attempting heavy weights.
Avoid excessive leaning if experiencing any discomfort.
formCues: Keep your eyes on the kettlebell throughout the movement.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
Press the kettlebell vertically, not forward or backward.
commonMistakes: Allowing the kettlebell to drift forward or backward during the press.
Not maintaining a stable core, leading to excessive spinal flexion.
Using too heavy a weight, compromising form.

name: Bicycling
instructions: To begin, seat yourself on the bike and adjust the seat to your height.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Bicycling can exacerbate symptoms due to repetitive knee flexion and extension.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The seated position may increase lumbar spine pressure, aggravating pain.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Difficulty in maintaining balance can increase the risk of falls, especially on a moving bicycle.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip or knee surgery: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by the repetitive motion and load on the joints.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The cardiovascular demand of bicycling can be too intense for individuals with severe heart conditions.

modifications.easier: Use a stationary bike with back support to reduce balance demands and joint stress.
modifications.harder: Increase resistance or incline on a stationary bike or ride uphill on a road bike.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a recumbent bike to provide better lumbar support.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Lower the seat slightly to reduce knee flexion angle and use lower resistance.

safetyNotes: Always wear a helmet when bicycling outdoors.
Ensure the bike is properly adjusted to your height to prevent joint strain.
Stay hydrated, especially during long rides.
formCues: Keep your back straight and shoulders relaxed.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to absorb shocks.
Pedal smoothly in a circular motion, not just pushing down.
commonMistakes: Incorrect seat height leading to knee strain.
Hunching the shoulders, causing neck and back discomfort.
Pedaling with only the toes, which can lead to calf strain.

name: Bicycling, Stationary
instructions: To begin, seat yourself on the bike and adjust the seat to your height.

Select the desired option from the menu. You may have to start pedaling to turn it on. You can use the manual setting, or you can select a program to use. Typically, you can enter your age and weight to estimate the amount of calories burned during exercise. The level of resistance can be changed throughout the workout. The handles can be used to monitor your heart rate to help you stay at an appropriate intensity.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Moderate to severe osteoarthritis may cause pain during cycling due to repetitive knee flexion and extension.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: The repetitive motion of cycling can aggravate hip bursitis, leading to increased pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or recent heart attack should avoid high-intensity cycling.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery may require avoiding or modifying cycling to prevent stress on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Use a lower resistance setting and shorter duration to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase resistance and incorporate interval training for higher intensity.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce resistance and ensure proper seat height to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain an upright posture and avoid leaning forward excessively to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat height is adjusted so that the knee is slightly bent at the bottom of the pedal stroke.
Start with a warm-up to gradually increase heart rate and prepare muscles.
Stay hydrated and monitor heart rate to avoid overexertion.
formCues: Keep your back straight and shoulders relaxed.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
Pedal smoothly and avoid bouncing in the seat.
commonMistakes: Setting the seat too low or too high, leading to improper knee alignment.
Using excessive resistance, which can strain the knees and hips.
Leaning too far forward, causing back strain.

recommendedReps.interval: 5-10 minutes of high intensity followed by 2-5 minutes of low intensity

name: Board Press
instructions: Begin by lying on the bench, getting your head beyond the bar if possible. One to five boards, made out of 2x6's, can be screwed together and held in place by a training partner, bands, or just tucked under your shirt.

Tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement.

You can take a standard bench grip, or shoulder width to focus on the triceps. Pull the bar out of the rack without protracting your shoulders. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart.
Lower the bar to the boards, and then drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity. The board press involves significant shoulder movement which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: High severity. The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, potentially worsening a tear.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate severity. The triceps involvement can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Moderate severity. Gripping the barbell can strain the wrist, especially if already injured.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Low severity. The Valsalva maneuver often used in heavy lifting can increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Moderate severity. The arching of the back and pressure on the spine can exacerbate spinal issues.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or use a narrower grip to focus more on the triceps.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip bar to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Reduce the arch in the back and ensure proper lumbar support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the boards are securely positioned to prevent slipping.
Have a spotter present to assist with lifting the barbell off the rack and for safety.
Avoid excessive arching of the back to prevent spinal strain.
formCues: Keep the elbows tucked in until lockout to protect the shoulders.
Maintain a tight grip and try to pull the bar apart for stability.
Drive through the feet to stabilize the body on the bench.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, increasing shoulder strain.
Failing to maintain a tight body position, leading to instability.
Dropping the bar too quickly onto the boards, risking injury.

name: Body-Up
instructions: Assume a plank position on the ground. You should be supporting your bodyweight on your toes and forearms, keeping your torso straight. Your forearms should be shoulder-width apart. This will be your starting position.
Pressing your palms firmly into the ground, extend through the elbows to raise your body from the ground. Keep your torso rigid as you perform the movement.
Slowly lower your forearms back to the ground by allowing the elbows to flex.
Repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension of the elbow may aggravate tendinitis, particularly lateral epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Weight-bearing on the wrists can increase discomfort and exacerbate existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists in a plank position can worsen symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which can be problematic for those with rotator cuff pathology.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The plank position may increase intra-abdominal pressure and spinal load, potentially aggravating disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The plank position can increase lumbar spine stress, which may be contraindicated for those with spondylolisthesis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on your knees instead of toes to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Elevate your feet on a bench or step to increase the difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, avoiding full extension.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or dumbbells to keep wrists in a neutral position.

safetyNotes: Ensure a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar extension.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Engage your core to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Press through the palms evenly to lift your body.
Keep your elbows close to your body during the ascent and descent.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag or rise, breaking the plank position.
Flaring the elbows out too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Rushing through the movement without control.

name: Body Tricep Press
instructions: Position a bar in a rack at chest height.
Standing, take a shoulder width grip on the bar and step a yard or two back, feet together and arms extended so that you are leaning on the bar. This will be your starting position.
Begin by flexing the elbow, lowering yourself towards the bar.
Pause, and then reverse the motion by extending the elbows.
Progress from bodyweight by adding chains over your shoulders.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High stress on the shoulder joint can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive elbow extension can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Weight bearing on wrists may worsen pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists can increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise can strain the rotator cuff, delaying recovery.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (third trimester): Balance and core stability may be compromised.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may be stressed by weight-bearing activities.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with the bar positioned higher, reducing the angle of lean.
modifications.harder: Lower the bar to increase the angle of lean or add resistance with a weighted vest.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform tricep extensions with resistance bands to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a wider grip to reduce strain on the elbows.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use padded grips or wrist wraps to alleviate pressure.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely positioned in the rack.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body during the movement.
Engage core muscles to maintain stability.
Control the descent to avoid bouncing off the bar.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out excessively.
Arching the back or losing core engagement.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Bodyweight Flyes
instructions: Position two equally loaded EZ bars on the ground next to each other. Ensure they are able to roll.
Assume a push-up position over the bars, supporting your weight on your toes and hands with your arms extended and body straight.
Place your hands on the bars. This will be your starting position.
Using a slow and controlled motion, move your hands away from the midline of your body, rolling the bars apart. Inhale during this portion of the motion.
After moving the bars as far apart as you can, return to the starting position by pulling them back together. Exhale as you perform this movement.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The wide arm movement can exacerbate impingement by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The rolling motion and weight bearing on the wrists can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists during the exercise can increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Maintaining a plank position can strain the lower back, especially if core stability is lacking.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The prone position and core engagement may not be suitable, particularly in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with knees on the ground to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Elevate feet on a bench or step to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive abduction.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up handles to keep wrists neutral and reduce strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise against a wall in a standing position to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure bars are stable and can roll smoothly to prevent sudden jerks.
Avoid excessive range of motion to protect shoulder joints.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep core engaged to prevent sagging hips.
Inhale as you roll the bars apart, exhale as you bring them together.
Keep elbows slightly bent to reduce stress on the joints.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise, compromising core stability.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Overextending arms, risking shoulder strain.

name: Bodyweight Mid Row
instructions: Begin by taking a medium to wide grip on a pull-up apparatus with your palms facing away from you. From a hanging position, tuck your knees to your chest, leaning back and getting your legs over your side of the pull-up apparatus. This will be your starting position.
Beginning with your arms straight, flex the elbows and retract the shoulder blades to raise your body up until your legs contact the pull-up apparatus.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The overhead position and shoulder retraction may exacerbate symptoms.

rotator cuff tendinitis.explanation: The exercise involves significant shoulder stabilization and movement, which can aggravate tendinitis.

herniated disc.explanation: The hanging position and spinal flexion can increase intradiscal pressure.

spondylolisthesis.explanation: The exercise may place undue stress on the lumbar spine, worsening the condition.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: Gripping the bar can exacerbate symptoms due to wrist flexion and pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform inverted rows using a barbell set at hip height with feet on the ground.
modifications.harder: Add a weighted vest or perform the exercise with one arm.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated rows with a resistance band to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a neutral grip and limit range of motion to avoid pain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the pull-up apparatus is secure and can support your body weight.
Avoid swinging or using momentum to complete the movement.
formCues: Engage your core to maintain a stable torso.
Retract your shoulder blades fully at the top of the movement.
Keep your elbows close to your body as you pull.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug during the exercise.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Bodyweight Squat
instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. You can place your hands behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your knees and hips, sitting back with your hips.
Continue down to full depth if you are able,and quickly reverse the motion until you return to the starting position. As you squat, keep your head and chest up and push your knees out.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or severe sciatica should avoid deep squats and may need to limit range of motion.

joint issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should avoid deep squats and may benefit from using a chair for support.

cardiovascular conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension should avoid holding their breath during the squat to prevent blood pressure spikes.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should focus on maintaining balance and may need to limit depth as pregnancy progresses.

surgical recovery.details: Recent knee or hip surgery patients should avoid squats until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid deep squats to reduce spinal compression risk.

acute injuries.details: Avoid squats if experiencing acute knee or back pain until evaluated by a healthcare provider.

neurological conditions.details: Those with balance disorders should perform squats near a stable surface for support.

modifications.easier: Perform a partial squat, limiting depth to comfort and maintaining balance.
modifications.harder: Add a jump at the top of the movement for a plyometric variation.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform wall squats with a stability ball to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a chair for support and limit depth to avoid pain.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep arms at sides or crossed over chest instead of behind the head.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before starting squats to prepare muscles and joints.
Avoid locking knees at the top of the movement to maintain muscle tension.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent back strain.
formCues: Keep chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Push through heels to activate glutes and maintain balance.
Ensure knees track over toes and do not cave inward.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward, increasing risk of injury.
Rounding the lower back, which can lead to spinal strain.
Leaning too far forward, shifting weight onto toes.

name: Bodyweight Walking Lunge
instructions: Begin standing with your feet shoulder width apart and your hands on your hips.

Step forward with one leg, flexing the knees to drop your hips. Descend until your rear knee nearly touches the ground. Your posture should remain upright, and your front knee should stay above the front foot.
Drive through the heel of your lead foot and extend both knees to raise yourself back up.
Step forward with your rear foot, repeating the lunge on the opposite leg.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High impact on the knee joint may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: The dynamic nature of the exercise can increase the risk of ankle sprains.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of lunges.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Requires stability and coordination, increasing fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.advanced osteoporosis: Risk of fractures due to the load on the lower extremities.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: The movement can irritate the bursa, worsening inflammation.

modifications.easier: Perform stationary lunges instead of walking lunges to reduce complexity.
modifications.harder: Add a jump at the top of each lunge for increased intensity.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce range of motion and avoid deep lunges.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a shorter stride to minimize lumbar stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure a clear, flat surface to prevent tripping.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the joints and muscles.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core throughout the movement.
Ensure your front knee does not extend past your toes.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to cave inward.
Leaning forward excessively, causing back strain.
Taking too short or too long strides, affecting balance.

name: Bosu Ball Cable Crunch With Side Bends
instructions: Connect a standard handle to each arm of a cable machine, and position them in the most downward position.
Grab a Bosu Ball and position it in front and center of the cable machine.
Lie down on the Bosu Ball with the small of your back arched around the ball. Your rear end should be close to the floor without touching it.
With both hands, reach back and grab the handle of each cable.
With your feet positioned in a wide stance, extend your arms straight out in front of you and in between your knees. Your hands should be at knee level.
Keep your arms straight and in-line with the upward angle of the cable. Elevate your torso in a crunching motion without dropping or bending your arms.
Maintain the rigid position with your arms. Slowly descend back to the starting position with your back arched around the Bosu Ball and your abdominals elongated.
Repeat the same series of movements to failure.
