Once you reach failure, keep your abs tight and raise your torso into plank position so your back is elevated off the Bosu Ball.
Lower your arms down to your side; keep them straight. Start doing alternating side bends; reach for your heels! This finishing movement will focus on your obliques.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and instability.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or shoulder impingement should modify the exercise to reduce joint strain, particularly in the shoulders and lower back.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid this exercise due to the risk of abdominal strain and balance challenges.

osteoporosis.details: The exercise involves spinal flexion and rotation, which can increase fracture risk in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute back, shoulder, or abdominal injuries to prevent further damage.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without cables, focusing on bodyweight crunches on the Bosu Ball to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase cable resistance or perform the exercise on a stability ball for added balance challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion and focus on engaging the core without full spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use lighter resistance or perform the exercise with arms crossed over the chest to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the Bosu Ball is stable and properly positioned to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive spinal flexion to reduce the risk of lower back strain.
Maintain control throughout the movement to prevent jerking motions.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Keep your arms straight and aligned with the cable angle.
Perform the movement slowly and with control, focusing on the contraction of the abdominals.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to excessively arch or flatten.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Dropping the arms or bending the elbows during the movement.

name: Bottoms-Up Clean From The Hang Position
instructions: Initiate the exercise by standing upright with a kettlebell in one hand.
Swing the kettlebell back forcefully and then reverse the motion forcefully. Crush the kettlebell handle as hard as possible and raise the kettlebell to your shoulder.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and dynamic nature of the exercise can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Gripping and dynamic wrist movements can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise requires significant shoulder stabilization, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the kettlebell tightly can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The swinging motion and load transfer can strain the lower back, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature and single-arm load can challenge balance, increasing fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter kettlebell or use both hands to stabilize the movement.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid the overhead position, focusing on a partial clean.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps for support or perform the exercise with a dumbbell for a neutral grip.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is of appropriate weight to maintain control throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid jerky movements to reduce the risk of joint injury.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your wrist straight and grip the kettlebell firmly.
Drive through your hips to initiate the upward movement.
commonMistakes: Using too heavy a kettlebell, leading to compromised form.
Allowing the wrist to bend excessively, increasing strain.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in lower back arching.

name: Bottoms Up
instructions: Begin by lying on your back on the ground. Your legs should be straight and your arms at your side. This will be your starting position.

To perform the movement, tuck the knees toward your chest by flexing the hips and knees. Following this, extend your legs directly above you so that they are perpendicular to the ground. Rotate and elevate your pelvis to raise your glutes from the floor.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The spinal flexion and pelvic rotation can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. Flexion of the spine may increase pressure on the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise can increase anterior shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. The movement may irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High severity. Spinal flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Supine position can reduce blood flow and cause discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. The exercise may stress healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with bent knees throughout the movement to reduce the load on the abdominals.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a pelvic tilt instead, focusing on engaging the core without lifting the hips.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep knees slightly bent throughout the movement to reduce strain on the joints.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking movements to prevent unnecessary strain on the spine.
Maintain control throughout the exercise to ensure proper muscle engagement.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Lift your hips using your abdominal muscles, not momentum.
Keep your neck relaxed and avoid tensing your shoulders.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle control to lift the hips.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively during the movement.
Holding breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure.

name: Box Jump (Multiple Response)
instructions: Assume a relaxed stance facing the box or platform approximately an arm's length away. Arms should be down at the sides and legs slightly bent.
Using the arms to aid in the initial burst, jump upward and forward, landing with feet simultaneously on top of the box or platform.
Immediately drop or jump back down to the original starting place; then repeat the sequence.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: high - High-impact landing can exacerbate spinal conditions such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: moderate - Individuals with knee or ankle arthritis or tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce impact.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: moderate - Those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity exercises.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid high-impact exercises to reduce the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: high - Avoid during recovery from lower limb or spinal surgeries until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.chronic_conditions: moderate - Osteoporosis patients should avoid high-impact activities that increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: high - Avoid if experiencing acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the lower extremities.
contraindicationDetails.neurological_conditions: moderate - Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase fall risk; modifications are necessary.

modifications.easier: Step-up onto the box instead of jumping to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase box height or add a weighted vest for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform step-ups or use a lower box to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a lower box and focus on controlled landings to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit arm swing and focus on lower body mechanics.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and on a non-slip surface.
Wear appropriate footwear with good grip.
Warm up thoroughly before performing box jumps.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Use arms to generate upward momentum.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Allowing knees to cave inward upon landing.
Not using arms effectively to aid the jump.

name: Box Skip
instructions: You will need several boxes lined up about 8 feet apart.
Begin facing the first box with one leg slightly behind the other.
Drive off the back leg, attempting to gain as much height with the hips as possible.

Immediately upon landing on the box, drive the other leg forward and upward to gain height and distance, leaping from the box. Land between the first two boxes with the same leg that landed on the first box.
Then, step to the next box and repeat.

spinal_injuries.details: High-impact landings can exacerbate spinal conditions such as herniated discs or sciatica.

joint_issues.details: The impact and force on the knees and ankles can aggravate conditions like arthritis or tendinitis.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: The exercise involves high-intensity movements that may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.details: The risk of falls and abdominal pressure makes this exercise unsuitable during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.details: Individuals recovering from lower limb or spinal surgery should avoid high-impact exercises until cleared by a physician.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls and should be considered before performing this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform step-ups on a lower box, focusing on controlled movements rather than jumping.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the boxes or add a weighted vest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform step-ups with a focus on core engagement and avoid high-impact jumps.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a lower box and focus on landing softly with a slight bend in the knees.

safetyNotes: Ensure boxes are stable and on a non-slip surface.
Wear supportive footwear to absorb impact.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare muscles and joints for explosive movements.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Drive through the heel of the landing foot to propel forward.
commonMistakes: Landing with locked knees, increasing joint stress.
Not using arms to aid in momentum and balance.
Failing to engage the core, leading to poor posture.

name: Box Squat
instructions: The box squat allows you to squat to desired depth and develop explosive strength in the squat movement. Begin in a power rack with a box at the appropriate height behind you. Typically, you would aim for a box height that brings you to a parallel squat, but you can train higher or lower if desired.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wider for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings, or closer together for more quad development. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Pause when you reach the box, and relax the hip flexors. Never bounce off of a box.
Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward off of the box as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and potential for spinal compression.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress, such as using a lower weight or a higher box.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid heavy lifting and may require medical clearance before performing compound exercises.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance changes and increased intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, knees, or hips, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.

osteoporosis.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid exercises with high axial loading to prevent fractures.

modifications.easier: Use a higher box to reduce the range of motion and decrease the load on the knees and lower back.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom position without relaxing on the box to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat and ensure knees do not travel beyond toes.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and at an appropriate height to prevent falls.
Avoid bouncing off the box to reduce stress on the spine and knees.
Maintain a tight core and neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Push your knees out to align with your toes.
Drive through your heels as you stand up.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward.
Rounding the lower back during the descent.
Using momentum to rise from the box.

name: Box Squat with Bands
instructions: Begin in a power rack with a box at the appropriate height behind you. Set up the bands on the sleeves, secured to either band pegs, the rack, or dumbbells so that there is appropriate tension. If dumbbells are used, secure them so that they don't move. Also, ensure that the dumbbells you are using are heavy enough for the bands that you are using. Additional plates can be used to hold the dumbbells down. If more tension is needed, you can either widen the base on the floor or choke the bands. Typically, you would aim for a box height that brings you to a parallel squat, but you can train higher or lower if desired.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wider for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings, or closer together for more quad development. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Pause when you reach the box, and relax the hip flexors. Never bounce off of a box.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward off of the box as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe. Use care to return the barbell to the rack.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and potential for spinal compression.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: People with knee arthritis, hip impingement, or tendinitis should be cautious as the exercise places significant stress on these joints.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: Those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid heavy lifting due to increased cardiovascular strain.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Pregnant individuals, particularly in the second and third trimesters, should avoid due to balance changes and intra-abdominal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Individuals recovering from recent surgeries, especially involving the spine, hips, or knees, should avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.neurological_conditions: Conditions affecting balance or proprioception, such as neuropathy, may increase the risk of falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight box squats or use lighter resistance bands with a lower barbell weight.
modifications.harder: Increase band tension or add additional weight plates to the barbell.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine with a shallower squat depth.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Reduce the range of motion and ensure the shins remain vertical to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Consider using a safety squat bar to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and at an appropriate height to prevent falls.
Secure bands properly to avoid slippage during the exercise.
Avoid bouncing off the box to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged and maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Push your knees outwards to align with your toes during the descent.
Drive through your heels to stand up, leading with your head and chest.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inwards during the squat.
Rounding the lower back, especially when sitting on the box.
Using momentum to bounce off the box rather than controlled movement.

name: Box Squat with Chains
instructions: Begin in a power rack with a box at the appropriate height behind you. Typically, you would aim for a box height that brings you to a parallel squat, but you can train higher or lower if desired.

To set up the chains, begin by looping the leader chain over the sleeves of the bar. The heavy chain should be attached using a snap hook. Adjust the length of the lead chain so that a few links are still on the floor at the top of the movement.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wider for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings, or closer together for more quad development. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Pause when you reach the box, and relax the hip flexors. Never bounce off of a box.
Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward off of the box as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or knee tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce stress on the joints, such as using a higher box or lighter weights.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before attempting due to the high exertion level.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid due to balance and intra-abdominal pressure concerns.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from recent surgeries, particularly in the lower body or spine, should avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are any recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back.

modifications.easier: Perform box squats without chains or with a lighter barbell to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or lower the box height to increase the range of motion and difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a higher box to limit the range of motion and reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Focus on a wider stance to engage more of the posterior chain and reduce knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and at the correct height to prevent falls.
Do not bounce off the box; always pause to maintain control and reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout to prevent lower back injury.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels to engage the posterior chain.
Keep the knees aligned with the toes to prevent valgus collapse.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the ascent.
Bouncing off the box, which can lead to loss of control and increased injury risk.
Rounding the back, especially at the bottom of the squat, increasing spinal injury risk.

name: Brachialis-SMR
instructions: Lie on your side, with your upper arm against the foam roller. The upper arm should be more or less aligned with your body, with the outside of the bicep pressed against the foam roller.
Raise your hips off of the floor, supporting your weight on your arm and on your feet. Hold for 10-30 seconds, and then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The pressure and positioning on the foam roller may exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms due to the arm's positioning and the load on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Individuals with rotator cuff injuries may experience discomfort or aggravation of symptoms due to the pressure and positioning required in this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.acute bicep tendinitis: The direct pressure on the biceps may worsen symptoms in those with acute tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Supporting body weight on the hands can exacerbate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with the hips on the ground to reduce the load on the upper body.
modifications.harder: Add a slight rolling motion back and forth to increase the intensity of the myofascial release.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder issues, perform the exercise with the arm in a more neutral position and reduce pressure by keeping hips on the ground.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive pressure on the biceps to prevent bruising or discomfort.
Ensure the foam roller is positioned correctly to avoid unnecessary strain on the shoulder joint.
formCues: Align the upper arm with the torso to maintain proper posture.
Engage the core to stabilize the body and prevent excessive movement.
Keep the neck in a neutral position to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag, which can reduce effectiveness and increase strain on the shoulder.
Rolling too quickly, which can reduce the effectiveness of the myofascial release.

name: Bradford/Rocky Presses
instructions: Sit on a Military Press Bench with a bar at shoulder level with a pronated grip (palms facing forward). Tip: Your grip should be wider than shoulder width and it should create a 90-degree angle between the forearm and the upper arm as the barbell goes down. This is your starting position.
Once you pick up the barbell with the correct grip, lift the bar up over your head by locking your arms.
Now lower the bar down to the back of the head slowly as you inhale.
Lift the bar back up to the starting position as you exhale.
Lower the bar down to the starting position slowly as you inhale. This is one repetition.
Alternate in this manner until you complete the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High overhead movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise involves significant shoulder rotation and stabilization, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The position of the barbell behind the head can place stress on the cervical spine, especially if mobility is limited.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive lifting and lowering of the barbell can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The load on the spine and shoulders can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter barbell or use a dowel rod to focus on form and mobility.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise standing to engage more core stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a front press only, avoiding the behind-the-head portion to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a supported bench with back support to maintain a neutral spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure a proper warm-up focusing on shoulder mobility and activation.
Avoid excessive weight to maintain control and prevent injury.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid undue stress on the cervical region.
formCues: Grip the barbell wider than shoulder-width to maintain a 90-degree elbow angle.
Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso throughout the movement.
Move the barbell in a controlled manner, avoiding jerky or rapid movements.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to compromised form.
Allowing the barbell to drift too far behind the head, increasing cervical stress.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in an unstable torso.

name: Butt-Ups
instructions: Begin a pushup position but with your elbows on the ground and resting on your forearms. Your arms should be bent at a 90 degree angle.
Arch your back slightly out rather than keeping your back completely straight.

Raise your glutes toward the ceiling, squeezing your abs tightly to close the distance between your ribcage and hips. The end result will be that you'll end up in a high bridge position. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Lower back down slowly to your starting position as you breathe in. Tip: Don't let your back sag downwards.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The flexion and extension movements can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The exercise may increase spinal compression, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise can increase lumbar lordosis, aggravating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The movement may irritate the sciatic nerve; modifications are necessary.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - Spinal flexion can increase fracture risk; modifications required.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: moderate - Weight-bearing on the shoulders may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: low - Pressure on the wrists can be uncomfortable; consider modifications.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - Abdominal pressure and position may be uncomfortable; modifications needed.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with knees on the ground to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with one leg raised to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a plank instead, maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a stability ball under the forearms to reduce shoulder load.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use a rolled towel under the wrists or perform on fists to reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive arching of the back to prevent lumbar strain.
Maintain a neutral neck position to avoid cervical strain.
Ensure a controlled movement to prevent jerking motions.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement.
Squeeze the glutes at the top of the movement.
Keep elbows directly under the shoulders.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to sag, increasing lumbar strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Placing elbows too far forward, increasing shoulder strain.

name: Butt Lift (Bridge)
instructions: Lie flat on the floor on your back with the hands by your side and your knees bent. Your feet should be placed around shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
Pushing mainly with your heels, lift your hips off the floor while keeping your back straight. Breathe out as you perform this part of the motion and hold at the top for a second.
Slowly go back to the starting position as you breathe in.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with these conditions should avoid excessive lumbar extension and may require modifications to reduce spinal load.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip issues should ensure proper alignment and may need to reduce range of motion.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify the exercise to avoid supine positions for extended periods.

surgical_recovery.details: Avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider, as it may stress healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the bridge with a reduced range of motion or with a stability ball under the back for support.
modifications.harder: Add a single-leg variation or place a weight on the pelvis for increased resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the bridge with a smaller range of motion and ensure the spine remains neutral.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Place a cushion under the knees to reduce discomfort and focus on engaging the glutes.

safetyNotes: Avoid hyperextending the lower back at the top of the movement.
Ensure the feet remain flat on the ground throughout the exercise.
formCues: Engage the core to maintain a neutral spine.
Press through the heels to lift the hips.
Squeeze the glutes at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to collapse inward.
Arching the lower back excessively.
Raising the hips too high, causing hyperextension.

name: Butterfly
instructions: Sit on the machine with your back flat on the pad.
Take hold of the handles. Tip: Your upper arms should be positioned parallel to the floor; adjust the machine accordingly. This will be your starting position.
Push the handles together slowly as you squeeze your chest in the middle. Breathe out during this part of the motion and hold the contraction for a second.
Return back to the starting position slowly as you inhale until your chest muscles are fully stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The butterfly exercise involves significant shoulder joint movement, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.

rotator cuff tendinitis.explanation: The exercise can place stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially worsening tendinitis.

pectoralis major tear.explanation: This exercise directly targets the pectoral muscles, which could aggravate a tear.

recent shoulder surgery.explanation: Post-surgical healing requires avoiding stress on the shoulder joint until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight setting on the machine to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort, focusing on a partial movement that does not cause pain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your body size to prevent strain.
Avoid locking elbows at the end of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your back flat against the pad throughout the exercise.
Exhale as you bring the handles together and inhale as you return to the starting position.
Focus on squeezing the chest muscles at the peak of the contraction.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to bring the handles together instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulders to roll forward, which can lead to poor posture and potential injury.
Setting the seat too low or too high, which can misalign the shoulder joint.

name: Cable Chest Press
instructions: Adjust the weight to an appropriate amount and be seated, grasping the handles. Your upper arms should be about 45 degrees to the body, with your head and chest up. The elbows should be bent to about 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending through the elbow, pressing the handles together straight in front of you. Keep your shoulder blades retracted as you execute the movement.
After pausing at full extension, return to th starting position, keeping tension on the cables.
You can also execute this movement with your back off the pad, at an incline or decline, or alternate hands.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to overhead arm position and pressing motion.

rotator cuff tendinitis.explanation: Pressing movements can increase inflammation and pain in the rotator cuff.

chest surgery recovery.explanation: Recent surgery requires complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

severe osteoporosis.explanation: Risk of fractures due to potential falls or improper form.

acute shoulder or chest injuries.explanation: Performing this exercise can worsen acute injuries.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip and reduce the range of motion.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Ensure proper back support by using a bench with adequate lumbar support.

safetyNotes: Always warm up before performing the exercise to prevent injury.
Ensure the cable machine is properly adjusted to your height and body mechanics.
formCues: Keep your shoulder blades retracted throughout the movement.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows at the end of the pressing motion.
Avoid locking out the elbows to reduce joint stress.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to round forward during the press.
Using too much weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.
Failing to maintain a stable core, leading to excessive back arching.

name: Cable Crossover
instructions: To get yourself into the starting position, place the pulleys on a high position (above your head), select the resistance to be used and hold the pulleys in each hand.

Step forward in front of an imaginary straight line between both pulleys while pulling your arms together in front of you. Your torso should have a small forward bend from the waist. This will be your starting position.

With a slight bend on your elbows in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon, extend your arms to the side (straight out at both sides) in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, the arms and torso should remain stationary; the movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.
Return your arms back to the starting position as you breathe out. Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Hold for a second at the starting position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pulley position and arm movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves shoulder abduction and internal rotation, which can stress inflamed tendons.
contraindicationDetails.chest surgery recovery: Recent surgery can make the chest area vulnerable to strain and injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The forward bend and weight resistance can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or chest injuries: Any recent injury to the shoulder or chest may be aggravated by the movement and resistance.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Forward bending can exacerbate symptoms by increasing spinal canal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The forward lean may increase lumbar spine stress, worsening the condition.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance or perform the exercise on a stability ball to engage core muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, avoiding full extension.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is properly adjusted and secure before starting.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form and increases injury risk.
Maintain a controlled movement throughout the exercise to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows to protect the biceps tendon.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso and prevent excessive forward lean.
Focus on a smooth, controlled arc motion at the shoulder joint.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the arms instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the torso to sway or lean excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Locking the elbows during the movement, increasing stress on the joints.

name: Cable Crunch
instructions: Kneel below a high pulley that contains a rope attachment.
Grasp cable rope attachment and lower the rope until your hands are placed next to your face.
Flex your hips slightly and allow the weight to hyperextend the lower back. This will be your starting position.

With the hips stationary, flex the waist as you contract the abs so that the elbows travel towards the middle of the thighs. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement and hold the contraction for a second.

Slowly return to the starting position as you inhale. Tip: Make sure that you keep constant tension on the abs throughout the movement. Also, do not choose a weight so heavy that the lower back handles the brunt of the work.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to increased spinal flexion and potential for exacerbating symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Those with lumbar arthritis or lower back impingement may need modifications to reduce stress on the spine.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid exercises that involve significant spinal flexion and pressure on the abdomen.

osteoporosis.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of vertebral fractures from spinal flexion.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the back or core muscles.

modifications.easier: Perform a basic crunch on a mat without added resistance to reduce load on the spine.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a Bosu ball for added challenge.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a stability ball for support under the lower back to reduce spinal load and maintain a neutral spine.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight that causes strain on the lower back.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive flexion to protect the vertebrae.
formCues: Keep the hips stationary throughout the movement.
Focus on contracting the abs rather than pulling with the arms.
Exhale as you crunch forward and inhale as you return to the start.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the lower back to hyperextend excessively.
Pulling with the arms instead of engaging the core.

name: Cable Deadlifts
instructions: Move the cables to the bottom of the towers and select an appropriate weight. Stand directly in between the uprights.
To begin, squat down be flexing your hips and knees until you can reach the handles.
After grasping them, begin your ascent. Driving through your heels extend your hips and knees keeping your hands hanging at your side. Keep your head and chest up throughout the movement.
After reaching a full standing position, Return to the starting position and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The forward bending and load on the spine can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. The exercise may increase spinal compression and worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise can increase lumbar spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Moderate severity. Squatting motion may aggravate symptoms; modifications needed.
contraindicationDetails.hip osteoarthritis: Moderate severity. Hip flexion and load may increase discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Moderate severity. Isometric contraction and heavy lifting can elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Moderate severity. Risk of falls; modifications needed for stability.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the movement with a resistance band.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform single-leg cable deadlifts for added challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral spine and reduce the range of motion.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit knee flexion and focus on hip hinge movement.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Ensure the shoulders are relaxed and avoid excessive shrugging.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid rounding the lower back to prevent injury.
Ensure the weight is appropriate to avoid excessive strain.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Drive through your heels during the ascent.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Allowing the knees to cave inward.

name: Cable Hammer Curls - Rope Attachment
instructions: Attach a rope attachment to a low pulley and stand facing the machine about 12 inches away from it.
Grasp the rope with a neutral (palms-in) grip and stand straight up keeping the natural arch of the back and your torso stationary.
Put your elbows in by your side and keep them there stationary during the entire movement. Tip: Only the forearms should move; not your upper arms. This will be your starting position.
Using your biceps, pull your arms up as you exhale until your biceps touch your forearms. Tip: Remember to keep the elbows in and your upper arms stationary.
After a 1 second contraction where you squeeze your biceps, slowly start to bring the weight back to the original position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive flexion and gripping can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis in the elbow.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Keeping the elbows close to the body might still cause discomfort if shoulder impingement is present.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The grip required can increase pressure on the median nerve, potentially worsening symptoms.

severe hypertension.explanation: Isometric holds and the Valsalva maneuver during exertion can dangerously elevate blood pressure.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the elbows and shoulders.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid excessive strain on the forearm and wrist.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked to your sides throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid leaning back.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum by swinging the body.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on controlled movements to minimize stress on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce shoulder strain.

name: Cable Hip Adduction
instructions: Stand in front of a low pulley facing forward with one leg next to the pulley and the other one away.
Attach the ankle cuff to the cable and also to the ankle of the leg that is next to the pulley.
Now step out and away from the stack with a wide stance and grasp the bar of the pulley system.
Stand on the foot that does not have the ankle cuff (the far foot) and allow the leg with the cuff to be pulled towards the low pulley. This will be your starting position.
Now perform the movement by moving the leg with the ankle cuff in front of the far leg by using the inner thighs to abduct the hip. Breathe out during this portion of the movement.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then repeat the same movement with the opposite leg.

contraindicationDetails.hip osteoarthritis: Moderate to severe hip osteoarthritis may be aggravated by the adduction movement, increasing joint stress.
contraindicationDetails.groin strain: Performing hip adduction can exacerbate a groin strain due to the involvement of the adductor muscles.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Individuals with knee osteoarthritis may experience discomfort due to the stabilizing demands placed on the knee joint.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: This exercise requires balance and stability, which may be challenging for individuals with balance disorders, increasing fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform seated hip adduction using a machine to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad to challenge stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight and ensure a neutral spine to minimize spinal stress.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit range of motion and focus on controlled movements to reduce knee joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the ankle cuff is securely fastened to prevent slipping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form or balance.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain stability.
Move slowly and with control, especially when returning to the starting position.
Avoid locking the knee of the standing leg to reduce joint stress.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the leg instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the torso to lean excessively, compromising balance.
Not maintaining a neutral spine, leading to potential back strain.

name: Cable Incline Pushdown
instructions: Lie on incline an bench facing away from a high pulley machine that has a straight bar attachment on it.

Grasp the straight bar attachment overhead with a pronated (overhand; palms down) shoulder width grip and extend your arms in front of you. The bar should be around 2 inches away from your upper thighs. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the upper arms stationary, lift your arms back in a semi circle until the bar is straight over your head. Breathe in during this portion of the movement.
Slowly go back to the starting position using your lats and hold the contraction once you reach the starting position. Breathe out during the execution of this movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and shoulder movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves shoulder movement that can irritate the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The position may place strain on the cervical spine, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The head-down position can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which may not be suitable post-surgery.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm variation to increase the challenge and engage core stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a seated position with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back during the movement.
Maintain controlled movements to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Do not lock your elbows at the bottom of the movement.
Focus on using your lats to control the movement, not your arms.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug upwards during the movement.
Hyperextending the neck or lower back.

name: Cable Incline Triceps Extension
instructions: Lie on incline an bench facing away from a high pulley machine that has a straight bar attachment on it.

Grasp the straight bar attachment overhead with a pronated (overhand; palms down) narrow grip (less than shoulder width) and keep your elbows tucked in to your sides. Your upper arms should create around a 25 degree angle when measured from the floor.
Keeping the upper arms stationary, extend the arms as you flex the triceps. Breathe out during this portion of the movement and hold the contraction for a second.
Slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and extension of the arms could exacerbate symptoms due to compression of shoulder structures.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension motion can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Lying on an incline bench may increase lumbar lordosis, potentially worsening lower back pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The position on the incline bench may strain the cervical spine, particularly if the head is not supported properly.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform triceps pushdowns with a rope attachment to minimize shoulder involvement.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip with a rope attachment to reduce stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is set at a stable incline to prevent slipping.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine position to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked close to the body throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the triceps at the top of the extension.
Control the weight as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, reducing triceps activation.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Arching the back excessively, leading to potential lower back strain.

name: Cable Internal Rotation
instructions: Sit next to a low pulley sideways (with legs stretched in front of you or crossed) and grasp the single hand cable attachment with the arm nearest to the cable. Tip: If you can adjust the pulley's height, you can use a flat bench to sit on instead.
Position the elbow against your side with the elbow bent at 90° and the arm pointing towards the pulley. This will be your starting position.

Pull the single hand cable attachment toward your body by internally rotating your shoulder until your forearm is across your abs. You will be creating an imaginary semi-circle. Tip: The forearm should be perpendicular to your torso at all times.
Slowly go back to the initial position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then repeat the movement with the next arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The internal rotation movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms by further compressing the structures within the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: This exercise can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening a tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: The rotational movement can aggravate symptoms in individuals with advanced osteoarthritis in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Sitting posture and shoulder movement may exacerbate cervical spine conditions due to tension and poor alignment.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder bursitis: The exercise may increase inflammation and pain in the shoulder bursa.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band instead of a cable to reduce the load and allow for more controlled movement.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizing muscles and increase core activation.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with a towel or no weight to focus on the range of motion and reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is set at an appropriate height to maintain proper elbow alignment.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent undue stress on the shoulder joint.
formCues: Keep your elbow tucked close to your body throughout the movement.
Maintain a 90-degree angle at the elbow to ensure proper form.
Control the movement, especially when returning to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to improper form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the elbow to drift away from the body, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.
Failing to control the eccentric (return) phase of the movement.

name: Cable Iron Cross
instructions: Begin by moving the pulleys to the high position, select the resistance to be used, and take a handle in each hand.
Stand directly between both pulleys with your arms extended out to your sides. Your head and chest should be up while your arms form a "T". This will be your starting position.
Keeping the elbows extended, pull your arms straight to your sides.
Return your arms back to the starting position after a pause at the peak contraction.
Continue the movement for the prescribed number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and arm movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves significant shoulder joint movement, which can irritate inflamed tendons.
contraindicationDetails.chest surgery recovery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the stretch and contraction involved in this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The exercise involves a wide range of motion and potential for falls, which can be risky for individuals with fragile bones.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or chest injuries: Any recent trauma to the shoulder or chest area can be aggravated by the movement and load of this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a stability ball to engage core muscles more.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, avoiding the end range where pain occurs.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure a neutral spine and engage core muscles to support the lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is properly set up and the weights are secure.
Do not hyperextend the elbows during the movement.
Maintain a stable stance to prevent loss of balance.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to lock out completely.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the lower back.

name: Cable Judo Flip
instructions: Connect a rope attachment to a tower, and move the cable to the lowest pulley position. Stand with your side to the cable with a wide stance, and grab the rope with both hands.
Twist your body away from the pulley as you bring the rope over your shoulder like you're performing a judo flip.
Shift your weight between your feet as you twist and crunch forward, pulling the cable downward.
Return to the starting position and repeat until failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the rotational and compressive forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: Those with shoulder impingement or tendinitis may experience discomfort due to the overhead and rotational movement.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises involving twisting and heavy abdominal engagement.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The rotational and bending movements could increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Recent sprains or strains, particularly in the back or shoulders, may be exacerbated by this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should be cautious due to the potential for increased blood pressure during exertion.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable for less resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable or perform the exercise on a single leg to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid excessive twisting. Focus on core engagement without full rotation.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with arms closer to the body to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached before starting.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Do not use momentum to pull the cable; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Keep your knees slightly bent and feet grounded.
Twist through the torso, not just the arms, to engage the core effectively.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the back to round excessively during the twist.
Neglecting to engage the core, resulting in over-reliance on the arms.

name: Cable Lying Triceps Extension
instructions: Lie on a flat bench and grasp the straight bar attachment of a low pulley with a narrow overhand grip. Tip: The easiest way to do this is to have someone hand you the bar as you lay down.
With your arms extended, position the bar over your torso. Your arms and your torso should create a 90-degree angle. This will be your starting position.

Lower the bar by bending at the elbow while keeping the upper arms stationary and elbows in. Go down until the bar lightly touches your forehead. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Flex the triceps as you lift the bar back to its starting position. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise involves significant elbow flexion and extension, which can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position and movement may cause discomfort or further impingement in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.acute cervical spine issues: Lying on a bench with neck extension can aggravate cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding stress on the elbow joint until cleared by a medical professional.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The supine position and potential for dropping the bar pose a risk for fractures in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load on the triceps.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase the challenge and engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform triceps pushdowns using a rope attachment to minimize shoulder involvement.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a resistance band for a smoother range of motion and less joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before beginning the exercise.
Have a spotter assist with handing the bar to avoid unnecessary strain.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in and stationary throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, reducing triceps activation.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively, which can strain the lumbar spine.

name: Cable One Arm Tricep Extension
instructions: With your right hand, grasp a single handle attached to the high-cable pulley using a supinated (underhand; palms facing up) grip. You should be standing directly in front of the weight stack.

Now pull the handle down so that your upper arm and elbow are locked in to the side of your body. Your upper arm and forearm should form an acute angle (less than 90-degrees). You can keep the other arm by the waist and you can have one leg in front of you and the other one back for better balance. This will be your starting position.

As you contract the triceps, move the single handle attachment down to your side until your arm is straight. Breathe out as you perform this movement. Tip: Only the forearms should move. Your upper arms should remain stationary at all times.
Squeeze the triceps and hold for a second in this contracted position.
Slowly return the handle to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform the same movement with the other arm.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension movement can exacerbate inflammation and pain in the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Maintaining a stable shoulder position is crucial, and any impingement can lead to discomfort or injury.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Standing posture and potential for improper form can increase lumbar strain.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow surgery: Post-surgical tissues need time to heal, and this exercise can stress the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is higher, especially with the potential for sudden movements or loss of balance.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load on the triceps.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slower tempo or add an isometric hold at the bottom of the extension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip (hammer grip) to minimize stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable pulley is securely attached and functioning properly.
Maintain a stable stance to avoid losing balance during the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbow at the bottom of the movement to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep the elbow close to the body throughout the exercise.
Focus on moving only the forearm while keeping the upper arm stationary.
Exhale during the extension phase and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum or swinging the arm to complete the movement.
Allowing the elbow to drift away from the body.
Overextending the elbow joint at the end of the movement.

name: Cable Preacher Curl
instructions: Place a preacher bench about 2 feet in front of a pulley machine.
Attach a straight bar to the low pulley.
Sit at the preacher bench with your elbow and upper arms firmly on top of the bench pad and have someone hand you the bar from the low pulley.
Grab the bar and fully extend your arms on top of the preacher bench pad. This will be your starting position.
Now start pilling the weight up towards your shoulders and squeeze the biceps hard at the top of the movement. Exhale as you perform this motion. Also, hold for a second at the top.
Now slowly lower the weight to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms and potential for shoulder elevation can aggravate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the bar can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: Isometric contractions and breath-holding during exertion can elevate blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip using a rope attachment to reduce stress on the elbow.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Ensure the shoulder is not elevated during the exercise and consider reducing the range of motion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the preacher bench is stable and secure before beginning the exercise.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the bottom of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your upper arms firmly against the pad throughout the movement.
Exhale as you curl the weight up and inhale as you lower it back down.
Focus on controlled movements to maximize muscle engagement and minimize injury risk.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulders to elevate, which can lead to impingement.
Not fully extending the arms, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.

name: Cable Rear Delt Fly
instructions: Adjust the pulleys to the appropriate height and adjust the weight. The pulleys should be above your head.
Grab the left pulley with your right hand and the right pulley with your left hand, crossing them in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by moving your arms back and outward, keeping your arms straight as you execute the movement.
Pause at the end of the motion before returning the handles to the start position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to the overhead and abduction movement pattern.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: May increase strain on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening the tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Can cause discomfort and further joint degradation due to repetitive shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The exercise may place stress on the cervical spine, aggravating existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Isometric contraction and overhead arm position can increase blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with resistance bands instead of cables to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise in a staggered stance to challenge stability.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion or use a lighter weight.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the pulley height is correctly adjusted to prevent shoulder strain.
Start with a lighter weight to master the form before increasing resistance.
Avoid locking the elbows to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together at the end of the motion.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the weights instead of controlled movements.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug, which can lead to neck strain.
Not maintaining a neutral spine, leading to potential back discomfort.

name: Cable Reverse Crunch
instructions: Connect an ankle strap attachment to a low pulley cable and position a mat on the floor in front of it.
Sit down with your feet toward the pulley and attach the cable to your ankles.
Lie down, elevate your legs and bend your knees at a 90-degree angle. Your legs and the cable should be aligned. If not, adjust the pulley up or down until they are.
With your hands behind your head, bring your knees inward to your torso and elevate your hips off the floor.
Pause for a moment and in a slow and controlled manner drop your hips and bring your legs back to the starting 90-degree angle. You should still have tension on your abs in the resting position.
Repeat the same movement to failure.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and instability.

joint_issues.details: Those with hip or knee arthritis should modify the exercise to reduce joint strain.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to the risk of abdominal strain and supine positioning.

osteoporosis.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of vertebral fractures from spinal flexion.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are any recent abdominal, hip, or lower back injuries to prevent further damage.

modifications.easier: Perform the reverse crunch without the cable resistance to focus on form and control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase difficulty.
modifications.injury_friendly: For lower back discomfort, perform a reverse crunch on a stability ball to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable pulley is properly adjusted to align with your legs.
Avoid jerking motions to prevent unnecessary strain on the lower back.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement.
Lift your hips by contracting your abdominals, not by swinging your legs.
Keep your head and neck relaxed with your hands behind your head.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively during the movement.
Not maintaining tension in the abdominals throughout the exercise.

name: Cable Rope Overhead Triceps Extension
instructions: Attach a rope to the bottom pulley of the pulley machine.

Grasping the rope with both hands, extend your arms with your hands directly above your head using a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Your elbows should be in close to your head and the arms should be perpendicular to the floor with the knuckles aimed at the ceiling. This will be your starting position.
Slowly lower the rope behind your head as you hold the upper arms stationary. Inhale as you perform this movement and pause when your triceps are fully stretched.
Return to the starting position by flexing your triceps as you breathe out.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position may exacerbate symptoms due to compression of structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive extension can aggravate tendinitis, particularly if performed with poor form or excessive weight.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The standing position requires core stabilization, which can strain the lower back if not properly engaged.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The overhead position can place stress on the cervical spine, particularly if the head is not aligned correctly.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The overhead position and potential for poor balance can increase the risk of falls or fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the demand on core stabilizers and improve balance.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm variation to increase the challenge on the triceps and core stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a triceps pushdown instead to avoid overhead positioning.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on a smaller range of motion to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the rope is securely attached to the pulley to prevent accidents.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows close to your head and stationary throughout the movement.
Engage your core to maintain a stable trunk.
Exhale as you extend your arms and inhale as you lower the rope.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing triceps engagement.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.

name: Cable Rope Rear-Delt Rows
instructions: Sit in the same position on a low pulley row station as you would if you were doing seated cable rows for the back.
Attach a rope to the pulley and grasp it with an overhand grip. Your arms should be extended and parallel to the floor with the elbows flared out.
Keep your lower back upright and slide your hips back so that your knees are slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Pull the cable attachment towards your upper chest, just below the neck, as you keep your elbows up and out to the sides. Continue this motion as you exhale until the elbows travel slightly behind the back. Tip: Keep your upper arms horizontal, perpendicular to the torso and parallel to the floor throughout the motion.
Go back to the initial position where the arms are extended and the shoulders are stretched forward. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to the overhead and abducted arm position.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: Pulling motion can strain the rotator cuff, especially if not fully healed.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint stress may aggravate pain and inflammation in the shoulder or cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Positioning and pulling force can increase cervical spine stress, potentially worsening conditions like stenosis or herniated discs.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Isometric tension and Valsalva maneuver can increase blood pressure, posing risks.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip and reduce the range of motion to avoid pain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a back support or perform the exercise standing with a slight forward lean to reduce lumbar stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is set at the appropriate height to avoid awkward pulling angles.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent compromising form and increasing injury risk.
Maintain control throughout the movement to prevent jerking motions.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together at the peak of the movement.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which can lead to spinal strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to drop below shoulder level, reducing effectiveness.

name: Cable Russian Twists
instructions: Connect a standard handle attachment, and position the cable to a middle pulley position.
Lie on a stability ball perpendicular to the cable and grab the handle with one hand. You should be approximately arm's length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable.
Grab the handle with both hands and fully extend your arms above your chest. You hands should be directly in-line with the pulley. If not, adjust the pulley up or down until they are.
Keep your hips elevated and abs engaged. Rotate your torso away from the pulley for a full-quarter rotation. Your body should be flat from head to knees.
Pause for a moment and in a slow and controlled manner reset to the starting position. You should still have side tension on the cable in the resting position.
Repeat the same movement to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the rotational forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or shoulder impingement should modify the exercise to reduce joint strain.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve lying on the back and rotational forces.

osteoporosis.details: This exercise can place excessive stress on the spine, increasing fracture risk in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent trauma or sprains, particularly in the back or shoulders.
