cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing exercises with significant core engagement.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the cable, using a medicine ball for resistance to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable or perform the exercise on a decline bench for added difficulty.
modifications.injury_friendly: For back pain, perform seated cable twists on a bench to minimize spinal loading. For shoulder pain, reduce the range of motion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached and the equipment is in good condition.
Avoid excessive rotation to prevent spinal strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Engage your core before starting the movement.
Keep your arms fully extended and in line with the cable pulley.
Rotate through the torso, not the arms.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the hips to drop during the exercise.
Rotating beyond a comfortable range of motion.

name: Cable Seated Crunch
instructions: Seat on a flat bench with your back facing a high pulley.

Grasp the cable rope attachment with both hands (with the palms of the hands facing each other) and place your hands securely over both shoulders. Tip: Allow the weight to hyperextend the lower back slightly. This will be your starting position.
With the hips stationary, flex the waist so the elbows travel toward the hips. Breathe out as you perform this step.
As you inhale, go back to the initial position slowly.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the flexion and load on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or lumbar joint issues should modify or avoid this exercise to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to the pressure on the abdomen and spine.

osteoporosis.details: The spinal flexion involved can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute back pain or recent trauma to the spine or abdomen.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights, focusing on bodyweight crunches to reduce load on the spine.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a Bosu ball to engage more stabilizer muscles.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with lower back pain, perform a standing cable crunch to reduce spinal flexion and pressure.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached before starting.
Do not use excessive weight that forces poor form.
Avoid jerky movements; maintain control throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Avoid pulling with your arms; focus on using your abdominals.
Maintain a neutral spine as much as possible.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Allowing the lower back to excessively hyperextend.
Pulling with the arms instead of engaging the core.

name: Cable Seated Lateral Raise
instructions: Stand in the middle of two low pulleys that are opposite to each other and place a flat bench right behind you (in perpendicular fashion to you; the narrow edge of the bench should be the one behind you). Select the weight to be used on each pulley.
Now sit at the edge of the flat bench behind you with your feet placed in front of your knees.
Bend forward while keeping your back flat and rest your torso on the thighs.

Have someone give you the single handles attached to the pulleys. Grasp the left pulley with the right hand and the right pulley with the left after you select your weight. The pulleys should run under your knees and your arms will be extended with palms facing each other and a slight bend at the elbows. This will be the starting position.

While keeping the arms stationary, raise the upper arms to the sides until they are parallel to the floor and at shoulder height. Exhale during the execution of this movement and hold the contraction for a second.
Slowly lower your arms to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions. Tip: Maintain upper arms perpendicular to torso and a fixed elbow position (10 degree to 30 degree angle) throughout exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead and lateral arm movement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: Increased stress on the shoulder joint can worsen the tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint stress from the exercise may aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Forward bending posture may increase cervical spine strain.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Isometric holds and exertion may elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Forward bending position can increase disc pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Forward flexion may exacerbate vertebral slippage.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter resistance bands instead of cables.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion or use a lighter weight.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise standing with a neutral spine to reduce lower back strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable to prevent tipping.
Avoid excessive weight to maintain control and prevent injury.
Do not lock elbows; keep a slight bend to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your back flat and chest up while bending forward.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Lift with your shoulders, not your arms, to target the deltoids.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled motion.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug during the lift.
Not maintaining a flat back, leading to potential lower back strain.

name: Cable Shoulder Press
instructions: Move the cables to the bottom of the towers and select an appropriate weight.
Stand directly in between the uprights. Grasp the cables and hold them at shoulder height, palms facing forward. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your head and chest up, extend through the elbow to press the handles directly over head.
After pausing at the top, return to the starting position and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead motion.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: Overhead pressing can increase strain on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint loading in the shoulder may cause pain and further joint degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Overhead movements can place stress on the cervical spine, aggravating conditions like stenosis or disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Overhead pressing can elevate blood pressure further, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the load and range of motion required for this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder bursitis: Inflammation of the bursa can be aggravated by overhead pressing.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce core stabilization demands.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm cable shoulder press to increase core engagement and balance challenge.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress. Limit range of motion to avoid pain.

safetyNotes: Ensure cables are securely attached and weight is appropriate for your strength level.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the press to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Press the handles directly overhead, not in front or behind the body.
Control the movement on the way down to prevent shoulder strain.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Arching the lower back excessively during the press.
Allowing the elbows to flare out too much, increasing shoulder joint stress.

name: Cable Shrugs
instructions: Grasp a cable bar attachment that is attached to a low pulley with a shoulder width or slightly wider overhand (palms facing down) grip.
Stand erect close to the pulley with your arms extended in front of you holding the bar. This will be your starting position.

Lift the bar by elevating the shoulders as high as possible as you exhale. Hold the contraction at the top for a second. Tip: The arms should remain extended at all times. Refrain from using the biceps to help lift the bar. Only the shoulders should be moving up and down.
Lower the bar back to the original position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity. Elevating the shoulders can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Moderate severity. Individuals with cervical spine conditions such as herniated discs or stenosis should avoid excessive loading and neck strain.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Moderate severity. The exercise may place additional stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.acute neck pain: High severity. Shrugging can increase tension in the neck muscles, potentially aggravating pain.

modifications.easier: Perform shrugs with lighter resistance bands instead of cables to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm cable shrug to increase the challenge on each side individually, enhancing unilateral strength and stability.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder pain, perform shrugs with dumbbells while seated to minimize shoulder joint strain and stabilize the movement.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid unnecessary strain on the lower back.
Avoid jerking the shoulders up; the movement should be controlled and smooth.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back to ensure proper posture.
Focus on lifting with the traps, not the arms, to isolate the target muscle.
commonMistakes: Using the arms to lift the weight instead of the shoulders.
Allowing the head to jut forward, which can strain the neck.

name: Cable Wrist Curl
instructions: Start out by placing a flat bench in front of a low pulley cable that has a straight bar attachment.

Use your arms to grab the cable bar with a narrow to shoulder width supinated grip (palms up) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the top of your thighs. Your wrists should be hanging just beyond your knees.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling. Keep the contraction for a second.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
contraindications: severe arthritis in the wrist or elbow

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The wrist flexion involved in this exercise can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the median nerve.

wrist tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive wrist flexion can aggravate inflammation and worsen the condition.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The exercise may place additional strain on the elbow tendons, requiring modification or avoidance.

severe arthritis in the wrist or elbow.explanation: The exercise can increase joint stress and pain in individuals with severe arthritis.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load on the wrists.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a thicker grip bar to increase forearm activation.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist curls with a dumbbell, allowing for more controlled movement and reduced strain on the wrist.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the wrist and forearm muscles.
Ensure the bench height allows your forearms to rest comfortably on your thighs.
formCues: Keep your forearms stationary and only move your wrists.
Exhale as you curl your wrists upwards and inhale as you lower them back down.
Maintain a neutral spine and seated posture throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled wrist movement.
Allowing the elbows to lift off the thighs, reducing isolation of the forearm muscles.
Overextending the wrists at the top of the movement, which can lead to strain.

name: Calf-Machine Shoulder Shrug
instructions: Position yourself on the calf machine so that the shoulder pads are above your shoulders. Your torso should be straight with the arms extended normally by your side. This will be your starting position.
Raise your shoulders up towards your ears as you exhale and hold the contraction for a full second.
Slowly return to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with spinal injuries such as herniated discs or stenosis should avoid this exercise due to the axial load on the spine, which can exacerbate symptoms.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: The upward movement of the shoulders can aggravate impingement symptoms. Modifications or alternative exercises should be considered.

hypertension.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver, often inadvertently performed during this exercise, can increase blood pressure. Controlled breathing and monitoring are advised.

modifications.easier: Perform shoulder shrugs with dumbbells or resistance bands to reduce load and allow for greater control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the calf machine or perform the exercise with a pause at the top for increased time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with back pain, perform seated shrugs with dumbbells to reduce spinal load. Ensure proper lumbar support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height to avoid excessive strain on the neck and shoulders.
Avoid using excessive weight, which can lead to poor form and increased risk of injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Lift your shoulders straight up towards your ears without rolling them forward or backward.
Control the movement both on the way up and down to maximize muscle engagement and safety.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulders to roll forward, which can lead to shoulder impingement.
Holding the breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure and blood pressure.

name: Calf Press
instructions: Adjust the seat so that your legs are only slightly bent in the start position. The balls of your feet should be firmly on the platform.
Select an appropriate weight, and grasp the handles. This will be your starting position.

Straighten the legs by extending the knees, just barely lifting the weight from the stack. Your ankle should be fully flexed, toes pointing up. Execute the movement by pressing downward through the balls of your feet as far as possible.
After a brief pause, reverse the motion and repeat.

Achilles tendinitis.explanation: The calf press can exacerbate inflammation in the Achilles tendon due to repetitive loading and stretching.

Plantar fasciitis.explanation: Excessive pressure on the plantar fascia during the push phase can worsen symptoms.

Recent ankle sprain.explanation: The exercise places stress on the ankle joint, which may impede healing.

Severe osteoarthritis in the ankle.explanation: Increased joint loading can lead to further cartilage degradation and pain.

Peripheral neuropathy.explanation: Reduced sensation in the feet can lead to improper form and increased risk of injury.

modifications.easier: Perform seated calf raises with no added weight to focus on form and control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform single-leg calf presses to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.Achilles tendinitis: Perform calf stretches and use a lighter weight with a reduced range of motion.
injury_friendly.Plantar fasciitis: Use a cushioned platform to reduce pressure on the plantar fascia.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat is adjusted properly to avoid hyperextension of the knees.
Do not lock the knees at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Maintain control throughout the movement to avoid sudden jerks.
formCues: Keep the balls of your feet firmly on the platform.
Press through the balls of your feet, not your toes.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Allowing the heels to lift off the platform.
Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Bouncing at the bottom of the movement instead of controlling the descent.

name: Calf Press On The Leg Press Machine
instructions: Using a leg press machine, sit down on the machine and place your legs on the platform directly in front of you at a medium (shoulder width) foot stance.

Lower the safety bars holding the weighted platform in place and press the platform all the way up until your legs are fully extended in front of you without locking your knees. (Note: In some leg press units you can leave the safety bars on for increased safety. If your leg press unit allows for this, then this is the preferred method of performing the exercise.) Your torso and the legs should make perfect 90-degree angle. Now carefully place your toes and balls of your feet on the lower portion of the platform with the heels extending off. Toes should be facing forward, outwards or inwards as described at the beginning of the chapter. This will be your starting position.

Press on the platform by raising your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending at any time. Hold the contracted position by a second before you start to go back down.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering your heels as you bend the ankles until calves are stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: High stress on the Achilles tendon during calf press can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.Plantar fasciitis: Pressure on the forefoot can aggravate plantar fascia inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.Recent ankle sprain: The exercise involves significant ankle movement, which can hinder recovery.
contraindicationDetails.Severe osteoarthritis in the ankle: Joint compression and movement may increase pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.Peripheral neuropathy: Reduced sensation can impair balance and increase injury risk.
contraindicationDetails.Sciatica: Seated position and leg press can increase lumbar spine pressure.
contraindicationDetails.Severe hypertension: Isometric holds and high exertion may elevate blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform seated calf raises with a lighter weight or resistance band.
modifications.harder: Use a single leg for the calf press to increase difficulty and balance challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Ensure lumbar support is adjusted properly and avoid excessive weight.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit range of motion to avoid knee discomfort and use lighter weights.
injury_friendly.ankle_pain: Perform seated calf raises with minimal weight to reduce ankle stress.

safetyNotes: Always warm up before performing calf exercises to prevent strains.
Ensure the leg press machine is properly adjusted to your body size.
Do not lock your knees at the top of the movement to avoid joint stress.
formCues: Keep your knees slightly bent to avoid locking them.
Focus on controlled movements, both upward and downward.
Maintain a neutral spine with the back fully supported by the seat.
commonMistakes: Locking the knees at full extension.
Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Bouncing at the bottom of the movement instead of controlled lowering.

name: Calf Raise On A Dumbbell
instructions: Hang on to a sturdy object for balance and stand on a dumbbell handle, preferably one with round plates so that it rolls as in this manner you have to work harder to stabilize yourself; thus increasing the effectiveness of the exercise.
Now roll your foot slightly forward so that you can get a nice stretch of the calf. This will be your starting position.

Lift the calf as you roll your foot over the top of the handle so that you get a full extension. Exhale during the execution of this movement. Contract the calf hard at the top and hold for a second. Tip: As you come up, roll the dumbbell slightly backward.
Now inhale as you roll the dumbbell slightly forward as you come down to get a better stretch.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: High risk of further injury due to the unstable surface of the dumbbell.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Increased risk of falls and injury due to the need for balance on a rolling surface.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle or foot surgery: Risk of compromising surgical recovery and healing.
contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: Exacerbation of symptoms due to excessive strain on the tendon.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: Potential to worsen pain and inflammation in the plantar fascia.

modifications.easier: Perform calf raises on a flat, stable surface such as the floor or a step.
modifications.harder: Perform single-leg calf raises on the dumbbell for increased difficulty.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a calf raise machine or perform seated calf raises to reduce load on the ankle and foot.

safetyNotes: Ensure the dumbbell is stable and does not roll excessively.
Use a sturdy support for balance, such as a wall or rail.
Avoid excessive rolling of the foot to prevent ankle strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Avoid locking your knees; keep them slightly bent.
Focus on a controlled movement, both up and down.
commonMistakes: Allowing the dumbbell to roll too much, leading to loss of balance.
Using momentum instead of muscle control.
Not fully extending the ankle at the top of the movement.

name: Calf Raises - With Bands
instructions: Grab an exercise band and stand on it with your toes making sure that the length of the band between the foot and the arms is the same for both sides.

While holding the handles of the band, raise the arms to the side of your head as if you were getting ready to perform a shoulder press. The palms should be facing forward with the elbows bent and to the sides. This movement will create tension on the band. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the hands by your shoulder, stand up on your toes as you exhale and contract the calves hard at the top of the movement.
After a one second contraction, slowly go back down to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: High severity. The exercise places stress on the Achilles tendon, which can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.Plantar fasciitis: Moderate severity. The exercise can increase tension on the plantar fascia, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.Ankle instability: High severity. The exercise requires stable ankle support, and instability can lead to injury.
contraindicationDetails.Balance disorders: Moderate severity. Standing on toes requires good balance, and those with balance disorders may be at risk of falling.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the band to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on a single leg to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.ankle_pain: Perform seated calf raises using a resistance band to minimize ankle stress.
injury_friendly.balance_issues: Hold onto a stable surface or perform seated variations.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely placed under the feet to prevent slipping.
Avoid locking the knees to maintain joint safety.
Perform the exercise on a non-slip surface to prevent falls.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain balance.
Lift through the toes, not the heels, to target the calves effectively.
Maintain a controlled pace, especially on the descent.
commonMistakes: Allowing the heels to drop too quickly, which can reduce muscle engagement.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Not maintaining equal tension on both sides of the band.

name: Calf Stretch Elbows Against Wall
instructions: Stand facing a wall from a couple feet away.
Lean against the wall, placing your weight on your forearms.
Attempt to keep your heels on the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds. You may move further or closer the wall, making it more or less difficult, respectively.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: Stretching the calf muscles can exacerbate symptoms by placing additional strain on the Achilles tendon.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: The stretch may increase tension on the plantar fascia, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Leaning against the wall requires some balance; those with balance issues may be at risk of falling.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle sprain: The exercise may place undue stress on healing ligaments, delaying recovery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Individuals with severe joint degeneration may experience pain or discomfort during the stretch.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with one foot closer to the wall to reduce the intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the distance from the wall or perform the stretch on an incline to increase the stretch intensity.

injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a slight bend in the knees to reduce lower back strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid locking the knees and keep a slight bend to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the wall is stable and can support your weight.
Avoid bouncing during the stretch to prevent muscle strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a neutral spine.
Ensure your heels remain on the ground throughout the stretch.
Align your feet parallel to each other for optimal stretch.
commonMistakes: Lifting the heels off the ground, reducing the effectiveness of the stretch.
Overarching the lower back, which can lead to discomfort or injury.
Bouncing during the stretch, increasing the risk of muscle strain.

name: Calf Stretch Hands Against Wall
instructions: Stand facing a wall from several feet away. Stagger your stance, placing one foot forward.
Lean forward and rest your hands on the wall, keeping your heel, hip and head in a straight line.
Attempt to keep your heel on the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds and then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: High severity; stretching the calf can exacerbate inflammation in the Achilles tendon.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle sprain: High severity; stretching may stress healing ligaments and delay recovery.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Moderate severity; the staggered stance may challenge balance and increase fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: Moderate severity; stretching may aggravate the plantar fascia if not done carefully.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Moderate severity; joint alignment and load may cause discomfort or pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with both feet parallel and closer to the wall to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the distance between the back foot and the wall to deepen the stretch.

injury_friendly.Achilles tendinitis: Perform a seated calf stretch using a towel to gently pull the toes towards you.
injury_friendly.balance disorders: Perform the stretch while seated or using a stable chair for support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the heel of the back foot remains in contact with the ground to avoid excessive strain on the Achilles tendon.
Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
formCues: Keep your back leg straight and your front knee slightly bent.
Maintain a straight line from your heel to your head.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
commonMistakes: Lifting the heel of the back foot off the ground.
Allowing the hips to sag or rotate.
Overarching the lower back.

name: Calves-SMR
instructions: Begin seated on the floor. Place a foam roller underneath your lower leg. Your other leg can either be crossed over the opposite or be placed on the floor, supporting some of your weight. This will be your starting position.

Place your hands to your side or just behind you, and press down to raise your hips off of the floor, placing much of your weight against your calf muscle. Roll from below the knee to above the ankle, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat for the other leg.

deep vein thrombosis.explanation: Foam rolling can dislodge a clot, leading to serious complications.

severe varicose veins.explanation: Pressure from foam rolling can exacerbate vein issues.

acute muscle strains.explanation: Foam rolling can worsen the injury and delay healing.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Tissue healing may be compromised, and pressure can disrupt recovery.

severe peripheral neuropathy.explanation: Reduced sensation may prevent the detection of excessive pressure or pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with both legs on the foam roller to distribute weight more evenly and reduce pressure.
modifications.harder: Cross one leg over the other to increase pressure on the calf being rolled.

injury_friendly.back pain: Keep the non-rolling leg bent with the foot flat on the floor to reduce strain on the lower back.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid crossing the legs and keep the non-rolling leg straight on the floor.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly over joints such as the knee or ankle.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your body while rolling.
Use your arms to control the pressure and movement speed.
Pause and hold on tender spots for 10-30 seconds to release tension.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly, which reduces effectiveness.
Applying too much pressure, causing unnecessary pain.
Neglecting to engage core muscles, leading to poor posture.

name: Car Deadlift
instructions: This event apparatus typically has neutral grip handles, however some have a straight bar that you can approach like a normal deadlift. The apparatus can be loaded with a vehicle or other heavy objects such as tractor tires or kegs.

Center yourself between the handles if you are a strong squatter, or back a couple inches if you are a strong deadlifter. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the handles. With your feet and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and flex the knees.

Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. As the weight comes up, pull your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward.
Lower the weight by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.

contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: High severity due to the axial loading and bending involved, which can exacerbate pain.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity as the exercise places significant stress on the lumbar spine, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity because the exercise can increase nerve compression and pain.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Moderate severity due to the load on the knee joints during the lift.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: High severity as the exercise requires full lower limb strength and stability.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Moderate severity as maintaining balance is crucial during the lift.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Moderate severity due to the potential for increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.

modifications.easier: Use a trap bar deadlift with lighter weights to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the load by adding more weight to the apparatus or using a heavier vehicle.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a partial range of motion deadlift with lighter weight, focusing on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a higher handle position to reduce knee flexion and stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints for heavy lifting.
Use a spotter or coach to monitor form and provide assistance if needed.
Avoid lifting if experiencing pain or discomfort during the exercise.
formCues: Keep your chest up and back arched throughout the lift.
Drive through the heels to engage the posterior chain effectively.
Pull shoulder blades together as you lift to maintain upper back stability.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which increases the risk of spinal injury.
Lifting with the arms instead of driving through the legs.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward, which can lead to knee injuries.

name: Car Drivers
instructions: While standing upright, hold a barbell plate in both hands at the 3 and 9 o'clock positions. Your palms should be facing each other and your arms should be extended straight out in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by rotating the plate as far to one side as possible. Use the same type of movement you would use to turn a steering wheel to one side.
Reverse the motion, turning it all the way to the opposite side.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The rotational movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding the weight in front of the body can strain the neck, especially if posture is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping and rotating the barbell plate can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow region.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The gripping and rotational action may increase discomfort in individuals with wrist pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The gripping and wrist positioning can exacerbate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or a smaller plate to reduce the load on the shoulders and arms.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell plate or perform the exercise with a longer hold at each end of the rotation.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a barbell plate to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or perform the exercise with a neutral grip dumbbell to minimize wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight is manageable to avoid excessive strain on the shoulders and wrists.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent neck and back strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce joint strain.
Rotate the plate smoothly and avoid jerky movements.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to compromised form.
Allowing the shoulders to elevate, causing neck strain.
Not engaging the core, resulting in an unstable posture.

name: Carioca Quick Step
instructions: Begin with your feet a few inches apart and your left arm up in a relaxed, athletic position.
With your right foot, quick step behind and pull the knee up.
Fire your arms back up when you pull the right knee, being sure that your knee goes straight up and down. Avoid turning your feet as you move and continue to look forward as you move to the side.

contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: The lateral movement and quick stepping can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.groin strain: The adductor activation and lateral movement can aggravate existing strains.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Twisting or poor form may increase lumbar stress, worsening back pain.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: The dynamic nature of the exercise may compromise healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Balance and coordination may be affected, increasing fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise at a slower pace with a reduced range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase speed and add a lateral jump after each step.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a focus on core engagement and reduced speed.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to reduce stress on the knees.
injury_friendly.hip pain: Perform side steps without crossing the feet to minimize hip stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate warm-up to prepare the adductors and surrounding muscles.
Perform on a non-slip surface to prevent falls.
Maintain a controlled pace to avoid unnecessary joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Avoid twisting your torso; keep your chest facing forward.
Ensure your knees track over your toes during the step.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the step.
Turning the feet outward, which can stress the knees.
Neglecting arm movement, which aids in balance and coordination.

name: Cat Stretch
instructions: Position yourself on the floor on your hands and knees.
Pull your belly in and round your spine, lower back, shoulders, and neck, letting your head drop.
Hold for 15 seconds.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The flexion of the spine may exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the disc.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: moderate - Flexion can relieve symptoms, but should be done cautiously and under supervision.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - Spinal flexion can increase instability and should be avoided.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - Flexion may relieve or worsen symptoms depending on the cause; professional guidance is recommended.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - Spinal flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: high - Consult with a healthcare provider before performing any spinal flexion exercises.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - As pregnancy progresses, modifications may be necessary to accommodate changes in balance and comfort.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while seated in a chair, rounding the back gently.
modifications.harder: Transition from cat stretch to cow stretch by alternating between spinal flexion and extension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with a neutral spine, avoiding excessive rounding.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Place a cushion under the knees for added comfort.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive rounding of the spine, especially if you have a history of back issues.
Perform the exercise on a soft surface to protect the knees.
formCues: Engage the core by pulling the belly button towards the spine.
Ensure hands are directly under shoulders and knees under hips.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on the stretch rather than the range of motion.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to collapse, reducing the effectiveness of the stretch.
Arching the back too much, which can cause discomfort or injury.
Holding the breath instead of breathing deeply and evenly.

name: Catch and Overhead Throw
instructions: Begin standing while facing a wall or a partner.
Using both hands, position the ball behind your head, stretching as much as possible, and forcefully throw the ball forward.

Ensure that you follow your throw through, being prepared to receive your rebound from your throw. If you are throwing against the wall, make sure that you stand close enough to the wall to receive the rebound, and aim a little higher than you would with a partner.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The explosive nature and overhead motion can exacerbate spinal conditions such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: Overhead throwing can aggravate shoulder impingement due to repetitive overhead motion.

rotator_cuff_tendinitis.explanation: The exercise may increase inflammation in the rotator cuff tendons due to the overhead and forceful nature of the throw.

hypertension.explanation: The exercise involves explosive movements that can temporarily increase blood pressure.

pregnancy.explanation: Balance and core stability may be compromised, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

osteoporosis.explanation: The risk of fracture is increased with high-impact and explosive movements.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter medicine ball or use a wall for support to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated on a stability ball to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion and use a lighter ball to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Use a ball with a weight appropriate for your strength level.
Warm up thoroughly before performing explosive movements.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement.
Keep your elbows slightly bent to reduce joint stress.
Follow through with your arms to ensure a smooth motion.
commonMistakes: Using too heavy a ball, leading to poor form.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in excessive spinal movement.
Not following through with the arms, causing abrupt stops.

name: Chain Handle Extension
instructions: You will need two cable handle attachments and a flat bench, as well as chains, for this exercise. Clip the middle of the chains to the handles, and position yourself on the flat bench. Your elbows should be pointing straight up.
Begin by extending through the elbow, keeping your upper arm still, with your wrists pronated.
Pause at the lockout, and reverse the motion to return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint can exacerbate tendinitis, especially if the exercise is performed with poor form.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position may aggravate symptoms due to compression of the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Overhead movements can strain the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow or shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not yet be strong enough to handle the load, risking re-injury.

modifications.easier: Use lighter chains or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase chain weight or add resistance bands for additional tension.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Perform tricep pushdowns with a rope attachment to reduce elbow stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform lying tricep extensions with dumbbells, keeping elbows slightly in front of the shoulders.

safetyNotes: Ensure chains are securely attached to prevent slipping.
Maintain control throughout the movement to avoid joint strain.
Avoid locking out the elbows forcefully to prevent hyperextension.
formCues: Keep elbows pointing straight up throughout the movement.
Engage core to stabilize the body on the bench.
Move only at the elbows; keep upper arms stationary.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, reducing tricep engagement.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively, which can strain the spine.

name: Chain Press
instructions: Begin by connecting the chains to the cable handle attachments. Position yourself on the flat bench in the same position as for a dumbbell press. Your wrists should be pronated and arms perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.
Lower the chains by flexing the elbows, unloading some of the chain onto the floor.
Continue until your elbow forms a 90 degree angle, and then reverse the motion by extending through the elbow to lockout.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the compression of the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate existing rotator cuff tears or strains.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension and flexion of the elbow may worsen tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the chains can increase pressure on the median nerve, exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The load and position may increase the risk of fractures, especially in the thoracic spine.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise should be avoided until full recovery and clearance from a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use resistance bands instead of chains to reduce load and provide a more controlled motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the chain weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to target different angles of the chest.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a floor press with dumbbells to limit range of motion and reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to decrease strain on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure chains are securely attached to prevent slipping.
Maintain control throughout the movement to avoid excessive swinging of the chains.
Avoid locking elbows forcefully at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Lower the chains slowly to maintain control and prevent momentum.
Ensure your wrists remain aligned with your forearms to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the chains to swing excessively, which can lead to joint instability.
Arching the back excessively, increasing the risk of lower back strain.
Failing to maintain wrist alignment, leading to potential wrist strain.

name: Chair Leg Extended Stretch
instructions: Sit upright in a chair and grip the seat on the sides.
Raise one leg, extending the knee, flexing the ankle as you do so.
Slowly move that leg outward as far as you can, and then back to the center and down.
Repeat for your other leg.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or spinal stenosis should avoid this exercise or perform it with caution, as the seated position and leg extension can increase spinal pressure.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should be cautious, as extending the leg can place stress on the knee joint.

neurological_conditions.details: Individuals with balance disorders or neuropathy should perform this exercise with caution to prevent falls or loss of balance.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if you have recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lower leg lift, keeping the knee slightly bent to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Hold the extended leg position for a longer duration or add ankle weights for increased resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lumbar support cushion to maintain proper spinal alignment.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid full extension if discomfort occurs.

safetyNotes: Ensure the chair is stable and does not slide during the exercise.
Avoid locking the knee during extension to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Sit up straight with your back supported by the chair.
Engage your core muscles to maintain stability.
Flex the ankle as you extend the leg to engage the hamstrings effectively.
commonMistakes: Slouching or leaning back excessively in the chair.
Locking the knee during leg extension.
Allowing the foot to drop instead of maintaining ankle flexion.

name: Chair Lower Back Stretch
instructions: Sit upright on a chair.
Bend to one side with your arm over your head. You can hold onto the chair with your free hand.
Hold for 10 seconds, and repeat for your other side.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - Bending and twisting can exacerbate disc herniation and cause further injury.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: moderate - Lateral bending may increase pressure on the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: moderate - Forward slippage of vertebrae can be aggravated by certain bending motions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: high - Increased risk of vertebral fractures with bending and twisting.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high - Stretching can strain surgical sites and impede healing.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - Risk of falling or losing balance during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with one hand on the hip and the other reaching overhead without bending too far.
modifications.harder: Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds and incorporate a slight twist at the waist.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with minimal bending and focus on deep breathing to reduce tension.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep the arm at shoulder height rather than overhead to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive bending to prevent strain on the lower back.
Ensure the chair is stable to prevent tipping over.
Perform the stretch slowly and avoid jerky movements.
formCues: Sit tall with your feet flat on the floor.
Engage your core to support the spine.
Reach over your head with your arm, keeping it in line with your ear.
commonMistakes: Leaning too far forward instead of to the side.
Allowing the back to round excessively.
Holding the breath during the stretch.

name: Chair Squat
instructions: To begin, first set the bar to a position that best matches your height. Once the bar is loaded, step under it and position it across the back of your shoulders.
Take the bar with your hands facing forward, unlock it and lift it off the rack by extending your legs.

Move your feet forward about 18 inches in front of the bar. Position your legs using a shoulder width stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Look forward at all times and maintain a neutral or slightly arched spine. This will be your starting position.
Slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper and lower leg breaks 90 degrees.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heels of your feet, extending the knees and returning to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

herniated disc.explanation: The axial loading and spinal flexion during squats can exacerbate disc herniation symptoms.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The compressive forces on the knee joint can increase pain and inflammation in individuals with osteoarthritis.

severe cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver and increased blood pressure during squats can pose risks for those with severe heart conditions.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the stress of squatting, risking re-injury.

balance disorders.explanation: The need for stability during squats can be challenging for those with balance issues, increasing fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight chair squats without added resistance.
modifications.harder: Use a barbell for added resistance or perform single-leg chair squats.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a Smith machine to stabilize the bar path and reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the squat to above 90 degrees and use a resistance band around the knees for support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely positioned on the shoulders, not the neck.
Use a spotter or safety bars if lifting heavy weights.
Warm up thoroughly before performing squats to prevent injury.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels to return to the starting position.
Avoid letting your knees collapse inward; keep them aligned with your toes.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to extend past the toes excessively.
Rounding the back or losing spinal alignment.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Chair Upper Body Stretch
instructions: Sit on the edge of a chair, gripping the back of it.
Straighten your arms, keeping your back straight, and pull your upper body forward so you feel a stretch. Hold for 20-30 seconds.
contraindications: severe arthritis in the shoulder or spine

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: This exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to the arm position and potential compression of shoulder structures.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Pulling on the chair can strain the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The forward pull may increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with severe osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical protocols often restrict certain movements to allow for healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the shoulder or spin: The exercise may cause discomfort or pain due to joint stress.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with a resistance band instead of gripping the chair to reduce the intensity.
modifications.harder: Add a gentle twist to the torso to increase the stretch across the upper back and shoulders.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with shoulder pain, perform the stretch with one arm at a time to reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements during the stretch.
Ensure the chair is stable and does not tip over during the exercise.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your back straight and avoid rounding the shoulders.
Engage your core to support your spine.
Breathe deeply and evenly throughout the stretch.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back instead of keeping it straight.
Using excessive force to pull forward, leading to potential strain.
Holding the breath during the stretch.

name: Chest And Front Of Shoulder Stretch
instructions: Start off by standing with your legs together, holding a bodybar or a broomstick.
Take a slightly wider than shoulder width grip on the pole and hold it in front of you with your palms facing down.
Carefully lift the pole up and behind your head.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: Lifting the arms overhead and behind the head can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to compression of the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator_cuff_injuries: This stretch may place excessive strain on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening tears or inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical_spine_issues: The position may place stress on the cervical spine, aggravating conditions such as herniated discs or stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid this stretch due to the risk of fractures, especially in the thoracic spine.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: During pregnancy, increased joint laxity and changes in posture may make this stretch uncomfortable or unsafe.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with a towel instead of a bar, allowing for a more flexible grip and reduced range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by using a wider grip and gently pulling the bar further behind the head, ensuring no pain is felt.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder pain, perform the stretch lying on your back with a rolled towel under the spine to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid forcing the stretch beyond your comfort zone.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort in the shoulders or neck.
Ensure a controlled movement to prevent sudden jerks.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support the spine.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce joint strain.
Lift the bar slowly and smoothly, focusing on the stretch in the chest and shoulders.
commonMistakes: Overextending the arms, leading to shoulder strain.
Arching the lower back excessively, which can cause lumbar discomfort.
Using momentum to lift the bar, reducing the effectiveness of the stretch.

name: Chest Push from 3 point stance
instructions: Begin in a three point stance, squatted down with your back flat and one hand on the ground. Place the medicine ball directly in front of you.
To begin, take your first step as you pull the ball to your chest, positioning both hands to prepare for the throw.
As you execute the second step, explosively release the ball forward as hard as possible.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The explosive nature and forward bending position can exacerbate spinal injuries such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: The forceful push can aggravate shoulder impingement, requiring modifications to reduce shoulder stress.

hypertension.explanation: The explosive movement and potential for breath-holding can spike blood pressure, necessitating careful monitoring.

recent_abdominal_surgery.explanation: The core engagement and explosive movement can stress healing tissues post-surgery.

balance_disorders.explanation: The dynamic movement and stance require good balance, posing a risk for those with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise from a kneeling position to reduce the complexity and balance requirement.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier medicine ball or increase the distance of the throw to add intensity.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise against a wall to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Reduce the range of motion and use a lighter ball to decrease shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for explosive movement.
Avoid holding your breath during the exercise to prevent blood pressure spikes.
formCues: Keep your back flat and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through your legs to generate power for the throw.
Follow through with your arms fully extended to ensure a complete throw.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the setup or execution.
Failing to engage the core, leading to instability.
Throwing the ball without using the legs, reducing power and increasing shoulder strain.

name: Chest Push (multiple response)
instructions: Begin in a kneeling position facing a wall or utilize a partner. Hold the ball with both hands tight into the chest.
Execute the pass by exploding forward and outward with the hips while pushing the ball as hard as possible.
Follow through by falling forward, catching yourself with your hands.
Immediately return to an upright position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: The explosive nature of the chest push can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the rapid overhead motion.
contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal load during the explosive movement.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise may pose a risk for those with balance issues, increasing the likelihood of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent_abdominal_surgery: The forceful movement and core engagement can stress healing tissues post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Explosive exercises can cause a temporary spike in blood pressure, which may be unsafe for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise from a standing position to reduce the need for balance and coordination.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on one leg to add a balance challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise seated on a stability ball to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter ball and focus on a slower, controlled push to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Use a non-slip mat to prevent slipping during the exercise.
Warm up thoroughly before performing explosive movements.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement to protect the spine.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive arching of the back.
Follow through with the arms fully extended and the ball released at chest level.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to arch excessively during the push.
Failing to engage the core, leading to potential lower back strain.
Not following through with the arms, resulting in reduced power and effectiveness.

name: Chest Push (single response)
instructions: Begin in a kneeling position holding the medicine ball with both hands tightly into the chest.
Execute the pass by exploding forward and outward with the hips while pushing the ball as far as possible.
Follow through by falling forward, catching yourself with your hands.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The explosive nature of the movement and the forward fall can exacerbate spinal issues such as herniated discs or sciatica.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: The pushing motion can aggravate shoulder impingement, especially if form is compromised.

balance_disorders.explanation: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, which can be challenging for individuals with balance disorders.

recent_abdominal_surgery.explanation: The core engagement and explosive movement can stress the abdominal region, risking complications post-surgery.

hypertension.explanation: The explosive nature of the exercise can cause a temporary spike in blood pressure, which may be risky for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise from a seated position on a stability ball to reduce the complexity and balance requirement.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise from a standing position to engage more muscles.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise while seated on a bench to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter medicine ball and focus on a slower, controlled push to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent injury during the forward fall.
Use a medicine ball of appropriate weight to avoid overexertion.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Explode forward with the hips, not just the arms.
Maintain a neutral spine to protect the back.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to arch excessively during the push.
Failing to engage the core, leading to poor balance.
Using too heavy a medicine ball, compromising form.

name: Chest Push with Run Release
instructions: Begin in an athletic stance with the knees bent, hips back, and back flat. Hold the medicine ball near your legs. This will be your starting position.
While taking your first step draw the medicine ball into your chest.
As you take the second step, explosively push the ball forward, immediately sprinting for 10 yards after the release. If you are really fast, you can catch your own pass!

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: High impact and explosive movements can exacerbate spinal injuries such as herniated discs or sciatica.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: The explosive push motion can aggravate shoulder impingement or rotator cuff issues.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The explosive nature of the exercise may cause a spike in blood pressure, which is a concern for those with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The transition from a static position to a sprint may be challenging for individuals with balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent_abdominal_surgery: The core engagement and explosive movement may strain the abdominal region, delaying recovery.
contraindicationDetails.knee_issues: The sprinting component may aggravate conditions like arthritis or tendinitis in the knees.

modifications.easier: Perform the chest push without the sprint, focusing on controlled throws.
modifications.harder: Increase the distance of the sprint or use a heavier medicine ball.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise seated on a bench to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Eliminate the sprint and perform the push from a stable stance.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter medicine ball and focus on a controlled push without full extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles before performing the sprint.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for explosive movements.
Start with a lighter medicine ball to master the technique before progressing.
formCues: Maintain a neutral spine with a slight forward lean.
Engage the core throughout the movement to stabilize the torso.
Push through the chest and shoulders, not the arms alone.
Explode forward with the legs during the sprint.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the push.
Failing to engage the core, leading to excessive lumbar extension.
Using too heavy a medicine ball, compromising form.
Not transitioning smoothly into the sprint.

name: Chest Stretch on Stability Ball
instructions: Get on your hands and knees next to an exercise ball.
Place your elbows on top of the ball, keeping your arm out to your side. This will be your starting position.
Lower your torso towards the floor, keeping your elbow on top of the ball. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds, and repeat with the other arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position may exacerbate symptoms due to the overhead arm position, which can compress the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The stretch may place undue stress on the rotator cuff, risking further injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The forward bending position may increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical protocols typically restrict overhead and stretching movements until healing is adequate.
contraindicationDetails.severe kyphosis: The position may be uncomfortable or exacerbate postural issues due to the thoracic spine curve.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the arm resting on a chair or bench instead of a stability ball to reduce instability.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch intensity by gently pressing the chest further towards the floor while maintaining proper form.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the stretch with the arm at a lower angle or use a wall for support to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch seated on a chair with the arm supported on a table to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure the stability ball is properly inflated to maintain balance.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back during the stretch.
Do not force the stretch beyond a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to support the lower back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the stretch.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch without bouncing.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to sag excessively.
Forcing the stretch too far, leading to discomfort or pain.
Using a ball that is too large or too small, affecting stability.

name: Child's Pose
instructions: Get on your hands and knees, walk your hands in front of you.
Lower your buttocks down to sit on your heels. Let your arms drag along the floor as you sit back to stretch your entire spine.
Once you settle onto your heels, bring your hands next to your feet and relax. "breathe" into your back. Rest your forehead on the floor. Avoid this position if you have knee problems.

contraindicationDetails.knee problems: High pressure on the knees can exacerbate conditions like arthritis or previous injuries.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Flexion of the spine may increase intradiscal pressure, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion can exacerbate nerve compression symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Forward flexion may increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: In later stages, the position may compress the abdomen and affect breathing.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of vertebral compression fractures with excessive spinal flexion.

modifications.easier: Place a cushion or bolster between the calves and thighs to reduce knee flexion.
modifications.harder: Extend arms further forward to increase the stretch in the shoulders and upper back.

injury_friendly.knee_pain: Place a rolled towel or yoga block under the hips to reduce knee flexion.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the pose with a slight arch in the lower back to reduce pressure.

safetyNotes: Avoid if experiencing acute knee or back pain.
Use a mat or soft surface to protect the knees.
formCues: Keep the spine elongated as you lower the hips.
Relax the shoulders away from the ears.
Breathe deeply into the lower back.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to tense up.
Not breathing deeply, which can limit the stretch.
Forcing the hips to the heels, causing knee discomfort.

name: Chin-Up
instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing your torso and a grip closer than the shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, keep your torso as straight as possible while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position. Tip: Keeping the torso as straight as possible maximizes biceps stimulation while minimizing back involvement.

As you breathe out, pull your torso up until your head is around the level of the pull-up bar. Concentrate on using the biceps muscles in order to perform the movement. Keep the elbows close to your body. Tip: The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.

After a second of squeezing the biceps in the contracted position, slowly lower your torso back to the starting position; when your arms are fully extended. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity. Overhead movements can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate severity. The exercise can increase inflammation if not modified.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate severity. Gripping and pulling can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate severity. Gripping the bar may increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: High severity. The exercise can increase cervical spine compression.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (third trimester): Moderate severity. Altered balance and core stability may require modifications.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use an assisted pull-up machine or resistance bands to reduce body weight load.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a dip belt or weighted vest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform lat pull-downs with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a thicker bar or grips to decrease strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper core engagement and consider using a supported pull-up machine.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing chin-ups to reduce injury risk.
Avoid swinging or using momentum to complete the movement.
Ensure a secure grip to prevent slipping from the bar.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
Keep elbows close to the body throughout the movement.
Pull with the arms while keeping the shoulders down and back.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back.
commonMistakes: Using momentum or kipping to complete the movement.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up towards the ears.
Failing to fully extend the arms at the bottom of the movement.
Not engaging the core, leading to excessive swinging.

name: Chin To Chest Stretch
instructions: Get into a seated position on the floor.
Place both hands at the rear of your head, fingers interlocked, thumbs pointing down and elbows pointing straight ahead. Slowly pull your head down to your chest. Hold for 20-30 seconds.

contraindicationDetails.cervical spine injury: Individuals with cervical spine injuries such as herniated discs or stenosis should avoid this stretch as it may exacerbate their condition.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Those with severe osteoporosis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of fractures in the cervical vertebrae.
contraindicationDetails.recent neck surgery: Patients recovering from neck surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by their healthcare provider to prevent complications.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch without using the hands to apply pressure, simply allowing the weight of the head to stretch the neck.
modifications.harder: Add gentle resistance by applying slight pressure with the hands, but only if no discomfort is felt.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with mild neck discomfort, perform the stretch lying down with a rolled towel under the neck for support.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling the head down with excessive force.
Stop immediately if any pain or discomfort occurs.
Ensure the stretch is felt in the muscles and not the joints.
formCues: Keep the back straight and shoulders relaxed.
Engage the core to maintain a stable seated position.
Breathe deeply and evenly throughout the stretch.
commonMistakes: Using too much force with the hands.
Rounding the upper back instead of isolating the neck.
Holding the breath during the stretch.

name: Circus Bell
instructions: The circus bell is an oversized dumbbell with a thick handle. Begin with the dumbbell between your feet, and grip the handle with both hands.
Clean the dumbbell by extending through your hips and knees to deliver the implement to the desired shoulder, letting go with the extra hand.

Ensure that you get one of the dumbbell heads behind the shoulder to keep from being thrown off balance. To raise it overhead, dip by flexing the knees, and the drive upwards as you extend the dumbbell overhead, leaning slightly away from it as you do so.
Carefully guide the bell back to the floor, keeping it under control as much as possible. It is best to perform this event on a thick rubber mat to prevent damage to the floor.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to overhead movement and heavy load, which can exacerbate impingement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: High risk as the exercise places significant stress on the shoulder complex.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High risk due to the axial loading and potential for spinal flexion under load.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High risk as the exercise involves spinal loading and extension.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Moderate risk due to the potential for increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High risk as the exercise involves significant shoulder stress and mobility.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: High risk due to the need for stability and balance during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter dumbbell or kettlebell and perform a single-arm shoulder press without the clean.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the circus bell or perform the exercise with a single arm throughout.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter weight and perform the exercise seated to reduce spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up focusing on shoulder mobility and core activation.
Use a spotter if attempting maximum loads.
Perform on a non-slip surface to prevent falls.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to protect the spine.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Drive through the legs during the overhead press phase.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the clean phase.
Allowing the shoulder to internally rotate excessively.
Using momentum rather than controlled strength.

name: Clean
instructions: With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take an overhand (or hook) grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.

Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.

Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.

As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery.
Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high load on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or tendinitis in the knees, hips, or shoulders should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.
