cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before attempting high-intensity exercises like the clean.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance and core stability challenges.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery, particularly involving the spine, knees, or shoulders, requires clearance from a healthcare professional before performing cleans.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis or advanced diabetes with neuropathy may require modifications to reduce risk of injury.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid performing cleans with any recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the involved joints or muscles.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may necessitate modifications to ensure safety.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang clean starting from above the knees to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Perform a full clean and jerk to increase complexity and total body involvement.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a power clean from blocks to reduce the range of motion and lower back strain.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat during the catch phase to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on form to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before performing cleans to prepare the muscles and joints.
Use appropriate footwear with good support and grip.
Start with lighter weights to master form before progressing to heavier loads.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift.
Drive through the heels to initiate the lift.
Maintain a neutral spine and engaged core.
Fully extend the hips, knees, and ankles during the second pull.
Catch the bar with elbows high and chest up.
commonMistakes: Pulling with the arms too early.
Not fully extending the hips during the second pull.
Catching the bar with elbows down.
Rounding the back during the lift.
Using too much weight before mastering technique.

name: Clean Deadlift
instructions: Begin standing with a barbell close to your shins. Your feet should be directly under your hips with your feet turned out slightly. Grip the bar with a double overhand grip or hook grip, about shoulder width apart. Squat down to the bar. Your spine should be in full extension, with a back angle that places your shoulders in front of the bar and your back as vertical as possible.

Begin by driving through the floor through the front of your heels. As the bar travels upward, maintain a constant back angle. Flare your knees out to the side to help keep them out of the bar's path.
After the bar crosses the knees, complete the lift by driving the hips into the bar until your hips and knees are extended.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high compressive forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or hip impingement should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing heavy lifts.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid heavy lifting and consult a healthcare provider for appropriate modifications.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical patients, especially those recovering from spinal or lower limb surgeries, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.

osteoporosis.details: Due to the risk of fractures, individuals with osteoporosis should avoid heavy lifting exercises like the clean deadlift.

modifications.easier: Perform a Romanian deadlift with lighter weights to focus on form and reduce load.
modifications.harder: Progress to a full clean by adding a power clean movement after the deadlift.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright posture.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion, or perform a partial deadlift from blocks.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the lift to prevent injury.
Avoid rounding the back, especially during the initial pull.
Ensure the barbell path is close to the body to reduce shear forces on the spine.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core before lifting.
Drive through your heels and keep the bar close to your shins.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Allowing the bar to drift away from the body.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Clean Pull
instructions: With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take an overhand or hook grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.

Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight and elbows out. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.

Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended. Full extension should be violent and abrupt, and ensure that you do not prolong the extension for longer than necessary.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and explosive movements involved.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or shoulder arthritis, impingement, or tendinitis should modify or avoid this exercise as it places stress on these joints.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should use caution due to the high-intensity nature of the exercise.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance and abdominal pressure concerns.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, knees, or shoulders, contraindicate this exercise until fully healed and cleared by a physician.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of injury; modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

modifications.easier: Perform a deadlift to focus on the initial pull phase without the explosive second pull.
modifications.harder: Progress to a full clean by catching the barbell on the shoulders after the pull.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright posture.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on the hip hinge to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the second pull and focus on controlled deadlifts.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell path is close to the body to reduce the risk of injury.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent back strain.
Avoid jerking the weight; focus on smooth, controlled acceleration.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders slightly in front of the bar at the start.
Drive through your heels and keep your arms straight during the first pull.
Explode through your hips, knees, and ankles during the second pull.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Pulling with the arms too early.
Not fully extending the hips during the second pull.

name: Clean Shrug
instructions: Begin with a shoulder width, double overhand or hook grip, with the bar hanging at the mid thigh position. Your back should be straight and inclined slightly forward.
Shrug your shoulders towards your ears. While this exercise can usually by loaded with heavier weight than a clean, avoid overloading to the point that the execution slows down.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead movement and shoulder shrugging can exacerbate symptoms of impingement.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The load on the shoulders and neck can increase stress on the cervical spine, potentially worsening conditions like cervical disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The shrugging motion can strain the rotator cuff, especially if the muscles are already compromised.
contraindicationDetails.acute neck pain: The exercise can increase tension in the neck muscles, potentially aggravating pain.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward lean and load can increase spinal compression, which may exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The forward lean and spinal loading can increase shear forces on the spine, potentially worsening this condition.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells or a lighter barbell to reduce the load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight gradually while maintaining speed and form, or perform the exercise from a hang position to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a trap bar to keep the load closer to the body's center of gravity, reducing spinal stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive shoulder elevation and reduce weight.

safetyNotes: Avoid overloading to maintain speed and proper form.
Ensure a stable stance with feet shoulder-width apart.
Keep the core engaged to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep your back straight and slightly inclined forward.
Engage your core throughout the movement.
Shrug your shoulders directly upwards towards your ears.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight, leading to poor form.
Rounding the back during the exercise.
Jerking the weight instead of a controlled shrug.

name: Clean and Jerk
instructions: With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take an overhand or hook grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.

Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.

Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.

As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery.
Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position.

The second phase is the jerk, which raises the weight overhead. Standing with the weight racked on the front of the shoulders, begin with the dip. With your feet directly under your hips, flex the knees without moving the hips backward. Go down only slightly, and reverse direction as powerfully as possible.
Drive through the heels create as much speed and force as possible, and be sure to move your head out of the way as the bar leaves the shoulders.

At this moment as the feet leave the floor, the feet must be placed into the receiving position as quickly as possible. In the brief moment the feet are not actively driving against the platform, the athletes effort to push the bar up will drive them down. The feet should be split, with one foot forward, and one foot back. Receive the bar with the arms locked out overhead. Return to a standing position.

spinal injuries.explanation: The clean and jerk involves significant spinal loading and dynamic movement, which can exacerbate spinal injuries such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Overhead movements can aggravate shoulder impingement; modifications or alternative exercises may be necessary.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: The dynamic and overhead nature of the exercise can worsen rotator cuff injuries.

knee injuries.explanation: The deep squat and explosive movements can stress the knees, requiring modifications for those with knee issues.

wrist injuries.explanation: The wrist position during the catch and jerk phases can exacerbate wrist injuries.

cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The high-intensity nature of the exercise can increase cardiovascular demand, requiring medical clearance for those with heart conditions.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise involves high loads and dynamic movements that are not recommended during pregnancy.

osteoporosis.explanation: The risk of fracture due to high-impact and heavy loading makes this exercise unsuitable for individuals with osteoporosis.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints for the dynamic movements.
Use a spotter or perform the exercise in a controlled environment to reduce the risk of injury.
Avoid excessive weights that compromise form and increase injury risk.
formCues: Keep the back straight and core engaged throughout the lift.
Drive through the heels and keep the bar close to the body.
Ensure full hip extension before initiating the pull under the bar.
Maintain a stable and upright torso during the catch phase.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Pulling with the arms too early, reducing the effectiveness of the hip drive.
Failing to fully extend the hips before the catch.
Improper foot placement during the jerk, leading to instability.

modifications.easier: Perform the power clean and push press separately to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the catch position to enhance stability and strength.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use lighter weights and focus on form, or perform the exercise with dumbbells to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the squat depth or perform a power clean to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a push press instead of a jerk to reduce shoulder strain.

name: Clean and Press
instructions: Assume a shoulder-width stance, with knees inside the arms. Now while keeping the back flat, bend at the knees and hips so that you can grab the bar with the arms fully extended and a pronated grip that is slightly wider than shoulder width. Point the elbows out to sides. The bar should be close to the shins. Position the shoulders over or slightly ahead of the bar. Establish a flat back posture. This will be your starting position.

Begin to pull the bar by extending the knees. Move your hips forward and raise the shoulders at the same rate while keeping the angle of the back constant; continue to lift the bar straight up while keeping it close to your body.

As the bar passes the knee, extend at the ankles, knees, and hips forcefully, similar to a jumping motion. As you do so, continue to guide the bar with your hands, shrugging your shoulders and using the momentum from your movement to pull the bar as high as possible. The bar should travel close to your body, and you should keep your elbows out.

At maximum elevation, your feet should clear the floor and you should start to pull yourself under the bar. The mechanics of this could change slightly, depending on the weight used. You should descend into a squatting position as you pull yourself under the bar.

As the bar hits terminal height, rotate your elbows around and under the bar. Rack the bar across the front of the shoulders while keeping the torso erect and flexing the hips and knees to absorb the weight of the bar.
Stand to full height, holding the bar in the clean position.
Without moving your feet, press the bar overhead as you exhale. Lower the bar under control .

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High shoulder abduction and external rotation may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Overhead pressing can increase stress on the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The overhead position can strain the cervical spine, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping and pressing motions can aggravate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The spinal loading and dynamic movement can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The dynamic nature and spinal loading can increase anterior shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High-impact and heavy loading exercises can increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the movement with a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the catch position.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a seated shoulder press to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the squat during the catch phase.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before performing the exercise.
Use a spotter or safety racks when attempting heavier loads.
Avoid hyperextending the back during the press phase.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift.
Engage your core to maintain a neutral spine.
Drive through your heels during the initial pull.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using arms too early in the pull phase.
Failing to fully extend the hips and knees.

name: Clean from Blocks
instructions: With a barbell on boxes or stands of the desired height, take an overhand or hook grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.
Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight with the elbows pointed out.

As full extension is achieved, transition into the receiving position by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. Aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery.
Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position. Return the weight to the boxes for the next rep.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and dynamic nature of the movement, which can exacerbate spinal issues.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or shoulder arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint strain, as the clean involves significant knee and shoulder engagement.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should be cautious due to the high-intensity nature of the exercise, which can elevate blood pressure and heart rate.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Individuals recovering from recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, knees, or shoulders, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are any recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the involved areas to prevent further injury.

neurological_conditions.details: Those with balance disorders or neuropathy should modify or avoid this exercise due to the risk of falls and improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang clean from a higher starting position or use lighter weights to reduce the complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform a full clean from the floor to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright posture.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat and focus on the power pull phase.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on form, avoiding excessive shrugging or arm pull.

safetyNotes: Ensure the boxes or stands are stable and at an appropriate height to prevent tipping.
Warm-up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for explosive movements.
Use proper lifting techniques to avoid injury.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement to protect the spine.
Drive through the heels to maintain balance and power.
Keep elbows high during the catch phase to secure the bar properly.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift, which can lead to spinal injury.
Pulling with the arms too early, reducing the effectiveness of the leg drive.
Failing to fully extend the hips before transitioning to the catch phase.

name: Clock Push-Up
instructions: Move into a prone position on the floor, supporting your weight on your hands and toes.
Your arms should be fully extended with the hands around shoulder width. Keep your body straight throughout the movement. This will be your starting position.
Descend by flexing at the elbow, lowering your chest toward the ground.
At the bottom, reverse the motion by pushing yourself up through elbow extension as quickly as possible until you are air borne. Aim to "jump" 12-18 inches to one side.
As you accelerate up, move your outside foot away from your direction of travel. Leaving the ground, shift your body about 30 degrees for the next repetition.
Return to the starting position and repeat the exercise, working all the way around until you are back where you started.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to shoulder joint stress during push-up movements.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Pressure on wrists can worsen inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Dynamic movement and load on shoulders can aggravate existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Weight-bearing on hands can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Core engagement is critical; improper form can exacerbate pain.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Prone position and dynamic movement may not be suitable, especially in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High-intensity shoulder activity can hinder recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform regular push-ups without the jumping and rotational component.
modifications.harder: Increase the rotational angle to 45 degrees or add a clap between jumps.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform push-ups on an incline to reduce shoulder load.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars to keep wrists in a neutral position.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Focus on core engagement and reduce range of motion as needed.

safetyNotes: Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare the shoulders and wrists.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back.
Land softly to minimize joint impact.
formCues: Keep your core tight and engaged.
Maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Use your chest and triceps to push explosively.
Rotate your body smoothly and control the landing.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise excessively.
Failing to engage the core, leading to lower back strain.
Landing heavily, increasing joint stress.
Not maintaining shoulder stability during the jump.

name: Close-Grip Barbell Bench Press
instructions: Lie back on a flat bench. Using a close grip (around shoulder width), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest. Tip: Make sure that - as opposed to a regular bench press - you keep the elbows close to the torso at all times in order to maximize triceps involvement.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your triceps muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The close grip can exacerbate impingement by increasing stress on the shoulder joint.

rotator cuff tear.explanation: The exercise places significant load on the shoulder, which can worsen a tear.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The triceps activation can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow.

wrist pain.explanation: The wrist position during the lift can increase discomfort or injury risk.

hypertension.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver often used in lifting can spike blood pressure.

osteoporosis.explanation: The load on the upper body may increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely racked before and after the exercise.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy weights.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise.

modifications.harder: Add resistance bands or chains to increase load at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.elbow_pain: Use an EZ curl bar to reduce strain on the elbows.

name: Close-Grip Dumbbell Press
instructions: Place a dumbbell standing up on a flat bench.

Ensuring that the dumbbell stays securely placed at the top of the bench, lie perpendicular to the bench with only your shoulders lying on the surface. Hips should be below the bench and your legs bent with your feet firmly on the floor.

Grasp the dumbbell with both hands and hold it straight over your chest at arm's length. Both palms should be pressing against the underside of the sides of the dumbbell. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by lowering the dumbbell to your chest.
Return to the starting position by extending the elbows.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The close-grip position can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the internal rotation and adduction of the shoulder.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places significant stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required can strain an already compromised rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: The exercise may place undue stress on healing tissues, especially in the chest or shoulder region.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a single dumbbell held with both hands.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a stability ball to engage more core muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a floor press variation to limit shoulder range of motion.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a resistance band instead of a dumbbell to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the dumbbell is securely placed on the bench before starting.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive arching of the back.
Do not allow the elbows to flare out excessively.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your body throughout the movement.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
Lower the dumbbell in a controlled manner and avoid bouncing it off your chest.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, increasing shoulder stress.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Arching the back excessively, leading to potential lower back strain.

name: Close-Grip EZ-Bar Curl with Band
instructions: Attach a band to each end of the bar. Take the bar, placing a foot on the middle of the band. Stand upright with a narrow, supinated grip on the EZ bar. The elbows should be close to the torso. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the upper arms in place, flex the elbows to execute the curl. Exhale as the weight is lifted.
Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second and squeeze the biceps hard.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The exercise may cause discomfort due to the close grip and shoulder positioning.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The grip required may increase pressure on the median nerve.

severe hypertension.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver, often used unconsciously during exertion, can dangerously elevate blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band or without the band, using just the EZ-bar.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance by using a thicker band or adding weight plates to the EZ-bar.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a wider grip to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise seated to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely attached to prevent it from snapping.
Avoid locking the elbows at the bottom of the movement to maintain tension.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Focus on a controlled motion, especially during the eccentric phase.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid excessive strain.
commonMistakes: Using momentum by swinging the body.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Close-Grip EZ-Bar Press
instructions: Lie on a flat bench with an EZ bar loaded to an appropriate weight.
Using a narrow grip lift the bar and hold it straight over your torso with your elbows in. The arms should be perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.
Now lower the bar down to your lower chest as you breathe in. Keep the elbows in as you perform this movement.
Using the triceps to push the bar back up, press it back to the starting position by extending the elbows as you exhale.
Repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The close-grip position can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to increased internal rotation and stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places significant stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The grip required may strain the wrists, especially if there is pre-existing pain or weakness.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding heavy loads and stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The exercise involves weight-bearing on the upper body, which could increase fracture risk in individuals with severe osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use dumbbells for better control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Perform tricep pushdowns with a resistance band to minimize elbow stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or a neutral grip bar to alleviate wrist discomfort.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely loaded and balanced before starting.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a controlled motion to prevent injury.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked close to the body throughout the movement.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Lower the bar slowly and under control to the lower chest.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out, which can increase shoulder strain.
Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and potential injury.
Bouncing the bar off the chest instead of controlling the descent.

name: Close-Grip EZ Bar Curl
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding an E-Z Curl Bar at the closer inner handle. The palm of your hands should be facing forward and they should be slightly tilted inwards due to the shape of the bar. The elbows should be close to the torso. This will be your starting position.
While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second and squeeze the biceps hard.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive motion of curling can exacerbate inflammation in the tendons around the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Keeping the elbows close to the torso may cause discomfort or further impingement in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The grip required for this exercise can place additional stress on the wrist joint, potentially aggravating existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The gripping and curling motion can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Stabilizing the shoulder during the curl can strain an already compromised rotator cuff.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slower tempo or add an isometric hold at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a wider grip to reduce stress on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or a neutral grip bar to minimize wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid excessive strain.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weight; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep elbows close to your torso throughout the movement.
Engage your core to prevent swaying or leaning back.
Exhale as you curl the bar up and inhale as you lower it.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the torso.
Using excessive weight, compromising form.

name: Close-Grip Front Lat Pulldown
instructions: Sit down on a pull-down machine with a wide bar attached to the top pulley. Make sure that you adjust the knee pad of the machine to fit your height. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the resistance attached to the bar.

Grab the bar with the palms facing forward using the prescribed grip. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than your shoulder width. For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you - while holding the bar at the chosen grip width - bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

As you breathe out, bring the bar down until it touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary (only the arms should move). The forearms should do no other work except for holding the bar; therefore do not try to pull the bar down using the forearms.

After a second in the contracted position, while squeezing your shoulder blades together, slowly raise the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched. Inhale during this portion of the movement.
6. Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pulling motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may increase inflammation in the rotator cuff tendons due to repetitive motion.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The exercise can place additional stress on the spine, potentially worsening disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during heavy lifts, can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or back surgery: The exercise may impede recovery by placing undue stress on healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise may pose a risk of fracture due to spinal loading and potential jerky movements.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to spinal extension and loading.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band anchored above to perform a similar motion with less resistance.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase the challenge to the stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure the knee pads are adjusted properly to prevent being lifted by the weight.
Avoid using momentum to pull the bar down; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your chest lifted and shoulders down and back throughout the movement.
Focus on pulling with your elbows rather than your hands to engage the lats effectively.
commonMistakes: Leaning too far back, turning the exercise into a row.
Using the forearms to pull the bar instead of engaging the lats.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up during the pull.

name: Close-Grip Push-Up off of a Dumbbell
instructions: Lie on the floor and place your hands on an upright dumbbell. Supporting your weight on your toes and hands, keep your torso rigid and your elbows in with your arms straight. This will be your starting position.
Lower your body, allowing the elbows to flex while you inhale. Keep your body straight, not allowing your hips to rise or sag.
Press yourself back up to the starting position by extending the elbows. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High stress on the shoulder joint during the lowering phase can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The close-grip position increases stress on the elbow tendons, potentially worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Supporting body weight on the wrists can aggravate existing wrist pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists can increase symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise requires significant shoulder stabilization, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Maintaining a rigid torso can be challenging and may exacerbate lower back pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on your knees to reduce the load on the upper body.
modifications.harder: Elevate your feet on a stable surface to increase the difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a wider grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or a neutral grip to alleviate wrist pressure.

safetyNotes: Ensure the dumbbell is stable and will not roll during the exercise.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to protect the joints.
formCues: Keep elbows close to your body throughout the movement.
Engage your core to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Inhale as you lower down, exhale as you push up.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise, compromising spinal alignment.
Flaring elbows out to the sides, increasing shoulder stress.
Not maintaining a neutral wrist position, leading to wrist strain.

name: Close-Grip Standing Barbell Curl
instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands, palms up and a few inches apart.

Stand with your torso straight and your head up. Your feet should be about shoulder width and your elbows close to your torso. This will be your starting position. Tip: You will keep your upper arms and elbows stationary throughout the movement.

Curl the bar up in a semicircular motion until the forearms touch your biceps. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement and contract your biceps hard for a second at the top. Tip: Avoid bending the back or using swinging motions as you lift the weight. Only the forearms should move.
Slowly go back down to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate - The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate - Keeping elbows close to the torso may increase shoulder joint stress.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Moderate - The close grip can place additional strain on the wrists.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate - The grip position may compress the median nerve further.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Moderate - Stabilization demands on the shoulder can aggravate existing injuries.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or switch to dumbbells for better control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase or add resistance bands.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a wider grip to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize shoulder involvement.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use an EZ curl bar to reduce wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid using momentum to lift the barbell.
Keep the core engaged to prevent lower back strain.
Ensure wrists are in a neutral position to avoid excessive strain.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Exhale as you curl the bar up, inhale as you lower it.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the torso.
Using a grip that is too wide, reducing bicep activation.

name: Cocoons
instructions: Begin by lying on your back on the ground. Your legs should be straight and your arms extended behind your head. This will be your starting position.

To perform the movement, tuck the knees toward your chest, rotating your pelvis to lift your glutes from the floor. As you do so, flex the spine, bringing your arms back over your head to perform a simultaneous crunch motion.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The flexion and rotation involved in cocoons can exacerbate disc herniation by increasing intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Spinal flexion can further narrow the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Pelvic rotation and spinal flexion can increase shear forces on the vertebrae.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The movement may irritate the sciatic nerve due to increased lumbar flexion.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Flexion of the spine can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Supine exercises can reduce blood flow and cause discomfort, especially in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: The exercise may place undue stress on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with bent knees and reduced range of motion to decrease intensity.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight in your hands to increase resistance during the crunch phase.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with lower back pain, perform a partial crunch without lifting the pelvis off the floor.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking movements to prevent strain on the lower back.
Ensure a controlled motion throughout the exercise.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you crunch and bring your knees towards your chest.
Keep your movements smooth and controlled.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively during the return to the starting position.
Not fully engaging the core, leading to strain on the neck or lower back.

name: Conan's Wheel
instructions: With the weight loaded, take a zurcher hold on the end of the implement. Place the bar in the crook of the elbow and hold onto your wrist. Try to keep the weight off of the forearms.

Begin by lifting the weight from the ground. Keep a tight, upright posture as you being to walk, taking short, fast steps. Look up and away as you turn in a circle. Do not hold your breath during the event. Continue walking until you complete one or more complete turns.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High axial load and forward flexion can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The forward lean and axial load may increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Weight-bearing and repetitive motion can aggravate joint pain.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance to prevent falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow or shoulder surgery: The Zurcher hold places stress on the elbow and shoulder joints.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The exercise is physically demanding and may increase cardiovascular strain.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or a shorter distance to reduce load and fatigue.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or the number of laps to enhance intensity.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform with a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the distance and avoid sharp turns to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a harness to distribute weight away from the arms.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight is securely loaded to prevent shifting during movement.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare muscles and joints for the exercise.
Maintain an upright posture to protect the spine.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Take short, controlled steps to maintain balance.
Look ahead to help maintain an upright posture.
commonMistakes: Allowing the weight to rest on the forearms, increasing strain.
Leaning too far forward, which can stress the lower back.
Taking overly long steps, which can disrupt balance.

name: Concentration Curls
instructions: Sit down on a flat bench with one dumbbell in front of you between your legs. Your legs should be spread with your knees bent and feet on the floor.

Use your right arm to pick the dumbbell up. Place the back of your right upper arm on the top of your inner right thigh. Rotate the palm of your hand until it is facing forward away from your thigh. Tip: Your arm should be extended and the dumbbell should be above the floor. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Tip: At the top of the movement make sure that the little finger of your arm is higher than your thumb. This guarantees a good contraction. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to starting position as your breathe in. Caution: Avoid swinging motions at any time.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions. Then repeat the movement with the left arm.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arm and potential for shoulder movement can aggravate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with the potential for sudden or uncontrolled movements.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Stabilization of the shoulder during the exercise may strain an injured rotator cuff.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter dumbbell or perform the exercise with a resistance band for less load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizing muscles or increase the weight.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and perform slow, controlled movements to reduce strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with the arm supported on a bench to minimize shoulder involvement.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use a neutral grip (hammer curl position) to reduce wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid using momentum to lift the weight.
Ensure the back is straight and supported by the bench to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep the upper arm stationary against the thigh.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement.
Lower the weight slowly to maintain control.
commonMistakes: Swinging the dumbbell to generate momentum.
Allowing the elbow to move away from the thigh.
Not fully extending the arm at the bottom of the movement.

name: Cross-Body Crunch
instructions: Lie flat on your back and bend your knees about 60 degrees.
Keep your feet flat on the floor and place your hands loosely behind your head. This will be your starting position.

Now curl up and bring your right elbow and shoulder across your body while bring your left knee in toward your left shoulder at the same time. Reach with your elbow and try to touch your knee. Exhale as you perform this movement. Tip: Try to bring your shoulder up towards your knee rather than just your elbow and remember that the key is to contract the abs as you perform the movement; not just to move the elbow.
Now go back down to the starting position as you inhale and repeat with the left elbow and the right knee.
Continue alternating in this manner until all prescribed repetitions are done.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The twisting motion and spinal flexion can exacerbate disc herniation, increasing pain and risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion and rotation of the spine may worsen symptoms by compressing the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase anterior shear forces on the spine, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The movement may irritate the sciatic nerve, leading to increased pain and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal flexion and rotation can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Supine exercises can reduce blood flow to the fetus, and the twisting motion may be uncomfortable or unsafe.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion or keep the feet on the floor without lifting the knees.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a Bosu ball to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, focusing on a gentle contraction of the abs without lifting the shoulders too high.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid lifting the knees and instead focus on the upper body twist only.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep the hands crossed over the chest instead of behind the head to reduce strain on the shoulders.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with the hands to prevent strain.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive twisting to protect the lower back.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you twist and lift, inhale as you return to the starting position.
Focus on bringing the shoulder towards the knee, not just the elbow.
commonMistakes: Pulling on the neck with the hands.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: Cross Body Hammer Curl
instructions: Stand up straight with a dumbbell in each hand. Your hands should be down at your side with your palms facing in.

While keeping your palms facing in and without twisting your arm, curl the dumbbell of the right arm up towards your left shoulder as you exhale. Touch the top of the dumbbell to your shoulder and hold the contraction for a second.
Slowly lower the dumbbell along the same path as you inhale and then repeat the same movement for the left arm.
Continue alternating in this fashion until the recommended amount of repetitions is performed for each arm.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis, causing pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The movement may cause further compression in the shoulder joint, aggravating impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with weight-bearing exercises, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise may place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase, taking 3-4 seconds to lower the weight.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a resistance band instead of dumbbells to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort, stopping before any pain occurs.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid excessive strain.
Avoid swinging the weights to prevent momentum from taking over the movement.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your body throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the curl.
Control the weight on the way down to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing bicep engagement.
Leaning back or using body momentum to lift the weight.

name: Cross Over - With Bands
instructions: Secure an exercise band around a stationary post.
While facing away from the post, grab the handles on both ends of the band and step forward enough to create tension on the band.

Raise your arms to the sides, parallel to the floor, perpendicular to your torso (your torso and the arms should resemble the letter "T") and with the palms facing forward. Have them extended with a slight bend at the elbows. This will be your starting position.
While keeping your arms straight, bring them across your chest in a semicircular motion to the front as you exhale and flex your pecs. Hold the contraction for a second.
Slowly return to the starting position as you inhale.
Perform for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and cross-body motion may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise can increase inflammation due to repetitive shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: The isometric contraction and potential Valsalva maneuver can dangerously elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which may impair healing.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: The physical exertion can trigger angina attacks due to increased cardiac demand.
contraindicationDetails.chronic shoulder instability: The exercise can exacerbate instability by placing stress on the shoulder joint.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter resistance bands or perform a single-arm version to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier resistance band or perform the exercise on a stability ball to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion and lighter resistance to minimize shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bands are securely anchored to prevent snapping or slipping.
Avoid locking the elbows to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Exhale as you bring the bands together and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to lock out during the movement.
Using momentum rather than controlled movement.
Failing to maintain tension in the bands throughout the exercise.

name: Crossover Reverse Lunge
instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Perform a rear lunge by stepping back with one foot and flexing the hips and front knee. As you do so, rotate your torso across the front leg.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position and repeat on the other side, continuing in an alternating fashion.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The rotational component of the exercise can exacerbate disc herniation symptoms by increasing spinal load.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The exercise may increase spinal compression and aggravate symptoms due to the rotational movement.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The rotational and flexion movements can increase instability in the lumbar spine.
contraindicationDetails.severe knee arthritis: The deep knee flexion involved can cause pain and further joint degradation.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The unilateral nature of the exercise may increase the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: The exercise places stress on the lower limbs, which may not be suitable during recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform a stationary reverse lunge without the crossover to reduce complexity and balance demands.
modifications.harder: Add a dumbbell in each hand to increase resistance and challenge stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Avoid the rotational component and focus on a straight reverse lunge.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the lunge and ensure the knee does not travel past the toes.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to protect the lower back.
Ensure the knee of the front leg does not extend beyond the toes to minimize joint stress.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Keep your chest up and shoulders back during the lunge.
Focus on a controlled descent and ascent to maintain balance.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to collapse inward, increasing stress on the joint.
Rounding the back during the torso rotation, which can lead to spinal strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements, reducing effectiveness and increasing injury risk.

name: Crucifix
instructions: In the crucifix, you statically hold weights out to the side for time. While the event can be practiced using dumbbells, it is best to practice with one of the various implements used, such as axes and hammers, as it feels different.

Begin standing, and raise your arms out to the side holding the implements. Your arms should be parallel to the ground. In competition, judges or sensors are used to let you know when you break parallel. Hold for as long as you can. Typically, the weights should be heavy enough that you fail in 30-60 seconds.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Holding weights in a static position can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to prolonged shoulder abduction.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which may aggravate existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping weights for extended periods can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the shoulders: Static holds can increase joint stress, worsening arthritis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the static load, risking re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Holding weights statically can increase blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or extend the hold duration beyond 60 seconds.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with elbows slightly bent to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Avoid locking elbows to reduce joint stress.
Ensure weights are manageable to prevent sudden failure.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent back strain.
formCues: Keep arms parallel to the ground.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees for balance.
commonMistakes: Allowing arms to drop below parallel.
Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Neglecting core engagement, causing back arching.

recommendedReps.strength: Hold for 15-30 seconds with heavier weights

name: Crunch - Hands Overhead
instructions: Lie on the floor with your back flat and knees bent with around a 60-degree angle between the hamstrings and the calves.
Keep your feet flat on the floor and stretch your arms overhead with your palms crossed. This will be your starting position.

Curl your upper body forward and bring your shoulder blades just off the floor. At all times, keep your arms aligned with your head, neck and shoulder. Don't move them forward from that position. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement and hold the contraction for a second.
Slowly lower down to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal flexion can exacerbate symptoms and increase disc pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion may worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Flexion can increase anterior shear forces on the spine, worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Flexion may irritate the sciatic nerve, increasing pain.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal flexion increases the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Supine position can reduce blood flow and abdominal exercises can stress the rectus abdominis.

modifications.easier: Perform a basic crunch with hands crossed over the chest to reduce lever arm and strain.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight or medicine ball overhead to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a standing cable crunch to maintain a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep hands crossed over the chest to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with the hands.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent excessive flexion.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you curl up and inhale as you lower down.
Keep elbows extended and in line with the ears.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the torso.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Tucking the chin into the chest.

name: Crunch - Legs On Exercise Ball
instructions: Lie flat on your back with your feet resting on an exercise ball and your knees bent at a 90 degree angle.
Place your feet three to four inches apart and point your toes inward so they touch.
Place your hands lightly on either side of your head keeping your elbows in. Tip: Don't lock your fingers behind your head.
Push the small of your back down in the floor in order to better isolate your abdominal muscles. This will be your starting position.

Begin to roll your shoulders off the floor and continue to push down as hard as you can with your lower back. Your shoulders should come up off the floor only about four inches, and your lower back should remain on the floor. Breathe out as you execute this portion of the movement. Squeeze your abdominals hard at the top of the contraction and hold for a second. Tip: Focus on a slow, controlled movement. Refrain from using momentum at any time.
Slowly go back down to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity; the flexion of the spine can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity; spinal flexion may increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity; spinal flexion can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity; flexion may aggravate nerve irritation.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity; risk of vertebral fracture with spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity; avoid supine position after the first trimester.

modifications.easier: Perform the crunch with feet flat on the floor instead of on the exercise ball.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight plate on your chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a partial crunch with minimal spinal flexion, focusing on engaging the core without lifting the shoulders too high.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure the knees are supported and stable on the ball, or perform the exercise with feet on the floor.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with your hands to prevent strain.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive flexion.
formCues: Engage your core before lifting your shoulders.
Exhale as you lift, inhale as you lower.
Keep movements slow and controlled.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the shoulders.
Pulling on the neck with the hands.
Allowing the lower back to arch off the floor.

name: Crunches
instructions: Lie flat on your back with your feet flat on the ground, or resting on a bench with your knees bent at a 90 degree angle. If you are resting your feet on a bench, place them three to four inches apart and point your toes inward so they touch.
Now place your hands lightly on either side of your head keeping your elbows in. Tip: Don't lock your fingers behind your head.
While pushing the small of your back down in the floor to better isolate your abdominal muscles, begin to roll your shoulders off the floor.

Continue to push down as hard as you can with your lower back as you contract your abdominals and exhale. Your shoulders should come up off the floor only about four inches, and your lower back should remain on the floor. At the top of the movement, contract your abdominals hard and keep the contraction for a second. Tip: Focus on slow, controlled movement - don't cheat yourself by using momentum.
After the one second contraction, begin to come down slowly again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - Crunches can exacerbate spinal compression and increase intradiscal pressure, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The flexion of the spine during crunches can increase pressure on the spinal canal, aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The forward flexion can cause vertebral slippage, increasing pain and instability.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The exercise may aggravate nerve compression; modifications are necessary.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - Spinal flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high - Healing tissues may be stressed by abdominal contractions.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - The supine position and abdominal pressure may be unsafe, especially in the second and third trimesters.

modifications.easier: Perform a partial crunch, lifting only the head and shoulders slightly off the ground.
modifications.harder: Add a twist at the top of the movement to engage obliques more intensely.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform crunches on a stability ball to reduce spinal load and provide support.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Keep the neck neutral and use hands to support the head lightly without pulling.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck to prevent strain.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive flexion.
Engage the core throughout to protect the lower back.
formCues: Press the lower back into the floor to stabilize the spine.
Lift with the chest, not the neck, to initiate the movement.
Exhale as you lift, inhale as you lower.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the torso.
Pulling on the neck with hands.
Lifting too high, causing the lower back to arch.

name: Cuban Press
instructions: Take a dumbbell in each hand with a pronated grip in a standing position. Raise your upper arms so that they are parallel to the floor, allowing your lower arms to hang in the "scarecrow" position. This will be your starting position.

To initiate the movement, externally rotate the shoulders to move the upper arm 180 degrees. Keep the upper arms in place, rotating the upper arms until the wrists are directly above the elbows, the forearms perpendicular to the floor.
Now press the dumbbells by extending at the elbows, straightening your arms overhead.
Return to the starting position as you breathe in by reversing the steps.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The external rotation component of the Cuban Press can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves significant rotator cuff activation, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights overhead can increase cervical spine loading, potentially worsening conditions like herniated discs or stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The overhead pressing motion may pose a fracture risk due to increased spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead pressing can elevate blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad to engage more stabilizers.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder pain, perform external rotations with a resistance band at shoulder height without the pressing motion.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up of the shoulder complex before performing the exercise.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent undue stress on the shoulder joints.
formCues: Maintain a neutral spine and engage the core throughout the movement.
Keep the elbows in line with the shoulders during the external rotation phase.
Press the weights overhead in a controlled manner, avoiding locking the elbows.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights, which can lead to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the elbows to drop below shoulder level during the external rotation phase.

name: Dancer's Stretch
instructions: Sit up on the floor.
Cross your right leg over your left, keeping the knee bent. Your left leg is straight and down on the floor.
Place your left arm on your right leg and your right hand on the floor.
Rotate your upper body to the right, and hold for 10-20 seconds. Switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High risk due to spinal rotation which may exacerbate disc protrusion.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Moderate risk as spinal rotation can increase pressure on the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High risk due to potential for increased vertebral slippage with rotation.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate risk as the stretch may irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate risk of vertebral fracture due to spinal rotation.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: High risk; avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate risk in later stages due to balance and flexibility changes; consult with a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the back against a wall for support to limit rotation.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds and deepen the twist by using the opposite elbow to push against the knee.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch lying on your back with knees bent and gently twist side to side.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep both legs straight and avoid crossing the legs to reduce knee strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive force when rotating the spine.
Do not perform if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
formCues: Sit tall with a straight back before initiating the twist.
Engage the core to support the spine during the rotation.
Use your hand on the floor for balance and support.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively during the twist.
Using momentum to deepen the stretch instead of controlled movement.
Holding the breath; remember to breathe deeply and evenly.

name: Dead Bug
instructions: Begin lying on your back with your hands extended above you toward the ceiling.
Bring your feet, knees, and hips up to 90 degrees.

Exhale hard to bring your ribcage down and flatten your back onto the floor, rotating your pelvis up and squeezing your glutes. Hold this position throughout the movement. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the exercise by extending one leg, straightening the knee and hip to bring the leg just above the ground.
Maintain the position of your lumbar and pelvis as you perform the movement, as your back is going to want to arch.
Stay tight and return the working leg to the starting position.
Repeat on the opposite side, alternating until the set is complete.

herniated disc.explanation: The exercise may exacerbate symptoms by increasing intra-abdominal pressure and lumbar flexion.

spinal stenosis.explanation: Lumbar flexion may worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal.

spondylolisthesis.explanation: The exercise can increase lumbar instability and anterior translation of the vertebrae.

sciatica.explanation: May aggravate nerve compression due to pelvic tilt and lumbar pressure.

osteoporosis.explanation: Risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal flexion and pressure.

recent abdominal surgery.explanation: Risk of disrupting healing tissues and increasing intra-abdominal pressure.

pregnancy.explanation: Exercise may be uncomfortable due to changes in center of gravity and abdominal pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with knees bent and feet on the floor, extending only one arm at a time.
modifications.harder: Hold a light dumbbell in each hand to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a rolled towel under the lower back for support.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Keep arms by your sides and focus on leg movements only.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid excessive lumbar extension or arching of the back.
Engage the core to stabilize the pelvis and lower back.
formCues: Keep your back flat against the floor.
Exhale as you extend the leg to engage the core.
Move slowly and with control to maintain stability.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch off the floor.
Moving too quickly, which can reduce control and increase injury risk.
Not engaging the core fully, leading to lumbar strain.

name: Deadlift with Bands
instructions: To deadlift with short bands, simply loop them over the bar before you start, and step into them to set up. For long bands, they will need to be anchored to a secure base, such as heavy dumbbells or a rack.

With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal loading can exacerbate disc herniation, leading to increased pain and potential nerve damage.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The compressive forces on the spine can worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The forward slippage of a vertebra can be aggravated by heavy lifting, increasing instability.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may irritate the sciatic nerve, causing pain to radiate down the leg.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: Joint stress, particularly in the spine and knees, can increase discomfort and inflammation.
