contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver often used in heavy lifting can spike blood pressure, posing risks for those with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Increased risk of vertebral fractures due to reduced bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: Healing tissues are vulnerable to re-injury under heavy loads.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The need for stability during the lift can pose a fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the deadlift with a lighter resistance band or use a kettlebell for a sumo deadlift variation.
modifications.harder: Increase the band tension or add additional weight plates to the barbell.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright torso.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform Romanian deadlifts to minimize knee flexion and focus on hip hinge.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely anchored to prevent snapping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the lift to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Use proper footwear to ensure stability and traction.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back.
Engage the core before initiating the lift.
Drive through the heels and keep the bar close to the body.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Starting the lift with the hips too high or too low.
Allowing the knees to cave inward.

name: Deadlift with Chains
instructions: You can attach the chains to the sleeves of the bar, or just drape the middle over the bar so there is a greater weight increase as you lift.

Approach the bar so that it is centered over your feet. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to protract. Typically, you would use an overhand grip or an over/under grip on heavier sets. With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar.

Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The axial loading and spinal flexion can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - Compression of the spine can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - Forward slippage of a vertebra can be aggravated by heavy lifting.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high - The exercise may increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: moderate - Joint stress can exacerbate symptoms; modifications are necessary.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: moderate - The Valsalva maneuver can increase blood pressure; avoid breath-holding.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - Risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: high - Healing tissues are vulnerable to re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - The exercise requires good proprioception; modifications are necessary.

modifications.easier: Perform a Romanian deadlift with lighter weights to reduce spinal load.
modifications.harder: Increase chain weight or perform deficit deadlifts to increase range of motion.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal stress and maintain a more upright posture.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit knee flexion by performing a Romanian deadlift variation.

safetyNotes: Ensure chains are securely attached to prevent shifting during the lift.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid injury.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body to reduce lower back strain.
Engage your core before initiating the lift to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels to activate the posterior chain effectively.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Starting the lift with the bar too far from the shins.
Using too much weight, leading to compromised form.

name: Decline Barbell Bench Press
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and slowly lay down on the bench.

Using a medium width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. The arms should be perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position. Tip: In order to protect your rotator cuff, it is best if you have a spotter help you lift the barbell off the rack.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your lower chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up).
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The decline angle increases stress on the shoulder joint, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places significant demand on the rotator cuff for stabilization, potentially aggravating existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: The exertion and breath-holding can increase cardiac workload, posing a risk for those with unstable angina.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The movement requires significant shoulder mobility and strength, which may not be suitable post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture due to the load on the upper body is increased in individuals with severe osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries like herniated disc: The decline position can increase lumbar spine pressure, potentially worsening spinal conditions.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The decline position may increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for a more natural range of motion and reduced load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a flat bench to reduce lumbar spine stress.

safetyNotes: Always use a spotter to assist with lifting the bar off the rack and during the exercise.
Ensure the bench is securely set at the correct decline angle to prevent slipping.
Avoid locking the elbows aggressively at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your feet securely anchored to prevent sliding.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
Engage the core to stabilize the body throughout the movement.
Lower the barbell in a controlled manner to the lower chest.
commonMistakes: Bouncing the bar off the chest to gain momentum.
Flaring the elbows excessively, which can increase shoulder stress.
Arching the back excessively, leading to lumbar strain.
Using too much weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.

name: Decline Close-Grip Bench To Skull Crusher
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and slowly lay down on the bench.

Using a close grip (a grip that is slightly less than shoulder width), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked and elbows in. The arms should be perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position. Tip: In order to protect your rotator cuff, it is best if you have a spotter help you lift the barbell off the rack.
Now lower the bar down to your lower chest as you breathe in. Keep the elbows in as you perform this movement.
Using the triceps to push the bar back up, press it back to the starting position as you exhale.

As you breathe in and you keep the upper arms stationary, bring the bar down slowly by moving your forearms in a semicircular motion towards you until you feel the bar slightly touch your forehead. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Lift the bar back to the starting position by contracting the triceps and exhaling.
Repeat steps 3-6 until the recommended amount of repetitions is performed.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High stress on the shoulder joint can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The exercise requires stabilization from the rotator cuff, which can be compromised if torn.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The triceps and forearm muscles are heavily engaged, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Close grip can place additional stress on the wrists, aggravating existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The decline position can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The decline position may strain the neck, particularly if form is compromised.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a flat bench to reduce the angle and stress on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier weight or add resistance bands for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for more natural arm movement.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Reduce range of motion or use lighter weights to minimize stress on the elbows.

safetyNotes: Always use a spotter when lifting heavy weights to prevent accidents.
Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbows completely to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in close to the body throughout the movement.
Maintain a controlled motion; avoid bouncing the bar off the chest or forehead.
Engage the core to stabilize the body on the decline bench.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out, which can increase shoulder and elbow stress.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the bar to drift away from the forehead during the skull crusher phase.

name: Decline Crunch
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down.
Now place your hands lightly on either side of your head keeping your elbows in. Tip: Don't lock your fingers behind your head.
While pushing the small of your back down in the bench to better isolate your abdominal muscles, begin to roll your shoulders off it.

Continue to push down as hard as you can with your lower back as you contract your abdominals and exhale. Your shoulders should come up off the bench only about four inches, and your lower back should remain on the bench. At the top of the movement, contract your abdominals hard and keep the contraction for a second. Tip: Focus on slow, controlled movement - don't cheat yourself by using momentum.
After the one second contraction, begin to come down slowly again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

herniated disc.explanation: The decline crunch can exacerbate disc herniation due to increased spinal flexion and pressure on the lumbar spine.

spinal stenosis.explanation: Spinal flexion in this exercise may worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.

spondylolisthesis.explanation: The exercise increases shear forces on the spine, which can aggravate spondylolisthesis.

sciatica.explanation: The position and movement may irritate the sciatic nerve, worsening symptoms.

osteoporosis.explanation: The flexion movement can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

pregnancy.explanation: Lying on a decline bench may cause discomfort and potential strain on the abdominal wall, especially in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard crunch on a flat surface to reduce the intensity.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight plate or medicine ball against your chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a plank or standing cable crunch to minimize spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Cross arms over the chest instead of placing hands near the head to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with your hands to prevent strain.
Ensure the decline bench is stable and secure before starting.
Stop immediately if you feel any sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Engage your core before starting the movement.
Exhale as you crunch up and inhale as you return to the starting position.
Keep movements slow and controlled to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the shoulders instead of engaging the core.
Pulling on the neck with the hands, leading to strain.
Lifting too high, which can reduce the effectiveness of the exercise.

name: Decline Dumbbell Bench Press
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.
Once you are laying down, move the dumbbells in front of you at shoulder width.
Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. This will be your starting position.
Bring down the weights slowly to your side as you breathe out. Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times. Tip: Throughout the motion, the forearms should always be perpendicular to the floor.

As you breathe out, push the dumbbells up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up..
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The decline angle can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the increased range of motion and potential for anterior shoulder stress.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places significant demand on shoulder stability, which may aggravate existing rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The decline position can place strain on the neck, potentially worsening cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The decline position and weight load may increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The decline position can increase intra-abdominal pressure, potentially exacerbating lumbar disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The decline position can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a flat bench to reduce the angle and stress on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a flat bench and ensure proper lumbar support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is securely set at the correct decline angle to prevent slipping.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy weights to ensure safety.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the movement to maintain tension on the chest.
formCues: Keep your feet securely anchored to prevent sliding.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
Engage your core to stabilize your body throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder strain.
Bouncing the dumbbells off the chest to gain momentum.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lumbar strain.

name: Decline Dumbbell Flyes
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.

Once you are laying down, move the dumbbells in front of you at shoulder width. The palms of the hands should be facing each other and the arms should be perpendicular to the floor and fully extended. This will be your starting position.

With a slight bend on your elbows in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon, lower your arms out at both sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, the arms should remain stationary; the movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.
Return your arms back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and breathe out. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The wide arc of motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the overhead position and abduction of the arms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate existing rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying on a decline bench may increase pressure on the cervical spine, particularly if the neck is not properly supported.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The decline position and handling of weights can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The decline position may increase lumbar spine pressure, potentially worsening disc herniation symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The decline position can exacerbate anterior slippage of the vertebrae, increasing discomfort and risk of injury.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a flat bench to reduce the angle and decrease the difficulty.
modifications.harder: Use a stability ball instead of a bench to increase core engagement and balance challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive stretch and stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a flat bench and support the lower back with a towel or cushion to reduce lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the decline bench is securely locked in position to prevent accidents.
Start with lighter weights to master the form and avoid shoulder strain.
Avoid locking elbows to prevent undue stress on the joints.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Focus on moving through the shoulder joint, not the elbows.
Maintain a controlled tempo to avoid momentum and ensure muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to drop too low, increasing shoulder strain.
Using excessive weight, leading to compromised form.
Failing to maintain a neutral wrist position, which can cause wrist strain.

name: Decline Dumbbell Triceps Extension
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.

Once you are laying down, move the dumbbells in front of you at shoulder width. The palms of the hands should be facing each other and the arms should be perpendicular to the floor and fully extended. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in and you keep the upper arms stationary (and elbows in), bring the dumbbells down slowly by moving your forearms in a semicircular motion towards you until your thumbs are next to your ears. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Lift the dumbbells back to the starting position by contracting the triceps and exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension of the elbow can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise requires stabilization from the shoulder, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells may increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The decline position can increase neck strain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a flat bench to reduce the angle and stress on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Use a barbell instead of dumbbells to increase load and stability challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use lighter weights and focus on controlled movements to minimize joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before beginning the exercise.
Do not lock the elbows at the top of the movement to avoid joint stress.
Keep the core engaged to maintain spinal alignment.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in close to the body throughout the movement.
Lower the dumbbells slowly to maintain control.
Exhale as you extend the arms back to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, which increases shoulder strain.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.

name: Decline EZ Bar Triceps Extension
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and slowly lay down on the bench.

Using a close grip (a grip that is slightly less than shoulder width), lift the EZ bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked and elbows in. The arms should be perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position. Tip: In order to protect your rotator cuff, it is best if you have a spotter help you lift the barbell off the rack.

As you breathe in and you keep the upper arms stationary, bring the bar down slowly by moving your forearms in a semicircular motion towards you until you feel the bar slightly touch your forehead. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.
Lift the bar back to the starting position by contracting the triceps and exhaling.
Repeat until the recommended amount of repetitions is performed.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and elbow flexion can exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The exercise involves significant shoulder stabilization, which can strain a compromised rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive elbow extension can aggravate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The grip and load can stress the wrist joints, exacerbating pain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The decline position may increase blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The decline position can increase spinal pressure, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The decline angle may increase lumbar lordosis, aggravating this condition.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a flat bench to reduce the angle and stress on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lighter weight and ensure elbows are not flaring out to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce stress on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a flat bench or standing to minimize spinal compression.

safetyNotes: Always use a spotter when lifting heavy weights to ensure safety.
Ensure the decline bench is securely set to prevent slipping.
Avoid locking out the elbows completely to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in close to the body throughout the movement.
Maintain a controlled motion, especially during the lowering phase.
Engage the core to stabilize the body on the decline bench.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out, which increases shoulder stress.
Using excessive weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.
Bouncing the bar off the forehead instead of controlling the descent.

name: Decline Oblique Crunch
instructions: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and slowly lay down on the bench.
Raise your upper body off the bench until your torso is about 35-45 degrees if measured from the floor.
Put one hand beside your head and the other on your thigh. This will be your starting position.

Raise your upper body slowly from the starting position while turning your torso to the left. Continue crunching up as you exhale until your right elbow touches your left knee. Hold this contracted position for a second. Tip: Focus on keeping your abs tight and keeping the movement slow and controlled.
Lower your body back down slowly to the starting position as you inhale.

After completing one set on the right for the recommended amount of repetitions, switch to your left side. Tip: Focus on really twisting your torso and feeling the contraction when you are in the up position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The decline oblique crunch can exacerbate symptoms by increasing intra-abdominal pressure and spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion of the spine may worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase shear forces on the spine, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Twisting and flexion can irritate the sciatic nerve, leading to increased pain.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal flexion and twisting can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The supine position and abdominal pressure can be unsafe, especially in the second and third trimesters.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a flat surface instead of a decline bench to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight or medicine ball at chest level to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated oblique twists with a resistance band to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure proper leg support and avoid excessive knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerky or rapid movements to reduce the risk of injury.
Ensure the decline bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement to protect your spine.
Exhale as you twist and crunch, inhale as you return to the starting position.
Keep movements slow and controlled to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle control.
Allowing the neck to strain forward or excessively twisting the neck.
Not maintaining a stable lower body position.

name: Decline Push-Up
instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart while holding your torso up at arms length. Move your feet up to a box or bench. This will be your starting position.
Next, lower yourself downward until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Now breathe out and press your upper body back up to the starting position while squeezing your chest.
After a brief pause at the top contracted position, you can begin to lower yourself downward again for as many repetitions as needed.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The decline angle increases stress on the shoulder joint, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The extended wrist position can aggravate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists in this position can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder, which may aggravate existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The decline position can increase lumbar spine stress, potentially worsening pain.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (third trimester): The prone position and abdominal pressure are not recommended during late pregnancy.

modifications.easier: Perform incline push-ups with hands elevated on a bench or step to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Perform decline push-ups with one leg raised to increase core engagement and instability.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform wall push-ups to reduce shoulder load.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or fists to keep wrists neutral.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench or box is stable and secure to prevent falls.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back to prevent lumbar strain.
Maintain a neutral neck position to avoid cervical strain.
formCues: Engage the core to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Lower the body in a controlled manner, avoiding bouncing at the bottom.
Keep elbows at a 45-degree angle to the body to protect the shoulders.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag, which can strain the lower back.
Flaring elbows out too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Inadequate range of motion, reducing exercise effectiveness.

name: Decline Reverse Crunch
instructions: Lie on your back on a decline bench and hold on to the top of the bench with both hands. Don't let your body slip down from this position.

Hold your legs parallel to the floor using your abs to hold them there while keeping your knees and feet together. Tip: Your legs should be fully extended with a slight bend on the knee. This will be your starting position.
While exhaling, move your legs towards the torso as you roll your pelvis backwards and you raise your hips off the bench. At the end of this movement your knees will be touching your chest.
Hold the contraction for a second and move your legs back to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The flexion and pressure on the lumbar spine can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. Lumbar flexion may increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise can increase lumbar instability.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. The movement may aggravate nerve irritation.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High severity. Spinal flexion can increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Supine position and abdominal pressure may be contraindicated, especially in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent strain on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a flat surface instead of a decline bench to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or hold a medicine ball between the knees for increased resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a pelvic tilt on the floor to engage the core without excessive lumbar flexion.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform the exercise with knees bent throughout to reduce strain on the knee joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the decline bench is stable and secure before starting.
Avoid jerking movements to prevent unnecessary spinal stress.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Engage your core before starting the movement.
Keep your movements slow and controlled.
Exhale as you lift your hips and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of core strength to lift the hips.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Holding the breath during the exercise.

name: Decline Smith Press
instructions: Place a decline bench underneath the Smith machine. Now place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Using a pronated grip that is wider than shoulder width, unlock the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms extended. This will be your starting position.
As you inhale, lower the bar under control by allowing the elbows to flex, lightly contacting the torso.
After a brief pause, bring the bar back to the starting position by extending the elbows, exhaling as you do so.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When the set is complete, lock the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The decline angle and wide grip can exacerbate impingement by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.pectoral strain: The stretch and load on the pectoral muscles can aggravate or cause strains.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the load and range of motion required.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The decline position may increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: The decline position can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a flat bench to reduce the range of motion and stress on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or use a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support and engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is securely positioned and the Smith machine is properly set up.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy to prevent accidents.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the floor to stabilize your body.
Maintain a slight arch in your lower back without overarching.
Lower the bar to just below the chest level, not touching the chest.
Keep elbows slightly tucked to protect the shoulders.
commonMistakes: Bouncing the bar off the chest, which can cause injury.
Flaring elbows too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Arching the back excessively, leading to potential spinal injury.

name: Deficit Deadlift
instructions: Begin by having a platform or weight plates that you can stand on, usually 1-3 inches in height. Approach the bar so that it is centered over your feet. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to protract. Typically, you would use an overhand grip or an over/under grip on heavier sets.

With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: moderate

modifications.easier: Perform a standard deadlift without a deficit to reduce the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the platform or use a heavier weight.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright torso.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on hip hinge mechanics.

safetyNotes: Ensure the platform is stable and can support your weight.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the lower back and hamstrings.
Avoid rounding the lower back during the lift.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift.
Engage your core before initiating the lift.
Drive through your heels and keep your chest up.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Starting with the hips too high or too low.
Not engaging the core, leading to instability.

name: Depth Jump Leap
instructions: For this drill you will need two boxes or benches, one 12 to 16 inches high and the other 22 to 26 inches high.

Stand on one of the two boxes with arms at the sides; feet should be together and slightly off the edge as in the depth jump. Place the other box approximately two or three feet in front of and facing the performer.
Begin by dropping off the initial box, landing and simultaneously taking off with both feet.
Rebound by driving upward and outward as intensely as possible, using the arms and full extension of the body to jump onto the higher box. Again, allow the legs to absorb the impact.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact landing and jumping can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The impact and explosive movements can increase stress on the lumbar spine.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, increasing the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: High-impact activities can interfere with healing and recovery.
contraindicationDetails.achilles tendinitis: Jumping and landing place significant stress on the Achilles tendon, potentially worsening the condition.

modifications.easier: Perform a step-up onto the lower box instead of jumping.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the boxes or add a weighted vest for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform a depth step instead of a jump to reduce impact.
injury_friendly.back pain: Reduce the height of the boxes and focus on controlled landings.
injury_friendly.balance issues: Use a stable support or perform the exercise next to a wall for assistance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the boxes are stable and on a non-slip surface.
Warm up thoroughly before performing high-impact exercises.
Avoid locking the knees upon landing to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Use the arms to generate upward momentum during the jump.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Not using the arms effectively to aid the jump.
Allowing the knees to cave inward upon landing.

name: Dip Machine
instructions: Sit securely in a dip machine, select the weight and firmly grasp the handles.
Now keep your elbows in at your sides in order to place emphasis on the triceps. The elbows should be bent at a 90 degree angle.
As you contract the triceps, extend your arms downwards as you exhale. Tip: At the bottom of the movement, focus on keeping a little bend in your arms to keep tension on the triceps muscle.
Now slowly let your arms come back up to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The dip machine can exacerbate symptoms due to the shoulder's range of motion and load. Exercise should be avoided or modified.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension of the elbow can aggravate tendinitis. Consider modifications or alternative exercises.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical protocols often restrict weight-bearing exercises. Clearance from a healthcare provider is necessary.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The load on the upper body may increase the risk of fractures. Exercise should be avoided or significantly modified.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or assistive dip machine setting to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform bodyweight dips on parallel bars for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit range of motion to avoid deep flexion and use lighter weights.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Focus on controlled movements and reduce weight to minimize stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat and handles are adjusted to fit your body size.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the bottom of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows close to your body throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid leaning forward excessively.
Exhale as you extend your arms and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to complete the movement instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing elbows to flare out, which can reduce triceps engagement and increase shoulder stress.
Locking out elbows at the bottom, which can increase joint stress.

name: Dips - Chest Version
instructions: For this exercise you will need access to parallel bars. To get yourself into the starting position, hold your body at arms length (arms locked) above the bars.
While breathing in, lower yourself slowly with your torso leaning forward around 30 degrees or so and your elbows flared out slightly until you feel a slight stretch in the chest.
Once you feel the stretch, use your chest to bring your body back to the starting position as you breathe out. Tip: Remember to squeeze the chest at the top of the movement for a second.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The forward lean and flared elbows can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The load on the triceps and elbow joint can worsen tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Supporting body weight on the wrists can increase discomfort for those with wrist issues.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of falls and the load on the upper body may be unsuitable for individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which may hinder recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform assisted dips using a dip machine or resistance bands to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a dip belt to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform bench dips with feet on the floor to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use padded grips or parallel bars with a neutral grip to minimize wrist extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bars are stable and can support your body weight.
Avoid excessive forward lean to prevent shoulder strain.
Warm up thoroughly before performing dips to prepare the shoulder joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Maintain a slight forward lean without excessive arching of the lower back.
Flare elbows slightly but do not let them go beyond a 45-degree angle from the body.
commonMistakes: Leaning too far forward, which can strain the shoulders.
Not controlling the descent, leading to a rapid drop and potential injury.
Locking elbows forcefully at the top, which can stress the joint.

name: Dips - Triceps Version
instructions: To get into the starting position, hold your body at arm's length with your arms nearly locked above the bars.

Now, inhale and slowly lower yourself downward. Your torso should remain upright and your elbows should stay close to your body. This helps to better focus on tricep involvement. Lower yourself until there is a 90 degree angle formed between the upper arm and forearm.
Then, exhale and push your torso back up using your triceps to bring your body back to the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to the shoulder joint's position during dips, which can exacerbate impingement.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate risk as the exercise places stress on the elbow joint, potentially aggravating tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Moderate risk due to weight-bearing on the wrists, which can exacerbate pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate risk as the wrist position during dips can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: High risk because the exercise involves significant shoulder movement and stabilization.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High risk due to the involvement of shoulder muscles and joints, which can hinder recovery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate risk due to potential for fractures under load.

modifications.easier: Perform dips with feet on the ground to reduce load on the arms.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a dip belt to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform tricep pushdowns with a resistance band to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a resistance band for tricep extensions to minimize joint stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform tricep kickbacks with dumbbells to avoid wrist extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure shoulders are warmed up before performing dips.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a controlled movement to prevent excessive joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body throughout the movement.
Maintain an upright torso to focus on triceps.
Lower until elbows are at a 90-degree angle.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out, which can increase shoulder stress.
Leaning forward excessively, shifting focus to the chest.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Donkey Calf Raises
instructions: For this exercise you will need access to a donkey calf raise machine. Start by positioning your lower back and hips under the padded lever provided. The tailbone area should be the one making contact with the pad.

Place both of your arms on the side handles and place the balls of your feet on the calf block with the heels extending off. Align the toes forward, inward or outward, depending on the area you wish to target, and straighten the knees without locking them. This will be your starting position.

Raise your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending at any time. Hold the contracted position by a second before you start to go back down.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering your heels as you bend the ankles until calves are stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

herniated disc.explanation: The forward bending position can exacerbate symptoms by increasing spinal pressure.

sciatica.explanation: The position may aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to increased lumbar flexion.

severe arthritis in the ankles.explanation: The exercise places significant stress on the ankle joint, potentially worsening symptoms.

recent ankle surgery.explanation: Healing tissues may be compromised by the load and range of motion required.

balance disorders.explanation: The elevated position on the calf block may increase the risk of falls.

modifications.easier: Perform standing calf raises with body weight only, using a wall or sturdy object for support.
modifications.harder: Perform single-leg donkey calf raises to increase difficulty and balance challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a seated calf raise machine to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform seated calf raises with a resistance band to limit ankle stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height to avoid excessive spinal flexion.
Use a controlled motion to prevent jerking movements that can strain the Achilles tendon.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support your lower back.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees to avoid locking them.
Focus on a full range of motion, raising onto the balls of your feet and lowering until a stretch is felt in the calves.
commonMistakes: Locking the knees, which can increase stress on the joint.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the heels to drop too quickly, which can strain the Achilles tendon.

name: Double Kettlebell Alternating Hang Clean
instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.
Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder and hold on to the other kettlebell.
With a fluid motion, lower the top kettlebell while driving the bottom kettlebell up.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The dynamic nature and spinal loading of this exercise can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis.

joint_issues.explanation: Individuals with arthritis or tendinitis, especially in the shoulders or wrists, may experience increased discomfort due to the repetitive lifting and lowering motion.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The exercise involves high-intensity movements that can elevate heart rate significantly, which may not be suitable for those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise's dynamic and balance-demanding nature poses a risk for pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries, particularly in the abdominal, spinal, or shoulder regions, may be compromised by the exercise's demands.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma, especially in the lower back, shoulders, or wrists, can be aggravated by this exercise.

modifications.easier: Single Kettlebell Hang Clean: Perform the exercise with one kettlebell to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Double Kettlebell Hang Clean to Press: Add an overhead press after the clean for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter kettlebell and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat portion and ensure proper knee alignment over toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the exercise if pain persists; consider substituting with a kettlebell deadlift to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before performing the exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without compromising form.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent back strain.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips explosively during the clean.
Keep your elbows close to your body as you lift the kettlebell.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift, which increases the risk of spinal injury.
Using too much arm strength instead of relying on hip drive.
Allowing the kettlebell to swing too far from the body, reducing control.

name: Double Kettlebell Jerk
instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle in each hand.

Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so, so that the palms face forward. This will be your starting position.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.
Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum.
As you do so, press the kettlebells overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weights.
Return your feet to the ground in a split fashion, with one foot forward and one foot back.
Keeping the weights overhead, return to a standing position, bringing your feet together. Lower the weights to perform the next repetition.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate shoulder impingement by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The dynamic overhead movement can increase inflammation and pain in the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The load and overhead position can increase cervical spine stress, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver and overhead lifting can spike blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the load and dynamic movement, risking re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The dip and drive phase can stress the knee joint, exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature and split stance require good balance, posing a risk for falls.

modifications.easier: Perform a single kettlebell push press, which reduces the load and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom of the dip.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated kettlebell press to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the dip depth or perform the exercise seated to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on strict form to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up, focusing on shoulder and hip mobility.
Start with lighter weights to master form before progressing.
Avoid locking out the knees during the dip to protect the joints.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels during the dip and drive phase.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in lumbar hyperextension.
Allowing the knees to cave inward during the dip.

name: Double Kettlebell Push Press
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders.
Squat down a few inches and reverse the motion rapidly. Use the momentum from the legs to drive the kettlebells overhead.
Once the kettlebells are locked out, lower the kettlebells to your shoulders and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The dynamic pressing motion may increase inflammation and pain in the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The overhead load can place additional stress on the cervical spine, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver and overhead lifting can spike blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the load and dynamic movement, risking re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The explosive nature of the exercise can strain the lumbar spine, particularly if core stability is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The need for coordination and balance increases the risk of falls or improper form in individuals with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Single Kettlebell Push Press: Use one kettlebell to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Double Kettlebell Jerk: Incorporate a deeper squat and more explosive drive for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated single-arm dumbbell press to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Use a back-supported seated press machine to minimize lumbar stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up focusing on shoulder and hip mobility.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without excessive strain.
Avoid locking out the elbows forcefully to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels and use leg power to assist the press.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in lumbar hyperextension.
Allowing the knees to cave in during the dip phase.

name: Double Kettlebell Snatch
instructions: Place two kettlebells behind your feet. Bend your knees and sit back to pick up the kettlebells.
Swing the kettlebells between your legs forcefully and reverse the direction.
Drive through with your hips and lock the ketttlebells overhead in one uninterrupted motion.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High overhead motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The dynamic nature of the snatch can strain the rotator cuff, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The overhead position and rapid movement can increase cervical spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The intense nature of the exercise can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Overhead lifting can disrupt healing post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The explosive hip drive and spinal loading can aggravate lower back issues.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic movement requires good balance and coordination.

modifications.easier: Single Kettlebell Snatch: Use one kettlebell to reduce load and complexity.
modifications.harder: Double Kettlebell Snatch with Pause: Add a pause at the top to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Kettlebell Swing: Focus on hip drive without the overhead component.
injury_friendly.back pain: Kettlebell Deadlift: Emphasize controlled lifting without the explosive snatch motion.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up focusing on shoulder and hip mobility.
Use appropriate weight to maintain control throughout the movement.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back during the overhead phase.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the hips explosively to generate upward momentum.
Lock the elbows at the top with the kettlebells directly over the shoulders.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the initial lift.
Using the arms instead of the hips to drive the kettlebells up.
Failing to lock out the elbows at the top.

name: Double Kettlebell Windmill
instructions: Place a kettlebell in front of your front foot and clean and press a kettlebell overhead with your opposite arm. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward.

Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, push your butt out in the direction of the locked out kettlebell. Turn your feet out at a forty-five degree angle from the arm with the locked out kettlebell.
Bending at the hip to one side, sticking your butt out, slowly lean until you can retrieve the kettlebell from the floor. Keep your eyes on the kettlebell that you hold over your head at all times.
Pause for a second after retrieving the kettlebell from the ground and reverse the motion back to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: The rotational and bending movements can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: Overhead positioning may aggravate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator_cuff_tendinitis: The overhead load can strain the rotator cuff, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The exercise requires significant balance and stability, posing a fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The bending and twisting motions could increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The exercise involves significant core engagement and balance, which may be challenging during pregnancy.
contraindicationDetails.acute_lower_back_pain: The exercise can put undue stress on the lower back, aggravating pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a single kettlebell overhead and use the other hand for balance support on the thigh.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise without weight, focusing on the movement pattern and core engagement.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid locking the kettlebell overhead.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before attempting this exercise.
Start with a lighter weight to master the form before progressing.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your eyes on the kettlebell overhead at all times.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Push your hips back as you lean to the side.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Using too heavy a weight before mastering the form.
Not keeping the arm fully extended overhead.

name: Double Leg Butt Kick
instructions: Begin standing with your knees slightly bent.
Quickly squat a short distance, flexing the hips and knees, and immediately extend to jump for maximum vertical height.
As you go up, tuck your heels by flexing the knees, attempting to touch the buttocks.
Finish the motion by landing with the knees only partially bent, using your legs to absorb the impact.

spinal injuries.explanation: Jumping and landing impact can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or sciatica.

knee joint issues.explanation: High-impact nature of the exercise can worsen arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis.

cardiovascular conditions.explanation: Exercise increases heart rate significantly, which may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: Jumping can increase intra-abdominal pressure and risk of falls, especially in later stages.

acute injuries.explanation: Recent sprains or strains can be aggravated by the impact and dynamic movement.

balance disorders.explanation: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, posing a fall risk.

safetyNotes: Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare muscles and joints for impact.
Perform on a soft surface to reduce joint stress.
Stop immediately if you experience pain or discomfort.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Keep the chest up and shoulders back throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Landing with locked knees, increasing joint stress.
Allowing the torso to collapse forward, which can strain the lower back.
Failing to engage core muscles, leading to poor balance and control.

modifications.easier: Perform butt kicks without jumping, focusing on bringing heels to the buttocks while marching in place.
modifications.harder: Add a tuck jump by bringing knees to the chest before extending legs to kick the buttocks.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform butt kicks while walking or marching in place to reduce impact.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit range of motion and avoid jumping; focus on controlled heel lifts.

name: Downward Facing Balance
instructions: Lie facedown on top of an exercise ball.
While resting on your stomach on the ball, walk your hands forward along the floor and lift your legs, extending your elbows and knees.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The exercise involves spinal extension and stabilization, which can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The position may increase nerve tension and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: moderate - Weight bearing on the shoulders can aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: high - Lying prone on the ball can be uncomfortable and unsafe, especially in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: high - The exercise requires significant balance and coordination.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with the ball closer to the hips for more stability and support.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise with one leg lifted higher for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with the ball under the hips and limit the range of motion to avoid excessive spinal extension.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Place a cushion under the hands to reduce pressure on the shoulders.

safetyNotes: Ensure the exercise ball is properly inflated and stable.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back to prevent strain.
Maintain a controlled movement to prevent falling off the ball.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Keep the neck in a neutral position, aligned with the spine.
Extend the legs fully without locking the knees.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to sag excessively.
Failing to engage the core muscles.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.

name: Drag Curl
instructions: Grab a barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing forward) and get your elbows close to your torso and back. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, curl the bar up while keeping the elbows to the back as you "Drag" the bar up by keeping it in contact with your torso. Tip: As you can see, you will not be keeping the elbows pinned to your sides, but instead you will be bringing them back. Also, do not lift your shoulders.
Slowly go back to the starting position as you keep the bar in contact with the torso at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The movement may cause further compression of the shoulder structures.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Supinated grip can strain the wrist, worsening existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the barbell can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise may place undue stress on the rotator cuff muscles.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize shoulder involvement.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use an EZ curl bar to reduce wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the elbows and wrists.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to reduce stress on the joints.
formCues: Keep the bar in contact with your torso throughout the movement.
Do not allow your shoulders to rise during the curl.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the bar instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing bicep activation.
Lifting the shoulders during the curl, which can lead to shoulder strain.

name: Drop Push
instructions: Position low boxes or other platforms 2-3 feet apart.
Move to a pushup position between them, supporting yourself by placing your hands on the boxes.
With good posture, drop from the platforms by pressing up and moving your hands to shoulder width, cushioning your landing by absorbing the impact through the arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The rapid movement and impact absorption can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The dynamic nature of the exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, increasing the risk of aggravation.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The impact on landing can worsen symptoms of tendinitis in the wrist.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrist during landing can aggravate carpal tunnel symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The impact from the drop can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or wrist pain: Performing this exercise with acute pain can lead to further injury.

modifications.easier: Perform regular push-ups on the floor or incline push-ups using a bench to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the platforms or add a clap between the drop and landing for more advanced plyometric training.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform push-ups on a soft surface or with push-up handles to reduce wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the platforms are stable and non-slip to prevent accidents.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the joints and muscles for impact.
Avoid locking elbows upon landing to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Engage the core to maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Land softly by bending the elbows and absorbing the impact with the arms.
Keep the shoulders down and back to avoid excessive strain.
commonMistakes: Landing with locked elbows, increasing joint stress.
Allowing the lower back to sag, leading to potential strain.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in loss of control.

name: Dumbbell Alternate Bicep Curl
instructions: Stand (torso upright) with a dumbbell in each hand held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso and the palms of your hand should be facing your thighs.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the right weight as you rotate the palm of the hands until they are facing forward. At this point continue contracting the biceps as you breathe out until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbell back to the starting position as your breathe in. Tip: Remember to twist the palms back to the starting position (facing your thighs) as you come down.
Repeat the movement with the left hand. This equals one repetition.
Continue alternating in this manner for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High severity. The repetitive motion and load on the elbow joint can exacerbate inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The exercise can be performed with caution, ensuring no excessive shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate severity. Gripping the dumbbell tightly can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Moderate severity. Avoid if there is pain during the exercise; consider lighter weights and controlled motion.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High severity. The risk of fracture due to bone fragility may be increased with improper form or excessive weight.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load on the joints.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise seated on an incline bench to increase range of motion and challenge the biceps more.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip (hammer curl) to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, avoiding full extension of the arm.

safetyNotes: Avoid swinging the body or using momentum to lift the weights.
Keep the elbows close to the torso to minimize shoulder involvement.
Select an appropriate weight to avoid straining the biceps and forearm muscles.
formCues: Keep your torso upright and stable throughout the movement.
Rotate the palm smoothly as you curl the weight up.
Focus on contracting the biceps at the top of the movement.
Lower the weight slowly and with control.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the torso.
Swinging the body to assist in lifting the weight.
Not fully rotating the wrist during the curl.

name: Dumbbell Bench Press
instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand resting on top of your thighs. The palms of your hands will be facing each other.
Then, using your thighs to help raise the dumbbells up, lift the dumbbells one at a time so that you can hold them in front of you at shoulder width.

Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. The dumbbells should be just to the sides of your chest, with your upper arm and forearm creating a 90 degree angle. Be sure to maintain full control of the dumbbells at all times. This will be your starting position.

Then, as you breathe out, use your chest to push the dumbbells up. Lock your arms at the top of the lift and squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then begin coming down slowly. Tip: Ideally, lowering the weight should take about twice as long as raising it.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate symptoms of shoulder impingement by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid heavy lifting that could increase the risk of fractures, especially in the spine and upper body.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often performed unconsciously during heavy lifting, can dangerously increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to re-injury; therefore, heavy lifting should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a resistance band to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a floor press variation to limit the range of motion and reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure feet are flat on the floor and engage the core to stabilize the spine, or perform on a decline bench to reduce lumbar stress.

safetyNotes: Always use a spotter when lifting heavy weights.
Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbows forcefully at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the floor to maintain stability.
Engage your core throughout the movement to protect your lower back.
Lower the dumbbells slowly and under control to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can increase shoulder stress.
Bouncing the dumbbells off the chest to gain momentum.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.

name: Dumbbell Bench Press with Neutral Grip
instructions: Take a dumbbell in each hand and lay back onto a flat bench. Your feet should be flat on the floor and your shoulder blades retracted.
Maintaining a neutral grip, palms facing each other, begin with your arms extended directly above you, perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing the elbow, lowering the upper arms to the side. Descend until the dumbbells are to your torso.
Pause, then extend the elbow and return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The neutral grip can reduce stress on the shoulder, but individuals with impingement may still experience discomfort due to the range of motion involved.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise involves shoulder stabilization, which can exacerbate existing rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and pressing motion can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow region.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Those with osteoporosis should be cautious with any weight-bearing exercise that could risk fracture.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that stress the shoulder joint until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to target the upper chest more intensely.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort or perform the exercise with a resistance band.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support by using a bench with lumbar support or performing the exercise on the floor.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before beginning the exercise.
Avoid arching the lower back excessively during the lift.
Maintain a controlled motion throughout the exercise to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your shoulder blades retracted and pressed against the bench.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid unnecessary strain.
Exhale as you press the dumbbells up and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can increase shoulder stress.
Bouncing the dumbbells off the chest instead of controlling the descent.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of muscle strength.

name: Dumbbell Bicep Curl
instructions: Stand up straight with a dumbbell in each hand at arm's length. Keep your elbows close to your torso and rotate the palms of your hands until they are facing forward. This will be your starting position.

Now, keeping the upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the weights while contracting your biceps. Continue to raise the weights until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a brief pause as you squeeze your biceps.
Then, inhale and slowly begin to lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High severity; repetitive flexion can exacerbate inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity; maintaining proper form is crucial to avoid exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate severity; gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Moderate severity; stabilization of the shoulder joint may be compromised.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High severity; risk of fracture due to bone fragility.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase or use a resistance band for added tension.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip (hammer curl) to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
