injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Avoid swinging the weights to prevent strain on the lower back.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to reduce stress on the forearm and wrist.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Focus on a controlled movement, especially during the lowering phase.
Engage the core to maintain stability and prevent swaying.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the body.
Hyperextending the wrists during the curl.

name: Dumbbell Clean
instructions: Begin standing with a dumbbell in each hand with your feet shoulder width apart.
Lower the weights to the floor by flexing at the hips and knees, pushing your hips back until the dumbbells reach the floor. This will be your starting position.

To initiate the movement, violently jump upward by extending the hips, knees, and ankles to acclerate the weights upward. Maintaining a neutral grip on the dumbbells, keep the arms straight until full extension is reached.
After full extension, rebend the hips and knees to receive the weight in a squat position. Allow the arms to bend, guiding the dumbbells to your shoulders.
Upon receiving the weight in the squat position, extend the hips and knees to finish in a standing position with the weights on your shoulders.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and shear forces.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or shoulder arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before attempting this exercise due to its high-intensity nature.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid heavy lifting and exercises that could affect balance, especially in the third trimester.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery, particularly involving the spine, knees, or shoulders, requires clearance from a healthcare provider before performing this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis patients should avoid high-impact and heavy lifting exercises to prevent fractures.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to prevent further injury.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls; modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang clean variation, starting with the dumbbells at knee height instead of the floor.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise with a barbell for added complexity.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with lighter weights and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat and ensure proper knee alignment over the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the overhead press portion and focus on the clean movement only.

safetyNotes: Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints for explosive movements.
Use a weight that allows for control throughout the exercise to prevent injury.
Maintain a neutral spine position to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the heels and extend the hips explosively.
Keep the dumbbells close to the body during the lift.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using the arms to lift instead of driving with the legs and hips.
Landing with the knees caving inward.

name: Dumbbell Floor Press
instructions: Lay on the floor holding dumbbells in your hands. Your knees can be bent. Begin with the weights fully extended above you.
Lower the weights until your upper arm comes in contact with the floor. You can tuck your elbows to emphasize triceps size and strength, or to focus on your chest angle your arms to the side.
Pause at the bottom, and then bring the weight together at the top by extending through the elbows.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The exercise involves shoulder movement that may exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The pressing motion can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise can place stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells may increase wrist strain, exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by the stress of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The load and position may increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Use lighter dumbbells or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on a bench to increase range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with elbows tucked closer to the body to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip to minimize stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weights are manageable to avoid dropping them.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
Avoid arching the lower back excessively.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Lower the weights slowly and with control.
Pause briefly when your upper arms touch the floor before pressing back up.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Failing to maintain a stable shoulder position.

name: Dumbbell Flyes
instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell on each hand resting on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.

Then using your thighs to help raise the dumbbells, lift the dumbbells one at a time so you can hold them in front of you at shoulder width with the palms of your hands facing each other. Raise the dumbbells up like you're pressing them, but stop and hold just before you lock out. This will be your starting position.

With a slight bend on your elbows in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon, lower your arms out at both sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, the arms should remain stationary; the movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.
Return your arms back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and breathe out. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
contraindications: severe arthritis in the shoulder joint

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The wide arc of motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen existing tears or inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of fracture increases with the stress placed on the bones during the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or chest injury: Performing this exercise can aggravate injuries due to the stretch and load on the muscles.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the shoulder joint: The movement may cause pain and further joint degradation.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion and difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a floor fly with limited range of motion to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lower back support by using a bench with lumbar support or performing on the floor.

safetyNotes: Avoid locking the elbows to prevent undue stress on the joints.
Maintain a controlled motion to prevent shoulder strain.
Do not lower the dumbbells too far to avoid excessive shoulder stretch.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the chest muscles as you bring the dumbbells together.
Ensure the movement is slow and controlled, especially when lowering the weights.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to lock out.
Using momentum to lift the weights.
Lowering the dumbbells too quickly or too far.

name: Dumbbell Incline Row
instructions: Using a neutral grip, lean into an incline bench.
Take a dumbbell in each hand with a neutral grip, beginning with the arms straight. This will be your starting position.
Retract the shoulder blades and flex the elbows to row the dumbbells to your side.
Pause at the top of the motion, and then return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward-leaning position and spinal loading can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The position may increase spinal compression and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase lumbar spine stress, worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The rowing motion may aggravate shoulder impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: The prone position and exertion can elevate blood pressure further.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which may not be suitable during recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle of the bench or use heavier dumbbells to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with a chest-supported row machine to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid excessive shoulder retraction.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at a comfortable incline angle.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent back strain.
Avoid jerking the weights to prevent shoulder and back injuries.
formCues: Keep your chest pressed against the bench to maintain stability.
Retract your shoulder blades fully at the top of the movement.
Exhale as you lift the weights and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled movements.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.
Arching the back or lifting the chest off the bench.

name: Dumbbell Incline Shoulder Raise
instructions: Sit on an Incline Bench while holding a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs.

Lift your legs up to kick the weights to your shoulders and lean back. Position the dumbbells above your shoulders with your arms extended. The arms should be perpendicular to the floor with your palms facing forward and knuckles pointing towards the ceiling. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the arms straight and locked, lift the dumbbells by raising the shoulders from the bench as you breathe out.
Bring back the dumbbells to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead nature of this exercise can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Lifting weights overhead can increase stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially worsening inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The incline position and shoulder elevation may place additional strain on the cervical spine, aggravating existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is increased with overhead movements, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead exercises can lead to increased blood pressure, which may be risky for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle of the bench to 45 degrees or use heavier dumbbells.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated lateral raise with lighter weights to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.cervical spine issues: Use a lower incline angle to decrease neck strain, or perform standing lateral raises.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is securely positioned and stable before starting the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbows completely to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent back strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your body.
Lift the weights using your shoulders, not your arms.
Exhale as you lift the weights and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Allowing the elbows to bend excessively, turning the movement into a press.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.

name: Dumbbell Lunges
instructions: Stand with your torso upright holding two dumbbells in your hands by your sides. This will be your starting position.

Step forward with your right leg around 2 feet or so from the foot being left stationary behind and lower your upper body down, while keeping the torso upright and maintaining balance. Inhale as you go down. Note: As in the other exercises, do not allow your knee to go forward beyond your toes as you come down, as this will put undue stress on the knee joint. Make sure that you keep your front shin perpendicular to the ground.
Using mainly the heel of your foot, push up and go back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat the movement for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform with the left leg.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: Lunges can exacerbate knee pain due to increased joint loading, especially if form is compromised.

patellar tendinitis.explanation: The exercise may increase strain on the patellar tendon, worsening symptoms.

ankle instability.explanation: The forward stepping motion can challenge ankle stability, risking further injury.

severe balance disorders.explanation: The dynamic movement requires good balance, posing a fall risk.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the stress of lunges, risking re-injury.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper footwear to provide adequate support and traction.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for exercise.
Avoid lunges if experiencing acute pain in the knees or ankles.
formCues: Keep the torso upright throughout the movement.
Ensure the front knee does not extend past the toes.
Engage the core to maintain balance and stability.
Push through the heel of the front foot to return to starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to extend past the toes.
Leaning the torso too far forward.
Not maintaining a straight line from head to tailbone.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

modifications.easier: Perform lunges without weights to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Use a barbell instead of dumbbells to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform reverse lunges to reduce anterior knee stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a split squat variation to minimize forward lean and spinal load.

name: Dumbbell Lying One-Arm Rear Lateral Raise
instructions: While holding a dumbbell in one hand, lay with your chest down on a slightly inclined (around 15 degrees when measured from the floor) adjustable bench. The other hand can be used to hold to the leg of the bench for stability.

Position the palm of the hand that is holding the dumbbell in a neutral manner (palms facing your torso) as you keep the arm extended with the elbow slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the arm with the dumbbell to the side until your elbow is at shoulder height and your arm is roughly parallel to the floor as you exhale. Tip: Maintain your arm perpendicular to the torso while keeping your arm extended throughout the movement. Also, keep the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly lower the dumbbell to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and lateral movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the tendons in the shoulder.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying prone on an incline bench can strain the neck, especially if the head is not properly supported.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture increases with osteoporosis, especially with exercises involving weight-bearing on the upper body.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder injuries: Any recent trauma or inflammation in the shoulder should be fully healed before performing this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or without a dumbbell to focus on form and range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with both arms simultaneously for added challenge.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a resistance band instead of a dumbbell to reduce joint stress and allow for a more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and set at the correct incline to avoid unnecessary strain on the lower back.
Avoid using excessive weight, which can compromise form and increase the risk of injury.
formCues: Keep the elbow slightly bent throughout the movement to reduce stress on the joint.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid arching the back.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulder to internally rotate, which can lead to impingement.
Neglecting to keep the core engaged, leading to instability.

name: Dumbbell Lying Pronation
instructions: Lie on a flat bench face down with one arm holding a dumbbell and the other hand on top of the bench folded so that you can rest your head on it.
Bend the elbows of the arm holding the dumbbell so that it creates a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm.

Now raise the upper arm so that the forearm is perpendicular to the floor and the upper arm is perpendicular to your torso. Tip: The upper arm should be parallel to the floor and also creating a 90-degree angle with your torso. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, externally rotate your forearm so that the dumbbell is lifted forward as you maintain the 90 degree angle bend between the upper arms and the forearm. You will continue this external rotation until the forearm is parallel to the floor. At this point you will hold the contraction for a second.
As you breathe in, slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The external rotation involved in this exercise can exacerbate symptoms of shoulder impingement, leading to increased pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The rotational movement may aggravate the tendons of the rotator cuff, especially if there is existing inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Holding and rotating the dumbbell can place stress on the elbow joint, potentially worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure on the median nerve, exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute forearm strain: The exercise places direct stress on the forearm muscles, which can worsen an acute strain.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter dumbbell or perform the exercise without weights to focus on the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or add a pause at the top of the movement for added time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a dumbbell to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full pronation and reduce stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and positioned correctly to avoid slipping.
Do not use excessive weight as it can compromise form and increase injury risk.
Warm up adequately before performing the exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep the upper arm parallel to the floor throughout the movement.
Maintain a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and forearm.
Rotate the forearm slowly and with control to avoid jerking motions.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the dumbbell instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the upper arm to drop below parallel to the floor.
Over-rotating the forearm beyond parallel to the floor.

name: Dumbbell Lying Rear Lateral Raise
instructions: While holding a dumbbell in each hand, lay with your chest down on a slightly inclined (around 15 degrees when measured from the floor) adjustable bench.
Position the palms of the hands in a neutral manner (palms facing your torso) as you keep the arms extended with the elbows slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the arms to the side until your elbows are at shoulder height and your arms are roughly parallel to the floor as you exhale. Tip: Maintain your arms perpendicular to the torso while keeping them extended throughout the movement. Also, keep the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly lower the dumbbells to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch to the other arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms laterally can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves shoulder abduction, which can irritate an inflamed rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying prone can increase cervical spine stress, especially if the neck is not properly supported.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The prone position and weight-bearing on the arms can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder injuries: Any acute injury to the shoulder may be aggravated by the movement and load of this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights or with lighter resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline of the bench to 30 degrees to increase the range of motion and muscle activation.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, focusing on scapular retraction without full arm lift for those with shoulder pain.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Ensure the bench is stable and properly inclined.
Do not hyperextend the neck; keep it neutral.
formCues: Keep elbows slightly bent throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together at the top of the lift.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid arching the back.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to drop below shoulder level.
Raising the head or hyperextending the neck.

name: Dumbbell Lying Supination
instructions: Lie sideways on a flat bench with one arm holding a dumbbell and the other hand on top of the bench folded so that you can rest your head on it.
Bend the elbows of the arm holding the dumbbell so that it creates a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm.

Now raise the upper arm so that the forearm is parallel to the floor and perpendicular to your torso (Tip: So the forearm will be directly in front of you). The upper arm will be stationary by your torso and should be parallel to the floor (aligned with your torso at all times). This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, externally rotate your forearm so that the dumbbell is lifted up in a semicircle motion as you maintain the 90 degree angle bend between the upper arms and the forearm. You will continue this external rotation until the forearm is perpendicular to the floor and the torso pointing towards the ceiling. At this point you will hold the contraction for a second.
As you breathe in, slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch to the other arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: External rotation of the shoulder can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves external rotation which can strain inflamed rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Holding and rotating a dumbbell can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow, particularly lateral epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell may increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute forearm strain: The exercise places stress on the forearm muscles, which can worsen an existing strain.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter dumbbell or perform the exercise without weights to focus on the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a resistance band to reduce joint stress and allow for a more controlled movement.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on a smaller range of motion to minimize stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid using excessive weight which can compromise form and increase injury risk.
formCues: Keep the upper arm stationary and parallel to the torso throughout the movement.
Maintain a 90-degree angle at the elbow to ensure proper isolation of the forearm muscles.
Move slowly and with control, especially during the eccentric phase.
commonMistakes: Allowing the upper arm to move away from the torso, reducing isolation of the forearm.
Using momentum to swing the dumbbell instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Holding the breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure and affect stability.

name: Dumbbell One-Arm Shoulder Press
instructions: Grab a dumbbell and either sit on a military press bench or a utility bench that has a back support on it as you place the dumbbells upright on top of your thighs or stand up straight.
Clean the dumbbell up to bring it to shoulder height. The other hand can be kept fully extended to the side, by the waist or grabbing a fixed surface.
Rotate the wrist so that the palm of your hand is facing forward. This is your starting position.
As you exhale, push the dumbbell up until your arm is fully extended.
After a second pause, slowly come down back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch arms.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen inflammation or pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The exercise may strain the neck, especially if performed with poor posture or excessive weight.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Overhead lifting can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with compromised bone density.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead exercises can increase blood pressure, which may be risky for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated with a lighter dumbbell to reduce the load and improve stability.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise standing on one leg to increase core engagement.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder pain, perform a partial range of motion press, stopping before any discomfort occurs.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench or standing position provides adequate back support to prevent lumbar strain.
Avoid locking the elbow at the top of the press to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a neutral wrist position throughout the movement.
Exhale during the pressing phase and inhale during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the back to arch excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Flaring the elbow too far out, which can increase shoulder joint stress.

name: Dumbbell One-Arm Triceps Extension
instructions: Grab a dumbbell and either sit on a military press bench or a utility bench that has a back support on it as you place the dumbbells upright on top of your thighs or stand up straight.

Clean the dumbbell up to bring it to shoulder height and then extend the arm over your head so that the whole arm is perpendicular to the floor and next to your head. The dumbbell should be on top of you. The other hand can be kept fully extended to the side, by the waist, supporting the upper arm that has the dumbbell or grabbing a fixed surface.
Rotate the wrist so that the palm of your hand is facing forward and the pinkie is facing the ceiling. This will be your starting position.
Slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head as you hold the upper arm stationary. Inhale as you perform this movement and pause when your triceps are fully stretched.
Return to the starting position by flexing your triceps as you breathe out. Tip: It is imperative that only the forearm moves. The upper arm should remain at all times stationary next to your head.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and switch arms.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the elbow joint, potentially aggravating tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Overhead movements can strain the rotator cuff, especially if the shoulder is unstable.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell tightly can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding heavy lifting and overhead movements until cleared by a physician.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The seated position with weight overhead may increase spinal compression.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Overhead lifting can exacerbate symptoms due to increased spinal loading.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter dumbbell or use a resistance band for less strain.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise standing on one leg to engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a lying triceps extension to reduce shoulder involvement.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip to minimize stress on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure the dumbbell is securely gripped to prevent dropping.
Avoid excessive arching of the back by engaging the core.
Do not lock the elbow at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep the upper arm stationary and close to the head.
Move only the forearm during the exercise.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to flare out, which reduces triceps activation.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled movement.
Failing to keep the core engaged, leading to excessive back arching.

name: Dumbbell One-Arm Upright Row
instructions: Grab a dumbbell and stand up straight with your arm extended in front of you with a slight bend at the elbows and your back straight. This will be your starting position. Tip: The dumbbell should be resting on top of your thigh with the palm of your hands facing your thighs.
Keep the other hand can be kept fully extended to the side, by the waist or grabbing a fixed surface. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the dumbbell as you exhale. The dumbbell should be close to the body as you move it up. Continue to lift it until the dumbbell is nearly in line with your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the dumbbell, your elbow should always be higher than your forearm. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the dumbbell back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and switch arms.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The upright row position can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the internal rotation and elevation of the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The exercise requires stabilization of the neck and upper back, which can be problematic for individuals with cervical spine issues.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with weight-bearing exercises that involve the shoulders and upper back.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and lifting motion can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slow tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid lifting the elbow above shoulder height.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder and elbow strain.
Maintain a neutral spine position to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep the dumbbell close to the body during the lift.
Lead with the elbow, ensuring it stays higher than the forearm.
Engage the core to maintain a stable torso.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight, which reduces muscle engagement.
Allowing the elbows to drop below the forearm, increasing shoulder strain.
Rounding the back or leaning forward during the lift.

name: Dumbbell Prone Incline Curl
instructions: Grab a dumbbell on each hand and lie face down on an incline bench with your shoulders near top of the incline. Your knees can rest on the seat or your legs can be straddled to the sides (my preferred way).
Let your arms extend and hang naturally in front of you so that they are perpendicular to the floor.
Now keep your elbows in by your side and face the palms forward. This will be your starting position.

Raise the dumbbells by contracting the biceps until your arms are fully flexed. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement and ensure that only the forearms move. The upper arms should remain stationary at all times.
Lower the dumbbells until your arms are fully extended.
Repeat for the recommended amount of times.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position on the incline bench may place stress on the shoulder joint, potentially worsening impingement.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure on the median nerve, aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise may strain the shoulder stabilizers, increasing the risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is heightened due to the load on the arms and shoulders.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Lying prone on an incline bench can place stress on the spine, particularly if there is a pre-existing condition.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a more upright bench position to reduce spinal stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort at the shoulder joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at the correct incline to prevent slipping.
Avoid using excessive weight that could compromise form.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body throughout the movement.
Focus on contracting the biceps without swinging the arms.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Arching the back excessively during the lift.

name: Dumbbell Raise
instructions: Grab a dumbbell in each arm and stand up straight with your arms extended by your sides with a slight bend at the elbows and your back straight. This will be your starting position. Tip: The dumbbell should be next to your thighs with the palm of your hands facing back.

Use your side shoulders to lift the dumbbells as you exhale. The dumbbells should be to the side of the body as you move them up. Continue to lift it until the dumbbells are nearly in line with your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the dumbbell, your elbow should always be higher than your forearm. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: This exercise may aggravate tendinitis due to repetitive overhead movements.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights and lifting them can strain the neck, especially if posture is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to potential falls or improper handling of weights.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Holding breath during exertion (Valsalva maneuver) can increase blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the movement or increase the weight.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, lifting only to shoulder height.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to protect the lower back.
Do not lock the elbows to avoid joint stress.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Lead with the elbows, keeping them slightly bent.
Lift the dumbbells smoothly and control the descent.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Shrugging the shoulders during the lift.
Allowing the wrists to bend excessively.

name: Dumbbell Rear Lunge
instructions: Stand with your torso upright holding two dumbbells in your hands by your sides. This will be your starting position.

Step backward with your right leg around two feet or so from the left foot and lower your upper body down, while keeping the torso upright and maintaining balance. Inhale as you go down. Tip: As in the other exercises, do not allow your knee to go forward beyond your toes as you come down, as this will put undue stress on the knee joint. Make sure that you keep your front shin perpendicular to the ground. Keep the torso upright during the lunge; flexible hip flexors are important. A long lunge emphasizes the Gluteus Maximus; a short lunge emphasizes Quadriceps.
Push up and go back to the starting position as you exhale. Tip: Use the ball of your feet to push in order to accentuate the quadriceps. To focus on the glutes, press with your heels.
Now repeat with the opposite leg.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The rear lunge places significant stress on the knee joint, which can exacerbate symptoms of osteoarthritis.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The exercise involves repetitive knee flexion and extension, potentially aggravating tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Stepping backward requires ankle stability, which may be compromised in individuals with instability.
contraindicationDetails.severe balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise can challenge balance, posing a risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery may not tolerate the stress and range of motion required by lunges.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The exercise can increase spinal load, potentially worsening disc herniation symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Lunges may exacerbate sciatic nerve irritation due to hip and spinal positioning.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: The movement may increase joint stress, aggravating arthritic symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights or use a TRX system for support.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the lunge and ensure the knee does not pass the toes.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on maintaining a neutral spine and consider reducing weight or range of motion.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform stationary lunges to minimize ankle movement.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing lunges to prepare the joints and muscles.
Avoid lunging too far back, which can destabilize the movement and increase injury risk.
Ensure proper footwear to provide adequate support and cushioning.
formCues: Keep your torso upright and core engaged throughout the movement.
Step back far enough to create a 90-degree angle at both knees.
Push through the heel of the front foot to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to extend past the toes, increasing knee joint stress.
Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement, reducing effectiveness and increasing injury risk.

name: Dumbbell Scaption
instructions: This corrective exercise strengthens the muscles that stabilize your shoulder blade. Hold a light weight in each hand, hanging at your sides. Your thumbs should pointing up.
Begin the movement raising your arms out in front of you, about 30 degrees off center. Your arms should be fully extended as you perform the movement.
Continue until your arms are parallel to the ground, and then return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms can exacerbate impingement symptoms by further compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may increase inflammation or irritation of the tendons involved in the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights and lifting arms can strain the neck, potentially worsening cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures increases with osteoporosis, especially with overhead movements.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not be ready for the stress of this exercise, risking re-injury.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise with a slow tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise lying supine on a bench to reduce shoulder joint stress and provide support.

safetyNotes: Start with light weights to ensure proper form and reduce injury risk.
Avoid lifting weights above shoulder level if experiencing pain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent neck strain.
formCues: Keep your thumbs pointing up to promote external rotation of the shoulder.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Lift your arms in a controlled manner, avoiding any jerky movements.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight, leading to compromised form.
Raising the arms too high, which can cause shoulder impingement.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug during the lift, which shifts focus away from the target muscles.

name: Dumbbell Seated Box Jump
instructions: Position a box a couple feet to the side of a bench. Hold a dumbbell to your chest with both hands and seat yourself on the bench facing the box. This will be your starting position.
Plant your feet firmly on the ground as you lean forward, extending through the hips and knees to jump up and forward.
Land on the box with both feet, absorbing the impact by allowing the hips and knees to bend.
Step down and return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact landing can exacerbate joint pain and degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: Jumping and landing can increase stress on the patellar tendon.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Landing impact may lead to further instability or injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe balance disorders: Jumping requires significant balance and coordination, increasing fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may be compromised by impact forces.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Jumping with a load can increase spinal compression and exacerbate conditions.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular conditions: Sudden exertion can increase heart rate and blood pressure significantly.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Balance and impact concerns, especially in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High-impact activities increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight seated box jump without the dumbbell.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the box or use a heavier dumbbell.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a step-up onto the box instead of a jump.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce box height and focus on controlled step-ups.
injury_friendly.ankle instability: Use a lower box and perform step-ups with a focus on balance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and on a non-slip surface.
Warm up thoroughly before performing plyometric exercises.
Use appropriate footwear to provide support and cushioning.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Land softly on the box, absorbing impact with the knees and hips.
Maintain a neutral spine position during the jump and landing.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inwards upon landing.
Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Using momentum rather than controlled power to jump.

name: Dumbbell Seated One-Leg Calf Raise
instructions: Place a block on the floor about 12 inches from a flat bench.
Sit on a flat bench and place a dumbbell on your upper left thigh about 3 inches above your knee.
Now place the ball of your left foot on the block. This will be your starting position.
Raise your toes up as high as possible as you exhale and you contract your calf muscle. Hold the contraction for a second.
Slowly return to the starting position, stretching as far down as possible.
Repeat for your prescribed number of repetitions and then repeat with the right leg.

contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: The exercise places significant load on the ankle joint, which may exacerbate instability.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Single-leg stance increases the risk of falls in individuals with balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle or foot surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the load and range of motion required.
contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: The exercise can aggravate the Achilles tendon due to repetitive loading.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: Pressure on the forefoot can worsen plantar fascia inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.severe knee osteoarthritis: Weight-bearing on a single leg may increase knee joint stress.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a dumbbell to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper posture by engaging core muscles to support the spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit range of motion to a comfortable level or perform seated calf raises with both legs.

safetyNotes: Ensure the block is stable and non-slip to prevent accidents.
Avoid locking the knee of the working leg to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Press through the ball of the foot to lift the heel.
Avoid bouncing at the top of the movement; control the descent.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Allowing the knee to collapse inward.
Neglecting to hold the contraction at the top of the lift.

name: Dumbbell Shoulder Press
instructions: While holding a dumbbell in each hand, sit on a military press bench or utility bench that has back support. Place the dumbbells upright on top of your thighs.
Now raise the dumbbells to shoulder height one at a time using your thighs to help propel them up into position.
Make sure to rotate your wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing forward. This is your starting position.
Now, exhale and push the dumbbells upward until they touch at the top.
Then, after a brief pause at the top contracted position, slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Sitting with poor posture or using excessive weight can strain the cervical spine, worsening existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The load and overhead position increase the risk of fractures, especially in the spine and shoulder girdle.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead pressing can increase blood pressure significantly, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise should be avoided during the initial recovery phase to prevent re-injury or complications.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce strain on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing to engage core stabilizers or use a single-arm press to increase unilateral demand.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid pain, or use resistance bands to reduce joint loading.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support and maintain a neutral spine to minimize stress on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench has adequate back support to prevent hyperextension of the spine.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Use a controlled motion to prevent shoulder strain and maintain muscle engagement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement to stabilize the torso.
Align your wrists directly above your elbows to maintain proper joint alignment.
Press the dumbbells upward in a straight line, avoiding excessive arching of the back.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulder joints.
Neglecting to engage the core, resulting in an unstable base and potential back strain.

name: Dumbbell Shrug
instructions: Stand erect with a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing your torso), arms extended on the sides.

Lift the dumbbells by elevating the shoulders as high as possible while you exhale. Hold the contraction at the top for a second. Tip: The arms should remain extended at all times. Refrain from using the biceps to help lift the dumbbells. Only the shoulders should be moving up and down.
Lower the dumbbells back to the original position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High shoulder elevation can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The load on the shoulders and neck during shrugs can aggravate conditions like cervical spondylosis or herniated discs in the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Elevating the shoulders under load can strain the rotator cuff muscles, particularly if there is an existing tear or tendinitis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform shrugs with a reduced range of motion, avoiding the top position where impingement is most likely.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Use a seated position with back support to minimize neck strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive weight to prevent strain on the neck and shoulders.
Maintain a neutral spine to reduce stress on the cervical region.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Lift your shoulders directly upwards without rolling them forward or backward.
Keep your head in a neutral position, avoiding forward head posture.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Allowing the shoulders to roll forward or backward.
Bending the elbows and using the biceps to assist in lifting.

name: Dumbbell Side Bend
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on the left hand (palms facing the torso) as you have the right hand holding your waist. Your feet should be placed at shoulder width. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your back straight and your head up, bend only at the waist to the right as far as possible. Breathe in as you bend to the side. Then hold for a second and come back up to the starting position as you exhale. Tip: Keep the rest of the body stationary.
Now repeat the movement but bending to the left instead. Hold for a second and come back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then change hands.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The lateral flexion movement can exacerbate disc herniation by increasing intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Side bending may compress the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase shear forces on the spine, potentially aggravating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Bending can irritate the sciatic nerve, leading to increased pain.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise may increase the risk of vertebral fractures due to lateral bending forces.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: The movement can strain healing tissues in the abdominal region.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights, focusing on the range of motion and control.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad to engage more stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform side bends seated on a bench to reduce spinal load and maintain better posture.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Hold the dumbbell with both hands in front of the body to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive lateral flexion to prevent spinal strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Do not use momentum to complete the exercise.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the bend.
Keep your shoulders level and avoid twisting.
Breathe in as you bend and exhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the weight.
Allowing the torso to twist instead of bending directly to the side.
Bending the knees excessively, which reduces the effectiveness of the exercise.

name: Dumbbell Squat
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.

Begin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise your torso as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High stress on the knee joint during squats can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The load on the knee tendons can worsen inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Requires stable ankle support to prevent further injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe balance disorders: Risk of falling due to instability during the movement.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the mechanical load.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Spinal loading can increase disc pressure and exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Improper form can increase lumbar strain and sciatic nerve irritation.

modifications.easier: Bodyweight squat without dumbbells to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Goblet squat holding a single dumbbell at chest level for increased core engagement.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform partial squats to reduce knee flexion range.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a wall squat variation to support the back.
injury_friendly.ankle instability: Perform squats on a stable surface or with ankle support.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid letting the knees cave inward (valgus collapse).
Ensure proper footwear to provide adequate support.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core before descending.
Drive through your heels to return to standing.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to extend past toes.
Rounding the lower back.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Dumbbell Squat To A Bench
instructions: Stand up straight with a flat bench behind you while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.

Begin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until you slightly touch the bench behind you. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High stress on the knee joint during squats can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The exercise involves knee flexion and extension, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Requires stable ankle support; instability can increase the risk of injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe balance disorders: Balance is crucial for safety; severe disorders can lead to falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires clearance from a healthcare provider before performing weight-bearing exercises.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Spinal loading and bending can increase intradiscal pressure, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Compression and flexion of the spine may aggravate sciatic nerve pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights or use a lighter weight to focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad to engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the depth of the squat and ensure knees do not pass the toes.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at an appropriate height to avoid excessive knee flexion.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent undue stress on the lower back.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Dumbbell Step Ups
instructions: Stand up straight while holding a dumbbell on each hand (palms facing the side of your legs).

Place the right foot on the elevated platform. Step on the platform by extending the hip and the knee of your right leg. Use the heel mainly to lift the rest of your body up and place the foot of the left leg on the platform as well. Breathe out as you execute the force required to come up.

Step down with the left leg by flexing the hip and knee of the right leg as you inhale. Return to the original standing position by placing the right foot of to next to the left foot on the initial position.
Repeat with the right leg for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform with the left leg.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High impact and load on the knee joint can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The exercise can increase stress on the patellar tendon, leading to pain.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Stepping up and down can challenge ankle stability, increasing the risk of injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe balance disorders: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, which may be compromised.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may be stressed by the load and movement pattern.
contraindicationDetails.hip osteoarthritis: The exercise can place stress on the hip joint, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lumbar spine issues: Holding weights and stepping can increase spinal load, potentially aggravating conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform the step-up without weights or use a lower platform.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the platform or use heavier dumbbells.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a lower step and focus on controlled movements.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use lighter weights and focus on core engagement to stabilize the spine.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform the exercise on a stable surface and consider ankle support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the platform is stable and non-slip.
Avoid locking the knee at the top of the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Drive through the heel of the stepping leg.
Keep the chest up and shoulders back.
Control the descent to minimize impact.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to cave inward (valgus collapse).
Using momentum instead of controlled strength.
Leaning too far forward, placing stress on the lower back.
Not fully engaging the stepping leg, leading to imbalance.

name: Dumbbell Tricep Extension -Pronated Grip
instructions: Lie down on a flat bench holding two dumbbells directly above your shoulders. Your arms should be fully extended and form a 90 degree angle from your torso and the floor.
The palms of your hands should be facing forward, and your elbows should be tucked in. This will be your starting position.
Now, inhale and slowly lower the dumbbells until they are near your ears. Be sure to keep your upper arms stationary and your elbows tucked in.
Then, exhale and use your triceps to return the weight to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position may exacerbate symptoms by compressing structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Stabilization of the shoulder joint is required, which can be challenging with a compromised rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Grip and wrist positioning may increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Any recent surgical intervention in the shoulder, elbow, or wrist may be compromised by the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with loading of the arms in a supine position.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with one dumbbell held in both hands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a decline bench to increase the range of motion and triceps engagement.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a controlled motion to avoid excessive momentum.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in and stationary throughout the movement.
Lower the dumbbells slowly to maintain control.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows outward, which can increase shoulder strain.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: Dynamic Back Stretch
instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight, swing them straight up in front of you 5-10 times, increasing the range of motion each time until your arms are above your head.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs or spinal stenosis should avoid excessive spinal extension and flexion, which can exacerbate symptoms.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: Swinging the arms overhead can aggravate shoulder impingement; modifications may be necessary to limit range of motion.

severe_osteoporosis.explanation: Rapid arm movements and spinal extension can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with severe osteoporosis.

recent_shoulder_surgery.explanation: Post-surgery individuals should avoid dynamic movements that could stress the healing tissues.

balance_disorders.explanation: Standing exercises may pose a fall risk; seated modifications are recommended.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Add light hand weights to increase resistance and muscle engagement.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion to avoid excessive spinal movement.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit arm elevation to shoulder height to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Warm up adequately before performing dynamic stretches.
Avoid jerky movements; focus on controlled swings.
Stop if you feel any pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support the spine.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Gradually increase the range of motion with each swing.
commonMistakes: Swinging the arms too quickly, causing loss of control.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Neglecting to engage the core muscles.

name: Dynamic Chest Stretch
instructions: Stand with your hands together, arms extended directly in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight, quickly move your arms back as far as possible and back in again, similar to an exaggerated clapping motion. Repeat 5-10 times, increasing speed as you do so.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The dynamic movement may exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the rapid motion and range of motion required.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise can place stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially worsening existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder bursitis: Inflammation of the bursa can be aggravated by repetitive arm movements.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Rapid arm movements could increase the risk of fractures in individuals with compromised bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent chest surgery: Healing tissues may be disrupted by the stretching and dynamic nature of the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise at a slower pace to reduce the intensity and range of motion.
modifications.harder: Add light resistance bands to increase the challenge by providing resistance during the arm movement.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion and slower speed to minimize stress on the shoulders.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive hyperextension of the arms to prevent shoulder strain.
Maintain a controlled speed to reduce the risk of injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Ensure your shoulders are relaxed and not elevated towards your ears.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to protect the joints.
commonMistakes: Moving too quickly, which can lead to loss of control and increased injury risk.
Allowing the shoulders to elevate, which can cause neck and shoulder tension.
Hyperextending the arms, placing undue stress on the shoulder joints.

name: EZ-Bar Curl
instructions: Stand up straight while holding an EZ curl bar at the wide outer handle. The palms of your hands should be facing forward and slightly tilted inward due to the shape of the bar. Keep your elbows close to your torso. This will be your starting position.
Now, while keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps. Focus on only moving your forearms.
Continue to raise the weight until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the top contracted position for a moment and squeeze the biceps.
Then inhale and slowly lower the bar back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The exercise may cause discomfort due to the position of the arms and potential shoulder elevation.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: Gripping the bar can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.

severe hypertension.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during lifting, can dangerously increase blood pressure.

wrist arthritis.explanation: The grip and wrist position may cause pain or discomfort in individuals with arthritis.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise seated to reduce strain on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slower tempo or add resistance bands for increased tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight or perform partial range of motion to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or a thicker bar to decrease stress on the wrists.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the elbows and wrists.
Maintain a neutral spine position to avoid lower back strain.
Do not lock the knees; keep them slightly bent to reduce pressure on the lower back.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Focus on moving only the forearms; avoid swinging the upper arms.
Exhale during the curl and inhale while lowering the bar.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to lift the weight, which reduces bicep engagement.
Allowing the elbows to drift forward, reducing tension on the biceps.
Using a grip that is too narrow or too wide, which can strain the wrists.

name: EZ-Bar Skullcrusher
instructions: Using a close grip, lift the EZ bar and hold it with your elbows in as you lie on the bench. Your arms should be perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the upper arms stationary, lower the bar by allowing the elbows to flex. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Pause once the bar is directly above the forehead.
Lift the bar back to the starting position by extending the elbow and exhaling.
Repeat.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow can exacerbate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms during the exercise may aggravate shoulder impingement.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Gripping the EZ-bar can place stress on the wrists, potentially worsening existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow or shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable and this exercise can place undue stress on healing structures.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture due to bone fragility is increased with the load and position of this exercise.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for more natural wrist positioning.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on a decline bench to increase the range of motion and challenge the triceps further.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip using dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use resistance bands instead of weights to decrease joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar does not drift too far back towards the head to avoid excessive shoulder strain.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in and stationary throughout the movement.
Lower the bar slowly and with control to just above the forehead.
Exhale as you extend the elbows to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Flaring the elbows out during the movement.
Using momentum to lift the bar instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the bar to drift too far back, increasing shoulder strain.

name: Elbow Circles
instructions: Sit or stand with your feet slightly apart.
Place your hands on your shoulders with your elbows at shoulder level and pointing out.
Slowly make a circle with your elbows. Breathe out as you start the circle and breathe in as you complete the circle.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to repetitive shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: High risk as the exercise can strain the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Moderate risk; may cause pain or discomfort in the shoulder joints.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High risk; avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Moderate risk; neck positioning may exacerbate symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with smaller circles to reduce the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed of the circles while maintaining control to add intensity.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce strain on the shoulders.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive speed to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent neck and back discomfort.
Stop if you experience any sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your elbows at shoulder height throughout the movement.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Move your elbows in a smooth, controlled manner.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to drop below shoulder level.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Arching the back or leaning forward.

name: Elbow to Knee
instructions: Lie on the floor, crossing your right leg across your bent left knee. Clasp your hands behind your head, beginning with your shoulder blades on the ground. This will be your starting position.
Perform the motion by flexing the spine and rotating your torso to bring the left elbow to the right knee.
Return to the starting position and repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

herniated disc.explanation: Flexion and rotation of the spine can exacerbate disc herniation and cause nerve impingement.

spinal stenosis.explanation: Spinal flexion may increase pressure on the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.

spondylolisthesis.explanation: Spinal flexion and rotation can increase instability in the vertebrae.

sciatica.explanation: Flexion and rotation can irritate the sciatic nerve, worsening symptoms.
