osteoporosis.explanation: Spinal flexion increases the risk of vertebral fractures.

recent abdominal surgery.explanation: The exercise places stress on the abdominal region, which can disrupt healing.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise may cause discomfort and is not recommended in later stages due to balance and core stability changes.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with the feet flat on the floor and knees bent, reducing the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight behind the head to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a seated twist with feet on the floor, keeping the spine neutral.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid crossing the legs and perform the movement with feet flat on the floor.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with your hands.
Maintain a neutral spine as much as possible.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you twist towards the knee.
Keep the movement controlled and avoid jerking.
commonMistakes: Pulling on the neck with hands.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: Elbows Back
instructions: Stand up straight.
Place both hands on your lower back, fingers pointing downward and elbows out.
Then gently pull your elbows back aiming to touch them together.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Pulling the elbows back may exacerbate impingement symptoms by further compressing the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: This exercise can strain the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening tears or inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder bursitis: The movement may increase inflammation and pain in the shoulder bursa.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The posture and movement could increase the risk of fractures, especially in the thoracic spine.
contraindicationDetails.recent thoracic or shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not be able to handle the stress of this movement, risking re-injury.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the demand on postural muscles.
modifications.harder: Add resistance by holding a light resistance band between the hands.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform a gentle chest stretch lying supine with a foam roller under the spine to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid forcing the elbows together; focus on a gentle stretch.
Discontinue if you experience sharp pain in the shoulders or chest.
formCues: Keep your shoulders relaxed and down, away from your ears.
Engage your core to maintain a neutral spine.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together gently.
commonMistakes: Overarching the lower back to compensate for limited shoulder mobility.
Forcing the elbows too far back, leading to potential shoulder strain.
Allowing the head to jut forward, causing neck strain.

name: Elevated Back Lunge
instructions: Position a bar onto a rack at shoulder height loaded to an appropriate weight. Place a short, raised platform behind you.
Rack the bar onto your upper back, keeping your back arched and tight. Step onto your raised platform with both feet. This will be your starting position.
Begin by stepping backwards with one leg. Descend by flexing your hips and knees until your knee touches the floor.
Pause, and extend through the hips and knees to rise up, returning all the way to the starting position before alternating.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial load and potential for exacerbating spinal compression.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce knee stress. Consider using a lighter weight or performing a partial range of motion.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing heavy compound lifts due to increased cardiovascular demand.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, particularly in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and increased intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the spine, knees, or hips require clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a barbell, using body weight only or holding dumbbells at your sides.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the lunge to reduce knee flexion and avoid any discomfort.

safetyNotes: Ensure the platform is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for the movement.
Avoid locking out the knees at the top of the movement to maintain muscle tension.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back to maintain a neutral spine.
Engage your core throughout the movement to stabilize the torso.
Control the descent and avoid letting the back knee slam into the ground.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to extend past the toes, which increases stress on the knee joint.
Rounding the back or leaning forward excessively, which can lead to spinal strain.
Using too much weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.

name: Elevated Cable Rows
instructions: Get a platform of some sort (it can be an aerobics or calf raise platform) that is around 4-6 inches in height.
Place it on the seat of the cable row machine.
Sit down on the machine and place your feet on the front platform or crossbar provided making sure that your knees are slightly bent and not locked.
Lean over as you keep the natural alignment of your back and grab the V-bar handles.

With your arms extended pull back until your torso is at a 90-degree angle from your legs. Your back should be slightly arched and your chest should be sticking out. You should be feeling a nice stretch on your lats as you hold the bar in front of you. This is the starting position of the exercise.

Keeping the torso stationary, pull the handles back towards your torso while keeping the arms close to it until you touch the abdominals. Breathe out as you perform that movement. At that point you should be squeezing your back muscles hard. Hold that contraction for a second and slowly go back to the original position while breathing in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated lumbar disc: High severity. The forward lean and pulling motion can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.lumbar stenosis: High severity. The exercise may increase lumbar compression and exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise can increase shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The pulling motion may aggravate the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate severity. The exercise can stress the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Low severity. Ensure controlled breathing to avoid Valsalva maneuver.
contraindicationDetails.recent lumbar or shoulder surgery: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform seated cable rows without elevation to reduce range of motion and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase resistance or perform single-arm elevated cable rows for added challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a supported chest pad to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit range of motion and use lighter weights.

safetyNotes: Ensure the platform is stable to prevent falls.
Avoid locking knees to reduce stress on the joints.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent back injury.
formCues: Keep your chest out and shoulders back.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Pull with your elbows, not your hands, to engage the lats.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the pull.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up.

name: Elliptical Trainer
instructions: To begin, step onto the elliptical and select the desired option from the menu. Most ellipticals have a manual setting, or you can select a program to run. Typically, you can enter your age and weight to estimate the amount of calories burned during exercise. Elevation can be adjusted to change the intensity of the workout.
The handles can be used to monitor your heart rate to help you stay at an appropriate intensity.

severe cardiovascular conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or severe heart disease should avoid high-intensity cardiovascular exercises like the elliptical trainer without medical clearance.

knee osteoarthritis.details: The elliptical trainer can be used with caution and potentially lower resistance settings to minimize joint stress.

hip bursitis.details: Avoid high resistance and excessive incline settings to prevent aggravating hip pain.

recent lower limb surgery.details: Post-surgical patients should avoid using the elliptical until cleared by a healthcare provider.

balance disorders.details: Individuals with significant balance issues should use the elliptical with caution and may require supervision or support.

modifications.easier: Use a lower resistance and incline setting to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase resistance and incline to add intensity and engage more muscle groups.

injury_friendly.knee_pain: Focus on maintaining a smooth, controlled motion with minimal resistance.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Maintain an upright posture and avoid excessive leaning on the handles.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height and body size.
Start with a warm-up to gradually increase heart rate.
Stay hydrated and monitor your heart rate to avoid overexertion.
formCues: Maintain an upright posture with your core engaged.
Keep your feet flat on the pedals throughout the motion.
Use a smooth, controlled motion to avoid jerking movements.
commonMistakes: Leaning heavily on the handles, which can reduce the effectiveness of the workout.
Using excessive resistance or incline too quickly, leading to potential injury.
Allowing the knees to lock out during the motion.

name: Exercise Ball Crunch
instructions: Lie on an exercise ball with your lower back curvature pressed against the spherical surface of the ball. Your feet should be bent at the knee and pressed firmly against the floor. The upper torso should be hanging off the top of the ball. The arms should either be kept alongside the body or crossed on top of your chest as these positions avoid neck strains (as opposed to the hands behind the back of the head position).
Lower your torso into a stretch position keeping the neck stationary at all times. This will be your starting position.

With the hips stationary, flex the waist by contracting the abdominals and curl the shoulders and trunk upward until you feel a nice contraction on your abdominals. The arms should simply slide up the side of your legs if you have them at the side or just stay on top of your chest if you have them crossed. The lower back should always stay in contact with the ball. Exhale as you perform this movement and hold the contraction for a second.
As you inhale, go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, spondylolisthesis, or sciatica should avoid this exercise due to the potential for exacerbating spinal compression and discomfort.

pregnancy.details: During pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, lying supine on a ball may cause discomfort and affect circulation. Modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

osteoporosis.details: Due to the risk of vertebral fractures, individuals with osteoporosis should avoid exercises that place stress on the spine.

recent_abdominal_surgery.details: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that stress the abdominal region until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform the crunch on a mat without the ball to reduce instability and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight plate or medicine ball across the chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion and ensure the lower back remains in contact with the ball at all times.
injury_friendly.neck_pain: Keep the arms crossed over the chest or alongside the body to prevent neck strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the exercise ball is properly inflated for stability.
Maintain contact between the lower back and the ball to prevent excessive spinal extension.
Avoid pulling on the neck if hands are placed behind the head.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you crunch up, inhale as you return to the starting position.
Keep the movement slow and controlled to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to lose contact with the ball.
Using momentum rather than muscle contraction to perform the crunch.
Pulling on the neck with the hands, leading to strain.

name: Exercise Ball Pull-In
instructions: Place an exercise ball nearby and lay on the floor in front of it with your hands on the floor shoulder width apart in a push-up position.

Now place your lower shins on top of an exercise ball. Tip: At this point your legs should be fully extended with the shins on top of the ball and the upper body should be in a push-up type of position being supported by your two extended arms in front of you. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your back completely straight and the upper body stationary, pull your knees in towards your chest as you exhale, allowing the ball to roll forward under your ankles. Squeeze your abs and hold that position for a second.
Now slowly straighten your legs, rolling the ball back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal load and flexion.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder_instability: Those with shoulder instability or impingement may find it difficult to maintain the push-up position without exacerbating their condition.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Pregnant individuals, particularly in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and abdominal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent_abdominal_surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that stress the abdominal region to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: Individuals with balance disorders should avoid this exercise due to the risk of falls and inability to stabilize on the ball.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with the ball closer to the knees rather than the shins to reduce the lever arm and decrease difficulty.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with one leg lifted off the ball to increase core stabilization demands.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion and focus on engaging the core without full knee flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with forearms on the floor instead of hands to reduce shoulder load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the exercise ball is properly inflated to maintain stability.
Perform the exercise on a non-slip surface to prevent the ball from moving unexpectedly.
Avoid excessive lumbar flexion to reduce the risk of lower back strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a straight line from head to heels in the starting position.
Move slowly and with control, avoiding momentum.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag, which increases lower back strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Placing the ball too far under the feet, increasing difficulty unnecessarily.

name: Extended Range One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
instructions: Lie on the floor and position a kettlebell for one arm to press. The kettlebell should be held by the handle. The leg on the same side that you are pressing should be bent, with the knee crossing over the midline of the body.
Press the kettlebell by extending the elbow and adducting the arm, pressing it above your body. Return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate a tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Joint loading in the shoulder can increase pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not be ready for load-bearing activities.
contraindicationDetails.chronic wrist pain: Gripping the kettlebell can exacerbate wrist pain.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The position and load can increase intra-abdominal pressure, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise may place undue stress on the lumbar spine, exacerbating the condition.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter kettlebell or use a dumbbell for more control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a heavier kettlebell or add a stability challenge by using a stability ball under the upper back.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with a dumbbell to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Place a rolled towel under the lower back for additional support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is secure and handle is gripped firmly to prevent dropping.
Avoid excessive arching of the back during the press.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Press the kettlebell directly above the shoulder joint.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulder.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Failing to keep the core engaged, leading to lower back strain.

name: External Rotation
instructions: Lie sideways on a flat bench with one arm holding a dumbbell and the other hand on top of the bench folded so that you can rest your head on it.
Bend the elbows of the arm holding the dumbbell so that it creates a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm. Tip: Keep the arm parallel to your torso.

Now bend the elbow while keeping the upper arm stationary. In this manner, the forearm will be parallel to the floor and perpendicular to your torso (Tip: So the forearm will be directly in front of you). The upper arm will be stationary by your torso and should be parallel to the floor (aligned with your torso at all times). This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, externally rotate your forearm so that the dumbbell is lifted up in a semicircle motion as you maintain the 90 degree angle bend between the upper arms and the forearm. You will continue this external rotation until the forearm is perpendicular to the floor and the torso pointing towards the ceiling. At this point you will hold the contraction for a second.
As you breathe in, slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch to the other arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to the movement's demand on shoulder external rotation, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate risk as the exercise targets the rotator cuff, potentially aggravating tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Low risk but requires caution if neck positioning causes discomfort or strain.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High risk due to potential for fracture with improper form or excessive load.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder injuries: High risk as any recent trauma or strain may be worsened by the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights or use a resistance band for lighter resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizing muscles.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with a towel roll under the arm to reduce stress on the shoulder joint, or use a cable machine for controlled resistance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the shoulder joint is warmed up before performing the exercise.
Avoid jerky or fast movements to prevent strain on the shoulder joint.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid unnecessary neck strain.
formCues: Keep the elbow at a 90-degree angle throughout the movement.
Ensure the upper arm remains stationary and parallel to the torso.
Rotate the forearm slowly and with control, focusing on the external rotation of the shoulder.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to drift away from the body.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back or lifting the shoulder off the bench.

name: External Rotation with Band
instructions: Choke the band around a post. The band should be at the same height as your elbow. Stand with your left side to the band a couple of feet away.
Grasp the end of the band with your right hand, and keep your elbow pressed firmly to your side. We recommend you hold a pad or foam roll in place with your elbow to keep it firmly in position.
With your upper arm in position, your elbow should be flexed to 90 degrees with your hand reaching across the front of your torso. This will be your starting position.
Execute the movement by rotating your arm in a backhand motion, keeping your elbow in place.
Continue as far as you are able, pause, and then return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity. The exercise may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: High severity. This exercise can strain the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High severity. Post-surgical protocols often restrict external rotation to allow healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Risk of fracture due to bone fragility, especially if resistance is too high.
contraindicationDetails.thoracic outlet syndrome: Moderate severity. Exercise may increase symptoms by affecting the neurovascular bundle.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter resistance band or perform the exercise without a band to focus on the motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance of the band or perform the exercise with a slow tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a towel roll under the armpit to reduce stress on the shoulder joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored to prevent it from snapping back.
Avoid using excessive resistance that causes pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep the elbow tucked to your side throughout the movement.
Rotate the arm smoothly without jerking or using momentum.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid unnecessary strain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to drift away from the body.
Using the torso to generate momentum instead of isolating the shoulder rotation.
Overextending the range of motion beyond comfort.

name: External Rotation with Cable
instructions: Adjust the cable to the same height as your elbow. Stand with your left side to the band a couple of feet away.
Grasp the handle with your right hand, and keep your elbow pressed firmly to your side. We recommend you hold a pad or foam roll in place with your elbow to keep it firmly in position.
With your upper arm in position, your elbow should be flexed to 90 degrees with your hand reaching across the front of your torso. This will be your starting position.
Execute the movement by rotating your arm in a backhand motion, keeping your elbow in place.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity. External rotation can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: High severity. This exercise can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Moderate severity. Joint stress may increase pain and inflammation in affected individuals.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Moderate severity. Maintaining proper posture is crucial to avoid exacerbating neck pain.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent disrupting the healing process.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable machine or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a towel roll under the elbow to reduce joint stress and ensure proper alignment.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is set at elbow height to maintain proper alignment.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Stop the exercise if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your elbow tucked closely to your side throughout the movement.
Rotate your arm in a controlled manner, avoiding any jerky motions.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid unnecessary strain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to drift away from the body, reducing exercise effectiveness.
Using momentum to swing the arm instead of controlled rotation.
Overextending the range of motion, which can lead to shoulder strain.

name: Face Pull
instructions: Facing a high pulley with a rope or dual handles attached, pull the weight directly towards your face, separating your hands as you do so. Keep your upper arms parallel to the ground.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and pulling motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The exercise can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening a tear.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The position and movement can strain the neck, aggravating cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint stress from the exercise can exacerbate pain and inflammation in severely arthritic shoulders.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder bursitis: The movement can increase inflammation and pain in the shoulder bursa.

modifications.easier: Use resistance bands instead of cables to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise in a kneeling position to increase core engagement.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform a seated face pull with a resistance band to reduce strain on the shoulders and neck.

safetyNotes: Ensure the pulley is set at a height that allows for a comfortable and controlled pull towards the face.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent compromising form and increasing injury risk.
formCues: Keep your elbows high and parallel to the ground throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together at the end of the pull.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid arching the back.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to drop below shoulder level.
Overextending the neck or leaning back excessively.

name: Farmer's Walk
instructions: There are various implements that can be used for the farmers walk. These can also be performed with heavy dumbbells or short bars if these implements aren't available. Begin by standing between the implements.
After gripping the handles, lift them up by driving through your heels, keeping your back straight and your head up.
Walk taking short, quick steps, and don't forget to breathe. Move for a given distance, typically 50-100 feet, as fast as possible.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and potential for increased spinal compression.

joint issues.details: Those with severe arthritis, shoulder impingement, or tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before attempting due to the potential for increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the third trimester, should modify or avoid due to balance changes and potential for increased intra-abdominal pressure.

acute injuries.details: Avoid if there are any recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower or upper body.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise with one hand at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or distance walked, or perform the exercise on an incline.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a weight belt for additional support and reduce the load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Focus on maintaining an upright posture and reduce the stride length to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a trap bar or farmer's walk handles to maintain a neutral grip and reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the walking path is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Use appropriate footwear with good grip to avoid slipping.
Start with a manageable weight to focus on form before increasing load.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core throughout the movement.
Take short, controlled steps to maintain balance.
commonMistakes: Allowing the weights to swing uncontrollably.
Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Taking overly long strides, which can compromise balance.

name: Fast Skipping
instructions: Start in a relaxed position with one leg slightly forward. This will be your starting position.
Skip by executing a step-hop pattern of right-right-step to left-left-step, and so on, alternating back and forth.
Perform fast skips by maintaining close contact with the ground and reduce air time, moving as quickly as possible.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or sciatica should avoid high-impact activities that may exacerbate symptoms.

joint issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should avoid or modify to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular conditions.details: High-impact exercises can increase heart rate and blood pressure, posing risks for those with heart disease or uncontrolled hypertension.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid high-impact activities due to balance and joint stability concerns.

acute injuries.details: Recent sprains or strains, particularly in the lower extremities, require avoidance of high-impact activities.

neurological conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy can increase the risk of falls during fast skipping.

modifications.easier: Perform slow marching in place, focusing on form and balance.
modifications.harder: Increase speed and add arm movements to enhance cardiovascular challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform slow, controlled skips on a softer surface to reduce impact.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a skipping rope to limit ground contact and reduce knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure a clear, flat surface to minimize tripping hazards.
Wear supportive footwear to reduce impact on joints.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare muscles and joints for dynamic movement.
formCues: Maintain an upright posture with a slight forward lean.
Keep core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Use a quick, light foot strike to minimize ground contact time.
commonMistakes: Overextending the stride, leading to loss of balance.
Landing heavily, increasing joint stress.
Neglecting arm movement, which aids in balance and rhythm.

recommendedReps.speed: Perform for 15-30 seconds at maximum effort.

name: Finger Curls
instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands and your palms facing up; hands spaced about shoulder width.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Lower the bar as far as possible by extending the fingers. Allowing the bar to roll down the hands, catch the bar with the final joint in the fingers.
Now curl bar up as high as possible by closing your hands while exhaling. Hold the contraction at the top.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The repetitive gripping and finger flexion can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the median nerve.

wrist tendinitis.explanation: The exercise involves repetitive wrist and finger movements that can worsen inflammation and pain.

arthritis in the hands.explanation: The gripping and curling motion may increase joint stress and discomfort in individuals with arthritis.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load and stress on the fingers and wrists.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise with a thicker bar to challenge grip strength further.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with a resistance band to reduce joint stress and allow for a more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is not too heavy to prevent excessive strain on the fingers and wrists.
Avoid using momentum to lift the barbell; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your body to stabilize the forearms.
Focus on a slow and controlled curl of the fingers to engage the forearm muscles effectively.
Exhale as you curl the barbell up and inhale as you lower it.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to improper form and increased risk of injury.
Allowing the barbell to roll too far down the fingers, which can cause strain.

name: Flat Bench Cable Flyes
instructions: Position a flat bench between two low pulleys so that when you are laying on it, your chest will be lined up with the cable pulleys.
Lay flat on the bench and keep your feet on the ground.
Have someone hand you the handles on each hand. You will grab each single handle attachment with a palms up grip.

Extend your arms by your side with a slight bend on your elbows. Tip: You will keep this bend constant through the whole movement. Your arms should be parallel to the floor. This is your starting position.

Now start lifting the arms in a semi-circle motion directly in front of you by pulling the cables together until both hands meet at the top of the movement. Squeeze your chest as you perform this motion and breathe out during this movement. Also, hold the contraction for a second at the top. Tip: When performed correctly, at the top position of this movement, your arms should be perpendicular to your torso and the floor touching above your chest.
Slowly come back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and wide arc motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.chest surgery recovery: Post-surgical tissue may not tolerate the stretch and contraction forces.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture due to bone fragility is increased with high loads.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or chest injuries: Any acute injury may be aggravated by the exercise's demands.
contraindicationDetails.severe carpal tunnel syndrome: Grip and wrist positioning may exacerbate symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with resistance bands instead of cables to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to target the upper chest more.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, stopping before any pain is felt.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Ensure proper lumbar support by placing a small cushion under the lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and positioned correctly between the pulleys.
Avoid locking the elbows to prevent joint strain.
Do not allow the arms to drop below the level of the bench to avoid excessive shoulder strain.
formCues: Maintain a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Keep the shoulder blades retracted and pressed against the bench.
Focus on squeezing the chest muscles at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to drop too low, increasing shoulder strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Failing to maintain a consistent elbow bend.

name: Flat Bench Leg Pull-In
instructions: Lie on an exercise mat or a flat bench with your legs off the end.

Place your hands either under your glutes with your palms down or by the sides holding on to the bench (or with palms down by the side on an exercise mat). Also extend your legs straight out. This will be your starting position.
Bend your knees and pull your upper thighs into your midsection as you breathe out. Continue this movement until your knees are near your chest. Hold the contracted position for a second.
As you breathe in, slowly return to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High intra-abdominal pressure and spinal flexion can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion of the spine may increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Lumbar flexion can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Flexion may aggravate nerve root irritation.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal flexion increases risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Supine position can reduce venous return and cause discomfort.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with bent knees throughout the movement to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a stability ball to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive lumbar flexion to reduce spinal stress.
Maintain controlled movements to prevent momentum-based injuries.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement.
Exhale as you pull your knees towards your chest.
Keep the lower back pressed against the bench or mat.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Not engaging the core muscles effectively.

name: Flat Bench Lying Leg Raise
instructions: Lie with your back flat on a bench and your legs extended in front of you off the end.
Place your hands either under your glutes with your palms down or by the sides holding on to the bench. This will be your starting position.

As you keep your legs extended, straight as possible with your knees slightly bent but locked raise your legs until they make a 90-degree angle with the floor. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement and hold the contraction at the top for a second.
Now, as you inhale, slowly lower your legs back down to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High intra-abdominal pressure and lumbar flexion can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Lumbar extension and flexion may increase symptoms due to nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Lumbar flexion can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Leg raises may aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to increased pressure on the lumbar spine.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Increased intra-abdominal pressure can interfere with healing.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with bent knees to reduce the load on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise with a slow tempo for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform lying leg raises on the floor with a rolled towel under the lower back for support.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Focus on core engagement without lifting the legs too high to minimize knee strain.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid swinging the legs to maintain control and reduce injury risk.
formCues: Engage the core by pulling the navel towards the spine.
Keep the movement slow and controlled, especially on the descent.
Avoid arching the lower back by keeping it pressed against the bench.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch off the bench.
Using momentum to lift the legs instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Holding breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure.

name: Flexor Incline Dumbbell Curls
instructions: Hold the dumbbell towards the side farther from you so that you have more weight on the side closest to you. (This can be done for a good effect on all bicep dumbbell exercises). Now do a normal incline dumbbell curl, but keep your wrists as far back as possible so as to neutralize any stress that is placed on them.
Sit on an incline bench that is angled at 45-degrees while holding a dumbbell on each hand.

Let your arms hang down on your sides, with the elbows in, and turn the palms of your hands forward with the thumbs pointing away from the body. Tip: You will keep this hand position throughout the movement as there should not be any twisting of the hands as they come up. This will be your starting position.

Curl up the two dumbbells at the same time until your biceps are fully contracted and exhale. Tip: Do not swing the arms or use momentum. Keep a controlled motion at all times. Hold the contracted position for a second at the top.
As you inhale, slowly go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High repetition or heavy load can exacerbate inflammation and pain in the elbow tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The incline position may place additional stress on the shoulder joint, potentially worsening impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The incline position can strain the shoulder stabilizers, potentially aggravating existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is increased with weight-bearing exercises, especially in a seated position.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle of the bench to 60 degrees or use heavier weights.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip (hammer curl) to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a lower incline angle or seated upright to minimize shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps for additional support or perform the exercise with a neutral grip.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain in the elbows, shoulders, or wrists.
formCues: Keep your back pressed against the bench throughout the movement.
Maintain a controlled motion; avoid swinging the dumbbells.
Keep your wrists in a neutral position to minimize stress.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Arching the back excessively during the lift.

name: Floor Glute-Ham Raise
instructions: You can use a partner for this exercise or brace your feet under something stable.
Begin on your knees with your upper legs and torso upright. If using a partner, they will firmly hold your feet to keep you in position. This will be your starting position.
Lower yourself by extending at the knee, taking care to NOT flex the hips as you go forward.

Place your hands in front of you as you reach the floor. This movement is very difficult and you may be unable to do it unaided. Use your arms to lightly push off the floor to aid your return to the starting position.

knee injuries.explanation: The exercise places significant stress on the knee joint, which can exacerbate existing injuries.

lower back pain.explanation: The exercise requires core stability, and improper form can strain the lower back.

sciatica.explanation: Forward movement and knee extension can aggravate sciatic nerve pain.

recent knee surgery.explanation: Post-surgical knees are vulnerable to stress and should avoid high-load exercises.

balance disorders.explanation: The exercise requires significant balance and control, which may be challenging for those with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band anchored in front of you to assist in the upward phase.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with added weight or resistance on the back.

injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform partial range of motion and use a soft surface to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Focus on maintaining a neutral spine and engage the core throughout.

safetyNotes: Ensure your feet are securely anchored to prevent slipping.
Do not hyperextend the back during the movement.
Use a mat or soft surface to protect the knees.
formCues: Keep the torso and upper legs aligned throughout the movement.
Engage the core to maintain stability.
Lower yourself slowly and with control.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to flex during the descent.
Using excessive momentum to return to the starting position.
Not engaging the core, leading to lower back strain.

name: Floor Press
instructions: Adjust the j-hooks so they are at the appropriate height to rack the bar. Begin lying on the floor with your head near the end of a power rack. Keeping your shoulder blades pulled together; pull the bar off of the hooks.

Lower the bar towards the bottom of your chest or upper stomach, squeezing the bar and attempting to pull it apart as you do so. Ensure that you tuck your elbows throughout the movement. Lower the bar until your upper arm contacts the ground and pause, preventing any slamming or bouncing of the weight.
Press the bar back up as fast as you can, keeping the bar, your wrists, and elbows in line as you do so.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate - The floor press can exacerbate impingement due to the shoulder's position and load. Modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: High - The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening tears.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate - The exercise can aggravate tendinitis due to repetitive elbow extension under load.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Low - Ensure proper wrist alignment and consider wrist wraps for support.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Moderate - The Valsalva maneuver often used in heavy lifts can increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: High - Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate - Ensure proper form and avoid excessive load to prevent fractures.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural wrist and elbow position.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Decrease the load and focus on a controlled tempo to minimize joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely racked before starting.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy to prevent accidents.
Avoid bouncing the bar off the floor to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep shoulder blades retracted throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
Tuck elbows at a 45-degree angle to the torso to protect shoulders.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively.
Bouncing the bar off the floor.
Failing to maintain a tight core and stable shoulder position.

name: Floor Press with Chains
instructions: Adjust the j-hooks so they are at the appropriate height to rack the bar. For this exercise, drape the chains directly over the end of the bar, trying to keep the ends away from the plates.
Begin lying on the floor with your head near the end of a power rack. Keeping your shoulder blades pulled together, pull the bar off of the hooks.

Lower the bar towards the bottom of your chest or upper stomach, squeezing the bar and attempting to pull it apart as you do so. Ensure that you tuck your elbows throughout the movement. Lower the bar until your upper arm contacts the ground and pause, preventing any slamming or bouncing of the weight.
Press the bar back up as fast as you can, keeping the bar, your wrists, and elbows in line as you do so.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The floor press with chains can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the need for shoulder stabilization and the potential for improper elbow positioning.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: Individuals with a rotator cuff tear may experience increased pain and risk of further injury due to the load on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise involves significant elbow extension, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The weight and chain dynamics can place additional stress on the wrists, potentially worsening existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during heavy lifts, can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The compressive forces and potential for improper form can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter chains or no chains to reduce the variable resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the chains or add more chains to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a neutral grip bar to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow_pain: Reduce the range of motion by stopping just above the ground.
injury_friendly.wrist_pain: Use wrist wraps for additional support.

safetyNotes: Ensure chains are securely attached to prevent shifting during the lift.
Avoid bouncing the bar off the floor to prevent joint stress.
Maintain a controlled tempo to ensure safety and effectiveness.
formCues: Keep shoulder blades retracted throughout the movement.
Tuck elbows to maintain shoulder stability.
Squeeze the bar and attempt to pull it apart to engage stabilizers.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, increasing shoulder stress.
Bouncing the bar off the floor, leading to potential injury.
Neglecting to secure the chains properly, causing imbalance.

name: Flutter Kicks
instructions: On a flat bench lie facedown with the hips on the edge of the bench, the legs straight with toes high off the floor and with the arms on top of the bench holding on to the front edge.
Squeeze your glutes and hamstrings and straighten the legs until they are level with the hips. This will be your starting position.
Start the movement by lifting the left leg higher than the right leg.
Then lower the left leg as you lift the right leg.

Continue alternating in this manner (as though you are doing a flutter kick in water) until you have done the recommended amount of repetitions for each leg. Make sure that you keep a controlled movement at all times. Tip: You will breathe normally as you perform this movement.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased lumbar stress and exacerbation of symptoms.

joint_issues.explanation: Those with hip or lower back arthritis may experience discomfort due to the repetitive motion and should modify or avoid the exercise.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that require lying prone or increase intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent abdominal or spinal surgery patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.explanation: Avoid if there are any recent strains or sprains in the lower back or hip region to prevent aggravation.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on the floor instead of a bench to reduce the range of motion and stabilize the lower back.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance and challenge the glutes and hamstrings further.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a glute bridge instead, which provides similar glute activation with less strain on the lower back.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Focus on isometric glute squeezes while lying prone to reduce joint movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Move the legs in a controlled manner, avoiding jerky movements.
Maintain a neutral head position to prevent neck strain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to sag or arch excessively.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Holding breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure.

name: Foot-SMR
instructions: This exercise stretches the fascia of the muscles in the feet. Start off seated with your shoes removed. Using a foot roller or a similar object, such as a small section of pvc pipe, place your foot against the roller across the arch of your foot. This will be your starting position.
Press down firmly, rolling across the arch of your foot. Hold for 10-30 seconds, and then switch feet.

contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: Rolling may exacerbate symptoms by applying pressure to an already inflamed area.
contraindicationDetails.acute foot or ankle sprain: Pressure and movement could aggravate the injury and delay healing.
contraindicationDetails.recent foot surgery: The area may still be healing and susceptible to damage from pressure.
contraindicationDetails.severe neuropathy: Reduced sensation may lead to unintentional injury due to inability to gauge pressure.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Increased risk of stress fractures in the foot bones due to pressure.

modifications.easier: Use a softer object like a foam roller or a tennis ball to reduce pressure.
modifications.harder: Stand while performing the exercise to increase pressure and engagement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure knees are supported and avoid excessive bending.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive pressure to prevent bruising or injury.
Discontinue if sharp pain occurs.
Ensure the roller is stable to prevent slipping.
formCues: Maintain a neutral spine while seated.
Apply even pressure across the arch.
Roll slowly to control the movement.
commonMistakes: Using excessive force leading to discomfort or injury.
Rolling too quickly, reducing effectiveness.
Neglecting to switch feet, leading to imbalance.

name: Forward Drag with Press
instructions: Attach a dual handled chain or rope attachment to the sled. You should be facing away from the sled, holding a handle in each hand.

Begin the movement by moving forward for one step. Leaning forward, extend through the legs and hips to move, pausing with each step to extend through the elbows, pressing your hands forward. Step forward until you return to the start position prepared to press.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The pressing motion can exacerbate shoulder impingement by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The dynamic pressing action may strain the rotator cuff, particularly if there is pre-existing damage.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive pressing motion can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow, especially lateral epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the handles tightly may increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lumbar disc herniation: The forward lean and dynamic movement can increase intra-abdominal pressure and strain the lumbar spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Forward leaning and leg drive may exacerbate sciatic nerve irritation.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The compound nature and potential for high exertion can be risky for those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter sled or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the sled weight or perform the exercise on an incline to add resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip and reduce the range of motion to minimize shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a more upright posture and engage the core to support the lumbar spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure the sled is on a stable surface to prevent slipping.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the shoulders and core.
Avoid excessive forward lean to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive arching.
Press forward with control, not momentum.
commonMistakes: Leaning too far forward, placing strain on the lower back.
Using momentum rather than controlled pressing.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug upwards during the press.

name: Frankenstein Squat
instructions: This drill teaches you the proper positioning of both the bar and your body during the clean and front squat.

Place the barbell on the front of the shoulders, releasing your grip and extending your arms out in front of you. The shoulders should be pushed forward to create a shelf, and the bar should be in contact with the throat. Ensure that you only move your shoulder blades forward; don't round the thoracic spine.

Squat by flexing the knees and hips, sitting in between your legs. Keep the torso upright, the arms up, and the shoulders forward, and the bar should stay in place. Go to the bottom of the squat, until your hamstrings contact your calves.
Return to the upright position by driving through the front of the heel and extending the knees and hips.

spinal_injuries.description: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis may experience increased spinal loading and should avoid this exercise.

joint_issues.description: Those with knee arthritis, shoulder impingement, or tendinitis may find the exercise exacerbates symptoms due to the load and positioning.

cardiovascular_conditions.description: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid heavy lifting due to increased cardiovascular strain.

pregnancy.description: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that require holding a barbell in front of the body due to balance and core stability concerns.

surgical_recovery.description: Recent surgeries involving the spine, knees, or shoulders require a clearance from a healthcare provider before performing this exercise.

osteoporosis.description: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid exercises that put significant axial load on the spine.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or a dowel rod to practice form without significant load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter load and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat to reduce stress on the knees, ensuring the knees do not extend past the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a front squat harness to reduce shoulder strain or perform goblet squats as an alternative.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is properly balanced on the shoulders to avoid neck strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent lower back injury.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the chest up and the core engaged throughout the squat.
Drive through the heels to stand up, avoiding pushing through the toes.
Ensure the knees track over the toes to maintain proper alignment.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the squat, which can lead to spinal injury.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward, increasing the risk of knee injury.
Holding the barbell incorrectly, leading to shoulder or wrist strain.

name: Freehand Jump Squat
instructions: Cross your arms over your chest.
With your head up and your back straight, position your feet at shoulder width.
Keeping your back straight and chest up, squat down as you inhale until your upper thighs are parallel, or lower, to the floor.
Now pressing mainly with the ball of your feet, jump straight up in the air as high as possible, using the thighs like springs. Exhale during this portion of the movement.
When you touch the floor again, immediately squat down and jump again.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid jump squats due to the compressive and shear forces on the spine.

knee joint issues.details: Conditions like arthritis, tendinitis, or recent knee surgery can be exacerbated by the impact and stress on the knee joint during jump squats.

cardiovascular conditions.details: Those with hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before performing high-intensity exercises like jump squats.

pregnancy.details: Jumping movements are generally not recommended during pregnancy due to potential risks to the mother and fetus.

osteoporosis.details: The high-impact nature of jump squats can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma should be fully healed before attempting jump squats to prevent further injury.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight squats without the jump to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Add a weighted vest or hold dumbbells to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform box squats to a safe height to limit range of motion and reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Focus on partial squats or use a TRX for support to minimize knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints for high-impact activity.
Use a soft surface or mat to reduce impact stress on joints.
Maintain control during the landing phase to prevent injury.
formCues: Keep your chest up and back straight throughout the movement.
Land softly on the balls of your feet and immediately transition into the next squat.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine during the jump.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward during landing.
Failing to maintain a neutral spine, leading to excessive forward lean.
Not using the arms for balance and momentum.

name: Frog Hops
instructions: Stand with your hands behind your head, and squat down keeping your torso upright and your head up. This will be your starting position.
Jump forward several feet, avoiding jumping unnecessarily high. As your feet contact the ground, absorb the impact through your legs, and jump again. Repeat this action 5-10 times.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities like frog hops can exacerbate joint pain and degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Jumping movements may increase the risk of ankle sprains or further instability.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the impact forces involved in jumping.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of frog hops requires good balance to prevent falls.
contraindicationDetails.advanced osteoporosis: High-impact exercises can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: The impact and spinal loading during jumps can aggravate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The intense nature of this exercise may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

modifications.easier: Perform stationary squat jumps instead of forward jumps to reduce complexity and impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the distance of each jump or add a tuck jump at the peak of each hop.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform low-impact squats without jumping to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the squat and perform gentle step-ups instead of jumps.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform seated leg extensions to engage the quadriceps without impact.

safetyNotes: Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints for high-impact activity.
Choose a soft surface, like grass or a gym mat, to reduce impact forces on the joints.
Maintain a controlled landing to absorb impact through the legs and avoid jarring the joints.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Land softly on the balls of your feet and roll through to the heels.
Use your arms to help balance and control the movement if needed.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, which increases joint stress.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward upon landing, risking injury.
Jumping too high, which can lead to loss of control and increased impact.

name: Frog Sit-Ups
instructions: Lie with your back flat on the floor (or exercise mat) and your legs extended in front of you.
Now bend at the knees and place your outer thighs by the floor (or mat) as you make the soles of your feet touch each other.

Now try pushing both soles and bringing them up as near you as possible while you keep the outer thighs on the floor (or at least almost touching it). Tip: In this position your legs should create a diamond shape.
Now, cross your arms in front of you by touching the opposite shoulders. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale flatten your lower back to the floor while curling the torso upwards. Tip: This will be like performing the first 1/4 movement of a sit up. Hold at the top position for a second.
As you inhale, slowly lower back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity due to increased spinal flexion, which can exacerbate disc protrusion.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity as spinal flexion may increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity; flexion can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity; flexion may aggravate nerve irritation.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High severity; spinal flexion increases risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity; supine position can reduce venous return and increase intra-abdominal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity; exercise may disrupt healing tissue.

modifications.easier: Perform a basic crunch with feet flat on the floor to reduce hip flexor involvement.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight plate across the chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a partial crunch with feet flat and hands supporting the head to reduce spinal strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep feet flat on the floor to avoid stress on the knees.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with hands to prevent cervical strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to reduce lumbar stress.
Engage the core before initiating the movement to protect the lower back.
formCues: Exhale as you curl up to engage the core effectively.
Keep the movement slow and controlled to maximize muscle engagement.
Focus on lifting with the abdominals, not the neck or shoulders.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the torso instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively during the movement.
Holding the breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure.

name: Front Barbell Squat
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, bring your arms up under the bar while keeping the elbows high and the upper arm slightly above parallel to the floor. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids and cross your arms while grasping the bar for total control.
Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the middle of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial load on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Knee arthritis or tendinitis may be exacerbated by the deep knee flexion required in this exercise.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity exercises like the front squat.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises with heavy loads and potential balance issues.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, particularly in the lower body or spine, require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

osteoporosis.details: The axial loading and potential for falls make this exercise unsuitable for individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back necessitate avoiding this exercise until fully healed.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form, requiring modifications or avoidance.

modifications.easier: Goblet squat with a dumbbell or kettlebell to reduce load and improve balance.
modifications.harder: Perform the front squat with a pause at the bottom position to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a safety squat bar or perform box squats to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit depth to a partial squat or use a resistance band around the knees to encourage proper alignment.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a front squat harness or straps to hold the bar if shoulder mobility is limited.

safetyNotes: Always use a squat rack with safety bars set at an appropriate height.
Ensure proper warm-up before attempting heavy lifts.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to maintain muscle tension and joint safety.
formCues: Keep elbows high and chest up to maintain bar position.
Engage core muscles to support the spine throughout the movement.
Drive through the midfoot and heels to maintain balance and power.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the ascent.
Leaning too far forward, causing the bar to roll off the shoulders.
Rounding the lower back at the bottom of the squat.

name: Front Barbell Squat To A Bench
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set a flat bench behind you and set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, bring your arms up under the bar while keeping the elbows high and the upper arm slightly above parallel to the floor. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids and cross your arms while grasping the bar for total control.
Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until you touch the bench with your glutes. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and potential for spinal compression.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or patellar tendinitis should be cautious due to the stress placed on the knee joint. Modifications or alternative exercises may be necessary.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before performing this exercise due to the potential for increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance changes and abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery in the lower back, knees, or hips requires avoiding this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid heavy loading due to fracture risk. Modifications may be necessary.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back should preclude this exercise until recovery is complete.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications or alternative exercises to ensure safety.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight squat to the bench to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform a pause at the bottom position to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a safety squat bar or perform goblet squats to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit depth to a partial squat or use a resistance band above the knees to improve knee alignment.

safetyNotes: Always use a squat rack with safety bars set at an appropriate height.
Ensure the bench is stable and positioned correctly to avoid tipping.
formCues: Keep elbows high and chest up to maintain bar position.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels to initiate the upward phase.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to collapse inward (valgus collapse).
Leaning forward excessively, losing the upright torso position.
Not maintaining a straight line from knees to toes, leading to excessive knee stress.

name: Front Box Jump
instructions: Begin with a box of an appropriate height 1-2 feet in front of you. Stand with your feet should width apart. This will be your starting position.
Perform a short squat in preparation for jumping, swinging your arms behind you.
Rebound out of this position, extending through the hips, knees, and ankles to jump as high as possible. Swing your arms forward and up.
Land on the box with the knees bent, absorbing the impact through the legs. You can jump from the box back to the ground, or preferably step down one leg at a time.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid high-impact activities like box jumps due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and nerve irritation.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis, knee or ankle impingement, or tendinitis should avoid this exercise as it places significant stress on the joints, potentially worsening symptoms.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should perform this exercise with caution and under medical supervision due to the increased cardiovascular demand.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid high-impact exercises like box jumps to reduce the risk of falls and abdominal trauma.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical patients, especially those recovering from lower limb or spinal surgeries, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.
