chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis or advanced diabetes complications should modify or avoid this exercise due to the risk of fractures or balance issues.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if experiencing recent sprains, strains, or trauma to prevent further injury.

neurological_conditions.details: Those with balance disorders or neuropathy should modify this exercise to reduce fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform a step-up onto the box instead of jumping to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the box height or perform the jump with a weighted vest for added challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform step-ups instead of jumps to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a lower box and focus on controlled landings to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit arm swing and focus on lower body mechanics to reduce shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and on a non-slip surface.
Wear supportive footwear to absorb impact.
Warm up thoroughly before performing high-impact exercises.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the spine during the jump.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Keep the chest up and eyes forward throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Allowing knees to cave inward upon landing, risking knee injury.
Using an inappropriate box height, leading to poor form or injury.

name: Front Cable Raise
instructions: Select the weight on a low pulley machine and grasp the single hand cable attachment that is attached to the low pulley with your left hand.

Face away from the pulley and put your arm straight down with the hand cable attachment in front of your thighs at arms' length with the palms of the hand facing your thighs. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the left arm to the front with a slight bend on the elbow and the palms of the hand always faces down. Continue to go up until you arm is slightly above parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this portion of the movement and pause for a second at the top.
Now as you inhale lower the arm back down slowly to the starting position.
Once all of the recommended amount of repetitions have been performed for this arm, switch arms and perform the exercise with the right one.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arm may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: This exercise can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: The movement may increase joint pain and inflammation in individuals with advanced osteoarthritis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Maintaining a stable neck position is crucial, and any cervical instability could be aggravated.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The exertion and breath-holding during the lift could elevate blood pressure further.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with both arms simultaneously or increase the weight.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a partial range of motion, lifting the arm only to shoulder height.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated to reduce strain on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Do not swing the torso; keep the core engaged for stability.
Control the movement, especially during the lowering phase.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbow to reduce joint stress.
Engage the core to maintain a stable torso.
Lift the arm in a controlled manner, avoiding momentum.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Swinging the body to lift the weight.
Lifting the arm too high, causing shoulder impingement.

name: Front Cone Hops (or hurdle hops)
instructions: Set up a row of cones or other small barriers, placing them a few feet apart.
Stand in front of the first cone with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Begin by jumping with both feet over the first cone, swinging both arms as you jump.
Absorb the impact of landing by bending the knees, rebounding out of the first leap by jumping over the next cone.
Continue until you have jumped over all of the cones.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The impact from jumping can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.

acute lower back pain.explanation: Jumping can increase spinal load and aggravate pain.

balance disorders.explanation: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, posing a fall risk.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Healing tissues may not withstand the impact forces from jumping.

ankle instability.explanation: Jumping can increase the risk of ankle sprains or strains.

severe cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The exercise is high-intensity and may not be suitable for individuals with severe heart conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform step-overs instead of jumps to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the cones or perform the exercise on one leg.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a lower barrier and focus on soft landings.
injury_friendly.back pain: Limit the number of repetitions and ensure proper core engagement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the surface is flat and non-slip to prevent falls.
Wear supportive footwear to absorb impact.
Maintain a safe distance between cones to avoid tripping.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb shock.
Use your arms to help propel yourself over the cones.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Not using arms effectively, reducing jump height.
Allowing knees to cave inward upon landing, risking injury.

name: Front Dumbbell Raise
instructions: Pick a couple of dumbbells and stand with a straight torso and the dumbbells on front of your thighs at arms length with the palms of the hand facing your thighs. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the left dumbbell to the front with a slight bend on the elbow and the palms of the hands always facing down. Continue to go up until you arm is slightly above parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this portion of the movement and pause for a second at the top. Inhale after the second pause.
Now lower the dumbbell back down slowly to the starting position as you simultaneously lift the right dumbbell.
Continue alternating in this fashion until all of the recommended amount of repetitions have been performed for each arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms above shoulder level can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The repetitive motion and load on the shoulder can aggravate tendinitis, leading to increased pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Maintaining a stable neck position is crucial; any strain or incorrect posture can worsen cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures increases with osteoporosis, particularly with overhead movements that may stress the bones.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the need for core stabilization and balance.
modifications.harder: Use a resistance band instead of dumbbells to increase tension throughout the range of motion.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Do not swing the weights; maintain control throughout the movement.
Keep the core engaged to support the spine.
formCues: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart.
Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Raise the dumbbells to just above shoulder height.
Pause briefly at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Lifting the weights too high, causing shoulder impingement.
Allowing the back to arch excessively.

name: Front Incline Dumbbell Raise
instructions: Sit down on an incline bench with the incline set anywhere between 30 to 60 degrees while holding a dumbbell on each hand. Tip: You can change the angle to hit the muscle a little differently each time.
Extend your arms straight in front of you and have your palms facing down with the dumbbells raised about 1 inch above your thighs. This will be your starting position.

Slowly raise the dumbbells straight up until they are slightly above your shoulders, while keeping your elbows locked. Squeeze at the top for a second and make sure you breathe out during this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep your head resting down against the bench and your legs on the floor at all times.
Lower the arms back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms above shoulder level can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves shoulder elevation which can increase stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The incline position can place stress on the cervical spine, especially if the head is not properly supported.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture increases with overhead movements, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric holds and overhead movements can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lower weight or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support by adjusting the bench angle to a more upright position.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weights.
Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Exhale as you lift the dumbbells and inhale as you lower them.
Keep your elbows slightly bent to reduce joint stress.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the head to lift off the bench, causing neck strain.
Swinging the weights instead of lifting them in a controlled manner.

name: Front Leg Raises
instructions: Stand next to a chair or other support, holding on with one hand.
Swing your leg forward, keeping the leg straight. Continue with a downward swing, bringing the leg as far back as your flexibility allows. Repeat 5-10 times, and then switch legs.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. Swinging the leg can exacerbate disc issues due to increased lumbar motion.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity. The swinging motion may irritate the sciatic nerve, especially if flexibility is limited.
contraindicationDetails.hamstring tendinitis: Moderate severity. The exercise involves dynamic stretching of the hamstrings, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: High severity. Post-surgical protocols often limit range of motion and dynamic movements.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Moderate severity. Standing on one leg may pose a fall risk for individuals with impaired balance.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion and slower speed to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance or perform the exercise without holding onto support.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise lying supine on the floor, lifting one leg at a time to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Focus on controlled, slow movements to minimize joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the supporting surface is stable to prevent falls.
Avoid excessive swinging to reduce the risk of muscle strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain balance.
Avoid locking the knee of the standing leg.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle control.
Allowing the torso to lean backward excessively.
Failing to engage the core, leading to instability.

name: Front Plate Raise
instructions: While standing straight, hold a barbell plate in both hands at the 3 and 9 o'clock positions. Your palms should be facing each other and your arms should be extended and locked with a slight bend at the elbows and the plate should be down near your waist in front of you as far as you can go. Tip: The arms will remain in this position throughout the exercise. This will be your starting position.

Slowly raise the plate as you exhale until it is a little above shoulder level. Hold the contraction for a second. Tip: make sure that you do not swing the weight or bend at the elbows. Your torso should remain stationary throughout the movement as well.
As you inhale, slowly lower the plate back down to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms above shoulder level can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding a weight in front of the body can strain the neck, especially if posture is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures increases with load-bearing exercises, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise can place undue stress on healing tissues and should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a heavier weight or on one leg to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a front raise with dumbbells, keeping elbows slightly bent to reduce stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Avoid using momentum to lift the weight.
Keep the core engaged to support the spine.
Do not lock the elbows completely; maintain a slight bend.
formCues: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart.
Engage your core and glutes to stabilize the body.
Lift the plate with control, avoiding any swinging motion.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to swinging motion.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug during the lift.
Arching the lower back excessively.

name: Front Raise And Pullover
instructions: Lie on a flat bench while holding a barbell using a palms down grip that is about 15 inches apart.
Place the bar on your upper thighs, extend your arms and lock them while keeping a slight bend on the elbows. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the weight using a semicircular motion and keeping your arms straight as you inhale. Continue the same movement until the bar is on the other side above your head . (Tip: the bar will travel approximately 180-degrees). At this point your arms should be parallel to the floor with the palms of your hands facing the ceiling.
Now return the barbell to the starting position by reversing the motion as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to the overhead motion which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise involves significant shoulder movement which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: The physical exertion may trigger symptoms; consult a physician before performing.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Overhead movements can disrupt healing; clearance from a healthcare provider is essential.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fractures due to the load and movement involved.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The exercise can increase spinal load, potentially aggravating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The back position and load can exacerbate symptoms.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for a more natural range of motion.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a bench with back support to minimize spinal stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting.
Do not lock the elbows completely to avoid joint strain.
Avoid excessive arching of the back during the movement.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Move slowly and with control, especially when lowering the bar.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the bar instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Allowing the elbows to lock out completely.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to injury.

name: Front Squat (Clean Grip)
instructions: To begin, first set the bar in a rack slightly below shoulder level. Rest the bar on top of the deltoids, pushing into the clavicles, and lightly touching the throat. Your hands should be in a clean grip, touching the bar only with your fingers to help keep it in position.

Lift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso. Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head and elbows up at all times. This will be your starting position.

Bend at the knees, sitting down between your legs. Continue down until your hamstrings are on your calves. Keep your knees aligned with your feet by consciously using your abductors to push your knees out as you squat.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the heel or middle of your foot as you straighten the legs again and return to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial load and potential for spinal compression.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or patellar tendinitis may need to modify the depth or avoid this exercise to prevent exacerbating symptoms.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: People with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing this exercise due to the potential for increased blood pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, may need to modify or avoid this exercise due to balance changes and abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the spine, knees, or shoulders require clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid heavy loading and may need to modify the exercise to reduce spinal compression risk.

modifications.easier: Goblet squat with a dumbbell or kettlebell to reduce load and improve balance.
modifications.harder: Perform the front squat with a pause at the bottom position to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a safety squat bar to reduce spinal load and maintain a more upright torso.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat to a partial range of motion to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a cross-arm grip or straps to hold the bar if shoulder mobility is limited.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely racked at the correct height before starting.
Use a spotter or safety pins in the rack for added safety.
Warm up thoroughly before performing heavy sets.
formCues: Keep your elbows high to maintain bar position.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through your heels to initiate the upward movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to drop, causing the bar to roll forward.
Rounding the lower back at the bottom of the squat.
Letting the knees collapse inward during the ascent.

name: Front Squats With Two Kettlebells
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.

Looking straight ahead at all times, squat as low as you can and pause at the bottom. As you squat down, push your knees out. You should squat between your legs, keeping an upright torso, with your head and chest up.
Rise back up by driving through your heels and repeat.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the compressive forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify depth and load to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing this exercise due to the potential for increased blood pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance and intra-abdominal pressure concerns.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery in the lower body or spine requires clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis patients should avoid heavy loading and deep squats to prevent fractures.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications or supervision.

modifications.easier: Perform goblet squats with a single kettlebell held at chest level to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball to challenge stability.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat to reduce knee flexion and stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a single kettlebell or use a front rack position with a barbell to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
Ensure the kettlebells are of appropriate weight to maintain control and proper form.
Avoid rounding the back or letting the knees collapse inward during the squat.
formCues: Keep your chest up and back straight throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels as you rise from the squat.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Leaning too far forward, causing the back to round.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.

name: Front Two-Dumbbell Raise
instructions: Pick a couple of dumbbells and stand with a straight torso and the dumbbells on front of your thighs at arms length with the palms of the hand facing your thighs. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the dumbbells to the front with a slight bend on the elbow and the palms of the hands always facing down. Continue to go up until you arms are slightly above parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this portion of the movement and pause for a second at the top.
As you inhale, lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms above shoulder level can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise can place stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially worsening inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights in front of the body can increase neck strain, particularly in individuals with cervical spine pathologies.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is higher with osteoporosis, especially with exercises involving weights and potential for poor form.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping dumbbells can exacerbate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome due to increased pressure on the median nerve.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Use a slow tempo with a pause at the top of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize neck strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce stress on the elbow joint.
Do not swing the weights; keep the movement controlled.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Lift the weights with a smooth, controlled motion.
Exhale as you lift the weights and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Raising the weights too high, which can lead to shoulder impingement.
Allowing the back to arch or sway during the lift.

name: Full Range-Of-Motion Lat Pulldown
instructions: Either standing or seated on a high bench, grasp two stirrup cables that are attached to the high pulleys. Grab with the opposing hand so your arms are crisscrossed about you and your palms are facing forward.

Keeping your chest up and maintaining a slight arch in your lower back, pull the handles down as if you were doing a regular pulldown. The range of motion will be more of an arc. During the movement, rotate your hands so that in the bottom position your palms face each other rather than forward. Return slowly to the starting position and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The exercise involves overhead movements that can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The rotational component of the exercise may aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The axial load and spinal positioning can increase disc pressure.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver during exertion can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or back surgery: The exercise places stress on healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal loading and potential jerking motions can increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Lumbar extension and loading can exacerbate vertebral slippage.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band anchored above for a lighter load and more control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase stabilization demands.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit range of motion to avoid overhead positions and use a neutral grip.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent undue stress on the shoulders and spine.
Maintain a controlled tempo to reduce the risk of injury.
Ensure proper equipment setup to avoid awkward postures.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders down throughout the movement.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Rotate your hands smoothly to avoid jerky motions.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull the cables down.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up during the movement.
Arching the lower back excessively.

name: Gironda Sternum Chins
instructions: Grasp the pull-up bar with a shoulder width underhand grip.
Now hang with your arms fully extended and stick your chest out and lean back. Tip: You will be leaning back throughout the entire movement. This will be your starting position.

Start pulling yourself towards the bar with your spine arched throughout the movement and your head leaning back as far away from the bar as possible. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: At the upper end of the movement, your hips and legs will be at about a 45-degree angle to the floor.

Keep pulling until your collarbone passes the bar and your lower chest or sternum area touches it. Hold that contraction for a second. Tip: By the time you've completed this portion of the movement; your head will be parallel to the floor.
Slowly start going back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and backward pulling motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The stress on the shoulder joint during the pull can aggravate tendinitis, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and pulling motion places stress on the elbow tendons, potentially worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The grip required can exacerbate existing wrist pain or conditions like carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The backward head position and neck extension can strain the cervical spine, especially in those with pre-existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The spinal extension and arching can increase pressure on the discs, potentially worsening herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The hyperextension of the spine can exacerbate this condition, increasing the risk of slippage.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The stress on the spine and potential for falls can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band for assistance to reduce the load and make the movement more manageable.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a dip belt to increase resistance and challenge the muscles further.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a neutral grip pull-up to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid excessive arching to minimize spinal stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the pull-up bar is secure and can support your weight.
Avoid excessive swinging or kipping to prevent unnecessary strain on the joints.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Maintain a strong arch in the back throughout the movement.
Keep the chest lifted and aim to touch the sternum to the bar.
Avoid letting the shoulders roll forward; keep them retracted and depressed.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to elevate or roll forward during the pull.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Failing to maintain the backward lean, resulting in a standard chin-up form.

name: Glute Ham Raise
instructions: Begin by adjusting the equipment to fit your body. Place your feet against the footplate in between the rollers as you lie facedown. Your knees should be just behind the pad.

Start from the bottom of the movement. Keep your back arched as you begin the movement by flexing the knees. Drive your toes into the foot plate as you do so. Keep your upper body straight, and continue until your body is upright.
Return to the starting position, keeping your descent under control.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal loading and extension.

knee_joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or tendinitis in the knees may experience discomfort due to the knee flexion and should modify or avoid the exercise.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before performing this exercise due to the potential for increased blood pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve lying prone and significant abdominal pressure.

acute_injuries.details: Recent trauma or sprains, particularly in the lower back or legs, require complete avoidance until fully healed.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion or use a band-assisted variation to decrease resistance.
modifications.harder: Add weight by holding a plate or dumbbell against the chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a Roman chair to perform back extensions instead, focusing on controlled movements.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform hamstring curls on a machine to reduce knee stress while still targeting the hamstrings.

safetyNotes: Ensure the equipment is properly adjusted to your body size to prevent injury.
Avoid hyperextending the back at the top of the movement.
Maintain control throughout the entire range of motion to prevent sudden jerks.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Drive your toes into the footplate to activate the hamstrings.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round or hyperextend.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Incorrect equipment setup leading to improper body alignment.

name: Glute Kickback
instructions: Kneel on the floor or an exercise mat and bend at the waist with your arms extended in front of you (perpendicular to the torso) in order to get into a kneeling push-up position but with the arms spaced at shoulder width. Your head should be looking forward and the bend of the knees should create a 90-degree angle between the hamstrings and the calves. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, lift up your right leg until the hamstrings are in line with the back while maintaining the 90-degree angle bend. Contract the glutes throughout this movement and hold the contraction at the top for a second. Tip: At the end of the movement the upper leg should be parallel to the floor while the calf should be perpendicular to it.
Go back to the initial position as you inhale and now repeat with the left leg.
Continue to alternate legs until all of the recommended repetitions have been performed.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise or perform it with caution, as the position may exacerbate symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Knee or hip arthritis may be aggravated by the kneeling position; modifications or alternative exercises may be necessary.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify this exercise to avoid excessive strain on the abdominal region.

acute_injuries.details: Recent knee, hip, or lower back injuries should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

neurological_conditions.details: Conditions affecting balance or coordination may require modifications or supervision.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion or against a wall for support.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or resistance bands to increase the challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise on all fours with a neutral spine and avoid excessive arching.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Place a cushion under the knees or perform standing kickbacks using a chair for support.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Ensure the movement is controlled and deliberate.
Focus on squeezing the glutes at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back excessively.
Allowing the head to drop or the neck to strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle activation.

name: Goblet Squat
instructions: Stand holding a light kettlebell by the horns close to your chest. This will be your starting position.
Squat down between your legs until your hamstrings are on your calves. Keep your chest and head up and your back straight.
At the bottom position, pause and use your elbows to push your knees out. Return to the starting position, and repeat for 10-20 repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to potential spinal loading and flexion.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the depth of the squat to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing this exercise due to increased intra-abdominal pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify the exercise to avoid excessive intra-abdominal pressure and maintain balance.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery involving the lower back, hips, or knees requires clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid deep squats to minimize fracture risk. Those with diabetes should ensure stable blood glucose levels.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body until fully healed.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require additional support or modifications to ensure safety.

modifications.easier: Perform the squat to a chair or box to limit depth and provide support.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the squat on an unstable surface to engage stabilizers more.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter kettlebell and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit squat depth and ensure knees track over toes to reduce joint strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Hold the kettlebell lower or use a dumbbell to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid letting the knees collapse inward.
Do not allow the heels to lift off the ground.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Press through the heels to return to standing.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the squat.
Allowing the knees to cave inward.
Leaning too far forward, shifting weight onto the toes.

name: Good Morning
instructions: Begin with a bar on a rack at shoulder height. Rack the bar across the rear of your shoulders as you would a power squat, not on top of your shoulders. Keep your back tight, shoulder blades pinched together, and your knees slightly bent. Step back from the rack.
Begin by bending at the hips, moving them back as you bend over to near parallel. Keep your back arched and your cervical spine in proper alignment.
Reverse the motion by extending through the hips with your glutes and hamstrings. Continue until you have returned to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the significant load on the lumbar spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis should modify the range of motion to avoid exacerbating symptoms.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid heavy lifting and consult with a healthcare provider.

pregnancy.details: Due to changes in balance and joint laxity, pregnant individuals should avoid this exercise.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical patients, especially those recovering from back or hip surgery, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

osteoporosis.details: The forward bending motion increases the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter barbell or a broomstick to focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on one leg to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and limit the range of motion to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Ensure knees are slightly bent and avoid deep bends to reduce knee strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a safety squat bar to reduce shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Always warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise.
Avoid rounding the back during the movement to prevent spinal injury.
Ensure the barbell is securely placed on the shoulders, not the neck.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees.
Hinge at the hips, not the waist.
Keep the back straight and chest up.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Bending the knees excessively.
Placing the barbell on the neck instead of the shoulders.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Good Morning off Pins
instructions: Begin with a bar on a rack at about the same height as your stomach. Bend over underneath the bar and rack the bar across the rear of your shoulders as you would a power squat, not on top of your shoulders. At the proper height, you should be near parallel to the floor when bent over. Keep your back tight, shoulder blades pinched together, and your knees slightly bent. Keep your back arched and your cervical spine in proper alignment.
Begin the motion by extending through the hips with your glutes and hamstrings, and you are standing with the weight. Slowly lower the weight back to the pins returning to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the significant load on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: Those with arthritis or tendinitis in the knees or hips may experience discomfort due to the bending and load-bearing nature of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: People with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid heavy lifting exercises that can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The exercise involves a forward bending position and significant load, which may not be suitable during pregnancy, especially in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Individuals recovering from surgeries involving the spine, hips, or knees should avoid this exercise until fully cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Due to the risk of spinal compression and fractures, individuals with osteoporosis should avoid this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter barbell or a PVC pipe to focus on form and reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom position to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a Smith machine or perform seated good mornings to reduce strain on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely racked at the correct height before starting.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid undue stress on the lower back.
Avoid rounding the back, especially when lifting the weight.
formCues: Keep your core engaged and your back straight.
Initiate the movement by hinging at the hips, not the lower back.
Drive through your heels as you return to the standing position.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Not keeping the knees slightly bent, leading to hyperextension.

name: Gorilla Chin/Crunch
instructions: Hang from a chin-up bar using an underhand grip (palms facing you) that is slightly wider than shoulder width.
Now bend your knees at a 90 degree angle so that the calves are parallel to the floor while the thighs remain perpendicular to it. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, pull yourself up while crunching your knees up at the same time until your knees are at chest level. You will stop going up as soon as your nose is at the same level as the bar. Tip: When you get to this point you should also be finishing the crunch at the same time.
Slowly start to inhale as you return to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal flexion and compression during the crunch can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Spinal flexion may increase nerve compression symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Spinal flexion can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Leg lifting and spinal flexion can aggravate sciatic nerve pain.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Hanging position may exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The hanging position can stress the shoulder tendons.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric contractions and head elevation may increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Hanging and abdominal crunching are not recommended during pregnancy.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal flexion increases the risk of vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform hanging knee raises without the chin-up component.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise with straight legs for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform lying leg raises or planks to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform lying or seated core exercises to avoid shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a secure grip on the bar to prevent slipping.
Avoid jerky movements to reduce strain on the spine and shoulders.
Do not hold your breath; maintain steady breathing throughout.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Keep elbows slightly bent to reduce shoulder strain.
Synchronize the chin-up and crunch for smooth motion.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to gain momentum.
Not fully engaging the core, leading to excessive spinal arching.
Pulling with the arms instead of focusing on the core.

name: Groin and Back Stretch
instructions: Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet together.
Interlock your fingers behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Curl downwards, bringing your elbows to the inside of your thighs. After a brief pause, return to the starting position with your head up and your back straight. Repeat for 10-20 repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: This exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to the stress placed on the hip joint during the stretch.
contraindicationDetails.groin strain: Stretching the adductors can worsen a strain, delaying recovery.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The forward bending motion can increase pressure on the lumbar spine, potentially aggravating pain.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: Post-surgical protocols often restrict hip flexion and adduction to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Hormonal changes increase joint laxity, and this stretch may pose a risk of overstretching.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Forward flexion can increase intradiscal pressure, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The position may irritate the sciatic nerve, especially if there is already compression or inflammation.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while lying on your back with feet together and knees bent, gently pressing knees towards the floor.
modifications.harder: Add a slight forward lean while maintaining a straight back to increase the stretch intensity.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the stretch lying on your back with a pillow under your knees for support.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Place a cushion under each knee to reduce pressure and avoid deep flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Keep movements controlled and within a comfortable range of motion.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your back straight as you lean forward.
Engage your core to support your spine.
Press your elbows gently against your thighs without forcing the stretch.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively during the forward curl.
Forcing the knees down with the elbows, leading to overstretching.
Holding the breath instead of maintaining a steady breathing pattern.

name: Groiners
instructions: Begin in a pushup position on the floor. This will be your starting position.
Using both legs, jump forward landing with your feet next to your hands. Keep your head up as you do so.
Return to the starting position and immediately repeat the movement, continuing for 10-20 repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal load and flexion.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should perform this exercise with caution due to the dynamic nature and potential for increased heart rate.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise to prevent excessive intra-abdominal pressure.

acute_injuries.details: Acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the lower body or core should preclude this exercise until recovery.

modifications.easier: Step one foot forward at a time instead of jumping to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Add a push-up between each groiner for increased intensity.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a standing version by stepping forward into a lunge position.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat when landing to reduce knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate space to perform the exercise safely.
Warm up thoroughly before starting to prevent injury.
Stop immediately if you experience pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Land softly on the balls of your feet to reduce impact.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding your back.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag or rise too high in the starting position.
Landing with locked knees, which increases joint stress.
Failing to engage the core, leading to poor stability.

name: Hack Squat
instructions: Place the back of your torso against the back pad of the machine and hook your shoulders under the shoulder pads provided.
Position your legs in the platform using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Tip: Keep your head up at all times and also maintain the back on the pad at all times.
Place your arms on the side handles of the machine and disengage the safety bars (which on most designs is done by moving the side handles from a facing front position to a diagonal position).

Now straighten your legs without locking the knees. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

Begin to slowly lower the unit by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up (back on the pad at all times). Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the unit as you exhale by pushing the floor with mainly with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High compressive forces on the knee joint can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The exercise may increase stress on the patellar tendon, worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The axial load on the spine can aggravate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may exacerbate nerve compression symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee surgery: Healing tissues may not tolerate the load and range of motion required.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The exercise can increase blood pressure and heart rate significantly.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires stability, which may be compromised in individuals with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight squat or use a leg press machine with lighter weight.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform single-leg hack squats for added challenge.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion and reduce weight.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support and avoid excessive forward lean.

safetyNotes: Always warm up before performing hack squats to prepare the muscles and joints.
Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to fit your body size and shape.
Do not lock the knees at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your back flat against the pad throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding the lower back.
Drive through the heels to engage the glutes and protect the knees.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the ascent.
Rounding the back or lifting the hips off the pad.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.

name: Hammer Curls
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell on each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
The palms of the hands should be facing your torso. This will be your starting position.

Now, while holding your upper arm stationary, exhale and curl the weight forward while contracting the biceps. Continue to raise the weight until the biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbell is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a brief moment as you squeeze the biceps. Tip: Focus on keeping the elbow stationary and only moving your forearm.
After the brief pause, inhale and slowly begin the lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during curls can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position and movement can aggravate shoulder impingement due to the involvement of stabilizing muscles.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure on the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fractures due to bone fragility, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the need for core stabilization.
modifications.harder: Use a thicker grip or heavier weights to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use lighter weights and perform partial range of motion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip and avoid lifting the dumbbells too high.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid excessive strain.
Avoid swinging the weights to prevent momentum from taking over the movement.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Focus on contracting the biceps at the top of the movement.
Lower the weights slowly to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Using body momentum to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Hammer Grip Incline DB Bench Press
instructions: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.
By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbells up, clean the dumbbells one arm at a time so that you can hold them at shoulder width.

Once at shoulder width, keep the palms of your hands with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Keep your elbows flared out with the upper arms in line with the shoulders (perpendicular to the torso) and the elbows bent creating a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm. This will be your starting position.
Now bring down the weights slowly to your side as you breathe in. Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times.

As you breathe out, push the dumbbells up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the dumbbells back in your thighs and then on the floor. This is the safest manner to dispose of the dumbbells.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The exercise involves shoulder abduction and external rotation, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: The stabilizing role of the rotator cuff during this exercise can lead to further strain and injury.

cervical spine issues.explanation: The incline position may place stress on the cervical spine, especially if the head is not properly supported.

osteoporosis.explanation: The exercise involves weight-bearing on the upper body, which may increase fracture risk in individuals with osteoporosis.

herniated disc.explanation: The incline position can increase lumbar spine load, potentially aggravating disc issues.

hypertension.explanation: The exercise can be performed with caution, ensuring not to hold breath (avoid Valsalva maneuver) to prevent blood pressure spikes.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or on a flat bench to reduce the incline angle.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, stopping before any pain occurs.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Ensure proper lumbar support and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is set at a safe incline angle (30-45 degrees) to avoid excessive shoulder stress.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy weights to prevent accidents.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to maintain muscle tension and protect the joints.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the floor for stability.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
Engage your core to stabilize the torso and protect the lower back.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to drop too low, which can increase shoulder stress.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lumbar strain.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.

name: Hamstring-SMR
instructions: In a seated position, extend your legs over a foam roll so that it is position on the back of the upper legs. Place your hands to the side or behind you to help support your weight. This will be your starting position.
Using your hands, lift your hips off of the floor and shift your weight on the foam roll to one leg. Relax the hamstrings of the leg you are stretching.
Roll over the foam from below the hip to above the back of the knee, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat for the other leg.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity due to potential for increased spinal pressure when lifting hips off the floor.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity as the pressure on the sciatic nerve may be exacerbated by the foam rolling motion.
contraindicationDetails.recent hamstring strain: High severity; rolling can aggravate the injury and delay healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate severity; risk of fracture due to pressure and movement over the foam roller.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with both legs on the foam roller to distribute weight more evenly and reduce pressure.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance and challenge the stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.back pain: Keep the hips on the ground and gently roll without lifting to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a softer foam roller to decrease pressure on the knee joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly over joints such as the knee.
Do not apply excessive pressure; discomfort should be mild and not painful.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support the lower back.
Relax the hamstring muscle as you roll to allow deeper pressure.
Use your arms to control the movement and pressure.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly, which can reduce effectiveness and increase risk of injury.
Holding breath, which can increase tension and reduce relaxation of the muscle.

name: Hamstring Stretch
instructions: Lie on your back with one leg extended above you, with the hip at ninety degrees. Keep the other leg flat on the floor.
Loop a belt, band, or rope over the ball of your foot. This will be your starting position.
Pull on the belt to create tension in the calves and hamstrings. Hold this stretch for 10-30 seconds, and repeat with the other leg.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The position may increase lumbar spine pressure, exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. Stretching may irritate the sciatic nerve, leading to increased pain.
contraindicationDetails.recent hamstring strain: High severity. Stretching can impede healing and increase the risk of re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Moderate severity. The position may exacerbate symptoms and increase discomfort.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the knee slightly bent to reduce tension on the hamstring.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch duration to 60 seconds or add ankle dorsiflexion to intensify the stretch.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with a pillow under the lower back for support.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep the knee slightly bent to reduce strain on the joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking motions during the stretch.
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep the non-stretching leg flat on the floor.
Ensure the stretching leg is perpendicular to the floor.
Use a controlled pull on the belt or band.
commonMistakes: Allowing the non-stretching leg to lift off the floor.
Bending the knee of the stretching leg excessively.
Pulling too hard, causing discomfort or pain.

name: Handstand Push-Ups
instructions: With your back to the wall bend at the waist and place both hands on the floor at shoulder width.

Kick yourself up against the wall with your arms straight. Your body should be upside down with the arms and legs fully extended. Keep your whole body as straight as possible. Tip: If doing this for the first time, have a spotter help you. Also, make sure that you keep facing the wall with your head, rather than looking down.
Slowly lower yourself to the ground as you inhale until your head almost touches the floor. Tip: It is of utmost importance that you come down slow in order to avoid head injury.
Push yourself back up slowly as you exhale until your elbows are nearly locked.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High shoulder abduction and external rotation can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The pressure on the cervical spine during inversion can worsen conditions like herniated discs.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Inversion can increase blood pressure and is not recommended for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The load on the wrists can aggravate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Inversion requires significant balance and proprioception, posing a risk for falls.

modifications.easier: Pike push-ups on the floor or elevated pike push-ups with feet on a box.
modifications.harder: Freestanding handstand push-ups without wall support.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform seated dumbbell shoulder presses to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use parallettes to keep wrists in a neutral position.

safetyNotes: Ensure a clear area around you to prevent injury from falls.
Use a spotter when attempting for the first time.
Avoid locking elbows completely to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Engage your core to maintain a straight body line.
Keep your head neutral, facing the wall.
Lower yourself slowly and under control.
commonMistakes: Arching the back excessively, leading to a loss of core engagement.
Bouncing the head off the ground, increasing injury risk.
Allowing elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.

name: Hang Clean
instructions: Begin with a shoulder width, double overhand or hook grip, with the bar hanging at the mid thigh position. Your back should be straight and inclined slightly forward.
Begin by aggressively extending through the hips, knees and ankles, driving the weight upward. As you do so, shrug your shoulders towards your ears.
Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high compressive and shear forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or shoulder arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint strain.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid high-intensity lifts and consult a physician.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid heavy lifting due to changes in balance and joint stability.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, require clearance from a healthcare provider before performing this exercise.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the involved muscle groups.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang power clean, which involves catching the bar in a higher position, reducing the need for deep squat mobility.
modifications.harder: Progress to a full clean from the floor, increasing the range of motion and technical demand.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use lighter weights and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the catch position to reduce knee flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Reduce the load and focus on the shrug and pull phase, avoiding the catch if painful.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing hang cleans to prepare the joints and muscles.
Ensure the lifting area is clear of obstacles and has a non-slip surface.
Use appropriate footwear with good support.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift.
Engage your core to protect your lower back.
Drive through your heels during the upward phase.
Keep elbows high during the catch to stabilize the bar.
commonMistakes: Starting with the bar too far from the body, leading to poor leverage.
Rounding the back, increasing the risk of injury.
Using the arms too early instead of driving with the legs and hips.
Failing to fully extend the hips, knees, and ankles.

name: Hang Clean - Below the Knees
instructions: Begin with a shoulder width, double overhand or hook grip, with the bar hanging just below the knees. Your back should be straight and inclined slightly forward.

Begin by aggressively extending through the hips, knees and ankles, driving the weight upward. As you do so, shrug your shoulders towards your ears. As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out.

At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery.
Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The dynamic nature and load of the hang clean can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spinal stenosis due to the rapid extension and flexion of the spine.

joint_issues.explanation: Individuals with knee, hip, or shoulder arthritis or tendinitis should modify or avoid this exercise due to the high impact and range of motion required.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The explosive nature of the exercise can cause a rapid increase in heart rate and blood pressure, which may be unsafe for those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise involves high-impact movements and a risk of abdominal pressure, which are not recommended during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery, especially involving the spine, knees, or shoulders, requires avoiding high-impact and heavy load exercises like the hang clean.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent trauma, sprains, or strains in the involved muscles or joints necessitate avoiding this exercise until fully healed.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang clean from above the knees to reduce the range of motion and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the load or perform the exercise with a pause at the catch position to enhance stability and strength.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use lighter weights and focus on form, or substitute with a power clean from blocks to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat catch or perform a power clean to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Focus on the pull phase only, avoiding the catch, or substitute with a high pull.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the joints and muscles for explosive movements.
Use a spotter or perform in a controlled environment with safety equipment.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Keep the back straight and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the heels during the lift.
Ensure elbows are high and rotate under the bar quickly during the catch.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using arms to lift the bar instead of driving through the legs and hips.
Catching the bar with elbows down, leading to poor rack position.

name: Hang Snatch
instructions: Begin with a wide grip on the bar, with an overhand or hook grip. The feet should be directly below the hips with the feet turned out. Your knees should be slightly bent, and the torso inclined forward. The spine should be fully extended and the head facing forward. The bar should be at the hips. This will be your starting position.
Aggressively extend through the legs and hips. At peak extension, shrug the shoulders and allow the elbows to flex to the side.

As you move your feet into the receiving position, forcefully pull yourself below the bar as you elevate the bar overhead. Receive the bar with your body as low as possible and the arms fully extended overhead.
Return to a standing position with the weight overhead. Follow by returning the weight to the ground under control.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high axial load and dynamic movement, which can exacerbate these conditions.

shoulder_issues.details: Those with shoulder impingement, rotator cuff tears, or tendinitis should modify or avoid this exercise as the overhead position can increase stress on the shoulder joint.

knee_issues.details: Individuals with knee arthritis or tendinitis should be cautious due to the explosive nature of the movement which can stress the knee joint.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity exercises like the hang snatch.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance and core stability challenges.

surgical_recovery.details: Individuals recovering from recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

neurological_conditions.details: Those with balance disorders or neuropathy should avoid or modify this exercise due to the risk of falls and coordination challenges.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang power snatch, where the catch is in a partial squat rather than a full squat.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform a full snatch from the floor for added complexity and strength demand.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on form, or perform a snatch pull to avoid the overhead position.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat in the catch phase to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a snatch high pull to avoid the overhead position.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up, focusing on shoulder, hip, and ankle mobility.
Use a spotter or perform in a controlled environment with safety equipment.
Do not attempt maximal lifts without proper supervision and experience.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift.
Engage your core to maintain a neutral spine.
Drive through the heels and fully extend the hips.
commonMistakes: Starting with the hips too high or too low.
Pulling with the arms too early.
Failing to fully extend the hips before the catch.

name: Hang Snatch - Below Knees
instructions: Begin with a wide grip on the bar, with an overhand or hook grip. The feet should be directly below the hips with the feet turned out. Your knees should be slightly bent, and the torso inclined forward. The spine should be fully extended and the head facing forward. The bar should be just below the knees. This will be your starting position.
Aggressively extend through the legs and hips. At peak extension, shrug the shoulders and allow the elbows to flex to the side.

As you move your feet into the receiving position, forcefully pull yourself below the bar as you elevate the bar overhead. Receive the bar with your body as low as possible and the arms fully extended overhead.
Return to a standing position with the weight overhead, and then return the weight to the floor under control.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high load on the spine during the lift.

joint_issues.details: Those with shoulder impingement, knee arthritis, or tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint strain.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity lifts.

pregnancy.details: Due to balance and core stability challenges, this exercise is not recommended during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, especially involving the back, shoulders, or knees, require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to prevent exacerbation of the injury.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Hang Power Snatch: Start from a higher position to reduce the range of motion and technical complexity.
modifications.harder: Full Snatch: Start from the floor to increase the range of motion and technical demand.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on form, or perform a seated overhead press instead.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat during the receiving position or perform a power snatch variation.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Reduce the weight and avoid the overhead portion, focusing on the pull phase only.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints.
Use a spotter or perform in a controlled environment to manage the bar safely.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Keep the bar close to the body throughout the lift.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels and fully extend the hips.
commonMistakes: Starting with the bar too far from the body.
Failing to fully extend the hips before pulling under the bar.
Using arms too early in the lift instead of relying on leg and hip drive.

name: Hanging Bar Good Morning
instructions: Begin with a bar on a rack at about the same height as your stomach. Suspend the bar using chains or suspension straps.

Bend over underneath the bar and rack the bar across the rear of your shoulders as you would a power squat, not on top of your traps. At the proper height, you should be near parallel to the floor when bent over. Keep your back tight, shoulder blades pinched together, and your knees slightly bent. Keep your back arched and your cervical spine in proper alignment.
Begin the motion by extending through the hips with your glutes and hamstrings, and you are standing with the weight.
Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position, where it is supported by the chains.
