contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and shear forces.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: Those with knee or hip arthritis, or shoulder impingement should proceed with caution due to potential joint stress.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid heavy lifting that can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that require significant core stabilization and bending at the waist.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Individuals recovering from recent surgeries, particularly in the spine, hips, or knees, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Those with osteoporosis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of vertebral fractures from spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the back, hips, or knees.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter barbell or a PVC pipe to focus on form and reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a single leg to increase difficulty and balance challenge.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a Smith machine to control the bar path and reduce the need for stabilization, or perform a seated good morning to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely suspended to prevent unexpected movement.
Avoid rounding the back to prevent spinal injury.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your shoulder blades pinched together to stabilize the upper back.
Engage your core to maintain spinal alignment.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips to stand up.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the movement.
Allowing the knees to lock out or hyperextend.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.

name: Hanging Leg Raise
instructions: Hang from a chin-up bar with both arms extended at arms length in top of you using either a wide grip or a medium grip. The legs should be straight down with the pelvis rolled slightly backwards. This will be your starting position.
Raise your legs until the torso makes a 90-degree angle with the legs. Exhale as you perform this movement and hold the contraction for a second or so.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal flexion and load can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Extension and flexion of the spine can increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Spinal loading and flexion may worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Leg raises can increase nerve tension and pain.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Hanging position may exacerbate shoulder pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Grip strength and wrist position may increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Hanging and exertion may elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Abdominal pressure and hanging may not be safe.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of vertebral fracture due to spinal loading.

modifications.easier: Perform lying leg raises on the floor to reduce spinal load.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise with a twist to engage obliques more.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform lying leg raises with knees bent to reduce spinal stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a Roman chair to support the upper body and reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a secure grip on the bar to prevent falls.
Avoid swinging the legs to maintain control and reduce spinal strain.
Engage the core throughout the movement to protect the spine.
formCues: Keep the legs straight and together during the raise.
Exhale as you lift the legs and inhale as you lower them.
Maintain a slight posterior pelvic tilt to engage the lower abdominals.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the legs up.
Arching the lower back excessively.
Failing to engage the core throughout the movement.

name: Hanging Pike
instructions: Hang from a chin-up bar with your legs and feet together using an overhand grip (palms facing away from you) that is slightly wider than shoulder width. Tip: You may use wrist wraps in order to facilitate holding on to the bar.

Now bend your knees at a 90 degree angle and bring the upper legs forward so that the calves are perpendicular to the floor while the thighs remain parallel to it. This will be your starting position.
Pull your legs up as you exhale until you almost touch your shins with the bar above you. Tip: Try to straighten your legs as much as possible while at the top.
Lower your legs as slowly as possible until you reach the starting position. Tip: Avoid swinging and using momentum at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal flexion and compression can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Spinal flexion may increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Lumbar stress can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Leg lifting can aggravate sciatic nerve pain.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Hanging position may exacerbate shoulder discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Grip stress can worsen wrist symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Inverted positions may elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High spinal load increases fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Perform lying leg raises on the floor or use a captain's chair.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise with a slow tempo.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform lying leg raises with knees bent.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a captain's chair to eliminate shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist straps or perform lying variations.

safetyNotes: Ensure a secure grip to prevent falls.
Avoid swinging to reduce momentum and stress on the spine.
Engage core muscles throughout to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep legs straight and together during the lift.
Exhale as you lift your legs to engage the core.
Lower legs slowly and with control to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing legs up.
Allowing shoulders to shrug or tense up.
Arching the back excessively during the lift.

name: Heaving Snatch Balance
instructions: This drill helps you learn the snatch. Begin by holding a light weight across the back of the shoulders. Your feet should be slightly wider than hip width apart with the feet turned out, the same position that you would perform a squat with.
Begin by dipping with the knees slightly, and popping back up to briefly unload the bar. Drive yourself underneath the bar, elevating it overhead as you descend into a full squat.
Return to a standing position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and explosive movements that can exacerbate these conditions.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis, shoulder impingement, or tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress, as the dynamic nature of the movement can aggravate these conditions.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should be cautious due to the potential for increased blood pressure during explosive lifts.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid this exercise, especially in the second and third trimesters, due to balance challenges and abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery, particularly involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, necessitates avoiding this exercise until fully cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Conditions like osteoporosis require caution due to the risk of fractures from the dynamic and loaded nature of the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform an overhead squat with a dowel or light barbell to focus on form and stability.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the movement from a deficit to increase range of motion and difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on a controlled tempo to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat and ensure proper knee alignment over toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a wider grip or use dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the lifting area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Use collars on the barbell to prevent weight plates from sliding off during the exercise.
Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints for dynamic movements.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement to protect the spine.
Drive through the heels and keep the knees aligned with the toes during the squat.
Focus on a smooth transition from the dip to the drive under the bar.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Failing to fully extend the hips and knees at the top of the movement.
Using too much weight, leading to compromised form and increased injury risk.

name: Heavy Bag Thrust
instructions: Utilize a heavy bag for this exercise. Assume an upright stance next to the bag, with your feet staggered, fairly wide apart. Place your hand on the bag at about chest height. This will be your starting position.
Begin by twisting at the waist, pushing the bag forward as hard as possible. Perform this move quickly, pushing the bag away from your body.
Receive the bag as it swings back by reversing these steps.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The pushing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The dynamic nature of the exercise can strain the rotator cuff, especially if the shoulder is not stabilized properly.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Twisting at the waist can aggravate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.osteoarthritis: The impact and twisting motion may increase joint pain and inflammation, particularly in the shoulders and spine.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular conditions: The exertion required can elevate heart rate and blood pressure, which may be risky for individuals with heart disease or uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The twisting motion and potential for imbalance can be unsafe, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.
contraindicationDetails.acute wrist or elbow injuries: Pushing against resistance can worsen pain and delay healing in these areas.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter bag or against a wall to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed and force of the thrust or use a heavier bag.

injury_friendly.back pain: Avoid twisting and perform a straight push with a stable core.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on a gentle push without full extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the heavy bag is securely anchored to prevent unexpected movement.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for dynamic movement.
Use a controlled motion to avoid excessive strain on the joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce joint stress.
Push through the chest and shoulders, not just the arms.
commonMistakes: Overextending the arms, leading to shoulder strain.
Neglecting core engagement, resulting in poor balance and potential back injury.
Using excessive force without control, increasing the risk of joint injury.

name: High Cable Curls
instructions: Stand between a couple of high pulleys and grab a handle in each arm. Position your upper arms in a way that they are parallel to the floor with the palms of your hands facing you. This will be your starting position.

Curl the handles towards you until they are next to your ears. Make sure that as you do so you flex your biceps and exhale. The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Hold for a second in the contracted position as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly bring back the arms to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The elevated arm position can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive curling motion can aggravate the tendons around the elbow, increasing inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the handles tightly may increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during exertion, can spike blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The position of the arms and potential neck strain can exacerbate cervical spine conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lower weight or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a single arm to increase the challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with the arms slightly lower to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip or reduce the range of motion to minimize stress on the elbow.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached to prevent accidental release.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep upper arms parallel to the floor throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the curl.
Avoid swinging the body or using momentum to lift the weight.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to drop, reducing bicep engagement.
Using momentum by swinging the body.
Overextending the wrists, leading to strain.

name: Hip Circles (prone)
instructions: Position yourself on your hands and knees on the ground. Maintaining good posture, raise one bent knee off of the ground. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the knee in a bent position, rotate the femur in an arc, attempting to make a big circle with your knee.
Perform this slowly for a number of repetitions, and repeat on the other side.

spinal injuries.explanation: Individuals with spinal injuries such as herniated discs or sciatica should avoid excessive spinal flexion or rotation, which can be exacerbated by improper form during hip circles.

hip joint issues.explanation: Conditions like hip impingement or severe arthritis can be aggravated by the rotational movement of the femur in the hip socket.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, should be cautious with exercises that require prolonged time in a prone position due to potential discomfort and pressure on the abdomen.

acute knee injuries.explanation: Those with recent knee injuries or surgeries should avoid exercises that place additional stress on the knee joint until cleared by a healthcare professional.

modifications.easier: Perform smaller circles or limit the range of motion to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance and challenge the muscles further.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise while lying on your back with knees bent, making circles in the air to reduce pressure on the spine and knees.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid unnecessary strain.
Avoid excessive arching or rounding of the back.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the pelvis.
Keep the movement slow and controlled.
Focus on making smooth, circular motions with the knee.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to sag or arch excessively.
Moving too quickly, which can lead to loss of control and improper form.
Failing to engage the core, leading to pelvic instability.

name: Hip Extension with Bands
instructions: Secure one end of the band to the lower portion of a post and attach the other to one ankle.
Facing the attachment point of the band, hold on to the column to stabilize yourself.
Keeping your head and your chest up, move the resisted leg back as far as you can while keeping the knee straight.
Return the leg to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High intra-abdominal pressure and lumbar extension can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may aggravate sciatic nerve irritation due to hip extension.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: May cause discomfort due to joint stress during hip extension.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle sprain: The band attachment can stress the recovering ligaments.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a band, focusing on bodyweight control.
modifications.harder: Use a thicker band for increased resistance or perform the exercise with a slight forward lean to increase glute activation.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform lying prone on a mat, lifting the leg without resistance.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Focus on a smaller range of motion to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely attached to prevent snapping.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid hyperextending the knee during the movement.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the pelvis.
Keep the movement slow and controlled.
Focus on squeezing the glutes at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle control.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Not maintaining a straight leg throughout the exercise.

name: Hip Flexion with Band
instructions: Secure one end of the band to the lower portion of a post and attach the other to one ankle.
Face away from the attachment point of the band.
Keeping your head and your chest up, raise your knee up to 90 degrees and pause.
Return the leg to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Individuals with hip arthritis may experience increased joint pain due to the repetitive flexion movement.
contraindicationDetails.knee tendinitis: The exercise may exacerbate knee tendinitis symptoms due to the load on the knee joint during flexion.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Those with lower back pain might experience discomfort due to the stabilization required from the core muscles.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: This exercise requires balance and stability, which may be challenging for individuals with balance disorders.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the band to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Use a thicker band to increase resistance or add ankle weights.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise while seated to reduce strain on the lower back.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely attached to prevent snapping.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid locking the knee at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Lift your knee to hip level, no higher.
Maintain an upright posture with shoulders back.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the knee instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the back to arch excessively.
Failing to keep the standing leg stable.

name: Hip Lift with Band
instructions: After choosing a suitable band, lay down in the middle of the rack, after securing the band on either side of you. If your rack doesn't have pegs, the band can be secured using heavy dumbbells or similar objects, just ensure they won't move.
Adjust your position so that the band is directly over your hips. Bend your knees and place your feet flat on the floor. Your hands can be on the floor or holding the band in position.
Keeping your shoulders on the ground, drive through your heels to raise your hips, pushing into the band as high as you can.
Pause at the top of the motion, and return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The exercise involves spinal flexion and extension, which can exacerbate symptoms in individuals with a herniated disc.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The movement may increase nerve compression, causing pain or discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: The pressure and movement at the hip joint can aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle sprain: The exercise requires stable foot positioning, which may be compromised in a recent sprain.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Flexion and pressure on the knees can increase discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (third trimester): Supine exercises can reduce venous return and cause dizziness or discomfort.

modifications.easier: Perform the hip lift without the band to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Use a thicker band or add a weight plate on the hips for increased resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Place a cushion under the lower back for support and reduce band tension.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored to prevent it from snapping back.
Avoid hyperextending the back at the top of the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the pelvis.
Drive through the heels, not the toes, to activate the glutes.
Squeeze the glutes at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to collapse inward.
Lifting the shoulders off the ground.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Hug A Ball
instructions: Seat yourself on the floor.
Straddle an exercise ball between both legs and lower your hips down toward the floor.

Hug your arms around the ball to support your body. Adjust your legs so that your feet are flat on the floor and your knees line up over your ankles. Keep a good grip on the ball so it doesn't roll away from you and send you back onto your buttocks.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity; this exercise may exacerbate disc protrusion due to spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity; flexion can increase pressure on the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity; flexion may aggravate vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity; flexion may irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity; flexion increases risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: High severity; consult a physician before engaging in any spinal flexion exercises.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity; avoid prolonged supine positions and excessive spinal flexion.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller ball or a pillow to reduce the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Extend the legs further out to increase the challenge on the core muscles.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller ball and maintain a neutral spine position.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Place a cushion under the knees to reduce pressure.

safetyNotes: Ensure the exercise ball is properly inflated to maintain stability.
Avoid excessive spinal flexion to prevent strain on the lower back.
Maintain control of the ball at all times to prevent rolling.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the floor with knees aligned over ankles.
Engage your core to support the lower back.
Maintain a gentle hug around the ball without squeezing too tightly.
commonMistakes: Allowing the ball to roll away, leading to loss of balance.
Excessive rounding of the back, increasing stress on the spine.
Placing feet too close or too far from the body, affecting stability.

name: Hug Knees To Chest
instructions: Lie down on your back and pull both knees up to your chest.
Hold your arms under the knees, not over (that would put to much pressure on your knee joints).
Slowly pull the knees toward your shoulders. This also stretches your buttocks muscles.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The flexion of the spine can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the intervertebral discs.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Moderate severity. Flexion may relieve symptoms in some cases, but should be approached with caution.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. Flexion may increase anterior shear forces on the spine, worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. Flexion can aggravate symptoms depending on the cause of sciatica.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High severity. Spinal flexion increases the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Lying on the back can compress major blood vessels, and the position may be uncomfortable.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. The exercise can place stress on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise one leg at a time to reduce strain on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Add a gentle rocking motion side to side to increase the stretch.

injury_friendly.back pain: Place a rolled towel under the lower back for support and perform one leg at a time.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Hold behind the thighs instead of under the knees to reduce knee joint pressure.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling too hard on the knees to prevent excessive spinal flexion.
Stop immediately if you experience any sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your head and neck relaxed on the floor.
Engage your core gently to support the spine.
Breathe deeply and evenly throughout the stretch.
commonMistakes: Pulling the knees too forcefully towards the chest.
Holding the knees over the top instead of underneath.
Allowing the head to lift off the ground, straining the neck.

name: Hurdle Hops
instructions: Set up a row of hurdles or other small barriers, placing them a few feet apart.
Stand in front of the first hurdle with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Begin by jumping with both feet over the first hurdle, swinging both arms as you jump.
Absorb the impact of landing by bending the knees, rebounding out of the first leap by jumping over the next hurdle. Continue until you have jumped over all of the hurdles.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high impact and spinal loading.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis in the knees or ankles should avoid due to joint stress during landing.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before attempting due to increased cardiovascular demand.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid due to balance changes and risk of falls.

surgical_recovery.details: Avoid if recovering from lower limb or spinal surgery until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Those with osteoporosis should avoid due to risk of fractures from impact.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower limbs.

neurological_conditions.details: Individuals with balance disorders or neuropathy should modify or avoid due to fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform step-overs instead of jumps to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the hurdles or perform single-leg hops.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform lateral step-overs with a focus on core engagement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Reduce hurdle height and focus on soft landings with bent knees.
injury_friendly.ankle_pain: Perform on a soft surface and reduce jump height.

safetyNotes: Ensure the surface is non-slip and free of obstacles.
Use hurdles that are stable and not prone to tipping over.
Wear supportive footwear to absorb impact.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Use arm swing to assist with momentum.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Not using arms effectively, reducing jump height.
Allowing knees to collapse inward upon landing.

name: Hyperextensions (Back Extensions)
instructions: Lie face down on a hyperextension bench, tucking your ankles securely under the footpads.
Adjust the upper pad if possible so your upper thighs lie flat across the wide pad, leaving enough room for you to bend at the waist without any restriction.

With your body straight, cross your arms in front of you (my preference) or behind your head. This will be your starting position. Tip: You can also hold a weight plate for extra resistance in front of you under your crossed arms.

Start bending forward slowly at the waist as far as you can while keeping your back flat. Inhale as you perform this movement. Keep moving forward until you feel a nice stretch on the hamstrings and you can no longer keep going without a rounding of the back. Tip: Never round the back as you perform this exercise. Also, some people can go farther than others. The key thing is that you go as far as your body allows you to without rounding the back.

Slowly raise your torso back to the initial position as you inhale. Tip: Avoid the temptation to arch your back past a straight line. Also, do not swing the torso at any time in order to protect the back from injury.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. Hyperextensions can exacerbate disc herniation by increasing intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. The extension of the spine can narrow the spinal canal further, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. Extension movements can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. Can aggravate symptoms if not performed with proper form and control.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High severity. Risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Avoid lying face down and excessive spinal loading.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on the floor without equipment, focusing on lifting the chest slightly off the ground.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight plate or dumbbell across the chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform partial range of motion, avoiding full extension and focusing on controlled movements.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure proper padding and support under the knees, or perform on a flat surface.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid hyperextending the back beyond a straight line.
Do not use momentum to lift the torso.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Keep the head aligned with the spine.
Move slowly and with control.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Hyperextending the back at the top of the movement.
Using momentum to lift the torso.

name: Hyperextensions With No Hyperextension Bench
instructions: With someone holding down your legs, slide yourself down to the edge a flat bench until your hips hang off the end of the bench. Tip: Your entire upper body should be hanging down towards the floor. Also, you will be in the same position as if you were on a hyperextension bench but the range of motion will be shorter due to the height of the flat bench vs. that of the hyperextension bench.

With your body straight, cross your arms in front of you (my preference) or behind your head. This will be your starting position. Tip: You can also hold a weight plate for extra resistance in front of you under your crossed arms.

Start bending forward slowly at the waist as far as you can while keeping your back flat. Inhale as you perform this movement. Keep moving forward until you almost touch the floor or you feel a nice stretch on the hamstrings (whichever comes first). Tip: Never round the back as you perform this exercise.

Slowly raise your torso back to the initial position as you exhale. Tip: Avoid the temptation to arch your back past a straight line. Also, do not swing the torso at any time in order to protect the back from injury.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High risk of exacerbating disc herniation due to spinal flexion and extension.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Increased lumbar extension can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal loading and flexion.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Potential for increased intra-abdominal pressure and balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: Stress on healing tissues can impede recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on the floor with a smaller range of motion.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight plate against the chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform prone back extensions on the floor with minimal range of motion.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure proper padding under knees and avoid excessive hip flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure someone is securely holding your legs to prevent slipping.
Avoid any jerking or swinging motions to protect the spine.
Do not hyperextend the back past a neutral position.
formCues: Keep the back flat and avoid rounding during the movement.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on the contraction of the lower back muscles.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Hyperextending the spine at the top of the movement.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.

name: IT Band and Glute Stretch
instructions: Loop a belt, rope, or band around one of your feet, and swing that leg across your body to the opposite side, keeping the leg extended as you lay on the ground. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your foot off of the floor, pull on the belt, using the tension to pull the toes up. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and repeat on the other side.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The twisting motion and leg extension can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the spinal discs.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity. The stretch may irritate the sciatic nerve, leading to increased pain or discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Moderate severity. The exercise may cause discomfort due to joint inflammation and should be modified or avoided if pain occurs.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: High severity. Post-surgical patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. The supine position and leg crossing may be uncomfortable or unsafe, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the knee bent to reduce tension on the IT band and lower back.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds and add a slight twist of the torso to deepen the stretch.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with a pillow under the lower back for support and keep the opposite leg bent.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid crossing the leg too far over the body to minimize strain on the knee joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements during the stretch.
Do not force the leg beyond a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Keep the leg straight but not locked.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive twisting of the torso.
Use controlled breathing to enhance relaxation and stretch effectiveness.
commonMistakes: Allowing the opposite shoulder to lift off the ground.
Overstretching beyond a comfortable range.
Holding the breath during the stretch.

name: Iliotibial Tract-SMR
instructions: Lay on your side, with the bottom leg placed onto a foam roller between the hip and the knee. The other leg can be crossed in front of you.
Place as much of your weight as is tolerable onto your bottom leg; there is no need to keep your bottom leg in contact with the ground. Be sure to relax the muscles of the leg you are stretching.
Roll your leg over the foam from you hip to your knee, pausing for 10-30 seconds at points of tension. Repeat with the opposite leg.

contraindicationDetails.iliotibial band syndrome: high - This exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to direct pressure on the inflamed area.
contraindicationDetails.acute knee injuries: high - Rolling over an injured knee can increase pain and delay healing.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: moderate - Direct pressure on the hip area can aggravate bursitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: moderate - Risk of fractures due to pressure on the femur and hip.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with less body weight on the foam roller by using your arms and the opposite leg for support.
modifications.harder: Increase the pressure by lifting the supporting leg off the ground, placing more body weight on the roller.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid rolling directly over the knee joint; focus on the upper thigh and hip area.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a softer foam roller to reduce pressure and avoid excessive spinal rotation.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly over joints to prevent unnecessary stress.
Do not perform if experiencing sharp pain or discomfort.
Use a foam roller with appropriate density to avoid excessive pressure.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain balance and control.
Relax the leg muscles to allow effective myofascial release.
Move slowly and deliberately to identify points of tension.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly, which can reduce the effectiveness of the exercise.
Applying too much pressure, leading to bruising or discomfort.
Neglecting to relax the muscles, which limits the release of tension.

name: Inchworm
instructions: Stand with your feet close together. Keeping your legs straight, stretch down and put your hands on the floor directly in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Begin by walking your hands forward slowly, alternating your left and your right. As you do so, bend only at the hip, keeping your legs straight.
Keep going until your body is parallel to the ground in a pushup position.
Now, keep your hands in place and slowly take short steps with your feet, moving only a few inches at a time.
Continue walking until your feet are by hour hands, keeping your legs straight as you do so.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward bending and spinal flexion involved in the inchworm can exacerbate symptoms of a herniated disc.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The stretch and forward bending may irritate the sciatic nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hamstring tendinitis: The exercise involves significant hamstring stretching, which could aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.recent wrist surgery: Weight-bearing on the hands may stress healing tissues post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic movement and transitions require good balance, posing a fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, bending the knees slightly to decrease hamstring tension.
modifications.harder: Add a push-up when reaching the plank position to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a slight bend in the knees to reduce spinal stress.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid locking the knees.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform the exercise on fists or with push-up handles to reduce wrist extension.

safetyNotes: Avoid locking the knees to prevent hyperextension.
Maintain a neutral spine to reduce lower back strain.
Ensure the movement is controlled to prevent falls.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement.
Keep your shoulders aligned over your hands in the plank position.
Walk hands and feet in small, controlled steps.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively during the forward bend.
Moving too quickly, compromising control and balance.
Allowing the hips to sag in the plank position.

name: Incline Barbell Triceps Extension
instructions: Hold a barbell with an overhand grip (palms down) that is a little closer together than shoulder width.
Lie back on an incline bench set at any angle between 45-75-degrees.
Bring the bar overhead with your arms extended and elbows in. The arms should be in line with the torso above the head. This will be your starting position.

Now lower the bar in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Inhale as you perform this movement. Tip: Keep your upper arms stationary and close to your head at all times. Only the forearms should move.
Return to the starting position as you breathe out and you contract the triceps. Hold the contraction for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the angle and load on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension and flexion of the elbow under load can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The incline position and weight overhead can strain the cervical spine, especially if there is pre-existing degeneration or instability.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The overhead position and potential for Valsalva maneuver can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with hypertension.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or switch to dumbbells for more control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a steeper incline.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip using dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use resistance bands instead of a barbell to decrease joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and securely set at the desired incline.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in close to your head throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid undue stress.
Engage your core to stabilize your body on the incline bench.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, which can increase shoulder stress.
Using momentum to lift the barbell instead of controlled movement.
Arching the back excessively, which can strain the lower back.

name: Incline Bench Pull
instructions: Grab a dumbbell in each hand and lie face down on an incline bench that is set to an incline that is approximately 30 degrees.
Let the arms hang to your sides fully extended as they point to the floor.
Turn the wrists until your hands have a pronated (palms down) grip.
Now flare the elbows out. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, start to pull the dumbbells up as if you are doing a reverse bench press. You will do this by bending at the elbows and bringing the upper arms up as you let the forearms hang. Continue this motion until the upper arms are at the same level as your back. Tip: The elbows will come out to the side and your upper arms and torso should make the letter "T" at the top of the movement. Hold the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly go back down to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

herniated disc.explanation: The prone position and pulling motion can exacerbate spinal compression and nerve irritation.

spinal stenosis.explanation: The exercise can increase lumbar extension, potentially worsening symptoms.

spondylolisthesis.explanation: Prone positioning and pulling can increase lumbar lordosis and stress the lower back.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The exercise involves shoulder abduction and external rotation, which can aggravate impingement.

rotator cuff tendinitis.explanation: The movement may strain the rotator cuff muscles, requiring modification or avoidance.

pregnancy.explanation: Prone positioning is generally not recommended, especially in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter dumbbells or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise with a barbell for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a supported bench with a lower incline to reduce spinal stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid flaring elbows excessively to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and set at the correct incline to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back during the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a neutral wrist position throughout the exercise.
Avoid shrugging the shoulders; focus on pulling with the back muscles.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to drop below the level of the back at the top of the movement.
Rounding the shoulders forward during the lift.

name: Incline Cable Chest Press
instructions: Adjust the weight to an appropriate amount and be seated, grasping the handles. Your upper arms should be about 45 degrees to the body, with your head and chest up. The elbows should be bent to about 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending through the elbow, pressing the handles together straight in front of you. Keep your shoulder blades retracted as you execute the movement.
After pausing at full extension, return to the starting position, keeping tension on the cables.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to shoulder abduction and flexion.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: High risk of aggravating the tendons involved in shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.chest surgery recovery: High risk of disrupting healing tissues; avoid until cleared by a physician.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate risk of fractures due to potential for excessive load on the upper body.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or chest injuries: High risk of worsening the injury; exercise should be avoided until recovery.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: High risk of cardiovascular events; avoid until medically cleared.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: High risk of disrupting surgical repairs; avoid until cleared by a physician.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a stability ball to engage core muscles more.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Reduce the range of motion and keep elbows closer to the body to minimize shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support by using a bench with adequate padding and maintain a neutral spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat and cables are properly adjusted to avoid awkward angles.
Do not lock out the elbows at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Maintain control of the cables throughout the exercise to avoid sudden jerks.
formCues: Keep your shoulder blades retracted throughout the movement.
Press the handles together in a controlled manner, focusing on chest contraction.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows at full extension to protect the joints.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder stress.
Using momentum to press the cables instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Failing to adjust the seat height, leading to improper alignment.

name: Incline Cable Flye
instructions: To get yourself into the starting position, set the pulleys at the floor level (lowest level possible on the machine that is below your torso).
Place an incline bench (set at 45 degrees) in between the pulleys, select a weight on each one and grab a pulley on each hand.
With a handle on each hand, lie on the incline bench and bring your hands together at arms length in front of your face. This will be your starting position.

With a slight bend of your elbows (in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon), lower your arms out at both sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, the arms should remain stationary. The movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.

Return your arms back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and exhale. Hold the contracted position for a second. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
contraindications: spinal issues such as herniated disc or stenosis

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and wide arc movement can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.chest surgery recovery: Stress on the chest muscles can impede healing post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures increases with weight-bearing exercises that stress the upper body.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or chest injuries: Any acute injury can be worsened by the stress of this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.spinal issues such as herniated disc or: Incline positioning may exacerbate spinal compression or nerve impingement.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a steeper incline to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, avoiding the bottom part of the arc.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support by adjusting the bench angle and using a lower weight.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and securely positioned.
Do not lock the elbows to prevent joint strain.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Maintain a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the chest muscles at the top of the movement.
Keep the shoulders down and back to avoid unnecessary strain.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to drop too low, increasing shoulder strain.
Arching the back excessively during the movement.

name: Incline Dumbbell Bench With Palms Facing In
instructions: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.
By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbells up, clean the dumbbells one arm at a time so that you can hold them at shoulder width.

Once at shoulder width, keep the palms of your hands with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Keep your elbows flared out with the upper arms in line with the shoulders (perpendicular to the torso) and the elbows bent creating a 90-degree angle between the upper arm and the forearm. This will be your starting position.
Now bring down the weights slowly to your side as you breathe in. Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times.

As you breathe out, push the dumbbells up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the dumbbells back in your thighs and then on the floor. This is the safest manner to dispose of the dumbbells.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to the overhead pressing motion which can exacerbate impingement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Moderate risk as the exercise involves stabilization by the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate risk due to the load on the elbow joint during pressing.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Moderate risk if the wrists are not kept neutral.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Low risk if performed with proper form, but caution is advised due to potential for bone stress.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular conditions: Moderate risk due to the potential for increased blood pressure during exertion.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Low risk in the first trimester but may require modification as pregnancy progresses.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a resistance band.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle of the bench or use heavier dumbbells.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion or use a flat bench.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is set at a stable incline angle.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy weights to prevent accidents.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the ground for stability.
Maintain a neutral wrist position throughout the exercise.
Engage your core to support your lower back.
commonMistakes: Arching the back excessively during the lift.
Allowing the elbows to flare out too much, which can strain the shoulders.
Dropping the weights too quickly, which can lead to loss of control.

name: Incline Dumbbell Curl
instructions: Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand held at arms length. Keep your elbows close to your torso and rotate the palms of your hands until they are facing forward. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms in an incline can increase the risk of shoulder impingement.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can exacerbate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required by the shoulder can aggravate existing rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased due to the load on the arms and shoulders.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The incline position may place stress on the cervical spine, especially if the head is not supported properly.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle of the bench or use heavier weights.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full extension and flexion of the elbow.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is set to a stable incline to prevent slipping.
Avoid using excessive weights that compromise form.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent cervical strain.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Rotate palms forward before starting the curl.
Focus on contracting the biceps and avoid swinging the weights.
Control the movement on the way down to maintain tension.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Arching the back excessively.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Incline Dumbbell Flyes
instructions: Hold a dumbbell on each hand and lie on an incline bench that is set to an incline angle of no more than 30 degrees.
Extend your arms above you with a slight bend at the elbows.
Now rotate the wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing you. Tip: The pinky fingers should be next to each other. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in, start to slowly lower the arms to the side while keeping the arms extended and while rotating the wrists until the palms of the hand are facing each other. Tip: At the end of the movement the arms will be by your side with the palms facing the ceiling.

As you exhale start to bring the dumbbells back up to the starting position by reversing the motion and rotating the hands so that the pinky fingers are next to each other again. Tip: Keep in mind that the movement will only happen at the shoulder joint and at the wrist. There is no motion that happens at the elbow joint.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to the overhead and wide arm position, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: High risk as the exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, potentially aggravating rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Moderate risk due to the position on the incline bench, which may strain the neck if not properly supported.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate risk due to potential for excessive load on the bones, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.chest surgery recovery: High risk as the exercise targets the chest muscles directly, which may not be fully healed post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder bursitis: High risk as the movement can irritate the bursa in the shoulder, worsening inflammation.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle slightly or use heavier weights to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support on the bench and engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Ensure the bench is stable and set at the correct incline angle.
Do not allow the elbows to drop below shoulder level to prevent shoulder joint stress.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Engage the core to maintain stability and prevent arching of the lower back.
Focus on a controlled motion, both during the lowering and lifting phases.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to compromised form.
Allowing the elbows to drop too low, increasing shoulder stress.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.

name: Incline Dumbbell Flyes - With A Twist
instructions: Hold a dumbbell in each hand and lie on an incline bench that is set to an incline angle of no more than 30 degrees.
Extend your arms above you with a slight bend at the elbows.
Now rotate the wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing you. Tip: The pinky fingers should be next to each other. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in, start to slowly lower the arms to the side while keeping the arms extended and while rotating the wrists until the palms of the hand are facing each other. Tip: At the end of the movement the arms will be by your side with the palms facing the ceiling.

As you exhale start to bring the dumbbells back up to the starting position by reversing the motion and rotating the hands so that the pinky fingers are next to each other again. Tip: Keep in mind that the movement will only happen at the shoulder joint and at the wrist. There is no motion that happens at the elbow joint.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and wide arc motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise involves significant shoulder rotation, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying on an incline bench may place stress on the cervical spine, particularly if the neck is not supported.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with osteoporosis, especially with the potential for dropping weights.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder strain: The wide range of motion can aggravate a strained shoulder muscle.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and wrist rotation may exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis in the elbow.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a steeper incline for greater challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort, and keep the elbows slightly more bent.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure the lower back is supported and maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and set to the correct incline angle.
Select an appropriate weight to avoid overloading the shoulder joint.
Avoid locking the elbows to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Control the descent and ascent of the dumbbells to maintain tension.
Rotate the wrists smoothly and in coordination with the shoulder movement.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to drop too low, causing shoulder strain.
Failing to maintain a consistent wrist rotation.

name: Incline Dumbbell Press
instructions: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand atop your thighs. The palms of your hands will be facing each other.
Then, using your thighs to help push the dumbbells up, lift the dumbbells one at a time so that you can hold them at shoulder width.
Once you have the dumbbells raised to shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. This will be your starting position.
Be sure to keep full control of the dumbbells at all times. Then breathe out and push the dumbbells up with your chest.
Lock your arms at the top, hold for a second, and then start slowly lowering the weight. Tip Ideally, lowering the weights should take about twice as long as raising them.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the dumbbells back on your thighs and then on the floor. This is the safest manner to release the dumbbells.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The incline position may strain the neck, particularly if the head is not supported properly.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of fracture increases with heavy weights and improper form.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The incline position can increase lumbar spine pressure, potentially worsening disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The incline position can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a flat bench to reduce the incline angle.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle or use heavier weights for added resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Ensure proper lumbar support by keeping the lower back pressed against the bench.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is set at a 30-45 degree incline to avoid excessive shoulder stress.
Maintain control of the dumbbells throughout the movement to prevent injury.
Avoid locking the elbows completely at the top to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the floor for stability.
Engage your core to support the lower back.
Lower the dumbbells slowly to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Arching the back excessively, which can lead to spinal strain.
Allowing the elbows to flare out too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.

name: Incline Hammer Curls
instructions: Seat yourself on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. You should pressed firmly against he back with your feet together. Allow the dumbbells to hang straight down at your side, holding them with a neutral grip. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by flexing at the elbow, attempting to keep the upper arm stationary.
Continue to the top of the movement and pause, then slowly return to the start position.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position on the incline bench may place stress on the shoulder joint, potentially aggravating impingement.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The incline position may strain the rotator cuff, especially if the shoulder is not stabilized.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased due to the potential for sudden, uncontrolled movements or falls.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or seated on a flat bench to reduce the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle or use heavier weights to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lower incline angle to reduce stress on the lower back.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, avoiding full extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the elbows and shoulders.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to reduce stress on the forearm and wrist.
formCues: Keep your upper arms stationary throughout the movement.
Engage your core to maintain stability on the incline bench.
Exhale as you curl the weights up and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Swinging the weights or using momentum to lift.
Allowing the elbows to drift forward or backward.
Arching the back excessively to lift heavier weights.

name: Incline Inner Biceps Curl
instructions: Hold a dumbbell in each hand and lie back on an incline bench.
The dumbbells should be at arm's length hanging at your sides and your palms should be facing out. This will be your starting position.

Now as you exhale curl the weight outward and up while keeping your forearms in line with your side deltoids. Continue the curl until the dumbbells are at shoulder height and to the sides of your deltoids. Tip: The end of the movement should look similar to a double biceps pose.
After a second contraction at the top of the movement, start to inhale and slowly lower the weights back to the starting position using the same path used to bring them up.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation and pain in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms during the curl can lead to compression of the shoulder structures, worsening impingement.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise requires stabilization from the rotator cuff muscles, which can be problematic if injured.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with weight-bearing exercises, especially with the arms in an extended position.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying on an incline bench can put stress on the cervical spine, potentially worsening conditions like herniated discs.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline of the bench or use heavier weights for added resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full extension and flexion, reducing stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is set at a secure incline to prevent slipping.
Avoid using excessive weight to maintain control throughout the movement.
Stop the exercise if you experience sharp pain in the shoulders, elbows, or wrists.
formCues: Keep your back flat against the bench to maintain stability.
Engage your core to support your lower back.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on the contraction of the biceps.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights, which reduces biceps engagement.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, which can lead to shoulder strain.
Overextending the wrists, which can lead to discomfort or injury.

name: Incline Push-Up
instructions: Stand facing bench or sturdy elevated platform. Place hands on edge of bench or platform, slightly wider than shoulder width.
Position forefoot back from bench or platform with arms and body straight. Arms should be perpendicular to body. Keeping body straight, lower chest to edge of box or platform by bending arms.
Push body up until arms are extended. Repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate - The incline push-up can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the overhead angle and load on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Moderate - The exercise places pressure on the wrists, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: High - The exercise can strain the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate - The weight-bearing position on the wrists can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Moderate - Maintaining a straight body position can strain the lower back if core engagement is insufficient.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Low - During later stages, the incline position may cause discomfort or balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform the push-up against a wall instead of a bench to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Perform the push-up with one leg raised to increase core engagement and difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Reduce the range of motion and ensure elbows are not flaring out excessively.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform the exercise on fists or use push-up bars to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Focus on engaging the core and avoid arching the back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench or platform is stable and at an appropriate height to avoid excessive strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
Engage your core to prevent sagging hips.
Lower your chest to the bench with control, avoiding bouncing.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag, leading to lower back strain.
Flaring elbows out too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Bouncing off the bench instead of controlled lowering.

name: Incline Push-Up Close-Grip
instructions: Stand facing a Smith machine bar or sturdy elevated platform at an appropriate height.
Place your hands next to one another on the bar.
Position your feet back from the bar with arms and body straight. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lower your chest to the bar by bending the arms.
Return to the starting position by extending the elbows, pressing yourself back up.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The close-grip position may exacerbate impingement symptoms due to increased internal rotation and stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places significant load on the triceps and elbows, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The wrist extension required can increase discomfort in individuals with wrist pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrist can exacerbate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise can place stress on the rotator cuff, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.advanced osteoporosis: Weight-bearing on the upper body may pose a fracture risk in individuals with severe osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may be compromised by the load and movement patterns of the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with hands on a higher platform or wall to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Elevate the feet on a platform to increase the difficulty by shifting more body weight onto the arms.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Widen the grip slightly to reduce internal rotation stress on the shoulders.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or a rolled towel under the palms to keep wrists in a neutral position.

safetyNotes: Ensure the platform is stable and secure to prevent slipping.
Maintain a straight line from head to heels to avoid excessive lumbar extension or flexion.
formCues: Engage the core to maintain a straight body line.
Keep elbows close to the body throughout the movement.
Lower the chest to the bar in a controlled manner.
Press through the palms to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag or pike, disrupting body alignment.
Flaring elbows out too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Bouncing off the bar instead of controlling the descent.

name: Incline Push-Up Depth Jump
instructions: For this drill you will need a box about 12 inches high, and two thick mats or aerobics steps.

Place the steps just outside of your shoulders, and place your feet on top of the box so that you are in an incline pushup position, your hands just inside the steps. This will be your starting position.

Begin by bending at the elbows to lower your body, quickly reversing position to push your body off of the ground. As you leave the ground, move your hands onto the steps, bending your elbows to absorb the impact.
Repeat the motion to return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The explosive nature and impact absorption can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The dynamic movement and load on the shoulders can aggravate existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The pressure on the wrists during push-off and landing can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The exercise may increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High-impact activities can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the forces involved in this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance and coordination.

modifications.easier: Perform regular incline push-ups without the depth jump to reduce impact and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the box or steps to add difficulty and range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise on a stable surface without the jump to minimize shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up handles to keep wrists in a neutral position and reduce stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box and mats are stable and secure to prevent slipping.
Warm up thoroughly before performing explosive movements.
Avoid locking elbows during the push-off phase to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Land softly on the steps, using your elbows to absorb impact.
Push explosively but control the descent to prevent jarring impacts.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag, leading to lower back strain.
Failing to absorb impact with elbows, increasing shoulder stress.
Using momentum instead of muscle control, reducing effectiveness.

name: Incline Push-Up Medium
instructions: Stand facing a Smith machine bar or sturdy elevated platform at an appropriate height.
Place your hands on the bar, with your hands about shoulder width apart.
Position your feet back from the bar with arms and body straight. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lower your chest to the bar by bending the arms.
Return to the starting position by extending the elbows, pressing yourself back up.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The exercise involves shoulder flexion and can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Weight-bearing on the wrists can increase pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise can place stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists may aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Improper form can lead to increased lumbar strain.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (late stages): Prone positions may be uncomfortable and affect breathing.
contraindicationDetails.recent chest or shoulder surgery: Healing tissues may be stressed by the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the push-up against a wall or higher surface to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Elevate feet on a platform to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Reduce range of motion or perform against a wall.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up handles to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Engage core and reduce range of motion.
