safetyNotes: Ensure the bar or platform is stable to prevent slipping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
Engage your core to prevent sagging in the lower back.
Inhale as you lower your chest and exhale as you push back up.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or pike.
Flaring elbows out excessively.
Bouncing off the bar instead of controlled movement.

name: Incline Push-Up Reverse Grip
instructions: Stand facing a Smith machine bar or sturdy elevated platform at an appropriate height.
Place your hands on the bar palms up, with your hands about shoulder width apart.
Position your feet back from the bar with arms and body straight. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lower your chest to the bar by bending the arms.
Return to the starting position by extending the elbows, pressing yourself back up.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The reverse grip can increase stress on the shoulder joint, potentially exacerbating impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The supinated grip places additional strain on the wrist extensors, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The position and movement may place undue stress on the rotator cuff, risking further injury.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The wrist position can compress the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Maintaining a straight body position requires core engagement, which may be challenging for those with lower back issues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a higher incline, such as against a wall, to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a lower incline or on a stability ball to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or a rolled towel under the wrists to maintain a neutral wrist position.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Engage the core and slightly bend the knees to reduce strain on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar or platform is stable and secure before starting.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your body as you lower down.
Engage your core to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Press through the palms evenly as you push back up.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag or rise, compromising spinal alignment.
Flaring the elbows out too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Using momentum rather than controlled movement.

name: Incline Push-Up Wide
instructions: Stand facing a Smith machine bar or sturdy elevated platform at an appropriate height.
Place your hands on the bar, with your hands wider than shoulder width.
Position your feet back from the bar with arms and body straight. Your arms should be perpendicular to the body. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lower your chest to the bar by bending the arms.
Return to the starting position by extending the elbows, pressing yourself back up.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Wide hand placement can exacerbate shoulder impingement by increasing the angle at which the shoulder joint is stressed.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Weight-bearing on the wrists can aggravate tendinitis due to repetitive strain.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The wide arm position can place additional stress on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists can increase symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Improper form or core instability can lead to increased lumbar stress, aggravating lower back pain.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid exercises that could lead to falls or excessive pressure on fragile bones.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that stress the shoulder joint until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with hands on a higher platform, such as a countertop, to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Elevate the feet on a platform to increase the angle and load on the upper body.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Narrow the hand placement to reduce shoulder stress and perform on a higher incline.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or fists to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Focus on core engagement and perform on a higher incline to reduce lumbar stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the platform is stable and can support your weight.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement.
formCues: Engage the core to keep the body in a straight line.
Lower the chest towards the bar with control.
Keep elbows slightly bent at the top to maintain tension.
commonMistakes: Sagging hips due to lack of core engagement.
Flaring elbows excessively, which can increase shoulder stress.
Bouncing off the bar instead of controlled movement.

name: Intermediate Groin Stretch
instructions: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Loop a belt, rope, or band around one of your feet, and swing that leg as far to the side as you can. This will be your starting position.
Pull gently on the belt to create tension in your groin and hamstring muscles. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and repeat on the other side.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or sciatica should avoid this exercise or perform it with significant modifications to prevent exacerbating symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Those with hip or knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the stretch to avoid excessive strain on the joints.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify the position to avoid lying flat on the back for extended periods.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical recovery, particularly involving the hip, knee, or lower back, requires clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this stretch.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if experiencing acute strains or sprains in the groin or hamstring area.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the leg bent at the knee to reduce tension on the hamstrings.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds and add a slight pulsing motion to deepen the stretch.
modifications.injury_friendly: For lower back pain, perform the stretch with the non-stretching leg bent and foot flat on the floor to reduce spinal stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking motions to prevent muscle strain.
Ensure the band or rope is secure to prevent slipping.
formCues: Keep your back flat against the floor.
Engage your core to stabilize your pelvis.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to arch off the floor.
Using a band that is too short, causing excessive tension.
Holding the breath during the stretch.

name: Intermediate Hip Flexor and Quad Stretch
instructions: Lie face down on the floor, with a rope, belt, or band looped around one foot.

Flex the knee and extend the hip of the leg to be stretched, using both hands to pull on the belt. Your knee and your hip should come off of the floor, creating tension in the hip flexors and quadriceps. Hold the stretch for 10-20 seconds, and repeat on the other leg.

herniated disc.explanation: The exercise involves spinal extension which may exacerbate symptoms.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The knee flexion and pressure may increase joint stress.

hip impingement.explanation: Extreme hip extension may aggravate symptoms.

recent knee surgery.explanation: The exercise places stress on the knee joint which may hinder recovery.

pregnancy.explanation: Lying prone and the stretch may be uncomfortable and unsafe, especially in later stages.

acute lower back pain.explanation: The exercise could increase lumbar spine stress and exacerbate pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the knee on the ground and use a wall for support instead of lying prone.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds and add a slight pelvic tilt to intensify the stretch.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the stretch standing, using a chair for support to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a softer surface or pad under the knee to reduce pressure.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive force when pulling on the band to prevent muscle strain.
Ensure the band is secure to prevent slipping.
Do not perform if experiencing sharp pain in the hip or knee.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to protect the lower back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the stretch.
Ensure the hips remain square to the ground.
commonMistakes: Overarching the lower back.
Allowing the knee to flare out to the side.
Pulling too aggressively on the band.

name: Internal Rotation with Band
instructions: Choke the band around a post. The band should be at the same height as your elbow. Stand with your right side to the band a couple of feet away.
Grasp the end of the band with your right hand, and keep your elbow pressed firmly to your side. We recommend you hold a pad or foam roll in place with your elbow to keep it firmly in position.
With your upper arm in position, your elbow should be flexed to 90 degrees with your hand reaching away from your torso. This will be your starting position.
Execute the movement by rotating your arm in a forehand motion, keeping your elbow in place.
Continue as far as you are able, pause, and then return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity; the exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to the internal rotation motion.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: High severity; internal rotation can strain the rotator cuff muscles, delaying healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate severity; risk of fracture due to sudden or excessive force on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High severity; avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.bursitis: Moderate severity; inflammation may worsen with repetitive motion.
contraindicationDetails.tendinitis: Moderate severity; repetitive motion can exacerbate inflammation and pain.

modifications.easier: Reduce band resistance or perform the exercise without a band to focus on the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase band resistance or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform isometric holds at the end range of motion to minimize movement while still engaging the muscles.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored to prevent snapping back.
Avoid using excessive resistance that compromises form.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
formCues: Keep your elbow tucked into your side throughout the movement.
Maintain a 90-degree angle at the elbow.
Rotate your arm smoothly without jerking.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to drift away from the body.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Over-rotating the shoulder beyond a comfortable range.

name: Inverted Row
instructions: Position a bar in a rack to about waist height. You can also use a smith machine.

Take a wider than shoulder width grip on the bar and position yourself hanging underneath the bar. Your body should be straight with your heels on the ground with your arms fully extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by flexing the elbow, pulling your chest towards the bar. Retract your shoulder blades as you perform the movement.
Pause at the top of the motion, and return yourself to the start position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or severe spinal stenosis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal loading and strain.

shoulder_impingement.details: Those with shoulder impingement may experience discomfort due to the overhead pulling motion. Modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

elbow_tendinitis.details: Elbow tendinitis sufferers should monitor for pain and may need to reduce grip width or load.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify the exercise to avoid supine positions and excessive strain.

recent_abdominal_surgery.details: Avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider due to the potential for increased intra-abdominal pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with knees bent and feet flat on the ground to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Elevate feet on a bench or stability ball to increase the difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform with a TRX or suspension trainer to allow for a more neutral spine position.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely positioned and can support your weight.
Maintain a straight line from head to heels to avoid excessive lumbar extension.
formCues: Engage core muscles to maintain a neutral spine.
Retract shoulder blades fully at the top of the movement.
Keep elbows close to the body throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise excessively, leading to poor spinal alignment.
Using momentum rather than controlled movements.
Failing to retract shoulder blades fully.

name: Inverted Row with Straps
instructions: Hang a rope or suspension straps from a rack or other stable object. Grasp the ends and position yourself in a supine position hanging from the ropes. Your body should be straight with your heels on the ground with your arms fully extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by flexing the elbow, pulling your chest to your hands. Retract your shoulder blades as you perform the movement.
Pause at the top of the motion, and return yourself to the start position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pulling motion can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may increase inflammation and pain due to repetitive shoulder movements.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The supine position and pulling motion can increase spinal load, potentially worsening disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can place stress on the lower back, potentially aggravating this condition.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the straps can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The pulling motion and potential for falls can increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a higher body angle by raising the straps or using a barbell set at a higher height to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Elevate the feet on a bench or box to increase the difficulty by changing the angle of pull.

injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a neutral spine and engage core muscles to reduce stress on the lower back.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort and focus on scapular retraction.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use padded grips or wrist straps to reduce strain on the wrists.

safetyNotes: Ensure the suspension straps are securely anchored to prevent falls.
Maintain a straight line from head to heels to avoid excessive spinal load.
Avoid jerky movements to reduce the risk of injury.
formCues: Engage the core to maintain a straight body line.
Retract the shoulder blades fully at the top of the movement.
Keep the elbows close to the body during the pull.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag, which increases lower back strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Flaring the elbows out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.

name: Iron Cross

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and lateral arm movements can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights with arms extended can strain the neck, especially in those with cervical spine problems.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is increased due to the load and range of motion involved in the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Holding weights overhead can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or without weights to focus on form and control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage more stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, avoiding the overhead position.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize neck strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before performing the exercise to reduce the risk of injury.
Avoid locking the elbows to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to protect the back.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Lift the weights in a controlled manner, avoiding momentum.
Ensure the wrists are aligned with the forearms to prevent strain.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the arms to drop too quickly, increasing injury risk.
Arching the back excessively, which can strain the lumbar spine.

name: Iron Crosses (stretch)
instructions: Lie face down on the floor, with your arms extended out to your side, palms pressed to the floor. This will be your starting position.
To begin, flex one knee and bring that leg across the back of your body, attempting to touch it to the ground near the opposite hand.
Promptly return the leg to the starting postion, and quickly repeat with the other leg. Continue alternating for 10-20 repetitions.

spinal injuries.explanation: The rotational movement and spinal extension may exacerbate symptoms and cause further injury.

joint issues.explanation: The exercise involves significant hip rotation and shoulder stabilization, which may aggravate joint pain.

pregnancy.explanation: Lying prone and twisting may be uncomfortable and potentially unsafe, especially in later stages.

acute injuries.explanation: The exercise can place stress on healing tissues and should be avoided until fully recovered.

modifications.easier: Perform the movement more slowly and with a smaller range of motion to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed of the movement or add ankle weights for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a soft surface and limit the range of motion to avoid excessive spinal rotation.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Focus on controlled movements and avoid overextending the leg to minimize stress on the knee joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate space around you to prevent injury from hitting nearby objects.
Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Maintain a steady breathing pattern throughout the exercise.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back during the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Allowing the hips to lift excessively off the ground.
Failing to return to the starting position fully before switching legs.

name: Isometric Chest Squeezes
instructions: While either seating or standing, bend your arms at a 90-degree angle and place the palms of your hands together in front of your chest. Tip: Your hands should be open with the palms together and fingers facing forward (perpendicular to your torso).
Push both hands against each other as you contract your chest. Start with slow tension and increase slowly. Keep breathing normally as you execute this contraction.
Hold for the recommended number of seconds.
Now release the tension slowly.
Rest for the recommended amount of time and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity; pressing the palms together can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Moderate severity; pressure on the wrists may cause discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: High severity; the exercise may strain the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate severity; pressure on the palms can increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High severity; any chest pressure can increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent chest surgery: High severity; chest pressure can interfere with healing.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: High severity; any isometric exercise can increase cardiac workload.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a towel or soft ball between the palms to reduce pressure.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the hold or perform the exercise with a resistance band around the forearms.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with elbows slightly lower than shoulder height to reduce strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform with fists together instead of palms to reduce wrist extension.

safetyNotes: Avoid holding your breath during the contraction to prevent a Valsalva maneuver.
Ensure that the pressure is applied evenly to avoid joint strain.
formCues: Keep shoulders relaxed and away from the ears.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to elevate towards the ears.
Holding the breath during the contraction.
Applying uneven pressure between the hands.

name: Isometric Neck Exercise - Front And Back
instructions: With your head and neck in a neutral position (normal position with head erect facing forward), place both of your hands on the front side of your head.
Now gently push forward as you contract the neck muscles but resisting any movement of your head. Start with slow tension and increase slowly. Keep breathing normally as you execute this contraction.
Hold for the recommended number of seconds.
Now release the tension slowly.
Rest for the recommended amount of time and repeat with your hands placed on the back side of your head.

contraindicationDetails.cervical spine injury: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or other cervical spine injuries should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spondylosis: Degenerative changes in the cervical spine can be aggravated by isometric contractions, potentially leading to increased pain or nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.recent neck surgery: Post-surgical patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent disruption of the healing process.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with osteoporosis, especially in the cervical spine, making this exercise potentially hazardous.
contraindicationDetails.acute neck pain: Performing isometric exercises during acute pain episodes can worsen symptoms or delay recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with less resistance by using only one hand or reducing the force applied.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the hold or add a slight resistance band around the head for additional resistance.
modifications.injury_friendly: For individuals with mild neck discomfort, perform the exercise lying down to reduce gravitational forces on the cervical spine.

safetyNotes: Avoid sudden movements or jerking motions during the exercise.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
Ensure the neck is in a neutral position to prevent excessive strain.
formCues: Keep your head and neck aligned with your spine.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
Breathe steadily throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Applying too much force too quickly.
Holding breath during the contraction.
Allowing the head to tilt or rotate.

name: Isometric Neck Exercise - Sides
instructions: With your head and neck in a neutral position (normal position with head erect facing forward), place your left hand on the left side of your head.

Now gently push towards the left as you contract the left neck muscles but resisting any movement of your head. Start with slow tension and increase slowly. Keep breathing normally as you execute this contraction.
Hold for the recommended number of seconds.
Now release the tension slowly.
Rest for the recommended amount of time and repeat with your right hand placed on the right side of your head.

contraindicationDetails.cervical spine injury: High severity. Any existing injury to the cervical spine could be exacerbated by the isometric contraction, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spondylosis: Moderate severity. Degenerative changes in the cervical spine may lead to discomfort or increased pain during isometric exercises.
contraindicationDetails.recent neck surgery: High severity. Post-surgical recovery requires clearance from a healthcare provider before engaging in neck exercises.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High severity. Increased risk of fractures in the cervical vertebrae due to compromised bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute neck pain: High severity. Exercise could exacerbate pain and underlying conditions.
contraindicationDetails.cervical radiculopathy: Moderate severity. Pressure on the cervical nerves may be increased, leading to pain or numbness.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with less force and shorter hold times, focusing on gentle activation.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the hold or apply more force, ensuring no pain is felt.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise supine to reduce gravitational load on the neck, ensuring minimal force is used.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerky or sudden movements.
Stop immediately if any pain or discomfort occurs.
Maintain normal breathing throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep head and neck in a neutral position.
Apply force gradually and evenly.
Ensure shoulders remain relaxed and not elevated.
commonMistakes: Holding breath during the contraction.
Applying force too quickly or too forcefully.
Allowing the head to tilt or rotate.

name: Isometric Wipers
instructions: Assume a push-up position, supporting your weight on your hands and toes while keeping your body straight. Your hands should be just outside of shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
Begin by shifting your body weight as far to one side as possible, allowing the elbow on that side to flex as you lower your body.
Reverse the motion by extending the flexed arm, pushing yourself up and then dropping to the other side.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The dynamic shifting of weight can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to increased compression in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The weight-bearing nature of the exercise can aggravate wrist tendinitis due to repetitive stress on the wrist joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise requires strong rotator cuff stabilization, which can be compromised in individuals with existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Prolonged wrist extension during the exercise can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Maintaining a plank position can strain the lower back, especially if core engagement is insufficient.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The flexion and extension of the elbow under load can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on your knees instead of toes to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Elevate your feet on a stable surface to increase the difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform the exercise on fists or use push-up bars to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Focus on engaging the core and reduce the range of motion to minimize strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a stable surface to prevent slipping.
Warm up adequately before performing the exercise.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Distribute weight evenly between hands and feet.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise, compromising spinal alignment.
Failing to engage the core, leading to lower back strain.
Shifting weight too quickly, which can cause loss of control.

name: JM Press
instructions: Start the exercise the same way you would a close grip bench press. You will lie on a flat bench while holding a barbell at arms length (fully extended) with the elbows in. However, instead of having the arms perpendicular to the torso, make sure the bar is set in a direct line above the upper chest. This will be your starting position.

Now beginning from a fully extended position lower the bar down as if performing a lying triceps extension. Inhale as you perform this movement. When you reach the half way point, let the bar roll back about one inch by moving the upper arms towards your legs until they are perpendicular to the torso. Tip: Keep the bend at the elbows constant as you bring the upper arms forward.
As you exhale, press the bar back up by using the triceps to perform a close grip bench press.
Now go back to the starting position and start over.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The JM Press involves shoulder movement that can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the position of the arms and the load on the shoulder joint.

rotator cuff tear.explanation: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which can worsen a rotator cuff tear.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The triceps activation and elbow flexion/extension can aggravate tendinitis symptoms.

wrist pain.explanation: Holding the barbell can put strain on the wrists, especially if there is pre-existing pain.

hypertension.explanation: While the exercise is not inherently risky for blood pressure, individuals with hypertension should monitor their response to heavy lifting.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for a more natural wrist position and reduced load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion and challenge the stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive shoulder extension and use lighter weights.
injury_friendly.elbow_pain: Use resistance bands instead of a barbell to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely gripped to prevent slippage.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy to ensure safety.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in close to the body throughout the movement.
Maintain a controlled tempo to prevent excessive momentum.
Focus on engaging the triceps by squeezing at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out, which can increase shoulder stress.
Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Bouncing the bar off the chest, which reduces muscle activation and increases injury risk.

name: Jackknife Sit-Up
instructions: Lie flat on the floor (or exercise mat) on your back with your arms extended straight back behind your head and your legs extended also. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, bend at the waist while simultaneously raising your legs and arms to meet in a jackknife position. Tip: The legs should be extended and lifted at approximately a 35-45 degree angle from the floor and the arms should be extended and parallel to your legs. The upper torso should be off the floor.
While inhaling, lower your arms and legs back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high: The flexion and rotation involved can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high: Lumbar flexion may increase symptoms by compressing the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high: Spinal flexion can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high: The exercise may aggravate sciatic nerve irritation.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate: Spinal flexion increases fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate: Core exercises involving spinal flexion are generally not recommended, especially in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high: Avoid until cleared by a physician to prevent strain on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform a bent-knee version where the knees are bent at 90 degrees, reducing the lever arm and stress on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or hold a light dumbbell in your hands to increase resistance.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform a partial range of motion or substitute with a plank to reduce spinal flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking motions to prevent strain on the lower back.
Maintain a neutral neck position to avoid cervical strain.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you lift your arms and legs, inhale as you return to the starting position.
Keep movements controlled and smooth.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the body instead of core engagement.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively during the movement.
Lifting the neck excessively, leading to strain.

name: Janda Sit-Up
instructions: Position your body on the floor in the basic sit-up position; knees to a ninety degree angle with feet flat on the floor and arms either crossed over your chest or to the sides. This will be your starting position.

As you strongly tighten your glutes and hamstrings, fill your lungs with air and in a slow (three to six second count) ascent, slowly exhale. Tip: It is important to tighten the glutes and hamstrings as this will cause the hip flexors to be inactivated in a process called reciprocal inhibition, which basically means that opposite muscles to the contracted ones will relax.
As you inhale, slowly go back in a controlled manner to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The flexion of the spine during the sit-up can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - Spinal flexion can increase pressure on the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - Lumbar flexion can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high - Flexion may aggravate sciatic nerve pain.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - Spinal flexion increases the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - Supine position and abdominal pressure may be uncomfortable or unsafe, especially in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high - Stress on the abdominal region can impede healing.

modifications.easier: Perform a partial sit-up, lifting only the head and shoulders off the ground.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight plate on the chest to increase resistance.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform a plank or dead bug exercise to engage the core without spinal flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking motions to prevent strain on the spine.
Ensure the lower back remains in contact with the floor to minimize lumbar stress.
formCues: Engage the core by drawing the navel towards the spine.
Exhale slowly during the ascent to maintain control.
Keep the chin slightly tucked to avoid neck strain.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the torso instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Allowing the feet to lift off the ground, reducing stability.
Arching the lower back excessively during the ascent.

name: Jefferson Squats
instructions: Place a barbell on the floor.
Stand in the middle of the bar length wise.
Bend down by bending at the knees and keeping your back straight and grasp the front of the bar with your right hand. Your palm should be in (neutral grip) facing the left side.

Grasp the rear of the bar with your left hand. The palm of your hand should be in neutral grip alignment (palms facing the right side). Tip: Ensure that your grip is even on the bar. Your torso should be positioned right in the middle of the bar and the distance between your torso and your right hand (which should be at the front) should be the same as the distance between your torso and your left hand (which should be to your back).
Now stand straight up with the weight. Tip: Your feet should be shoulder width apart and your toes slightly pointed out.

Squat down by bending at the knees and keeping your back straight until your upper thighs are parallel with the floor. Tip: Keep your back as vertical as possible with the floor and your head up. Also remember to not let your knees go past your toes. Inhale during this portion of the movement.

Now drive yourself back up to the starting position by pushing with the feet . Tip: Keep the bar hanging at arm's length and your elbows locked with a slight bend. The arms only serve as hooks. Avoid doing any lifting with them. Do the lifting with your thighs; not your arms.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid Jefferson Squats due to the axial load and potential for spinal compression.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: Those with knee arthritis, hip impingement, or tendinitis should be cautious due to the stress on the knee and hip joints during the squat movement.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: People with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid heavy lifting exercises like Jefferson Squats due to the increase in blood pressure and heart rate.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and potential strain on the lower back.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Individuals recovering from recent surgeries, particularly in the lower back, hips, or knees, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.
contraindicationDetails.chronic_conditions: Those with osteoporosis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of fractures from axial loading.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Avoid if experiencing acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the lower body or back.
contraindicationDetails.neurological_conditions: Individuals with balance disorders or neuropathy should avoid this exercise due to the risk of falls and inability to maintain proper form.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a dumbbell instead of a barbell to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to maintain a more upright posture and reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep squatting and reduce stress on the knees.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a safety squat bar or hold the barbell lower on the back to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is evenly loaded and securely gripped.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent back injury.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels to engage the posterior chain.
Keep your chest up and shoulders back to maintain a neutral spine.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to collapse inward during the squat.
Rounding the back, especially at the bottom of the squat.
Using the arms to lift the weight instead of the legs.

name: Jerk Balance
instructions: This drill helps you learn to drive yourself low enough during the jerk and corrects those who move backward during the movement. Begin with the bar racked in the jerk position, with the shoulders forward, torso upright, and the feet split slightly apart.
Initiate the movement as you would a normal jerk, dipping at the knees while keeping your torso vertical, and driving back up forcefully, using momentum and not your arms to elevate the weight.
Keep the rear foot in place, using it to drive your body forward into a full split as you jerk the weight. Recover by standing up with the weight overhead.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and dynamic movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The rapid overhead motion can strain the rotator cuff, increasing the risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The load on the shoulders and neck can aggravate cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The forceful extension of the arms can worsen tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lumbar spine instability: The dynamic nature of the exercise can stress the lower back, especially if core stability is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The split stance and dynamic movement require good balance, posing a risk for those with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform a push press instead of a jerk balance to reduce complexity and demand on coordination.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise from a deficit to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural shoulder movement.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the dip and focus on a controlled movement to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated to reduce lower back strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely racked before beginning.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on shoulder and hip mobility.
Use a spotter if attempting heavier weights.
formCues: Keep your torso upright throughout the movement.
Drive through the legs, not the arms, to elevate the weight.
Maintain a stable core to protect the lower back.
Ensure the rear foot remains in place during the drive.
commonMistakes: Leaning forward or backward excessively during the dip.
Using the arms instead of the legs to drive the weight.
Allowing the back foot to move during the split.

name: Jerk Dip Squat
instructions: This movement strengthens the dip portion of the jerk. Begin with the bar racked in the jerk position, with the shoulders forward to create a shelf and the bar lightly contacting the throat. The feet should be directly under the hips, with the feet turned out as is comfortable.

Keeping the torso vertical, dip by flexing the knees, allowing them to travel forward and without moving the hips to the rear. The dip should not be excessive. Return the weight to the starting position by driving forcefully though the feet.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The vertical loading and dynamic movement can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

joint_issues.explanation: Knee and hip arthritis or tendinitis may be aggravated by the dip and drive motion.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The exertion involved can increase blood pressure and heart rate, posing risks for those with hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise's balance and core stability demands can be unsafe during pregnancy, especially in later trimesters.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, knees, or hips, require avoiding heavy loading and dynamic movements.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or spine necessitate avoiding this exercise until fully healed.

modifications.easier: Perform the movement with a lighter barbell or PVC pipe to focus on form and control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the movement with a pause at the bottom of the dip to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the dip to reduce stress on the knees and ensure proper alignment.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is properly secured on the shoulders to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive forward lean to minimize spinal stress.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the joints and muscles for the movement.
formCues: Keep the torso upright and core engaged throughout the movement.
Initiate the dip by bending the knees, not by pushing the hips back.
Drive through the heels to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the dip.
Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Using too much weight, compromising form and safety.

name: Jogging, Treadmill
instructions: To begin, step onto the treadmill and select the desired option from the menu. Most treadmills have a manual setting, or you can select a program to run. Typically, you can enter your age and weight to estimate the amount of calories burned during exercise. Elevation can be adjusted to change the intensity of the workout.

Treadmills offer convenience, cardiovascular benefits, and usually have less impact than jogging outside. A 150 lb person will burn almost 250 calories jogging for 30 minutes, compared to more than 450 calories running. Maintain proper posture as you jog, and only hold onto the handles when necessary, such as when dismounting or checking your heart rate.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities like jogging can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: Jogging increases heart rate and blood pressure, which can be risky for individuals with uncontrolled heart conditions.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the repetitive impact of jogging.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The impact and repetitive motion can aggravate spinal issues.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The moving surface of a treadmill can increase the risk of falls.

modifications.easier: Walking on the treadmill at a moderate pace.
modifications.harder: Increasing the treadmill incline or speed to simulate running.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a treadmill with cushioning and maintain a slight incline to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on maintaining a neutral spine and avoid excessive incline.

safetyNotes: Always use the safety clip to stop the treadmill in case of emergency.
Ensure the treadmill is on a stable surface to prevent tipping.
Start at a slow pace to warm up before increasing speed.
formCues: Keep your head up and gaze forward.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows and swing arms naturally.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Land softly on the midfoot to reduce impact.
commonMistakes: Holding onto the handrails for support, which can lead to poor posture.
Overstriding, which increases impact on the joints.
Slouching or leaning forward excessively.

recommendedReps.endurance: Continuous jogging for the duration of the set

name: Keg Load
instructions: To load kegs, place the desired number a distance from the loading platform, typically 30-50 feet.
Begin by grabbing the close handle of the first keg, tilting it onto its side to grab the opposite edge of the bottom of the keg. Lift the keg up to your chest.

The higher you can place the keg, the faster you should be able to move to the platform. Shouldering is usually not allowed. Be sure to keep a firm hold on the keg. Move as quickly as possible to the platform, and load it, extending through your hips, knees, and ankles to get it as high as possible.
Return to the starting position to retrieve the next keg, and repeat until the event is completed.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal loading and flexion can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The spinal extension and compression can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Lumbar loading can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Heavy lifting may aggravate nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: Joint stress can exacerbate pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Heavy lifting can cause dangerous spikes in blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.heart disease: Intense physical exertion can strain the cardiovascular system.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High risk of fractures due to bone fragility.
contraindicationDetails.recent back surgery: Healing tissues may be compromised by heavy lifting.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Carrying heavy loads may increase fall risk.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter keg or sandbag to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the distance to the platform or use a heavier keg.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a partial lift using a lighter keg and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit knee flexion and focus on hip hinge mechanics.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Avoid lifting the keg above chest height and use a lighter load.

safetyNotes: Always warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise.
Ensure the path to the platform is clear to prevent tripping.
Use appropriate footwear for stability and grip.
formCues: Keep your back straight and core engaged throughout the lift.
Lift with your legs, not your back, by driving through your heels.
Maintain a firm grip on the keg to prevent slipping.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using the arms instead of the legs to lift the keg.
Failing to secure a proper grip on the keg.

name: Kettlebell Arnold Press
instructions: Clean a kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The palm should be facing inward.
Looking straight ahead, press the kettlebell out and overhead, rotating your wrist so that your palm faces forward at the top of the motion.
Return the kettlebell to the starting position, with the palm facing in.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by further compressing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The load on the shoulders and neck during the press can aggravate cervical disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Overhead exercises can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise requires significant shoulder mobility and stability, which may not be suitable during the recovery phase.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis of the shoulder: The joint stress from pressing movements can exacerbate pain and degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The unilateral nature of the exercise requires good balance and proprioception, which can be challenging for individuals with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform a seated dumbbell Arnold press to reduce balance demands and use lighter weights.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise standing on one leg to challenge balance further.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a partial range of motion press, avoiding the top range where pain is typically exacerbated.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare the shoulder joint and surrounding muscles.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the press to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to protect the lower back.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Keep the wrist neutral and aligned with the forearm.
Rotate the wrist smoothly as you press overhead.
Control the kettlebell on the way down to avoid jerky movements.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Failing to rotate the wrist properly during the press.
Neglecting to engage the core, leading to instability.

name: Kettlebell Dead Clean
instructions: Place kettlebell between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Lower the kettlebell, keeping the hamstrings loaded by keeping your back straight and your butt out.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and instability.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or shoulder impingement should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress and avoid excessive rotation.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before performing high-intensity exercises like the kettlebell dead clean.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance changes and abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical recovery, particularly involving the spine or shoulders, requires clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Conditions like osteoporosis require caution due to the risk of fractures; modifications to reduce impact and load are advised.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma should completely avoid this exercise until fully healed to prevent further injury.

modifications.easier: Perform a kettlebell deadlift instead of a clean to reduce complexity and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier kettlebell or perform the exercise with two kettlebells for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid deep squatting positions to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the clean portion and perform a deadlift only to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is of appropriate weight to maintain control throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid jerky movements and focus on smooth transitions.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips explosively.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using the arms too much instead of the hips and legs.
Allowing the kettlebell to swing away from the body.

name: Kettlebell Figure 8
instructions: Place one kettlebell between your legs and take a wider than shoulder width stance. Bend over by pushing your butt out and keeping your back flat.
Pick up a kettlebell and pass it to your other hand between your legs. The receiving hand should reach from behind the legs. Go back and forth for several repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: The bending and twisting motion can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or sciatica.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: The arm movement may aggravate shoulder impingement or rotator cuff issues.
contraindicationDetails.rotator_cuff_tendinitis: Repetitive arm motion can increase inflammation in the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance and coordination.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The bending and twisting can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The forward bending and twisting may not be suitable, especially in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter kettlebell or without any weight to focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion and focus on core engagement.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid passing the kettlebell too far behind the legs.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is of appropriate weight to maintain control.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent lower back strain.
Engage the core muscles to stabilize the torso.
formCues: Keep your back flat and chest up as you bend forward.
Push your hips back rather than bending at the waist.
Pass the kettlebell close to your body to maintain control.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the movement.
Using too heavy a kettlebell, leading to loss of control.
Not engaging the core, leading to instability.

name: Kettlebell Hang Clean
instructions: Place kettlebell between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.

Clean kettlebell to your shoulder. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.
Lower kettlebell to a hanging position between your legs while keeping the hamstrings loaded. Keep your head up at all times.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal stress.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or shoulder impingement should modify the exercise to reduce joint strain.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before attempting due to the dynamic nature of the exercise.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid due to balance and core stability challenges.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from surgeries, particularly in the lower back, shoulders, or knees, should avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid due to the risk of fractures. Those with diabetes should monitor blood sugar levels closely.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing any acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the involved areas.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications to ensure safety.

modifications.easier: Perform a kettlebell deadlift instead to focus on form and reduce complexity.
modifications.harder: Progress to a single-arm kettlebell clean to increase difficulty and unilateral stability demands.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter kettlebell and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat and ensure proper alignment to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the clean portion and perform a controlled kettlebell swing instead.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is of appropriate weight to maintain control throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
formCues: Start with feet shoulder-width apart and kettlebell between feet.
Push hips back and keep chest up as you lower into the starting position.
Drive through the heels and extend hips and knees explosively.
Rotate wrist as kettlebell approaches shoulder, keeping it close to the body.
Control the descent back to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using arms instead of hips to lift the kettlebell.
Allowing the kettlebell to swing too far from the body.

name: Kettlebell One-Legged Deadlift
instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle in one hand. Stand on one leg, on the same side that you hold the kettlebell.
Keeping that knee slightly bent, perform a stiff legged deadlift by bending at the hip, extending your free leg behind you for balance.
Continue lowering the kettlebell until you are parallel to the ground, and then return to the upright position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and instability.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

balance_disorders.details: Individuals with significant balance issues or neuropathy should avoid this exercise due to the risk of falls.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance changes and potential strain on the lower back.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a kettlebell to focus on balance and form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a two-legged deadlift variation to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and ensure the knee is slightly bent throughout the movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without compromising form.
formCues: Keep the back straight and hinge at the hips.
Engage the core to maintain balance.
Keep the shoulders square and avoid twisting.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Allowing the knee to lock or collapse inward.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Kettlebell Pass Between The Legs
instructions: Place one kettlebell between your legs and take a comfortable stance. Bend over by pushing your butt out and keeping your back flat.
Pick up a kettlebell and pass it to your other hand between your legs, in the fashion of a "W". Go back and forth for several repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: The forward bending motion and rotational component can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or sciatica.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: The arm movements may aggravate shoulder impingement or rotator cuff issues.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise can pose a fall risk for individuals with balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The bending and twisting can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The forward bending and twisting may be uncomfortable or unsafe, especially in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter kettlebell or without any weight to master the movement pattern.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise on a single leg to challenge balance and stability.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on engaging the core to support the spine.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the exercise if shoulder pain persists; consider a static core exercise like a plank instead.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is securely gripped to prevent dropping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to protect the lower back.
Avoid excessive twisting or bending beyond comfort.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Push your hips back as you bend forward, maintaining a flat back.
Pass the kettlebell smoothly between your legs, keeping your movements controlled.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the bend.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward.

name: Kettlebell Pirate Ships
instructions: With a wide stance, hold a kettlebell with both hands. Allow it to hang at waist level with your arms extended. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by turning to one side, swinging the kettlebell to head height. Briefly pause at the top of the motion.
Allow the bell to drop as you rotate to the opposite side, again raising the kettlebell to head height.
Repeat for the desired amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead swinging motion may exacerbate impingement symptoms due to narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Repetitive swinging can increase inflammation in the tendons of the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The dynamic nature and head-height swings can place undue stress on the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The rapid changes in body position and potential for Valsalva maneuver can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-operative tissues are vulnerable to re-injury with overhead and dynamic movements.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The rotational and swinging movements require good balance and proprioception.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The rotational force and weight of the kettlebell can exacerbate lower back pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter kettlebell or use a dumbbell for more control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to below shoulder height and reduce weight.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated kettlebell swings to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure a clear area around you to prevent accidents.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise.
Avoid jerky movements; maintain control throughout the swing.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Keep your shoulders down and back to avoid impingement.
Use your hips to initiate the swing, not just your arms.
commonMistakes: Using too heavy a kettlebell, leading to poor form.
Allowing the kettlebell to swing too far back, causing hyperextension.
Neglecting core engagement, leading to potential back strain.

name: Kettlebell Pistol Squat
instructions: Pick up a kettlebell with two hands and hold it by the horns. Hold one leg off of the floor and squat down on the other.
Squat down by flexing the knee and sitting back with the hips, holding the kettlebell up in front of you.
Hold the bottom position for a second and then reverse the motion, driving through the heel and keeping your head and chest up.
Lower yourself again and repeat.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The unilateral load and deep squat position can exacerbate spinal issues such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

joint_issues.explanation: Knee and hip joint stress is significant in this exercise, which can aggravate conditions like arthritis or tendinitis.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The exercise can elevate heart rate significantly, which may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: Balance and core stability challenges make this exercise unsafe during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Post-surgical individuals, particularly those recovering from knee, hip, or spinal surgeries, should avoid this exercise.

neurological_conditions.explanation: Balance and proprioception demands are high, posing risks for individuals with balance disorders or neuropathy.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back should preclude participation in this exercise.

chronic_conditions.explanation: Conditions like osteoporosis require caution due to the risk of fractures from falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight pistol squat or use a TRX suspension trainer for support.
modifications.harder: Increase the kettlebell weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter kettlebell and perform the exercise with a back support or wall for balance.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to a half squat and use a knee brace if necessary.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare joints and muscles.
Avoid locking the knee at the top of the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back.
Engage the core to maintain balance.
Drive through the heel of the supporting leg.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to collapse inward.
Rounding the back or leaning forward excessively.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Kettlebell Seated Press
instructions: Sit on the floor and spread your legs out comfortably.
Clean one kettlebell to your shoulder.
Press the kettlebell up and out until it is locked out overhead. Return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Pressing overhead can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Overhead pressing can increase inflammation and pain in the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The load on the shoulder and neck can aggravate cervical disc issues, leading to increased pain or neurological symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Overhead pressing can cause a significant increase in blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable and may not withstand the load and range of motion required for this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Sitting on the floor with legs spread can increase lumbar spine compression, aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The seated position and overhead load can increase shear forces on the spine, worsening the condition.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter kettlebell or use a dumbbell for better control.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier kettlebell or perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a landmine press to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Sit on a bench with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is securely gripped to prevent dropping.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back during the press.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the torso.
Press the kettlebell in a straight line overhead.
Keep your elbow slightly in front of your body at the start of the press.
commonMistakes: Leaning back excessively during the press.
Allowing the elbow to flare out too much.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Kettlebell Seesaw Press
instructions: Clean two kettlebells two your shoulders.
Press one kettlebell.
Lower the kettlebell and immediately press the other kettlebell. Make sure to do the same amount of reps on both sides.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by further compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Pressing movements can increase inflammation and pain in the tendons of the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The load on the shoulders and neck during pressing can increase cervical spine compression, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The overhead position can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which may not be suitable during the recovery phase post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance and coordination, which could be challenging for individuals with balance disorders.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture due to the load and dynamic movement is increased in individuals with severe osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Perform a seated dumbbell press to reduce the need for balance and coordination.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance further.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a landmine press to reduce overhead stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up of the shoulder and upper body before performing the exercise.
Start with lighter weights to master the form before progressing to heavier loads.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the press to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Engage the core to maintain a stable torso throughout the movement.
Keep the wrists neutral and aligned with the forearms.
Press the kettlebell directly overhead, avoiding any forward or backward lean.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Failing to maintain a neutral wrist position.

name: Kettlebell Sumo High Pull
instructions: Place a kettlebell on the ground between your feet. Position your feet in a wide stance, and grasp the kettlebell with two hands. Set your hips back as far as possible, with your knees bent. Keep your chest and head up. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending the hips and knees, simultaneously pulling the kettlebell to your shoulders, raising your elbows as you do so. Reverse the motion to return to the starting position.

herniated disc.explanation: The dynamic movement and spinal loading can exacerbate disc herniation and increase risk of nerve compression.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The high pull phase can aggravate shoulder impingement due to the overhead movement and shoulder abduction.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The wide stance and knee flexion may increase joint stress, potentially worsening symptoms.

hypertension.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver often used in lifting can spike blood pressure, posing risks for those with hypertension.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise involves dynamic movements and balance challenges that may not be suitable during pregnancy, especially in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the movement with a lighter kettlebell or use a dumbbell for more control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a seated high pull with resistance bands to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the squat to reduce knee flexion and stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a sumo deadlift without the high pull to avoid shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Drive through your heels during the upward phase.
Lead with your elbows during the pull to engage the traps.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward.

name: Kettlebell Thruster
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so. This will be your starting position.
Begin to squat by flexing your hips and knees, lowering your hips between your legs. Maintain an upright, straight back as you descend as low as you can.

At the bottom, reverse direction and squat by extending your knees and hips, driving through your heels. As you do so, press both kettlebells overhead by extending your arms straight up, using the momentum from the squat to help drive the weights upward.
As you begin the next repetition, return the weights to the shoulders.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High overhead load can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Pressing movements can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: Overhead pressing can increase cervical spine compression.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Valsalva maneuver and overhead pressing can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Overhead movements can compromise surgical recovery.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Deep squatting can increase joint stress and pain.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The load on the spine during squatting and pressing can aggravate symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a single kettlebell held with both hands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise on an unstable surface.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit squat depth to a comfortable range and use lighter weights.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a push press instead of a full thruster to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before performing the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbows forcefully at the top of the press.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Drive through your heels during the squat phase.
Use the momentum from the squat to assist the press.
