commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Overarching the lower back during the press.
Using excessive weight leading to poor form.

name: Kettlebell Turkish Get-Up (Lunge style)
instructions: Lie on your back on the floor and press a kettlebell to the top position by extending the elbow. Bend the knee on the same side as the kettlebell.

Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, pivot to the opposite side and use your non- working arm to assist you in driving forward to the lunge position. Using your free hand, push yourself to a seated position, then progressing to one knee.
While looking up at the kettlebell, slowly stand up. Reverse the motion back to the starting position and repeat.
contraindications: severe arthritis in knees or shoulders

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and rotational movements can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise requires significant shoulder stability and can strain an already inflamed rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The rotational and load-bearing nature of the exercise can increase disc pressure.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The isometric hold and full-body engagement can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or knee surgery: The exercise involves complex movements that can strain healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires significant balance and coordination, posing a fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in knees or shoulders: The load and movement can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a kettlebell, focusing on the movement pattern.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier kettlebell or perform the exercise with a slow tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the lunge or perform the exercise on a soft surface to reduce joint impact.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lighter kettlebell and ensure proper shoulder alignment throughout the movement.

safetyNotes: Always keep your eyes on the kettlebell to maintain focus and alignment.
Ensure the kettlebell is securely gripped and balanced before starting the movement.
Avoid twisting or jerking motions to prevent strain on the spine and shoulders.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement to stabilize your spine.
Keep the kettlebell directly above your shoulder at all times.
Move slowly and deliberately, focusing on controlled transitions between positions.
commonMistakes: Allowing the kettlebell to drift away from the shoulder line.
Rushing through the movement, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Neglecting core engagement, resulting in a lack of stability.

name: Kettlebell Turkish Get-Up (Squat style)
instructions: Lie on your back on the floor and press a kettlebell to the top position by extending the elbow. Bend the knee on the same side as the kettlebell.
Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, pivot to the opposite side and use your non- working arm to assist you in driving forward to the lunge position.

Using your free hand, push yourself to a seated position, then progressing to your feet. While looking up at the kettlebell, slowly stand up. Reverse the motion back to the starting position and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the compression of structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise requires significant shoulder stabilization, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The rotational and load-bearing aspects of the exercise can increase spinal pressure, worsening disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The exercise involves significant isometric holds and can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or spinal surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not be ready for the load and range of motion required, risking re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires significant balance and coordination, which can be challenging for individuals with balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of falls and fractures is higher due to the dynamic and load-bearing nature of the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the Turkish Get-Up without a kettlebell to focus on form and stability.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise with a slow tempo to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lighter kettlebell or perform the exercise with a dumbbell to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on core engagement and reduce the range of motion to minimize spinal stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area around you is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Use a weight that allows you to maintain control throughout the movement.
Avoid jerky or uncontrolled movements, especially during transitions.
formCues: Keep your eyes on the kettlebell throughout the movement to maintain alignment.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine during the exercise.
Drive through your heel when transitioning to a standing position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the kettlebell to drift away from the centerline of the body.
Neglecting core engagement, leading to a loss of balance.
Rushing through the movement without maintaining control.

name: Kettlebell Windmill
instructions: Place a kettlebell in front of your lead foot and clean and press it overhead with your opposite arm. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward. Press it overhead by extending the elbow.

Keeping the kettlebell locked out at all times, push your butt out in the direction of the locked out kettlebell. Turn your feet out at a forty-five degree angle from the arm with the locked out kettlebell. Bending at the hip to one side, sticking your butt out, slowly lean until you can touch the floor with your free hand. Keep your eyes on the kettlebell that you hold over your head at all times.
Pause for a second after reaching the ground and reverse the motion back to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The rotational and bending movements can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: Overhead position may aggravate impingement symptoms due to the compression of shoulder structures.

rotator_cuff_tendinitis.explanation: The exercise requires shoulder stability which can strain inflamed tendons.

balance_disorders.explanation: The exercise requires significant balance and coordination, posing a fall risk.

osteoporosis.explanation: The bending and twisting motions increase the risk of vertebral fractures.

hypertension.explanation: Overhead lifting can transiently increase blood pressure; monitor closely.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a kettlebell, focusing on form and balance.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier kettlebell or perform the exercise on a single leg for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight and limit the range of motion to avoid excessive spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a dumbbell instead of a kettlebell to reduce shoulder strain and keep the weight closer to the body.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the shoulders and core.
Avoid excessive weight to prevent loss of control.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your eyes on the kettlebell at all times.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Push your hips back rather than bending at the waist.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round, increasing spinal stress.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Not keeping the kettlebell directly overhead, leading to shoulder strain.

name: Kipping Muscle Up
instructions: Grip the rings using a false grip, with the base of your palms on top of the rings.
Begin with a movement swinging your legs backward slightly.

Counter that movement by swinging your legs forward and up, jerking your chin and chest back, pulling yourself up with both arms as you do so. As you reach the top position of the pull-up, pull the rings to your armpits as you roll your shoulders forward, allowing your elbows to move straight back behind you. This puts you into the proper position to continue into the dip portion of the movement.
Maintaining control and stability, extend through the elbow to complete the motion.
Use care when lowering yourself to the ground.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The dynamic and overhead nature of the kipping muscle up can exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms due to excessive range of motion and load on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The pulling and pushing phases can aggravate elbow tendinitis due to repetitive strain.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The false grip and transition phases can increase stress on the wrists, exacerbating existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The swinging and pulling motions can strain the cervical spine, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The dynamic nature of the exercise can increase spinal load, potentially worsening herniated disc symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise's dynamic movements can increase lumbar spine stress, exacerbating spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of falls and high-impact movements can be dangerous for individuals with osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places high demands on shoulder stability and strength, which may not be suitable during recovery.

modifications.easier: Use band-assisted muscle ups or perform strict pull-ups and dips separately to build strength.
modifications.harder: Increase the number of repetitions or add weight using a weighted vest.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform strict pull-ups and dips separately with controlled motion and reduced range of motion.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on strict pull-ups with core engagement to minimize lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure rings are securely fastened and can support your weight.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on shoulder and core activation.
Avoid excessive swinging to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Maintain a strong false grip throughout the movement.
Engage your core to stabilize your body during the swing.
Pull the rings to your armpits and keep elbows close to your body.
commonMistakes: Using excessive momentum instead of controlled strength.
Failing to maintain a false grip, leading to loss of control.
Allowing elbows to flare out during the transition phase.

name: Knee Across The Body
instructions: Lie down on the floor with your right leg straight. Bend your left leg and lower it across your body, holding the knee down toward the floor with your right hand. (The knee doesn't need to touch the floor if you're tight.)

Place your left arm comfortably beside you and turn your head to the left. Imagine you have a weight tied to your tailbone. let your tailbone fall back toward the floor as your chest reaches in the opposite direction to stretch your lower back. Switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. Twisting movements can exacerbate symptoms and increase pressure on the disc.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. The stretch may aggravate the sciatic nerve, especially if performed incorrectly.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Moderate severity. The exercise may cause discomfort or pain in the hip joint.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: High severity. Twisting and stretching can interfere with the healing process.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Twisting motions may increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. As pregnancy progresses, lying on the back can cause discomfort and twisting may not be advisable.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the bent knee supported by a pillow or bolster to reduce the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Extend the stretch by gently pulling the bent knee closer to the floor while maintaining proper form.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with both knees bent and feet flat on the floor, gently rocking the knees side to side.
injury_friendly.hip pain: Reduce the range of motion and avoid crossing the knee too far over the body.

safetyNotes: Avoid forcing the knee to the floor; the stretch should be gentle.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive twisting.
formCues: Keep your shoulders flat on the ground.
Engage your core to support the lower back.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulder to lift off the ground.
Forcing the knee to touch the floor, causing strain.
Holding the breath, which can increase tension.

name: Knee Circles
instructions: Stand with your legs together and hands by your waist.
Now move your knees in a circular motion as you breathe normally.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High stress on the knee joint during circular motion can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.meniscus tears: Rotational movement may increase the risk of further injury to the meniscus.
contraindicationDetails.patellofemoral pain syndrome: Circular knee movements can increase patellar tracking issues and pain.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee surgery: Post-surgical knees may not tolerate rotational forces well during recovery.
contraindicationDetails.severe balance disorders: The exercise requires balance, which may be challenging for those with significant balance impairments.

modifications.easier: Perform knee circles while seated to reduce load and improve stability.
modifications.harder: Perform knee circles on one leg to increase balance and core engagement.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the range of motion and perform the exercise slowly to minimize joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Engage core muscles to maintain a neutral spine and reduce lumbar stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive range of motion to prevent undue stress on the knee joint.
Maintain a controlled pace to ensure stability and prevent falls.
Stop immediately if you experience pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your feet together and knees slightly bent.
Engage your core to maintain balance.
Move your knees in a smooth, controlled circular motion.
commonMistakes: Using too large a range of motion, leading to joint strain.
Performing the exercise too quickly, compromising balance.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward, increasing stress on the joint.

name: Knee/Hip Raise On Parallel Bars
instructions: Position your body on the vertical leg raise bench so that your forearms are resting on the pads next to the torso and holding on to the handles. Your arms will be bent at a 90 degree angle.
The torso should be straight with the lower back pressed against the pad of the machine and the legs extended pointing towards the floor. This will be your starting position.

Now as you breathe out, lift your legs up as you keep them extended. Continue this movement until your legs are roughly parallel to the floor and then hold the contraction for a second. Tip: Do not use any momentum or swinging as you perform this exercise.
Slowly go back to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and nerve impingement.

hip_joint_issues.details: Those with hip impingement or arthritis may experience discomfort or pain due to the hip flexion involved. Modifications are recommended.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: People with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should exercise caution due to potential increases in intra-abdominal pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to potential strain on the abdominal wall and lower back.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from abdominal or hip surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with bent knees to reduce the load on the abdominals and hip flexors.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise with a slow tempo to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform lying leg raises on the floor to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.hip_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort in the hip joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid using momentum or swinging the legs to prevent undue stress on the lower back.
Ensure the lower back remains pressed against the pad to maintain spinal alignment.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement.
Keep the movement slow and controlled.
Exhale as you lift your legs and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the legs up.
Allowing the lower back to arch away from the pad.
Failing to engage the core muscles adequately.

name: Knee Tuck Jump
instructions: Begin in a comfortable standing position with your knees slightly bent. Hold your hands in front of you, palms down with your fingertips together at chest height. This will be your starting position.
Rapidly dip down into a quarter squat and immediately explode upward. Drive the knees towards the chest, attempting to touch them to the palms of the hands.
Jump as high as you can, raising your knees up, and then ensure a good land be re-extending your legs, absorbing impact through be allowing the knees to rebend.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities like knee tuck jumps can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: Jumping can increase strain on the patellar tendon, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: The dynamic nature of the jump increases the risk of ankle sprains.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee or ankle surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the impact forces of jumping.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, which may be compromised.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: The explosive movement can place stress on the spine, potentially aggravating existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular conditions: The high-intensity nature of the exercise can elevate heart rate and blood pressure significantly.

modifications.easier: Perform a standing knee raise without jumping, focusing on bringing the knees up to the chest.
modifications.harder: Add a tuck jump with a 180-degree turn for increased difficulty and coordination.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform low-impact knee raises while standing or seated.
injury_friendly.back pain: Avoid the jump and perform a seated or standing march to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate warm-up to prepare joints and muscles for explosive movement.
Perform on a soft surface to reduce impact stress on joints.
Maintain a safe environment, free of obstacles, to prevent tripping or falling.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso during the jump.
Land softly on the balls of your feet and roll back to the heels.
Keep knees slightly bent upon landing to absorb impact.
commonMistakes: Failing to engage the core, leading to excessive spinal movement.
Landing with stiff knees, increasing risk of injury.
Not using arms for balance, which can affect jump height and control.

name: Kneeling Arm Drill
instructions: This drill helps increase arm efficiency during the run. Begin kneeling, left foot in front, right knee down. Apply pressure through the front heel to keep your glutes and hamstrings activated.
Begin by blocking the arms in long, pendulum like swings. Close the arm angle, blocking with the arms as you would when jogging, progressing to a run and finally a sprint.
As soon as your hands pass the hip, accelerate them forward during the sprinting motion to move them as quickly as possible.
Switch knees and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The repetitive arm motion may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The exercise involves dynamic shoulder movements that could aggravate a tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Joint stress from repetitive motion may increase pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Healing tissues are vulnerable to stress from dynamic arm movements.
contraindicationDetails.knee pain: Kneeling position may increase discomfort or stress on the knee joint.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: Kneeling can put pressure on the hip, potentially aggravating bursitis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated on a stable chair to reduce the need for knee stabilization.
modifications.harder: Add light hand weights to increase resistance and challenge the shoulder muscles further.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid pain, focusing on smaller arm swings.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a padded mat or cushion under the knee to reduce discomfort.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a neutral spine and engage the core to support the lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure a stable kneeling position to prevent falls.
Avoid hyperextending the elbows during arm swings.
Use a soft surface to protect the knee.
formCues: Engage the core to maintain balance.
Keep shoulders relaxed and away from the ears.
Swing arms in a controlled, pendulum-like motion.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to shrug during arm swings.
Leaning too far forward or backward, losing balance.
Not engaging the core, leading to instability.

name: Kneeling Cable Crunch With Alternating Oblique Twists
instructions: Connect a rope attachment to a high pulley cable and position a mat on the floor in front of it.
Grab the rope with both hands and kneel approximately two feet back from the tower.
Position the rope behind your head with your hands by your ears.
Keep your hands in the same place, contract your abs and pull downward on the rope in a crunching movement until your elbows reach your knees.
Pause briefly at the bottom and rise up in a slow and controlled manner until you reach the starting position.
Repeat the same downward movement until you're halfway down, at which time you'll begin rotating one of your elbows to the opposite knee.
Again, pause briefly at the bottom and rise up in a slow and controlled manner until you reach the starting position.
Repeat the same movement as before, but alternate the other elbow to the opposite knee.
Continue this series of movements to failure.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The flexion and rotation involved in this exercise can exacerbate conditions such as herniated discs, spinal stenosis, and spondylolisthesis.

joint_issues.explanation: Individuals with arthritis or shoulder impingement may experience discomfort due to the overhead position and rotational movement.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise involves significant abdominal pressure and spinal flexion, which are not recommended during pregnancy.

osteoporosis.explanation: The spinal flexion and rotation can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent abdominal, spinal, or shoulder injuries can be aggravated by the movements required in this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the cable, using just body weight to focus on form and control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a Bosu ball for added core engagement.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with lower back pain, perform a standard cable crunch without the twisting motion to minimize spinal rotation.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached and the weight is appropriate for your strength level.
Avoid jerky movements to reduce the risk of injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine as you return to the starting position.
Focus on controlled breathing, exhaling as you crunch and inhaling as you return.
commonMistakes: Using momentum rather than muscle contraction to perform the movement.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.

name: Kneeling Cable Triceps Extension
instructions: Place a bench sideways in front of a high pulley machine.
Hold a straight bar attachment above your head with your hands about 6 inches apart with your palms facing down.
Face away from the machine and kneel.
Place your head and the back of your upper arms on the bench. Your elbows should be bent with the forearms pointing towards the high pulley. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your upper arms close to your head at all times with the elbows in, press the bar out in a semicircular motion until the elbows are locked and your arms are parallel to the floor. Contract the triceps hard and keep this position for a second. Exhale as you perform this movement.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and shoulder stabilization required can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places significant stress on the elbow joint, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.acute cervical spine issues: The position may strain the neck, especially if proper form is not maintained.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow surgery: The stress on the elbow joint can hinder recovery post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The kneeling position and potential for poor form can increase the risk of fractures.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The kneeling position and forward lean may increase lumbar spine pressure, exacerbating symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band instead of a cable.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a rope attachment to allow more natural wrist and elbow movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
Maintain a neutral spine position throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your head and stationary.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
Exhale as you extend your arms and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing triceps engagement.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Arching the back excessively, which can strain the lower back.

name: Kneeling Forearm Stretch
instructions: Start by kneeling on a mat with your palms flat and your fingers pointing back toward your knees.
Slowly lean back keeping your palms flat on the floor until you feel a stretch in your wrists and forearms. Hold for 20-30 seconds.

contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: High severity. The position may exacerbate symptoms due to increased pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Moderate severity. The stretch may aggravate inflammation in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.recent wrist fracture: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Moderate severity. The stretch may cause discomfort or pain in affected joints.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with your hands resting on a table or elevated surface to reduce the angle of wrist extension.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by leaning further back or by performing the stretch with fingers spread wide.

injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform a seated forearm stretch with the opposite hand gently pulling back on the fingers of the affected arm.

safetyNotes: Avoid forcing the stretch if you feel sharp pain.
Keep movements slow and controlled to prevent sudden strain.
formCues: Keep your palms flat on the floor throughout the stretch.
Ensure your fingers are pointing directly towards your knees.
Lean back gently until you feel a mild to moderate stretch.
commonMistakes: Allowing the palms to lift off the floor.
Bending the elbows excessively, reducing the effectiveness of the stretch.
Leaning back too quickly, which can cause strain.

name: Kneeling High Pulley Row
instructions: Select the appropriate weight using a pulley that is above your head. Attach a rope to the cable and kneel a couple of feet away, holding the rope out in front of you with both arms extended. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by flexing the elbows and fully retracting your shoulders, pulling the rope toward your upper chest with your elbows out.
After pausing briefly, slowly return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pulling motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may increase inflammation and pain in the rotator cuff tendons due to repetitive shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The pulling motion and kneeling position can place stress on the spine, potentially worsening disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The isometric contraction during the exercise can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or back surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the load and range of motion required by this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase lumbar spine stress, potentially aggravating this condition.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The kneeling position and pulling motion may increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated on a bench to reduce the demand on core stability.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm variation to increase the challenge on core stability and unilateral strength.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on a reduced range of motion to avoid exacerbating shoulder discomfort.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached and the weight is appropriate for your strength level.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent unnecessary spinal stress.
Avoid jerking the weight to prevent strain on the shoulders and back.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your elbows slightly bent and lead the movement with your elbows, not your hands.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the pull.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug during the pull, which can cause neck strain.
Rounding the back, which can increase spinal stress.

name: Kneeling Hip Flexor
instructions: Kneel on a mat and bring your right knee up so the bottom of your foot is on the floor and extend your left leg out behind you so the top of your foot is on the floor.
Shift your weight forward until you feel a stretch in your hip. Hold for 15 seconds, then repeat for your other side.

contraindicationDetails.hip osteoarthritis: Moderate to severe hip osteoarthritis can cause pain and discomfort during hip flexor stretches. This exercise may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Kneeling and weight-bearing on the knee joint can increase discomfort and pain in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip or knee surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires careful management of movement and load to avoid complications.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires balance and stability, which can be challenging for individuals with balance disorders.
contraindicationDetails.advanced osteoporosis: The risk of fractures increases with advanced osteoporosis, especially when weight is placed on joints.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while standing, using a wall or chair for support to reduce load on the knee.
modifications.harder: Add a slight backward lean to increase the stretch intensity on the hip flexors.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with a neutral spine and avoid excessive forward lean.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a padded mat or cushion under the knee to reduce discomfort.
injury_friendly.hip pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid pain and focus on gentle stretching.

safetyNotes: Ensure the knee is cushioned to prevent discomfort.
Avoid excessive forward lean to prevent lower back strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to reduce stress on the lumbar region.
formCues: Keep the torso upright and engage the core.
Align the front knee over the ankle to avoid excessive knee stress.
Press the hips forward gently to feel the stretch without forcing it.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to extend beyond the toes.
Arching the lower back excessively.
Neglecting to engage the core muscles.

name: Kneeling Jump Squat
instructions: Begin kneeling on the floor with a barbell racked across the back of your shoulders, or you can use your body weight for this exercise. This can be done inside of a power rack to make unracking easier.
Sit back with your hips until your glutes touch your feet, keeping your head and chest up.
Explode up with your hips, generating enough power to land with your feet flat on the floor.
Continue with the squat by driving through your heels and extending the knees to come to a standing position.

spinal_injuries.details: The explosive nature and spinal loading of the exercise can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

joint_issues.details: Knee and ankle joints are under significant stress during the jump and landing phases, which can aggravate arthritis or tendinitis.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: The high-intensity nature of the exercise may not be suitable for those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.details: The exercise poses a risk of falls and excessive intra-abdominal pressure, which is unsafe during pregnancy.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body can be worsened by the dynamic movements involved.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy can increase the risk of falls during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight kneeling jump without the barbell to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the barbell weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance and coordination.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a seated box jump to reduce spinal loading while still engaging explosive power.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a resistance band around the thighs to encourage proper knee tracking and reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise without the barbell or use a lighter weight to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Use a spotter or safety pins in a power rack if attempting with a heavy barbell.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the joints and muscles for explosive movement.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine during the jump.
Drive through the hips and extend fully to generate maximum power.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact and protect joints.
commonMistakes: Failing to maintain a neutral spine, leading to potential back injury.
Landing with stiff legs, increasing the risk of knee injury.
Using excessive weight before mastering the technique, compromising form.

name: Kneeling Single-Arm High Pulley Row
instructions: Attach a single handle to a high pulley and make your weight selection.
Kneel in front of the cable tower, taking the cable with one hand with your arm extended. This will be your starting position.

Starting with your palm facing forward, pull the weight down to your torso by flexing the elbow and retract the shoulder blade. As you do so, rotate the wrist so that at the completion of the movement, your palm is now facing you.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and shoulder rotation may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves shoulder movement that can irritate the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The kneeling position and spinal alignment can increase disc pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or back surgery: The exercise places stress on the shoulder and back, which may not be suitable post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The isometric hold and potential Valsalva maneuver can increase blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier weight or perform the exercise standing to engage more core stability.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid overhead positions.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached to prevent accidents.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid excessive arching of the back during the pull.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your shoulder blade retracted and down.
Rotate your wrist smoothly as you pull.
Pause briefly at the end of the movement for maximum contraction.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the shoulder to elevate during the pull.
Overextending the arm at the starting position.

name: Kneeling Squat
instructions: Set the bar to the proper height in a power rack. Kneel behind the bar; it may be beneficial to put a mat down to pad your knees. Slide under the bar, racking it across the back of your shoulders. Your shoulder blades should be retracted and the bar tight across your back. Unrack the weight.
With your head looking forward, sit back with your butt until you touch your calves.
Reverse the motion, returning the torso to an upright position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial load on the spine.

knee_joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or tendinitis in the knees may experience discomfort due to the kneeling position and should modify or avoid the exercise.

hip_joint_issues.details: Hip impingement or bursitis may be aggravated by the movement pattern; modifications are recommended.

pregnancy.details: The exercise involves an unstable position and load on the back, which is not recommended during pregnancy.

osteoporosis.details: The axial load and potential for spinal compression make this exercise unsuitable for individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.details: Recent trauma or sprains, especially in the lower body, require avoidance of this exercise until fully healed.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight kneeling squats without a barbell to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on controlled movements to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Place a thicker mat under the knees or use a Smith machine for guided movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely racked before starting.
Use a mat to protect the knees from hard surfaces.
Avoid excessive forward lean to reduce spinal stress.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid arching the back.
Drive through the hips to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round during the descent.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.
Failing to engage the core, leading to instability.

name: Landmine 180's
instructions: Position a bar into a landmine or securely anchor it in a corner. Load the bar to an appropriate weight.
Raise the bar from the floor, taking it to shoulder height with both hands with your arms extended in front of you. Adopt a wide stance. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by rotating the trunk and hips as you swing the weight all the way down to one side. Keep your arms extended throughout the exercise.
Reverse the motion to swing the weight all the way to the opposite side.
Continue alternating the movement until the set is complete.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High rotational forces may exacerbate disc herniation, leading to increased pain or nerve impingement.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Rotational movements can increase vertebral slippage, worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and extended arm position can aggravate shoulder impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The exercise involves significant core engagement and twisting, which may not be suitable during pregnancy.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High core activation and twisting can interfere with healing post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Twisting movements can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High-impact and twisting movements can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise may pose a fall risk for those with impaired balance.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band anchored to a low point for similar rotational movement.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Reduce the range of motion and focus on controlled, slow movements to minimize stress on the spine.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Lower the barbell to chest height instead of shoulder height to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely anchored to prevent slipping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar stress.
Avoid jerky movements; perform the exercise in a controlled manner.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Rotate through the hips and torso, not just the arms.
Keep your arms extended and shoulders stable throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Using momentum rather than controlled muscle engagement.
Failing to keep the core engaged, leading to poor form.

name: Landmine Linear Jammer
instructions: Position a bar into landmine or, lacking one, securely anchor it in a corner. Load the bar to an appropriate weight and position the handle attachment on the bar.
Raise the bar from the floor, taking the handles to your shoulders. This will be your starting position.
In an athletic stance, squat by flexing your hips and setting your hips back, keeping your arms flexed.

Reverse the motion by powerfully extending through the hips, knees, and ankles, while also extending the elbows to straighten the arms. This movement should be done explosively, coming out of the squat to full extension as powerfully as possible.
Return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to compression of the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise involves dynamic shoulder movements that can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The load and movement pattern may place stress on the cervical spine, potentially aggravating conditions like stenosis or herniated discs.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive extension of the elbows under load can worsen tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lumbar spine issues: The explosive hip extension can increase lumbar spine loading, which may be problematic for those with herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.knee arthritis: The squatting motion may exacerbate symptoms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High-impact and explosive movements can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter load or use a resistance band to reduce joint stress.
modifications.harder: Increase the load or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance and stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on controlled movements to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the depth of the squat and ensure proper knee alignment over the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Avoid full extension and keep the elbows slightly bent to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely anchored to prevent slipping.
Warm up thoroughly before performing explosive movements.
Use a weight that allows for controlled, explosive movement without compromising form.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels during the squat to maintain balance.
Extend your hips, knees, and ankles simultaneously for a powerful lift.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Rounding the back, especially during the explosive phase.
Using too much weight, leading to compromised form.

name: Lateral Bound
instructions: Assume a half squat position facing 90 degrees from your direction of travel. This will be your starting position.
Allow your lead leg to do a countermovement inward as you shift your weight to the outside leg.
Immediately push off and extend, attempting to bound to the side as far as possible.
Upon landing, immediately push off in the opposite direction, returning to your original start position.
Continue back and forth for several repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or sciatica should avoid high-impact lateral movements due to potential exacerbation of symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Knee or ankle arthritis and tendinitis may be aggravated by the lateral impact and rapid directional changes.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid high-intensity plyometric exercises without medical clearance.

pregnancy.details: The risk of balance loss and joint instability increases during pregnancy, making lateral bounds unsuitable.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains or strains in the lower extremities should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

neurological_conditions.details: Conditions affecting balance or proprioception may increase the risk of falls or improper landings.

modifications.easier: Perform lateral steps instead of bounds to reduce impact and focus on control.
modifications.harder: Increase the distance of the bound or add a single-leg landing to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform lateral bounds on a softer surface and reduce the distance to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Focus on controlled lateral steps with minimal knee flexion to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate warm-up to prepare muscles and joints for dynamic movement.
Perform on a non-slip surface to prevent falls.
Avoid if experiencing pain during the exercise.
formCues: Maintain a slight bend in the knees and hips to absorb impact.
Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Land softly on the balls of the feet and immediately transition to the next bound.
commonMistakes: Landing with locked knees, increasing joint stress.
Allowing the knees to cave inward, risking injury.
Failing to maintain an upright torso, leading to poor balance.

name: Lateral Box Jump
instructions: Assume a comfortable standing position, with a short box positioned next to you. This will be your starting position.
Quickly dip into a quarter squat to initiate the stretch reflex, and immediately reverse direction to jump up and to the side.
Bring your knees high enough to ensure your feet have good clearance over the box.
Land on the center of the box, using your legs to absorb the impact.
Carefully jump down to the other side of the box, and continue going back and forth for several repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact and lateral movements can exacerbate joint pain and degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Jumping and landing can increase the risk of ankle sprains or further instability.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: The impact and dynamic movement may impede recovery and healing.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, posing a fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The high-intensity nature of the exercise can place undue stress on the cardiovascular system.

modifications.easier: Perform lateral step-ups onto the box instead of jumps to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the box height or add a weighted vest for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform lateral jumps on a soft surface or use a lower box to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Use a resistance band around the thighs to limit lateral movement and reduce ankle strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and on a non-slip surface.
Wear supportive footwear to protect the feet and ankles.
Warm up thoroughly before performing high-impact exercises.
formCues: Engage your core to maintain balance.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Keep your chest up and eyes forward throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Not clearing the box completely, risking tripping.
Allowing knees to cave inward upon landing, which can strain the knee joint.

name: Lateral Cone Hops
instructions: Position a number of cones in a row several feet apart.
Stand next to the end of the cones, facing 90 degrees to the direction of travel. This will be your starting position.
Begin the jump by dipping with the knees to initiate a stretch reflex, and immediately reverse direction to push off the ground, jumping up and sideways over the cone.
Use your legs to absorb impact upon landing, and rebound into the next jump, continuing down the row of cones.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities can exacerbate joint pain and degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Jumping can increase the risk of ankle sprains or further instability.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the impact forces involved.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance to prevent falls.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The exercise may elevate heart rate and blood pressure significantly.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower limb injuries: Jumping can worsen sprains, strains, or fractures.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High-impact activities increase the risk of fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform lateral step-overs instead of hops to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the cones or perform the exercise on one leg.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform lateral shuffles instead of hops to minimize joint stress.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Use a lower cone height and focus on controlled lateral steps.

safetyNotes: Ensure the surface is even and free of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Wear supportive footwear to provide adequate cushioning and stability.
Avoid excessive fatigue, which can compromise form and increase injury risk.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance and control.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Focus on quick, controlled movements rather than height.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Allowing knees to cave inward upon landing, risking injury.
Neglecting to engage the core, leading to poor balance.

name: Lateral Raise - With Bands
instructions: To begin, stand on an exercise band so that tension begins at arm's length. Grasp the handles using a pronated (palms facing your thighs) grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The handles should be resting on the sides of your thighs. Your arms should be extended with a slight bend at the elbows and your back should be straight. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the handles to the sides as you exhale. Continue to lift the handles until they are slightly above parallel. Tip: As you lift the handles, slightly tilt the hand as if you were pouring water and keep your arms extended. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the handles back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The lateral raise can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the overhead motion and abduction of the arm.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: This exercise can place stress on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially aggravating an existing injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with osteoporosis, especially with exercises that involve arm elevation and resistance.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that strain the shoulder until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Individuals with cervical spine issues may experience discomfort or exacerbation of symptoms due to neck strain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter resistance bands or without bands to focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance by using a thicker band or performing the exercise with a single arm at a time.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder pain, perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, stopping at shoulder height.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored under your feet to prevent snapping.
Avoid using momentum to lift the bands; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Engage the core to maintain a stable torso.
Lift the arms no higher than parallel to the ground to avoid shoulder strain.
commonMistakes: Using too much resistance, leading to poor form.
Shrugging the shoulders during the lift, which can cause neck strain.
Allowing the wrists to bend, which can reduce effectiveness and increase injury risk.

name: Latissimus Dorsi-SMR
instructions: While lying on the floor, place a foam roll under your back and to one side, just behind your arm pit. This will be your starting position.
Keep the arm of the side being stretched behind and to the side of you as you shift your weight onto your lats, keeping your upper body off of the ground. Hold for 10-30 seconds, and switch sides.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and nerve irritation.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: Those with shoulder impingement may experience increased pain due to the overhead arm position. Modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

rotator_cuff_tendinitis.explanation: The overhead position may aggravate symptoms. Modifications should be considered to reduce strain on the shoulder.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance and comfort concerns.

osteoporosis.explanation: Those with osteoporosis should be cautious of pressure on the ribs and spine. Modifications to reduce load and pressure are advised.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a softer foam roll or use a towel under the roll to reduce pressure.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the hold to 45-60 seconds or use a denser foam roll.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with the arm closer to the body to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a softer foam roll and ensure the spine remains neutral throughout the exercise.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly on the spine.
Do not apply excessive pressure to the ribs.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid shrugging the shoulders.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly over the muscle.
Allowing the head to drop or tilt excessively.
Not maintaining a neutral spine.

name: Leg-Over Floor Press
instructions: Lie on the floor with one kettlebell in place on your chest, holding it by the handle. Extend leg on working side over leg on non-working side.Your free arm can be extended out to your side for support.
Press the kettlebll into a locked out position.
Lower the weight until the elbow touches the ground, keeping the kettlebell above the elbow. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: Pressing movements can strain the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Joint stress from pressing can increase pain and inflammation in affected joints.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which may not be suitable during recovery.
contraindicationDetails.chronic wrist pain: Holding the kettlebell can exacerbate wrist pain due to the grip and weight.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The position and load can increase spinal pressure, potentially aggravating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The leg-over position may irritate the sciatic nerve, especially if the lower back is not supported.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise involves load-bearing on the spine and joints, which may increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter kettlebell or use a dumbbell for easier grip control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise with both legs extended for added core challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lighter weight and limit the range of motion to avoid aggravating the shoulder.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with both feet flat on the floor to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is securely gripped to prevent it from slipping.
Avoid excessive arching of the back during the press.
Maintain control of the kettlebell throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep the kettlebell directly above the elbow during the press.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Press the kettlebell in a controlled manner, avoiding jerky movements.
commonMistakes: Allowing the kettlebell to drift away from the elbow line.
Arching the lower back excessively.
Using momentum to press the kettlebell instead of muscle control.

name: Leg-Up Hamstring Stretch
instructions: Lie flat on your back, bend one knee, and put that foot flat on the floor to stabilize your spine.

Extend the other leg in the air. If you're tight, you wont be able to straighten it. That's okay. Extend the knee so that the sole of the lifted foot faces the ceiling (or as close as you can get it).
Slowly straighten the legs as much as possible and then pull the leg toward your nose. Switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. Stretching the hamstrings can exacerbate symptoms by increasing spinal flexion and pressure on the disc.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. The stretch may aggravate the sciatic nerve, especially if the leg is pulled too aggressively.
contraindicationDetails.recent hamstring strain: High severity. Stretching a recently strained muscle can delay healing and increase the risk of re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Care should be taken to avoid excessive spinal flexion, which may increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: High severity. The exercise can increase lumbar spine stress, potentially worsening pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the leg bent at the knee to reduce strain on the hamstrings.
modifications.harder: Use a resistance band to add tension and increase the stretch intensity.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with the non-stretching leg elevated on a chair to reduce lumbar spine stress.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep a slight bend in the knee of the stretching leg to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling the leg aggressively to prevent muscle strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to minimize lumbar stress.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
formCues: Keep the non-stretching foot flat on the floor for stability.
Engage your core to support the lower back.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
commonMistakes: Pulling the leg too forcefully, risking muscle strain.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Holding the breath, which can increase tension.

name: Leg Extensions
instructions: For this exercise you will need to use a leg extension machine. First choose your weight and sit on the machine with your legs under the pad (feet pointed forward) and the hands holding the side bars. This will be your starting position. Tip: You will need to adjust the pad so that it falls on top of your lower leg (just above your feet). Also, make sure that your legs form a 90-degree angle between the lower and upper leg. If the angle is less than 90-degrees then that means the knee is over the toes which in turn creates undue stress at the knee joint. If the machine is designed that way, either look for another machine or just make sure that when you start executing the exercise you stop going down once you hit the 90-degree angle.
Using your quadriceps, extend your legs to the maximum as you exhale. Ensure that the rest of the body remains stationary on the seat. Pause a second on the contracted position.
Slowly lower the weight back to the original position as you inhale, ensuring that you do not go past the 90-degree angle limit.
Repeat for the recommended amount of times.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High stress on the knee joint during leg extensions can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The exercise places direct stress on the patellar tendon, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee surgery: Post-surgical knees may not tolerate the isolated stress and range of motion required.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The exertion may be inappropriate for individuals with uncontrolled cardiovascular issues.

modifications.easier: Use a lower weight and focus on a smaller range of motion, ensuring no discomfort.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight gradually while maintaining proper form and control.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform partial leg extensions, limiting the range of motion to avoid discomfort.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper seat adjustment to maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive lumbar flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is adjusted to fit your body size, particularly the seat height and pad position.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep your back pressed against the seat throughout the movement.
Exhale as you extend your legs and inhale as you return to the starting position.
Move in a controlled manner, avoiding jerky or rapid movements.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the knees to lock at the top of the extension.
Not adjusting the machine correctly, leading to improper biomechanics.

name: Leg Lift
instructions: While standing up straight with both feet next to each other at around shoulder width, grab a sturdy surface such as the sides of a squat rack or the top of a chair to brace yourself and keep balance.
With or without an ankle weight, lift one leg behind you as if performing a leg curl but standing up while keeping the other leg straight. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
Slowly bring the raised leg back to the floor as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Repeat the movement with the opposite leg.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with conditions such as herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to potential stress on the lumbar spine.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: Those with hip or knee arthritis or tendinitis may experience discomfort due to the load on the hip joint during leg extension.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: During later stages of pregnancy, balance may be compromised, and the exercise could strain the lower back.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Recent surgeries involving the lower back, hips, or knees require clearance from a healthcare provider before performing this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Avoid if there are recent sprains or strains in the lower body to prevent exacerbation.
contraindicationDetails.neurological_conditions: Conditions affecting balance or proprioception, such as neuropathy, may increase the risk of falls.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise lying prone on a mat, lifting one leg at a time to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or resistance bands to increase the load on the glutes.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise in a pool for reduced joint stress and improved support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the supporting surface is stable to prevent falls.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back during leg lifts.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Keep the standing leg slightly bent to absorb shock.
Lift the leg slowly and with control, focusing on squeezing the glutes.
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back excessively.
Using momentum rather than muscle control.
Failing to maintain balance, leading to instability.

name: Leg Press
instructions: Using a leg press machine, sit down on the machine and place your legs on the platform directly in front of you at a medium (shoulder width) foot stance. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).

Lower the safety bars holding the weighted platform in place and press the platform all the way up until your legs are fully extended in front of you. Tip: Make sure that you do not lock your knees. Your torso and the legs should make a perfect 90-degree angle. This will be your starting position.
As you inhale, slowly lower the platform until your upper and lower legs make a 90-degree angle.
Pushing mainly with the heels of your feet and using the quadriceps go back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and ensure to lock the safety pins properly once you are done. You do not want that platform falling on you fully loaded.

herniated disc.explanation: The leg press can increase intra-abdominal pressure and spinal load, exacerbating disc herniation.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The exercise can place significant stress on the knee joint, potentially worsening symptoms.

severe hypertension.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver often used during leg press can dangerously elevate blood pressure.

recent knee surgery.explanation: Post-surgical knees may not withstand the compressive forces involved in the leg press.

sciatica.explanation: The seated position and spinal load may aggravate sciatic nerve pain.

pregnancy (third trimester).explanation: The supine position can reduce blood flow and the exercise may increase intra-abdominal pressure.

modifications.easier: Use a lower weight and increase the number of repetitions to reduce joint stress.
modifications.harder: Perform single-leg presses to increase difficulty and engage stabilizer muscles more intensely.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a back support cushion to maintain lumbar support and reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion and reduce stress on the joint.

safetyNotes: Always ensure the safety pins are properly engaged before and after use.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to minimize spinal stress.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the platform and push through your heels.
Maintain a 90-degree angle between your torso and legs at the starting position.
Control the descent to avoid bouncing at the bottom of the movement.
commonMistakes: Locking the knees at the top of the movement.
Allowing the lower back to round during the exercise.
Using excessive weight, compromising form and safety.

name: Leg Pull-In
instructions: Lie on an exercise mat with your legs extended and your hands either palms facing down next to you or under your glutes. Tip: My preference is with the hands next to me. This will be your starting position.

Bend your knees and pull your upper thighs into your midsection as you breathe out. Continue the motion until your knees are around chest level. Contract your abs as you execute this movement and hold for a second at the top. Tip: As you perform the motion, the lower legs (calves) should always remain parallel to the floor.
Return to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity: The flexion involved in this exercise can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity: Lumbar flexion may increase symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity: Flexion can increase anterior shear forces on the vertebrae.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity: The exercise may irritate the sciatic nerve, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity: Spinal flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity: Supine position and abdominal pressure may be uncomfortable or unsafe during later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with one leg at a time to reduce the load on the abdominals and spine.
modifications.harder: Hold a light dumbbell between the feet to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a stability ball under the lower back to support the spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking or rapid movements to prevent strain on the lower back.
Ensure the lower back remains in contact with the mat to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a steady and controlled pace.
Exhale as you pull the knees in and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch off the mat.
Using momentum instead of muscle control.
Not keeping the calves parallel to the floor.

name: Leverage Chest Press
instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat for your height. The handles should be near the bottom or middle of the pectorals at the beginning of the motion.
Your chest and head should be up and your shoulder blades retracted. This will be your starting position.
Press the handles forward by extending through the elbow.
After a brief pause at the top, return the weight just above the start position, keeping tension on the muscles by not returning the weight to the stops until the set is complete.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The leverage chest press may exacerbate symptoms due to the overhead pressing motion, which can compress the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise can place stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially worsening inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.pectoralis major tear: Engaging in this exercise could further damage the muscle fibers if not fully healed.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-operative patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Those with severe osteoporosis should avoid heavy loading on the chest to prevent fractures.
contraindicationDetails.chest pain of cardiac origin: Individuals with known heart conditions should avoid this exercise until cleared by a cardiologist.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load on the muscles.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Reduce the range of motion to avoid discomfort, or use a neutral grip to decrease stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat is adjusted properly to align the handles with the chest.
Do not lock out the elbows at the top of the movement to maintain muscle tension and protect the joints.
Keep the shoulder blades retracted throughout the exercise to stabilize the shoulder girdle.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulder blades squeezed together.
Press the handles forward in a controlled manner, avoiding jerky movements.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows at the top of the press.
commonMistakes: Allowing the weight to drop too quickly on the return phase.
Overextending the elbows, leading to joint strain.
Failing to adjust the seat properly, which can lead to improper form.

name: Leverage Deadlift
instructions: Load the pins to an appropriate weight. Position yourself directly between the handles. Grasp the bottom handles with a comfortable grip, and then lower your hips as you take a breath. Look forward with your head and keep your chest up. This will be your starting position.
Return the weight to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal loading can exacerbate disc herniation and cause nerve impingement.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Compression forces may worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Forward slippage of vertebrae can be aggravated by axial loading.
contraindicationDetails.severe knee osteoarthritis: Increased knee joint stress can lead to pain and further degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Straining during lifting can cause dangerous spikes in blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Instability may increase the risk of falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform a partial range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a single leg for added balance challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a back support or perform the exercise seated to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the squat and ensure proper knee alignment over toes.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height.
Start with a light weight to master form before increasing load.
Keep the core engaged to protect the spine.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels to engage the posterior chain.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Allowing the knees to cave inward.
Lifting too heavy, compromising form.

name: Leverage Decline Chest Press
instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat for your height. The handles should be near the bottom of the pectorals at the beginning of the motion. Your chest and head should be up and your shoulder blades retracted. This will be your starting position.
Press the handles forward by extending through the elbow.
After a brief pause at the top, return the weight just above the start position, keeping tension on the muscles by not returning the weight to the stops until the set is complete.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The decline angle can exacerbate impingement by reducing subacromial space.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a flat bench press or use a neutral grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a flat bench or seated chest press machine to avoid decline positioning.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat and handles are properly adjusted to avoid excessive shoulder strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent back injury.
Avoid locking out elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.

Press handles forward with controlled motion, avoiding momentum.

Failing to adjust the seat and handles properly, leading to poor biomechanics.
