name: Leverage High Row
instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat height so that you can just reach the handles above you. Adjust the knee pad to help keep you down. Grasp the handles with a pronated grip. This will be your starting position.
Pull the handles towards your torso, retracting your shoulder blades as you flex the elbow.
Pause at the bottom of the motion, and then slowly return the handles to the starting position.
For multiple repetitions, avoid completely returning the weight to the stops to keep tension on the muscles being worked.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or spinal stenosis should avoid this exercise or perform it with caution, as the seated position and pulling motion can exacerbate symptoms.

shoulder impingement.details: The overhead pulling motion can aggravate shoulder impingement. Modifications or alternative exercises may be necessary.

rotator cuff tendinitis.details: Pulling motions can strain the rotator cuff, especially if performed with improper form or excessive weight.

hypertension.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension should avoid holding their breath during exertion (Valsalva maneuver) and monitor their blood pressure response.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight and focus on form, or perform a seated cable row instead.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a single arm to increase the challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a supported chest pad to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort and use a neutral grip.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat and knee pad are adjusted correctly to prevent strain.
Avoid jerking the weight to prevent injury.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.

commonMistakes: Using too much weight and compromising form.
Allowing the shoulders to round forward.
Not fully engaging the back muscles.

name: Leverage Incline Chest Press
instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat for your height. The handles should be near the top of the pectorals at the beginning of the motion. Your chest and head should be up and your shoulder blades retracted. This will be your starting position.
Press the handles forward by extending through the elbow.
After a brief pause at the top, return the weight just above the start position, keeping tension on the muscles by not returning the weight to the stops until the set is complete.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or slow down the eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

name: Leverage Iso Row
instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. Grasp the handles with either a neutral or pronated grip. This will be your starting position.
Pull the handles towards your torso, retracting your shoulder blades as you flex the elbow.

Pause at the bottom of the motion, and then slowly return the handles to the starting position. For multiple repetitions, avoid completely returning the weight to the stops to keep tension on the muscles being worked.

spinal injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs or severe spinal stenosis should avoid heavy loads and focus on maintaining a neutral spine to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Those with shoulder impingement should use a neutral grip and avoid excessive internal rotation to minimize shoulder joint stress.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Opt for a neutral grip and limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort.

Avoid jerking the weight to prevent undue stress on the joints and connective tissues.

Allowing the shoulders to round forward during the exercise.
Not fully retracting the shoulder blades.

name: Leverage Shoulder Press
instructions: Load an appropriate weight onto the pins and adjust the seat for your height. The handles should be near the top of the shoulders at the beginning of the motion. Your chest and head should be up and handles held with a pronated grip. This will be your starting position.
Press the handles upward by extending through the elbow.
After a brief pause at the top, return the weight to just above the start position, keeping tension on the muscles by not returning the weight to the stops until the set is complete.

shoulder impingement.explanation: This exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to the overhead pressing motion, which can compress the structures in the shoulder.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: Overhead pressing can strain the rotator cuff muscles and tendons, potentially worsening the injury.

severe osteoarthritis.explanation: Joint stress from pressing movements can increase pain and inflammation in individuals with advanced osteoarthritis.

Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to maintain muscle tension and protect joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Maintain a neutral spine with your head aligned with your spine.
Press the handles upward in a controlled manner, avoiding jerky movements.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder stress.
Failing to adjust the machine settings to fit individual body dimensions.

name: Leverage Shrug
instructions: Load the pins to an appropriate weight. Position yourself directly between the handles.
Grasp the top handles with a comfortable grip, and then lower your hips as you take a breath. Look forward with your head and keep your chest up.

Drive through the floor with your heels, extending your hips and knees as you rise to a standing position. Keep your arms straight throughout the movement, finishing with your shoulders back. This will be your starting position.
Raise the weight by shrugging the shoulders towards your ears, moving straight up and down.
Pause at the top of the motion, and then return the weight to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or other spinal issues should avoid this exercise due to the axial load and potential for exacerbating symptoms.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: The movement can aggravate shoulder impingement due to the elevation of the scapula. Modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

hypertension.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during heavy lifts, can increase blood pressure. Individuals with hypertension should avoid holding their breath and use lighter weights.

osteoporosis.explanation: The axial loading and potential for poor posture can increase fracture risk in individuals with osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise seated to reduce load and improve stability.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on one leg to add a balance challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated shrugs with a back support to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid pain at the top of the shrug.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
Do not jerk the weight; use a controlled motion.
Keep your core engaged to protect your spine.
formCues: Stand tall with your chest up and shoulders back.
Keep your arms straight and avoid bending the elbows.
Shrug your shoulders straight up towards your ears.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Allowing the head to jut forward.
Arching the lower back excessively.

name: Linear 3-Part Start Technique
instructions: This drill helps you accelerate as quickly as possible into a sprint from a dead stop. It helps to use a line to start from. Begin with two feet on the line. Place your left foot with the toe next to your right ankle. Place your right foot 4-6 inches behind the left.
Place your right hand onto the line, and thing bring your nose close to your left knee.
Squat down as you lean foward, your head being lower than your hips and your weight loaded onto the left leg. This will be your starting position.
Take your left hand up so that it is parallel to the ground, pointing behind you, and explode out when ready.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the forward flexion and explosive movement which can exacerbate symptoms.

joint issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress. Consider avoiding if symptoms are severe.

cardiovascular conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before performing high-intensity exercises.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, particularly in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve rapid acceleration and deceleration.

surgical recovery.details: Avoid if recovering from recent surgeries, especially in the lower body or spine, until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the lower body.

neurological conditions.details: Those with balance disorders or neuropathy should proceed with caution and consider modifications to ensure stability.

modifications.easier: Start from a standing position and take a step forward before accelerating to reduce the explosive demand.
modifications.harder: Add resistance bands around the thighs to increase resistance during the start.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a standing start with a focus on gradual acceleration to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a shorter stride and avoid deep squatting to reduce knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the surface is even and free of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for explosive movement.
Avoid if experiencing any pain during the exercise.
formCues: Keep your head lower than your hips to maintain a forward lean.
Load your weight onto the front leg to prepare for an explosive start.
Drive through the ball of your foot as you accelerate forward.
commonMistakes: Starting with an upright torso, which reduces acceleration efficiency.
Failing to fully load the front leg, leading to a slower start.
Allowing the back foot to drag, which can cause tripping.

name: Linear Acceleration Wall Drill
instructions: Lean at around 45 degrees against a wall. Your feet should be together, glutes contracted.
Begin by lifting your right knee quickly, pausing, and then driving it straight down into the ground.
Switch legs, raising the opposite knee, and then attacking the ground straight down.
Repeat once more with your right leg, and as soon as the right foot strikes the ground hammer them out rapidly, alternating left and right as fast as you can.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise or perform with caution due to the forward lean and potential spinal loading.

joint issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should be cautious due to the repetitive knee flexion and extension.

cardiovascular conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should monitor exertion levels and consult a healthcare provider.

chronic conditions.details: Those with osteoporosis should ensure proper form to avoid undue spinal stress.

acute injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the lower body.

neurological conditions.details: Balance disorders may require modifications or supervision.

modifications.easier: Perform the drill at a slower pace, focusing on controlled movements rather than speed.
modifications.harder: Add a resistance band around the thighs to increase difficulty and engage the glutes more.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform with a more upright posture to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to reduce stress on the knees.

Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Warm up adequately before performing the drill.

Drive the knee up quickly but with control.

name: Linear Depth Jump
instructions: You will need two boxes or benches spaced a few feet away from each other. Begin by standing on one box facing towards the other platform.
To initiate the movement, gently drop down to the ground between your platforms, allowing the knees and hips to flex.
Reverse the motion by exploding, extending through the hips, knees, and ankles to jump onto the other platform.
Land softly, asborbing the impact through the legs.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact landing can exacerbate joint pain and degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Impact and spinal loading can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Requires good balance to safely perform jumps and landings.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the impact forces.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Spinal loading and impact can increase disc pressure.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Jumping and landing can increase the risk of ankle sprains.

modifications.easier: Step down from the box instead of jumping and perform a bodyweight squat before stepping onto the next box.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the boxes or add a weighted vest for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform step-ups instead of jumps to reduce impact.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on box squats or step-ups to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform seated leg extensions or leg presses to avoid jumping.

safetyNotes: Ensure the boxes are stable and secure before starting.
Perform a thorough warm-up focusing on lower body mobility and activation.
Avoid this exercise if experiencing any acute pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Land softly by bending your knees and hips to absorb impact.
Maintain a neutral spine during the jump and landing phases.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, increasing the risk of injury.
Allowing knees to cave inward upon landing.
Not using arms to aid in the jump and landing balance.

name: Log Lift
instructions: Begin standing with the log in front of you. Grasp the handles, and begin to clean the log. As you are bent over to start the clean, attempt to get the log as high as possible, pulling it into your chest. Extend through the hips and knees to bring it up to complete the clean.

Push your head back and look up, creating a shelf on your chest to rest the log. Begin the press by dipping, flexing slightly through the knees and reversing the motion. This push press will generate momentum to start the log moving vertically. Continue by extending through the elbows to press the log above your head. There are no strict rules on form, so use whatever techniques you are most efficient with. As the log is pressed, ensure that you push your head through on each repetition, looking forward.
Repeat as many times as possible. Attempt to control the descent of the log as it is returned to the ground.

contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: High axial load and dynamic movement can exacerbate conditions such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Overhead pressing can worsen impingement symptoms due to compression of shoulder structures.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The dynamic nature and overhead position can strain the rotator cuff muscles and tendons.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during heavy lifts, can increase blood pressure significantly.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of this compound movement.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High risk of fracture due to the load and dynamic movement, especially in the spine and wrists.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The need for stability during the lift can pose a risk of falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter log or substitute with a barbell or dumbbells to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the log or perform the lift on an unstable surface to challenge balance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a seated log press to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the dip and drive phase or perform seated to avoid knee stress.

commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the clean phase.

name: London Bridges
instructions: Attach a climbing rope to a high beam or cross member. Below it, ensure that the smith machine bar is locked in place with the safeties and cannot move. Alternatively, a secure box could also be utilized.
Stand on the bar, using the rope to balance yourself. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your body straight, lean back and lower your body by slowly going hand over hand with the rope. Continue until you are perpendicular to the ground.
Keeping your body straight, reverse the motion, going hand over hand back to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pulling motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The repetitive pulling motion may aggravate inflammation in the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and pulling action can increase strain on the elbow tendons.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The grip required may place additional stress on the wrist joints, exacerbating pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The neck may be strained during the exercise, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The exercise places axial load on the spine, which can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase lumbar spine stress, potentially worsening the condition.

modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a weighted vest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive shoulder extension and internal rotation.

commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag, which increases lumbar stress.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Gripping the rope too tightly, leading to forearm fatigue.

name: Looking At Ceiling
instructions: Kneel on the floor, holding your heels with both hands.
Lift your buttocks up and forward while bringing your head back to look up at the ceiling, to give an arch in your back.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the hyperextension and compression forces on the spine.

knee issues.details: Those with knee osteoarthritis or recent knee surgery should modify or avoid this exercise to prevent undue stress on the knee joint.

cardiovascular conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid positions that may increase blood pressure or cause dizziness.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to the risk of balance loss and abdominal compression.

osteoporosis.details: Those with advanced osteoporosis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of vertebral fractures from spinal hyperextension.

acute injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent trauma or surgery involving the spine, knees, or shoulders.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion, keeping the hands on the lower back instead of the heels.
modifications.harder: Hold the position longer or add a slight twist to engage the obliques.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a seated back extension on a stability ball to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid kneeling and perform a standing back extension with hands on hips.

name: Low Cable Crossover
instructions: To move into the starting position, place the pulleys at the low position, select the resistance to be used and grasp a handle in each hand.
Step forward, gaining tension in the pulleys. Your palms should be facing forward, hands below the waist, and your arms straight. This will be your starting position.
With a slight bend in your arms, draw your hands upward and toward the midline of your body. Your hands should come together in front of your chest, palms facing up.
Return your arms back to the starting position after a brief pause.

contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The movement places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially aggravating tendinitis.

contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The exercise may place undue stress on the bones, increasing fracture risk.

modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, stopping before any pain occurs.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated or with back support to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.chest pain: Use lighter resistance and ensure proper warm-up before attempting.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is properly set up and secure before starting.
Avoid jerky movements to reduce the risk of muscle strain.
Maintain control throughout the exercise to prevent injury.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows to reduce joint stress.
Engage the core to maintain stability and prevent excessive spinal movement.
Focus on bringing the hands together smoothly, avoiding excessive force.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug, which can cause neck strain.
Not maintaining a slight bend in the elbows, increasing joint stress.

name: Low Cable Triceps Extension
instructions: Select the desired weight and lay down face up on the bench of a seated row machine that has a rope attached to it. Your head should be pointing towards the attachment.
Grab the outside of the rope ends with your palms facing each other (neutral grip).

Position your elbows so that they are bent at a 90 degree angle and your upper arms are perpendicular (90 degree angle) to your torso. Tip: Keep the elbows in and make sure that the upper arms point to the ceiling while your forearms point towards the pulley above your head. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, extend your lower arms until they are straight and vertical. The upper arms and elbows remain stationary throughout the movement. Only the forearms should move. Contract the triceps hard for a second.
As you breathe in slowly return to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during extension can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms may aggravate shoulder impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute cervical spine issues: Lying supine with head unsupported can strain the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow surgery: High: Avoid until cleared by a healthcare professional due to stress on the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate: Ensure proper form to avoid undue stress on bones, especially if osteoporotic.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band for less resistance.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm variation to increase difficulty and challenge stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform on a bench with lumbar support to maintain a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit range of motion to avoid discomfort, keeping elbows slightly more forward.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid hyperextending the elbows at the top of the movement.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in close to the head.
Focus on moving only the forearms while keeping upper arms stationary.
Engage core muscles to maintain stability and avoid arching the back.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, which reduces triceps activation.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Neglecting to breathe properly throughout the movement.

name: Low Pulley Row To Neck
instructions: Sit on a low pulley row machine with a rope attachment.

Grab the ends of the rope using a palms-down grip and sit with your back straight and your knees slightly bent. Tip: Keep your back almost completely vertical and your arms fully extended in front of you. This will be your starting position.

While keeping your torso stationary, lift your elbows and start bending them as you pull the rope towards your neck while exhaling. Throughout the movement your upper arms should remain parallel to the floor. Tip: Continue this motion until your hands are almost next to your ears (the forearms will not be parallel to the floor at the end of the movement as they will be angled a bit upwards) and your elbows are out away from your sides.
After holding for a second or so at the contracted position, come back slowly to the starting position as you inhale. Tip: Again, during no part of the movement should the torso move.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pulling motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: This exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening tears or causing pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Pulling towards the neck can strain the cervical spine, aggravating existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint stress from the exercise can worsen symptoms in individuals with advanced osteoarthritis.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder bursitis: The movement may increase inflammation and pain in the shoulder bursa.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable machine or perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated row with the elbows kept lower to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Avoid pulling towards the neck; instead, pull towards the chest to minimize cervical strain.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid jerking motions and control the weight during both the concentric and eccentric phases.
formCues: Keep your elbows high and parallel to the floor as you pull.
Engage your core to maintain a stable torso.
Exhale as you pull the rope towards your neck, and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the torso to lean backward during the pull.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Pulling the rope too quickly without proper form.

name: Lower Back-SMR
instructions: In a seated position, place a foam roll under your lower back. Cross your arms in front of you and protract your shoulders. This will be your starting position.

Raise your hips off of the floor and lean back, keeping your weight on your lower back. Now shift your weight slightly to one side, keeping your weight off of the spine and on the muscles to the side of it. Roll over your lower back, holding points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other side.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The pressure from the foam roll can exacerbate disc protrusion.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. Extension of the spine can increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. Lumbar extension may worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. Rolling may irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Risk of fractures with excessive pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: High severity. Healing tissues may be disrupted.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Hormonal changes and altered center of gravity require caution.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a softer foam roll or on a mat to reduce pressure.
modifications.harder: Use a firmer foam roll or increase the duration of pressure on tender spots.
modifications.injury_friendly: For lower back pain, perform the exercise with minimal weight on the foam roll and focus on gentle movements.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly on the spine to prevent injury.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
Ensure the foam roll is positioned correctly to target muscles, not bones.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support your lower back.
Maintain a neutral spine position throughout the exercise.
Shift weight slightly to one side to target the muscles, not the spine.
commonMistakes: Rolling directly on the spine.
Using a foam roll that is too firm for your level.
Holding your breath instead of breathing deeply.

recommendedReps.mobility: Hold each point of tension for 10-30 seconds.
recommendedReps.recovery: Focus on slow, controlled movements rather than repetitions.

name: Lower Back Curl
instructions: Lie on your stomach with your arms out to your sides. This will be your starting position.
Using your lower back muscles, extend your spine lifting your chest off of the ground. Do not use your arms to push yourself up. Keep your head up during the movement. Repeat for 10-20 repetitions.

herniated disc.explanation: This exercise can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the intervertebral discs.

spinal stenosis.explanation: Extension of the spine can worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal.

spondylolisthesis.explanation: Spinal extension can increase anterior slippage of the vertebra.

sciatica.explanation: May increase nerve compression; modifications needed to avoid exacerbation.

osteoporosis.explanation: Risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal extension forces.

pregnancy.explanation: Prone position may be uncomfortable; modifications recommended.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion, lifting only slightly off the ground.
modifications.harder: Hold the top position for a few seconds to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a stability ball to reduce spinal loading and increase support.

safetyNotes: Avoid hyperextending the spine to prevent injury.
Discontinue if any pain or discomfort is felt in the lower back.
formCues: Engage your core muscles before lifting.
Keep your movements slow and controlled.
Focus on lifting with your lower back rather than using momentum.
commonMistakes: Using arms to push off the ground.
Hyperextending the spine.
Using momentum instead of muscle control.

name: Lunge Pass Through
instructions: Stand with your torso upright holding a kettlebell in your right hand. This will be your starting position.
Step forward with your left foot and lower your upper body down by flexing the hip and the knee, keeping the torso upright. Lower your back knee until it nearly touches the ground.
As you lunge, pass the kettlebell under your front leg to your opposite hand.
Pressing through the heel of your foot, return to the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the recommended amount of repetitions, alternating legs.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal load and instability.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the depth of the lunge to reduce joint stress. Hip or ankle issues may also require modifications.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing this exercise due to the dynamic nature and potential for increased blood pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify the exercise to ensure balance and avoid excessive intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery involving the lower extremities or core may require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are any acute sprains or strains in the lower body or core until fully healed.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications to ensure safety and prevent falls.

modifications.easier: Perform the lunge without a kettlebell to focus on form and balance.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier kettlebell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter kettlebell and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the lunge and ensure the knee does not extend past the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the pass-through motion and keep the kettlebell in a stationary position.

safetyNotes: Ensure the kettlebell is of manageable weight to maintain control during the pass-through.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to protect the lower back.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the chest lifted and core engaged throughout the exercise.
Ensure the front knee is aligned with the second toe to prevent valgus collapse.
Pass the kettlebell smoothly under the front leg without twisting the torso.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to collapse inward.
Rounding the back during the pass-through.
Using too heavy a kettlebell, compromising form.

name: Lunge Sprint
instructions: Adjust a bar in a Smith machine to an appropriate height. Position yourself under the bar, racking it across the back of your shoulders. Unrack the bar, and then split your feet, moving one foot forward and one foot back. This will be your starting position.
Lower your back knee nearly to the ground, flexing the knees and lowering your hips as you do so.

At the bottom of the descent, immediately reverse direction. Explosively drive through the heel of your front foot with light pressure from your back foot. Jump up and reverse the position of your legs.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High impact and load on the knee joint can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: The dynamic movement and impact may irritate the hip bursa.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: Explosive movements can increase heart rate and blood pressure significantly.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: The exercise places stress on healing tissues and may impede recovery.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance and coordination.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The spinal load and dynamic movement can aggravate disc issues.

modifications.easier: Perform stationary lunges without the explosive jump to reduce impact and balance requirements.
modifications.harder: Add a weighted vest or increase the bar weight for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use lighter weights and focus on controlled movements without the jump.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid the jump, focusing on a controlled step-back lunge.

safetyNotes: Ensure the Smith machine bar is securely locked before starting.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for explosive movements.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the heel of the front foot to initiate the jump.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive forward lean.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to extend past the toes, increasing knee stress.
Using too much weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.
Failing to engage the core, leading to poor balance and potential back strain.

name: Lying Bent Leg Groin
instructions: Lie on your back with your knees bent and the soles of the feet pressed together. Have your partner hold your knees. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to squeeze your knees together, while your partner prevents any movement from occurring.
After 10-20 seconds, relax your muscles as your partner gently pushes your knees towards the floor. Be sure to inform your helper when the stretch is adequate to prevent injury or overstretching.

contraindicationDetails.hip osteoarthritis: High severity due to potential exacerbation of joint pain and stiffness.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: High severity as the exercise may disrupt healing and cause complications.
contraindicationDetails.groin strain: High severity since the exercise directly engages the adductors, risking further injury.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Moderate severity; may require modifications to reduce lumbar strain.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity; requires modifications to avoid supine position in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a partner, using a strap around the knees to provide resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the isometric contraction phase to 30 seconds.

injury_friendly.lower back pain: Place a cushion under the lower back to maintain a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.groin strain: Limit the range of motion and avoid the isometric contraction phase.

safetyNotes: Communicate clearly with your partner to avoid overstretching.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
Ensure the partner applies gentle and controlled pressure.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to support the lower back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Breathe steadily and avoid holding your breath.
commonMistakes: Overstretching the adductors leading to strain.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Holding the breath during the isometric contraction.

recommendedReps.strength: Not applicable as this is primarily a flexibility exercise

name: Lying Cable Curl
instructions: Grab a straight bar or E-Z bar attachment that is attached to the low pulley with both hands, using an underhand (palms facing up) shoulder-width grip.
Lie flat on your back on top of an exercise mat in front of the weight stack with your feet flat against the frame of the pulley machine and your legs straight.
With your arms extended and your elbows close to your body slightly bend your arms. This will be your starting position.
While keeping your upper arms stationary and the elbows close to your body, curl the bar up slowly toward your chest as you breathe out and you squeeze the biceps.
After a second squeeze at the top of the movement, slowly return to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Maintaining a supine position with shoulder flexion may aggravate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the bar can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: The supine position and potential for Valsalva maneuver can elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: Strain on the neck from lying flat may exacerbate cervical disc issues.

modifications.easier: Perform standing cable curls to reduce the complexity and stabilize the core.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm cable curl to increase the difficulty and engage stabilizers.

injury_friendly.back pain: Place a small pillow under the lower back for support.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on controlled movements to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is securely anchored to prevent tipping.
Avoid excessive weight to prevent undue stress on the elbows and shoulders.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body throughout the movement.
Engage the core to maintain a stable position.
Exhale during the curl phase and inhale during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing bicep engagement.
Hyperextending the wrists, leading to potential strain.

name: Lying Cambered Barbell Row
instructions: Place a cambered bar underneath an exercise bench.
Lie face down on the exercise bench and grab the bar using a palms down (pronated grip) that is wider than shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale row the bar up as you keep the elbows close to your body to either your chest, in order to target the upper mid back, or to your stomach if targeting the lats is your goal.
After a second hold at the top, lower back down to the starting position slowly as you inhale.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The prone position and spinal loading can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. The prone position may increase spinal compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise can increase lumbar stress.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity. The position may aggravate nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The shoulder position may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate severity. The exercise can strain the shoulder tendons.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Prone position is not recommended in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. The exercise can stress the abdominal region.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or resistance bands.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or use a tempo variation with a slower eccentric phase.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a seated cable row instead to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and can support your weight.
Avoid excessive arching of the back during the lift.
Do not use momentum to lift the weight.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine position.
Pull the bar towards your chest or stomach, depending on target muscles.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively.
Rushing through the movement without control.

name: Lying Close-Grip Bar Curl On High Pulley
instructions: Place a flat bench in front of a high pulley or lat pulldown machine.
Hold the straight bar attachment using an underhand grip (palms up) that is about shoulder width.
Lie on your back with your head over the end of the bench.
Now extend your arms straight above your shoulders. Your torso and your arms should make a 90-degree angle and the elbows should be in. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, curl the bar down in a semicircular motion until it touches your chin. Squeeze the biceps for a second at the top contracted position. Tip: As you execute this motion only the forearms should move. At no time should the upper arms be moving at all. They are to remain perpendicular throughout the movement.
Return to starting position slowly.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive motion of curling can exacerbate inflammation in the elbow tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Maintaining the arms perpendicular to the torso can increase stress on the shoulder joint, potentially aggravating impingement.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip and wrist position may increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: Isometric holds and the potential for breath-holding can elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying on the bench with the head unsupported can strain the cervical spine.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band instead of a cable machine.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm variation to increase the challenge and engage stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on slow, controlled movements.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and positioned correctly to prevent tipping.
Avoid locking the elbows at the start of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your elbows tucked in and stationary throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the curl.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out during the curl.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back or lifting the head off the bench.

name: Lying Close-Grip Barbell Triceps Extension Behind The Head
instructions: While holding a barbell or EZ Curl bar with a pronated grip (palms facing forward), lie on your back on a flat bench with your head close to the end of the bench. Tip: If you are holding a barbell grab it using a shoulder-width grip and if you are using an E-Z Bar grab it on the inner handles.

Extend your arms in front of you and slowly bring the bar back in a semi circular motion (while keeping the arms extended) to a position over your head. At the end of this step your arms should be overhead and parallel to the floor. This will be your starting position. Tip: Keep your elbows in at all times.
As you inhale, lower the bar by bending at the elbows and while keeping the upper arm stationary. Keep lowering the bar until your forearms are perpendicular to the floor.

As you exhale bring the bar back up to the starting position by pushing the bar up in a semi-circular motion until the lower arms are also parallel to the floor. Contract the triceps hard at the top of the movement for a second. Tip: Again, only the forearms should move. The upper arms should remain stationary at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead arm position and shoulder rotation.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Stress on the elbow joint can worsen tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Grip and wrist extension can aggravate existing wrist conditions.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Positioning on the bench may strain the neck, especially if the head is unsupported.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: Overhead and extension movements can increase the risk of further injury.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for a more natural wrist position and reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a resistance band instead of a barbell to reduce load and stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Perform tricep pushdowns with a cable machine to minimize elbow stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely gripped to prevent it from slipping.
Avoid excessive arching of the back to maintain spinal alignment.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy to ensure safety.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in close to the body throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid unnecessary strain.
Focus on slow, controlled movements to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out, which can increase shoulder strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: Lying Close-Grip Barbell Triceps Press To Chin
instructions: While holding a barbell or EZ Curl bar with a pronated grip (palms facing forward), lie on your back on a flat bench with your head off the end of the bench. Tip: If you are holding a barbell grab it using a shoulder-width grip and if you are using an E-Z Bar grab it on the inner handles.
Extend your arms in front of you as you hold the barbell over your chest. The arms should be perpendicular to your torso (90-degree angle). This will be your starting position.
As you inhale, lower the bar in a semi-circular motion by bending at the elbows and while keeping the upper arm stationary and elbows in. Keep lowering the bar until it lightly touches your chin.

As you exhale bring the bar back up to the starting position by pushing the bar up in a semi-circular motion. Contract the triceps hard at the top of the movement for a second. Tip: Again, only the forearms should move. The upper arms should remain stationary at all times.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and close grip can exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms due to the compression of the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places significant stress on the elbow joint, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The pronated grip and wrist positioning can cause discomfort or exacerbate existing wrist issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or elbow surgery: Post-surgical tissues require time to heal, and this exercise can place undue stress on these areas.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures increases with loading of the upper body in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The position of the head off the bench can strain the cervical spine, particularly if there are pre-existing conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for a more natural wrist position and reduce joint stress.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion and challenge the triceps further.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to minimize shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Reduce the range of motion to avoid full extension and flexion, or use resistance bands for a lighter load.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps for additional support or switch to a neutral grip with dumbbells.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before beginning the exercise.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral neck position to avoid cervical strain.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in close to the body throughout the movement.
Lower the bar in a controlled manner to avoid bouncing off the chin.
Engage the core to stabilize the body and prevent arching of the back.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out, which increases shoulder stress.
Using momentum to lift the bar, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.
Allowing the bar to drift away from the chin, which can increase strain on the shoulders and elbows.

name: Lying Crossover
instructions: Lie on your back with your legs extended.

Cross one leg over your body with the knee bent, attempting to touch the knee to the ground. Your partner should kneel beside you, holding your shoulder down with one hand and controlling the crossed leg with the other. this will be your starting position.
Attempt to raise the bent knee off of the ground as your partner prevents any actual movement.
After 10-20 seconds, relax the leg as your partner gently presses the knee towards the floor. Repeat with the other side.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The twisting motion can exacerbate conditions such as herniated discs or sciatica.

hip_joint_issues.explanation: Conditions like arthritis or bursitis may be aggravated by the rotational force on the hip joint.

pregnancy.explanation: The supine position and twisting can be uncomfortable and potentially unsafe, especially in the second and third trimesters.

acute_knee_injuries.explanation: The bent knee position and applied pressure can worsen conditions like sprains or meniscus tears.

osteoporosis.explanation: The twisting motion may increase the risk of vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a partner and reduce the range of motion to a comfortable level.
modifications.harder: Add an isometric hold at the end range of motion before relaxing.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid any twisting that causes discomfort.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Keep the knee slightly bent and avoid excessive pressure on the joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the partner applies gentle pressure and does not force the knee to the ground.
Avoid any sharp or sudden movements during the exercise.
formCues: Keep the shoulders flat on the ground throughout the movement.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Breathe steadily and do not hold your breath.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to lift off the ground.
Forcing the knee to the ground, risking injury.
Holding the breath during the exercise.

name: Lying Dumbbell Tricep Extension
instructions: Lie on a flat bench while holding two dumbbells directly in front of you. Your arms should be fully extended at a 90-degree angle from your torso and the floor. The palms should be facing in and the elbows should be tucked in. This is the starting position.
As you breathe in and you keep the upper arms stationary with the elbows in, slowly lower the weight until the dumbbells are near your ears.
At that point, while keeping the elbows in and the upper arms stationary, use the triceps to bring the weight back up to the starting position as you breathe out.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required may strain the rotator cuff, especially if the weights are too heavy.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with heavy weights and improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip and reduce the range of motion.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and ensure a slow, controlled movement to minimize joint stress.

safetyNotes: Always warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the triceps and shoulder muscles.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Ensure the bench is stable and secure to prevent accidents.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in to focus on the triceps.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid unnecessary strain.
Control the weight throughout the movement, especially during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out, which reduces tricep activation and increases shoulder stress.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively, which can lead to strain.

name: Lying Face Down Plate Neck Resistance
instructions: Lie face down with your whole body straight on a flat bench while holding a weight plate behind your head. Tip: You will need to position yourself so that your shoulders are slightly above the end of a flat bench in order for the upper chest, neck and face to be off the bench. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the plate secure on the back of your head slowly lower your head (as in saying "yes") as you breathe in.
Raise your head back up to the starting position in a semi-circular motion as you breathe out. Hold the contraction for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
contraindications: severe arthritis in the cervical spine

contraindicationDetails.cervical spine injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis in the cervical region should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Due to the potential for vertebral fractures, individuals with osteoporosis should avoid placing additional load on the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.recent neck surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that place stress on the neck until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the cervical spine: This exercise may increase pain and inflammation in individuals with advanced arthritis.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The position and movement may exacerbate symptoms in individuals with balance disorders, increasing the risk of falls.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a weight plate, using only the weight of the head for resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the plate gradually, ensuring proper form is maintained.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a resistance band anchored at the head level to provide a lighter, more controlled resistance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight plate is securely held to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive range of motion to prevent hyperextension of the neck.
Start with light weights to assess tolerance and gradually increase.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your body on the bench.
Move slowly and control the motion throughout the exercise.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid arching your back.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the weight plate to slip or move during the exercise.
Performing the exercise too quickly, reducing its effectiveness.

name: Lying Face Up Plate Neck Resistance
instructions: Lie face up with your whole body straight on a flat bench while holding a weight plate on top of your forehead. Tip: You will need to position yourself so that your shoulders are slightly above the end of a flat bench in order for the traps, neck and head to be off the bench. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the plate secure on your forehead slowly lower your head back in a semi-circular motion as you breathe in.
Raise your head back up to the starting position in a semi-circular motion as you breathe out. Hold the contraction for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
contraindications: severe arthritis in the cervical spine

contraindicationDetails.cervical spine injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or other cervical spine conditions should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating the injury.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The loading of the neck with a weight plate can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.recent neck surgery: Post-surgical patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by their healthcare provider to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the cervical spine: The exercise can exacerbate pain and inflammation in individuals with severe arthritis.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Individuals with balance issues may struggle to maintain proper form and stability during the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Holding a weight on the forehead and neck extension may increase blood pressure; those with uncontrolled hypertension should avoid this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a weight plate, using only the weight of the head for resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the plate or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage more stabilizing muscles.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a resistance band instead of a weight plate to reduce load and allow for more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight plate is securely held to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive neck extension to reduce strain on the cervical spine.
Stop the exercise immediately if you experience any pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your body.
Move slowly and control the motion throughout the exercise.
Breathe in as you lower your head and breathe out as you raise it.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the head to drop too far back, causing excessive cervical extension.
Neglecting to engage the core, resulting in instability.

name: Lying Glute
instructions: Lie on your back with your partner kneeling beside you.

Flex the hip of one leg, raising it off of the floor. Rotate the leg so the foot is over the opposite hip, the lower leg perpendicular to your body. Your partner should hold the knee and ankle in place. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to push your leg towards your partner, who should be preventing any actual movement of the leg.

After 10-20 seconds, completely relax as your partner gently pushes the ankle and knee towards your chest. Be sure to inform your helper when the stretch is adequate to prevent injury or overstretching.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal pressure and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.hip_joint_issues: Conditions such as arthritis or hip impingement may be exacerbated by the rotational and flexion forces applied during this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Pregnant individuals, particularly in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve lying on the back due to the risk of reduced blood flow and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower back, hips, or legs require caution as this exercise may aggravate these conditions.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Individuals recovering from surgeries involving the spine, hips, or knees should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard glute bridge with both feet on the ground to reduce complexity and intensity.
modifications.harder: Add resistance by using a resistance band around the thighs or by performing single-leg bridges.
modifications.injury_friendly: For lower back pain, perform a supported bridge with a pillow under the lower back to reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure clear communication with your partner to avoid overstretching.
Avoid jerky or sudden movements to reduce the risk of injury.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the pelvis.
Keep the non-working leg relaxed and grounded.
Communicate with your partner to ensure controlled resistance.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Not engaging the core, leading to instability.
Overstretching beyond comfort, risking injury.

name: Lying Hamstring
instructions: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Your partner should be kneeling beside you. Raise one leg up towards the ceiling and have your partner hold the ankle. Your partner can use their shoulder to brace your leg if necessary. This will be your starting position.
With your partner holding your leg in place, attempt to flex the knee, contracting the hamstrings for 10-20 seconds.

Then relax your leg, allowing your partner to gently push the leg towards your head. Be sure to inform your helper when the stretch is adequate to prevent injury or overstretching. Switch sides once complete.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal stress and exacerbation of symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis or tendinitis should modify the exercise to avoid excessive joint strain.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid lying supine for extended periods and may need to modify the position.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the lower back, hips, or knees require clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if there are any recent hamstring strains or lower limb injuries to prevent further damage.

neurological_conditions.details: Conditions affecting balance or proprioception may require modifications to ensure safety and prevent falls.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch without a partner by using a strap or towel around the foot to gently pull the leg towards you.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the isometric contraction phase to 30 seconds.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Place a small pillow under the lower back for support and reduce the range of motion.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Avoid the isometric contraction phase and focus on gentle static stretching.

safetyNotes: Communicate clearly with your partner to avoid overstretching.
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain or discomfort.
Ensure the partner applies pressure gradually and gently.
formCues: Keep the non-working leg flat on the ground.
Engage the core to stabilize the pelvis.
Breathe steadily throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Overstretching the hamstring, leading to strain.
Allowing the pelvis to tilt excessively.
Holding the breath during the contraction phase.

name: Lying High Bench Barbell Curl
instructions: Lie face forward on a tall flat bench while holding a barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing up). Tip: If you are holding a barbell grab it using a shoulder-width grip and if you are using an E-Z Bar grab it on the inner handles. Your upper body should be positioned in a way that the upper chest is over the end of the bench and the barbell is hanging in front of you with the arms extended and perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.
While keeping the elbows in and the upper arms stationary, curl the weight up in a semi-circular motion as you contract the biceps and exhale. Hold at the top of the movement for a second.
As you inhale, slowly go back to the starting position. Tip: Maintain full control of the weight at all times and avoid any swinging. Remember, only the forearms should move throughout the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during curling motion may exacerbate inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Positioning and movement can increase shoulder joint stress, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Supinated grip and barbell weight can strain the wrist, aggravating existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the barbell may increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Stabilization demands on the shoulder may exacerbate existing rotator cuff issues.
contraindicationDetails.spinal issues: Unsupported prone position may increase lumbar stress, especially in those with existing conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise using dumbbells with a lighter weight to reduce joint stress.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or use a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at an appropriate height to prevent falls.
Avoid using excessive weight to maintain control and prevent injury.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise to prepare muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body to minimize shoulder involvement.
Maintain a controlled motion without swinging the barbell.
Focus on contracting the biceps at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight, reducing effectiveness and increasing injury risk.
Allowing elbows to flare out, which can increase shoulder stress.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement, reducing range of motion.

name: Lying Leg Curls
instructions: Adjust the machine lever to fit your height and lie face down on the leg curl machine with the pad of the lever on the back of your legs (just a few inches under the calves). Tip: Preferably use a leg curl machine that is angled as opposed to flat since an angled position is more favorable for hamstrings recruitment.

Keeping the torso flat on the bench, ensure your legs are fully stretched and grab the side handles of the machine. Position your toes straight (or you can also use any of the other two stances described on the foot positioning section). This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, curl your legs up as far as possible without lifting the upper legs from the pad. Once you hit the fully contracted position, hold it for a second.
As you inhale, bring the legs back to the initial position. Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs or lumbar spine issues may experience increased pressure on the lower back due to the prone position.

knee_joint_issues.explanation: Those with knee arthritis, tendinitis, or recent knee surgery should avoid this exercise due to the strain it places on the knee joint.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The prone position can increase blood pressure; individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should proceed with caution.

pregnancy.explanation: Lying face down is generally not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the later stages.

acute_injuries.explanation: Avoid if there are recent hamstring strains or lower limb injuries.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight and perform partial range of motion to reduce strain on the hamstrings.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with one leg at a time to increase the challenge and focus on unilateral strength.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a seated leg curl machine to reduce pressure on the lower back.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full knee flexion, which can exacerbate knee pain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height to avoid undue stress on the knees and lower back.
Avoid hyperextending the knees at the start position.
formCues: Keep your hips pressed into the pad to prevent lower back arching.
Control the movement, especially on the way down, to maintain tension on the hamstrings.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to improper form and potential injury.
Allowing the hips to lift off the pad, which reduces hamstring activation and increases lower back strain.

name: Lying Machine Squat
instructions: Adjust the leg machine to a height that will allow you to get inside it with your knees bent and the thighs slightly below parallel.

Once you select the weight, position yourself inside the machine face up with the knees bent and thighs slightly below parallel to the platform. Make sure that the knees do not go past the toes. The angle created between the hamstrings and the calves should be one that is slightly less than 90 degrees (since your starting position requires you to start slightly below parallel). Your back and your head should be resting on the machine while your shoulders are pressed under the shoulder pads.
Place your hands by the handles and position your feet slightly pointing out at a shoulder width position. This will be your starting position.

While pressing with the balls of the feet as you breathe out, make your whole body erect as you squeeze the quads. Hold the contracted position for a second. Tip: Since you are starting below parallel, you can opt to use your hands to help you up by pressing on your thighs only on the first repetition.

Slowly squat down as you inhale but instead of going all the way down to the starting position, just stop once your thighs are parallel to the platform. The angle between your hamstrings and calves should be a 90-degree angle.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

herniated disc.explanation: The lying machine squat places compressive forces on the spine, which can exacerbate disc herniation.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The exercise involves significant knee flexion and extension, which may aggravate symptoms of osteoarthritis.

severe cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The exertion required can increase blood pressure and heart rate, posing risks for individuals with severe cardiovascular issues.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding high-load exercises to prevent complications and ensure proper healing.

balance disorders.explanation: Although the machine provides support, individuals with balance disorders may struggle with stability during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight and limit the range of motion to avoid going below parallel.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or add a pause at the bottom of the squat for increased time under tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a back support or cushion to maintain proper spinal alignment and reduce strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid deep squats to reduce stress on the knees.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height and leg length.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep your feet flat and press through the balls of your feet.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Avoid letting your knees collapse inward; keep them aligned with your toes.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to extend past the toes, increasing knee stress.
Rounding the lower back, which can lead to spinal injury.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Lying One-Arm Lateral Raise
instructions: While holding a dumbbell in one hand, lay with your chest down on a flat bench. The other hand can be used to hold to the leg of the bench for stability.

Position the palm of the hand that is holding the dumbbell in a neutral manner (palms facing your torso) as you keep the arm extended with the elbow slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the arm with the dumbbell to the side until your elbow is at shoulder height and your arm is roughly parallel to the floor as you exhale. Tip: Maintain your arm perpendicular to the torso while keeping your arm extended throughout the movement. Also, keep the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly lower the dumbbell to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arm laterally can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves shoulder abduction, which can stress inflamed tendons, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying prone on a bench may strain the cervical spine, especially if neck support is inadequate.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with weight-bearing exercises that stress the shoulder girdle.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the stress of this exercise until fully healed.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or no weight to focus on form and control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a dumbbell to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable to prevent tipping.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid cervical strain.
formCues: Keep the elbow slightly bent throughout the movement.
Engage the core to maintain stability.
Avoid shrugging the shoulders during the lift.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbow to drop below shoulder height at the top of the movement.
Overextending the arm, leading to elbow lockout.

name: Lying Prone Quadriceps
instructions: Lay face down on the floor with your partner kneeling beside you. Flex one knee and raise that leg off the ground, attempting to touch your glutes with your foot. Your partner should hold the knee and ankle. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to extend your knee while your partner prevents any actual movement.
After 10-20 seconds, relax your muscles as your partner gently pushes the foot towards your glutes, further stretching the quadriceps and hip flexors.
After 10-20 seconds, switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.knee injuries: Individuals with knee injuries such as ligament tears or severe tendinitis should avoid this exercise due to the stress placed on the knee joint during resisted extension.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Those with lower back pain may experience discomfort due to the prone position, which can exacerbate lumbar spine issues.
contraindicationDetails.hip impingement: This exercise may aggravate symptoms in individuals with hip impingement due to the flexion and extension movements involved.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The need for stability in the prone position may pose a challenge for individuals with balance disorders.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee or hip surgery: Post-surgical individuals should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional, as it may place undue stress on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform a standing quadriceps stretch using a wall or chair for support to reduce the intensity.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance during the isometric contraction phase.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with knee pain, perform a seated quadriceps stretch to minimize joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the partner applies gentle and controlled pressure to avoid overstretching.
Communicate with your partner to avoid sudden movements that could cause injury.
