formCues: Keep the pelvis flat against the floor to avoid arching the lower back.
Engage the core to maintain stability during the stretch.
Breathe steadily throughout the exercise to facilitate relaxation.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Applying too much force during the stretch, leading to potential injury.
Neglecting to communicate with the partner about discomfort or pain.

name: Lying Rear Delt Raise
instructions: While holding a dumbbell in each hand, lay with your chest down on a flat bench.
Position the palms of the hands in a neutral manner (palms facing your torso) as you keep the arms extended with the elbows slightly bent. This will be your starting position.

Now raise the arms to the side until your elbows are at shoulder height and your arms are roughly parallel to the floor as you exhale. Tip: Maintain your arms perpendicular to the torso while keeping them extended throughout the movement. Also, keep the contraction at the top for a second.
Slowly lower the dumbbells to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then switch to the other arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves repetitive shoulder abduction which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying prone may increase neck strain, especially if the head is not properly supported.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The prone position and weight-bearing can increase fracture risk in individuals with severe bone density loss.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding stress on healing tissues; this exercise may place undue stress on the shoulder.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with no weights or lighter resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion and lighter weights to minimize shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a bench with chest support to reduce strain on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at a comfortable height.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Keep the neck in a neutral position to avoid cervical strain.
formCues: Keep elbows slightly bent throughout the movement.
Raise arms until they are parallel to the floor.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the elbows to drop below shoulder level at the top of the movement.
Arching the back excessively during the lift.

name: Lying Supine Dumbbell Curl
instructions: Lie down on a flat bench face up while holding a dumbbell in each arm on top of your thighs.
Bring the dumbbells to the sides with the arms extended and the palms of the hands facing your thighs (neutral grip).

While keeping the arms close to your torso and elbows in, slowly lower your arms (as you keep them extended with a slight bend at the elbows) as far down towards the floor as you can go. Once you cannot go down any further, lock your upper arms in that position and that will be your starting position.

As you breathe out, slowly begin to curl the weights up as you simultaneously rotate your wrists so that the palms of the hands face up. Continue curling the weight until your biceps are fully contracted and squeeze hard at the top position for a second. Tip: Only the forearms should move. Upper arms should remain stationary and elbows should stay in throughout the movement.
Return back to the starting position very slowly.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during curling can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position may cause discomfort or exacerbate impingement due to shoulder positioning.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells may increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise may strain the rotator cuff muscles if not performed with proper form.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fractures due to bone fragility; avoid heavy weights.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Lying supine may increase lumbar pressure; caution with herniated discs or stenosis.

modifications.easier: Use lighter dumbbells or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip throughout to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use resistance bands instead of dumbbells to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and positioned correctly to avoid falls.
Do not hyperextend the elbows at the bottom of the movement.
Keep the core engaged to maintain spinal alignment.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Rotate wrists smoothly to avoid jerking motions.
Focus on a slow, controlled movement both up and down.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing elbows to flare out, which reduces bicep activation.
Neglecting to rotate the wrists, which limits full bicep engagement.

name: Lying T-Bar Row
instructions: Load up the T-bar Row Machine with the desired weight and adjust the leg height so that your upper chest is at the top of the pad. Tip: In some machines all you can do is stand on the appropriate step that allows you to be at a height that has the upper chest at the top of the pad.
Lay face down on the pad and grab the handles. You can either use a palms down, palms up, or palms in position depending on what part of your back you want to emphasize.
Lift the bar off the rack and extend your arms in front of you. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale slowly pull the weight up and squeeze your back at the top of the movement. Tip: Keep the upper arms as close to the torso as possible throughout the movement in order to better engage the back muscles. Also, do not lift your body off of the pad at any time and refrain from using the biceps to lift the weight.
After a second contraction at the top of the movement, as you inhale, slowly go back down to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal injuries.details: The prone position and spinal loading can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder impingement.details: The pulling motion can aggravate shoulder impingement if not performed with proper form and control.

rotator cuff tendinitis.details: The exercise may strain the rotator cuff muscles, especially if the weight is too heavy or form is compromised.

hypertension.details: The prone position may increase blood pressure; monitor closely and avoid holding breath.

pregnancy.details: Prone exercises are generally not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform a seated cable row to reduce spinal loading.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a single-arm variation to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated rows with a resistance band to minimize spinal stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain and limit range of motion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the chest pad is properly adjusted to prevent excessive spinal extension.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weight; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep your chest pressed firmly against the pad throughout the movement.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Pull through your elbows, not your hands, to engage the back muscles.
commonMistakes: Lifting the chest off the pad, which can lead to spinal hyperextension.
Using the biceps to initiate the pull instead of the back muscles.
Allowing the shoulders to round forward during the movement.

name: Lying Triceps Press
instructions: Lie on a flat bench with either an e-z bar (my preference) or a straight bar placed on the floor behind your head and your feet on the floor.

Grab the bar behind you, using a medium overhand (pronated) grip, and raise the bar in front of you at arms length. Tip: The arms should be perpendicular to the torso and the floor. The elbows should be tucked in. This is the starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the weight until the bar lightly touches your forehead while keeping the upper arms and elbows stationary.
At that point, use the triceps to bring the weight back up to the starting position as you breathe out.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places significant stress on the elbow joint, which can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms can lead to compression in the shoulder joint, aggravating impingement.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The grip on the bar can strain the wrists, especially if flexibility is limited.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow or shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to re-injury due to the load and movement pattern.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is increased due to the load on the upper body and potential for dropping the bar.

modifications.easier: Use lighter dumbbells instead of an EZ curl bar to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on a decline bench to increase the range of motion and challenge the triceps further.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use resistance bands instead of weights to decrease joint stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform tricep pushdowns with a cable machine to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar path is controlled to avoid hitting the face or head.
Keep the elbows tucked in to reduce stress on the shoulder joint.
Avoid excessive arching of the back during the exercise.
formCues: Keep upper arms perpendicular to the floor.
Lower the bar slowly and under control.
Engage the core to maintain a stable position on the bench.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, increasing shoulder stress.
Using momentum to lift the bar instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.

name: Machine Bench Press
instructions: Sit down on the Chest Press Machine and select the weight.
Step on the lever provided by the machine since it will help you to bring the handles forward so that you can grab the handles and fully extend the arms.

Grab the handles with a palms-down grip and lift your elbows so that your upper arms are parallel to the floor to the sides of your torso. Tip: Your forearms will be pointing forward since you are grabbing the handles. Once you bring the handles forward and extend the arms you will be at the starting position.
Now bring the handles back towards you as you breathe in.
Push the handles away from you as you flex your pecs and you breathe out. Hold the contraction for a second before going back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of reps.
When finished step on the lever again and slowly get the handles back to their original place.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The pressing motion can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the overhead and forward movement of the arms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The repetitive pressing motion may aggravate tendinitis in the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.pectoralis major tear: Individuals with a history of pectoralis major tears should avoid this exercise as it places significant stress on the chest muscles.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that stress the shoulder joint until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The load on the upper body may increase the risk of fractures, especially in the thoracic spine.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during pressing exercises, can temporarily increase blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight and focus on the range of motion without locking the elbows.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or slow down the eccentric phase to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Reduce the range of motion and avoid locking out the elbows to minimize shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat height is adjusted so that the handles are at chest level.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid arching the back excessively.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the floor for stability.
Engage your core to maintain a stable torso.
Exhale as you press the handles away and inhale as you bring them back.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug during the press.
Bouncing the weight at the bottom of the movement.

name: Machine Bicep Curl
instructions: Adjust the seat to the appropriate height and make your weight selection. Place your upper arms against the pads and grasp the handles. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by flexing the elbow, pulling your lower arm towards your upper arm.
Pause at the top of the movement, and then slowly return the weight to the starting position.
Avoid returning the weight all the way to the stops until the set is complete to keep tension on the muscles being worked.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow can exacerbate tendinitis symptoms.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The position of the arms during the exercise may aggravate shoulder impingement.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: Gripping the handles may increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.

recent upper limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding stress on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and ensure a neutral wrist position to minimize strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Adjust the seat height to ensure the shoulders are not elevated during the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat is adjusted so that the elbows are aligned with the machine's pivot point.
Avoid hyperextending the elbows at the bottom of the movement.
formCues: Keep the upper arms stationary and against the pads.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement.
Control the weight during the eccentric phase.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Not adjusting the seat height properly.

name: Machine Preacher Curls
instructions: Sit down on the Preacher Curl Machine and select the weight.

Place the back of your upper arms (your triceps) on the preacher pad provided and grab the handles using an underhand grip (palms facing up). Tip: Make sure that when you place the arms on the pad you keep the elbows in. This will be your starting position.

Now lift the handles as you exhale and you contract the biceps. At the top of the position make sure that you hold the contraction for a second. Tip: Only the forearms should move. The upper arms should remain stationary and on the pad at all times.
Lower the handles slowly back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation and pain in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms may cause discomfort or worsen impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The gripping action can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper limb surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the stress of this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with any resistance training involving the arms.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip if possible to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Ensure proper seat height to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat height is adjusted so that the elbows are aligned with the pivot point of the machine.
Avoid hyperextending the elbows at the bottom of the movement.
formCues: Keep your back straight and avoid leaning forward.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
Focus on a controlled movement, especially during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Not adjusting the seat height correctly.

name: Machine Shoulder (Military) Press
instructions: Sit down on the Shoulder Press Machine and select the weight.
Grab the handles to your sides as you keep the elbows bent and in line with your torso. This will be your starting position.
Now lift the handles as you exhale and you extend the arms fully. At the top of the position make sure that you hold the contraction for a second.
Lower the handles slowly back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead pressing motion.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Overhead pressing can strain the rotator cuff, delaying recovery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint compression and load may worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Overhead movements can hinder healing and recovery.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine disorders: Neck positioning and load can aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Overhead pressing can increase blood pressure significantly.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press with a neutral grip.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform a standing barbell military press.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support and maintain a neutral spine during the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat height is adjusted so that handles are at shoulder level.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine with core engaged to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep elbows slightly in front of the body to reduce shoulder joint stress.
Exhale during the pressing phase and inhale during the lowering phase.
Avoid shrugging shoulders during the lift; keep them down and back.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the back to arch excessively.
Failing to control the weight during the eccentric phase.

name: Machine Triceps Extension
instructions: Adjust the seat to the appropriate height and make your weight selection. Place your upper arms against the pads and grasp the handles. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by extending the elbow, pulling your lower arm away from your upper arm.
Pause at the completion of the movement, and then slowly return the weight to the starting position.
Avoid returning the weight all the way to the stops until the set is complete to keep tension on the muscles being worked.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension motion can exacerbate inflammation in the tendons of the elbow.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms may cause discomfort or exacerbate symptoms in individuals with shoulder impingement.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow or shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not be fully healed, and the exercise could disrupt recovery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The load on the arms and potential for sudden movements could increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.acute wrist injuries: Gripping the handles may aggravate wrist pain or delay healing.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and ensure a full warm-up to increase blood flow to the area.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Adjust the seat height to minimize shoulder involvement and ensure proper alignment.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat is adjusted so that the elbows are aligned with the axis of the machine.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the end of the extension to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep your back straight and core engaged throughout the movement.
Focus on moving through the elbows, not the shoulders.
Maintain a controlled pace, especially on the return phase.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the shoulders to move excessively during the exercise.
Returning the weight too quickly and losing muscle tension.

name: Medicine Ball Chest Pass
instructions: You will need a partner for this exercise. Lacking one, this movement can be performed against a wall.
Begin facing your partner holding the medicine ball at your torso with both hands.
Pull the ball to your chest, and reverse the motion by extending through the elbows. For sports applications, you can take a step as you throw.
Your partner should catch the ball, and throw it back to you.
Receive the throw with both hands at chest height.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: The overhead and forward motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms, leading to pain or further injury.
contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis may be aggravated by the dynamic movement and core engagement required.
contraindicationDetails.recent_abdominal_surgery: The exercise involves core engagement that can strain healing tissues post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The exertion and potential for holding breath during the throw can increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The dynamic nature of catching and throwing may challenge balance, increasing fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated on a bench or stability ball to reduce the need for balance and lower body engagement.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise standing on one leg to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a chest pass with a lighter ball or use a resistance band anchored at chest height to reduce strain.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the medicine ball is of appropriate weight to avoid strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbows when extending the arms.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Use a smooth, controlled motion when throwing and catching.
Align the wrists with the forearms to prevent strain.
commonMistakes: Using too heavy a medicine ball, leading to compromised form.
Allowing the back to arch excessively during the throw.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in poor stability.

name: Medicine Ball Full Twist
instructions: For this exercise you will need a medicine ball and a partner. Stand back to back with your partner, spaced 2-3 feet apart. This will be your starting position.
Hold the ball in front of the trunk. Open the hips and turn the shoulders at the same time as your partner.
For full rotation, you and your partner should twist in the same direction, i.e. counter-clockwise.
Pass the ball to your partner, and both of you can now twist in the opposite direction to repeat the procedure.

spinal injuries.explanation: Twisting motions can exacerbate conditions such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

joint issues.explanation: Rotational movements may aggravate conditions like arthritis or shoulder impingement.

pregnancy.explanation: Twisting can increase intra-abdominal pressure, which is not advisable during pregnancy.

osteoporosis.explanation: The twisting motion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.

acute injuries.explanation: Recent sprains or strains in the back or shoulders can be worsened by this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the twist without a partner and use a lighter ball or no ball at all.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on a balance board to engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated twists with a resistance band to reduce load on the spine.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Reduce the range of motion and use a lighter ball.

safetyNotes: Ensure there is ample space around you to avoid collisions.
Communicate clearly with your partner to synchronize movements.
Avoid jerky or rapid twisting motions to prevent injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine; avoid excessive arching or rounding.
Rotate through the torso, not just the arms.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward during the twist.
Failing to keep the core engaged, leading to excessive lower back strain.

name: Medicine Ball Scoop Throw
instructions: Assume a semisquat stance with a medicine ball in your hands. Your arms should hang so the ball is near your feet.
Begin by thrusting the hips forward as you extend through the legs, jumping up.
As you do, swing your arms up and over your head, keeping them extended, releasing the ball at the peak of your movement. The goal is to throw the ball the greatest distance behind you.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The explosive nature and spinal extension involved in the throw can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: Overhead throwing motion may aggravate impingement symptoms.

rotator_cuff_tendinitis.explanation: The dynamic overhead movement can increase strain on the rotator cuff.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The exercise involves explosive movements that may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: The jumping and throwing actions may not be safe during pregnancy, especially in later trimesters.

balance_disorders.explanation: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, which may be challenging for individuals with balance disorders.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the jump, focusing on a controlled throw from a standing position.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the throw while seated on a stability ball to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Avoid the jump and perform a controlled throw from a semi-squat position.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter ball and focus on a shorter range of motion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area behind you is clear before performing the throw.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without compromising form.
Warm up thoroughly before performing explosive exercises.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Drive through your hips and extend your legs explosively.
Keep your arms straight and follow through with the throw.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the initial squat position.
Using too heavy a ball, leading to compromised form.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in excessive spinal extension.

name: Middle Back Shrug
instructions: Lie facedown on an incline bench while holding a dumbbell in each hand. Your arms should be fully extended hanging down and pointing towards the floor. The palms of your hands should be facing each other. This will be your starting position.

As you exhale, squeeze your shoulder blades together and hold the contraction for a full second. Tip: This movement is just like the reverse action of a hug, or trying to perform rear laterals as if you had no arms.
As you inhale go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. Lying prone on an incline bench can increase intra-abdominal pressure and stress the spine.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. The prone position may exacerbate symptoms due to spinal extension.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. Spinal alignment and pressure could worsen the condition.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The movement may compress the shoulder structures.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: Moderate severity. Prone position can increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High severity. Healing tissues may be compromised by the movement.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights, focusing on the scapular movement only.
modifications.harder: Use heavier dumbbells or perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise standing with a resistance band to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on gentle scapular retraction.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at an appropriate incline to support the chest.
Avoid excessive weight that could compromise form and increase injury risk.
formCues: Keep your neck in a neutral position, aligned with the spine.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together without using the arms.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce joint strain.
commonMistakes: Using the arms to lift the weights instead of focusing on scapular movement.
Allowing the head to drop or hyperextend, causing neck strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.

name: Middle Back Stretch
instructions: Stand so your feet are shoulder width apart and your hands are on your hips.
Twist at your waist until you feel a stretch. Hold for 10 to 15 seconds, then twist to the other side.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid twisting movements that may exacerbate their condition.

osteoporosis.details: Twisting motions can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with low bone density.

pregnancy.details: During pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, twisting movements can be uncomfortable and may strain the abdominal area.

recent_abdominal_surgery.details: Twisting can place undue stress on healing tissues and should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.

balance_disorders.details: Individuals with balance disorders should perform this exercise with caution to prevent falls.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while seated on a chair to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 20-30 seconds and incorporate deep breathing to enhance the stretch.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with back pain, perform the stretch lying on the floor with knees bent and gently rotate the knees side to side.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements during the stretch.
Do not force the twist beyond a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Keep your hips facing forward while twisting your torso.
Engage your core muscles to support the spine during the twist.
Maintain an upright posture with shoulders relaxed.
commonMistakes: Twisting too quickly or forcefully.
Allowing the hips to rotate with the torso.
Holding the breath during the stretch.

name: Mixed Grip Chin
instructions: Using a spacing that is just about 1 inch wider than shoulder width, grab a pull-up bar with the palms of one hand facing forward and the palms of the other hand facing towards you. This will be your starting position.

Now start to pull yourself up as you exhale. Tip: With the arm that has the palms facing up concentrate on using the back muscles in order to perform the movement. The elbow of that arm should remain close to the torso. With the other arm that has the palms facing forward, the elbows will be away but in line with the torso. You will concentrate on using the lats to pull your body up.
After a second contraction at the top, start to slowly come down as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

On the following set, switch grips; so if you had the right hand with the palms facing you and the left one with the palms facing forward, on the next set you will have the palms facing forward for the right hand and facing you for the left.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: high
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: high
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: moderate
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: moderate
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: high
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: moderate

modifications.easier: Perform assisted chin-ups using a resistance band or an assisted pull-up machine.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a dip belt or weighted vest.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Focus on core engagement and avoid swinging.
injury_friendly.elbow_pain: Limit range of motion to avoid full extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the pull-up bar is secure and can support your weight.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise.
Avoid jerky movements to prevent strain on joints.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your body.
Keep your chest up and shoulders down and back.
Pull through your elbows, not your wrists.
Maintain a controlled movement throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull up instead of muscle strength.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up towards the ears.
Failing to switch grips between sets.
Not maintaining a full range of motion.

name: Monster Walk
instructions: Place a band around both ankles and another around both knees. There should be enough tension that they are tight when your feet are shoulder width apart.
To begin, take short steps forward alternating your left and right foot.
After several steps, do just the opposite and walk backward to where you started.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The lateral movement and band resistance can exacerbate knee joint pain and inflammation.

hip bursitis.explanation: The abduction movement may irritate the bursa in the hip, leading to increased pain.

severe lower back pain.explanation: The exercise requires core stabilization, which can strain the lower back if not performed correctly.

balance disorders.explanation: The exercise requires coordination and balance, which may be challenging for individuals with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band or only one band around the knees.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier resistance band or add ankle weights for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a band only around the knees and maintain a more upright posture to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and use a lighter resistance band to reduce stress on the knees.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely placed to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive forward lean to maintain proper posture.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees throughout the movement.
Take controlled, deliberate steps to maintain tension in the bands.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the movement.
Taking steps that are too large, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.
Leaning too far forward, which can strain the lower back.

name: Mountain Climbers
instructions: Begin in a pushup position, with your weight supported by your hands and toes. Flexing the knee and hip, bring one leg until the knee is approximately under the hip. This will be your starting position.

Explosively reverse the positions of your legs, extending the bent leg until the leg is straight and supported by the toe, and bringing the other foot up with the hip and knee flexed. Repeat in an alternating fashion for 20-30 seconds.

spinal injuries.explanation: The dynamic nature of mountain climbers can exacerbate spinal issues due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and spinal flexion.

joint issues.explanation: High-impact movements may aggravate joint pain and inflammation, particularly in the knees and wrists.

cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The exercise's intensity can elevate heart rate and blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with cardiovascular issues.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise can increase intra-abdominal pressure and may not be suitable for later stages of pregnancy.

surgical recovery.explanation: Individuals recovering from surgery, especially in the abdominal or lower limb regions, should avoid high-impact exercises.

chronic conditions.explanation: The impact and dynamic movement can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.

acute injuries.explanation: Recent injuries may be exacerbated by the high-impact and dynamic nature of the exercise.

neurological conditions.explanation: The coordination and balance required may pose a risk for falls or missteps.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise at a slower pace or step one foot forward at a time without jumping.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed or add a resistance band around the thighs for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with hands elevated on a bench to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion or perform the exercise on a softer surface to reduce impact.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform against a wall or with hands on an elevated surface to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a stable surface to prevent slipping.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Avoid locking elbows to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Drive knees towards the chest with control.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise too high.
Losing core engagement, leading to lower back strain.
Failing to maintain consistent breathing.

recommendedReps.strength: Perform for 15-20 seconds with added resistance.

name: Moving Claw Series
instructions: This move helps prepare your running form to help you excel at sprinting. As you run, be sure to flex the knee, aiming to kick your glutes as the hip extends.
Reload the quad as the leg moves back forward, attacking the ground on the next step.
Ensure that as you run, you block with the arms, punching through in a rapid 1-2 motion.

contraindicationDetails.knee injuries: High-impact movements and repetitive knee flexion can exacerbate existing knee issues.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The dynamic nature of the exercise may strain the lower back, especially if core stability is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: The exercise involves significant hip movement, which can aggravate arthritic symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The coordination and rapid movement required may increase the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by the stress placed on the lower limbs.

modifications.easier: Perform high-knee marches instead of running to reduce impact and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Incorporate ankle weights to increase resistance and challenge the muscles further.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform the exercise on a softer surface to reduce impact or limit the range of motion.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on core engagement and reduce speed to maintain control and minimize strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before performing the exercise to prevent muscle strain.
Maintain awareness of the running surface to avoid tripping or slipping.
Gradually increase intensity to allow the body to adapt to the exercise demands.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Drive your knees up towards your chest with each step.
Maintain a tall posture with your shoulders relaxed.
Use your arms to aid in balance and propulsion.
commonMistakes: Overstriding, which can lead to increased impact on the knees.
Allowing the torso to lean too far forward, causing imbalance.
Neglecting arm movement, which can disrupt rhythm and efficiency.

recommendedReps.strength: Perform for 15-20 seconds at higher intensity

name: Muscle Snatch
instructions: Begin with a loaded barbell held at the mid thigh position with a wide grip. The feet should be directly below the hips, with the feet turned out as needed. Lower the hips, with the chest up and the head looking forward. The shoulders should be just in front of the bar. This will be the starting position.

Begin the pull by driving through the front of the heels, raising the bar. Transition into the second pull by extending through the hips knees and ankles, driving the bar up as quickly as possible. The bar should be close to the body.
Continue raising the bar to the overhead position, without rebending the knees.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high load on the spine during the pull and overhead phases.

shoulder_issues.details: Those with shoulder impingement or rotator cuff injuries should modify or avoid this exercise due to the overhead component.

knee_issues.details: Individuals with knee arthritis or tendinitis should be cautious due to the explosive nature of the lift which can stress the knee joints.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before attempting due to the high-intensity nature of the exercise.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid due to balance and core stability challenges.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform a muscle snatch with a dowel or PVC pipe to practice form without added weight.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise from a deficit to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the initial pull to reduce knee flexion and stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a high pull instead, stopping before the overhead phase.

safetyNotes: Ensure the lifting area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on dynamic movements that prepare the shoulders, hips, and knees.
Use a spotter or coach if attempting heavy lifts.
formCues: Keep the bar close to the body throughout the lift.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels during the initial pull.
Fully extend the hips, knees, and ankles in the second pull.
commonMistakes: Starting with the hips too high or too low, leading to poor leverage.
Allowing the bar to drift away from the body.
Rebending the knees during the overhead phase.
Using too much arm pull instead of driving with the legs and hips.

name: Muscle Up
instructions: Grip the rings using a false grip, with the base of your palms on top of the rings. Initiate a pull up by pulling the elbows down to your side, flexing the elbows.

As you reach the top position of the pull-up, pull the rings to your armpits as you roll your shoulders forward, allowing your elbows to move straight back behind you. This puts you into the proper position to continue into the dip portion of the movement.
Maintaining control and stability, extend through the elbow to complete the motion.
Use care when lowering yourself to the ground.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and dynamic nature of the muscle-up can exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms due to the compression of the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The high demand on shoulder stability and strength can worsen inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The pulling and pushing phases place significant stress on the elbow tendons, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The false grip required can put additional strain on the wrists, potentially worsening existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The dynamic movement and potential for poor form can lead to neck strain, especially if the head is not kept in a neutral position.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip and wrist position may exacerbate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome due to increased pressure on the median nerve.

modifications.easier: Perform band-assisted muscle-ups or transition to pull-ups and dips separately to build strength.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a weight vest or belt to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Focus on strict pull-ups and dips separately, avoiding the transition phase.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip and avoid the false grip to reduce strain on the elbows.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps for additional support and consider using a neutral grip.

safetyNotes: Ensure rings are securely anchored and can support your weight.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on shoulder and wrist mobility.
Avoid kipping or excessive swinging to reduce joint strain.
formCues: Maintain a false grip throughout the movement.
Engage the core to stabilize the body.
Keep the head in a neutral position to avoid neck strain.
Control the descent to prevent joint stress.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of strength to complete the movement.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively.
Neglecting the false grip, leading to loss of control.
Failing to maintain a stable core, resulting in swinging.

name: Narrow Stance Hack Squats
instructions: Place the back of your torso against the back pad of the machine and hook your shoulders under the shoulder pads provided.

Position your legs in the platform using a less than shoulder width narrow stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Your feet should be around 3 inches or less apart. Tip: Keep your head up at all times and also maintain the back on the pad at all times.
Place your arms on the side handles of the machine and disengage the safety bars (which on most designs is done by moving the side handles from a facing front position to a diagonal position).
Now straighten your legs without locking the knees. This will be your starting position.

Begin to slowly lower the unit by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up (back on the pad at all times). Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Begin to raise the unit as you exhale by pushing the floor with mainly with the heels of your feet as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

herniated disc.explanation: The compressive forces on the spine during hack squats can exacerbate disc herniation.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The narrow stance increases stress on the knee joint, which may aggravate osteoarthritis symptoms.

severe cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The exertion required can elevate blood pressure and heart rate significantly, posing risks for individuals with severe cardiovascular issues.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the load and stress of this exercise, risking re-injury.

balance disorders.explanation: The need for stability during the exercise may pose a risk of falls or improper form for those with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight squat with a narrow stance to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the machine or perform single-leg hack squats for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a leg press machine with a wider stance to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep flexion and use lighter weights.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly set up and safety bars are engaged before starting.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your back flat against the pad throughout the movement.
Drive through the heels to engage the quadriceps effectively.
Maintain a controlled descent and ascent to avoid momentum.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Rounding the back away from the pad.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.

name: Narrow Stance Leg Press
instructions: Using a leg press machine, sit down on the machine and place your legs on the platform directly in front of you at a less-than-shoulder-width narrow stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Your feet should be around 3 inches or less apart. Tip: Keep your head up at all times and also maintain the back on the pad at all times.

Lower the safety bars holding the weighted platform in place and press the platform all the way up until your legs are fully extended in front of you. Tip: Make sure that you do not lock your knees. Your torso and the legs should make a perfect 90-degree angle. This will be your starting position.
As you inhale, slowly lower the platform until your upper and lower legs make a 90-degree angle.
Pushing mainly with the heels of your feet and using the quadriceps go back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and ensure to lock the safety pins properly once you are done. You do not want that platform falling on you fully loaded.

herniated disc.explanation: The axial load and flexion of the spine during the leg press can exacerbate disc herniation.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The compressive forces on the knee joint may worsen symptoms of osteoarthritis.

severe cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver and high intra-abdominal pressure can pose risks for individuals with heart conditions.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: The exercise can stress healing tissues and should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.

sciatica.explanation: The seated position and potential lumbar flexion can aggravate sciatic nerve pain.

hip bursitis.explanation: The hip flexion involved may irritate the bursa, causing pain and inflammation.

safetyNotes: Ensure the safety pins are securely in place before beginning the exercise.
Do not lock your knees at the top of the movement to prevent joint stress.
Keep your back firmly against the pad to avoid lumbar strain.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the platform and push through your heels.
Maintain a 90-degree angle between your torso and legs at the starting position.
Avoid letting your knees cave inward during the movement.
commonMistakes: Locking the knees at the top of the movement.
Allowing the lower back to round or lift off the pad.
Using too much weight, compromising form and safety.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight and perform the exercise with a wider stance to reduce stress on the knees.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight and perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a back support or lumbar pad to maintain a neutral spine and reduce lumbar stress.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion, which can reduce stress on the joint.

name: Narrow Stance Squats
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a less-than-shoulder-width narrow stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Feet should be around 3-6 inches apart. Keep your head up at all times (looking down will get you off balance) and maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial load on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the depth of the squat or use lighter weights to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with hypertension or heart disease should monitor their blood pressure and avoid holding their breath during the lift.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid heavy lifting and exercises that require balance.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the spine, knees, or hips require clearance from a healthcare provider before performing this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Those with osteoporosis should avoid heavy weights and focus on form to prevent fractures.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications or supervision to ensure safety.

modifications.easier: Bodyweight narrow stance squats or use of a Smith machine for guided movement.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform with a pause at the bottom of the squat.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep squatting and use a box squat variation.

safetyNotes: Always use a squat rack with safety bars set at an appropriate height.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting heavy lifts.
Ensure proper footwear with adequate support.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels and avoid letting your knees cave inward.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive forward lean.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to travel too far forward past the toes.
Rounding the back or losing the neutral spine position.
Using too much weight, compromising form and safety.

name: Natural Glute Ham Raise
instructions: Using the leg pad of a lat pulldown machine or a preacher bench, position yourself so that your ankles are under the pads, knees on the seat, and you are facing away from the machine. You should be upright and maintaining good posture.
This will be your starting position. Lower yourself under control until your knees are almost completely straight.
Remaining in control, raise yourself back up to the starting position.
If you are unable to complete a rep, use a band, a partner, or push off of a box to aid in completing a repetition.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward bending motion can exacerbate disc herniation symptoms due to increased spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to the stretch and load on the hamstrings and lower back.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Pressure on the knees during the lowering phase can increase joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee surgery: Post-surgical knees may not tolerate the stress and pressure applied during this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires significant balance and control, which may be challenging for individuals with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band anchored in front to assist in the upward phase.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with added weight, such as a weight vest.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a slight forward lean to reduce spinal stress.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a soft pad under the knees and limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the equipment is stable and secure before starting.
Avoid hyperextending the back at the top of the movement.
Maintain control throughout the entire range of motion.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Lower yourself slowly to maintain control.
Keep your body in a straight line from head to knees.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag during the lowering phase.
Using momentum instead of muscle control to return to the starting position.
Failing to engage the core, leading to excessive lumbar extension.

name: Neck-SMR
instructions: Using a muscle roller or a rolling pin, place the roller behind your head and against your neck. Make sure that you do not place the roller directly against the spine, but turned slightly so that the roller is pressed against the muscles to either side of the spine. This will be your starting position.
Starting at the top of your neck, slowly roll down the muscles of your neck, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds.
contraindications: severe arthritis in the cervical spine

contraindicationDetails.cervical spine injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or other cervical spine pathologies should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Those with osteoporosis should avoid pressure on the cervical vertebrae to prevent fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent neck surgery: Post-surgical patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the cervical spine: Arthritis can cause increased pain and inflammation; this exercise may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Individuals with balance issues may find it difficult to maintain proper positioning, increasing the risk of injury.
contraindicationDetails.acute neck strain: Performing this exercise with an acute strain can worsen the injury and delay healing.

modifications.easier: Use a softer foam roller or a towel to reduce pressure.
modifications.harder: Apply more pressure by using a firmer roller or adding slight weight with your hands.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform gentle neck stretches instead of rolling to avoid aggravating existing conditions.

safetyNotes: Avoid direct pressure on the cervical spine.
Do not apply excessive pressure to avoid nerve or muscle damage.
Stop immediately if you experience pain or dizziness.
formCues: Keep your head aligned with your spine.
Roll slowly and deliberately, focusing on muscle tension.
Breathe deeply to help relax the muscles.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly, which can cause muscle strain.
Applying pressure directly on the spine.
Holding breath, which can increase tension.

name: Neck Press
instructions: Lie back on a flat bench. Using a medium-width grip (a grip that creates a 90-degree angle in the middle of the movement between the forearms and the upper arms), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over your neck with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your neck.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up).
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The neck press places the shoulders in a position that can exacerbate impingement due to the bar path and shoulder angle.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise can strain the rotator cuff muscles, especially if they are already compromised.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: The exertion and potential for breath-holding during the lift can increase cardiovascular strain.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The stress on the shoulder joint during this exercise can disrupt healing post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is increased due to the load on the upper body and potential for improper form.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The bar path over the neck can exacerbate cervical spine conditions due to direct pressure and neck positioning.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard barbell bench press with a focus on controlled movement and lighter weight.
modifications.harder: Add resistance bands to the barbell for increased tension throughout the range of motion.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural arm path and reduced shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a spotter is present to assist with lifting and racking the bar.
Avoid excessive arching of the back to prevent lumbar strain.
Do not bounce the bar off the neck; control the descent.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the floor and maintain a stable base.
Engage your core to support your spine throughout the lift.
Lower the bar slowly and with control, aiming for a 2:1 descent to ascent ratio.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder strain.
Using too much weight, leading to compromised form and increased injury risk.
Failing to maintain a neutral wrist position, which can lead to wrist strain.

name: Oblique Crunches
instructions: Lie flat on the floor with your lower back pressed to the ground. For this exercise, you will need to put one hand beside your head and the other to the side against the floor.
Make sure your feet are elevated and resting on a flat surface.
Now lift the shoulder in which your hand is touching your head.

Simply elevate your shoulder and body upward until you touch your knee. For example, if you have your right hand besides your head, then you want to elevate your body upwards until your right elbow touches your left knee. The same variation can be applied doing the inverse and using your left elbow to touch your right knee.
After your knee touches your elbow, lower your body until you have reached the starting position.
Remember to breathe in during the eccentric (lowering) part of the exercise and to breathe out during the concentric (upward) part of the exercise.
Continue alternating in this manner until all of the recommended repetitions for each side have been completed.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High risk due to spinal flexion which can exacerbate the condition.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion of the spine may increase symptoms and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Spinal flexion can further destabilize the vertebrae.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: May aggravate symptoms due to nerve compression during spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of vertebral fracture due to spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Increased intra-abdominal pressure may disrupt healing.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Supine position and abdominal pressure are not recommended, especially in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with feet flat on the floor instead of elevated.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight or medicine ball in the hand touching the head for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform side planks or standing oblique crunches to reduce spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep both hands crossed over the chest to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with the hand to prevent strain.
Maintain a neutral spine as much as possible to reduce stress on the lower back.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Lift with the obliques, not the neck or arms.
Exhale during the upward phase, inhale during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Pulling on the neck with the hand.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: Oblique Crunches - On The Floor
instructions: Start out by lying on your right side with your legs lying on top of each other. Make sure your knees are bent a little bit.
Place your left hand behind your head.
Once you are in this set position, begin by moving your left elbow up as you would perform a normal crunch except this time the main emphasis is on your obliques.
Crunch as high as you can, hold the contraction for a second and then slowly drop back down into the starting position.
Remember to breathe in during the eccentric (lowering) part of the exercise and to breathe out during the concentric (elevation) part of the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The twisting motion and spinal flexion can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Moderate severity. Flexion and rotation may increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. Spinal flexion can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. The exercise may irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Spinal flexion can increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Lying on the back can be uncomfortable and unsafe in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a physician to prevent strain on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion or keep both feet on the ground for stability.
modifications.harder: Hold a small weight or medicine ball against the chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform side planks to engage the obliques without spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep the arm across the chest instead of behind the head to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking or using momentum to complete the movement.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain, especially in the back or neck.
formCues: Engage your core before starting the movement.
Keep your neck neutral to avoid strain.
Focus on a slow, controlled motion.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle contraction.
Pulling on the neck with the hand behind the head.
Allowing the legs to separate or move during the exercise.

name: Olympic Squat
instructions: Begin with a barbell supported on top of the traps. The chest should be up, and the head facing forward. Adopt a hip width stance with the feet turned out as needed.

Descend by flexing the knees, refraining from moving the hips back as much as possible. This requires that the knees travel forward; ensure that they stay aligned with the feet. The goal is to keep the torso as upright as possible. Continue all the way down, keeping the weight on the front of the heel.
At the moment the upper legs contact the lower, reverse the motion, driving the weight upward.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the compressive forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the depth and load to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Hypertension or heart disease patients should consult a physician before performing due to increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid heavy lifting and consult with a healthcare provider for appropriate modifications.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery on the spine, knees, or hips requires complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare professional.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis patients should avoid heavy loads and deep squats to prevent fractures.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the lower body.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or perform bodyweight squats to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform pause squats to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a safety squat bar to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit depth to a partial squat and use knee sleeves for support.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a front squat grip to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before attempting heavy lifts.
Use a spotter or safety bars in a squat rack for safety.
Avoid bouncing at the bottom of the squat to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep the chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Align knees with toes to prevent valgus collapse.
Drive through the heels to maintain balance and power.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward.
Leaning too far forward, causing excessive spinal flexion.
Rising onto the toes instead of keeping weight on the heels.

name: On-Your-Back Quad Stretch
instructions: Lie on a flat bench or step, and hang one leg and arm over the side.
Bend the knee and hold the top of the foot. As you do this, be careful not to arch your lower back.
Pull the belly button to the spine to stay in neutral. Press your foot down and into your hand. To add the hip stretch, lift the hip of the leg you're holding up toward the ceiling.
Switch sides.

herniated disc.explanation: The position may exacerbate symptoms by increasing lumbar spine extension.

lumbar stenosis.explanation: Lumbar extension can worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: Knee flexion may increase joint stress; modifications are necessary.

hip impingement.explanation: The stretch may aggravate symptoms; modifications are recommended.

pregnancy.explanation: Supine position may cause discomfort or reduced venous return; modifications are advised.

recent knee surgery.explanation: The exercise may place undue stress on the recovering joint.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch lying on your side with a pillow under the head for support.
modifications.harder: Add a resistance band around the ankle for increased tension during the stretch.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch on your side with a pillow under the head and avoid arching the back.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a strap to hold the foot instead of pulling directly with the hand to reduce knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid arching the lower back excessively.
Maintain a neutral spine by engaging the core.
Do not force the stretch beyond comfort.
formCues: Engage your core by pulling the belly button towards the spine.
Keep the pelvis level and avoid tilting.
Gently press the foot into the hand to activate the quadriceps.
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back excessively.
Pulling the foot too forcefully, causing knee strain.
Allowing the pelvis to tilt or rotate.

name: On Your Side Quad Stretch
instructions: Start off by lying on your right side, with your right knee bent at a 90-degree angle resting on the floor in front of you (this stabilizes the torso).
Bend your left knee behind you and hold your left foot with your left hand. To stretch your hip flexor, press your left hip forward as you push your left foot back into your hand. Switch sides.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or sciatica should avoid this exercise or perform it with caution, as the twisting motion and hip flexor stretch can exacerbate symptoms.

knee joint issues.details: Those with knee osteoarthritis or tendinitis should be cautious, as bending the knee can increase joint stress.

hip joint issues.details: Hip impingement or arthritis may be aggravated by the hip extension required in this stretch.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should modify the exercise to avoid lying on their side for extended periods, especially in the second and third trimesters.

recent lower limb surgery.details: Avoid this exercise during the early stages of recovery from surgeries involving the hip, knee, or ankle.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while standing, using a wall or chair for support to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by gently pulling the foot closer to the glutes while maintaining proper alignment.
modifications.injury_friendly: For back pain, perform the stretch with a pillow under the torso for support. For knee pain, reduce the degree of knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling too hard on the ankle to prevent knee strain.
Ensure the neck is aligned with the spine to avoid tension.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Align the hips vertically to prevent twisting.
Press the hip forward gently to enhance the stretch.
commonMistakes: Allowing the pelvis to rotate backward.
Overarching the lower back.
Pulling the foot too forcefully, causing knee discomfort.

name: One-Arm Dumbbell Row
instructions: Choose a flat bench and place a dumbbell on each side of it.

Place the right leg on top of the end of the bench, bend your torso forward from the waist until your upper body is parallel to the floor, and place your right hand on the other end of the bench for support.

Use the left hand to pick up the dumbbell on the floor and hold the weight while keeping your lower back straight. The palm of the hand should be facing your torso. This will be your starting position.

Pull the resistance straight up to the side of your chest, keeping your upper arm close to your side and keeping the torso stationary. Breathe out as you perform this step. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. Also, make sure that the force is performed with the back muscles and not the arms. Finally, the upper torso should remain stationary and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work except for holding the dumbbell; therefore do not try to pull the dumbbell up using the forearms.
Lower the resistance straight down to the starting position. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Repeat the movement for the specified amount of repetitions.
Switch sides and repeat again with the other arm.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal flexion and rotation can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Forward bending may increase spinal canal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Lumbar flexion can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Arm elevation may aggravate shoulder structures.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: Isometric holds and heavy lifting can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Increased intra-abdominal pressure may affect healing.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or using a resistance band.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with a support for the chest.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid shoulder discomfort.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid excessive torso rotation or lateral movement.
Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Pull the dumbbell towards your hip, not your shoulder.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together at the top.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using momentum to lift the weight.
Allowing the shoulder to internally rotate excessively.

name: One-Arm Flat Bench Dumbbell Flye
instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in one hand resting on top of your thigh. The palm of your hand with the dumbbell in it should be at a neutral grip.

By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbell up, clean the dumbbell so that you can hold it in front of you with your lifting arm being fully extended. Remember to maintain a neutral grip with this exercise. Your non lifting hand should be to the side holding the flat bench for better support. This will be your starting position.

Your arm with the weight should have a slight bend on your elbow in order to prevent stress at the biceps tendon. Begin by lowering your arm with the weight in it out in a wide arc until you feel a stretch on your chest. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Keep in mind that throughout the movement, your lifting arm should remain stationary; the movement should only occur at the shoulder joint.
Return your lifting arm back to the starting position as you squeeze your chest muscles and breathe out. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.
