Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The exercise involves a wide arc of motion that can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the positioning of the arm and shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The stabilization required by the rotator cuff muscles during this exercise can aggravate existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.biceps tendinitis: The slight bend in the elbow and the load on the biceps tendon can worsen tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with exercises that involve significant arm extension and load, especially in individuals with compromised bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or chest injuries: Performing this exercise can delay healing and increase pain in individuals with recent injuries to these areas.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, keeping the arm closer to the body.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper support of the lower back by engaging the core and keeping feet flat on the ground.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and your feet are flat on the ground for balance.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent undue stress on the shoulder joint.
formCues: Maintain a slight bend in the elbow throughout the movement.
Keep the movement slow and controlled, focusing on the stretch and contraction of the chest muscles.
Engage the core to maintain stability and prevent arching of the back.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to lock out, which can increase stress on the biceps tendon.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.

name: One-Arm High-Pulley Cable Side Bends
instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower. Move cable to highest pulley position.
Stand with side to cable. With one hand, reach up and grab handle with underhand grip.
Pull down cable until elbow touches your side and the handle is by your shoulder.
Position feet hip-width apart. Place free hand on hip to help gauge pivot point.
Keep arm in static position. Contract oblique to bring the weight down in a side crunch.
Once you reach maximum contraction, slowly release the weight to the starting position. The weight stack should never be unloaded in a resting position. The aim is constant tension during the set.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and lateral flexion stress.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or bursitis in the spine or hips should modify the exercise to reduce range of motion and load.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve significant lateral flexion and abdominal pressure.

osteoporosis.details: This exercise involves spinal flexion and lateral movement, which can increase fracture risk in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent trauma or strains to the back or abdominal region.

neurological_conditions.details: Individuals with balance disorders or neuropathy should perform this exercise with caution, potentially using support or assistance.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable to reduce load and allow for greater control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable machine or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a Bosu ball to engage more stabilizing muscles.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform side bends without weight, focusing on slow, controlled movements to minimize strain on the spine and joints.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lateral flexion.
Avoid jerking motions and ensure a controlled tempo to prevent injury.
formCues: Engage your core before starting the movement.
Keep your shoulders aligned and avoid twisting your torso.
Focus on the contraction of the obliques to move the weight.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to move the weight instead of muscle contraction.
Allowing the spine to excessively flex or extend during the movement.
Neglecting to keep the feet firmly planted and stable.

name: One-Arm Incline Lateral Raise
instructions: Lie down sideways on an incline bench press with a dumbbell in the hand. Make sure the shoulder is pressing against the incline bench and the arm is lying across your body with the palm around your navel.
Hold a dumbbell in your uppermost arm while keeping it extended in front of you parallel to the floor. This is your starting position.

While keeping the dumbbell parallel to the floor at all times, perform a lateral raise. Your arm should travel straight up until it is pointing at the ceiling. Tip: Exhale as you perform this movement. Hold the dumbbell in the position and feel the contraction in the shoulders for a second.
While inhaling lower the weight across your body back into the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Clean
instructions: Place a kettlebell between your feet. As you bend down to grab the kettlebell, push your butt back and keep your eyes looking forward.
Clean the kettlebell to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulder. The wrist should rotate as you do so.

name: One-Arm Kettlebell Clean and Jerk
instructions: Hold a kettlebell by the handle.
Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so, so that the palm faces forward.
Dip your body by bending the knees, keeping your torso upright.

Immediately reverse direction, driving through the heels, in essence jumping to create momentum. As you do so, press the kettlebell overhead to lockout by extending the arms, using your body's momentum to move the weight.
Receive the weight overhead by returning to a squat position underneath the weight.
Keeping the weight overhead, return to a standing position. Lower the weight to the floor to perform the next repetition.

Avoid jerking or using momentum to lift the weight.
Ensure the barbell is securely positioned in the landmine or corner to prevent slipping.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders retracted.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Pull with your elbow close to your body, not with your hand.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using excessive weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the shoulder to internally rotate excessively.

name: One-Arm Medicine Ball Slam
instructions: Start in a standing position with a staggered, athletic stance. Hold a medicine ball in one hand, on the same side as your back leg. This will be your starting position.
Begin by winding the arm, raising the medicine ball above your head. As you do so, extend through the hips, knees, and ankles to load up for the slam.
At peak extension, flex the shoulders, spine, and hips to throw the ball hard into the ground directly in front of you.
Catch the ball on the bounce and continue for the desired number of repetitions.

spinal injuries.explanation: The dynamic nature and spinal flexion involved in the exercise can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Overhead movements may aggravate impingement symptoms; modifications or avoidance advised.

rotator cuff tendinitis.explanation: The overhead and rapid motion can increase inflammation and pain in the rotator cuff.

wrist injuries.explanation: Catching the ball can place stress on the wrist joint, potentially worsening conditions like sprains or carpal tunnel syndrome.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise involves dynamic movements and potential balance challenges, which may not be suitable during pregnancy.

osteoporosis.explanation: High-impact movements can increase the risk of fractures, particularly in individuals with low bone density.

acute injuries.explanation: Performing this exercise with any acute musculoskeletal injury can exacerbate the condition and delay healing.

modifications.easier: Perform the slam with both hands to reduce the complexity and load on one side of the body.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter ball and focus on controlled movements, avoiding excessive spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full overhead extension, or perform a chest-level slam instead.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Avoid the deep knee bend by maintaining a more upright posture during the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or slipping.
Use a non-slip mat or surface to maintain stable footing.
Start with a lighter ball to master form before progressing to heavier weights.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement to protect the spine.
Keep the wrist neutral to avoid excessive strain.
Drive through the hips and legs to generate power, not just the arm.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively during the slam.
Using only the arm to generate force instead of engaging the whole body.
Failing to control the ball on the rebound, leading to poor form or injury.

name: One-Arm Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
instructions: Place one kettlebell between your feet.
Grab the handle with one hand and raise the kettlebell rapidly, let it flip so that the ball of the kettlebell lands in the palm of your hand.
Throw the kettlebell out in front of you and catch the handle with one hand.
Take the kettlebell to the floor and repeat. Make sure to work both arms.

spinal_injuries.details: The dynamic nature and spinal loading during the clean can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or sciatica.

joint_issues.details: Conditions such as shoulder impingement or tendinitis may be aggravated due to the overhead and catching movements.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: The explosive nature of the exercise can increase heart rate significantly, which may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.details: The exercise involves rapid movements and balance challenges, which are not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, require avoiding high-impact and dynamic exercises.

acute_injuries.details: Any recent sprains, strains, or trauma should be fully healed before attempting this exercise due to its explosive nature.

modifications.easier: Perform a kettlebell deadlift instead, focusing on controlled lifting and lowering without the clean motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise with a single-arm kettlebell snatch for added complexity.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter kettlebell and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid the flipping motion, focusing instead on a controlled lift and lower.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area around you is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or collisions.
Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints for dynamic movement.
Use a weight that allows you to maintain control throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to protect your lower back.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips explosively to lift the kettlebell.
Keep your wrist straight as you catch the kettlebell in your palm.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift, which can lead to spinal injury.
Using too much arm and not enough hip drive, reducing efficiency and increasing injury risk.
Allowing the kettlebell to swing too far from the body, which can cause loss of control.

name: One-Arm Overhead Kettlebell Squats
instructions: Clean and press a kettlebell with one arm. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder by extending through the legs and hips as you pull the kettlebell towards your shoulder. Rotate your wrist as you do so. Press the weight overhead by extending through the elbow.This will be your starting position.
Looking straight ahead and keeping a kettlebell locked out above you, flex the knees and hips and lower your torso between your legs, keeping your head and chest up.
Pause at the bottom position for a second before rising back to the top, driving through the heels of your feet.

spinal_injuries.details: The overhead position and squat mechanics can exacerbate spinal compression and instability, especially in cases of herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_joint_issues.details: The overhead position places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate conditions such as impingement or rotator cuff tendinitis.

knee_joint_issues.details: Deep squatting can increase stress on the knee joint, potentially worsening arthritis or patellar tendinitis.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: The exercise involves significant exertion and may elevate blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.details: The balance and core demands, along with the risk of abdominal pressure, make this exercise unsuitable during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, shoulder, or knee, require avoiding high-load and complex movements.

balance_disorders.details: The unilateral load and overhead position require significant balance and proprioception, posing a risk for falls.

modifications.easier: Perform a goblet squat with a single kettlebell held at chest level to reduce shoulder and balance demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance further.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and limit the depth of the squat to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform a partial squat and focus on maintaining knee alignment over the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the overhead position and perform a front squat variation with the kettlebell held at chest level.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up focusing on shoulder and hip mobility.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without compromising form.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the squat to maintain muscle engagement.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Ensure the knees track over the toes during the squat.
Keep the kettlebell directly above the shoulder with a locked elbow.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round during the squat.
Letting the knees cave inward.
Using too heavy a weight, compromising form.
Failing to maintain a stable shoulder position.

name: One-Arm Side Deadlift
instructions: Stand to the side of a barbell next to its center. Bend your knees and lower your body until you are able to reach the barbell.

Grasp the bar as if you were grabbing a briefcase (palms facing you since the bar is sideways). You may need a wrist wrap if you are using a significant amount of weight. This is your starting position.
Use your legs to help lift the barbell up while exhaling. Your arms should extend fully as bring the barbell up until you are in a standing position.
Slowly bring the barbell back down while inhaling. Tip: Make sure to bend your knees while lowering the weight to avoid any injury from occurring.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.

spinal_injuries.details: The asymmetric load and bending motion can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

joint_issues.details: Knee or hip arthritis may be aggravated by the loading pattern. Modifications or alternative exercises may be necessary.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Heavy lifting can increase blood pressure and may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.details: The balance and core demands, along with the potential for increased intra-abdominal pressure, make this exercise unsuitable.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, especially involving the spine, hips, or knees, require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

osteoporosis.details: The risk of fractures due to the load and bending motion is significant for individuals with low bone density.

acute_injuries.details: Any recent trauma or sprains in the lower back, hips, or knees should preclude this exercise until fully healed.

modifications.easier: Use a dumbbell instead of a barbell to reduce the load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on an unstable surface, such as a balance pad, to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a suitcase deadlift with lighter weights and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion and reduce the load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is centered and balanced before lifting.
Avoid twisting your torso during the lift.
Do not lock your knees at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding your back.
Drive through your heels as you lift the barbell.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using the arms to lift instead of the legs.
Allowing the knees to cave inward.

name: One-Arm Side Laterals
instructions: Pick a dumbbell and place it in one of your hands. Your non lifting hand should be used to grab something steady such as an incline bench press. Lean towards your lifting arm and away from the hand that is gripping the incline bench as this will allow you to keep your balance.
Stand with a straight torso and have the dumbbell by your side at arm's length with the palm of the hand facing you. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the dumbbell to your side with a slight bend on the elbow and your hand slightly tilted forward as if pouring water in a glass. Continue to go up until you arm is parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this movement and pause for a second at the top.
Lower the dumbbell back down slowly to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Lifting the arm laterally can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Leaning and holding a weight can strain the cervical spine, potentially aggravating existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fractures increases with weight-bearing exercises, especially if balance is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder injuries: Any recent trauma or injury to the shoulder should be fully healed before performing this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or without any weight to focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a dumbbell to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Ensure a stable base of support by gripping a steady object with the non-lifting hand.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbow to reduce stress on the joint.
formCues: Keep the torso stationary and avoid swinging the body.
Lift the dumbbell until the arm is parallel to the floor.
Tilt the hand slightly forward as if pouring water from a glass.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Lifting the arm above shoulder height, which can increase the risk of impingement.
Allowing the torso to sway or twist during the lift.

name: One-Legged Cable Kickback
instructions: Hook a leather ankle cuff to a low cable pulley and then attach the cuff to your ankle.
Face the weight stack from a distance of about two feet, grasping the steel frame for support.

While keeping your knees and hips bent slightly and your abs tight, contract your glutes to slowly "kick" the working leg back in a semicircular arc as high as it will comfortably go as you breathe out. Tip: At full extension, squeeze your glutes for a second in order to achieve a peak contraction.
Now slowly bring your working leg forward, resisting the pull of the cable until you reach the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch legs and repeat the movement for the other side.

spinal_injuries.description: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis may experience increased spinal loading and discomfort during this exercise.

joint_issues.description: Those with hip or knee arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should avoid or modify this exercise due to potential joint stress.

pregnancy.description: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, may find this exercise uncomfortable and should consult with a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.description: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights, focusing on the glute contraction.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable machine or perform the exercise with a resistance band for added tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise lying face down on a mat, lifting the leg without resistance to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion and extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the ankle cuff is securely fastened to prevent slipping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid lower back strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the pelvis.
Avoid arching the lower back as the leg extends.
Focus on squeezing the glutes at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the lower back to hyperextend.
Not maintaining a slight bend in the supporting knee.

name: One Arm Against Wall
instructions: From a standing position, place a bent arm against a wall or doorway.
Slowly lean toward your arm until you feel a stretch in your lats.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: Leaning into the wall can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder.
contraindicationDetails.rotator_cuff_injury: This exercise may place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe_osteoporosis: The leaning motion could increase the risk of fractures in individuals with significantly weakened bones.
contraindicationDetails.recent_shoulder_surgery: Post-surgical tissues need time to heal, and this stretch could disrupt the healing process.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the arm slightly bent and avoid leaning too far into the wall to reduce the intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by stepping further away from the wall and leaning deeper into the stretch.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the stretch with the arm lower on the wall to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Keep the spine neutral and avoid excessive leaning to prevent back strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking motions during the stretch.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a neutral spine.
Ensure your shoulder is relaxed and not elevated towards your ear.
Lean gently into the stretch until you feel a mild tension.
commonMistakes: Leaning too far and causing shoulder strain.
Allowing the shoulder to elevate, leading to improper form.
Holding the breath instead of breathing deeply and regularly.

name: One Arm Chin-Up
instructions: For this exercise, start out by placing a towel around a chin up bar.
Grab the chin-up bar with your palm facing you. One hand will be grabbing the chin-up bar and the other will be grabbing the towel.
Bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.v

Pull your torso up until the bar touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High stress on the shoulder joint can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places significant load on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The spinal load and traction forces can aggravate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Spinal extension and load may increase slippage risk.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Grip strength and wrist position can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High demand on the elbow flexors can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric holds and intense exertion can elevate blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Use an assisted pull-up machine or resistance bands for support.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise without the towel, using only one arm on the bar.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform two-arm chin-ups or use a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a supported pull-up machine to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the chin-up bar is secure and can support your body weight.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on shoulder and back mobility.
Avoid jerky movements to prevent strain on joints and muscles.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your chest lifted and shoulders down and back.
Focus on pulling through your back muscles, not your arms.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the body instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up towards the ears.
Not fully extending the arm at the bottom of the movement.

name: One Arm Dumbbell Bench Press
instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in one hand on top of your thigh.

By using your thigh to help you get the dumbbell up, clean the dumbbell up so that you can hold it in front of you at shoulder width. Use the hand you are not lifting with to help position the dumbbell over you properly.
Once at shoulder width, rotate your wrist forward so that the palm of your hand is facing away from you. This will be your starting position.

Bring down the weights slowly to your side as you breathe in. Keep full control of the dumbbell at all times. Tip: Use the hand that you are not lifting with to help keep the dumbbell balance as you may struggle a bit at first. Only use your non-lifting hand if it is needed. Otherwise, keep it resting to the side.

As you breathe out, push the dumbbells up using your pectoral muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, squeeze your chest, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can aggravate existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.wrist instability: Holding a dumbbell in one hand requires significant wrist stabilization, which can be problematic for those with instability or previous injuries.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture from the load and potential imbalance is heightened in individuals with severe osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues need time to heal, and the exercise can place undue stress on the recovering shoulder.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter dumbbell or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or a wrist brace to provide additional support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and positioned on a non-slip surface.
Start with a manageable weight to master form before progressing.
Avoid locking the elbow at the top of the movement to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the floor for stability.
Engage your core to maintain balance and prevent arching of the lower back.
Lower the dumbbell slowly and with control, ensuring the elbow stays slightly bent at the bottom.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to flare out excessively, which can increase shoulder strain.
Using momentum to lift the dumbbell, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.
Neglecting to engage the core, leading to potential lower back strain.

name: One Arm Dumbbell Preacher Curl
instructions: Grab a dumbbell with the right arm and place the upper arm on top of the preacher bench or the incline bench. The dumbbell should be held at shoulder length. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbell until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.

As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbell is at shoulder height. Again, remember that to ensure full contraction you need to bring that small finger higher than the thumb.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The exercise may exacerbate inflammation and pain in the elbow tendons due to repetitive flexion.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The position of the arm may cause compression in the shoulder joint, aggravating impingement symptoms.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.

rotator cuff injuries.explanation: The exercise can place undue stress on the shoulder, risking further injury to the rotator cuff.

severe osteoporosis.explanation: The risk of fracture is increased due to the load on the arm and potential for sudden movements.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter dumbbell or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (hammer curl) to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with the arm supported on a flat bench to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the preacher bench is adjusted to a comfortable height to avoid excessive strain on the shoulder.
Avoid locking the elbow at the bottom of the movement to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep the wrist straight and aligned with the forearm.
Maintain a controlled tempo throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the curl.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight, which reduces biceps engagement.
Allowing the elbow to drift away from the bench, increasing shoulder involvement.

name: One Arm Floor Press
instructions: Lie down on a flat surface with your back pressing against the floor or an exercise mat. Make sure your knees are bent.

Have a partner hand you the bar on one hand. When starting, your arm should be just about fully extended, similar to the starting position of a barbell bench press. However, this time your grip will be neutral (palms facing your torso).
Make sure the hand you are not using to lift the weight is placed by your side.
Begin the exercise by lowering the barbell until your elbow touches the ground. Make sure to breathe in as this is the eccentric (lowering part of the exercise).
Then start lifting the barbell back up to the original starting position. Remember to breathe out during the concentric (lifting part of the exercise).
Repeat until you have performed your recommended repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The movement may exacerbate impingement due to the shoulder's range of motion and load.

rotator cuff tear.explanation: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder, potentially worsening a tear.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The exercise involves elbow extension, which can aggravate tendinitis.

wrist pain.explanation: The grip and load can exacerbate wrist pain, especially if not properly aligned.

hypertension.explanation: Isometric holds during the exercise can increase blood pressure temporarily.

spinal issues.explanation: Lying on the floor may not provide adequate support for those with spinal conditions.

modifications.easier: Use a dumbbell instead of a barbell to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on a bench to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight and ensure a neutral wrist position.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Place a small pillow under the lower back for support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely gripped to avoid dropping.
Have a spotter assist with the hand-off and re-rack of the barbell.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Lower the barbell slowly and with control.
Avoid locking the elbow at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to flare out excessively.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Failing to maintain a neutral wrist position.

name: One Arm Lat Pulldown
instructions: Select an appropriate weight and adjust the knee pad to help keep you down. Grasp the handle with a pronated grip. This will be your starting position.
Pull the handle down, squeezing your elbow to your side as you flex the elbow.
Pause at the bottom of the motion, and then slowly return the handle to the starting position.
For multiple repetitions, avoid completely returning the weight to keep tension on the muscles being worked.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pulling motion can exacerbate symptoms by compressing structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may increase inflammation or pain due to repetitive shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The exercise can increase spinal load and exacerbate nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Holding breath or straining can increase blood pressure; monitor closely.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or back surgery: The exercise may disrupt healing tissues or compromise surgical repairs.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce the load and allow for more controlled movement.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slower tempo or add an isometric hold at the bottom of the movement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the knee pad is properly adjusted to prevent lifting off the seat.
Avoid jerking or sudden movements to prevent strain on the shoulder and back.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Pull through your elbow, not your hand, to focus on engaging the lats.
Pause briefly at the bottom of the movement to maximize muscle contraction.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Leaning back excessively, which shifts focus away from the lats and increases spinal load.
Allowing the weight to drop too quickly, which can cause joint strain.

name: One Arm Pronated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
instructions: Lie flat on a bench while holding a dumbbell at arms length. Your arm should be perpendicular to your body. The palm of your hand should be facing towards your feet as a pronated grip is required to perform this exercise.
Place your non lifting hand on your bicep for support.
Slowly begin to lower the dumbbell down as you breathe in.
Then, begin lifting the dumbbell upward as you contract the triceps. Remember to breathe out during the concentric (lifting part of the exercise).
Repeat until you have performed your set repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The overhead position may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the shoulder structures.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The exercise involves repetitive elbow extension, which can aggravate tendinitis.

rotator cuff injuries.explanation: The exercise requires shoulder stabilization, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The pronated grip may increase pressure on the median nerve.

recent upper body surgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by the stress placed on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use both arms simultaneously to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise standing to engage core stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow_pain: Use a resistance band instead of a dumbbell to decrease joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbow at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your elbow close to your head to maintain proper alignment.
Control the weight throughout the movement to avoid momentum.
Engage your core to stabilize your body on the bench.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbow to flare out, which can increase shoulder strain.
Not maintaining a controlled tempo, leading to potential injury.

name: One Arm Supinated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
instructions: Lie flat on a bench while holding a dumbbell at arms length. Your arm should be perpendicular to your body. The palm of your hand should be facing towards your face as a supinated grip is required to perform this exercise.
Place your non lifting hand on your bicep for support.
Slowly begin to lower the dumbbell down as you breathe in.
Then, begin lifting the dumbbell upward as you contract the triceps. Remember to breathe out during the concentric (lifting part of the exercise).
Repeat until you have performed your set repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the movement.
Switch arms again and repeat the movement.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and supinated grip can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis, particularly in the triceps tendon.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required by the shoulder can strain an injured rotator cuff, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip required can increase pressure on the median nerve, exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Any recent surgery involving the shoulder, elbow, or wrist may be compromised by the load and movement pattern of this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing to engage core stabilizers or increase the weight.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on a controlled range of motion to minimize joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbow at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep the upper arm perpendicular to the floor throughout the exercise.
Maintain a controlled motion, avoiding any jerky movements.
Engage the core to stabilize the body and prevent arching of the back.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to flare out, which can reduce triceps activation.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Failing to maintain a supinated grip, which alters the exercise mechanics.

name: One Half Locust
instructions: Lie facedown on the floor.
Put your left hand under your left hipbone to pad your hip and pubic bone.
Bend your right knee so you can hold the foot in your right hand.

Lift the foot in the air and simultaneously lift your shoulders off the floor. This also stretches the right hip flexor and the chest and shoulders. Switch sides. If it doesn't bother your back, you can try it with both arms and legs at the same time.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal extension and compression.

joint issues.details: Those with shoulder impingement or tendinitis should be cautious due to the shoulder extension involved. Knee arthritis may also be aggravated by the quadriceps engagement.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid lying prone and may experience discomfort with abdominal pressure.

acute injuries.details: Recent trauma or surgery to the back, shoulders, or knees should preclude participation until cleared by a healthcare provider.

neurological conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may affect the ability to safely perform this exercise due to coordination and proprioception challenges.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with one leg and arm at a time, keeping the opposite limbs on the ground for stability.
modifications.harder: Lift both legs and arms simultaneously, maintaining balance and control.
modifications.injury_friendly: For back pain, perform the exercise with a pillow under the abdomen to reduce spinal extension. For shoulder pain, avoid lifting the shoulders off the ground.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive arching of the lower back to prevent strain.
Ensure a gradual progression in difficulty to avoid overloading the muscles.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Lift the leg and arm smoothly, avoiding jerky movements.
Keep the neck in a neutral position to prevent strain.
commonMistakes: Hyperextending the lower back.
Holding the breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure.
Lifting the head excessively, leading to neck strain.

name: One Handed Hang
instructions: Grab onto a chinup bar with one hand, using a pronated grip. Keep your feet on the floor or a step. Allow the majority of your weight to hang from that hand, while keeping your feet on the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds and switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Hanging can increase strain on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping the bar can aggravate the tendons in the elbow, increasing pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Supporting body weight with one hand can stress the wrist joint, exacerbating pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Hanging can place traction on the cervical spine, potentially worsening conditions like stenosis or herniated discs.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip required may compress the median nerve, worsening symptoms.

modifications.easier: Use both hands to hang, reducing the load on each arm.
modifications.harder: Lift your feet off the ground to hang fully from one hand.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with both hands to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist straps to alleviate pressure on the wrists.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is secure and can support your weight.
Avoid jerking or swinging motions to prevent joint strain.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your body.
Keep your shoulders down and away from your ears.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbow to reduce joint stress.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulder to elevate towards the ear.
Swinging the body excessively.
Overextending the elbow joint.

name: One Knee To Chest
instructions: Start off by lying on the floor.
Extend one leg straight and pull the other knee to your chest. Hold under the knee joint to protect the kneecap.
Gently tug that knee toward your nose.
Switch sides. This stretches the buttocks and lower back of the bent leg and the hip flexor of the straight leg.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: This exercise can exacerbate symptoms by increasing lumbar flexion and pressure on the disc.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Pulling the knee to the chest may irritate the sciatic nerve, especially if the nerve is already compressed.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: The movement may cause discomfort or pain due to reduced joint space and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: Post-surgical tissue may be vulnerable to strain or injury from the flexion involved.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Excessive spinal flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a towel or strap around the knee to reduce the need for flexibility.
modifications.harder: Add a gentle twist by bringing the knee slightly across the body to increase the stretch.

injury_friendly.back pain: Place a small pillow under the lower back to maintain a neutral spine position.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep the knee slightly bent instead of fully pulling it to the chest to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling directly on the kneecap to prevent joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
formCues: Keep the extended leg straight and relaxed on the floor.
Hold under the knee joint, not on the kneecap.
Gently pull the knee towards the chest without forcing the range of motion.
commonMistakes: Pulling on the kneecap instead of under the knee joint.
Allowing the lower back to excessively round.
Forcing the knee too close to the chest, causing discomfort.

name: One Leg Barbell Squat
instructions: Start by standing about 2 to 3 feet in front of a flat bench with your back facing the bench. Have a barbell in front of you on the floor. Tip: Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.
Bend the knees and use a pronated grip with your hands being wider than shoulder width apart from each other to lift the barbell up until you can rest it on your chest.

Then lift the barbell over your head and rest it on the base of your neck. Move one foot back so that your toe is resting on the flat bench. Your other foot should be stationary in front of you. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. Tip: Make sure your back is straight and chest is out while performing this exercise.
As you inhale, slowly lower your leg until your thigh is parallel to the floor. At this point, your knee should be over your toes. Your chest should be directly above the middle of your thigh.
Leading with the chest and hips and contracting the quadriceps, elevate your leg back to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch legs and repeat the movement.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: High axial load and balance requirements may exacerbate conditions such as herniated discs or sciatica.
contraindicationDetails.knee_joint_issues: The exercise places significant stress on the knee joint, which can aggravate arthritis or tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.ankle_instability: Single-leg stance increases the risk of ankle sprains or strains, especially in individuals with previous injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: The exercise's intensity and balance demands may pose risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The balance and load distribution challenges are not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Individuals recovering from lower limb or spinal surgeries should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The single-leg nature of the exercise can be unsafe for those with compromised balance or neurological conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform a Bulgarian split squat using dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce the load and improve balance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance further.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a Smith machine to provide more stability and reduce the load on the spine.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform a partial range of motion or use resistance bands for support to decrease knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a safety squat bar to reduce shoulder strain or perform the exercise without a barbell.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely positioned on the upper back and not the neck.
Use a spotter or safety bars in a squat rack to prevent falls.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Ensure the front knee does not extend past the toes.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Descend slowly and with control to prevent loss of balance.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to collapse inward.
Rounding the back or leaning too far forward.
Using too much weight, compromising form and balance.
Not maintaining a stable foot position on the bench.

name: Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
instructions: Place one kettlebell between your feet. Clean the kettlebell by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebell towards your shoulders.
Release the kettlebell as it comes up, and let it flip so that the ball of the kettlebell lands in the palms of your hands.
Release the kettlebell out in front of you and catch the handle with both hands. Lower the kettlebell to the starting position and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: The explosive nature and spinal loading can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: The dynamic movement may aggravate arthritis or tendinitis, particularly in the shoulders and wrists.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: The high-intensity nature may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The exercise involves rapid movements and balance challenges, which may not be safe during pregnancy.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Individuals recovering from surgeries, especially involving the spine, shoulders, or hips, should avoid this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Recent sprains or strains, particularly in the lower back or shoulders, can be aggravated by this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.neurological_conditions: Conditions affecting balance or coordination, such as neuropathy, may increase the risk of injury.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard kettlebell clean without the open palm release to reduce complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebell or perform the exercise with a single arm for added challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter kettlebell and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the release and catch phase, and perform a controlled clean to shoulder height.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate space around you to safely release and catch the kettlebell.
Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints for explosive movements.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to protect your lower back.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips explosively.
Keep the kettlebell close to your body during the clean phase.
Catch the kettlebell softly with your palms to absorb the impact.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift, increasing the risk of spinal injury.
Using the arms to lift instead of driving through the hips.
Failing to engage the core, leading to instability and potential injury.
Poor timing in the release and catch phase, increasing the risk of dropping the kettlebell.

name: Otis-Up
instructions: Secure your feet and lay back on the floor. Your knees should be bent. Hold a weight with both hands to your chest. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by flexing the hips and spine to raise your torso up from the ground.
As you move up, press the weight up so that it is above your head at the top of the movement.
Return the weight to your chest as you reverse the sit-up motion, ensuring not to go all the way down to the floor.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the flexion and load on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with hip or knee arthritis may experience discomfort due to the bent knee position and should modify or avoid.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid holding their breath and may need to avoid weighted exercises.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid supine positions and exercises that increase intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent abdominal or spinal surgery patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

osteoporosis.details: Those with osteoporosis should avoid spinal flexion exercises to prevent vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a weight or reduce the range of motion by only lifting the shoulders off the ground.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a partial crunch without weight, focusing on engaging the core without full spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Place a pillow or pad under the knees to reduce pressure and discomfort.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking or using momentum to lift the torso.
Maintain control throughout the movement, especially when lowering back down.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Keep the neck neutral and avoid pulling on the head.
Press the weight directly upward, aligning it with the shoulders at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of core strength to lift the torso.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Holding the breath during the exercise.

name: Overhead Cable Curl
instructions: To begin, set a weight that is comfortable on each side of the pulley machine. Note: Make sure that the amount of weight selected is the same on each side.
Now adjust the height of the pulleys on each side and make sure that they are positioned at a height higher than that of your shoulders.

Stand in the middle of both sides and use an underhand grip (palms facing towards the ceiling) to grab each handle. Your arms should be fully extended and parallel to the floor with your feet positioned shoulder width apart from each other. Your body should be evenly aligned the handles. This is the starting position.
While exhaling, slowly squeeze the biceps on each side until your forearms and biceps touch.
While inhaling, move your forearms back to the starting position. Note: Your entire body is stationary during this exercise except for the forearms.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions prescribed in your program.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position may exacerbate symptoms due to compression of the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion can aggravate tendinitis, especially if performed with improper form.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the handles can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: The isometric contraction and overhead position can elevate blood pressure significantly.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise can place undue stress on the shoulder joint, potentially worsening the injury.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band to reduce load and allow for more control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a single arm to increase the challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a standard cable curl with the pulley set at a lower position to avoid shoulder elevation.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on slow, controlled movements to minimize joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight is evenly distributed on both sides to prevent muscle imbalances.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weight, as this can lead to injury.
formCues: Keep your elbows stationary and close to your body throughout the movement.
Engage your core to maintain a stable position.
Focus on a slow, controlled motion, especially during the eccentric phase.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and potential injury.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing bicep engagement.
Leaning back or using body momentum to lift the weight.

name: Overhead Lat
instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you. Raise one arm straight up, and flex the elbow, attempting to touch your hand to your back. Your parner should hold your tricep and wrist. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to pull your upper arm to your side as your partner prevents you from doing actually doing so.
After 10-20 seconds, relax the arm and allow your partner to further stretch the lat by applying gentle pressure to the tricep. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead positioning and partner-applied pressure.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Overhead stretching and resistance can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Isometric contraction against resistance may worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Sitting posture and overhead arm position can increase cervical spine strain.
contraindicationDetails.thoracic outlet syndrome: Overhead arm position may compress neurovascular structures.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Healing tissues may be compromised by stretching and resistance.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without partner resistance, focusing on gentle active stretching.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the isometric hold to 30 seconds and apply more resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a gentle doorway lat stretch instead, avoiding overhead positions.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise lying supine with a towel under the lumbar spine for support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the partner applies gentle and controlled pressure to avoid overstretching.
Avoid this exercise if experiencing acute shoulder or neck pain.
Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the shoulder joint.
formCues: Sit with a tall spine and engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your head aligned with your spine, avoiding forward head posture.
Communicate with your partner to ensure pressure is comfortable and controlled.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round or slouch during the exercise.
Applying excessive force or pressure, leading to overstretching.
Neglecting to warm up properly before performing the exercise.

name: Overhead Slam
instructions: Hold a medine ball with both hands and stand with your feet at shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the countermovement by raising the ball above your head and fully extending your body.
Reverse the motion, slamming the ball into the ground directly in front of you as hard as you can.
Receive the ball with both hands on the bounce and repeat the movement.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: The explosive nature and spinal flexion involved in the overhead slam can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: The overhead motion may aggravate impingement symptoms due to the repetitive overhead movement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator_cuff_tendinitis: The dynamic nature of the exercise can strain the rotator cuff, especially if there is pre-existing inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The explosive movement can cause a temporary spike in blood pressure, which may be risky for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The rapid movement and potential for loss of balance make this exercise unsuitable during pregnancy, particularly in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High-impact activities can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter medicine ball or use a slower, controlled motion to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball to engage more stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a seated medicine ball slam to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full overhead extension or perform a chest-level slam instead.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Use a non-slip surface to prevent slipping during the exercise.
Start with a lighter ball to master the form before progressing to heavier weights.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement to protect your spine.
Keep your elbows slightly bent to reduce stress on the shoulder joints.
Follow through with your hips and knees to generate power from your lower body.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively during the slam.
Failing to engage the core, leading to potential lower back strain.
Using only the arms instead of incorporating the whole body.

name: Overhead Squat
instructions: Start out by having a barbell in front of you on the floor. Your feet should be wider than shoulder width apart from each other.

Bend the knees and use a pronated grip (palms facing you) to grab the barbell. Your hands should be at a wider than shoulder width apart from each other before lifting. Once you are positioned, lift the barbell up until you can rest it on your chest.

Move the barbell over and slightly behind your head and make sure your arms are fully extended. Keep your head up at all times and also maintain a straight back. Retract your shoulder blades. This is your starting position.

Slowly lower the weight by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground while inhaling. Tip: Keep your back straight while performing this exercise to avoid any injuries and your arms should remain extended and over your head at all times.
Now use your feet and legs to help bring the weight back up to the starting position while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The overhead squat places significant axial load on the spine, which can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_issues.explanation: The overhead position requires significant shoulder mobility and stability, which can aggravate conditions like impingement, tendinitis, or rotator cuff injuries.

knee_issues.explanation: The deep squat position can increase stress on the knee joint, potentially worsening conditions like arthritis or patellar tendinitis.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The exercise can elevate blood pressure and heart rate significantly, posing risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: The balance and stability demands, along with potential for increased intra-abdominal pressure, make this exercise unsuitable during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, require avoiding high-load exercises like the overhead squat.

osteoporosis.explanation: The axial loading and potential for falls make this exercise risky for individuals with low bone density.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before attempting the exercise.
Use a spotter or safety bars in a squat rack for added safety.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive forward lean.
Ensure the knees track over the toes during the squat.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to collapse inward (valgus collapse).
Rounding the back or losing lumbar stability.
Failing to keep the barbell aligned over the mid-foot.

modifications.easier: Perform a goblet squat with a dumbbell held at chest level to reduce shoulder and spinal load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise on a single leg to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and perform the exercise with a resistance band overhead instead of a barbell.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat to reduce knee joint stress, or perform a box squat variation.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a front squat or use a safety squat bar to reduce shoulder involvement.

name: Overhead Stretch
instructions: Standing straight up, lace your fingers together and open your palms to the ceiling. Keep your shoulders down as you extend your arms up.
To create a full torso stretch, pull your tailbone down and stabilize your torso as you do this. Stretch the muscles on both the front and the back of the torso.

herniated disc.explanation: The overhead stretch can exacerbate symptoms by increasing spinal extension and pressure on the discs.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Raising arms overhead may compress the shoulder joint, aggravating impingement symptoms.

hypertension.explanation: Overhead movements can cause a transient increase in blood pressure; monitor closely.

osteoporosis.explanation: Excessive spinal extension can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch seated to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Add a side bend to increase the stretch intensity on the obliques and intercostals.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with a slight forward lean to reduce spinal extension.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep arms slightly bent and lower to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid hyperextending the spine to prevent lower back strain.
Keep movements slow and controlled to maintain balance and prevent dizziness.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Keep shoulders relaxed and away from the ears.
Distribute weight evenly on both feet.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Shrugging shoulders towards the ears.
Holding breath during the stretch.

name: Overhead Triceps
instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your partner behind you. Raise one arm straight up, and flex the elbow, attempting to touch your hand to your back. Your parner should hold your elbow and wrist. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to extend the arm straight into the air as your partner prevents you from doing actually doing so.
After 10-20 seconds, relax the arm and allow your partner to further stretch the tricep by applying gentle pressure to the wrist. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead position and external resistance.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Potential for increased strain on the elbow joint during resisted extension.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Overhead position can place undue stress on the rotator cuff muscles and tendons.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Sitting position with overhead movement may increase cervical spine strain.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper limb surgery: Risk of disrupting healing tissues; clearance from a healthcare provider is necessary.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a partner's resistance, focusing on gentle active stretching.
modifications.harder: Use a resistance band for self-resisted triceps extension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a lying triceps extension with light dumbbells, keeping elbows close to the body.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Focus on isometric holds without partner resistance, ensuring no pain is felt.

safetyNotes: Ensure the partner applies gentle and controlled resistance.
Avoid any jerky or sudden movements during the stretch.
Communicate with your partner about any discomfort or pain.
formCues: Keep your back straight and core engaged while seated.
Align your elbow with your shoulder to avoid unnecessary strain.
Breathe steadily and maintain a relaxed posture throughout.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round or arch excessively.
Applying too much force during the resisted phase.
Neglecting to communicate with the partner about resistance level.

name: Pallof Press
instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower, and—if possible—position the cable to shoulder height. If not, a low pulley will suffice.
With your side to the cable, grab the handle with both hands and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm's length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable.
With your feet positioned hip-width apart and knees slightly bent, hold the cable to the middle of your chest. This will be your starting position.
Press the cable away from your chest, fully extending both arms. You core should be tight and engaged.
Hold the repetition for several seconds before returning to the starting position.
At the conclusion of the set, repeat facing the other direction.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or spinal stenosis should avoid this exercise or perform it under professional supervision due to the rotational forces involved.

shoulder_issues.details: Those with shoulder impingement or tendinitis should modify the exercise to avoid exacerbating symptoms.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify the exercise to reduce core pressure and avoid supine positions.

osteoporosis.details: Due to the risk of fractures, individuals with osteoporosis should perform this exercise with caution and potentially under supervision.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if recovering from recent trauma or acute injuries to the back or shoulders.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise seated on a stability ball to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Reduce the range of motion and keep elbows slightly bent to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached and set at the correct height.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid twisting the torso; focus on keeping the core engaged and stable.
formCues: Stand with feet hip-width apart and knees slightly bent.
Engage the core by pulling the navel towards the spine.
Press the handle straight out from the chest without rotating the torso.
commonMistakes: Allowing the torso to rotate during the press.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Setting the cable too high or too low, affecting the exercise's effectiveness.

name: Pallof Press With Rotation
instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower, and position the cable to shoulder height.

With your side to the cable, grab the handle with one hand and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm's length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable. Align outstretched arm with cable.
With your feet positioned hip-width apart, pull the cable into your chest and grab the handle with your other hand. Both hands should be on the handle at this time.
Facing forward, press the cable away from your chest. You core should be tight and engaged.
Keeping your hips straight, twist your torso away from the pulley until you get a full quarter rotation.
Maintain your rigid stance and straight arms. Return to the neutral position in a slow and controlled manner. Your arms should be extended in front of you.
With the side tension still engaging your core, bring your hands to your chest and immediately press outward to a fully extended position. This constitutes one rep.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to rotational forces that can exacerbate spinal issues.

joint_issues.details: Those with shoulder or hip impingement, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint strain.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises with significant rotational movements to prevent strain on the abdominal wall.

osteoporosis.details: Rotational movements can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the torso or upper body.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may affect the ability to maintain a stable stance during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without rotation, focusing on the static hold of the Pallof press to build core stability.
modifications.harder: Increase the cable resistance or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance and core engagement.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise seated on a bench to reduce spinal load while maintaining core engagement.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Reduce the range of motion and avoid full extension if shoulder discomfort occurs.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is set at shoulder height to prevent undue stress on the shoulders.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to protect the lower back.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the press.
Keep hips facing forward during the rotation.
Move in a slow and controlled manner to maximize muscle engagement and minimize injury risk.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to rotate with the torso.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Not maintaining a neutral spine.

name: Palms-Down Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.

Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells with a pronated grip (palms facing down) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

carpal_tunnel_syndrome.explanation: The exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to increased pressure on the median nerve.

elbow_tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive wrist flexion can aggravate the tendons around the elbow.

acute_forearm_strain.explanation: Performing this exercise can worsen the strain due to the load on the forearm muscles.

wrist_arthritis.explanation: The exercise may increase joint stress and inflammation in the wrist.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist curls with a neutral grip using a resistance band to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at a comfortable height.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent overloading the wrist and forearm.
formCues: Keep your forearms flat on the bench and stationary.
Focus on controlled wrist movement without jerking.
Exhale as you curl the wrist upwards and inhale as you lower it.
