commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled wrist movement.
Allowing the forearms to lift off the bench.
Holding the breath during the exercise.

name: Palms-Down Wrist Curl Over A Bench
instructions: Start out by placing a barbell on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.
Use your arms to grab the barbell with a pronated grip (palms down) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: High severity. This exercise can exacerbate inflammation and pain in the tendons of the wrist.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate severity. The exercise may increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis in the wrist: Moderate severity. Can cause increased pain and inflammation in the wrist joints.
contraindicationDetails.recent wrist fracture: High severity. Avoid until fully healed and cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Risk of fracture due to bone fragility, especially if using heavy weights.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load and strain on the wrists.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise with one hand at a time for increased difficulty.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a wrist brace or support to stabilize the joint and reduce strain during the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at a comfortable height to avoid unnecessary strain.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent wrist strain or injury.
Maintain a neutral wrist position at the bottom of the movement to avoid hyperextension.
formCues: Keep your forearms flat on the bench and stationary throughout the movement.
Focus on a controlled motion, especially during the lowering phase.
Engage your core to maintain stability and prevent unnecessary movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled wrist flexion.
Allowing the wrists to hyperextend at the bottom of the movement.
Lifting the forearms off the bench during the exercise.

name: Palms-Up Barbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
instructions: Start out by placing a barbell on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.
Use your arms to grab the barbell with a supinated grip (palms up) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: High stress on the wrist joint may exacerbate inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The position and movement can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis in the wrist: The exercise may increase joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.recent wrist fracture: The exercise can impede healing and increase the risk of re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Increased risk of fractures due to bone fragility.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load on the wrists.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise with one arm at a time for increased intensity.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist curls with a resistance band to reduce joint stress and allow for more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure to prevent slipping.
Avoid using excessive weight to reduce the risk of wrist strain.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain in the wrists or forearms.
formCues: Keep forearms flat and stable on the bench throughout the movement.
Focus on a slow and controlled motion, especially during the lowering phase.
Exhale as you curl the wrists upwards and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled wrist movement.
Allowing the forearms to lift off the bench, reducing isolation of the wrist flexors.
Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.

name: Palms-Up Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on one side of a flat bench.
Kneel down on both of your knees so that your body is facing the flat bench.
Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells with a supinated grip (palms up) and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against the flat bench. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.
Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling. Make sure to inhale during this part of the exercise.
Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The exercise involves wrist flexion which can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the median nerve.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: Repetitive wrist flexion can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow, particularly in the flexor tendons.

acute forearm strain.explanation: Performing this exercise can worsen the strain due to the direct load on the forearm muscles.

wrist arthritis.explanation: The movement may cause discomfort or pain due to joint inflammation, especially if performed with heavy weights.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with one dumbbell at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower eccentric phase to increase difficulty.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist curls with a resistance band to reduce joint stress and allow for a more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the wrist and forearm.
Ensure the bench is stable to prevent slipping or imbalance during the exercise.
formCues: Keep your forearms stationary on the bench.
Move only your wrists during the exercise.
Exhale as you curl your wrists upwards, inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Allowing the forearms to lift off the bench.
Holding the breath during the movement.

name: Parallel Bar Dip
instructions: Stand between a set of parallel bars. Place a hand on each bar, and then take a small jump to help you get into the starting position with your arms locked out.
Begin by flexing the elbow, lowering your body until your arms break 90 degrees. Avoid swinging, and maintain good posture throughout the descent.
Reverse the motion by extending the elbow, pushing yourself back up into the starting position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The downward motion of the dip can exacerbate shoulder impingement by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: This exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive elbow extension and flexion can aggravate tendinitis, particularly lateral epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or elbow surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to stress, and this exercise can impede healing.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The position of the wrists during dips can exacerbate pain, especially if the wrists are not kept neutral.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The pressure on the wrists can increase symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.

modifications.easier: Assisted dips using a dip machine or resistance bands to reduce body weight load.
modifications.harder: Weighted dips by adding a dip belt with weights to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform bench dips with feet on the ground to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a dip machine with adjustable resistance to control the load on the elbows.

safetyNotes: Ensure the shoulders are not elevated towards the ears to prevent impingement.
Avoid excessive forward lean to reduce stress on the shoulders.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back throughout the movement.
Lower yourself in a controlled manner to at least 90 degrees at the elbows.
Engage the core to stabilize the body and prevent swinging.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to shrug during the exercise.
Bouncing at the bottom of the movement instead of controlling the descent.
Leaning too far forward, which shifts the focus away from the triceps.

name: Pelvic Tilt Into Bridge
instructions: Lie down with your feet on the floor, heels directly under your knees.
Lift only your tailbone to the ceiling to stretch your lower back. (Don't lift the entire spine yet.) Pull in your stomach.
To go into a bridge, lift the entire spine except the neck.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity; the exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to spinal flexion and extension.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Moderate severity; avoid excessive lumbar extension, which can compress the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity; lumbar extension can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity; may irritate the sciatic nerve if not performed with proper alignment.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity; avoid excessive spinal flexion to reduce fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: High severity; consult a healthcare provider before attempting.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity; avoid supine position after the first trimester and consult with a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform only the pelvic tilt portion without lifting into a full bridge.
modifications.harder: Perform the bridge with one leg extended to increase core and glute engagement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on the pelvic tilt only, keeping the spine neutral.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Place a cushion under the feet to reduce knee strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid hyperextending the lower back during the bridge phase.
Ensure even weight distribution through the feet and shoulders.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the pelvis.
Lift the spine one vertebra at a time, starting from the tailbone.
Keep the knees aligned with the hips and shoulders.
commonMistakes: Lifting the entire spine too quickly without segmental control.
Allowing the knees to splay outward or inward.
Hyperextending the lumbar spine at the top of the bridge.

name: Peroneals-SMR
instructions: Lay on your side, supporting your weight on your forearm and on a foam roller placed on the outside of your lower leg. Your upper leg can either be on top of your lower leg, or you can cross it in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Raise your hips off of the ground and begin to roll from below the knee to above the ankle on the side of your leg, pausing at points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other leg.

contraindicationDetails.deep vein thrombosis: High risk due to potential dislodging of a clot. Avoid this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.severe varicose veins: Moderate risk of exacerbating symptoms. Consider alternative exercises.
contraindicationDetails.acute muscle strains: High risk of further injury. Avoid until healed.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: High risk of disrupting healing. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.severe peripheral neuropathy: Moderate risk due to impaired sensation. Proceed with caution and under supervision.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Low risk if performed with controlled pressure. Monitor for discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Moderate risk due to potential instability. Ensure a stable environment or assistance.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with both legs on the ground to reduce pressure.
modifications.harder: Increase the pressure by stacking the legs and applying more body weight.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a softer foam roller or perform seated calf stretches if experiencing back pain or knee discomfort.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly over joints or bones.
Do not apply excessive pressure that causes pain.
Ensure the foam roller is placed correctly to target the peroneals.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability.
Roll slowly and pause at tender spots for 10-30 seconds.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive arching or rounding.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly without pausing at tension points.
Applying too much pressure causing pain.
Allowing the hips to sag, losing core engagement.

name: Peroneals Stretch
instructions: In a seated position, loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot. This will be your starting position.

With the leg extended and the heel off of the ground, pull on the belt so that the foot is inverted, with the inside of the foot being pulled towards you. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.acute ankle sprain: High severity. Stretching the peroneals can exacerbate pain and delay healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the ankle: Moderate severity. Inversion of the foot may cause discomfort and should be modified or avoided.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: High severity. Consult with a healthcare provider before performing this stretch to avoid compromising surgical outcomes.
contraindicationDetails.peripheral neuropathy: Moderate severity. Reduced sensation may lead to overstretching and potential injury.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the foot resting on the ground to reduce the intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds or add a slight dorsiflexion to intensify the stretch.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with mild ankle discomfort, perform the stretch with a towel instead of a band to allow for more controlled tension.

safetyNotes: Avoid overstretching to prevent injury to the ankle ligaments.
Ensure the band or belt is secure to prevent slipping.
formCues: Keep the leg fully extended without locking the knee.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid slouching.
Gently pull the band to invert the foot without forcing the movement.
commonMistakes: Using excessive force to pull the foot, risking ligament strain.
Allowing the knee to bend, reducing the effectiveness of the stretch.
Slouching or rounding the back, which can lead to poor posture and discomfort.

name: Physioball Hip Bridge
instructions: Lay on a ball so that your upper back is on the ball with your hips unsupported. Both feet should be flat on the floor, hip width apart or wider. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending the hips using your glutes and hamstrings, raising your hips upward as you bridge.
Pause at the top of the motion and return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The exercise involves spinal extension which can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high - The hip bridge position may increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: moderate - Spinal extension may worsen symptoms; modifications needed.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise can increase lumbar spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.knee arthritis: moderate - Pressure on knees may require modification.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: high - The instability of the ball can pose a fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - Exercise may be uncomfortable in later stages; modifications advised.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high - Core engagement may interfere with healing.

modifications.easier: Perform the bridge on the floor without the ball to reduce instability.
modifications.harder: Place one foot on the ball and perform a single-leg bridge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform on the floor with a pillow under the lower back for support.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep feet closer to the body to reduce knee strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Ensure the upper back is well supported on the ball to avoid shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the ball is properly inflated to maintain stability.
Perform the exercise in a clear area to prevent falls.
Start with a smaller range of motion if new to the exercise.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Press through your heels as you lift your hips.
Keep your neck relaxed and aligned with your spine.
Pause and squeeze the glutes at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag at the top of the movement.
Overextending the lower back, leading to hyperlordosis.
Using momentum rather than controlled muscle engagement.
Placing feet too far from the body, increasing knee strain.

name: Pin Presses
instructions: Pin presses remove the eccentric phase of the bench press, developing starting strength. They also allow you to train a desired range of motion.

The bench should be set up in a power rack. Set the pins to the desired point in your range of motion, whether it just be lockout or an inch off of your chest. The bar should be moved to the pins and prepared for lifting.

Begin by lying on the bench, with the bar directly above the contact point during your regular bench. Tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement.
You can take a standard bench grip, or shoulder width to focus on the triceps. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart.
Drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.
Return the bar to the pins, pausing before beginning the next repetition.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: High: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, potentially worsening the tear.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate: The pressing motion can aggravate the tendons in the elbow, increasing inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Moderate: The need to stabilize the bar can place stress on the wrists, exacerbating pain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Moderate: The Valsalva maneuver often used during heavy lifts can increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Moderate: The arching of the back can place stress on the spine, particularly if there is a history of disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High: The exercise should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare professional due to the stress on the shoulder joint.

modifications.easier: Perform floor presses to limit range of motion and reduce load on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Add resistance bands or chains to increase the load at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip bar to reduce shoulder rotation and stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure a flat back position on the bench with minimal arching to reduce spinal stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the pins are set at the correct height to prevent excessive range of motion.
Use a spotter or safety bars to prevent accidents in case of muscle failure.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the shoulder and elbow joints.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked in to protect the shoulder joint.
Maintain a tight grip on the bar to stabilize the wrists.
Drive through the feet to engage the entire kinetic chain.
commonMistakes: Setting pins too low, leading to excessive range of motion and shoulder strain.
Allowing elbows to flare out, increasing shoulder stress.
Using too much weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.

name: Piriformis-SMR
instructions: Sit with your buttocks on top of a foam roll. Bend your knees, and then cross one leg so that the ankle is over the knee. This will be your starting position.

Shift your weight to the side of the crossed leg, rolling over the buttocks until you feel tension in your upper glute. You may assist the stretch by using one hand to pull the bent knee towards your chest. Hold this position for 10-30 seconds, and then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity. The pressure from the foam roller may exacerbate sciatic nerve pain.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Moderate severity. Lumbar flexion and pressure may increase disc herniation symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: High severity. Direct pressure on the hip area can aggravate bursitis.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: High severity. Healing tissues may be disrupted by pressure and movement.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Hormonal changes can affect joint stability, and certain positions may be uncomfortable.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated on a chair and use a tennis ball for gentler pressure.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the hold up to 60 seconds and add a gentle rocking motion.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a softer foam roller and maintain a neutral spine without excessive flexion.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep the non-crossed leg more extended to reduce knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly on the spine.
Do not apply excessive pressure if discomfort increases.
Ensure the foam roller is stable and does not slip.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support the lower back.
Maintain a relaxed breathing pattern.
Shift weight gradually to find the tension point.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly over the muscle.
Holding breath during the stretch.
Allowing the foam roller to slip out from under the body.

name: Plank
instructions: Get into a prone position on the floor, supporting your weight on your toes and your forearms. Your arms are bent and directly below the shoulder.
Keep your body straight at all times, and hold this position as long as possible. To increase difficulty, an arm or leg can be raised.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The plank position can increase intra-abdominal pressure and stress on the lumbar spine, potentially exacerbating disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: moderate - Holding a plank may compress the spinal canal, aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The anterior shear force on the spine during a plank can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: moderate - Weight bearing on the shoulders can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: moderate - Supporting body weight on the forearms can stress the wrists.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - As pregnancy progresses, core exercises like planks may need modification to avoid excessive intra-abdominal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high - Engaging the core muscles intensely post-surgery can hinder healing.

modifications.easier: Knee plank: Perform the plank with knees on the ground to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Single-arm or single-leg plank: Lift one arm or leg to increase instability and challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Wall plank: Perform the plank standing against a wall to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Forearm plank with elbows wider apart to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use a push-up bar or perform on fists to keep wrists neutral.

safetyNotes: Ensure the spine remains neutral to avoid excessive lumbar lordosis or kyphosis.
Avoid holding the plank if you experience pain, especially in the lower back or shoulders.
formCues: Engage the core by pulling the navel towards the spine.
Keep the body in a straight line from head to heels.
Position elbows directly under shoulders.
Avoid letting hips sag or rise too high.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise, leading to poor spinal alignment.
Holding breath instead of breathing steadily.
Placing elbows too far forward, increasing shoulder strain.

recommendedReps.strength: Hold for 15-30 seconds with added resistance

name: Plate Pinch
instructions: Grab two wide-rimmed plates and put them together with the smooth sides facing outward
Use your fingers to grip the outside part of the plate and your thumb for the other side thus holding both plates together. This is the starting position.
Squeeze the plate with your fingers and thumb. Hold this position for as long as you can.
Repeat for the recommended amount of sets prescribed in your program.
Switch arms and repeat the movements.

contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: This exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to the sustained grip required, potentially increasing pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: Individuals with arthritis in the hands or wrists may experience increased pain and inflammation due to the gripping action.
contraindicationDetails.recent hand or wrist surgery: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by the stress placed on healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.neuropathy: Those with neuropathy may have impaired grip strength and sensation, increasing the risk of dropping the plates.

modifications.easier: Use lighter plates or a single plate to reduce the load on the fingers and thumb.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the plates or extend the duration of the hold.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a grip strength tool or a towel roll to reduce stress on the joints while still engaging the forearm muscles.

safetyNotes: Ensure the plates are securely gripped to avoid dropping them.
Avoid holding the plates if you experience numbness or tingling in your hands.
formCues: Keep your wrist neutral and avoid excessive flexion or extension.
Engage your core to maintain balance and stability while holding the plates.
commonMistakes: Using too heavy plates leading to poor form or dropping them.
Allowing the wrist to bend excessively, which can lead to strain.

recommendedReps.strength: Hold for 10-30 seconds with heavier plates

name: Plate Twist
instructions: Lie down on the floor or an exercise mat with your legs fully extended and your upper body upright. Grab the plate by its sides with both hands out in front of your abdominals with your arms slightly bent.

Slowly cross your legs near your ankles and lift them up off the ground. Your knees should also be bent slightly. Note: Move your upper body back slightly to help keep you balanced turning this exercise. This is the starting position.
Move the plate to the left side and touch the floor with it. Breathe out as you perform that movement.

Come back to the starting position as you breathe in and then repeat the movement but this time to the right side of the body. Tip: Use a slow controlled movement at all times. Jerking motions can injure the back.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the rotational stress on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or shoulder impingement should modify the exercise to reduce joint strain.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing exercises that increase intra-abdominal pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve lying supine or excessive twisting.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent abdominal or spinal surgery patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid high-impact or high-torque exercises to prevent fractures.

acute_injuries.details: Those with recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the back or core should avoid this exercise until fully healed.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without holding a weight plate, or keep the feet on the ground while twisting.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the plate or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated Russian twists with feet on the ground and a reduced range of motion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter weight or no weight and focus on controlled movements.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking motions to prevent back injury.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Do not hold your breath; practice controlled breathing.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Rotate your torso, not just your arms.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the back to round excessively.
Holding the breath during the exercise.

name: Platform Hamstring Slides
instructions: For this movement a wooden floor or similar is needed. Lay on your back with your legs extended. Place a gym towel or a light weight underneath your heel. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing the knee, keeping your other leg straight.
Continue bringing the heel closer to you, sliding it on the floor.
At full knee flexion, reverse the movement to return to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or sciatica should avoid this exercise due to the risk of aggravating the lower back.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should be cautious as the sliding motion can stress the knee joint.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, may find this position uncomfortable and should modify or avoid.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent knee or hip surgery patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are any recent sprains or strains in the lower body.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with both legs simultaneously to reduce the load on each leg.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise on a slicker surface to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Place a small cushion under the lower back for support.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the floor surface is not too slippery to prevent loss of control.
Avoid hyperextending the knee during the return phase.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the pelvis.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Slide the heel slowly to control the motion.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag during the movement.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Not maintaining a straight leg on the non-working side.

name: Plie Dumbbell Squat
instructions: Hold a dumbbell at the base with both hands and stand straight up. Move your legs so that they are wider than shoulder width apart from each other with your knees slightly bent.
Your toes should be facing out. Note: Your arms should be stationary while performing the exercise. This is the starting position.
Slowly bend the knees and lower your legs until your thighs are parallel to the floor. Make sure to inhale as this is the eccentric part of the exercise.
Press mainly with the heel of the foot to bring the body back to the starting position while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The wide stance and knee flexion can exacerbate pain and discomfort in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the patellar tendon, which can aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hip impingement: The wide stance and external rotation of the hips may increase discomfort in those with hip impingement.
contraindicationDetails.severe balance disorders: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, which may be challenging for individuals with balance disorders.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires caution with weight-bearing exercises to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The axial loading and potential forward lean can exacerbate symptoms of spinal stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may increase lumbar spine stress, potentially aggravating sciatica symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a dumbbell or use a lighter weight to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the depth of the squat and ensure knees track over toes to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a more upright torso and engage the core to reduce lumbar spine stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before performing the exercise to prevent injury.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to maintain muscle tension and joint safety.
Keep the core engaged throughout the exercise to support the spine.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back to maintain an upright posture.
Ensure knees track over toes and do not collapse inward.
Press through the heels to engage the glutes and protect the knees.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Leaning too far forward, which can increase stress on the lower back.
Using momentum to rise instead of controlled muscle engagement.

name: Plyo Kettlebell Pushups
instructions: Place a kettlebell on the floor. Place yourself in a pushup position, on your toes with one hand on the ground and one hand holding the kettlebell, with your elbows extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by lowering yourself as low as you can, keeping your back straight.

Quickly and forcefully reverse direction, pushing yourself up to the other side of the kettlebell, switching hands as you do so. Continue the movement by descending and repeating the movement back and forth.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The explosive nature of the exercise can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to rapid shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The dynamic push and stabilization required can increase the risk of further injury to the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.wrist instability: The exercise places significant stress on the wrists, which can be problematic for those with instability or previous injuries.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to re-injury with high-impact activities.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists during the exercise can aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.chronic wrist pain: The load and impact on the wrists can worsen pain and underlying conditions.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The exercise requires core stability and can place undue stress on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High-impact movements can exacerbate spinal instability.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The explosive nature of the exercise can increase the risk of fractures.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic movement and need for coordination can pose a fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform regular push-ups with hands on the floor or elevated on a bench to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Add a weighted vest or perform the exercise with feet elevated to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform push-ups on an incline or against a wall to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or perform knuckle push-ups to keep wrists in a neutral position.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on core engagement and perform on a stable surface to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure kettlebells are stable and on a non-slip surface.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on shoulder and wrist mobility.
Avoid if you have any acute pain during the exercise.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Explode upwards with control, ensuring a smooth transition between hands.
Land softly to reduce impact on the wrists and shoulders.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag, leading to lower back strain.
Not fully engaging the core, resulting in poor stability.
Landing too hard, increasing risk of wrist or shoulder injury.

name: Plyo Push-up
instructions: Move into a prone position on the floor, supporting your weight on your hands and toes.
Your arms should be fully extended with the hands around shoulder width. Keep your body straight throughout the movement. This will be your starting position.
Descend by flexing at the elbow, lowering your chest towards the ground.
At the bottom, reverse the motion by pushing yourself up through elbow extension as quickly as possible. Attempt to push your upper body up until your hands leave the ground.
Return to the starting position and repeat the exercise.
For added difficulty, add claps into the movement while you are air borne.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The explosive nature of the plyo push-up can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to rapid shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The impact on the wrists during landing can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The dynamic push-off and landing can strain the rotator cuff, increasing injury risk.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists can worsen symptoms due to repetitive impact.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Maintaining a plank position under dynamic conditions can stress the lumbar spine.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The high-impact nature of the exercise may increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the explosive forces involved.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on an incline, such as a bench or step, to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Add a clap at the top of the movement or wear a weighted vest.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a standard push-up or incline push-up to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars to keep wrists in a neutral position.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Perform on knees to reduce lumbar stress and focus on core engagement.

safetyNotes: Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare the joints and muscles for explosive movements.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Land softly to minimize impact on the wrists and shoulders.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Explode off the ground using chest and triceps, aiming for a controlled lift.
Absorb the landing softly by bending elbows slightly.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag, leading to lower back strain.
Flaring elbows out excessively, increasing shoulder stress.
Landing with stiff arms, which can increase joint impact.

name: Posterior Tibialis Stretch
instructions: In a seated position, loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot. This will be your starting position.

With the leg extended and the heel off of the ground, pull on the belt so that the foot is everted, with the outside of the foot being pulled towards you. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.acute ankle sprain: High severity. Stretching may exacerbate inflammation and delay healing of the ligaments.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the ankle: Moderate severity. Eversion may cause pain and discomfort in the joint.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower leg surgery: High severity. Post-surgical protocols often restrict range of motion exercises to prevent stress on healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.peripheral neuropathy: Moderate severity. Altered sensation may lead to overstretching or improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the foot resting on the ground to reduce the intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds or add slight dorsiflexion to increase the stretch.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with mild ankle discomfort, perform the stretch with a towel instead of a band to allow for more controlled tension.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling too hard on the band to prevent overstretching.
Ensure the band is securely looped to prevent slipping.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
formCues: Keep the leg fully extended and relaxed.
Focus on a gentle pull to achieve a mild stretch.
Maintain an upright seated posture to avoid slumping.
commonMistakes: Using excessive force, leading to overstretching.
Allowing the knee to bend, reducing the effectiveness of the stretch.
Failing to maintain a neutral spine position.

name: Power Clean
instructions: Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder width apart and toes pointing out slightly.
Squat down and grasp bar with a closed, pronated grip. Your hands should be slightly wider than shoulder width apart outside knees with elbows fully extended.
Place the bar about 1 inch in front of your shins and over the balls of your feet.
Your back should be flat or slightly arched, your chest held up and out and your shoulder blades should be retracted.
Keep your head in a neutral position (in line with vertebral column and not tilted or rotated) with your eyes focused straight ahead. Inhale during this phase.

Lift the bar from the floor by forcefully extending the hips and the knees as you exhale. Tip: The upper torso should maintain the same angle. Do not bend at the waist yet and do not let the hips rise before the shoulders (this would have the effect of pushing the glutes in the air and stretching the hamstrings.
Keep elbows fully extended with the head in a neutral position and the shoulders over the bar.
As the bar raises keep it as close to the shins as possible.
As the bar passes the knees, thrust your hips forward and slightly bend the knees to avoid locking them. Tip: At this point your thighs should be against the bar.
Keep the back flat or slightly arched, elbows fully extended and your head neutral. Tip: You will hold your breath until the next phase.
Inhale and then forcefully and quickly extend your hips and knees and stand on your toes.

Keep the bar as close to your body as possible. Tip: Your back should be flat with the elbows pointed out to the sides and your head in a neutral position. Also, keep your shoulders over the bar and arms straight as long as possible.
When your lower body joints are fully extended, shrug the shoulders upward rapidly without letting the elbows flex yet. Exhale during this portion of the movement.
As the shoulders reach their highest elevation flex your elbows to begin pulling your body under the bar.

Continue to pull the arms as high and as long as possible. Tip: Due to the explosive nature of this phase, your torso will be erect or with an arched back, your head will be tilted back slightly and your feet may lose contact with the floor.
After the lower body has fully extended and the bar reaches near maximal height, pull your body under the bar and rotate the arms around and under the bar.
Simultaneously, flex the hips and knees into a quarter squat position.
Once the arms are under the bar, inhale and then lift your elbows to position the upper arms parallel to the floor. Rack the bar across the front of your collar bones and front shoulder muscles.
Catch the bar with an erect and tight torso, a neutral head position and flat feet. Exhale during this movement.
Stand up by extending the hips and knees to a fully erect position.
Lower the bar by gradually reducing the muscular tension of the arms to allow a controlled descent of the bar to the thighs. Inhale during this movement.
Simultaneously flex the hips and knees to cushion the impact of the bar on the thighs.
Squat down with the elbows fully extended until the bar touches the floor.
Start over at Phase 1 and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to high spinal loading and risk of exacerbating injuries.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis, shoulder impingement, or knee tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity exercises like the power clean.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises with high impact and risk of abdominal trauma.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from recent surgeries, particularly in the spine, shoulders, or knees, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis or diabetes complications should modify the exercise to reduce risk of fractures or hypoglycemic events.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid performing the power clean with any recent sprains, strains, or trauma to prevent further injury.

neurological_conditions.details: Those with balance disorders or neuropathy should perform this exercise with caution and possibly under supervision.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang power clean, starting from a standing position with the bar at thigh level to reduce complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the load or perform a full clean, which includes a deeper squat catch position.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat catch and ensure proper knee alignment over the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid the shrugging motion and focus on a controlled pull with lighter weights.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate warm-up before performing power cleans to prepare muscles and joints.
Use a spotter or perform in a controlled environment to manage risk of dropping the bar.
Avoid using excessive weights that compromise form.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding the back.
Drive through the heels and extend the hips explosively.
commonMistakes: Rising the hips before the shoulders, leading to a rounded back.
Pulling with the arms too early instead of driving with the legs.
Failing to fully extend the hips and knees before shrugging.

name: Power Clean from Blocks
instructions: With a barbell on boxes of the desired height, take a grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.

Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips.

In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight. At the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.

As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, pull yourself under the bar far enough that it can be racked onto the shoulders, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed.

Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position, and complete the repetition by returning the weight to the boxes.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high compressive and shear forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis, shoulder impingement, or tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity lifts.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance and intra-abdominal pressure concerns.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery on the spine, shoulders, or knees requires complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing any acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to prevent exacerbation.

neurological_conditions.details: Conditions affecting balance or coordination, such as neuropathy, may require significant modifications or alternative exercises.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang power clean, starting from a standing position with the barbell at thigh level, to reduce the range of motion and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the blocks to start from a lower position, increasing the range of motion and demand on the posterior chain.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright torso.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the catch phase to reduce knee flexion or perform a power clean from a higher block position.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Focus on the first pull only, avoiding the catch phase to minimize shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the blocks are stable and can support the weight of the barbell.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on dynamic stretches for the hamstrings, glutes, and shoulders.
Use appropriate footwear with a flat, stable sole to enhance balance and force transfer.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the lift to protect the spine.
Maintain a neutral spine with the chest up and shoulders slightly in front of the bar.
Drive through the heels and keep the bar close to the body during the pull.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift, increasing the risk of spinal injury.
Pulling with the arms too early, which can lead to inefficient lifting mechanics.
Failing to fully extend the hips, knees, and ankles during the second pull.

name: Power Jerk
instructions: Standing with the weight racked on the front of the shoulders, begin with the dip. With your feet directly under your hips, flex the knees without moving the hips backward. Go down only slightly, and reverse direction as powerfully as possible.
Drive through the heels create as much speed and force as possible, and be sure to move your head out of the way as the bar leaves the shoulders.

At this moment as the feet leave the floor, the feet must be placed into the receiving position as quickly as possible. In the brief moment the feet are not actively driving against the platform, the athletes effort to push the bar up will drive them down. The feet should be moved to a slightly wider stance, with the knees partially bent.
Receive the bar with the arms locked out overhead.
Return to a standing position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and explosive nature, which can exacerbate spinal issues.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee, hip, or shoulder arthritis, impingement, or tendinitis should avoid due to high joint stress and potential for aggravation.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid high-intensity exercises like the power jerk due to increased cardiovascular demand.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid due to balance challenges and abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical individuals, especially those recovering from shoulder, knee, or spinal surgery, should avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Those with osteoporosis should avoid due to the risk of fractures from high-impact landings.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to prevent further injury.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform a push press instead, which involves less explosive movement and a simpler technique.
modifications.harder: Increase the load or perform a split jerk for added complexity and balance challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter load and focus on strict form with a push press.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the dip and focus on a controlled push press.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural shoulder movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare joints and muscles for explosive movement.
Use a spotter or safety racks to prevent injury from failed lifts.
Avoid excessive arching of the back to protect the spine.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels to maximize power generation.
Move the head slightly back to clear the path for the barbell.
Lock out the arms overhead with elbows fully extended.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the dip.
Failing to fully extend the hips and knees during the drive.
Catching the bar with bent arms, risking shoulder injury.
Landing with feet too narrow or too wide, compromising balance.

name: Power Partials
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell on each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
The palms of the hands should be facing your torso. Your feet should be about shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight and the torso stationary, lift the weights out to your sides until they are about shoulder level height while exhaling.

Feel the contraction for a second and begin to lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling. Tip: Keep the palms facing down with the little finger slightly higher while lifting and lowering the weights as it will concentrate the stress on your shoulders mainly.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Lifting weights to shoulder height can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The repetitive lifting motion can irritate inflamed tendons, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights and lifting them laterally can strain the neck, especially if there is pre-existing cervical spine pathology.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture increases with overhead or lateral loading in individuals with compromised bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical protocols often restrict overhead or lateral movements to protect healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a partial range of motion, lifting only halfway up, or perform the exercise seated to reduce strain on the shoulders and neck.

safetyNotes: Avoid using momentum to lift the weights; control the movement at all times.
Do not lift the weights above shoulder height to minimize shoulder joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Lift the weights with your elbows slightly bent to reduce joint stress.
Exhale as you lift the weights and inhale as you lower them.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight, leading to poor form.
Shrugging the shoulders during the lift, which can lead to neck strain.
Leaning back or arching the lower back excessively.

name: Power Snatch
instructions: Begin with a loaded barbell on the floor. The bar should be close to or touching the shins, and a wide grip should be taken on the bar. The feet should be directly below the hips, with the feet turned out as needed. Lower the hips, with the chest up and the head looking forward. The shoulders should be just in front of the bar. This will be the starting position.
Begin the first pull by driving through the front of the heels, raising the bar from the ground. The back angle should stay the same until the bar passes the knees.

Transition into the second pull by extending through the hips knees and ankles, driving the bar up as quickly as possible. The bar should be close to the body. At peak extension, shrug the shoulders and allow the elbows to flex to the side.

As you move your feet into the receiving position, a slightly wider position, pull yourself below the bar as you elevate the bar overhead. The bar should be received in a partial squat. Continue raising the bar to the overhead position, receiving the bar locked out overhead.
Return to a standing position with the weight over head.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high compressive and shear forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with shoulder impingement, knee arthritis, or tendinitis should modify or avoid the exercise to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity lifts.

pregnancy.details: Due to balance and core stability challenges, pregnant individuals should avoid this exercise, especially in the second and third trimesters.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, require clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to prevent further injury.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form, requiring modifications or avoidance.

modifications.easier: Hang Power Snatch: Start from a standing position with the barbell at thigh level to reduce the range of motion and complexity.
modifications.harder: Full Snatch: Perform the exercise with a full squat catch to increase difficulty and flexibility demands.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on technique, or perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the catch or perform a power clean instead to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a high pull instead, avoiding the overhead catch to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the joints and muscles.
Use a spotter or coach when attempting heavy lifts.
Avoid excessive weight to maintain control and form.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift.
Drive through the heels and extend the hips explosively.
Lock out the elbows as you catch the bar overhead.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Pulling with the arms too early instead of using the hips.
Failing to fully extend the hips and knees.

name: Power Snatch from Blocks
instructions: Begin with a loaded barbell on boxes or stands of the desired height. A wide grip should be taken on the bar. The feet should be directly below the hips, with the feet turned out as needed. Lower the hips, with the chest up and the head looking forward. The shoulders should be just in front of the bar, with the elbows pointed out. This will be the starting position.
Begin the first pull by driving through the front of the heels, raising the bar from the boxes.

Transition into the second pull by extending through the hips knees and ankles, driving the bar up as quickly as possible. The bar should be close to the body. At peak extension, shrug the shoulders and allow the elbows to flex to the side.

As you move your feet into the receiving position, forcefully pull yourself below the bar as you elevate the bar overhead. The feet should move to just outside the hips, turned out as necessary. Receive the bar above a full squat and with the arms fully extended overhead.
Keeping the bar aligned over the front of the heels, your head and chest up, drive through heels of the feet to move to a standing position. Carefully return the weight to the boxes.

spinal_injuries.details: The explosive nature and overhead position can exacerbate spinal conditions such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

joint_issues.details: Shoulder, knee, or hip arthritis and tendinitis may be aggravated by the dynamic and loaded movements.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: The high-intensity nature of the exercise can increase blood pressure and heart rate significantly.

pregnancy.details: The exercise involves heavy lifting and dynamic movements, which are not recommended during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, especially involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, require avoidance of heavy lifting and explosive movements.

chronic_conditions.details: Conditions like osteoporosis may increase the risk of fractures with heavy loads and dynamic movements.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform a power snatch from the hang position, reducing the range of motion and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the full snatch from the floor for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use lighter weights and focus on technique, or substitute with a seated overhead press.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat or perform a power clean instead.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a narrower grip or substitute with a push press to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the boxes or stands are stable and at an appropriate height.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting the exercise.
Use a spotter if lifting near maximal loads.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift.
Maintain a neutral spine and engage your core.
Drive through your heels and fully extend your hips, knees, and ankles.
commonMistakes: Starting with the hips too high or too low.
Allowing the bar to drift away from the body.
Failing to fully extend the hips during the second pull.

name: Power Stairs
instructions: In the power stairs, implements are moved up a staircase. For training purposes, these can be performed with a tire or box.

Begin by taking the implement with both hands. Set your feet wide, with your head and chest up. Drive through the ground with your heels, extending your knees and hips to raise the weight from the ground.
As you lean back, attempt to swing the weight onto the stairs, which are usually around 16-18" high. You can use your legs to help push the weight onto the stair.
Repeat for 3-5 repetitions, and continue with a heavier weight, moving as fast as possible.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The power stairs exercise involves significant spinal loading and dynamic movement, which can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

joint_issues.explanation: Individuals with knee or hip arthritis may experience increased joint stress due to the explosive nature of the exercise.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The high-intensity nature of the exercise can elevate heart rate and blood pressure, posing risks for those with hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: The balance and core stability required, along with the risk of falls, make this exercise unsuitable during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries, especially involving the lower body or spine, may be compromised by the dynamic and heavy lifting components.

osteoporosis.explanation: The risk of fractures is increased due to the impact and load-bearing nature of the exercise.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma can be aggravated by the demands of this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform step-ups with a lower box or platform, using body weight or light dumbbells.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the implement or perform the exercise with a weighted vest.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Reduce the height of the stairs and ensure proper knee alignment over toes during the lift.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Avoid using the arms to swing the weight; focus on leg drive and core stability.

safetyNotes: Ensure the stairs or platform is stable and can support the weight.
Use a spotter if attempting heavier weights.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the joints and muscles for explosive movement.
formCues: Keep your chest up and back straight throughout the lift.
Drive through your heels and engage your core for stability.
Use your legs to assist in lifting the weight onto the stairs.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward.
Using too much arm swing instead of leg drive.

name: Preacher Curl
instructions: To perform this movement you will need a preacher bench and an E-Z bar. Grab the E-Z curl bar at the close inner handle (either have someone hand you the bar which is preferable or grab the bar from the front bar rest provided by most preacher benches). The palm of your hands should be facing forward and they should be slightly tilted inwards due to the shape of the bar.
With the upper arms positioned against the preacher bench pad and the chest against it, hold the E-Z Curl Bar at shoulder length. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the bar until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps is fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder height. Squeeze the biceps hard and hold this position for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during the curl can exacerbate this condition.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms may lead to discomfort or worsening of symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Gripping the bar can aggravate wrist conditions, especially if the grip is not neutral.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The pressure on the median nerve can increase with gripping and flexion activities.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Stabilization required by the shoulder can strain an already injured rotator cuff.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with one arm at a time for additional challenge.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip bar or dumbbells to reduce strain on the elbow.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort in the shoulder.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps for support or switch to dumbbells for a more neutral grip.

safetyNotes: Ensure the preacher bench is adjusted to the correct height to avoid overextension.
Avoid using excessive weight that could compromise form.
formCues: Keep your back straight and chest against the pad.
Avoid swinging the bar; focus on controlled movements.
Keep elbows stationary and close to the body.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Preacher Hammer Dumbbell Curl
instructions: Place the upper part of both arms on top of the preacher bench as you hold a dumbbell in each hand with the palms facing each other (neutral grip).
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbells until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder height.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis, leading to increased pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms during the exercise may cause discomfort or aggravate symptoms in individuals with shoulder impingement.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required by the shoulder may strain an already compromised rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The loading on the arms and potential for sudden movements could increase the risk of fractures in individuals with severe osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight and focus on a controlled range of motion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Avoid full extension at the bottom of the movement to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the preacher bench is adjusted to the correct height to support the upper arms fully.
Avoid using excessive weight that could compromise form and increase injury risk.
formCues: Keep your back straight and avoid leaning forward.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
Focus on a slow, controlled movement throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the wrists to flex or extend excessively, which can lead to strain.
Not fully extending the arms, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.

name: Press Sit-Up
instructions: To begin, lie down on a bench with a barbell resting on your chest. Position your legs so they are secure on the extension of the abdominal bench. This is the starting position.

While inhaling, tighten your abdominals and glutes. Simultaneously curl your torso as you do when performing a sit-up and press the barbell to an overhead position while exhaling. Tip: Use your arms to push the barbell out as you perform this exercise while still focusing on the abdominal muscles.
Lower your upper body back down to the starting position while bringing the barbell back down to your torso. Remember to breathe in while lowering the body.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The spinal flexion involved in the sit-up component can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The spinal movement and load can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Overhead pressing can aggravate shoulder impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Abdominal pressure and supine position can be unsafe, especially in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Increased intra-abdominal pressure can interfere with healing.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver and supine position can elevate blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the barbell, focusing on the sit-up motion only.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier barbell or perform the exercise on a decline bench.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a partial sit-up with a lighter barbell or use a stability ball for support.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Avoid the overhead press and focus on the sit-up component only.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is not too heavy to maintain control throughout the movement.
Avoid jerking motions to prevent strain on the spine and shoulders.
Maintain a neutral spine to reduce the risk of injury.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Press the barbell overhead in a controlled manner.
Exhale during the sit-up and press phase, and inhale while returning to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to complete the sit-up.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Failing to engage the core, leading to reliance on the arms.

name: Prone Manual Hamstring
instructions: You will need a partner for this exercise. Lay face down with your legs straight. Your assistant will place their hand on your heel.

To begin, flex the knee to curl your leg up. Your partner should provide resistance, starting light and increasing the pressure as the movement is completed. Communicate with your partner to monitor appropriate resistance levels.
Pause at the top, returning the leg to the starting position as your partner provides resistance going the other direction.

contraindicationDetails.knee injuries: The resistance applied during the exercise can exacerbate pain or instability in individuals with existing knee injuries.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Lying prone may increase lumbar extension, potentially aggravating lower back pain.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The prone position and knee flexion may irritate the sciatic nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee surgery: Post-surgical knees may not tolerate the resistance and flexion required in this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Assistance from a partner is required, and any sudden loss of balance could lead to injury.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with minimal resistance or use a resistance band instead of manual resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance provided by the partner or perform the exercise with ankle weights.

injury_friendly.back pain: Place a small pillow under the abdomen to reduce lumbar extension.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep flexion and reduce resistance.

safetyNotes: Ensure communication with your partner to adjust resistance appropriately.
Avoid excessive resistance that causes pain or discomfort.
Maintain a neutral spine position to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep the hips pressed into the ground.
Flex the knee smoothly without jerking.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
commonMistakes: Using too much resistance, leading to poor form.
Allowing the hips to lift off the ground.
Failing to communicate effectively with the partner.

name: Prowler Sprint
instructions: Place your sled on an appropriate surface, loaded to a suitable weight. The sled should provide enough resistance to require effort, but not so heavy that you are significantly slowed down.
You may use the upright or the low handles for this exercise. Place your hands on the handles with your arms extended, leaning into the implement.
With good posture, drive through the ground with alternating, short steps. Move as fast as you can for a short distance.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the forward-leaning posture and potential spinal loading.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis may experience discomfort due to the repetitive stress and should consider modifications.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before attempting high-intensity exercises like prowler sprints.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance and core stability concerns.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical patients, particularly those recovering from lower body or spinal surgeries, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

modifications.easier: Reduce the weight on the sled and focus on walking instead of sprinting to decrease intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the sled weight or perform the exercise on an incline to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter sled and maintain a more upright posture to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Focus on shorter strides and ensure proper footwear to minimize joint impact.

safetyNotes: Ensure the surface is suitable for sled use to prevent slipping.
Do not overload the sled to the point where form is compromised.
Warm up thoroughly before performing high-intensity sprints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged and maintain a neutral spine.
Drive through the balls of your feet and keep steps short and quick.
Lean slightly forward but avoid excessive bending at the waist.
commonMistakes: Overloading the sled, leading to compromised form.
Allowing the back to round, increasing spinal stress.
Taking overly long strides, which can reduce efficiency and increase injury risk.

name: Pull Through
instructions: Begin standing a few feet in front of a low pulley with a rope or handle attached. Face away from the machine, straddling the cable, with your feet set wide apart.

Begin the movement by reaching through your legs as far as possible, bending at the hips. Keep your knees slightly bent. Keeping your arms straight, extend through the hip to stand straight up. Avoid pulling upward through the shoulders; all of the motion should originate through the hips.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for exacerbating spinal compression and shear forces.
