joint_issues.details: Those with hip or knee arthritis may experience discomfort due to the hip hinge motion and should modify the range of motion or avoid if pain persists.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should be cautious due to balance changes and may need to modify or avoid this exercise.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower back, hips, or knees.

osteoporosis.details: Those with osteoporosis should be cautious with forward bending movements to avoid vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable machine or perform the exercise on one leg to increase difficulty and balance challenge.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a shorter range of motion and focus on engaging the core to support the spine.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Reduce the depth of the hip hinge and ensure knees remain slightly bent without excessive flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable path is clear and unobstructed to prevent tripping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Keep the chest lifted and shoulders back.
Drive through the heels and squeeze the glutes at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the hinge.
Using the arms to pull instead of driving through the hips.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward.

name: Pullups
instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing forward using the prescribed grip. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than your shoulder width. For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

Pull your torso up until the bar touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity; pulling motion can exacerbate impingement by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate severity; overhead pulling can strain inflamed tendons.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate severity; gripping and pulling can worsen tendon irritation.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate severity; gripping the bar can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: High severity; neck strain from improper form can worsen disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Moderate severity; spinal extension during pull-ups can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity; risk of fracture from falls or improper form.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Low severity; avoid breath-holding and ensure proper breathing to prevent blood pressure spikes.

modifications.easier: Assisted pull-ups using a resistance band or machine.
modifications.harder: Weighted pull-ups by adding a weight belt.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform neutral grip pull-ups to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a pull-up assist machine to decrease load on the spine.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a thicker bar or grips to reduce strain on the elbows.

safetyNotes: Ensure the pull-up bar is secure and can support your weight.
Avoid swinging or kipping to prevent unnecessary strain on joints.
Warm up properly to prepare the shoulder and back muscles.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
Keep shoulders down and back to avoid shrugging.
Maintain a slight arch in the lower back without excessive extension.
Exhale as you pull up, inhale as you lower down.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to complete the movement.
Not achieving full range of motion (chin not reaching above the bar).
Allowing shoulders to shrug up towards ears.
Bending wrists excessively, leading to strain.

name: Push-Up Wide
instructions: With your hands wide apart, support your body on your toes and hands in a plank position. Your elbows should be extended and your body straight. Do not allow your hips to sag. This will be your starting position.
To begin, allow the elbows to flex, lowering your chest to the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position by extending the elbows. Exhale as you perform this step.
After pausing at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Wide push-ups can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the increased abduction and external rotation of the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The extended wrist position can aggravate tendinitis, causing pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The wide hand position increases stress on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrist in a push-up position can compress the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Improper form or weak core muscles may lead to excessive lumbar lordosis, aggravating lower back pain.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive elbow extension and flexion can exacerbate tendinitis, especially with improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform the push-up on your knees instead of your toes to reduce the load on the upper body.
modifications.harder: Elevate your feet on a stable surface to increase the difficulty and engage the upper chest more.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the push-up with a narrower hand position to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or perform the exercise on fists to keep the wrists in a neutral position.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Engage the core more actively and reduce the range of motion to maintain a neutral spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Warm up adequately before performing push-ups to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
Lower your chest until it is just above the ground, then push back up.
Keep your elbows at a 45-degree angle to your body.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag or rise, disrupting the plank position.
Flaring the elbows out too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Failing to engage the core, leading to lower back arching.

name: Push-Ups - Close Triceps Position
instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands closer than shoulder width for a close hand position. Make sure that you are holding your torso up at arms' length.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your triceps and some of your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High stress on the shoulder joint can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive nature of push-ups can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Weight-bearing on the wrists can worsen pain or injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists during push-ups can increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise can strain the rotator cuff, worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Maintaining a neutral spine is crucial; those with injuries should avoid or modify.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: As pregnancy progresses, core stability changes, and modifications may be necessary.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Stress on healing tissues can impede recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform push-ups on knees to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Elevate feet on a bench or perform plyometric push-ups.

injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform push-ups on fists or with push-up bars to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit range of motion to avoid deep flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure wrists are aligned under shoulders to avoid undue stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the movement.
formCues: Engage core to keep hips from sagging.
Keep elbows close to the body to emphasize triceps engagement.
Lower body in a controlled manner.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise excessively.
Flaring elbows out too wide.
Not maintaining a straight line from head to heels.

name: Push-Ups With Feet Elevated
instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart from each other holding your torso up at arms length.
Place your toes on top of a flat bench. This will allow your body to be elevated. Note: The higher the elevation of the flat bench, the higher the resistance of the exercise is.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Elevated push-ups can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to increased stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The wrist extension required in this exercise can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The load on the shoulders can worsen rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists can increase symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The elevated position can increase lumbar stress, potentially worsening back pain.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The exercise can increase spinal load, potentially aggravating disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The position may increase lumbar spine stress, worsening this condition.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric holds and increased pressure during exertion can elevate blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform regular push-ups on the floor without elevation.
modifications.harder: Increase the elevation of the feet or add a weighted vest.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform push-ups with hands on an elevated surface to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or perform on fists to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Engage core fully and reduce elevation to minimize lumbar stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench or platform is stable to prevent slipping.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar stress.
Avoid locking elbows to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows at a 45-degree angle to the body.
Engage core to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Inhale on the way down, exhale on the way up.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise, disrupting spinal alignment.
Flaring elbows too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Performing the movement too quickly, reducing control.

name: Push-Ups With Feet On An Exercise Ball
instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart from each other holding your torso up at arms length.
Place your toes on top of an exercise ball. This will allow your body to be elevated.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The elevated position and load on the shoulders can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The dynamic stabilization required can strain the rotator cuff, worsening tears.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Weight-bearing on wrists can increase inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists may aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Instability from the ball can increase lumbar strain.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The exercise can increase intra-abdominal pressure and spinal load, risking further disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (third trimester): Balance challenges and abdominal pressure make this exercise risky.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The instability of the ball requires good balance, posing a fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform push-ups with feet on the floor instead of the ball to reduce instability.
modifications.harder: Elevate feet higher by using a bench instead of a ball or add a weight vest for increased resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform push-ups on an incline (hands on a bench) to decrease shoulder load.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or perform on fists to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Perform on knees with feet on the ball to reduce lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the exercise ball is properly inflated and stable.
Avoid arching the lower back excessively during the movement.
Maintain control throughout the exercise to prevent falls.
formCues: Engage core muscles to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Keep elbows at a 45-degree angle to the body during descent.
Inhale on the way down, exhale on the way up.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise excessively.
Flaring elbows out too wide, increasing shoulder stress.
Bouncing off the floor instead of controlled movement.

name: Push Press

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead pressing motion.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Potential for further injury due to the demand on shoulder stabilizers.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Overhead load can increase cervical spine compression and exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive pressing can aggravate tendinitis, especially in the triceps tendon.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The axial load and need for core stabilization can increase lumbar spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Heavy lifting can acutely raise blood pressure, posing risks for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of fractures due to axial loading, especially in the spine.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load and allow for a neutral grip.
modifications.harder: Perform a single-arm push press to increase core stabilization demands.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.lower_back_pain: Use a seated position with back support to minimize lumbar spine loading.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing the push press to prepare the shoulder joints and muscles.
Ensure proper barbell grip and wrist alignment to prevent strain.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back by engaging the core throughout the movement.
formCues: Start with feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent.
Hold the barbell at shoulder height with an overhand grip.
Initiate the movement by dipping slightly at the knees and driving through the legs.
Press the bar overhead while keeping the core engaged and avoiding excessive arching of the back.
Lock out the elbows at the top and control the descent back to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in excessive lumbar extension.
Pressing the barbell too far forward instead of directly overhead.

name: Push Press - Behind the Neck
instructions: Standing with the weight racked on the back of the shoulders, begin with the dip. With your feet directly under your hips, flex the knees without moving the hips backward. Go down only slightly, and reverse direction as powerfully as possible. Drive through the heels create as much speed and force as possible, moving the bar in a vertical path.
Using the momentum generated, finish pressing the weight overhead be extending through the arms.
Return to the starting position, using your legs to absorb the impact.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The behind-the-neck position can exacerbate symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, increasing the risk of aggravation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The barbell's position can strain the cervical spine, particularly if mobility is limited.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The pressing motion can aggravate tendinitis due to repetitive strain.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: The axial load and dynamic movement may exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise's load and potential for poor form can increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard push press with the barbell in front of the neck.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a single leg to challenge balance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use dumbbells and perform an overhead press to allow for a more natural shoulder path.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated dumbbell presses to reduce spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate shoulder and thoracic mobility before attempting.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the shoulder joints and surrounding muscles.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back during the press.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a neutral head position to avoid cervical strain.
Drive through the heels and use the legs to generate power.
Ensure the barbell moves in a straight vertical path.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the dip.
Hyperextending the lower back to compensate for lack of shoulder mobility.
Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Failing to control the barbell during the descent.

name: Push Up to Side Plank
instructions: Get into pushup position on the toes with your hands just outside of shoulder width.
Perform a pushup by allowing the elbows to flex. As you descend, keep your body straight.
Do one pushup and as you come up, shift your weight on the left side of the body, twist to the side while bringing the right arm up towards the ceiling in a side plank.
Lower the arm back to the floor for another pushup and then twist to the other side.
Repeat the series, alternating each side, for 10 or more reps.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead arm movement and weight-bearing on the shoulders.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Weight-bearing on the wrists can increase inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The dynamic movement and stabilization required can strain the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrists can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The plank position and twisting motion can strain the lower back if not performed with proper core engagement.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Conditions like herniated discs or stenosis may be aggravated by the twisting and weight-bearing components.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The exercise may be uncomfortable or unsafe due to balance and core stability changes.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The side plank component requires good balance and may pose a fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on the knees instead of the toes to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Add a push-up before transitioning to each side plank or use a resistance band around the wrists for added resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the push-up portion only, avoiding the side plank.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or perform on fists to keep wrists in a neutral position.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Focus on maintaining a strong core and avoid excessive twisting; consider limiting range of motion.

safetyNotes: Ensure a stable surface to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive arching or sagging of the lower back during the push-up and plank.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to reduce strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Align the body in a straight line from head to heels.
Rotate the body as a unit during the side plank transition.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag during the push-up or plank.
Failing to engage the core, leading to lower back strain.
Rotating the torso without moving the feet, causing imbalance.

name: Pushups
instructions: Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart while holding your torso up at arms length.
Next, lower yourself downward until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Now breathe out and press your upper body back up to the starting position while squeezing your chest.
After a brief pause at the top contracted position, you can begin to lower yourself downward again for as many repetitions as needed.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to shoulder joint stress during the lowering phase.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Pressure on the wrists can aggravate tendinitis, especially in the extended position.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise can strain the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Wrist extension during pushups can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Improper form can lead to lumbar hyperextension, worsening back pain.
contraindicationDetails.advanced pregnancy: Prone position and abdominal pressure are not recommended.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Pressure on the abdominal area can interfere with healing.

modifications.easier: Knee push-ups: Perform the exercise with knees on the ground to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Decline push-ups: Elevate feet to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Wall push-ups: Perform against a wall to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or fists to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Focus on core engagement and limit range of motion.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid letting the lower back sag or arch excessively.
Ensure wrists are aligned under shoulders to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.
Keep elbows at a 45-degree angle to the body.
Lower body in a controlled manner, avoiding rapid descent.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise excessively.
Flaring elbows out to the sides, increasing shoulder stress.
Failing to engage core, leading to lower back strain.

name: Pushups (Close and Wide Hand Positions)
instructions: Lie on the floor face down and body straight with your toes on the floor and the hands wider than shoulder width for a wide hand position and closer than shoulder width for a close hand position. Make sure you are holding your torso up at arms length.
Lower yourself until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.
Using your pectoral muscles, press your upper body back up to the starting position and squeeze your chest. Breathe out as you perform this step.
After a second pause at the contracted position, repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High shoulder abduction and internal rotation can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Weight-bearing on wrists can increase pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Stress on the shoulder joint can aggravate the injury.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrist can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Improper form can lead to increased lumbar strain.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive elbow extension can exacerbate symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform push-ups on knees to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Elevate feet on a bench or perform plyometric push-ups.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform wall push-ups to reduce shoulder load.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or fists to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Engage core and perform on knees to reduce lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a neutral spine to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the movement.
Warm up shoulders and wrists before starting.
formCues: Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
Engage your core throughout the movement.
Lower your body until your chest is just above the floor.
commonMistakes: Sagging hips due to weak core engagement.
Flaring elbows out excessively, increasing shoulder stress.
Incomplete range of motion, not lowering chest sufficiently.

name: Pyramid
instructions: Start off by rolling your torso forward onto the ball so your hips rest on top of the ball and become the highest point of your body.

Rest your hands and feet on the floor. Your arms and legs can be slightly bent or straight, depending on the size of the ball, your flexibility, and the length of your limbs. This also helps develop stabilizing strength in your torso and shoulders.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The exercise involves spinal extension and stabilization, which can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - Extension of the spine may increase compression on the spinal cord or nerves.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The position may increase anterior shear forces on the vertebrae.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The exercise may aggravate nerve compression; modifications are required.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - Risk of fracture due to spinal loading; exercise should be modified.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - The exercise requires significant balance and stability.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion or with the ball closer to the hips for more stability.
modifications.harder: Extend arms and legs fully and hold the position for longer durations to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Place the ball closer to the hips and reduce the range of motion to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep arms slightly bent and closer to the body to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the exercise ball is properly inflated and stable.
Avoid excessive spinal extension to prevent lower back strain.
Engage core muscles to maintain stability and protect the spine.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine; avoid excessive arching.
Distribute weight evenly between hands and feet.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to hyperextend excessively.
Failing to engage the core, leading to instability.
Placing the ball too far forward, reducing stability.

name: Quad Stretch
instructions: Lay on your side. Loop a belt, rope, or band around your top foot. Flex the knee and extend your hip, attempting to touch your glutes with your foot, and holding the belt with your hands. This will be your starting position.
With the belt being held over the shoulder or overhead, gently pull to increase the stretch in the quadriceps. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High knee flexion can exacerbate symptoms and increase joint stress.
contraindicationDetails.acute knee injuries: Flexing the knee may aggravate pain or delay healing.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: Stretching the hip can irritate the bursa and worsen inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip or knee surgery: Post-surgical protocols often limit range of motion and stress on the joint.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Lying on the side may increase discomfort due to spinal alignment issues.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Lying on the side, especially in later stages, can be uncomfortable and may affect circulation.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch standing, using a wall or chair for support to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Add a slight posterior pelvic tilt to deepen the stretch.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a towel under the knee for support and reduce the range of motion.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch standing or seated to reduce pressure on the spine.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive pulling to prevent muscle strain.
Ensure the band or belt is secure to prevent slipping.
Do not force the heel to the glutes if experiencing pain.
formCues: Keep the hips aligned and stacked when lying on the side.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the stretch.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back excessively.
Allowing the hips to rotate backward.
Using momentum instead of a controlled stretch.

name: Quadriceps-SMR
instructions: Lay facedown on the floor with your weight supported by your hands or forearms. Place a foam roll underneath one leg on the quadriceps, and keep the foot off of the ground. Make sure to relax the leg as much as possible. This will be your starting position.
Shifting as much weight onto the leg to be stretched as is tolerable, roll over the foam from above the knee to below the hip, holding points of tension for 10-30 seconds. Switch sides.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with spinal conditions such as herniated discs or sciatica may experience discomfort due to pressure on the spine and should modify or avoid this exercise.

joint_issues.explanation: Knee or hip arthritis may be aggravated by the pressure applied during the rolling motion. Modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, should avoid lying prone and may need to use alternative positions or exercises.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent injuries to the quadriceps or surrounding areas should be fully healed before attempting this exercise to prevent further damage.

modifications.easier: Use a softer foam roller or reduce the amount of body weight applied to the roller.
modifications.harder: Use a denser foam roller or perform the exercise with both legs simultaneously.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a pillow under the abdomen to reduce spinal extension.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Focus on rolling the upper part of the quadriceps and avoid the area directly above the knee.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly over joints such as the knee or hip.
Do not apply excessive pressure if it causes pain beyond mild discomfort.
Ensure the foam roller is placed on a stable surface to prevent slipping.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain spinal alignment.
Relax the quadriceps as much as possible to allow deeper tissue release.
Move slowly and deliberately, pausing on tender spots.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly, which reduces effectiveness.
Holding the breath, which increases tension in the body.
Allowing the hips to sag, which can strain the lower back.

recommendedReps.flexibility: Roll each leg for 1-2 minutes, focusing on tension points.

name: Quick Leap
instructions: You will need a box for this exerise.
Begin facing the box standing 1-2 feet from its edge.
By utilizing your hips, hop onto the box, landing on both legs. Ensure that you land with your legs bent and your feet flat.
Immediately upon landing, fully extend through the entire body and swing your arms overhead to explode off of the box. Use your legs to absorb the impact of landing.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities like jumping can exacerbate knee pain and joint degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Jumping and landing can increase spinal load and aggravate pain.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance to prevent falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the impact forces involved in jumping.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Spinal compression during landing can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Jumping can increase the risk of ankle sprains or further instability.

modifications.easier: Step up onto the box instead of jumping, focusing on controlled movements.
modifications.harder: Increase the box height or hold light dumbbells to add resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a step-up with a focus on core engagement to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a lower box and focus on a soft landing with minimal knee flexion.
injury_friendly.ankle_instability: Perform on a stable surface without the box, focusing on balance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and on a non-slip surface.
Wear supportive footwear to reduce impact stress.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Use your arms to generate momentum during the jump.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Keep your chest up and eyes forward throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Landing with straight legs, increasing joint stress.
Allowing knees to cave inward upon landing.
Not using arms effectively to aid the jump.
Jumping too far from the box, risking a missed landing.

name: Rack Delivery
instructions: This drill teaches the delivery of the barbell to the rack position on the shoulders. Begin holding a bar in the scarecrow position, with the upper arms parallel to the floor, and the forearms hanging down. Use a hook grip, with your fingers wrapped over your thumbs.

Begin by rotating the elbows around the bar, delivering the bar to the shoulders. As your elbows come forward, relax your grip. The shoulders should be protracted, providing a shelf for the bar, which should lightly contact the throat.

It is important that the bar stay close to the body at all times, as with a heavier load any distance will result in an unwanted collision. As the movement becomes smoother, speed and load can be increased before progressing further.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to the overhead and rotational nature of the movement, which can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise involves significant shoulder rotation and load, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The barbell's position near the throat and the need for neck stability can aggravate cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The hook grip and elbow rotation may increase stress on the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The load on the shoulders and upper spine can pose a fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.thoracic outlet syndrome: The position of the arms and shoulders may compress neurovascular structures, worsening symptoms.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or PVC pipe to practice the movement pattern without significant load.
modifications.harder: Increase the load progressively as form and strength improve.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the movement with a resistance band to reduce load and stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated or with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell stays close to the body to prevent unwanted collisions.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid excessive neck extension to prevent cervical strain.
formCues: Keep elbows high and rotate them around the bar smoothly.
Relax the grip as elbows come forward to allow the bar to rest on the shoulders.
Protract shoulders to create a stable shelf for the bar.
commonMistakes: Allowing the bar to drift away from the body.
Failing to relax the grip, leading to poor bar placement.
Neglecting shoulder protraction, resulting in an unstable rack position.

name: Rack Pull with Bands
instructions: Set up in a power rack with the bar on the pins. The pins should be set to the desired point; just below the knees, just above, or in the mid thigh position. Attach bands to the base of the rack, or secure them with dumbbells. Attach the other end to the bar. You may need to choke the bands to provide tension.

Position yourself against the bar in proper deadlifting position. Your feet should be under your hips, your grip shoulder width, back arched, and hips back to engage the hamstrings. Since the weight is typically heavy, you may use a mixed grip, a hook grip, or use straps to aid in holding the weight.

With your head looking forward, extend through the hips and knees, pulling the weight up and back until lockout. Be sure to pull your shoulders back as you complete the movement. Return the weight to the pins and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The axial loading and spinal flexion/extension involved in rack pulls can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The compression forces may worsen symptoms associated with spinal stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise can increase shear forces on the spine, aggravating this condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The exercise may irritate the sciatic nerve, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: moderate - Joint stress can exacerbate symptoms, particularly in the spine and knees.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: moderate - The Valsalva maneuver and heavy lifting can elevate blood pressure significantly.

modifications.easier: Perform rack pulls without bands or use lighter resistance bands to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Increase band tension or perform the exercise from a lower pin setting to increase range of motion.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform partial range of motion rack pulls with lighter weights and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit knee flexion by setting the pins higher and focus on hip hinge movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the power rack is stable and the bands are securely attached to prevent slippage.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form, especially if new to the exercise.
formCues: Keep the back straight and avoid rounding the spine.
Engage the core throughout the movement to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels and extend the hips fully at the top.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Using too much weight, leading to improper form.
Not engaging the core, resulting in loss of stability.

name: Rack Pulls
instructions: Set up in a power rack with the bar on the pins. The pins should be set to the desired point; just below the knees, just above, or in the mid thigh position. Position yourself against the bar in proper deadlifting position. Your feet should be under your hips, your grip shoulder width, back arched, and hips back to engage the hamstrings. Since the weight is typically heavy, you may use a mixed grip, a hook grip, or use straps to aid in holding the weight.
With your head looking forward, extend through the hips and knees, pulling the weight up and back until lockout. Be sure to pull your shoulders back as you complete the movement.
Return the weight to the pins and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal loading can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Compression of the spine may worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Forward slippage of a vertebra can be aggravated by spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Increased pressure on the sciatic nerve can worsen pain.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: Joint stress may exacerbate symptoms, particularly in the spine.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Heavy lifting can cause a significant increase in blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: Healing tissues may not tolerate the stress of heavy lifting.

modifications.easier: Perform rack pulls with lighter weight or from a higher pin position to reduce range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise from a lower pin position to increase range of motion.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright posture.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure proper hip hinge to minimize knee flexion and focus on posterior chain engagement.

safetyNotes: Always warm up thoroughly before performing heavy lifts.
Use a belt for additional lumbar support if lifting near maximal loads.
Ensure the pins are securely set in the rack to prevent movement during the lift.
formCues: Keep your back straight and chest up throughout the lift.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips fully at the top.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Not fully locking out the hips at the top of the movement.

name: Rear Leg Raises
instructions: Place yourself on your hands knees on an exercise mat. Your head should be looking forward and the bend of the knees should create a 90-degree angle between the hamstrings and the calves. This will be your starting position.
Extend one leg up and behind you. The knee and hip should both extend. Repeat for 5-10 repetitions, and then switch sides.

spinal injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs or lumbar instability should avoid excessive spinal extension.

knee injuries.explanation: Those with patellar tendinitis or recent knee surgery should avoid kneeling positions that may cause discomfort.

hip impingement.explanation: Hip impingement can be aggravated by hip extension movements, requiring modification.

balance disorders.explanation: Balance issues can increase the risk of falls during this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion or keep the knee bent throughout the movement.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise with a resistance band around the thighs for increased resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive lumbar extension and maintain a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Place a cushion or folded towel under the knees for added comfort.
injury_friendly.hip pain: Reduce the height of the leg lift to minimize hip joint stress.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back during leg lifts.
Ensure the supporting knee is cushioned to prevent discomfort.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the pelvis.
Keep your head aligned with your spine, looking down at the mat.
Lift the leg slowly and with control, focusing on muscle activation.
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back excessively.
Allowing the hips to rotate or drop.
Using momentum instead of muscle control.

name: Recumbent Bike
instructions: To begin, seat yourself on the bike and adjust the seat to your height.

Select the desired option from the menu. You may have to start pedaling to turn it on. You can use the manual setting, or you can select a program to use. Typically, you can enter your age and weight to estimate the amount of calories burned during exercise. The level of resistance can be changed throughout the workout. The handles can be used to monitor your heart rate to help you stay at an appropriate intensity.

Recumbent bikes offer convenience, cardiovascular benefits, and have less impact than other activities. A 150 lb person will burn about 230 calories cycling at a moderate rate for 30 minutes, compared to 450 calories or more running.

contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: Individuals with severe heart disease or uncontrolled arrhythmias should avoid high-intensity cycling due to increased cardiovascular demand.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical patients should avoid cycling until cleared by their healthcare provider to prevent complications such as infection or re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.acute knee injuries: Cycling may exacerbate pain or delay healing in individuals with acute knee injuries such as ligament tears or severe sprains.
contraindicationDetails.severe hip osteoarthritis: Individuals with advanced hip osteoarthritis may experience increased joint pain and should consult with a healthcare provider for tailored advice.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: High-intensity cycling can elevate blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Reduce resistance to the lowest setting and cycle at a comfortable pace.
modifications.harder: Increase resistance and incorporate interval training with varying speeds.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Ensure proper seat adjustment to maintain a neutral spine and reduce strain.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Lower resistance and ensure proper seat height to minimize knee flexion beyond 90 degrees.

safetyNotes: Always warm up before starting your cycling session.
Ensure the seat is adjusted to the correct height to prevent knee strain.
Stay hydrated throughout the workout.
Stop exercising if you experience dizziness, chest pain, or severe discomfort.
formCues: Maintain a neutral spine with shoulders relaxed.
Keep your core engaged to support your lower back.
Pedal smoothly without bouncing in the seat.
Adjust the seat so that your knees are slightly bent at the bottom of the pedal stroke.
commonMistakes: Incorrect seat height leading to knee or hip discomfort.
Leaning too far forward, causing back strain.
Using too much resistance, leading to poor form and potential injury.
Neglecting to monitor heart rate for appropriate intensity.

name: Return Push from Stance
instructions: You will need a partner for this drill.
Begin in an athletic 2 or 3 point stance.
At the signal, move into a position to receive the pass from your partner.
Catch the medicine ball with both hands and immediately throw it back to your partner.
You can modify this drill by running different routes.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: The overhead and throwing motion may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator_cuff_tendinitis: The repetitive throwing motion can increase inflammation and pain in the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Conditions like herniated discs or stenosis could be aggravated by the dynamic movement and potential twisting.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: The exercise involves quick, explosive movements that can elevate heart rate and blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Balance and core stability may be compromised, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter medicine ball or from a seated position to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise with a single arm to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion or use a resistance band instead of a medicine ball.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Maintain a neutral spine and avoid twisting motions; perform the exercise seated if necessary.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or collisions.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
Communicate clearly with your partner to coordinate timing and movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Catch the medicine ball with soft elbows to absorb the impact.
Use your legs to help generate power when throwing the ball back.
commonMistakes: Failing to maintain a neutral spine, leading to potential back strain.
Using too heavy a medicine ball, which can compromise form and increase injury risk.
Not coordinating with the partner, leading to awkward catches or throws.

name: Reverse Band Bench Press
instructions: Position a bench inside a power rack, with the bar set to the correct height. Begin by anchoring bands either to band pegs or to the top of the rack. Ensure that you will be position properly under the bands. Attach the other end to the barbell.

Lie on the bench, tuck your feet underneath you and arch your back. Using the bar to help support your weight, lift your shoulder off the bench and retract them, squeezing the shoulder blades together. Use your feet to drive your traps into the bench. Maintain this tight body position throughout the movement. However wide your grip, it should cover the ring on the bar.

Pull the bar out of the rack without protracting your shoulders. Focus on squeezing the bar and trying to pull it apart. Lower the bar to your lower chest or upper stomach. The bar, wrist, and elbow should stay in line at all times.
Pause when the barbell touches your torso, and then drive the bar up with as much force as possible. The elbows should be tucked in until lockout.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead band setup and pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The dynamic nature of the exercise can place excessive strain on the rotator cuff, increasing the risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The pressing motion can aggravate tendinitis symptoms due to repetitive stress on the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Gripping the barbell tightly and the force exerted can worsen wrist pain, especially if the wrist is not properly aligned.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during heavy lifts, can spike blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The arching of the back and pressure on the spine can exacerbate symptoms of a herniated disc.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The back arch and load on the spine can increase the risk of vertebral slippage.

modifications.easier: Use lighter resistance bands or perform a standard bench press without bands to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase band tension or add additional weight plates for greater resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a floor press variation to limit shoulder range of motion and reduce stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a flat back position with feet on the floor to minimize spinal extension and pressure.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely anchored to prevent slippage.
Use a spotter when lifting heavy to ensure safety.
Avoid excessive arching of the back to prevent spinal strain.
formCues: Keep the wrists straight and aligned with the elbows.
Squeeze the shoulder blades together and maintain tension throughout the lift.
Drive through the feet to stabilize the body and support the lift.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder strain.
Failing to maintain a tight grip on the bar, leading to instability.
Arching the back excessively, risking spinal injury.

name: Reverse Band Box Squat
instructions: Begin in a power rack with a box at the appropriate height behind you. Set up the bands either on band pegs or attached to the top of the rack, ensuring they will be directly above the bar during the squat. Attach the other end to the bar.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wider for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings, or closer together for more quad development. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Pause when you reach the box, and relax the hip flexors. Never bounce off of a box.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward off of the box as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe. Use care to return the barbell to the rack.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the compressive forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress. Avoid if there is significant pain.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing heavy squats due to increased blood pressure during the lift.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance changes and abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the spine, knees, or hips require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Those with osteoporosis should avoid heavy loading due to fracture risk. Diabetes with neuropathy requires caution due to balance issues.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or other acute injuries to the lower body.

modifications.easier: Use lighter resistance bands or perform bodyweight box squats to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase band tension or add weight plates to the barbell for greater resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform box squats without the barbell or use a safety squat bar to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit depth to a higher box to reduce knee flexion and stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and at an appropriate height to prevent excessive knee flexion.
Do not bounce off the box; pause to eliminate momentum and reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent lower back injury.
formCues: Keep the core engaged and maintain a tight arch in the lower back.
Push the knees out during the descent to prevent valgus collapse.
Drive through the heels and lead with the chest during the ascent.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Bouncing off the box instead of pausing.
Leaning too far forward, which can increase lower back strain.

name: Reverse Band Deadlift
instructions: Set the bar up in a power rack. Attach bands to the top of the rack, using either bands pegs or the frame itself. Attach the other end of the bands to the bar.

Approach the bar so that it is centered over your feet. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hip to grip the bar at shoulder width, allowing your shoulder blades to protract. Typically, you would use an overhand grip or an over/under grip on heavier sets.

With your feet, and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and bend the knees until your shins contact the bar. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward.
After the bar passes the knees, aggressively pull the bar back, pulling your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward into the bar.
Lower the bar by bending at the hips and guiding it to the floor.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The axial loading and spinal flexion/extension can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The exercise may increase spinal compression, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The shear forces on the spine can aggravate this condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The exercise may irritate the sciatic nerve, requiring careful form and potential modification.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: moderate - Joint stress may exacerbate symptoms, especially in the lower back and knees.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - The risk of vertebral fractures due to axial loading is significant.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: high - The exercise should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: moderate - The Valsalva maneuver and heavy lifting can spike blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Use lighter resistance bands or perform a traditional deadlift with lighter weights.
modifications.harder: Increase band tension or add weight plates to the barbell.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a Romanian deadlift with lighter weights and focus on form.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit knee flexion and focus on hip hinge mechanics.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip or straps to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely attached to prevent slippage.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid hyperextending the back at the top of the lift.
formCues: Engage your core before lifting.
Drive through your heels.
Keep the bar close to your body.
Squeeze your glutes at the top of the lift.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back.
Starting the lift with the hips too high.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Not engaging the core properly.

recommendedReps.endurance: Not typically recommended for endurance training.

name: Reverse Band Power Squat
instructions: Begin in a power rack with the pins and bar set at the appropriate height. After loading the bar, attach bands to the top of the rack, using either pegs or the frame itself. Attach the other end of the bands to the bar.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wide for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings.

Keep your head facing forward. With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips as much as possible. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Lower bar position necessitates a greater torso lean to keep the bar over the heels. Continue until you break parallel, which is defined as the crease of the hip being in line with the top of the knee.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe, until you have returned to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, spondylolisthesis, or sciatica should avoid this exercise due to the high spinal load and potential for exacerbating symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis, knee or hip impingement, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify or avoid this exercise to prevent joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should proceed with caution due to the Valsalva maneuver and increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the spine, hips, or knees require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare professional.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis and diabetes with neuropathy may require modifications to reduce risk of fractures or balance issues.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or spine necessitate avoiding this exercise until fully healed.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications or avoidance due to stability demands.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform bodyweight squats with bands for assistance.
modifications.harder: Increase band tension or add chains to increase resistance at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform with a safety squat bar to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit depth to pain-free range or perform box squats to control depth.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a cambered bar to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely attached to prevent slippage.
Use a spotter or safety pins in the rack for added safety.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare joints and muscles for the load.
formCues: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Drive through the heels to initiate the ascent.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward during the ascent.
Rounding the lower back at the bottom of the squat.
Failing to maintain tension in the core and upper back.

name: Reverse Band Sumo Deadlift
instructions: Begin with a bar loaded on the floor inside of a power rack. Attach bands to the top of the rack, using either pegs or the frame itself. Attach the other end to the barbell.

Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip. Relax the shoulders, which in effect lengthens your arms.

Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.
As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.
Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high compressive and shear forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis or tendinitis should modify or avoid this exercise due to the stress placed on these joints during the wide stance and lifting motion.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should be cautious due to the Valsalva maneuver often used during heavy lifts, which can increase blood pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance changes and increased intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, hips, or knees, should avoid this exercise until fully cleared by a healthcare provider.

osteoporosis.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of fractures from high spinal loading.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard sumo deadlift without bands to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase band tension or perform the lift with a deficit by standing on a platform.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright torso.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit range of motion and ensure proper knee tracking over toes to reduce stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely attached to prevent snapping.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare muscles and joints for heavy lifting.
Use appropriate footwear to maintain stability and support.
formCues: Keep chest up and back straight throughout the lift.
Engage core muscles to protect the spine.
Drive through the heels and spread the floor with your feet.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Allowing knees to cave inward.
Using too much weight too soon, compromising form.

name: Reverse Barbell Curl
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a barbell at shoulder width with the elbows close to the torso. The palm of your hands should be facing down (pronated grip). This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the muscle.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during curling can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The exercise may cause discomfort due to shoulder positioning and movement.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The pronated grip can put additional strain on the wrist, aggravating existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip and wrist position can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Maintaining elbow position can strain the shoulder if the rotator cuff is compromised.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or switch to dumbbells for better control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase.

injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or a neutral grip bar to reduce strain.
injury_friendly.elbow tendinitis: Perform the exercise with resistance bands to decrease joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent joint strain.
Ensure a controlled movement to maintain muscle engagement and prevent injury.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Use a pronated grip and avoid wrist flexion or extension.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum by swinging the body.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Bending the wrists instead of keeping them neutral.

name: Reverse Barbell Preacher Curls
instructions: Grab an EZ-bar using a shoulder width and palms down (pronated) grip.
Now place the upper part of both arms on top of the preacher bench and have your arms extended. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weight up until your biceps are fully contracted and the barbell is at shoulder height. Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the barbell until your upper arms are extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The reverse grip can exacerbate pain and inflammation in the tendons around the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.wrist arthritis: The pronated grip may increase strain on the wrist joint, aggravating arthritis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip and wrist position can compress the median nerve further, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position may cause discomfort or exacerbate impingement symptoms due to shoulder positioning.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for more natural wrist positioning.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce strain on the elbow tendons.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform the exercise with wrist wraps or supports to stabilize the joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the preacher bench is adjusted to a comfortable height to avoid shoulder strain.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form or causes pain.
formCues: Keep your wrists straight and avoid excessive bending.
Engage your core to maintain stability and prevent unnecessary movement.
Focus on a controlled motion, especially during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of isolating the biceps.
Allowing the wrists to bend excessively, increasing strain on the joints.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement, reducing range of motion.

name: Reverse Cable Curl
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a bar attachment that is attached to a low pulley using a pronated (palms down) and shoulder width grip. Make sure also that you keep the elbows close to the torso. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the muscle.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The reverse cable curl can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis due to repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Maintaining the elbows close to the torso may cause discomfort or exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The pronated grip may increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: Isometric contractions and holding the breath during exertion can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load on the elbows and wrists.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase difficulty and engage stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip attachment to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the elbows and wrists.
Maintain a neutral spine to reduce stress on the lower back.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Use a controlled motion, avoiding swinging the weights.
Exhale during the curling phase and inhale during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Reverse Crunch
instructions: Lie down on the floor with your legs fully extended and arms to the side of your torso with the palms on the floor. Your arms should be stationary for the entire exercise.
Move your legs up so that your thighs are perpendicular to the floor and feet are together and parallel to the floor. This is the starting position.
While inhaling, move your legs towards the torso as you roll your pelvis backwards and you raise your hips off the floor. At the end of this movement your knees will be touching your chest.
Hold the contraction for a second and move your legs back to the starting position while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The flexion of the spine during the reverse crunch can exacerbate disc herniation by increasing intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Spinal flexion may aggravate symptoms by further narrowing the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase lumbar instability and cause slippage of the vertebrae.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Flexion of the lumbar spine may irritate the sciatic nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Supine exercises can reduce blood flow and increase intra-abdominal pressure, which is not recommended during pregnancy.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: The exercise places stress on the abdominal region, which may interfere with healing post-surgery.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with bent knees and limit the range of motion to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Hold a light dumbbell between the feet to increase resistance.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform a supine pelvic tilt with feet on the ground to engage the core without spinal flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking movements to prevent unnecessary spinal strain.
Ensure the lower back is supported by the floor throughout the movement.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Lift the hips using the abdominals, not by swinging the legs.
Exhale as you lift the hips and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle contraction.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively off the floor.
Failing to control the descent, leading to a hard landing.

name: Reverse Flyes
instructions: To begin, lie down on an incline bench with the chest and stomach pressing against the incline. Have the dumbbells in each hand with the palms facing each other (neutral grip).

Extend the arms in front of you so that they are perpendicular to the angle of the bench. The legs should be stationary while applying pressure with the ball of your toes. This is the starting position.

Maintaining the slight bend of the elbows, move the weights out and away from each other (to the side) in an arc motion while exhaling. Tip: Try to squeeze your shoulder blades together to get the best results from this exercise.
The arms should be elevated until they are parallel to the floor.
Feel the contraction and slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and lateral movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The repetitive motion may aggravate inflammation in the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The prone position and shoulder movement can strain the neck, worsening cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is increased with weight-bearing exercises, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder injuries: Any recent trauma or severe pain in the shoulder should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a stability ball to engage core muscles more.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion and lighter weights, focusing on scapular retraction.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid neck and back strain.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
Control the weights on the way down to avoid momentum.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to lock out, which can strain the joints.
Raising the shoulders towards the ears, which can cause neck tension.

name: Reverse Flyes With External Rotation
instructions: To begin, lie down on an incline bench set at a 30-degree angle with the chest and stomach pressing against the incline.

Have the dumbbells in each hand with the palms facing down to the floor. Your arms should be in front of you so that they are perpendicular to the angle of the bench. Tip: Your elbows should have a slight bend. The legs should be stationary while applying pressure with the ball of your toes (your heels should not be touching the floor). This is the starting position.
Maintaining the slight bend of the elbows, move the weights out and away from each other in an arc motion while exhaling.

As you lift the weight, your wrist should externally rotate by 90-degrees so that you go from a palms down (pronated) grip to a palms facing each other (neutral) grip. Tip: Try to squeeze your shoulder blades together to get the best results from this exercise.
The arms should be elevated until they are level with the head.
Feel the contraction and slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to the overhead and external rotation component, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate risk as the exercise involves significant rotator cuff activation, which may aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Moderate risk due to potential neck strain from lying prone on the bench.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High risk of fracture due to the load on the spine and shoulders.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Moderate risk as the prone position and load can increase spinal pressure.
