contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High risk due to the stress placed on healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a stability ball to engage core muscles more.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion and avoid full external rotation.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper bench support and consider performing the exercise seated to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive cervical or lumbar strain.
Avoid jerky movements to prevent shoulder joint stress.
Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Externally rotate the wrists smoothly as you lift the weights.
Squeeze the shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to lock out, increasing joint stress.
Failing to maintain a neutral spine, leading to neck or back strain.

name: Reverse Grip Bent-Over Rows
instructions: Stand erect while holding a barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing up).

Bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up. The barbell should hang directly in front of you as your arms hang perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the barbell as you breathe out, keeping the elbows close to the body and not doing any force with the forearm other than holding the weights. On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward bending position and loading of the spine can exacerbate disc herniation, increasing pain and risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The bent-over position may compress the spinal canal, worsening symptoms of stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise places shear forces on the spine, which can aggravate this condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Forward bending and lifting may increase nerve compression, worsening sciatica symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The arm position and movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Holding breath or straining during lifting can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells or a resistance band to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated cable rows to maintain a more neutral spine position.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform the exercise seated or with minimal knee flexion to reduce knee stress.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid rounding the shoulders or back to reduce the risk of injury.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without excessive strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support the lower back.
Lead the movement with your elbows, not your hands.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which increases the risk of spinal injury.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing the effectiveness on the target muscles.

name: Reverse Grip Triceps Pushdown
instructions: Start by setting a bar attachment (straight or e-z) on a high pulley machine.

Facing the bar attachment, grab it with the palms facing up (supinated grip) at shoulder width. Lower the bar by using your lats until your arms are fully extended by your sides. Tip: Elbows should be in by your sides and your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.
Slowly elevate the bar attachment up as you inhale so it is aligned with your chest. Only the forearms should move and the elbows/upper arms should be stationary by your side at all times.
Then begin to lower the cable bar back down to the original staring position while exhaling and contracting the triceps hard.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The supinated grip and repetitive extension can exacerbate inflammation in the elbow tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The exercise may stress the shoulder joint, especially if the elbows flare out.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Standing posture may increase lumbar strain if core engagement is insufficient.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding stress on healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid exercises that may increase the risk of fractures, especially if balance is compromised.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase difficulty and engage stabilizers.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip attachment to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is securely set up to prevent accidents.
Avoid locking the elbows at the bottom of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows tucked close to your sides throughout the movement.
Engage your core to maintain a stable posture.
Focus on a smooth, controlled motion without jerking the weight.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, which can lead to shoulder strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the lower back.

name: Reverse Hyperextension
instructions: Place your feet between the pads after loading an appropriate weight. Lay on the top pad, allowing your hips to hang off the back, while grasping the handles to hold your position.
To begin the movement, flex the hips, pulling the legs forward.
Reverse the motion by extending the hips, kicking the leg back. It is very important not to over-extend the hip on this movement, stopping short of your full range of motion.
Return by again flexing the hip, pulling the carriage forward as far as you can.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for increased spinal loading and extension.

hip_joint_issues.details: Those with hip impingement or arthritis may experience discomfort due to the range of motion required.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing exercises that may increase intra-abdominal pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid this exercise due to the prone position and potential for increased intra-abdominal pressure.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing recent trauma or strains in the lower back or hamstrings.

osteoporosis.details: Those with osteoporosis should exercise caution due to the risk of vertebral fractures from spinal loading.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without added weight, focusing on controlled movement and range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with one leg at a time for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive spinal extension and focus on engaging the glutes.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Ensure proper alignment and avoid locking the knees during the movement.

safetyNotes: Avoid hyperextending the spine during the movement.
Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height and weight.
Warm up adequately before performing this exercise.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Keep the movement slow and controlled.
Stop the leg extension just short of full range to prevent hyperextension.
commonMistakes: Hyperextending the lower back.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Improper machine setup leading to poor body alignment.

name: Reverse Machine Flyes
instructions: Adjust the handles so that they are fully to the rear. Make an appropriate weight selection and adjust the seat height so the handles are at shoulder level. Grasp the handles with your hands facing inwards. This will be your starting position.
In a semicircular motion, pull your hands out to your side and back, contracting your rear delts.
Keep your arms slightly bent throughout the movement, with all of the motion occurring at the shoulder joint.
Pause at the rear of the movement, and slowly return the weight to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The movement of reverse machine flyes can exacerbate impingement by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Individuals with advanced osteoarthritis in the shoulder may experience increased pain and joint stress.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not be fully healed, and this exercise could disrupt recovery.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine disorders: The seated position and shoulder movement may strain the neck, worsening cervical spine conditions.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise with a limited range of motion or use a cable machine to allow for a more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the seat and handles are adjusted to your body dimensions to prevent awkward shoulder angles.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent overloading the shoulder joint.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders down and back to maintain proper posture.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce stress on the joints.
Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together at the peak of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulders to hunch or the back to round during the exercise.
Setting the seat too high or too low, leading to improper shoulder alignment.

name: Reverse Plate Curls
instructions: Start by standing straight with a weighted plate held by both hands and arms fully extended. Use a pronated grip (palms facing down) and make sure your fingers grab the rough side of the plate while your thumb grabs the smooth side. Note: For the best results, grab the weighted plate at an 11:00 and 1:00 o'clock position.
Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other and the weighted plate should be near the groin area. This is the starting position.

Slowly lift the plate up while keeping the elbows in and the upper arms stationary until your biceps and forearms touch while exhaling. The plate should be evenly aligned with your torso at this point.
Feel the contraction for a second and begin to lower the weight back down to the starting position while inhaling
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The pronated grip can exacerbate symptoms by increasing strain on the elbow tendons.

wrist tendinitis.explanation: The grip position may aggravate wrist tendons, especially if the weight is too heavy.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Maintaining proper form is crucial to avoid shoulder discomfort due to improper arm positioning.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The grip and wrist position may increase pressure on the median nerve, exacerbating symptoms.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter plate or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the plate or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce strain on the elbow tendons.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform the exercise with a wrist brace or use a lighter weight to minimize wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a firm grip on the plate to prevent it from slipping.
Avoid swinging the plate; control the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body throughout the movement.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees for better balance.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the plate instead of muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing bicep engagement.
Neglecting to keep the wrists neutral, leading to strain.

name: Reverse Triceps Bench Press
instructions: Lie back on a flat bench. Using a close, supinated grip (around shoulder width), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked extended in front of you and perpendicular to the floor. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest. Tip: Make sure that as opposed to a regular bench press, you keep the elbows close to the torso at all times in order to maximize triceps involvement.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your triceps muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity. The supinated grip and close elbow position can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: High severity. The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate a tear.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate severity. The exercise involves significant elbow extension, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Moderate severity. The supinated grip can strain the wrist, especially if flexibility is limited.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Low severity. Ensure proper breathing technique to avoid excessive blood pressure spikes.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Moderate severity. Lying flat can exacerbate certain spinal conditions; ensure proper support and alignment.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for a more natural wrist position and reduced load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom of the movement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Reduce the range of motion and use lighter weights to minimize stress on the elbows.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or a neutral grip with dumbbells to alleviate wrist discomfort.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely racked before and after the exercise.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy to prevent accidents.
Maintain a controlled tempo to avoid excessive joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Engage the core to maintain stability and prevent arching of the back.
Exhale during the pressing phase and inhale during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows out, which reduces triceps activation and increases shoulder strain.
Bouncing the bar off the chest, which can lead to injury.
Using a grip that is too wide, reducing triceps involvement.

name: Rhomboids-SMR
instructions: Lay down with your back on the floor. Place a foam roll underneath your upper back, and cross your arms in front of you, protracting your shoulders. This will be your starting position.

Raise your hips off of the ground, placing your weight onto the foam roll. Shift your weight to one side at a time, rolling over your middle and upper back. Pause at points of tension for 10-30 seconds.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The pressure and movement on the spine can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Risk of fractures due to bone fragility.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: High severity. Healing tissues may be disrupted by pressure and movement.
contraindicationDetails.severe scoliosis: Moderate severity. Uneven pressure distribution may worsen spinal curvature.
contraindicationDetails.acute back pain: High severity. Rolling may increase pain and inflammation.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a softer foam roll or on a bed to reduce pressure.
modifications.harder: Use a denser foam roll and increase the duration of pauses at tension points.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a softer foam roll and limit the range of motion to avoid exacerbating pain.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep arms at the sides instead of crossing them to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid rolling directly on the spine to prevent excessive pressure on vertebrae.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp or worsening pain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a slow and controlled rolling motion.
Focus on rolling over the muscle tissue, not the bones.
commonMistakes: Rolling too quickly, which can reduce effectiveness and increase injury risk.
Allowing the hips to sag, leading to poor spinal alignment.
Using excessive pressure by lifting too high off the ground.

name: Rickshaw Carry
instructions: Position the frame at the starting point, and load with the appropriate weight. Standing in the center of the frame, begin by gripping the handles and driving through your heels to lift the frame. Ensure your chest and head are up and your back is straight.

Immediately begin walking briskly with quick, controlled steps. Keep your chest up and head forward, and make sure you continue breathing. Bring the frame to the ground after you have reached the end point.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and potential for exacerbating symptoms.

joint issues.details: Arthritis or tendinitis in the knees, hips, or shoulders may require modifications to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular conditions.details: Those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing this exercise due to the potential for increased blood pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and intra-abdominal pressure.

acute injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower back, knees, or ankles should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

neurological conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or shorter distances to reduce the intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or distance carried to challenge strength and endurance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a weight belt for additional support and reduce the load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Focus on maintaining a neutral spine and avoid excessive knee flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip and ensure proper shoulder alignment to minimize strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the path is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Do not twist the torso while carrying the weight.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or dizziness.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core throughout the movement.
Maintain a steady, controlled pace.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Taking excessively long strides.
Holding the breath instead of breathing continuously.

name: Rickshaw Deadlift
instructions: Load the frame with the desired weight. Center yourself between the handles. You feet should be about hip width apart. Bend at the hips to grip the handles, allowing your shoulder blades to protract.

With your feet and your grip set, take a big breath and then lower your hips and flex the knees. Look forward with your head, keep your chest up and your back arched, and begin driving through the heels to move the weight upward. As the weight comes up, pull your shoulder blades together as you drive your hips forward.
Lower the weight by bending at the hips and guiding it to the ground.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal loading can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Compression of the spine may worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Forward slippage of vertebrae can be aggravated by spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Increased intra-abdominal pressure and spinal loading can irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The exercise may increase joint stress, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Spinal loading can exacerbate pain.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires stability and balance, which may be compromised.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Increased intra-abdominal pressure and spinal loading are not recommended.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform a partial range of motion deadlift.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a sumo deadlift with a wider stance to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a trap bar to keep the arms in a neutral position, reducing shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid jerking the weight off the ground.
Ensure proper warm-up before attempting heavy lifts.
formCues: Keep your chest up and back arched.
Drive through your heels.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Pull your shoulder blades together at the top of the lift.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Lifting with the arms instead of driving through the legs.
Allowing the knees to cave inward.

name: Ring Dips
instructions: Grip a ring in each hand, and then take a small jump to help you get into the starting position with your arms locked out.
Begin by flexing the elbow, lowering your body until your arms break 90 degrees. Avoid swinging, and maintain good posture throughout the descent.
Reverse the motion by extending the elbow, pushing yourself back up into the starting position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The deep shoulder flexion required in ring dips can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The instability of rings can place excessive stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The high demand on the triceps and forearm muscles can aggravate tendinitis, particularly lateral or medial epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or elbow surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not yet be strong enough to handle the dynamic and unstable nature of ring dips.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The wrist extension and pressure on the joints can exacerbate pain, particularly in conditions like carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The pressure on the wrist and forearm muscles can increase symptoms of numbness and tingling.

modifications.easier: Perform dips on parallel bars or use resistance bands for assistance to reduce body weight load.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a dip belt or weighted vest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform dips on a stable surface like parallel bars with a reduced range of motion.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use resistance bands for assistance to decrease the load on the elbows.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or perform dips on parallel bars to reduce wrist extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure rings are securely fastened and can support your body weight.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on shoulder and elbow mobility.
Avoid excessive swinging or kipping to maintain control and reduce injury risk.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a stable body position.
Lower yourself slowly to control the descent and avoid joint strain.
Keep elbows close to your body to engage the triceps effectively.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body or using momentum to complete the movement.
Allowing the shoulders to internally rotate excessively at the bottom of the dip.
Failing to maintain a neutral spine and core engagement.

name: Rocket Jump
instructions: Begin in a relaxed stance with your feet shoulder width apart and hold your arms close to the body.
To initiate the move, squat down halfway and explode back up as high as possible.
Fully extend your entire body, reaching overhead as far as possible. As you land, absorb your impact through the legs.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities like jumping can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: Jumping can increase stress on the patellar tendon, worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Landing from jumps can lead to ankle sprains or further instability.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The explosive nature of the jump can strain the lower back, especially if core stability is lacking.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee or ankle surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the impact forces involved in jumping.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Jumping requires good balance and coordination, increasing the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The exercise is high-intensity and may not be suitable for those with uncontrolled heart conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform a squat to calf raise instead of jumping to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Add a tuck jump by bringing knees to chest at the peak of the jump.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform a partial squat jump, reducing the depth of the squat and the height of the jump.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on a controlled squat and avoid the explosive jump, emphasizing core engagement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the landing surface is stable and non-slip.
Wear supportive footwear to absorb impact.
Warm up thoroughly before performing explosive movements.
formCues: Keep the chest up and back straight during the squat.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward during landing.
Not using arms to generate upward momentum.
Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.

name: Rocking Standing Calf Raise
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place it on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck).
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance. Also maintain a straight back and keep the knees with a slight bend; never locked. This will be your starting position.

Raise your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending (other than the slight initial bend we created during positioning) at any time. Hold the contracted position by a second before you start to go back down.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering your heels as you bend the ankles until calves are stretched.
Now lift your toes by contracting the tibia muscles in the front of the calves as you breathe out.
Hold for a second and bring them back down as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.achilles tendinitis: High stress on the Achilles tendon during calf raises can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: The exercise can increase tension on the plantar fascia, worsening pain.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Weight-bearing exercises can increase joint stress, potentially aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: The rocking motion may increase the risk of ankle sprains or strains.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by undue stress on healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Loading the spine with a barbell can exacerbate disc-related symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Spinal loading may increase nerve compression, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires good balance, which may be challenging for those with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a barbell, using body weight only or holding onto a stable surface for support.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise on a single leg to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a Smith machine to provide more stability and reduce the risk of injury.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion and extension.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform seated calf raises to reduce load on the ankle joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely positioned on the shoulders to prevent slipping.
Use a squat rack with safety bars to catch the barbell if needed.
Avoid excessive forward lean to maintain spinal alignment.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Focus on a controlled movement, both upward and downward.
Keep your knees slightly bent throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Locking the knees, which can increase joint stress.
Allowing the barbell to roll onto the neck, increasing risk of injury.
Performing the movement too quickly, reducing effectiveness and increasing injury risk.

name: Rocky Pull-Ups/Pulldowns
instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing forward using a wide grip.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

Pull your torso up until the bar touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.

Now repeat the same movements as described above except this time your torso will remain straight as you go up and the bar will touch the back of the neck instead of the upper chest. Tip: Use the head to lean forward slightly as it will help you properly execute this portion of the exercise.
Once you have lowered yourself back down to the starting position, repeat the exercise for the prescribed amount of repetitions in your program.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping the bar tightly and the pulling motion can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The movement of the head and neck can place stress on the cervical spine, potentially worsening existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The curvature of the lower back and pulling motion can increase intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Hyperextension of the lower back can exacerbate this condition.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise involves high loads on the spine and shoulders, which can increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Use an assisted pull-up machine or resistance bands to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a dip belt or weighted vest.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform lat pulldowns with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a seated row machine to maintain a more neutral spine position.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely fastened to avoid accidents.
Warm up the shoulder and back muscles thoroughly before performing the exercise.
Avoid jerky movements to reduce the risk of injury.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Keep the chest lifted and shoulders retracted throughout the movement.
Avoid swinging the body; focus on controlled movements.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull up, which reduces muscle engagement.
Allowing the shoulders to internally rotate at the top of the movement.
Not maintaining a stable core, leading to excessive lower back arching.

name: Romanian Deadlift
instructions: Put a barbell in front of you on the ground and grab it using a pronated (palms facing down) grip that a little wider than shoulder width. Tip: Depending on the weight used, you may need wrist wraps to perform the exercise and also a raised platform in order to allow for better range of motion.
Bend the knees slightly and keep the shins vertical, hips back and back straight. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your back and arms completely straight at all times, use your hips to lift the bar as you exhale. Tip: The movement should not be fast but steady and under control.

Once you are standing completely straight up, lower the bar by pushing the hips back, only slightly bending the knees, unlike when squatting. Tip: Take a deep breath at the start of the movement and keep your chest up. Hold your breath as you lower and exhale as you complete the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and shear forces.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: Those with knee or hip arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should be cautious due to the load placed on these joints during the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: People with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid heavy lifting due to potential spikes in blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance changes and increased intra-abdominal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Recent surgeries involving the spine, hips, or knees may require avoiding this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid heavy lifting to prevent fractures, especially in the spine.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on a single leg to increase difficulty and engage stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a partial range of motion or use a trap bar to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit knee flexion and focus on hip hinge to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent injury.
Avoid excessive knee flexion to focus on hip hinge and protect the knees.
Ensure the barbell is close to the body to reduce lower back strain.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Push your hips back as if closing a door with your glutes.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which increases the risk of spinal injury.
Using the arms to lift the weight instead of the hips.
Allowing the knees to move forward excessively, turning it into a squat.

name: Romanian Deadlift from Deficit
instructions: Begin standing while holding a bar at arm's length in front of you. You can stand on a raised platform to increase the range of motion.

Begin by flexing the knees slightly, and then flex at the hip, moving your butt back as far as possible, lowering the torso as far as flexibility allows. The back should remain in absolute extension at all times, and the bar should remain in contact with the legs. If done properly, there should be heavy tension felt in the hamstrings.
Reverse the motion to return to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the significant load on the lumbar spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis should be cautious due to the increased range of motion and potential joint stress.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that require balance and heavy lifting.

osteoporosis.details: The risk of vertebral fractures is increased with heavy loading and forward bending.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute lower back pain, hamstring strains, or recent trauma to the lower body.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard Romanian Deadlift without the deficit to reduce the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform single-leg Romanian Deadlifts for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural grip and reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion and focus on hip hinge.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent injury.
Avoid rounding the back, especially in the lower lumbar region.
Ensure the platform is stable and secure if standing on a deficit.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your legs throughout the lift.
Initiate the movement by hinging at the hips, not bending at the waist.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Using the arms to lift the weight instead of the hips and hamstrings.
Allowing the knees to lock out or excessively bend.

name: Rope Climb
instructions: Grab the rope with both hands above your head. Pull down on the rope as you take a small jump.
Wrap the rope around one leg, using your feet to pinch the rope. Reach up as high as possible with your arms, gripping the rope tightly.
Release the rope from your feet as you pull yourself up with your arms, bringing your knees towards your chest.
Resecure your feet on the rope, and then stand up to take another high hold on the rope. Continue until you reach the top of the rope.
To lower yourself, loosen the grip of your feet on the rope as you slide down using a hand over hand motion.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pulling motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The repetitive pulling can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping and pulling may worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The grip required can strain the wrist joints.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Neck strain can occur due to head positioning and pulling forces.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The spinal loading and flexion can worsen disc conditions.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The spinal loading may increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The isometric holds and exertion can raise blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.heart disease: Intense exertion may not be suitable for those with heart conditions.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of falls and spinal loading can be dangerous.

modifications.easier: Use a rope climbing machine or a rope with knots to assist in climbing.
modifications.harder: Perform the climb without using legs for assistance, relying solely on upper body strength.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a thicker rope to reduce grip strain and avoid overhead reaching.
injury_friendly.back pain: Limit the height of the climb and ensure proper core engagement to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Focus on upper body pulling without using legs to pinch the rope.

safetyNotes: Ensure the rope is securely anchored and in good condition.
Use a crash mat underneath to protect against falls.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting the climb.
Avoid the exercise if fatigued to prevent accidents.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the climb.
Use your legs to assist by pinching the rope.
Keep your shoulders down and back to avoid strain.
Maintain a neutral spine position.
commonMistakes: Using only arms without engaging the legs.
Allowing the back to arch excessively.
Neglecting to secure the rope with the feet.
Rushing the climb, leading to poor form.

recommendedReps.strength: Climb to the top 1-3 times per set
recommendedReps.endurance: Climb to the top 4-6 times per set

name: Rope Crunch
instructions: Kneel 1-2 feet in front of a cable system with a rope attached.
After selecting an appropriate weight, grasp the rope with both hands reaching overhead. Your torso should be upright in the starting position.
To begin, flex at the spine, attempting to bring your rib cage to your legs as you pull the cable down.
Pause at the bottom of the motion, and then slowly return to the starting position.
These can be done with twists or to the side to hit the obliques.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the flexion and load on the spine, which can exacerbate these conditions.

joint_issues.explanation: Those with arthritis or tendinitis, particularly in the knees or shoulders, should modify the exercise to reduce stress on the joints.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals should avoid exercises involving spinal flexion and abdominal compression, especially in the second and third trimesters.

osteoporosis.explanation: The spinal flexion involved in this exercise can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent trauma or acute injuries, particularly in the back or knees, require complete avoidance until fully healed.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or without the cable, focusing on bodyweight crunches.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a Bosu ball to engage more stabilizing muscles.
modifications.injury_friendly: For back pain, perform standing cable crunches to reduce spinal flexion. For knee pain, perform seated cable crunches to avoid kneeling.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight is appropriate to avoid excessive strain on the spine.
Maintain control throughout the movement to prevent jerking motions.
formCues: Engage the core before starting the movement.
Keep the elbows close to the head and focus on bringing the rib cage towards the pelvis.
Avoid pulling with the arms; the movement should originate from the core.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Pulling with the arms instead of engaging the core.
Allowing the hips to shift backward during the crunch.

name: Rope Jumping
instructions: Hold an end of the rope in each hand. Position the rope behind you on the ground. Raise your arms up and turn the rope over your head bringing it down in front of you. When it reaches the ground, jump over it. Find a good turning pace that can be maintained. Different speeds and techniques can be used to introduce variation.
Rope jumping is exciting, challenges your coordination, and requires a lot of energy. A 150 lb person will burn about 350 calories jumping rope for 30 minutes, compared to over 450 calories running.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities like rope jumping can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The repetitive impact and spinal jarring can worsen symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The coordination and balance required for rope jumping may increase the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: High-impact activity may impede recovery and cause complications.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular conditions: The high-intensity nature of rope jumping can place excessive strain on the cardiovascular system.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: High-impact activities are generally discouraged due to potential strain on the pelvic floor and risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: The repetitive impact on the feet can worsen heel pain and inflammation.

modifications.easier: Perform a low-impact version by mimicking the rope jumping motion without actually using a rope, or use a slower pace.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed of the rope or incorporate double unders (two rope passes per jump).

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a softer surface to reduce impact or perform a seated rope swing to mimic the arm movement.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on maintaining a neutral spine and engage the core to stabilize the lower back.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion in the arms or use a lighter rope.

safetyNotes: Ensure the rope is the correct length to prevent tripping.
Use proper footwear to absorb impact and provide support.
Jump on a soft surface to reduce joint stress.
Stop immediately if you experience pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your body.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees.
Land softly on the balls of your feet.
Engage your core to stabilize your body.
commonMistakes: Jumping too high, which increases impact and energy expenditure.
Allowing the rope to hit the feet, causing tripping.
Using excessive arm movement instead of wrist rotation.
Failing to maintain a consistent rhythm.

name: Rope Straight-Arm Pulldown
instructions: Attach a rope to a high pulley and make your weight selection. Stand a couple feet back from the pulley with your feet staggered and take the rope with both hands. Lean forward from the hip, keeping your back straight, with your arms extended up in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight, extend the shoulder to pull the rope down to your thighs.
Pause at the bottom of the motion, squeezing your lats.
Return to the starting position without allowing the weight to fully rest on the stack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and shoulder extension may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves shoulder movement that could irritate the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: Forward leaning and spinal loading may increase disc pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or back surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the strain of this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Forward bending and spinal loading can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to forward bending and potential spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric holds and exertion may elevate blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight and perform the exercise seated to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a single arm to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a shorter range of motion, avoiding the top 20% of the movement.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Avoid hyperextending the lower back during the exercise.
Do not allow the weight stack to rest between repetitions to maintain constant tension.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees for better balance.
Keep your arms straight but not locked throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing your lats at the bottom of the motion.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull the rope down.
Allowing the shoulders to roll forward.
Bending the elbows excessively, turning it into a triceps exercise.

name: Round The World Shoulder Stretch
instructions: Stand up straight with your legs together, holding a bodybar or broomstick.
Hold the pole behind your hips with a wider than shoulder width grip. Your palms should be down and your thumbs facing out.
Slowly lift your arms up behind your head. Don't force it if it gets hard to lift further.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to overhead arm movement which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: High risk as the exercise involves significant shoulder rotation and elevation, potentially straining the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the shoulder: Moderate risk as the movement may cause pain and inflammation in arthritic joints.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High risk; avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider due to healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate risk due to potential for fracture with excessive force or improper form.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Moderate risk as hyperextension of the spine may exacerbate symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with a towel instead of a rigid pole to allow more flexibility and reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Use a narrower grip on the pole to increase the stretch intensity.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the stretch lying on your back with a towel, which reduces the load on the shoulders and spine.

safetyNotes: Avoid forcing the arms into a position that causes pain.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
Ensure the grip is wide enough to avoid excessive shoulder stress.
formCues: Stand tall with your core engaged.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
Lift the pole slowly and with control, stopping if you feel any pain.
commonMistakes: Using a grip that is too narrow, causing shoulder strain.
Arching the lower back excessively during the stretch.
Forcing the arms into a painful position.

name: Rowing, Stationary
instructions: To begin, seat yourself on the rower. Make sure that your heels are resting comfortably against the base of the foot pedals and that the straps are secured. Select the program that you wish to use, if applicable. Sit up straight and bend forward at the hips.

There are three phases of movement when using a rower. The first phase is when you come forward on the rower. Your knees are bent and against your chest. Your upper body is leaning slightly forward while still maintaining good posture. Next, push against the foot pedals and extend your legs while bringing your hands to your upper abdominal area, squeezing your shoulders back as you do so. To avoid straining your back, use primarily your leg and hip muscles.
The recovery phase simply involves straightening your arms, bending the knees, and bringing your body forward again as you transition back into the first phase.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The forward flexion and repetitive motion can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The flexed position may increase spinal canal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The rowing motion can increase shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - May aggravate symptoms; modifications needed.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: moderate - May cause discomfort; adjust resistance and range of motion.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: moderate - Avoid excessive shoulder movement; focus on leg drive.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: moderate - Monitor intensity and avoid high resistance.
contraindicationDetails.heart disease: high - Requires medical clearance and supervision.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - Postural changes and balance concerns; consult with a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high - Avoid until cleared by a surgeon.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - Avoid excessive forward flexion; maintain upright posture.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - Ensure stability and proper seating.

modifications.easier: Use a lower resistance setting and focus on form rather than speed.
modifications.harder: Increase resistance and incorporate interval training for intensity.

injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a more upright posture and reduce range of motion.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Focus on a higher stroke rate with less resistance to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit arm movement and emphasize leg drive.

safetyNotes: Ensure the foot straps are secure to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive forward flexion to protect the lower back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Drive through your heels and extend your legs powerfully.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the stroke.
Pulling with the arms too early in the stroke.
Leaning too far back at the end of the stroke.

name: Runner's Stretch
instructions: It's easiest to get into this stretch if you start standing up, put one leg behind you, and slowly lower your torso down to the floor.
Keep the front heel on the floor (if it lifts up, scoot your other leg further back).

Place your hands on either side of your front leg. To get more out of this stretch, push your butt up toward the ceiling, and then gradually lower it back toward the floor. You'll Stretch the hip flexor of the back leg and the hamstring and buttocks of the front.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. Forward bending can exacerbate disc protrusion, increasing pressure on spinal nerves.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. Stretching may aggravate sciatic nerve irritation, especially with improper form.
contraindicationDetails.recent hamstring strain: High severity. Stretching a healing muscle can lead to re-injury or delayed recovery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High severity. Forward bending poses a risk for vertebral fractures due to decreased bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: High severity. Forward flexion can increase pain and discomfort in acute phases.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Moderate severity. The position may cause discomfort or pain in the hip joint.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch lying on your back with one leg extended and the other leg raised, using a strap to gently pull the leg towards you.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by reaching your hands further forward or by elevating the front foot on a small step.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch lying on your back with a strap, keeping the spine neutral.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Place a cushion under the back knee to reduce pressure.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Do not force the stretch; move into it gradually.
Ensure the back leg is extended comfortably without hyperextension.
formCues: Keep the front heel grounded to maintain stability.
Engage the core to support the lower back.
Align the hips squarely to the front for balanced stretching.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front heel to lift off the ground.
Rounding the back excessively, which can strain the spine.
Twisting the hips, reducing the effectiveness of the stretch.

name: Running, Treadmill
instructions: To begin, step onto the treadmill and select the desired option from the menu. Most treadmills have a manual setting, or you can select a program to run. Typically, you can enter your age and weight to estimate the amount of calories burned during exercise. Elevation can be adjusted to change the intensity of the workout.

Treadmills offer convenience, cardiovascular benefits, and usually have less impact than running outside. A 150 lb person will burn over 450 calories running 8 miles per hour for 30 minutes. Maintain proper posture as you run, and only hold onto the handles when necessary, such as when dismounting or checking your heart rate.

contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: Running can significantly increase heart rate and blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.
contraindicationDetails.advanced osteoarthritis of the knee: The repetitive impact of running may exacerbate joint degeneration and pain.
contraindicationDetails.acute knee or ankle injuries: Running can worsen symptoms and delay healing of sprains, strains, or fractures.
contraindicationDetails.severe balance disorders: The dynamic nature of running increases fall risk for individuals with significant balance impairments.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Running can stress healing tissues and should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare professional.
contraindicationDetails.severe sciatica: Running may aggravate nerve compression and increase pain in individuals with severe sciatica.

modifications.easier: Walking on the treadmill at a moderate pace with no incline.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline or speed to simulate hill running or sprint intervals.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a lower speed and incline, and consider using cushioned or shock-absorbing shoes.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a slight forward lean and engage core muscles to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Focus on a shorter stride and ensure proper footwear to minimize impact.

safetyNotes: Always start with a warm-up to prepare the body for exercise.
Ensure the treadmill is in good working condition and the emergency stop is functional.
Stay hydrated and be aware of signs of overheating or fatigue.
formCues: Maintain an upright posture with a slight forward lean.
Keep your gaze forward and shoulders relaxed.
Use a midfoot strike to reduce impact on the joints.
commonMistakes: Holding onto the handles excessively, which can alter posture and reduce workout effectiveness.
Overstriding, which increases impact forces and risk of injury.
Ignoring pain or discomfort, which can lead to injury.

recommendedSets.advanced: 2-3 sets with intervals or hill simulations

recommendedReps.speed: Intervals of 30 seconds to 2 minutes at high speed

name: Russian Twist
instructions: Lie down on the floor placing your feet either under something that will not move or by having a partner hold them. Your legs should be bent at the knees.

Elevate your upper body so that it creates an imaginary V-shape with your thighs. Your arms should be fully extended in front of you perpendicular to your torso and with the hands clasped. This is the starting position.
Twist your torso to the right side until your arms are parallel with the floor while breathing out.
Hold the contraction for a second and move back to the starting position while breathing out. Now move to the opposite side performing the same techniques you applied to the right side.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The twisting motion and spinal flexion can exacerbate disc herniation, increasing pain and risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The exercise may compress the spinal canal, worsening symptoms of spinal stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The rotational force can increase instability in the spine, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Twisting can irritate the sciatic nerve, leading to increased pain and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise poses a risk of vertebral fractures due to the rotational and compressive forces on the spine.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with feet flat on the floor and torso more upright to reduce strain on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight or medicine ball in your hands to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated on a bench with minimal rotation, focusing on engaging the core without twisting the spine.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep feet flat on the floor to reduce stress on the knees.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive twisting to prevent strain on the lower back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Engage the core muscles to stabilize the spine.
formCues: Keep your back straight and chest lifted.
Rotate from the torso, not just the arms.
Exhale as you twist and inhale as you return to center.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which increases spinal stress.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the feet to lift off the ground, reducing stability.

name: Sandbag Load
instructions: To load sandbags or other objects, begin with the implements placed a distance from the loading platform, typically 50 feet.

Begin by lifting the sandbag. Sandbags are extremely awkward, and the manner of lifting them can vary depending on the particular sandbag used. Reach as far around it as possible, extending through the hips and knees to pull it up high. Shouldering is usually not allowed.
Move as quickly as possible to the platform, and load it, extending through your hips, knees, and ankles to get it as high as possible. Place it onto the platform, ensuring it doesn't fall off.
Return to the starting position to retrieve the next sandbag, and repeat until the event is completed.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The compressive and shear forces involved in lifting and carrying heavy, awkward loads can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high - The exercise may increase nerve compression and irritation due to the load and movement pattern.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: moderate - The exercise involves significant knee flexion and weight-bearing, which can aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: high - The load and movement can increase pain and risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: high - Carrying an unstable load over a distance requires good balance and coordination.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: moderate - The exercise involves shoulder stabilization which may be contraindicated post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular conditions: moderate - The exercise is physically demanding and may elevate heart rate and blood pressure significantly.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter sandbag or a smaller distance to the platform to reduce the load and intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the sandbag or the distance to the platform to enhance the challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter sandbag and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the distance to the platform and avoid deep knee flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Ensure the load is kept close to the body to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Always warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise.
Ensure the sandbag is secure and will not shift unexpectedly during the lift.
Use a flat, non-slip surface to prevent falls.
formCues: Keep your back straight and core engaged throughout the lift.
Lift with your legs, not your back, by driving through your heels.
Keep the sandbag close to your body to maintain control.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward.
Using momentum instead of controlled strength to lift the sandbag.

name: Scapular Pull-Up
instructions: Take a pronated grip on a pull-up bar.
From a hanging position, raise yourself a few inches without using your arms. Do this by depressing your shoulder girdle in a reverse shrugging motion.
Pause at the completion of the movement, and then slowly return to the starting position before performing more repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The scapular pull-up involves shoulder girdle movement, which can exacerbate symptoms in individuals with impingement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may aggravate the tendons of the rotator cuff due to the upward rotation and depression of the scapula.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Hanging exercises may pose a risk of fracture in individuals with severe bone density loss.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical shoulders may not tolerate the load and range of motion required for this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform scapular retractions while seated with resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Progress to full pull-ups by integrating elbow flexion into the movement.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform scapular pull-ups with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a supported pull-up machine to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure a secure grip on the bar to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive swinging or jerking motions.
Do not force the range of motion; move within comfortable limits.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the body.
Focus on moving the shoulder blades down and together.
Keep elbows straight to isolate scapular movement.
commonMistakes: Using the arms to pull up instead of focusing on scapular movement.
Allowing the body to swing excessively.
Failing to engage the core, leading to an unstable position.

name: Scissor Kick
instructions: To begin, lie down with your back pressed against the floor or on an exercise mat (optional). Your arms should be fully extended to the sides with your palms facing down. Note: The arms should be stationary the entire time.
With a slight bend at the knees, lift your legs up so that your heels are about 6 inches off the ground. This is the starting position.
Now lift your left leg up to about a 45 degree angle while your right leg is lowered until the heel is about 2-3 inches from the ground.
Switch movements by raising your right leg up and lowering your left leg. Remember to breathe while performing this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The exercise can exacerbate symptoms by increasing intra-abdominal pressure and spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. Lumbar flexion can aggravate symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise may increase anterior shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. Leg movements can irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High severity. Risk of vertebral fracture due to spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent strain on healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Supine position may cause discomfort and reduced venous return in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with knees bent at 90 degrees to reduce strain on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance and challenge the core muscles further.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a rolled towel under the lower back for support and keep the knees bent.
injury_friendly.hip pain: Limit the range of motion and keep the movements slow and controlled.

safetyNotes: Avoid arching the lower back; keep it pressed against the floor.
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement.
Keep your head and neck relaxed on the floor.
Move slowly and with control to maintain form.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to lift off the ground.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Holding breath during the exercise.

name: Scissors Jump
instructions: Assume a lunge stance position with one foot forward with the knee bent, and the rear knee nearly touching the ground.
Ensure that the front knee is over the midline of the foot. Extending through both legs, jump as high as possible, swinging your arms to gain lift.
As you jump as high as you can, switch the position of your legs, moving your front leg to the back and the rear leg to the front.
As you land, absorb the impact through the legs by adopting the lunge position, and repeat.

knee injuries.explanation: The impact and dynamic nature of the exercise can exacerbate knee pain and instability.

ankle instability.explanation: Jumping and landing require stable ankles to prevent sprains or further injury.

spinal injuries.explanation: The exercise involves spinal loading and dynamic movement, which can aggravate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The high-intensity nature of the exercise can elevate heart rate significantly, posing risks for individuals with heart disease or hypertension.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise involves high impact and balance challenges, which may not be suitable during pregnancy.

balance disorders.explanation: The exercise requires good balance and coordination, which can be challenging for individuals with balance disorders.

modifications.easier: Perform alternating reverse lunges without the jump to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Add a tuck jump at the top of the movement to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform stationary lunges with a focus on controlled movement and reduced range of motion.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Limit the depth of the lunge and avoid excessive forward lean to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure a soft landing by absorbing impact through the legs.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid excessive forward knee movement past the toes.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back.
Engage the core for stability.
Land softly with knees slightly bent.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to collapse inward.
Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Failing to switch legs fully in the air.

name: Seated Band Hamstring Curl
instructions: Secure a band close to the ground and place a bench a couple feet away from it.
Seat yourself on the bench and secure the band behind your ankles, beginning with your legs straight. This will be your starting position.
Flex the knees, bringing your feet towards the bench. You may need to lean back slightly to keep your feet from striking the floor.
Pause at the completion of the movement, and then slowly return to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with lumbar disc herniation or sciatica should avoid this exercise or perform it with caution, as the seated position may exacerbate symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the exercise to reduce knee flexion or avoid it if pain persists.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to changes in balance and joint laxity.

surgical_recovery.details: Individuals recovering from recent lower limb or spinal surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute hamstring or knee injuries to prevent further damage.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter resistance band or perform the exercise without a band to focus on the movement pattern.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance of the band or perform the exercise with one leg at a time for added challenge.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with back pain, ensure the back is supported by the bench and engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored to prevent it from snapping back.
Avoid hyperextending the knees at the starting position.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
Flex the knees smoothly and control the movement.
Keep feet parallel and avoid letting them turn inward or outward.
commonMistakes: Allowing the band to snap back uncontrolled.
Leaning too far back, which can strain the lower back.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.

name: Seated Barbell Military Press
instructions: Sit on a Military Press Bench with a bar behind your head and either have a spotter give you the bar (better on the rotator cuff this way) or pick it up yourself carefully with a pronated grip (palms facing forward). Tip: Your grip should be wider than shoulder width and it should create a 90-degree angle between the forearm and the upper arm as the barbell goes down.

Once you pick up the barbell with the correct grip length, lift the bar up over your head by locking your arms. Hold at about shoulder level and slightly in front of your head. This is your starting position.
Lower the bar down to the collarbone slowly as you inhale.
Lift the bar back up to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead motion can exacerbate compression of the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Lifting overhead can strain the rotator cuff muscles and tendons, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The seated position and overhead load can increase stress on the cervical spine, aggravating existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping and pressing can exacerbate pain and inflammation in the elbow tendons.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The axial load on the spine during this exercise can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during heavy lifts, can spike blood pressure, posing risks for those with hypertension.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural range of motion and reduce shoulder strain.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing to engage more core stabilizers and increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated dumbbell press with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a back support bench to maintain proper spinal alignment and reduce lower back strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench has proper back support to maintain spinal alignment.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back during the lift.
Use a spotter when lifting heavy to ensure safety and proper form.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid undue stress on the wrists.
Lower the barbell slowly and with control to the collarbone.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can increase shoulder joint stress.
Using momentum to lift the barbell instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Failing to engage the core, leading to excessive lumbar extension.

name: Seated Barbell Twist
instructions: Start out by sitting at the end of a flat bench with a barbell placed on top of your thighs. Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.
Grip the bar with your palms facing down and make sure your hands are wider than shoulder width apart from each other. Begin to lift the barbell up over your head until your arms are fully extended.
Now lower the barbell behind your head until it is resting along the base of your neck. This is the starting position.

While keeping your feet and head stationary, move your waist from side to side so that your oblique muscles feel the contraction. Only move from side to side as far as your waist will allow you to go. Stretching or moving too far can cause an injury to occur. Tip: Use a slow and controlled motion.
Remember to breathe out while twisting your body to the side and in when moving back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The rotational movement and load on the spine can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Twisting motions can increase pressure on the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise may increase lumbar instability and exacerbate slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Twisting can irritate the sciatic nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Positioning the barbell behind the neck can aggravate shoulder impingement.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The exercise may cause excessive strain on the abdominal region and lower back.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Twisting and load can interfere with healing post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise poses a risk of spinal fractures due to rotational forces.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a dowel or broomstick instead of a barbell to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated twists without a barbell, focusing on controlled movement and engaging the core.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Avoid placing the barbell behind the neck; instead, hold it in front of the chest.
