safetyNotes: Avoid excessive twisting to prevent spinal strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Do not use momentum to twist; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Twist only as far as comfortable without pain.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and down, away from your ears.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to twist instead of controlled movements.
Allowing the spine to flex or extend excessively.
Holding the breath during the exercise.

name: Seated Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
instructions: Sit down at the end of a flat bench with a dumbbell in one arm using a neutral grip (palms of the hand facing you).
Bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Make sure that you keep the head up.

The upper arm with the dumbbell should be close to the torso and aligned with it (lifted up until it is parallel to the floor while the forearms are pointing towards the floor as the hands hold the weights). Tip: There should be a 90-degree angle between the forearms and the upper arm. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arm stationary, use the triceps to lift the weight as you exhale until the forearm is parallel to the floor and the whole arm is extended. Like many other arm exercises, only the forearm moves.
After a second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbell back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arm during the exercise may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive extension of the elbow can aggravate tendinitis, especially if the load is too heavy.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise requires stabilization from the shoulder, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell may increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may be stressed by the load and movement, delaying recovery.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The bent-over position can increase spinal load, potentially worsening disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Forward bending can increase shear forces on the spine, exacerbating this condition.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The bent-over position and potential for poor form can increase fracture risk in those with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort and use a lighter weight.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weight; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep the upper arm stationary and close to the torso.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso and prevent excessive movement.
Exhale during the extension phase and inhale during the lowering phase.
commonMistakes: Allowing the upper arm to move away from the torso.
Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and potential injury.
Rounding the back, which can increase spinal stress.

name: Seated Bent-Over Rear Delt Raise
instructions: Place a couple of dumbbells looking forward in front of a flat bench.
Sit on the end of the bench with your legs together and the dumbbells behind your calves.
Bend at the waist while keeping the back straight in order to pick up the dumbbells. The palms of your hands should be facing each other as you pick them. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your torso forward and stationary, and the arms slightly bent at the elbows, lift the dumbbells straight to the side until both arms are parallel to the floor. Exhale as you lift the weights. (Note: avoid swinging the torso or bringing the arms back as opposed to the side.)
After a one second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The overhead arm position can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate severity. The exercise may strain the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Moderate severity. Forward bending posture may increase cervical spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High severity. Risk of fracture due to bending and weight bearing.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Moderate severity. Forward bending can increase lumbar spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. Bending at the waist can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. Forward bending can increase vertebral slippage.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or without weights to focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise standing for added core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with resistance bands to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Perform the exercise while seated on a stability ball to reduce lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weights; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your elbows slightly bent throughout the movement.
Lift the weights to shoulder height, not higher.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back while bending over.
Using momentum or swinging the weights.
Lifting the weights too high or behind the body.

name: Seated Bent-Over Two-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
instructions: Sit down at the end of a flat bench with a dumbbell in both arms using a neutral grip (palms of the hand facing you).
Bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Make sure that you keep the head up.

The upper arms with the dumbbells should be close to the torso and aligned with it (lifted up until they are parallel to the floor while the forearms are pointing towards the floor as the hands hold the weights). Tip: There should be a 90-degree angle between the forearms and the upper arm. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arms stationary, use the triceps to lift the weight as you exhale until the forearms are parallel to the floor and the whole arm is extended. Like many other arm exercises, only the forearm moves.
After a second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position of the arms can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required by the shoulder joint can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure on the carpal tunnel.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Bending forward can increase spinal pressure, exacerbating disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Forward bending can increase lumbar instability.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The forward bending position can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform triceps pushdowns with a resistance band to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure the spine remains neutral throughout the exercise to avoid excessive lumbar stress.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a stable torso.
Ensure your elbows remain close to your body throughout the movement.
Exhale as you extend your arms and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round, which can increase spinal stress.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Letting the elbows flare out, reducing triceps engagement.

name: Seated Biceps
instructions: Sit on the floor with your knees bent and your partner standing behind you. Extend your arms straight behind you with your palms facing each other. Your partner will hold your wrists for you. This will be the starting position.
Attempt to flex your elbows, while your partner prevents any actual movement.

After 10-20 seconds, relax your arms while your partner gently pulls your wrists up to stretch your biceps. Be sure to let your partner know when the stretch is appropriate to prevent injury or overstretching.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The position and force applied can exacerbate impingement symptoms.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The isometric contraction can increase strain on the elbow tendons.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: Wrist positioning may aggravate symptoms due to nerve compression.

rotator cuff injuries.explanation: The exercise can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, risking further injury.

hypertension.explanation: Isometric exercises can increase blood pressure; monitor closely.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of partner resistance to allow for controlled tension.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the isometric hold or add a light dumbbell for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a standing bicep curl with light dumbbells to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow_pain: Use a resistance band with less tension to minimize stress on the elbow.

safetyNotes: Communicate clearly with your partner to avoid overstretching.
Ensure the partner provides consistent resistance without jerking motions.
Stop immediately if you experience pain beyond normal muscle fatigue.
formCues: Keep your back straight and core engaged while seated.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid unnecessary strain.
Focus on controlled breathing throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to elevate, which can increase neck tension.
Not communicating effectively with the partner, leading to excessive force or stretch.
Holding breath, which can increase blood pressure.

name: Seated Cable Rows
instructions: For this exercise you will need access to a low pulley row machine with a V-bar. Note: The V-bar will enable you to have a neutral grip where the palms of your hands face each other. To get into the starting position, first sit down on the machine and place your feet on the front platform or crossbar provided making sure that your knees are slightly bent and not locked.
Lean over as you keep the natural alignment of your back and grab the V-bar handles.

With your arms extended pull back until your torso is at a 90-degree angle from your legs. Your back should be slightly arched and your chest should be sticking out. You should be feeling a nice stretch on your lats as you hold the bar in front of you. This is the starting position of the exercise.

Keeping the torso stationary, pull the handles back towards your torso while keeping the arms close to it until you touch the abdominals. Breathe out as you perform that movement. At that point you should be squeezing your back muscles hard. Hold that contraction for a second and slowly go back to the original position while breathing in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

herniated disc.explanation: The seated cable row can place significant stress on the lumbar spine, which may exacerbate symptoms of a herniated disc.

spinal stenosis.explanation: The forward lean and pulling motion can increase spinal compression, aggravating spinal stenosis.

spondylolisthesis.explanation: The exercise can increase lumbar lordosis and anterior shear forces, worsening spondylolisthesis.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The pulling motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms if not performed with proper scapular control.

rotator cuff tendinitis.explanation: The exercise may irritate the rotator cuff tendons if performed with poor form or excessive weight.

hypertension.explanation: Avoid holding breath (Valsalva maneuver) to prevent spikes in blood pressure.

osteoporosis.explanation: Care should be taken to avoid excessive spinal flexion or jerking movements that could increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce load and allow for more controlled movement.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with one arm at a time to increase core stabilization demands.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a chest-supported row machine to minimize lumbar strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a wider grip to reduce shoulder internal rotation and impingement risk.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight is manageable to maintain control throughout the movement.
Avoid jerking or using momentum to pull the weight.
Maintain a neutral spine position to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back throughout the movement.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Pull with your elbows, not your hands, to engage the back muscles effectively.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the pull.
Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Leaning too far back at the end of the pull.

name: Seated Cable Shoulder Press
instructions: Adjust the weight to an appropriate amount and be seated, grasping the handles. Your upper arms should be about 90 degrees to the body, with your head and chest up. The elbows should also be bent to about 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Begin by extending through the elbow, pressing the handles together above your head.
After pausing at the top, return the handles to the starting position. Ensure that you maintain tension on the cables.
You can also execute this movement with your back off the pad and alternate hands.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: This exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen tears or delay healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: The load and range of motion can increase joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The overhead position may strain the neck, aggravating conditions like herniated discs or stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Overhead pressing can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not be ready for the stress of this exercise, risking re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder bursitis: The movement can irritate the bursa, worsening inflammation and pain.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure back support by using a bench with a backrest to maintain spinal alignment.

safetyNotes: Always warm up the shoulder joint with dynamic movements before performing this exercise.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the press to maintain joint safety.
Ensure the weight is manageable to maintain control throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid unnecessary strain.
Press the handles up and slightly forward to follow the natural scapular plane.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder joint stress.
Failing to control the eccentric phase, leading to potential injury.

name: Seated Calf Raise
instructions: Sit on the machine and place your toes on the lower portion of the platform provided with the heels extending off. Choose the toe positioning of your choice (forward, in, or out) as per the beginning of this chapter.

Place your lower thighs under the lever pad, which will need to be adjusted according to the height of your thighs. Now place your hands on top of the lever pad in order to prevent it from slipping forward.
Lift the lever slightly by pushing your heels up and release the safety bar. This will be your starting position.
Slowly lower your heels by bending at the ankles until the calves are fully stretched. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Raise the heels by extending the ankles as high as possible as you contract the calves and breathe out. Hold the top contraction for a second.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: Moderate severity. The exercise places stress on the Achilles tendon, which may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.Plantar fasciitis: Moderate severity. The exercise can increase tension on the plantar fascia, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.Recent ankle sprain: High severity. Ankle stability is compromised, and the exercise may delay healing or cause further injury.
contraindicationDetails.Severe osteoarthritis in the ankle: High severity. The exercise can increase joint stress and exacerbate pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.Peripheral neuropathy: Moderate severity. Reduced sensation may lead to improper form and increased risk of injury.

modifications.easier: Perform seated calf raises without additional weight or use a resistance band for lighter resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the machine or perform single-leg seated calf raises to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Ensure proper lumbar support and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Adjust the seat height to ensure knees are not overly flexed, reducing stress on the joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height to avoid excessive strain on the knees and back.
Do not lock the knees; keep them slightly bent to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability and support the lower back.
Move through a full range of motion, ensuring a controlled descent and ascent.
Avoid bouncing or using momentum to lift the weight.
commonMistakes: Allowing the heels to drop too quickly, which can strain the Achilles tendon.
Using too much weight, leading to compromised form and increased injury risk.
Not adjusting the seat and lever pad properly, leading to poor biomechanics.

name: Seated Calf Stretch
instructions: Sit up straight on an exercise mat.
Bend one knee and put that foot on the floor to stabilize the torso.
Straighten your other leg and flex your ankle.
Using a band, towel, or your hand if you can reach, pull the toes toward you. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds, then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: Stretching the calf can exacerbate symptoms by placing additional strain on the Achilles tendon.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: Pulling the toes towards you can increase tension on the plantar fascia, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle sprain: The exercise may stress healing ligaments and delay recovery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint stiffness and pain may be aggravated by the stretch, especially if the knee is involved.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Flexing the ankle and stretching the calf can increase tension along the sciatic nerve pathway, potentially worsening symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with a towel or band to reduce the need for flexibility and reach.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds and add a slight forward lean to increase the stretch intensity.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch while lying on your back with the leg elevated to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep a slight bend in the knee to reduce strain on the joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing during the stretch to prevent muscle strain.
Do not force the stretch beyond a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Sit up straight with your spine neutral.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
Flex the ankle of the extended leg to engage the calf muscle.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back instead of maintaining an upright posture.
Pulling too hard on the toes, leading to discomfort or strain.
Holding the breath instead of breathing steadily.

name: Seated Close-Grip Concentration Barbell Curl
instructions: Sit down on a flat bench with a barbell or E-Z Bar in front of you in between your legs. Your legs should be spread with the knees bent and the feet on the floor.

Use your arms to pick the barbell up and place the back of your upper arms on top of your inner thighs (around three and a half inches away from the front of the knee). A supinated grip closer than shoulder width is needed to perform this exercise. Tip: Your arm should be extended at arms length and the barbell should be above the floor. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the barbell back to starting position as your breathe in. Tip: Avoid swinging motions at any time.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: This exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position may cause discomfort or worsen symptoms due to the arm positioning and potential shoulder strain.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The close grip and supinated position can increase stress on the wrist joint, potentially aggravating pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip position may compress the median nerve further, increasing symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Stabilizing the arm during the curl can strain the shoulder, potentially aggravating an existing injury.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The seated position and need for core stabilization may strain the lower back, especially if posture is not maintained.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or switch to dumbbells for better control and reduced load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.wrist_pain: Use wrist wraps or a neutral grip bar to reduce strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion or use a cable machine for controlled resistance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at a comfortable height.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent form breakdown.
Maintain a neutral spine to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep your elbows stationary against your thighs.
Avoid swinging the barbell; focus on controlled movements.
Engage your core to maintain stability and posture.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the barbell.
Allowing the elbows to move away from the thighs.
Rounding the back or slouching during the exercise.

name: Seated Dumbbell Curl
instructions: Sit on a flat bench with a dumbbell on each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
Rotate the palms of the hands so that they are facing your torso. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the weights and start twisting the wrists once the dumbbells pass your thighs so that the palms of your hands face forward at the end of the movement. Make sure that you contract the biceps as you breathe out and make sure that only the forearms move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to the starting position as your breathe in and as you rotate the wrists back to a neutral grip.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: This exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to repetitive flexion and load on the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The movement may cause discomfort or pain due to the rotation of the shoulder joint during the curl.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with weight-bearing exercises in individuals with severe bone density loss.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The rotation of the shoulder during the curl can strain the rotator cuff muscles and tendons.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load on the joints.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing to engage core muscles or use heavier weights.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip (hammer curl) to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid shoulder rotation or perform a preacher curl to stabilize the shoulder.

safetyNotes: Avoid swinging the weights to prevent momentum from taking over the exercise.
Ensure the back is supported by the bench to prevent strain on the lower back.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Rotate wrists smoothly as you curl the weights up.
Focus on contracting the biceps at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and potential injury.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the body.
Not controlling the weight during the eccentric (lowering) phase.

name: Seated Dumbbell Inner Biceps Curl
instructions: Sit on the end of a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
Rotate the palms of the hands so that they are facing inward in a neutral position. This will be your starting position.
While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the dumbbells out and up, turning the palms out as you lift and keeping your forearms in line with your outer deltoids. Tips:

Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to the starting position as your breathe in. Remember to rotate your arms as you lower the dumbbells so that you can switch back to a neutral grip.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The rotation of the arm during the curl may aggravate shoulder impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The rotation and stabilization required can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The potential for bone stress and fractures is increased with weight-bearing exercises.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise standing to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a resistance band instead of dumbbells to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip throughout to minimize shoulder rotation.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the elbows and shoulders.
Ensure a controlled motion to maintain joint integrity and muscle engagement.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your torso throughout the movement.
Rotate your palms outward as you lift to target the inner biceps.
Squeeze your biceps at the top of the curl for maximum contraction.
commonMistakes: Using momentum by swinging the weights.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the body.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Seated Dumbbell Palms-Down Wrist Curl
instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on the floor in front of a flat bench.
Sit down on the edge of the flat bench with your legs at about shoulder width apart. Make sure to keep your feet on the floor.

Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against your thighs with the palms of the hands facing down. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge of your thighs.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.

Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling. Make sure to inhale during this part of the exercise. Tip: Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
When finished, simply lower the dumbbells to the floor.

contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to increased pressure on the median nerve during wrist flexion and extension.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive wrist movements can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow, particularly lateral epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.acute forearm strain: Performing this exercise can worsen the strain by overloading the forearm muscles.
contraindicationDetails.wrist arthritis: The exercise may cause discomfort or pain due to the load on the wrist joint.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter dumbbell or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist curls using a resistance band to reduce joint stress or perform isometric holds at the top of the curl.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the wrist and forearm muscles.
Ensure a full range of motion without jerking or sudden movements to reduce injury risk.
formCues: Keep your forearms stationary and only move your wrists.
Exhale as you curl your wrists upwards and inhale as you lower them.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid leaning forward.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled wrist movement.
Allowing the forearms to lift off the thighs, reducing isolation of the wrist extensors.
Holding the breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure unnecessarily.

name: Seated Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl
instructions: Start out by placing two dumbbells on the floor in front of a flat bench.
Sit down on the edge of the flat bench with your legs at about shoulder width apart. Make sure to keep your feet on the floor.

Use your arms to grab both of the dumbbells and bring them up so that your forearms are resting against your thighs with the palms of the hands facing up. Your wrists should be hanging over the edge of your thighs.
Start out by curling your wrist upwards and exhaling.

Slowly lower your wrists back down to the starting position while inhaling. Make sure to inhale during this part of the exercise. Tip: Your forearms should be stationary as your wrist is the only movement needed to perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
When finished, simply lower the dumbbells to the floor.

contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: This exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to repetitive wrist flexion, increasing pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive motion can aggravate tendinitis, particularly lateral or medial epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.acute forearm strain: Performing this exercise can worsen the strain due to the load on the forearm muscles.
contraindicationDetails.wrist arthritis: The exercise may increase joint stress and pain in individuals with arthritis in the wrist.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise with one dumbbell at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.carpal tunnel: Use a wrist brace to stabilize the wrist and reduce strain.
injury_friendly.elbow tendinitis: Perform wrist curls with a neutral grip to minimize strain on the elbow.

safetyNotes: Ensure the wrists are not hyperextended at the bottom of the movement.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Keep forearms stationary and resting on thighs.
Move only the wrists while keeping a controlled motion.
Exhale while curling up, inhale while lowering.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled wrist movement.
Letting the elbows lift off the thighs.
Hyperextending the wrists at the bottom of the movement.

name: Seated Dumbbell Press
instructions: Grab a couple of dumbbells and sit on a military press bench or a utility bench that has a back support on it as you place the dumbbells upright on top of your thighs.
Clean the dumbbells up one at a time by using your thighs to bring the dumbbells up to shoulder height at each side.
Rotate the wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing forward. This is your starting position.
As you exhale, push the dumbbells up until they touch at the top.
After a second pause, slowly come down back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may increase inflammation and pain in the tendons due to repetitive overhead motion.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The seated position with overhead load can strain the cervical spine, especially if there is pre-existing degeneration or herniation.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of vertebral fractures increases with overhead loading, especially in individuals with compromised bone density.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead pressing can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise standing to engage more core stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated dumbbell press with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support and engage core muscles to maintain spinal alignment.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench has adequate back support to prevent hyperextension of the lumbar spine.
Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Press the dumbbells directly overhead without flaring the elbows out too wide.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Arching the back excessively during the press.
Allowing the elbows to flare out too wide.

name: Seated Flat Bench Leg Pull-In
instructions: Sit on a bench with the legs stretched out in front of you slightly below parallel and your arms holding on to the sides of the bench. Your torso should be leaning backwards around a 45-degree angle from the bench. This will be your starting position.
Bring the knees in toward you as you move your torso closer to them at the same time. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
After a second pause, go back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The flexion of the spine during this exercise can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the intervertebral discs.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion of the spine may increase nerve compression, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise may cause excessive movement at the vertebrae, increasing instability.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The movement can irritate the sciatic nerve, especially if the lumbar spine is not supported.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The flexion and potential spinal loading can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: The hip flexion involved may aggravate symptoms in individuals with hip joint arthritis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with feet on the ground, sliding them in and out to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Hold a light dumbbell between the feet to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a stability ball to support the lower back.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Avoid jerking movements; perform the exercise in a controlled manner.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement.
Keep the chest open and shoulders back.
Exhale as you bring the knees in, inhale as you extend them.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Holding breath during the exercise.

name: Seated Floor Hamstring Stretch
instructions: Sit on a mat with your right leg extended in front of you and your left leg bent with your foot against your right inner thigh.
Lean forward from your hips and reach for your ankle until you feel a stretch in your hamstring. Hold for 15 seconds, then repeat for your other side.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward bending motion can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the intervertebral discs.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Stretching may irritate the sciatic nerve, especially if there is nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.recent hamstring strain: Stretching a recently strained muscle can delay healing and increase the risk of re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Forward bending can increase the risk of vertebral fractures due to decreased bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Forward flexion may aggravate lower back pain by stressing the lumbar spine.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with a towel or strap around the foot to reduce the need for forward flexion.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds and add a slight dorsiflexion of the foot to intensify the stretch.

injury_friendly.back pain: Sit with a straight back against a wall to maintain spinal alignment and reduce lumbar strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Place a small cushion under the bent knee to reduce discomfort.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Do not force the stretch beyond a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Keep the spine elongated and hinge from the hips, not the lower back.
Relax the shoulders and neck to avoid unnecessary tension.
Breathe deeply to facilitate muscle relaxation.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back instead of hinging from the hips.
Pulling on the foot or ankle too aggressively.
Holding the breath during the stretch.

name: Seated Front Deltoid
instructions: Sit upright on the floor with your legs bent, your partner standing behind you. Stick your arms straight out to your sides, with your palms facing the ground. Attempt to move them as far behind you as possible, as your assistant holds your wrists. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your elbows straight, attempt to move your arms to the front, with your partner gently restraining you to prevent any actual movement for 10-20 seconds.
Now, relax your muscles and allow your partner to gently increase the stretch on the shoulders and chest. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating impingement due to the overhead and stretching nature of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Potential to aggravate existing injuries due to the stretching and isometric contraction involved.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Sitting posture and potential neck strain could worsen cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric exercises can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of fracture or injury due to the stretching and force applied to the shoulder girdle.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a partner, allowing for controlled resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the duration of the isometric hold to 30 seconds or add light weights to the wrists.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise lying supine with arms supported by a pillow to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure your partner applies gentle and controlled resistance.
Avoid any jerking or sudden movements during the stretch.
Stop immediately if you experience any pain or discomfort.
formCues: Sit upright with a neutral spine.
Keep your shoulders down and away from your ears.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to elevate towards the ears.
Bending the elbows during the isometric hold.
Overstretching beyond a comfortable range of motion.

name: Seated Glute
instructions: In a seated position with your knees bent, cross one ankle over the opposite knee. Your partner will stand behind you. Now, lean forward as your partner braces your shoulders with their hands. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to push your torso back for 10-20 seconds, as your partner prevents any actual movement of your torso.
Now relax your muscles as your partner increases the stretch by gently pushing your torso forward for 10-20 seconds.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, sciatica, or spinal stenosis should avoid this exercise due to the forward flexion and potential for increased spinal pressure.

hip_joint_issues.details: Those with hip impingement or arthritis may experience discomfort due to the external rotation and flexion of the hip joint.

knee_joint_issues.details: Crossing the ankle over the knee may exacerbate pain or discomfort in individuals with knee arthritis or tendinitis.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, should avoid exercises that involve forward bending and external pressure on the abdomen.

surgical_recovery.details: Individuals recovering from recent hip, knee, or spinal surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if experiencing recent trauma or injury to the lower back, hips, or knees.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch without a partner, leaning forward only as far as comfortable.
modifications.harder: Hold the forward stretch for a longer duration or add a gentle twist to increase the stretch on the glutes.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the stretch lying on your back with one ankle crossed over the opposite knee, pulling the uncrossed leg towards your chest.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Avoid crossing the ankle over the knee; instead, place the foot on the ground and lean forward gently.

safetyNotes: Ensure the partner applies gentle and controlled pressure.
Avoid bouncing or jerking movements during the stretch.
Communicate with your partner to avoid overstretching.
formCues: Keep your back straight as you lean forward.
Engage your core to support your lower back.
Breathe deeply and consistently throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively.
Forcing the stretch beyond comfort.
Not communicating with the partner about the level of pressure.

name: Seated Good Mornings
instructions: Set up a box in a power rack. The pins should be set at an appropriate height. Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders, not on top of your traps. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders.

Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back. Keep your head facing forward. With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the bar tight, bend forward at the hips as much as possible. If you set the pins to what would be parallel, you not only have a safety if you fail, but know when to stop.
Pause just above the pins and reverse the motion until your torso it upright.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The forward bending motion can exacerbate disc herniation and increase intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - Flexion of the spine can worsen symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise can increase shear forces on the spine, worsening slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - Forward bending can irritate the sciatic nerve; modifications are necessary.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis: moderate - Spinal loading and flexion can aggravate joint pain; modifications needed.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - The spinal loading and flexion increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: high - Healing tissues are vulnerable to stress and strain from this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a dowel or PVC pipe instead of a barbell to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise standing for greater range of motion.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter weight and limit the range of motion to avoid excessive spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure knees are stable and aligned; use a lighter weight to reduce stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely positioned on the back, not the neck.
Use a spotter or safety pins set at an appropriate height to catch the bar if needed.
Avoid excessive forward flexion to protect the spine.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine by not rounding your back.
Push your hips back as you bend forward, keeping the weight over your mid-foot.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Seated Hamstring
instructions: In a seated position with your legs extended, have your partner stand behind you. Now, lean forward as your partner braces your shoulders with their hands. This will be your starting position.
Attempt to push your torso back for 10-20 seconds, as your partner prevents any actual movement of your torso.
Now relax your muscles as your partner increases the stretch by gently pushing your torso forward for 10-20 seconds.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. Forward flexion can exacerbate disc herniation and increase pressure on the spinal nerves.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity. Stretching in this manner can aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to increased tension in the nerve pathway.
contraindicationDetails.recent hamstring strain: High severity. Stretching a recently strained muscle can delay healing and increase the risk of re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Forward bending can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: High severity. Forward flexion can increase discomfort and exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Moderate severity. Assistance from a partner is required to prevent falls or instability during the stretch.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch lying on your back with one leg extended and the other leg bent, using a towel or strap to gently pull the extended leg towards you.
modifications.harder: Perform the stretch with a resistance band around the feet, providing additional tension as you lean forward.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch lying on your back with knees bent, gently pulling one knee towards your chest at a time.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform the stretch in a supine position with a towel or strap around the foot, keeping the knee slightly bent.

safetyNotes: Ensure the partner is trained to apply gentle and controlled pressure.
Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep the spine neutral and avoid excessive rounding of the back.
Engage the core to support the lower back during the stretch.
Breathe deeply and steadily to facilitate muscle relaxation.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively during the forward lean.
Applying too much force too quickly, leading to muscle strain.
Holding the breath, which can increase tension and reduce effectiveness.

name: Seated Hamstring and Calf Stretch
instructions: Loop a belt, rope, or band around one foot. Sit down with both legs extended . This will be your starting position.
Leaning forward slightly, pull on the belt to draw the toes of your foot back. Hold this position for 10-20 seconds and then repeat with the other leg.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or severe sciatica should avoid forward flexion of the spine, which can exacerbate symptoms.

joint_issues.details: Knee or hip arthritis may limit range of motion and cause discomfort during the stretch.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid excessive forward flexion, especially in the third trimester, due to changes in balance and flexibility.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent lower limb or spinal surgery patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis patients should avoid excessive spinal flexion to reduce the risk of vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the knee slightly bent to reduce tension on the hamstrings and lower back.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30-45 seconds or perform the stretch with both feet simultaneously.
modifications.injury_friendly: For back pain, perform the stretch lying on your back with one leg raised and supported by a band.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Do not force the stretch beyond a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips rather than rounding the spine.
Engage your core to support the lower back during the stretch.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively, which can increase the risk of spinal injury.
Pulling too hard on the band, leading to overstretching.

name: Seated Head Harness Neck Resistance
instructions: Place a neck strap on the floor at the end of a flat bench. Once you have selected the weights, sit at the end of the flat bench with your feet wider than shoulder width apart from each other. Your toes should be pointed out.

Slowly move your torso forward until it is almost parallel with the floor. Using both hands, securely position the neck strap around your head. Tip: Make sure the weights are still lying on the floor to prevent any strain on the neck. Now grab the weight with both hands while elevating your torso back until it is almost perpendicular to the floor. Note: Your head and torso needs to be slightly tilted forward to perform this exercise.
Now place both hands on top of your knees. This is the starting position.
Slowly lower your neck down until your chin touches the upper part of your chest while breathing in.
While exhaling, bring your neck back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
contraindications: severe arthritis in the cervical spine

contraindicationDetails.cervical spine injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or other cervical spine injuries should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Those with osteoporosis are at increased risk of fractures, particularly in the cervical region, making this exercise potentially hazardous.
contraindicationDetails.recent neck surgery: Post-surgical patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent complications or re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the cervical spine: This exercise may increase pain and inflammation in individuals with advanced arthritis in the neck.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The forward-leaning position may pose a fall risk for individuals with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights, using only the resistance of the neck strap.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight incrementally while maintaining proper form.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a resistance band instead of weights to reduce the load on the neck and allow for more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the neck strap is securely fastened and comfortable.
Avoid jerking or rapid movements to prevent neck strain.
Start with a light weight to assess tolerance and form.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support your lower back.
Maintain a slight forward tilt of the head and torso throughout the movement.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on the neck muscles.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the torso to sway or move excessively.
Failing to keep the core engaged, leading to lower back strain.

name: Seated Leg Curl
instructions: Adjust the machine lever to fit your height and sit on the machine with your back against the back support pad.

Place the back of lower leg on top of padded lever (just a few inches under the calves) and secure the lap pad against your thighs, just above the knees. Then grasp the side handles on the machine as you point your toes straight (or you can also use any of the other two stances) and ensure that the legs are fully straight right in front of you. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, pull the machine lever as far as possible to the back of your thighs by flexing at the knees. Keep your torso stationary at all times. Hold the contracted position for a second.
Slowly return to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with spinal injuries such as herniated discs or sciatica should use caution due to potential strain on the lower back from improper seating posture or excessive weight.

knee_joint_issues.explanation: Those with knee arthritis, tendinitis, or recent knee surgeries should avoid this exercise as it places direct stress on the knee joint during flexion.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should monitor exertion levels, as the seated position can increase blood pressure.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to potential discomfort and strain on the lower back.

acute_injuries.explanation: Avoid if experiencing acute hamstring or calf strains or recent lower limb trauma.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight and perform partial range of motion to reduce strain on the knees.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight and perform the exercise with a controlled tempo, focusing on a slow eccentric phase.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Ensure proper lumbar support and use a lighter weight to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep flexion and use minimal resistance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to fit your body size.
Avoid hyperextending the knees at the starting position.
Do not use excessive weight that causes form breakdown.
formCues: Keep your back firmly against the pad.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
Move through the knees without swinging your body.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to improper form.
Allowing the knees to lock out forcefully at the end of the extension.
Failing to adjust the machine to fit your leg length.

name: Seated Leg Tucks
instructions: Sit on a bench with the legs stretched out in front of you slightly below parallel and your arms holding on to the sides of the bench. Your torso should be leaning backwards around a 45-degree angle from the bench. This will be your starting position.
Bring the knees in toward you as you move your torso closer to them at the same time. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
After a second pause, go back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The flexion and compression of the spine during seated leg tucks can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. Spinal flexion can increase pressure on the spinal cord or nerves.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise may increase anterior shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity. The movement can irritate the sciatic nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Spinal flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. The exercise may cause discomfort or strain on the abdominal area.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. The exercise can stress the healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with one leg at a time to reduce the load on the core.
modifications.harder: Hold a light dumbbell between the feet to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with the back supported against a bench or wall to minimize spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid full knee flexion to reduce stress on the knees.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking movements to prevent unnecessary strain on the spine.
Maintain a controlled pace to ensure proper form and reduce injury risk.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement to stabilize the spine.
Keep the movement smooth and controlled, avoiding any bouncing or jerking.
Exhale as you bring your knees towards your chest and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively, which can increase spinal stress.
Using momentum instead of core engagement to complete the movement.
Holding the breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure.

name: Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Down Wrist Curl
instructions: Sit on a flat bench with a dumbbell in your right hand.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart.

Lean forward and place your right forearm on top of your upper right thigh with your palm down. Tip: Make sure that the back of the wrist lies on top of your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the dumbbell as far as possible as you keep a tight grip on the dumbbell. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Now curl the dumbbell as high as possible as you contract the forearms and as you exhale. Keep the contraction for a second before you lower again. Tip: The only movement should happen at the wrist.
Perform for the recommended amount of repetitions, switch arms and repeat the movement.
contraindications: arthritis in the wrist or elbow

contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: This exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to increased pressure on the median nerve during wrist flexion and extension.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive wrist movements can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow, particularly lateral epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.acute forearm strain: Performing this exercise can worsen strain injuries due to the load on the forearm muscles.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis in the wrist or elbow: The repetitive motion and load can increase joint pain and inflammation.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter dumbbell or perform the exercise without weights to focus on the range of motion and muscle activation.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist curls with a resistance band to reduce joint stress and allow for a more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the wrist and forearm muscles.
Ensure the forearm is fully supported on the thigh to avoid unnecessary stress on the elbow.
formCues: Keep the forearm flat and stable on the thigh throughout the movement.
Focus on moving only the wrist, keeping the rest of the arm stationary.
Maintain a firm but not overly tight grip on the dumbbell.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the dumbbell instead of isolating the wrist movement.
Allowing the elbow to lift off the thigh, reducing stability and increasing injury risk.
Holding the breath during the exercise, which can increase blood pressure.

name: Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl
instructions: Sit on a flat bench with a dumbbell in your right hand.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart.

Lean forward and place your right forearm on top of your upper right thigh with your palm up. Tip: Make sure that the front of the wrist lies on top of your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the dumbbell as far as possible as you keep a tight grip on the dumbbell. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Now curl the dumbbell as high as possible as you contract the forearms and as you exhale. Keep the contraction for a second before you lower again. Tip: The only movement should happen at the wrist.
Perform for the recommended amount of repetitions, switch arms and repeat the movement.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The exercise involves wrist flexion, which can exacerbate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive wrist flexion may aggravate tendinitis in the elbow.

acute forearm strain.explanation: Performing this exercise with an acute strain can worsen the injury.

wrist arthritis.explanation: The exercise may cause discomfort or pain in individuals with wrist arthritis due to joint stress.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter dumbbell or perform the exercise without weights to focus on the movement pattern.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform wrist curls with a resistance band to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort and use a lighter weight.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the wrist and forearm.
Ensure the wrist is supported on the thigh to stabilize the movement.
formCues: Keep the forearm flat on the thigh to isolate the wrist flexors.
Move only at the wrist joint; avoid using the shoulder or elbow to lift the weight.
Maintain a controlled movement throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled wrist flexion.
Allowing the elbow to lift off the thigh, reducing isolation of the forearm muscles.
Holding the breath, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure unnecessarily.

name: Seated One-arm Cable Pulley Rows
instructions: To get into the starting position, first sit down on the machine and place your feet on the front platform or crossbar provided making sure that your knees are slightly bent and not locked.
Lean over as you keep the natural alignment of your back and grab the single handle attachment with your left arm using a palms-down grip.

With your arm extended pull back until your torso is at a 90-degree angle from your legs. Your back should be slightly arched and your chest should be sticking out. You should be feeling a nice stretch on your lat as you hold the bar in front of you. The right arm can be kept by the waist. This is the starting position of the exercise.

Keeping the torso stationary, pull the handles back towards your torso while keeping the arms close to it as you rotate the wrist, so that by the time your hand is by your abdominals it is in a neutral position (palms facing the torso). Breathe out as you perform that movement. At that point you should be squeezing your back muscles hard.

Hold that contraction for a second and slowly go back to the original position while breathing in. Tip: Remember to rotate the wrist as you go back to the starting position so that the palms are facing down again.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform the same movement with the right hand.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward flexion and pulling motion can exacerbate disc herniation symptoms by increasing intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The seated position and spinal loading may aggravate symptoms by compressing the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase lumbar lordosis, potentially worsening vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The shoulder rotation and pulling can irritate the subacromial space, worsening impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The repetitive pulling motion can exacerbate inflammation in the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The exercise may pose a risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal loading.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight and perform the exercise with both arms simultaneously to reduce load on each arm.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise standing to engage more core stabilization.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a supported chest pad to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid full extension to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is properly set up and secure before starting.
Avoid jerking or using momentum to pull the cable.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Pull the handle towards your torso, keeping your elbow close to your body.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the pull.
Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the shoulder to internally rotate excessively.

name: Seated Overhead Stretch
instructions: Sit up straight on an exercise mat.
Touch the soles of your feet together with your feet six to eight inches in front of your hips.
Place one hand on the floor beside you and your other hand behind your head.
Lift your elbow to the ceiling as you incline your torso to the other side. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds, then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The seated overhead stretch involves lateral flexion of the spine, which can exacerbate symptoms in individuals with a herniated disc.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arm overhead can increase subacromial space compression, worsening symptoms of shoulder impingement.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead movements can increase blood pressure; individuals with uncontrolled hypertension should avoid this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal flexion and rotation can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Lateral flexion may aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to increased pressure on the lumbar spine.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the arm resting on the hip instead of overhead to reduce the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Extend the arm fully overhead and hold a light dumbbell to increase the stretch and engage stabilizing muscles.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch while lying on your back with knees bent to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep the hand on the hip and focus on gentle side bending without lifting the elbow.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive lateral flexion to prevent spinal strain.
Do not force the stretch; move within a comfortable range of motion.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Sit up tall with a straight back.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Lift the elbow towards the ceiling without rotating the torso.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the stretch.
Allowing the head to drop forward.
Overextending the arm, causing shoulder strain.

recommendedReps.mobility: Perform dynamic movements for 5-10 reps per side

name: Seated Palm-Up Barbell Wrist Curl
instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands and your palms facing up; hands spaced about shoulder width.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart.
Lean forward and place your forearms on top of your upper thighs with your palms up. Tip: Make sure that the front of the wrists lay on top of your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the bar as far as possible while inhaling and keeping a tight grip.
Now curl bar up as high as possible while flexing the forearms and exhaling. Hold the contraction at the top for a second and Tip: Only the wrist should move.

contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: High severity. The repetitive motion of wrist curls can exacerbate inflammation and pain in tendons.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate severity. The exercise may increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis in the wrist: Moderate severity. Joint stress from the exercise can increase pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.recent wrist fracture: High severity. The exercise should be avoided until full recovery and clearance by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Risk of fracture due to bone fragility, especially with added weight.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load and stress on the wrists.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a thicker bar to increase grip challenge, or use a wrist roller.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist curls with a resistance band to decrease joint stress and allow for controlled resistance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the wrists are supported on the knees to prevent excessive strain.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent injury to the wrist and forearm muscles.
formCues: Keep forearms stationary and only move the wrists.
Maintain a firm grip on the barbell throughout the exercise.
Exhale while curling the bar up and inhale while lowering it.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the bar instead of controlled wrist movement.
Allowing the elbows to lift off the thighs, reducing isolation of the forearm muscles.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.

name: Seated Palms-Down Barbell Wrist Curl
instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands and your palms facing down; hands spaced about shoulder width.
Place your feet flat on the floor, at a distance that is slightly wider than shoulder width apart.
Lean forward and place your forearms on top of your upper thighs with your palms down. Tip: Make sure that the back of the wrists lay on top of your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the bar as far as possible while inhaling and keeping a tight grip.
Now curl bar up as high as possible while flexing the forearms and exhaling. Hold the contraction at the top for a second and Tip: Only the wrist should move.

wrist tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive motion and load on the wrist can exacerbate inflammation and pain.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: The position and movement can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.

arthritis in the wrist.explanation: The exercise may increase joint stress and discomfort, necessitating modifications or avoidance.

recent wrist fracture.explanation: The exercise places stress on the wrist, which may impede healing or cause re-injury.

severe osteoporosis.explanation: The risk of fracture due to bone fragility may be increased with this exercise.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a thicker bar to increase grip challenge.

injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use a wrist brace to provide support and limit motion.
injury_friendly.arthritis: Perform wrist curls with a resistance band to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent wrist strain.
Ensure wrists are supported by knees to minimize stress.
formCues: Keep elbows stationary and close to the body.
Focus on controlled movements to engage forearm muscles effectively.
Exhale during the upward curl and inhale while lowering the bar.
commonMistakes: Using momentum by swinging the barbell.
Allowing elbows to lift off thighs, reducing stability.
Gripping the bar too tightly, causing unnecessary tension.

name: Seated Side Lateral Raise
instructions: Pick a couple of dumbbells and sit at the end of a flat bench with your feet firmly on the floor. Hold the dumbbells with your palms facing in and your arms straight down at your sides at arms' length. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso stationary (no swinging), lift the dumbbells to your side with a slight bend on the elbow and the hands slightly tilted forward as if pouring water in a glass. Continue to go up until you arms are parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this movement and pause for a second at the top.
Lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Lifting the arms laterally can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves significant shoulder abduction, which can aggravate tendinitis by overloading the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights can strain the neck, particularly if the head is not aligned properly, potentially worsening cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with osteoporosis, especially if form is compromised or if the weights are too heavy.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that stress the shoulder until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or perform the exercise without weights to focus on form and shoulder mobility.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing to engage more core stabilizers or use resistance bands for variable resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, keeping the elbows slightly bent and below shoulder height.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support by using a bench with back support or perform the exercise standing with a slight knee bend.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid neck and back strain.
Do not lock the elbows to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the shoulders down and away from the ears.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Lift the dumbbells with control, avoiding momentum.
commonMistakes: Using momentum or swinging the weights.
Lifting the shoulders towards the ears.
Hyperextending the elbows.

name: Seated Triceps Press
instructions: Sit down on a bench with back support and grasp a dumbbell with both hands and hold it overhead at arm's length. Tip: a better way is to have somebody hand it to you especially if it is very heavy. The resistance should be resting in the palms of your hands with your thumbs around it. The palm of the hand should be facing inward. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your upper arms close to your head (elbows in) and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semi-circular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the dumbbell. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The triceps press places stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise requires stabilization from the rotator cuff, which can be problematic if injured.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Any recent surgical intervention in the shoulder, elbow, or wrist may require avoiding this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The overhead position can place strain on the cervical spine, especially if the weight is heavy.
