modifications.easier: Use a lighter dumbbell or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise standing to engage more core muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a triceps kickback instead to avoid overhead movement.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use resistance bands to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper back support and engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.

safetyNotes: Always use a bench with back support to prevent hyperextension of the spine.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
Ensure a spotter is present if using heavy weights.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the head to target the triceps effectively.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
commonMistakes: Flaring elbows outwards, which reduces triceps activation.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the back to arch excessively, leading to potential injury.

name: Seated Two-Arm Palms-Up Low-Pulley Wrist Curl
instructions: Put a bench in front of a low pulley machine that has a barbell or EZ Curl attachment on it.
Move the bench far enough away so that when you bring the handle to the top of your thighs tension is created on the cable due to the weight stack being moved up.
Now hold the handle with both hands, palms up, using a shoulder-width grip.
Step back and sit on the bench with your feet about shoulder width apart, firmly on the floor.
Lean forward and place the forearms on your thighs with the back of your wrists over your knees. This will be your starting position.
Lower the bar as far as possible, while inhaling and keeping a tight grip.
Now curl the bar up as high as possible while contracting the forearms. Tip: Only the wrist should move; not the forearms.
After a second contraction at the top go back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
contraindications: severe arthritis in the wrist or elbow

contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: This exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to repetitive wrist flexion and grip strength requirements.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The repetitive motion of wrist curls can aggravate tendinitis, leading to increased pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and curling action may worsen symptoms of tendinitis in the elbow, such as lateral or medial epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the wrist or elbow: The exercise may increase joint stress and pain in individuals with advanced arthritis.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load on the wrists.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a thicker grip bar to increase grip strength demands.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use wrist supports or wraps to stabilize the joint and reduce strain if experiencing mild discomfort.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and positioned correctly to avoid tipping.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form and increases injury risk.
formCues: Keep elbows stationary and close to the body.
Focus on moving only the wrists during the curl.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid leaning excessively forward.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to lift off the thighs.
Rounding the back or slouching during the exercise.

name: See-Saw Press (Alternating Side Press)
instructions: Grab a dumbbell with each hand and stand up erect.

Clean (lift) the dumbbells to the chest/shoulder level and then rotate your wrists so that your palms are facing towards you as if you were getting ready to perform an Arnold Press. This will be your starting position.

Now start extending your left arm overhead as you rotate the wrist so that the palm of your hand faces forward as you go up. Your elbows should come out also as you lift the weight. Simultaneously, you will also be bending from your hip to your opposite side. Tip: If you perform the exercise correctly, is should look as if you are trying to reach for something overhead on the right hand side of your body, but with your left arm. Breathe out as you perform this movement.
Once you reach the top position breathe in. Then, with the weight fully extended overhead and you bent over to your right hand side, begin the movement to the left side.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may place excessive stress on the rotator cuff tendons, worsening inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The overhead and lateral bending movements can strain the cervical spine, potentially aggravating existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The bending and twisting movements may increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead pressing can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The lateral bending and twisting can increase intradiscal pressure, risking further disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The bending motion may aggravate sciatic nerve symptoms due to increased lumbar spine stress.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands and focus on shoulder movement.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a strict overhead press without the lateral bending to minimize shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Avoid lateral bending and perform the exercise with a neutral spine, focusing on the shoulder press only.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent excessive lumbar stress.
Avoid excessive lateral bending to minimize risk to the spine and maintain balance.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without compromising form.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Keep your elbows slightly bent at the top of the press to reduce joint stress.
Rotate your wrist smoothly as you press overhead to ensure natural shoulder movement.
commonMistakes: Overarching the lower back during the press.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder strain.

name: Shotgun Row
instructions: Attach a single handle to a low cable.
After selecting the correct weight, stand a couple feet back with a wide-split stance. Your arm should be extended and your shoulder forward. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by retracting the shoulder and flexing the elbow. As you pull, supinate the wrist, turning the palm upward as you go.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The supination and retraction involved in the shotgun row can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The dynamic movement of the shoulder joint can increase inflammation and pain in individuals with tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The exercise involves spinal stabilization which can increase intradiscal pressure, potentially aggravating herniated discs.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to stress, and the exercise's range of motion may exceed safe limits for healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The isometric contraction required for stabilization can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated with the support of a bench to reduce the demand on core stabilization.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a single-arm row from a plank position to engage more core muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full retraction and supination, maintaining a neutral wrist position.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached before starting the exercise.
Avoid jerking motions to prevent undue stress on the shoulder and spine.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Initiate the pull by retracting the shoulder blade before bending the elbow.
Supinate the wrist gradually as you pull, not abruptly.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulder to elevate during the pull, which can lead to impingement.
Rounding the back or leaning excessively forward or backward.

name: Shoulder Circles
instructions: With shoulders relaxed and arms resting loosely at your sides (or in your lap if you're seated), gently roll your shoulders forward, up, back, and down.
Reverse direction. You can do this exercise alternating shoulders or both at the same time.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High severity. The movement may exacerbate symptoms by further compressing structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: High severity. The exercise could strain the rotator cuff muscles, delaying healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Moderate severity. Joint movement may cause pain or discomfort; modifications may be necessary.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High severity. Post-surgical protocols typically limit range of motion and load.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Moderate severity. Movement of the shoulders can affect the cervical spine, potentially worsening symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the load on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Add small weights in each hand to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform smaller circles or limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort.
injury_friendly.cervical spine issues: Keep the head and neck in a neutral position to avoid additional strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerky or rapid movements to prevent strain.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
formCues: Keep your shoulders relaxed throughout the movement.
Maintain a smooth, controlled motion when circling the shoulders.
commonMistakes: Shrugging the shoulders up towards the ears.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Shoulder Press - With Bands
instructions: To begin, stand on an exercise band so that tension begins at arm's length. Grasp the handles and lift them so that the hands are at shoulder height at each side.
Rotate the wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing forward. Your elbows should be bent, with the upper arms and forearms in line to the torso. This is your starting position.
As you exhale, lift the handles up until your arms are fully extended overhead.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead motion can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Lifting overhead may strain the injured tendons, delaying healing or worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The load on the spine and shoulders during the exercise could increase the risk of fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Overhead movements should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare professional to prevent compromising surgical repairs.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The overhead position may increase cervical spine loading, potentially aggravating conditions like stenosis or herniated discs.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: Overhead exercises can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the stabilization demand and use lighter resistance bands.
modifications.harder: Use a single arm at a time to increase core stabilization demand or use a thicker band for more resistance.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder pain, perform a seated shoulder press with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored under your feet to prevent snapping.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Press the bands overhead in a controlled manner, avoiding jerky movements.
Keep your elbows slightly in front of your body to protect the shoulder joint.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch excessively during the press.
Using momentum to lift the bands instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Failing to maintain wrist alignment, leading to unnecessary strain.

name: Shoulder Raise
instructions: Relax your arms to your sides and raise your shoulders up toward your ears, then back down.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the shoulders can exacerbate impingement by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: This exercise may increase strain on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening tears.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: The movement may increase pain and inflammation in individuals with advanced arthritis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the movement, risking re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Elevating the shoulders can increase cervical spine compression, aggravating conditions like stenosis or herniated discs.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce the load on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight in each hand to increase resistance.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform shoulder shrugs with a reduced range of motion or use resistance bands for controlled tension.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking or rapid movements to prevent muscle strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid unnecessary cervical stress.
formCues: Keep your neck relaxed and avoid tensing it.
Lift your shoulders straight up towards your ears without rotating them forward or backward.
Lower your shoulders slowly and with control.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the shoulders.
Allowing the head to tilt forward or backward.
Shrugging shoulders unevenly.

name: Shoulder Stretch
instructions: Reach your left arm across your body and hold it straight.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Stretching across the body may exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: This stretch can place undue stress on a compromised rotator cuff, potentially worsening the tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Individuals with severe arthritis may experience increased pain and inflammation with this stretch due to joint stress.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to stress, and this stretch could disrupt healing.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Reaching across the body may cause strain on the neck, aggravating existing cervical spine conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while seated to reduce balance demands and provide support.
modifications.harder: Add a gentle pull with the opposite hand to increase the stretch intensity.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the stretch with the arm slightly bent to reduce tension on the shoulder joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid overstretching to prevent injury.
Discontinue the stretch if you experience sharp pain.
Maintain a neutral neck position to avoid cervical strain.
formCues: Keep the arm straight but not locked.
Relax the shoulders and avoid shrugging.
Hold the stretch gently without bouncing.
commonMistakes: Overstretching the shoulder joint.
Shrugging the shoulders during the stretch.
Twisting the torso instead of isolating the shoulder.

name: Side-Lying Floor Stretch
instructions: First lie on your left side, bending your left knee in front of you to stabilize your torso (use your abdominal muscles as well to hold you upright).

Straighten your right leg and rest the right foot on the floor behind your left. Straighten your right arm over your head and gently pull on your right wrist to stretch the entire right side of the body. Switch sides.

herniated_disc.explanation: This exercise involves lateral flexion which can exacerbate disc herniation symptoms.

spinal_stenosis.explanation: Lateral bending may increase pressure on the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.

spondylolisthesis.explanation: The position can increase lumbar instability, potentially aggravating the condition.

severe_osteoporosis.explanation: Risk of fractures due to lateral bending and potential falls.

recent_abdominal_surgery.explanation: Stretching may put undue stress on healing tissues.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: Overhead arm position can exacerbate impingement symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the bottom leg straight and the top leg bent for additional support.
modifications.harder: Add a slight twist of the torso towards the ceiling to increase the stretch intensity.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the stretch with a pillow under the head and avoid excessive lateral flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Keep the arm lower, parallel to the body, to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive lateral flexion to prevent strain on the spine.
Ensure a stable position to prevent falls or loss of balance.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the torso.
Keep the neck in a neutral position, aligned with the spine.
Gently pull on the wrist without forcing the stretch.
commonMistakes: Overstretching the arm, leading to shoulder strain.
Allowing the torso to collapse, reducing the effectiveness of the stretch.
Neglecting core engagement, leading to instability.

name: Side Bridge

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The side bridge can place lateral stress on the spine, exacerbating disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The exercise may increase spinal compression, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The lateral load can aggravate vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: moderate - Weight-bearing on the shoulder may exacerbate impingement.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - Risk of vertebral fractures due to lateral loading; modifications advised.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: high - Increased intra-abdominal pressure can hinder recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform the side bridge with knees bent at 90 degrees to reduce the lever arm and decrease difficulty.
modifications.harder: Extend the top arm overhead or lift the top leg to increase instability and challenge core stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform on knees and focus on maintaining a neutral spine with minimal rotation.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Support the upper body on a stable surface such as a bench to reduce shoulder load.

safetyNotes: Ensure a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent excessive lateral flexion.
Avoid sagging or arching the lower back to reduce lumbar strain.
Discontinue if any sharp pain or discomfort occurs, especially in the spine or shoulder.
formCues: Align the elbow directly under the shoulder to provide stable support.
Engage the core and glutes to maintain a straight line from head to feet.
Keep the hips elevated and avoid letting them drop towards the floor.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag, reducing core engagement.
Positioning the elbow too far from the body, increasing shoulder strain.
Rotating the torso instead of maintaining a straight line.

name: Side Hop-Sprint
instructions: Stand to the side of a cone or hurdle.
Begin this drill by hopping sideways over the obstacle, rebounding out of your landing to hop back to where you started.
Hop for a prescribed number or repetitions as quickly as possible, and finish this drill by sprinting a short distance upon landing the last hop.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact lateral movements can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.acute ankle sprains: Lateral hopping can increase strain on healing ligaments.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise may increase the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by high-impact activities.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The intensity of the exercise may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled heart conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform lateral step-overs instead of hops, and walk instead of sprinting.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the obstacle or add a weighted vest.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform lateral shuffles instead of hops to reduce impact.
injury_friendly.ankle instability: Use a resistance band around the ankles for lateral walks.

safetyNotes: Ensure the landing surface is even and free from obstacles.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the joints and muscles for dynamic movement.
Maintain a soft knee bend upon landing to absorb impact.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Land softly with knees slightly bent.
Use your arms to aid in balance and propulsion.
commonMistakes: Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Allowing knees to collapse inward upon landing.
Neglecting to engage the core, leading to loss of balance.

name: Side Jackknife

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal flexion and rotation can exacerbate symptoms and increase disc pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion and rotation of the spine can narrow the spinal canal further, aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Spinal flexion and rotation may increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may irritate the sciatic nerve due to spinal flexion and rotation.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Spinal flexion increases the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The exercise may place stress on the shoulder joint, exacerbating impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The exercise may not be suitable due to changes in balance and core stability.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with knees bent to reduce leverage and decrease difficulty.
modifications.harder: Hold a light dumbbell in the top hand to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform side planks instead to reduce spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion or perform the exercise with the lower arm resting on the floor for support.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerky movements to prevent unnecessary strain on the spine.
Maintain a neutral spine position throughout the exercise.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating movement.
Lift the torso and legs simultaneously to maintain balance.
Keep the movement controlled and smooth.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle control.
Allowing the neck to strain forward.
Failing to engage the core adequately.

name: Side Lateral Raise
instructions: Pick a couple of dumbbells and stand with a straight torso and the dumbbells by your side at arms length with the palms of the hand facing you. This will be your starting position.

While maintaining the torso in a stationary position (no swinging), lift the dumbbells to your side with a slight bend on the elbow and the hands slightly tilted forward as if pouring water in a glass. Continue to go up until you arms are parallel to the floor. Exhale as you execute this movement and pause for a second at the top.
Lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead motion and abduction of the arm can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Lateral raises can strain the rotator cuff tendons, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights can increase tension in the neck and exacerbate cervical spine problems.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with any weight-bearing exercise, especially in the upper body.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder injuries: Any recent trauma or injury to the shoulder should be fully healed before performing this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a pause at the top or use heavier weights.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise seated or use a cable machine to reduce strain on the shoulder.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to reduce joint stress.
Do not swing the weights; control the movement throughout.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Lift the weights until your arms are parallel to the floor.
Tilt your hands slightly forward as if pouring water from a pitcher.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights.
Lifting the weights too high, above shoulder level.
Not maintaining a slight bend in the elbows.

name: Side Laterals to Front Raise
instructions: In a standing position, hold a pair of dumbbells at your side. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your elbows slightly bent, raise the weights directly in front of you to shoulder height, avoiding any swinging or cheating.
At the top of the exercise move the weights out in front of you, keeping your arms extended.
Lower the weights with a controlled motion.
On the next repetition, raise the weights in front of you to shoulder height before moving the weights laterally to your sides.
Lower the weights to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and lateral movements can exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves significant shoulder movement, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights at shoulder height can strain the neck, particularly if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture increases with overhead and lateral loading in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder injury: Any recent trauma or inflammation in the shoulder area can be worsened by this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on one leg to engage more core stabilizers.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the exercise seated to reduce spinal load and use a limited range of motion to avoid pain.

safetyNotes: Avoid using momentum to lift the weights.
Keep movements controlled and deliberate.
Do not lift weights above shoulder height.
formCues: Maintain a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Keep the shoulders down and back to avoid neck strain.
commonMistakes: Swinging the weights or using momentum.
Lifting weights too high, causing shoulder strain.
Allowing the back to arch excessively.

name: Side Leg Raises
instructions: Stand next to a chair, which you may hold onto as a support. Stand on one leg. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your leg straight, raise it as far out to the side as possible, and swing it back down, allowing it to cross the opposite leg.
Repeat this swinging motion 5-10 times, increasing the range of motion as you do so.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with lower back pain or conditions like herniated discs should proceed with caution as the exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to lateral movement and potential pelvic tilt.

joint_issues.details: Hip and knee arthritis or bursitis may be aggravated by the lateral movement. Modifications or alternative exercises should be considered.

pregnancy.details: During pregnancy, balance may be compromised. Holding onto a sturdy support is advised to prevent falls.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are any recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower extremities until fully healed.

neurological_conditions.details: Conditions affecting balance or proprioception may require additional support or supervision.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise lying on your side on a mat, lifting the top leg while keeping the bottom leg bent for stability.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance or perform the exercise without holding onto support.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform lying on your side to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort.

safetyNotes: Ensure the supporting surface is stable to prevent falls.
Avoid excessive swinging to maintain control and prevent injury.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the pelvis.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid locking the knee of the supporting leg.
commonMistakes: Allowing the torso to lean excessively to the side.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle activation.
Neglecting to engage the core, leading to pelvic tilt.

name: Side Lying Groin Stretch
instructions: Start off by lying on your right side and bend your right knee in front of you to stabilize the torso.
Rest your head on your right hand or shoulder. Lift your left leg upward and hold it by the back of the knee (easier) or the foot (harder).
Pull your left knee in toward your left shoulder and simultaneously press your foot or knee down to the floor. To intensify this stretch, straighten your left leg. Switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: The side lying groin stretch may exacerbate symptoms due to pressure on the hip joint.
contraindicationDetails.groin strain: Stretching the adductors can worsen a groin strain, delaying recovery.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Lying on the side and pulling the leg can strain the lower back, especially if there is existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: Post-surgical protocols often limit range of motion and stress on the hip joint.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The position may be uncomfortable and could strain the lower back or pelvis.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The stretch may aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to the position and pressure on the lower back.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The position may increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the top leg bent and supported by a pillow to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Straighten the top leg fully and pull it closer to the torso for a deeper stretch.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the stretch with the top leg supported on a chair or bench to reduce strain on the back.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Avoid pulling on the foot; instead, support the leg at the calf or thigh.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Do not force the stretch beyond a comfortable range of motion.
Ensure the supporting leg is stable to prevent rolling or twisting.
formCues: Keep the torso aligned and avoid twisting the spine.
Engage the core to support the lower back.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
commonMistakes: Pulling the leg too forcefully, leading to strain.
Allowing the torso to twist or collapse.
Holding the breath, which can increase tension.

recommendedReps.mobility: Perform dynamic movements for 10-15 reps per side.

name: Side Neck Stretch
instructions: Start with your shoulders relaxed, gently tilt your head towards your shoulder.
Assist stretch with a gentle pull on the side of the head.

contraindicationDetails.cervical spine injury: Individuals with recent or severe cervical spine injuries should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Those with severe osteoporosis are at risk of fractures, especially in the cervical vertebrae, during neck stretches.
contraindicationDetails.recent neck surgery: Post-operative patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.cervical stenosis: Narrowing of the spinal canal in the neck can be aggravated by neck stretches, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.cervical radiculopathy: Stretching may increase nerve compression symptoms in individuals with this condition.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while lying down to reduce the load on the neck muscles.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by gently pulling the head further towards the shoulder, ensuring no pain is felt.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with mild neck discomfort, perform the stretch seated with back support to stabilize the spine.

safetyNotes: Avoid overstretching to prevent muscle strain.
Stop immediately if you experience any sharp pain or dizziness.
Ensure movements are slow and controlled.
formCues: Keep shoulders relaxed and down.
Tilt the head gently without forcing the movement.
Use a gentle pull with the opposite hand for assistance.
commonMistakes: Tensing the shoulders during the stretch.
Pulling the head too forcefully.
Performing the stretch too quickly.

name: Side Standing Long Jump
instructions: Begin standing with your feet hip width apart in an athletic stance. Your head and chest should be up, knees and hips slightly bent. This will be your starting position.
Leaning to your right, extend through your hips, knees, and ankles to jump into the air. Block with the arms to lead the movement, jumping as far to your right as you can.
Land facing the same direction with your feet hip width apart, absorbing the impact through your lower body.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities can exacerbate symptoms and lead to further joint degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Jumping and landing can increase the risk of sprains or further instability.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: High-impact movements may interfere with healing and recovery.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise can increase the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.advanced osteoporosis: High-impact activities may increase the risk of fractures.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower limb injuries: Jumping can worsen injuries such as sprains or strains.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The exercise may impose excessive cardiovascular stress.

modifications.easier: Perform a side step instead of a jump to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Add a tuck jump at the peak of the jump for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform a lateral step with a slight bend in the knees, avoiding deep knee flexion.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform the movement on a softer surface to reduce impact.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on core engagement and reduce jump height to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the landing surface is stable and non-slip.
Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise.
Avoid locking the knees upon landing to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Use your arms to generate momentum and control the jump.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
commonMistakes: Landing with locked knees, increasing joint stress.
Not using arms effectively, reducing jump distance.
Allowing the knees to cave inward upon landing, risking injury.

name: Side To Side Chins
instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing forward using a wide grip.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at a wide grip, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

Pull your torso up while leaning to the left hand side until the bar almost touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space (no swinging) and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second of contraction, inhale as you go back to the starting position.

Now, pull your torso up while leaning to the right hand side until the bar almost touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second of contraction, inhale as you go back to the starting position.
Repeat steps 3-6 until you have performed the prescribed amount of repetitions for each side.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High stress on the shoulder joint can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The overhead pulling motion can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping the bar and pulling can worsen elbow tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The grip required can strain the wrists, especially if there are pre-existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Neck strain can occur if the head is not properly aligned.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The spinal loading and extension can exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can place undue stress on the lower back, worsening this condition.

modifications.easier: Use an assisted pull-up machine or resistance bands to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a dip belt or weighted vest.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a resistance band for assistance and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is secure and can support your body weight.
Avoid jerking or swinging motions to prevent injury.
Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your chest up and shoulders down and back throughout the movement.
Focus on pulling with your back muscles rather than your arms.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to gain momentum.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug upwards.
Using the forearms excessively instead of the back muscles.

name: Side Wrist Pull
instructions: This stretch works best standing. Cross your left arm over the midline of your body and hold the left wrist in your right hand down at the level of your hips. Start the stretch with a bent left arm.
Slowly straighten, pull, and lift it up to shoulder height, as pictured. Feel this stretch originate in your back, not your shoulders, and don't pull too hard on the shoulders joint. Switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Pulling on the shoulder joint can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to compression of the tendons or bursa.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The exercise may strain the rotator cuff, especially if there is already a partial or complete tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Joint stress from pulling can increase pain and inflammation in individuals with advanced arthritis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues need time to heal, and this exercise could disrupt the healing process.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Stretching across the body may place undue stress on the cervical spine, worsening conditions like cervical radiculopathy.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch seated to reduce balance demands and focus on gentle pulling.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by gently pulling the wrist further across the body, ensuring no pain is felt.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the stretch with the arm bent at 90 degrees to reduce stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch lying on your back to support the spine and reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling too hard on the shoulder joint to prevent strain.
Ensure the stretch is felt in the back and not excessively in the shoulder.
formCues: Keep the shoulders relaxed and down.
Focus on a gentle pull, feeling the stretch in the back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Pulling too hard on the shoulder joint.
Allowing the shoulder to rise towards the ear.
Twisting the torso instead of isolating the stretch to the shoulder girdle.

name: Side to Side Box Shuffle
instructions: Stand to one side of the box with your left foot resting on the middle of it.
To begin, jump up and over to the other side of the box, landing with your right foot on top of the box and your left foot on the floor. Swing your arms to aid your movement.
Continue shuffling back and forth across the box.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact movements can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Jumping and landing may increase spinal load and aggravate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise increases the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the impact and stress of jumping.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Jumping side to side can increase the risk of ankle sprains.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular conditions: The exercise elevates heart rate significantly, which may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled heart conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform a step-over instead of a jump, maintaining one foot on the ground at all times.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the box or add a weighted vest for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a lower box or step to reduce impact forces on the knees.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on stepping over rather than jumping to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and on a non-slip surface.
Wear supportive footwear to reduce impact on joints.
Warm up thoroughly before starting the exercise.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Land softly with a slight bend in the knees to absorb impact.
Use your arms to aid in the jumping motion and maintain rhythm.
commonMistakes: Landing with locked knees, increasing joint stress.
Not engaging the core, leading to loss of balance.
Using a box that is too high, increasing injury risk.

name: Single-Arm Cable Crossover
instructions: Begin by moving the pulleys to the high position, select the resistance to be used, and take a handle in each hand.

Step forward in front of both pulleys with your arms extended in front of you, bringing your hands together. Your head and chest should be up as you lean forward, while your feet should be staggered. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your left arm in place, allow your right arm to extend out to the side, maintaining a slight bend at the elbow. The right arm should be perpendicular to the body at approximately shoulder level.
Return your arm back to the starting position by pulling your hand back to the midline of the body.
Hold for a second at the starting position and repeat the movement on the opposite side. Continue alternating back and forth for the prescribed number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and lateral movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves significant shoulder movement, which can irritate inflamed tendons.
contraindicationDetails.chest surgery recovery: Post-surgical tissue may not withstand the stress of this exercise, risking re-injury or delayed healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The forward-leaning position and potential for imbalance could increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or chest injuries: Engaging injured tissues can worsen the injury and delay recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of cables to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a single leg to add a balance challenge.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder issues, perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion, keeping the elbow closer to the body to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is properly set up and stable before beginning.
Start with a lighter weight to master form before progressing to heavier loads.
Avoid locking the elbows to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Engage the core to maintain stability and prevent excessive arching of the back.
Focus on controlled movements, especially when returning to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the shoulder to internally rotate excessively, which can cause strain.
Neglecting to engage the core, resulting in an unstable posture.

name: Single-Arm Linear Jammer
instructions: Position a bar into a landmine or securely anchor it in a corner. Load the bar to an appropriate weight.
Raise the bar from the floor, taking it to your shoulders with one or both hands. Adopt a wide stance. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by extending the elbow, pressing the weight up. Move explosively, extending the hips and knees fully to produce maximal force.
Return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The dynamic pressing movement can strain or further injure the rotator cuff muscles or tendons.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The load and position may place stress on the cervical spine, potentially aggravating conditions like herniated discs.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive pressing motion can worsen tendinitis by overloading the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The explosive movement may strain the lower back, especially if core stability is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The axial load and dynamic movement may increase the risk of fractures in individuals with reduced bone density.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated single-arm dumbbell press to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely anchored to prevent it from slipping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid locking the elbow at the top of the press to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Drive through the heels and extend the hips explosively.
Keep the elbow slightly bent at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, compromising form.
Allowing the back to arch excessively during the press.
Failing to fully extend the hips and knees.

name: Single-Arm Push-Up
instructions: Begin laying prone on the ground. Move yourself into a position supporting your weight on your toes and one arm. Your working arm should be placed directly under the shoulder, fully extended. Your legs should be extended, and for this movement you may need a wider base, placing your feet further apart than in a normal push-up.
Maintain good posture, and place your free hand behind your back. This will be your starting position.
Lower yourself by allowing the elbow to flex until you touch the ground.
Descend slowly, and reverse direction be extending the arm to return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The single-arm push-up places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The exercise requires wrist extension and weight-bearing, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: High demand on shoulder stabilizers can worsen rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrist can increase symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Core stabilization is crucial; improper form can exacerbate lower back issues.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on an incline, such as a bench or step, to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Elevate the feet on a stable surface to increase the difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a wall push-up with one arm to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use push-up bars or perform on fists to keep wrists neutral.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Engage core fully and perform on knees to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the working arm is directly under the shoulder to prevent undue stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid locking the elbow at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Descend slowly and under control.
Keep the elbow close to the body during the descent.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag or rise excessively.
Flaring the elbow out to the side.
Rushing through the movement without control.

name: Single-Cone Sprint Drill
instructions: This drill teaches quick foot action. You need a single cone. Begin standing next to the cone with one arm back and one arm forward.
Chop the feet as quickly as possible, blocking with the arms. Circle the cone, keep your knees up, with violent foot action.
Rest after three trips around the cone.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact and repetitive stress on the knee joint can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute ankle sprain: Rapid foot movements and changes in direction can worsen the injury.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the drill may increase the risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Stress on healing tissues can impede recovery.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: High-intensity exercise may pose a risk to individuals with uncontrolled heart conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform the drill at a slower pace or with a shorter duration to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed of foot action or add a weighted vest for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform high-knee marches around the cone instead of sprints to reduce joint impact.
injury_friendly.ankle instability: Use an ankle brace and perform the drill on a flat, even surface.

safetyNotes: Ensure the surface is even and free of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Use proper footwear with good traction to avoid slipping.
Warm up thoroughly before starting the drill to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Drive your knees up high with each step.
Use your arms to help propel your movement around the cone.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to drop too low, reducing the effectiveness of the drill.
Neglecting arm movement, which can decrease speed and coordination.
Failing to maintain an upright posture, leading to potential imbalance.

recommendedReps.speed: 3-5 trips around the cone per set
recommendedReps.endurance: 5-7 trips around the cone per set

name: Single-Leg High Box Squat
instructions: Position a box in a rack. Secure a band or rope in place above the box.
Standing in front of it, step onto the box to a full standing position, letting your other leg remain unsupported. Hold onto the band for balance
. Continue stepping up and down on the same leg before switching to the opposite side.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The exercise places significant load on the knee joint, which may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The exercise requires core stability and may strain the lower back.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Single-leg exercises require good balance and proprioception, posing a fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery may not tolerate the load and balance demands of this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The exertion level may be too high for individuals with significant cardiovascular limitations.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lower box or step to reduce the range of motion and load.
modifications.harder: Add a weighted vest or hold dumbbells to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lower box and focus on maintaining a neutral spine with core engagement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat and ensure proper alignment of the knee over the foot.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Use the band or rope for balance, not to pull yourself up.
Avoid locking the knee at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding your back.
Align your knee over your foot to prevent valgus collapse.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the knee to cave inward.
Leaning too far forward or backward.

name: Single-Leg Hop Progression
instructions: Arrange a line of cones in front of you. Assume a relaxed standing position, balanced on one leg. Raise the knee of your opposite leg. This will be your starting position.
Hop forward, jumping and landing with the same leg over the cone.
Use a countermovement jump to hop from cone to cone.
At the end, turn around and go back on the other leg.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High impact on the knee joint can exacerbate symptoms and lead to further joint degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.acute ankle sprain: Hopping can increase strain on healing ligaments, delaying recovery.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Single-leg exercises require significant balance and proprioception, increasing fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: High-impact activities can disrupt healing tissues and increase risk of complications.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High-impact activities can increase fracture risk, especially in weight-bearing bones.
contraindicationDetails.chronic plantar fasciitis: Repeated impact can aggravate the plantar fascia, worsening symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform a two-leg hop over the cones to reduce balance and strength demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the distance between cones or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a soft mat.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform step-overs instead of hops to minimize impact.
injury_friendly.ankle instability: Use a balance aid such as a wall or rail for support during the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the surface is even and non-slip to prevent falls.
Warm up thoroughly before performing high-impact exercises.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Land softly on the ball of your foot to reduce impact forces.
Use your arms for balance and momentum.
commonMistakes: Landing with a locked knee, which increases joint stress.
Allowing the knee to collapse inward upon landing, increasing injury risk.
Not using the arms effectively for balance and propulsion.

name: Single-Leg Lateral Hop
instructions: Stand to the side of a cone or hurdle. To get into the start position, stand on one leg with your knee slightly bent.
To begin, execute a counterjump to hop sideways over the cone.
Land on your jumping leg, and immediately rebound out of it by jumping back to the start position.
Continue hopping back and forth.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The impact from hopping can exacerbate knee joint pain and inflammation.

acute ankle sprain.explanation: Hopping places significant stress on the ankle joint, which can impede healing.

balance disorders.explanation: Single-leg exercises require good balance and proprioception, increasing fall risk.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the impact and stress of hopping.

severe plantar fasciitis.explanation: Impact can worsen heel pain and inflammation.

neuropathy affecting lower limbs.explanation: Reduced sensation increases the risk of improper landing and injury.

safetyNotes: Ensure the landing surface is even and free of obstacles.
Warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise to prepare the joints and muscles.
Start with a low hurdle or cone to build confidence and technique.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Land softly on the ball of your foot to absorb impact.
Use your arms to help with balance and momentum.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to collapse inward upon landing, increasing injury risk.
Failing to maintain a slight bend in the knee, which can lead to joint strain.
Not using arms effectively, which can reduce balance and power.

modifications.easier: Perform lateral step-overs instead of hops to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the cone or hurdle to challenge jump height.

injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform lateral hops on a softer surface to reduce joint impact.
injury_friendly.ankle_instability: Use a balance aid, such as a wall or chair, to assist with stability.

name: Single-Leg Leg Extension
instructions: Seat yourself in the machine and adjust it so that you are positioned properly. The pad should be against the lower part of the shin but not in contact with the ankle. Adjust the seat so that the pivot point is in line with your knee. Select a weight appropriate for your abilities.
Maintaining good posture, fully extend one leg, pausing at the top of the motion.
Return to the starting position without letting the weight stop, keeping tension on the muscle.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The exercise can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation due to the load on the knee joint.

patellar tendinitis.explanation: The exercise places stress on the patellar tendon, potentially worsening the condition.

recent knee surgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that stress the knee joint until cleared by a healthcare professional.

severe cardiovascular conditions.explanation: While the exercise is not highly cardiovascular, individuals with severe conditions should consult a physician before engaging in resistance training.

balance disorders.explanation: While seated, balance is less of an issue, but care should be taken when transitioning in and out of the machine.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with both legs simultaneously to reduce the load on each individual knee.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Reduce the range of motion to avoid full extension if experiencing knee discomfort.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to fit your body dimensions.
Do not lock the knee at the top of the extension to avoid joint stress.
Maintain a controlled motion to prevent sudden jerks that can strain the knee.
formCues: Align the machine's pivot point with your knee joint.
Keep your back pressed against the seat to maintain posture.
Exhale as you extend the leg and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and potential injury.
Allowing the knee to lock out at full extension.
Not adjusting the machine properly, leading to misalignment and discomfort.

name: Single-Leg Stride Jump
instructions: Stand to the side of a box with your inside foot on top of it, close to the edge.
Begin by swinging the arms upward as you push through the top leg, jumping upward as high as possible. Attempt to drive the opposite knee upward.
Land in the same position that you started, using your inside leg to decelerate the impact.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities like jumping can exacerbate symptoms and lead to further joint degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The impact and twisting motion may aggravate existing lumbar spine issues.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance, posing a risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the stress of jumping, risking re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Jumping can increase the risk of ankle sprains or further instability.

modifications.easier: Perform a step-up onto the box without jumping to reduce impact and balance demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the box or add a weighted vest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform a low-impact step-up with a focus on controlled movement.
injury_friendly.back pain: Reduce the height of the box and focus on a gentle step-up to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and on a non-slip surface.
Wear supportive footwear to reduce impact on joints.
Warm up thoroughly before performing plyometric exercises.
formCues: Engage your core to maintain balance and control.
Drive through the heel of the foot on the box to engage the quadriceps and glutes.
Land softly with a slight bend in the knee to absorb impact.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to cave inward during the jump.
Landing with a locked knee, increasing joint stress.
Failing to use the arms for momentum and balance.

name: Single Dumbbell Raise
instructions: With a wide stance, hold a dumbell with both hands, grasping the head of the dumbbell instead of the handle. Your arms should be extended and hanging at the waist. This will be your starting position.
Raise the weight until it is above shoulder level, keeping your arms extended. Your torso and hips should remain stationary throughout the movement.
Return to the starting position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms above shoulder level can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves shoulder elevation which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding a weight in front can strain the neck, especially if posture is not maintained.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to load on the upper body and potential balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric holds and overhead movements can increase blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise with a single arm for increased core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to below shoulder height or perform lateral raises with a lighter weight.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weight.
Do not lock the elbows at the top of the movement.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Keep the shoulders down and away from the ears.
Lift the dumbbell in a controlled manner, focusing on the deltoids.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the torso to sway or lean forward.
Shrugging the shoulders during the lift.

name: Single Leg Butt Kick
instructions: Begin by standing on one leg, with the bent knee raised. This will be your start position.
Using a countermovement jump, take off upward by extending the hip, knee, and ankle of the grounded leg.
Immediately flex the knee and attempt to touch your butt with the heel of your jumping leg.
Return the leg to a partially bent position underneath the hips and land. Your opposite leg should stay in relatively the same position throughout the drill.

knee injuries.explanation: The dynamic nature and impact of the exercise can exacerbate knee pain or instability, especially in conditions like patellar tendinitis or meniscus tears.

ankle instability.explanation: Jumping and landing on one leg can increase the risk of ankle sprains or worsen existing instability.

balance disorders.explanation: The exercise requires good balance and proprioception, which can be challenging for individuals with vestibular disorders or neuropathy.

spinal injuries.explanation: The impact and dynamic movement can strain the lower back, particularly in individuals with herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The exercise involves high-intensity movements that may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: Balance and impact concerns increase the risk of falls and joint stress, particularly in the later stages of pregnancy.

osteoporosis.explanation: The impact from jumping can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.

safetyNotes: Ensure the landing surface is stable and non-slip.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise to reduce injury risk.
Avoid locking the knee of the standing leg during the jump.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain balance.
Land softly on the ball of the foot to reduce impact.
Maintain an upright posture throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to collapse inward during landing.
Failing to maintain balance on the standing leg.
Not engaging the core, leading to excessive trunk movement.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the jump, focusing on a controlled knee flexion and extension while maintaining balance.
modifications.harder: Add a small hop on the standing leg before initiating the jump with the opposite leg for increased intensity.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform a standing hamstring curl without jumping, focusing on controlled movement.
injury_friendly.back pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid excessive forward lean during the jump.

name: Single Leg Glute Bridge
instructions: Lay on the floor with your feet flat and knees bent.
Raise one leg off of the ground, pulling the knee to your chest. This will be your starting position.
Execute the movement by driving through the heel, extending your hip upward and raising your glutes off of the ground.
Extend as far as possible, pause and then return to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the potential for exacerbating spinal stress.

joint_issues.explanation: Those with hip or knee arthritis may experience discomfort or pain during the exercise and should modify or avoid it.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid supine positions and may require modifications.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries involving the spine, hips, or knees necessitate avoiding this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.explanation: Acute injuries such as sprains or strains in the lower body should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

neurological_conditions.explanation: Conditions affecting balance or proprioception may require modifications or additional support to perform safely.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard glute bridge with both feet on the ground to reduce the balance challenge.
modifications.harder: Place the elevated foot on a stability ball or perform the exercise with a resistance band around the thighs for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with both feet on the ground and a pillow under the lower back for support.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and ensure the knee of the supporting leg is aligned over the ankle.

safetyNotes: Ensure the supporting foot is firmly planted to prevent slipping.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back by keeping the core engaged.
formCues: Drive through the heel of the supporting leg.
Keep the hips level throughout the movement.
Engage the core to maintain a neutral spine.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to drop or tilt.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Arching the lower back excessively.

name: Single Leg Push-off
instructions: Stand on the ground with one foot resting on the box, heel close to the edge.
Push off with your foot on top of the box, trying to gain as much height as possible by extending through the hip and knee.
Land with the same foot on top of the box, returning your other foot back to the start position.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The impact and load on the knee joint during push-off and landing can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute knee injuries: Conditions such as sprains or strains may worsen with the dynamic nature of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The single-leg nature of the exercise requires good balance, which may pose a risk for those with balance impairments.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding high-impact and dynamic movements until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The explosive nature of the exercise can increase heart rate significantly, which may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled heart conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform a step-up onto the box without the explosive push-off to reduce impact and balance demands.
modifications.harder: Add a dumbbell in each hand to increase resistance and challenge balance further.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform the exercise on a lower box or step to reduce the range of motion and impact.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on engaging the core and maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement, or perform a seated leg press as an alternative.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and on a non-slip surface to prevent falls.
Warm up adequately before performing explosive movements to reduce injury risk.
Use proper footwear with good grip and support.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Drive through the heel of the foot on the box to maximize power and stability.
Land softly with a slight bend in the knee to absorb impact.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to collapse inward during push-off and landing.
Failing to engage the core, leading to excessive lumbar extension.
Using momentum rather than controlled muscle engagement.

name: Sit-Up
instructions: Lie down on the floor placing your feet either under something that will not move or by having a partner hold them. Your legs should be bent at the knees.
Place your hands behind your head and lock them together by clasping your fingers. This is the starting position.
Elevate your upper body so that it creates an imaginary V-shape with your thighs. Breathe out when performing this part of the exercise.
Once you feel the contraction for a second, lower your upper body back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The flexion of the spine during sit-ups can exacerbate disc herniation and increase pain.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. Spinal flexion can narrow the spinal canal further, increasing nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The forward flexion can cause slippage of the vertebrae, worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity. The exercise can aggravate the sciatic nerve, increasing pain and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Spinal flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. The increased intra-abdominal pressure can disrupt healing.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Supine position and abdominal pressure are not recommended, especially in the second and third trimesters.

modifications.easier: Perform a crunch instead of a full sit-up to reduce spinal flexion and pressure.
modifications.harder: Hold a weight plate or medicine ball on your chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a plank or dead bug exercise to engage the core without spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure feet are not anchored, or perform on a stability ball to reduce knee stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid pulling on the neck with your hands to prevent cervical strain.
Maintain a neutral spine as much as possible during the movement.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you lift your torso and inhale as you lower it.
Keep your feet flat and knees bent throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the torso instead of core engagement.
Pulling on the neck with the hands.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: Sit Squats
instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your knees and hips, sitting back with your hips.
Continue until you have squatted a portion of the way down, but are above parallel, and quickly reverse the motion until you return to the starting position. Repeat for 5-10 repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High stress on the knee joint during squatting can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.advanced osteoporosis: Risk of fractures due to potential falls or improper form.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the stress of squatting.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Increased risk of falls during the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.severe lower back pain: Flexion of the spine under load can aggravate symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform a partial squat with a chair behind for support.
modifications.harder: Perform a full squat or add a jump at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit depth and use a chair for support to reduce knee strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a more upright torso and engage core muscles to support the spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure knees do not extend past toes to minimize joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Engage core muscles to support lower back.
formCues: Keep feet shoulder-width apart.
Initiate the movement by bending at the hips.
Keep chest up and back straight.
Drive through the heels to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward.
Rounding the lower back.
Leaning too far forward.

name: Skating
instructions: Roller skating is a fun activity which can be effective in improving cardiorespiratory fitness and muscular endurance. It requires relatively good balance and coordination. It is necessary to learn the basics of skating including turning and stopping and to wear protective gear to avoid possible injury.

You can skate at a comfortable pace for 30 minutes straight. If you want a cardio challenge, do interval skating — speed skate two minutes of every five minutes, using the remaining three minutes to recover. A 150 lb person will typically burn about 175 calories in 30 minutes skating at a comfortable pace, similar to brisk walking.

balance disorders.explanation: Skating requires good balance and coordination. Individuals with balance disorders are at a high risk of falls and injuries.

severe knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The repetitive motion and impact on the knees during skating can exacerbate symptoms of osteoarthritis.

acute ankle sprains.explanation: Skating places stress on the ankles, which can hinder recovery from acute sprains and increase the risk of further injury.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding activities that stress the healing tissues.

severe cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The cardiovascular demands of skating can be too intense for individuals with severe heart conditions.

neuropathy.explanation: Neuropathy can affect balance and proprioception, increasing the risk of falls.

safetyNotes: Always wear protective gear including a helmet, wrist guards, knee pads, and elbow pads.
Ensure the skating surface is free of debris and hazards.
Warm up thoroughly before starting to skate to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the knees to absorb shock and maintain balance.
Engage the core muscles to stabilize the body.
Maintain an upright posture with shoulders relaxed.
commonMistakes: Leaning too far forward or backward, which can lead to loss of balance.
Neglecting to wear appropriate protective gear.
Skating on uneven or unsafe surfaces.

recommendedReps.cardio: Interval skating with 2 minutes high intensity followed by 3 minutes recovery

modifications.easier: Practice skating on a smooth, flat surface with minimal incline to reduce difficulty.
modifications.harder: Incorporate interval training with sprints and sharp turns to increase intensity.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use knee braces and focus on smooth, controlled movements to minimize joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain an upright posture and avoid sudden movements to reduce spinal load.

name: Sled Drag - Harness
