instructions: To begin, load the sled with the desired weight and attach the pulling strap. You can pull with handles, use a harness, or attach the pulling strap to a weight belt.
Whether pulling forwards or backwards, lean in the direction of travel and progress by extending through the hips and knees.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The sled drag can place additional stress on the knee joint, which may exacerbate symptoms of osteoarthritis.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The forward lean and load can increase lumbar spine stress, potentially worsening lower back pain.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance and coordination, which may be challenging for individuals with balance disorders.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires caution to avoid undue stress on healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The exercise can be physically demanding, potentially elevating heart rate and blood pressure to unsafe levels.

modifications.easier: Reduce the weight on the sled or perform the exercise on a flat, smooth surface to decrease resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the sled or perform the exercise on an incline for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter load and maintain a more upright posture to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform backward sled drags to reduce anterior knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the harness or belt is securely fastened to prevent slipping.
Start with a light load to assess tolerance and technique.
Perform the exercise on a stable, non-slippery surface.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability.
Lean slightly in the direction of travel to optimize force application.
Drive through your hips and knees to propel the sled forward.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to compromised form.
Allowing the back to round, increasing the risk of injury.
Failing to maintain a consistent pace, leading to jerky movements.

name: Sled Overhead Backward Walk
instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled connected by a rope or chain. Load the sled to a light weight.
Face the sled, backing up until there is some tension in the line. Hold your hands directly above your head with your elbows extended. This will be your starting position.
Walk backwards, keeping your arms raised above your head. Avoid jerky movements.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Holding weights overhead can strain the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Joint stress from holding the arms overhead and pulling weight can aggravate arthritic conditions.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, which may not be suitable during recovery.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Walking backward requires good balance and coordination, which may be compromised in individuals with balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The isometric hold and exertion can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with unmanaged hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without a sled or with a very light sled to focus on form and balance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the sled or perform the exercise on an incline for added resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with arms at shoulder height instead of overhead to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter sled and focus on maintaining a neutral spine to minimize lower back stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the walking surface is even and free of obstacles to prevent tripping.
Avoid excessive weight, especially if new to the exercise, to prevent undue strain on the shoulders and back.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability and prevent arching of the lower back.
Maintain a steady pace and avoid jerky movements to ensure control.
Keep your shoulders down and away from your ears to avoid tension in the neck.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch excessively, leading to potential strain.
Using too much weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in poor stability and balance.

name: Sled Overhead Triceps Extension
instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled using a chain or rope. Load the sled to an appropriate load.

Facing away from the sled, step away until there is tension in the line. Raise your hands above your head, keeping them together, palms facing each other. Your elbows should be pointed upward with the elbows flexed. This will be your starting position.
Extend through the elbow to straighten the arm. Ensure that your upper arm stays in position to isolate the triceps.
Upon full extension, step forward to take the slack out of the line. You may keep your feet staggered for more stability.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The exercise places stress on the elbow joint, which can exacerbate tendinitis.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Overhead movements can aggravate impingement symptoms.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: The overhead position can strain the rotator cuff, delaying recovery.

recent elbow or shoulder surgery.explanation: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to stress, risking re-injury.

spinal injuries.explanation: Maintaining a stable core is crucial; modifications may be needed to prevent spinal strain.

hypertension.explanation: Overhead exercises can increase blood pressure; monitor and modify as needed.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter sled or resistance band.
modifications.harder: Increase the sled weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform triceps extensions with a resistance band at chest height to avoid overhead stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated triceps extensions to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the sled is on a stable surface to prevent slipping.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows pointed upwards throughout the movement.
Engage core muscles to maintain a stable torso.
Move in a controlled manner, focusing on the triceps contraction.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, reducing triceps isolation.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Arching the back excessively, risking spinal strain.

name: Sled Push
instructions: Load your pushing sled with the desired weight.

Take an athletic posture, leaning into the sled with your arms fully extended, grasping the handles. Push the sled as fast as possible, focusing on extending your hips and knees to strengthen your posterior chain.

herniated disc.explanation: The forward leaning posture and load can exacerbate disc pressure and symptoms.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The exercise places significant stress on the knee joint, which may aggravate symptoms.

acute lower back pain.explanation: The exercise requires core stability and can increase lumbar strain.

balance disorders.explanation: The dynamic movement requires good balance and coordination, posing a risk of falls.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by the load and movement pattern.

hypertension.explanation: The intense exertion can spike blood pressure; caution is advised.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter sled or push on a slight incline to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the sled weight or perform the exercise on a rougher surface for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter load and maintain a more upright posture to reduce lumbar strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Focus on shorter distances and use a lighter sled to minimize knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the sled is on a stable, non-slippery surface to prevent accidents.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
Avoid locking the knees during the push to protect the joint.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive forward lean.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips fully.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round, which increases the risk of injury.
Pushing with the arms instead of driving with the legs.
Using too heavy a load, compromising form and safety.

name: Sled Reverse Flye
instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled connected by a rope or chain. Load the sled to a light weight.

Face the sled, backing up until there is some tension in the line. Take both handles at arms length at about waist level. Bend the knees slightly and keep your chest and head up. This will be your starting position.
Without flexing the elbow, pull the handles upward and apart, performing a reverse fly with some external rotation. Your palms should be facing forward as you do this.
Return to the starting position, taking a couple steps back to take the slack out of the line.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and external rotation movement may exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise involves significant shoulder stabilization and external rotation, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The exercise may pose a risk of fracture due to the dynamic nature and potential for falls.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-operative healing may be compromised by the demands of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the shoulder: The range of motion and load can aggravate arthritic symptoms.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weight or resistance bands instead of a sled to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the sled weight or perform the exercise on an incline for added resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion and ensure no pain during movement.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive leaning or twisting.

safetyNotes: Ensure the sled is on a stable surface to prevent slipping.
Start with a light weight to master form before increasing load.
Keep movements controlled to avoid jerking, which can strain the shoulders.
formCues: Maintain a slight bend in the knees for stability.
Keep the chest up and shoulders back to avoid rounding the upper back.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso throughout the movement.
Avoid locking the elbows; keep them slightly bent.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the shoulders to round forward.
Not maintaining tension in the line, resulting in a lack of resistance.
Flexing the elbows excessively, turning the movement into a row.

name: Sled Row
instructions: Attach dual handles to a sled connected by a rope or chain. Load the sled to an appropriate weight. Face the sled, backing up until there is some tension in the line.
With a handle in each hand, bend the knees slightly, keep your head and chest up, and begin with your arms extended.
To initiate the movement, flex the elbow as you retract your shoulder blades, pulling the sled towards you.
Take a step or two back to get tension in the line and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The forward bending and pulling motion can exacerbate spinal disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise can increase lumbar spine stress, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The pulling motion may aggravate shoulder impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate severity. The exercise can strain the rotator cuff muscles, requiring careful modification.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Low severity. Gripping the handles tightly can increase wrist strain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Moderate severity. The isometric contraction and exertion may elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High severity. The exercise should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter sled or resistance band to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Increase the sled weight or perform the exercise on an incline.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral spine and reduce the load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit knee flexion and focus on upper body movement.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a wider grip and reduce the range of motion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the sled is on a smooth surface to prevent sudden jerks.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core to stabilize the torso.
Pull with your elbows, not your hands.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Overextending the elbows at the end of the pull.

name: Sledgehammer Swings
instructions: You will need a tire and a sledgehammer for this exercise. Stand in front of the tire about two feet away from it with a staggered stance. Grip the sledgehammer.
If you are right handed, your left hand should be at the bottom of the handle, and your right hand should be choking up closer to the head.

As you bring the sledge up, your right hand slides toward the head; as you swing down, your right hand will slide down to join your left hand. Slam it down as hard as you can against the tire. Control the bounce of the hammer off of the tire.
Repeat on the other side.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the rotational forces and potential for spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder_joint_issues: Those with shoulder impingement, tendinitis, or bursitis should be cautious due to the overhead and swinging motion.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: People with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid high-intensity exercises like sledgehammer swings.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance and core stability challenges.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the upper body or core should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter sledgehammer or perform the motion without a sledgehammer to focus on form and control.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed and intensity of the swings or use a heavier sledgehammer.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a shorter range of motion and focus on core engagement to reduce spinal stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the swing height and maintain a neutral shoulder position to minimize strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area around you is clear of obstacles to prevent accidents.
Maintain a firm grip on the sledgehammer at all times.
Control the rebound of the sledgehammer to prevent it from bouncing back unpredictably.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement to protect your spine.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
Use your hips and legs to generate power, not just your arms.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round during the swing, increasing spinal stress.
Overextending the arms, which can lead to loss of control.
Neglecting to switch lead hands, which can cause muscle imbalances.

name: Smith Incline Shoulder Raise
instructions: Place an incline bench underneath the smith machine. Place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Once the weight you need is selected, lie down on the incline bench and make sure your shoulders are aligned right under the barbell.
Using a shoulder width pronated (palms forward) grip, lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with a slight bend at the elbows. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe out, lift the bar up until your arms are fully extended. Note: The contraction should be felt around the shoulders.
After a second pause, bring the bar back down to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating impingement due to overhead movement and shoulder abduction.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Can strain the rotator cuff muscles, especially if not fully healed.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Incline position may place additional stress on the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping and lifting can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to potential for sudden, uncontrolled movements or excessive load.

modifications.easier: Use lighter dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle or use a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with resistance bands to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support and maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is securely positioned under the Smith machine.
Do not lock elbows at the top of the movement to avoid joint strain.
Maintain a controlled motion to prevent sudden jerks or loss of control.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your body.
Align your shoulders directly under the barbell.
Use a slow and controlled motion, especially on the descent.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively.
Arching the back excessively during the lift.

name: Smith Machine Behind the Back Shrug
instructions: With the bar at thigh level, load an appropriate weight.

Stand with the bar behind you, taking a shoulder-width, pronated grip on the bar and unhook the weight. You should be standing up straight with your head and chest up and your arms extended. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by shrugging your shoulders straight up. Do not flex the arms or wrist during the movement.
After a brief pause return the weight to the starting position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before engaging the hooks to rack the weight.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The exercise places axial load on the spine, which can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or stenosis.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: The position of the bar behind the back can increase the risk of shoulder impingement due to the internal rotation of the shoulders.

hypertension.explanation: Holding the breath or excessive straining can increase blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with hypertension.

osteoporosis.explanation: The axial load and potential for poor posture can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Perform dumbbell shrugs with the weights held at the sides to reduce complexity and shoulder strain.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the Smith machine or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine. Consider seated shrugs to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform shrugs with a neutral grip using dumbbells to minimize shoulder rotation.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely racked before starting and after completing the set.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form and increases injury risk.
formCues: Keep your head and chest up throughout the movement.
Engage your core to maintain a neutral spine.
Avoid bending your elbows; focus on elevating the shoulders.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulders to roll forward, which can lead to shoulder impingement.
Bending the elbows, which shifts focus away from the traps.

name: Smith Machine Bench Press
instructions: Place a flat bench underneath the smith machine. Now place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Once the weight you need is selected, lie down on the flat bench. Using a pronated grip that is wider than shoulder width, unlock the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, lock the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The fixed path of the smith machine can exacerbate shoulder impingement by limiting natural shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The repetitive pressing motion can aggravate tendinitis in the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.pectoralis major tear: Individuals with a history of pectoralis major tears should avoid heavy pressing movements that stress the chest.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding exercises that place stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The load on the spine and upper body can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip position may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the median nerve.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for a more natural range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a floor press variation to limit shoulder extension and reduce stress on the joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper bench support and use a neutral spine position to minimize lumbar stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is properly aligned under the bar to avoid asymmetrical loading.
Do not lock elbows forcefully at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Use a spotter or safety stops to prevent accidents if the bar cannot be re-racked.
formCues: Keep feet flat on the floor for stability.
Maintain a slight arch in the lower back without excessive hyperextension.
Keep the wrists straight and aligned with the forearms.
Lower the bar to the mid-chest area, not the neck or abdomen.
commonMistakes: Bouncing the bar off the chest to gain momentum.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder stress.
Using too much weight, compromising form and safety.
Neglecting to engage the core for stability.

name: Smith Machine Bent Over Row
instructions: Set the barbell attached to the smith machine to a height that is about 2 inches below your knees.
Bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Tip: Make sure that you keep the head up.

Now grasp the barbell using an overhand (pronated) grip and unlock it from the smith machine rack. Then let it hang directly in front of you as your arms hang extended perpendicular to the floor and your torso. This is your starting position.

While keeping the torso stationary, lift the barbell as you breathe out, keeping the elbows close to the body and not doing any force with the forearm other than holding the weights. On the top contracted position, squeeze the back muscles and hold for a second.
Slowly lower the weight again to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal injuries.details: The bent-over position can exacerbate conditions such as herniated discs or spinal stenosis due to increased spinal loading.

shoulder impingement.details: The shoulder joint is involved in stabilizing the weight, which can aggravate impingement symptoms.

rotator cuff tendinitis.details: The exercise requires shoulder stabilization, which can strain an already inflamed rotator cuff.

hypertension.details: The bent-over position can increase blood pressure; caution is advised.

pregnancy.details: The bent-over position and potential strain on the lower back are not recommended during pregnancy.

osteoporosis.details: The forward bending and spinal loading can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the movement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with back support to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely locked in the smith machine before starting.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid jerking movements to reduce the risk of injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees to support the lower back.
Pull the barbell towards your lower rib cage.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which can lead to spinal injury.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, which reduces back engagement.

name: Smith Machine Calf Raise
instructions: Place a block or weight plate below the bar on the Smith machine. Set the bar to a position that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step onto the plates with the balls of your feet and place the bar on the back of your shoulders.
Take the bar with both hands facing forward. Rotate the bar to unrack it. This will be your starting position.

Raise your heels as high as possible by pushing off of the balls of your feet, flexing your calf at the top of the contraction. Your knees should remain extended. Hold the contracted position for a second before you start to go back down.
Return slowly to the starting position as you breathe in while lowering your heels.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: High stress on the Achilles tendon during calf raises can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.Plantar fasciitis: The exercise can increase tension in the plantar fascia, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.Recent ankle sprain: Weight-bearing exercises can delay healing and increase risk of re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.Severe osteoarthritis in the ankle: Loading the joint can increase pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.Peripheral neuropathy: Reduced sensation can affect balance and increase risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.Balance disorders: Standing on a raised surface with load can increase fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.Severe varicose veins: Increased venous pressure can exacerbate symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform standing calf raises without additional weight for balance practice.
modifications.harder: Perform single-leg Smith machine calf raises to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a seated calf raise machine to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform seated calf raises to minimize knee joint stress.
injury_friendly.ankle_pain: Perform calf raises on a flat surface without additional weight.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely locked before starting the exercise.
Use a spotter if unsure about balance or weight handling.
Avoid excessive weight to prevent strain on the Achilles tendon.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Do not lock your knees; keep them slightly bent.
Focus on a slow and controlled movement, especially on the descent.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Bouncing at the bottom of the movement instead of controlling the descent.
Allowing the heels to drop too quickly, which can strain the Achilles tendon.

name: Smith Machine Close-Grip Bench Press
instructions: Place a flat bench underneath the smith machine. Place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Once the weight you need is selected, lie down on the flat bench. Using a close and pronated grip (palms facing forward) that is around shoulder width, unlock the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.

As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest. Tip: Make sure that as opposed to a regular bench press, you keep the elbows close to the torso at all times in order to maximize triceps involvement.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your triceps muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, lock the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The close-grip position can exacerbate impingement by increasing stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places significant load on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or elbow surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the stress of this exercise, risking re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The load on the upper body may increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute wrist injuries: The grip and load can exacerbate pain and delay healing in wrist injuries.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The wrist position and load may increase compression on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a stability ball to engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a wider grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip attachment to decrease stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and properly aligned with the Smith machine.
Start with a light weight to assess comfort and form.
Avoid locking the elbows forcefully at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Lower the bar slowly and with control.
Exhale as you press the bar back up.
commonMistakes: Flaring the elbows out, which can increase shoulder stress.
Bouncing the bar off the chest.
Using excessive weight leading to poor form.

name: Smith Machine Decline Press
instructions: Position a decline bench in the rack so that the bar will be above your chest. Load an appropriate weight and take your place on the bench.
Rotate the bar to unhook it from the rack and fully extend your arms. Your back should be slightly arched and your shoulder blades retracted. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing your arms, lowering the bar to your chest.
Pause briefly, and then extend your arms to push the weight back to the starting position.
After completing the desired number of repetitions, rotate the bar to rack the weight.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The decline press can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the angle and load on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.pectoralis major tear: Heavy loads can further damage a partially torn pectoralis major.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding heavy loads and stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The decline position and load can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: The decline position can exacerbate spinal issues such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular conditions: The inverted position may increase blood pressure and is not recommended for those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a flat bench press to reduce the angle and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip or perform a floor press to limit shoulder range of motion.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a flat bench press or incline press to reduce stress on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is securely positioned and the bar is properly loaded.
Do not lock out elbows at the top of the movement to maintain tension and protect joints.
Use a spotter or safety stops to prevent accidents.
formCues: Keep shoulder blades retracted throughout the movement.
Maintain a slight arch in the lower back without excessive hyperextension.
Control the bar on the way down and avoid bouncing it off the chest.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can increase shoulder strain.
Bouncing the bar off the chest to gain momentum.
Using too much weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.

name: Smith Machine Hang Power Clean
instructions: Position the bar at knee height and load it to an appropriate weight.

Take a pronated grip on the bar outside of shoulder width and unhook the bar from the machine. Your arms should be fully extended with your head and chest up. Your elbows should be pointed out with your shoulders back and down. Your hips should be back, loading the tension into the hamstrings. This will be your starting position.
Initate the movement by forcefully extending the hips and knees, accelerating into the bar. Ensure that you keep your arms straight during this part of the motion.
Upon full extension, rebend the hips and knees to lower your receiving position.
Allow the arms to flex at this point, rotating the elbows around the bar to receive it on your shoulders.
Extend through the hips and knees to come to a standing position with the bar racked on your shoulders to complete the movement.

spinal_injuries.details: The explosive nature and load of the exercise can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

knee_joint_issues.details: The exercise involves significant knee extension and flexion, which can aggravate conditions such as arthritis or tendinitis.

shoulder_joint_issues.details: The catching phase can stress the shoulder joint, potentially aggravating impingement or rotator cuff injuries.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: The high-intensity nature of the exercise may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.details: The dynamic movement and load are not recommended during pregnancy due to balance and core stability challenges.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang clean with a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform a full power clean from the floor for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar for a more neutral spine position.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the receiving position to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a high pull instead, avoiding the catch phase.

safetyNotes: Ensure the Smith machine is properly secured and the bar is correctly loaded.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on dynamic stretches for the lower body and shoulders.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels during the extension phase.
Rotate your elbows quickly under the bar during the catch.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Failing to fully extend the hips and knees before the catch.
Allowing the back to round during the initial pull.

name: Smith Machine Hip Raise
instructions: Position a bench in the rack and load the bar to an appropriate weight. Lie down on the bench, placing the bottom of your feet against the bar. Unlock the bar and extend your legs. You may need to use your hands to assist you. For added stability grasp the sides of the Smith Machine. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by rotating your pelvis, flexing your spine to raise your hips off of the bench. Maintain a slight bend in the knees throughout the motion.
After a brief pause, return the hips to the bench.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The exercise involves spinal flexion and loading, which can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis.

pregnancy.explanation: Supine exercises and spinal flexion are generally discouraged during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters.

osteoporosis.explanation: Spinal flexion under load can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

hip_joint_issues.explanation: Individuals with hip impingement or arthritis may experience discomfort or pain due to the position and movement required.

modifications.easier: Perform a basic hip raise on the floor without weights to reduce load and complexity.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights or perform the exercise with a decline bench to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise on a stability ball to reduce spinal load and support the lower back.
injury_friendly.hip_pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on controlled pelvic tilts.

safetyNotes: Ensure the Smith Machine bar is securely locked before starting.
Avoid excessive weight to prevent undue spinal stress.
Maintain control throughout the movement to prevent jerking motions.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Keep a slight bend in the knees to reduce strain on the lower back.
Focus on a smooth, controlled motion when lifting and lowering the hips.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the hips instead of engaging the core.
Allowing the lower back to excessively arch during the movement.
Placing the feet too high or too low on the bar, leading to improper alignment.

name: Smith Machine Incline Bench Press
instructions: Place an incline bench underneath the smith machine. Place the barbell at a height that you can reach when lying down and your arms are almost fully extended. Once the weight you need is selected, lie down on the incline bench and make sure your upper chest is aligned with the barbell. Using a pronated grip (palms facing forward) that is wider than shoulder width, unlock the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your upper chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
When you are done, place the bar back in the rack.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.pectoralis major tear: The exercise involves significant chest activation, which can strain a healing pectoral muscle.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding heavy loads and overhead movements until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The incline position and load on the spine can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The incline position may exacerbate lumbar spine instability.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with dumbbells to allow for a more natural range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or add a pause at the bottom of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support by adjusting the bench angle to a lower incline.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is securely positioned under the Smith machine.
Do not lock the elbows forcefully at the top of the movement.
Maintain a controlled tempo to avoid excessive momentum.
formCues: Keep your feet flat on the ground for stability.
Engage your core to maintain a neutral spine.
Lower the bar to just above the chest, not bouncing off it.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, compromising form.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, increasing shoulder stress.
Bouncing the bar off the chest to gain momentum.

name: Smith Machine Leg Press
instructions: Position a Smith machine bar a couple feet off of the ground. Ensure that it is resting on the safeties. After loading the bar to an appropriate weight, lie underneath the bar. Place the middle of your feet on the bar, tucking your knees to your chest. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by driving through your feet to move the bar upward, extending the hips and knees. Do not lock out your knees.
At the top of the motion, pause briefly before returning to the starting position.

herniated disc.explanation: The exercise can exacerbate spinal compression and increase intradiscal pressure, potentially worsening the condition.

knee osteoarthritis.explanation: The exercise may increase joint stress, particularly if performed with improper form or excessive weight.

severe cardiovascular conditions.explanation: The exercise can increase blood pressure and heart rate, which may be unsafe for individuals with certain heart conditions.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical healing tissues may be compromised by the load and movement pattern of this exercise.

sciatica.explanation: The exercise may aggravate nerve compression or irritation, especially if form is not strictly maintained.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight wall sit to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the Smith machine or perform single-leg presses to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a leg press machine with a back support to maintain spinal alignment.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion and reduce stress on the knee joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the Smith machine safeties are properly set to prevent the bar from dropping unexpectedly.
Avoid locking out the knees at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your back flat against the floor and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the heels to engage the quadriceps and glutes effectively.
Maintain a controlled tempo to avoid bouncing or jerking the weight.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to collapse inward, which can increase stress on the knee joint.
Using excessive weight that compromises form and increases injury risk.
Failing to set the safeties correctly, risking the bar falling.

name: Smith Machine One-Arm Upright Row
instructions: With the bar at thigh level, load an appropriate weight.

Take a wide grip on the bar and unhook the weight, removing your off hand from the bar. Your arm should be extended as you stand up straight with your head and chest up. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing the elbow, raising the upper arm with the elbow pointed out. Continue until your upper arm is parallel to the floor.
After a brief pause, return the weight to the starting position.
Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before engaging the hooks to rack the weight.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The upward motion of the arm can exacerbate impingement by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint stress from the exercise can aggravate osteoarthritic conditions, particularly in the shoulder.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-operative healing requires avoidance of heavy lifting and stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine disorders: The exercise can place strain on the neck, potentially aggravating cervical spine issues.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and lifting motion can exacerbate tendinitis in the elbow.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band for less joint stress.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a dumbbell instead of the Smith machine to allow for a more natural range of motion and reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the Smith machine is properly secured before starting.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent undue stress on the shoulder joint.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid cervical strain.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back throughout the movement.
Lead with the elbow, keeping it higher than the wrist.
Pause briefly at the top of the movement to engage the shoulder muscles fully.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbow to drop below the wrist, which can reduce effectiveness and increase injury risk.
Shrugging the shoulders excessively, which can lead to neck strain.

name: Smith Machine Overhead Shoulder Press
instructions: To begin, place a flat bench (or preferably one with back support) underneath a smith machine. Position the barbell at a height so that when seated on the flat bench, the arms must be almost fully extended to reach the barbell.

Once you have the correct height, sit slightly in behind the barbell so that there is an imaginary straight line from the tip of your nose to the barbell. Your feet should be stationary. Grab the barbell with the palms facing forward, unlock it and lift it up so that your arms are fully extended. This is the starting position.
Slowly begin to lower the barbell until it is level with your chin while inhaling.
Then lift the barbell back to the starting position using your shoulders while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead motion can exacerbate impingement by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Lifting overhead can strain the rotator cuff muscles and tendons, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Overhead pressing can increase joint stress, leading to pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to stress and may not withstand the load of overhead pressing.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine disorders: The neck position during the lift can exacerbate cervical spine issues.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: Overhead pressing can increase cervical spine compression, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during lifting, can spike blood pressure levels.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press to reduce stabilization demands.
modifications.harder: Perform a standing overhead press with free weights to engage more stabilizing muscles.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use resistance bands for a lower-impact alternative, or perform a landmine press to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and the back support is secure to prevent injury.
Do not lock out the elbows at the top of the movement to avoid joint stress.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back by engaging the core.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a neutral spine.
Press the barbell upward in a straight line, avoiding forward or backward drift.
Inhale as you lower the bar and exhale as you press it upward.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.
Failing to maintain a neutral wrist position, which can lead to wrist strain.

name: Smith Machine Pistol Squat
instructions: To begin, first set the bar to a position that best matches your height. Step under it and position the bar across the back of your shoulders.
Take the bar with your hands facing forward, unlock it and lift it off the rack by extending your legs. 3

Move one foot forward about 12 inches in front of the bar. Extend the other leg out in front of you, holding it off the ground. Look forward at all times and maintain a neutral or slightly arched spine. This will be your starting position.
Maintaining good posture, lower yourself by flexing the knee and hip, going down as far as flexibility allows.
Pause briefly at the bottom and then return to the starting position by driving through the heel of your foot, extending the knee and hip.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High stress on the knee joint during deep flexion can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The exercise places significant load on the patellar tendon, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.meniscus tears: Deep knee flexion can increase shear forces on the meniscus, risking further injury.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Spinal loading and potential for poor form can aggravate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may exacerbate symptoms due to spinal loading and leg positioning.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Single-leg stance requires good balance, posing a fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the stress of this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform a pistol squat to a box or bench to reduce the range of motion and provide support.
modifications.harder: Add weight by holding a dumbbell or kettlebell in front of the chest.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform a supported single-leg squat using TRX straps or parallel bars.
injury_friendly.back pain: Limit the range of motion and ensure a neutral spine throughout the movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the Smith machine bar is securely locked before starting.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the knee and hip joints.
Do not attempt this exercise if you have significant balance issues.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back to maintain a neutral spine.
Drive through the heel of the working leg to engage the glutes and quadriceps.
Keep the non-working leg extended and parallel to the ground.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to cave inward, increasing stress on the joint.
Rounding the back, which can lead to spinal injury.
Using momentum rather than controlled movement.

name: Smith Machine Reverse Calf Raises
instructions: Adjust the barbell on the smith machine to fit your height and align a raised platform right under the bar.
Stand on the platform with the heels of your feet secured on top of it with the balls of your feet extending off it. Position your toes facing forward with a shoulder width stance.

Now, place your shoulders under the barbell while maintaining the foot positioning described and push the barbell up by extending your hips and knees until your torso is standing erect. The knees should be kept with a slight bend; never locked. This will be your starting position. Tip: The barbell on your back is only for balance purposes.

Raise the balls of your feet as you breathe out by extending your toes as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending at any time. Hold the contracted position for a second before you start to go back down.
Slowly go back down to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering the balls of your feet and toes.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: High severity due to potential for exacerbating inflammation and pain in the tendon.
contraindicationDetails.Plantar fasciitis: Moderate severity as the exercise can increase tension on the plantar fascia.
contraindicationDetails.Recent ankle sprain: High severity; avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.Severe osteoarthritis in the ankle: High severity; the exercise can increase joint stress and pain.
contraindicationDetails.Peripheral neuropathy: Moderate severity due to potential for impaired proprioception and balance.
contraindicationDetails.Balance disorders: High severity; risk of falls due to impaired balance.
contraindicationDetails.Herniated disc: Moderate severity; axial loading may exacerbate symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without additional weight, using body weight only.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the Smith machine or perform single-leg reverse calf raises.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated calf raises to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a lower platform to reduce range of motion and stress on the knee joint.
injury_friendly.ankle_pain: Perform seated calf raises with a resistance band for controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the platform is stable and secure to prevent slipping.
Avoid locking the knees to reduce stress on the joint.
Maintain a controlled movement to prevent strain on the Achilles tendon.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain balance.
Focus on a slow and controlled movement throughout the exercise.
Ensure your heels drop below the platform to maximize calf stretch.
commonMistakes: Locking the knees during the exercise.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the heels to rise too quickly, reducing muscle engagement.

name: Smith Machine Squat
instructions: To begin, first set the bar on the height that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side (palms facing forward), unlock it and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The axial loading and spinal flexion/extension involved can exacerbate these conditions.

joint_issues.explanation: The knee joint is heavily loaded, which can worsen symptoms.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The Valsalva maneuver and exertion can increase blood pressure.

pregnancy.explanation: Balance and abdominal pressure can be problematic.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the load and movement.

chronic_conditions.explanation: The risk of vertebral fracture due to axial loading is increased.

acute_injuries.explanation: The exercise can aggravate acute injuries.

neurological_conditions.explanation: The fixed path of the Smith machine can mask balance issues, leading to instability.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight squat or use a TRX for support.
modifications.harder: Add a pause at the bottom of the squat or increase the weight.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and ensure proper lumbar support.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to above parallel and focus on controlled movements.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Ensure proper bar placement and consider using a pad for comfort.

safetyNotes: Ensure the safety stops are set to prevent the bar from descending too low.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding your back.
Drive through your heels to engage the posterior chain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the ascent.
Leaning too far forward, placing excessive stress on the lower back.
Using too much weight, compromising form and safety.

name: Smith Machine Stiff-Legged Deadlift
instructions: To begin, set the bar on the smith machine to a height that is around the middle of your thighs. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, grasp the bar using a pronated (palms forward) grip that is shoulder width apart. You may need some wrist wraps if using a significant amount of weight.

Lift the bar up by fully extending your arms while keeping your back straight. Stand with your torso straight and your legs spaced using a shoulder width or narrower stance. The knees should be slightly bent. This is your starting position.

Keeping the knees stationary, lower the barbell to over the top of your feet by bending at the waist while keeping your back straight. Keep moving forward as if you were going to pick something from the floor until you feel a stretch on the hamstrings. Exhale as you perform this movement

Start bringing your torso up straight again as soon as you feel the hamstrings stretch by extending your hips and waist until you are back at the starting position. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: The forward bending motion and load on the spine can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis.

knee_joint_issues.details: Although the knees remain relatively stationary, individuals with severe arthritis or tendinitis may experience discomfort.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Heavy lifting can increase blood pressure and may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.details: The exercise involves bending at the waist, which is not recommended during pregnancy, especially in later stages.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the back or lower body should preclude performing this exercise.

osteoporosis.details: The forward bending and load can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is set at an appropriate height to avoid excessive bending.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent injury.
Avoid locking the knees to reduce stress on the joint.
formCues: Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Lower the bar slowly and with control.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Locking the knees, which can increase joint stress.
Using momentum to lift the bar instead of controlled muscle engagement.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage stabilizer muscles more.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion and ensure a neutral spine throughout.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Focus on maintaining a slight bend in the knees without locking them, and reduce the load.

name: Smith Machine Upright Row
instructions: To begin, set the bar on the smith machine to a height that is around the middle of your thighs. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, grasp the bar using a pronated (palms forward) grip that is shoulder width apart. You may need some wrist wraps if using a significant amount of weight.
Lift the barbell up and fully extend your arms with your back straight. There should be a slight bend at the elbows. This is the starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the bar as you exhale. The bar should be close to the body as you move it up. Continue to lift it until it nearly touches your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the bar, your elbows should always be higher than your forearms. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the bar back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder_impingement: The upright row position can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the internal rotation and elevation of the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator_cuff_injury: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially aggravating existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.wrist_tendinitis: The grip and lifting motion can strain the wrist tendons, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.elbow_tendinitis: The repetitive lifting motion may exacerbate tendinitis in the elbow region.
contraindicationDetails.cervical_spine_injuries: The exercise can place stress on the neck, potentially aggravating cervical spine issues.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance bands to reduce load and strain on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a wider grip to increase the range of motion and muscle activation.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform lateral raises with dumbbells to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.wrist_pain: Use wrist straps or a neutral grip bar to minimize wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent undue stress on the shoulder and wrist joints.
Maintain a controlled motion to reduce the risk of injury.
formCues: Keep elbows higher than wrists throughout the movement.
Maintain a straight back and engage core muscles for stability.
Lift the bar close to the body to ensure proper alignment.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the bar instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to drop below the wrists during the lift.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to spinal strain.

name: Smith Single-Leg Split Squat
instructions: To begin, place a flat bench 2-3 feet behind the smith machine. Then, set the bar on the height that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side (palms facing forward), unlock it and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.
Position your legs by placing one foot slightly forward under the bar and extending your other leg back and place the top of your foot on the bench. This will be your starting position

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knee as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calf becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knee should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knee is past that imaginary line (if it is past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten your leg again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch legs and repeat the movement.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The exercise places significant stress on the knee joint, which may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The loading and movement pattern can increase stress on the patellar tendon.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The axial loading and potential for spinal flexion can aggravate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The position and load may exacerbate sciatic nerve irritation.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The unilateral nature of the exercise requires good balance and proprioception.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery often requires avoiding loaded and complex movements.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight split squat without the Smith machine to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Add a pause at the bottom of the movement or increase the weight on the Smith machine.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the range of motion and ensure the knee does not travel past the toes.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure a neutral spine and consider using a lighter load or bodyweight.
injury_friendly.balance issues: Perform the exercise next to a stable surface for support or use a TRX suspension trainer for assistance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the Smith machine bar is set to the appropriate height to avoid excessive spinal flexion.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent back strain.
Avoid letting the front knee travel past the toes to minimize knee stress.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back.
Engage the core to maintain stability.
Drive through the heel of the front foot during the ascent.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to travel past the toes.
Leaning forward excessively, causing spinal flexion.
Using too much weight, compromising form and stability.

name: Snatch
instructions: Place your feet at a shoulder width stance with the barbell resting right above the connection between the toes and the rest of the foot.

With a palms facing down grip, bend at the knees and keeping the back flat grab the bar using a wider than shoulder width grip. Bring the hips down and make sure that your body drops as if you were going to sit on a chair. This will be your starting position.
Start pushing the floor as if it were a moving platform with your feet and simultaneously start lifting the barbell keeping it close to your legs.
As the bar reaches the middle of your thighs, push the floor with your legs and lift your body to a complete extension in an explosive motion.
Lift your shoulders back in a shrugging movement as you bring the bar up while lifting your elbows out to the side and keeping them above the bar for as long as possible.

Now in a very quick but powerful motion, you have to get your body under the barbell when it has reached a high enough point where it can be controlled and drop while locking your arms and holding the barbell overhead as you assume a squat position.
Finalize the movement by rising up out of the squat position to finish the lift. At the end of the lift both feet should be on line and the arms fully extended holding the barbell overhead.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The dynamic and explosive nature of the snatch places significant stress on the spine, particularly during the catch and overhead squat phases.

shoulder_issues.explanation: The overhead position requires significant shoulder stability and mobility, which can exacerbate conditions like impingement or tendinitis.

knee_issues.explanation: The deep squat position can increase stress on the knee joint, potentially aggravating conditions like arthritis or patellar tendinitis.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The explosive nature of the exercise can cause rapid increases in heart rate and blood pressure, which may be risky for individuals with heart disease or hypertension.

pregnancy.explanation: The risk of balance loss and abdominal pressure during the snatch makes it unsuitable during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries, especially those involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, require avoidance of high-stress exercises like the snatch.

osteoporosis.explanation: The risk of fractures due to the dynamic and high-impact nature of the snatch is significant for individuals with low bone density.

acute_injuries.explanation: Performing the snatch with any acute injury can exacerbate the condition and delay recovery.

modifications.easier: Dumbbell snatch or kettlebell snatch, which allows for lighter loads and easier handling.
modifications.harder: Performing the snatch with a pause at the catch phase to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on technique, or substitute with a power snatch to reduce the range of motion.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat or perform a power snatch to minimize knee flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a hang snatch or power snatch to reduce the overhead component.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up and mobility exercises before attempting the snatch.
Use a spotter or perform in a controlled environment with bumper plates.
Avoid excessive weight until technique is mastered.
formCues: Keep the bar close to the body throughout the lift.
Engage the core to maintain a neutral spine.
Drive through the heels during the lift-off phase.
Fully extend the hips and knees before transitioning to the catch phase.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift-off.
Pulling with the arms too early.
Failing to fully extend the hips.
Catching the bar with bent elbows.

name: Snatch Balance
instructions: Begin with the feet in the pulling position, the bar racked across the back of the shoulders, and the hands placed in a wide snatch grip.
Pop the bar with an abrupt dip and drive of the knees, and aggressively drive under the bar, transitioning the feet into the receiving position.
Receive the bar locked out overhead near the bottom of the squat. The torso should remain vertical, lowering the hips between the legs.
Continue to descend to full depth, and return to a standing position. Carefully lower the weight.

spinal_injuries.details: The dynamic nature and overhead position of the snatch balance can exacerbate spinal conditions such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_issues.details: Individuals with shoulder impingement, rotator cuff tears, or tendinitis should avoid this exercise due to the overhead load and rapid movement.

knee_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the depth and load to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: The explosive nature of the exercise may elevate heart rate significantly; caution is advised for those with hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.details: The balance and core stability required, along with the overhead component, make this unsuitable during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, especially involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Use safety collars on the barbell to prevent weight plates from sliding.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on shoulder and hip mobility.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Drive the knees outwards to maintain alignment with the toes.
Focus on a quick and aggressive dip and drive under the bar.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to collapse inward during the squat.
Failing to lock out the elbows fully overhead.
Rushing the movement, leading to poor control and balance.

modifications.easier: Perform an overhead squat with a dowel or light barbell to focus on form and stability.
modifications.harder: Increase the load or perform the exercise from a deficit by standing on a platform.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter load and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat and ensure proper knee alignment over the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a partial range of motion or substitute with a push press to reduce shoulder strain.

name: Snatch Deadlift
instructions: The snatch deadlift strengthens the first pull of the snatch. Begin with a wide snatch grip with the barbell placed on the platform. The feet should be directly under the hips, with the feet turned out. Squat down to the bar, keeping the back in absolute extension with the head facing forward.
Initiate the movement by driving through the heels, raising the hips. The back angle should remain the same until the bar passes the knees.
At that point, drive your hips through the bar as you lay back. Return the bar to the platform by reversing the motion.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The snatch deadlift places significant stress on the spine, particularly in the lumbar region. Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, spondylolisthesis, or sciatica should avoid this exercise to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.

joint_issues.explanation: Those with arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis in the knees, hips, or shoulders should modify or avoid this exercise due to the potential for joint strain.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should be cautious due to the increased cardiovascular demand and intra-abdominal pressure during heavy lifts.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, hips, or knees, require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

osteoporosis.explanation: The axial loading and potential for spinal flexion increase the risk of fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower back, knees, or shoulders necessitate avoidance of this exercise until fully healed.

modifications.easier: Romanian deadlift with a narrower grip and lighter weight.
modifications.harder: Perform the snatch deadlift from a deficit, standing on a platform to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep knee flexion, focusing on the hip hinge.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a narrower grip to reduce strain on the shoulders.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints.
Use a weightlifting belt if lifting near maximal loads.
Avoid rounding the back to prevent spinal injuries.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back throughout the lift.
Drive through the heels and maintain a flat back.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Starting with the hips too high, turning it into a stiff-leg deadlift.
Failing to keep the bar close to the body.

name: Snatch Pull
instructions: With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take a wide snatch grip. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.

Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.

Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the pull. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward.

There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back. Full extension should be violent and abrupt, and ensure that you do not prolong the extension for longer than necessary.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high load on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or tendinitis, especially in the shoulders or knees, should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity lifts.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid high-impact, heavy lifting exercises.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, should avoid this exercise.
