chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid heavy lifting due to increased fracture risk.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing any acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the back, shoulders, or knees.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form during execution.

modifications.easier: Perform a snatch grip deadlift to focus on form and reduce complexity.
modifications.harder: Add a high pull after the second pull to increase difficulty and power output.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal load and maintain a more upright posture.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid deep knee flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Reduce the grip width to decrease shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints.
Use appropriate footwear to maintain stability and support.
Start with lighter weights to master the technique before progressing.
formCues: Keep the bar close to the body throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding the back.
Drive through the heels and extend the hips forcefully.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using the arms to pull the bar instead of relying on hip extension.
Not achieving full extension of the hips, knees, and ankles.

name: Snatch Shrug
instructions: Begin with a wide grip, with the bar hanging at the mid thigh position. You can use a hook or overhand grip. Your back should be straight and inclined slightly forward.
Shrug your shoulders towards your ears. While this exercise can usually by loaded with heavier weight than a snatch, avoid overloading to the point that the execution slows down.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and shrugging motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The load and movement can increase strain on the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, aggravating existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.acute neck pain: Shrugging can increase tension and pain in the neck region.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward lean and load can increase pressure on spinal discs.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can exacerbate vertebral slippage due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The axial load and dynamic movement can increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with dumbbells to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight while maintaining speed and form, or perform from a deficit.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on controlled movements, or perform seated shrugs.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated shrugs or use a Smith machine for added stability.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive weight that compromises speed and form.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare the shoulder girdle and back muscles.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Shrug your shoulders directly upwards towards your ears.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to compromised form.
Rounding the back during the movement.
Failing to engage the core, leading to instability.

name: Snatch from Blocks
instructions: Begin with a loaded barbell on boxes or stands of the desired height. A wide grip should be taken on the bar. The feet should be directly below the hips, with the feet turned out as needed. Lower the hips, with the chest up and the head looking forward. The shoulders should be just in front of the bar, with the elbows pointed out. This will be the starting position.
Begin the first pull by driving through the front of the heels, raising the bar from the boxes.

Transition into the second pull by extending through the hips knees and ankles, driving the bar up as quickly as possible. The bar should be close to the body. At peak extension, shrug the shoulders and allow the elbows to flex to the side.

As you move your feet into the receiving position, forcefully pull yourself below the bar as you elevate the bar overhead. The feet should move to just outside the hips, turned out as necessary. Receive the bar with your body as low as possible and the arms fully extended overhead.
Keeping the bar aligned over the front of the heels, your head and chest up, drive through heels of the feet to move to a standing position. Carefully return the weight to the boxes.

spinal_injuries.details: The dynamic and explosive nature of the snatch can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis due to high spinal loading.

joint_issues.details: Individuals with arthritis or shoulder impingement may experience increased joint stress, especially in the shoulders and knees.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: The intense nature of this exercise can elevate heart rate and blood pressure, posing risks for those with hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.details: The risk of balance loss and abdominal pressure increase makes this exercise unsuitable during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical individuals, especially those recovering from spinal or shoulder surgeries, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma can be aggravated by the explosive movements required in this exercise.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy can increase the risk of falls or improper form during the lift.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang snatch from a standing position without blocks to reduce the range of motion and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform a full snatch from the floor to enhance difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use lighter weights and focus on technique, or perform a power snatch to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the catch position to reduce knee stress, or perform a muscle snatch.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a snatch-grip high pull to avoid overhead positioning.

safetyNotes: Ensure the blocks are stable and can support the weight of the barbell.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for explosive movements.
Use a spotter or perform in a controlled environment to minimize risk of injury.
formCues: Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Drive through your heels to initiate the lift.
Fully extend your hips, knees, and ankles at the top of the pull.
commonMistakes: Starting with the hips too high or too low, leading to poor leverage.
Allowing the bar to drift away from the body.
Failing to fully extend the hips during the second pull.
Catching the bar with bent elbows, leading to instability.

name: Speed Band Overhead Triceps
instructions: For this exercise anchor a band to the ground. We used an incline bench and anchored the band to the base, standing over the bench. Alternatively, this could be performed standing on the band.
To begin, pull the band behind your head, holding it with a pronated grip and your elbows up. This will be your starting position.
To perform the movement, extend through the elbow to to straighten your arms, ensuring that you keep your upper arm in place.
Pause, and then return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension of the elbow can exacerbate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms overhead can compress the shoulder joint, worsening impingement.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding the band behind the head can strain the neck, aggravating cervical conditions.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The overhead position may increase the risk of fracture in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues may be stressed by the overhead and extension movements.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band or seated to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a thicker band or perform the exercise with one arm at a time for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with elbows slightly lower to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full extension, reducing stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the band is securely anchored to prevent snapping.
Avoid hyperextending the elbows to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability.
Ensure elbows remain stationary and close to your head.
Move in a controlled manner, focusing on the triceps contraction.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing triceps activation.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively, which can strain the lower spine.

name: Speed Box Squat
instructions: Attach bands to the bar that are securely anchored near the ground. You may need to choke the bands to get adequate tension.

Use a box of an appropriate height for this exercise. Load the bar to a weight that still requires effort, but isn't so heavy that speed is compromised. Typically, that will be between 50-70% of your one rep max.
Position the bar on your upper back, shoulder blades retracted, back arched and everything tight head to toe. This will be the starting position.
Unrack the bar and position yourself in front of the box. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box, ensuring that you descend under control and don't crash onto the surface.
Pause briefly, and explode off of the box, extending through the hips and knees.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and potential for increased spinal compression.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should approach with caution and may require modifications to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before attempting due to the potential for increased blood pressure during exertion.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, hips, or knees, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis or advanced diabetes complications should modify or avoid this exercise to prevent injury.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the lower body or back.

neurological_conditions.details: Those with balance disorders or neuropathy should use caution and may require supervision or modifications.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight box squats or use lighter resistance bands without a barbell.
modifications.harder: Increase band tension or use a higher percentage of your one rep max, up to 70%.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter barbell or perform the exercise with just bands and no additional weight.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Reduce the depth of the squat or use a higher box to limit knee flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Consider using a safety squat bar to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely anchored to prevent slippage.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid bouncing off the box; control the descent and pause briefly.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged.
Drive through your heels as you explode off the box.
Retract shoulder blades and keep elbows under the bar.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to collapse inward (valgus collapse).
Using excessive weight that compromises speed and form.
Failing to maintain tension in the core and back.

name: Speed Squats
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.

Begin to raise the bar as fast as possible without involving momentum as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position. Note: You should perform these exercises as fast as possible but without breaking perfect form and without involving momentum.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid speed squats due to the compressive and shear forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: High-intensity exercises like speed squats can elevate blood pressure; individuals with hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician.

pregnancy.details: Due to balance changes and increased joint laxity, speed squats are not recommended during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.details: Post-surgical recovery, especially involving the spine or lower limbs, requires clearance from a healthcare provider before performing speed squats.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis increases fracture risk; modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid speed squats if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase fall risk; modifications or supervision are advised.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight squats or use a lighter barbell to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the barbell weight or perform jump squats for added intensity.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a safety squat bar or perform box squats to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit squat depth and focus on controlled movements; consider using knee sleeves for support.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a front squat grip or a safety squat bar to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Always warm up thoroughly before performing speed squats to prepare muscles and joints.
Use a squat rack with safety bars to prevent injury in case of muscle failure.
Avoid using momentum to lift the bar; focus on controlled, explosive movements.
formCues: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Keep knees aligned with toes to prevent undue stress on the joints.
Drive through the heels to engage the posterior chain effectively.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward during the ascent.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.
Failing to maintain a consistent tempo, leading to loss of control.

name: Spell Caster
instructions: Hold a dumbbell in each hand with a pronated grip. Your feet should be wide with your hips and knees extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by pulling both of the dumbbells to one side next to your hip, rotating your torso.
Keeping your arms straight and the dumbbells parallel to the ground, rotate your torso to swing the weights to your opposite side.
Continue alternating, rotating from one side to the other until the set is complete.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High rotational forces can exacerbate disc herniation and increase pain or neurological symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Twisting motions may compress the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Rotational movements can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Rotational forces may irritate the sciatic nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of vertebral fractures due to rotational stress on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Overhead and rotational movements can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Repetitive shoulder movements may aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Rapid twisting may cause instability and increase fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Rotational movements may strain the abdominal wall and affect balance.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a single dumbbell held in both hands to reduce load and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated on a bench to reduce spinal load and limit range of motion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use lighter weights and focus on controlled, slow movements to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid excessive spinal loading.
Avoid jerking or swinging the weights to prevent unnecessary stress on the joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Rotate through the torso, not just the arms, to ensure proper muscle activation.
Keep the dumbbells parallel to the ground to maintain control.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to bend excessively, reducing stability.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Over-rotating the torso, which can strain the spine.

name: Spider Crawl
instructions: Begin in a prone position on the floor. Support your weight on your hands and toes, with your feet together and your body straight. Your arms should be bent to 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement by raising one foot off of the ground. Externally rotate the leg and bring the knee toward your elbow, as far forward as possible.
Return this leg to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The prone position and spinal flexion can exacerbate symptoms by increasing intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Flexion and rotation of the spine may worsen symptoms by compressing the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Forward bending and rotation can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may aggravate nerve compression due to hip and spinal movements.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Weight-bearing on the shoulders can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Supporting body weight on the wrists can increase strain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Prone position may be uncomfortable and unsafe, especially in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Core engagement and pressure may disrupt healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on your knees instead of toes to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Add a push-up between each crawl to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the movement with a smaller range of motion and avoid excessive spinal rotation.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Place a cushion under the knees or perform on a softer surface to reduce pressure.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with hands elevated on a bench to reduce shoulder load.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Avoid jerky movements to reduce the risk of joint strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on the quality of each movement.
Ensure your shoulders are aligned over your wrists.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag or rise excessively.
Failing to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Rushing through the movement without control.

name: Spider Curl
instructions: Start out by setting the bar on the part of the preacher bench that you would normally sit on. Make sure to align the barbell properly so that it is balanced and will not fall off.

Move to the front side of the preacher bench (the part where the arms usually lay) and position yourself to lay at a 45 degree slant with your torso and stomach pressed against the front side of the preacher bench.
Make sure that your feet (especially the toes) are well positioned on the floor and place your upper arms on top of the pad located on the inside part of the preacher bench.
Use your arms to grab the barbell with a supinated grip (palms facing up) at about shoulder width apart or slightly closer from each other.
Slowly begin to lift the barbell upwards and exhale. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the barbell back to the starting position as your breathe in. .
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation in the tendons, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms may cause discomfort or exacerbate impingement symptoms due to shoulder positioning.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the bar can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: Isometric holds and heavy lifting can increase blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.wrist arthritis: The supinated grip and wrist positioning may increase joint stress and discomfort.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or resistance bands to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slower tempo or add a pause at the top of the curl.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce spinal strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip with dumbbells to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or a neutral grip bar to minimize wrist strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the elbows and wrists.
formCues: Keep your upper arms stationary on the pad throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the curl.
Control the weight during both the lifting and lowering phases.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the bar instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing bicep engagement.
Leaning back excessively, which can strain the lower back.

name: Spinal Stretch
instructions: Sit in a chair so your back is straight and your feet planted on the floor.
Interlace your fingers behind your head, elbows out and your chin down.
Twist your upper body to one side about 3 times as far as you can. Then lean forward and twist your torso to reach your elbow to the floor on the inside of your knee.
Return to upright position and then repeat for your other side.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the rotational and flexion forces applied to the spine, which can exacerbate these conditions.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The forward flexion and twisting motion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: During pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, the forward bending and twisting can be uncomfortable and may strain the abdominal region.
contraindicationDetails.recent_abdominal_surgery: Twisting and bending can place undue stress on healing tissues, potentially disrupting recovery.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The twisting and leaning movements may challenge balance, increasing the risk of falls or injury.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion, focusing on gentle twists without leaning forward.
modifications.harder: Add a resistance band around the upper back to increase resistance during the twist.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the twist while keeping the spine neutral and avoid leaning forward. Use a pillow for support if needed.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform the exercise with feet slightly wider apart to reduce stress on the knees.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive twisting or bending if you experience any discomfort or pain.
Ensure the chair is stable and does not move during the exercise.
formCues: Keep your back straight and engage your core throughout the movement.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on the stretch rather than the range of motion.
Breathe steadily, exhaling as you twist and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the forward lean.
Using momentum to twist instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward during the twist.

name: Split Clean
instructions: With a barbell on the floor close to the shins, take an overhand grip just outside the legs. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.

Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.

Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.

As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so.

Receive the bar with the feet split, aggressively moving one foot forward and one foot back. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom position, which will help in the recovery.
Immediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Bring the feet together as you stand up.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and dynamic movement, which can exacerbate these conditions.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee, hip, or shoulder arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress. Consider using lighter weights or partial range of motion.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should perform this exercise with caution due to the high-intensity nature and potential for increased blood pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the spine, knees, hips, or shoulders require complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare professional.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the involved joints or muscles.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications or avoidance due to the dynamic nature of the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform a hang clean instead of starting from the floor to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the catch position for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the split to reduce knee stress and ensure proper alignment.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a wider grip and ensure proper scapular retraction to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate warm-up to prepare muscles and joints for dynamic movement.
Use proper footwear to provide stability and support during the exercise.
Avoid excessive weight to maintain control and proper form.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to protect the spine.
Drive through the heels during the initial pull.
Maintain a straight back and avoid rounding the shoulders.
Focus on a smooth transition between pulls and the catch phase.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the initial pull.
Using the arms too early in the pull phase.
Failing to fully extend the hips, knees, and ankles.
Landing with an unstable or uneven split stance.

name: Split Jerk
instructions: Standing with the weight racked on the front of the shoulders, begin with the dip. With your feet directly under your hips, flex the knees without moving the hips backward.

Go down only slightly, and reverse direction as powerfully as possible. Drive through the heels create as much speed and force as possible, and be sure to move your head out of the way as the bar leaves the shoulders. At this moment as the feet leave the floor, the feet must be placed into the receiving position as quickly as possible.

In the brief moment the feet are not actively driving against the platform, the athlete's effort to push the bar up will drive them down. The feet should be moved to a split stance, one foot forward, one foot back, with the knees partially bent. Receive the bar with the arms locked out overhead.
Return to a standing position, bringing the feet together.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: High spinal loads and rapid movements can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder_issues: Overhead pressing can aggravate shoulder impingement or rotator cuff tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.knee_issues: The split stance and rapid movements can stress the knees, affecting those with arthritis or tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: The explosive nature of the exercise can increase blood pressure and heart rate, posing risks for those with hypertension or heart disease.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Balance and rapid movements are challenging during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Those recovering from surgeries, particularly in the shoulder, spine, or knees, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The dynamic and balance-intensive nature of the split jerk can be problematic for individuals with balance disorders.

modifications.easier: Perform a push press instead of a split jerk to reduce complexity and balance demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom of the dip to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on strict form, or perform a seated overhead press to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the dip and ensure proper knee alignment over the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural shoulder movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up before performing the exercise.
Use a spotter or perform in a power rack for safety.
Avoid hyperextending the lower back during the lift.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the heels during the dip and drive phase.
Ensure the bar path is vertical and close to the body.
Lock out the arms fully overhead at the end of the movement.
commonMistakes: Failing to fully lock out the arms overhead.
Allowing the knees to cave inward during the dip.
Leaning too far forward or backward during the split stance.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Split Jump
instructions: Assume a lunge stance position with one foot forward with the knee bent, and the rear knee nearly touching the ground.
Ensure that the front knee is over the midline of the foot.
Extending through both legs, jump as high as possible, swinging your arms to gain lift.
As you jump, bring your feet together, and move them back to their initial positions as you land.
Absorb the impact by reverting back to the starting position.

knee injuries.explanation: The impact and dynamic nature of the split jump can exacerbate knee pain and instability, especially in conditions like patellar tendinitis or meniscus tears.

spinal injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs or lower back pain may experience increased discomfort due to the compressive forces during landing.

cardiovascular conditions.explanation: High-impact exercises can elevate heart rate and blood pressure, posing risks for those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

balance disorders.explanation: The coordination and balance required for split jumps can be challenging and unsafe for individuals with balance impairments.

recent lower limb surgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding high-impact activities to prevent complications and ensure proper healing.

modifications.easier: Perform alternating reverse lunges without the jump to reduce impact and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Add a tuck jump at the peak of the split jump for increased difficulty and power demand.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform step-back lunges instead of jumping to minimize joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on stationary lunges with controlled tempo to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing split jumps to prepare the muscles and joints.
Ensure the landing surface is stable and non-slip to prevent falls.
Avoid excessive forward lean to protect the knees and lower back.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain balance and protect the spine.
Land softly on the balls of your feet to reduce impact forces.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to collapse inward during landing.
Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Failing to use arm swing for momentum and balance.

name: Split Snatch
instructions: Begin with a loaded barbell on the floor. The bar should be close to or touching the shins, and a wide grip should be taken on the bar. The feet should be directly below the hips, with the feet turned out as needed. Lower the hips, with the chest up and the head looking forward. The shoulders should be just in front of the bar. This will be the starting position.
Begin the first pull by driving through the front of the heels, raising the bar from the ground. The back angle should stay the same until the bar passes the knees.

Transition into the second pull by extending through the hips knees and ankles, driving the bar up as quickly as possible. The bar should be close to the body. At peak extension, shrug the shoulders and allow the elbows to flex to the side.

As you move your feet into the receiving position, forcefully pull yourself below the bar as you elevate the bar overhead. The feet should move forcefully to a split position, one foot forward one foot back. Receive the bar with your body as low as possible and the arms fully extended overhead.
Keeping the bar aligned over the front of the heels, your head and chest up, drive through heels of the feet to move to a standing position, bringing your feet together.
Carefully return the weight to floor.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: High risk due to the dynamic nature and spinal loading during the lift. Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: Moderate risk for those with arthritis or shoulder impingement due to overhead load. Modifications or alternative exercises may be necessary.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: Moderate risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease due to the intense nature of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: High risk, especially in the second and third trimesters, due to balance and core stability challenges.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: High risk post-surgery, particularly for the spine, shoulders, or knees. Clearance from a healthcare provider is necessary.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High risk due to potential for high-impact forces and risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: High risk for recent sprains, strains, or trauma. Healing must be complete before attempting.
contraindicationDetails.neurological_conditions: Moderate risk for those with balance disorders or neuropathy due to the coordination and balance required.

modifications.easier: Perform a power snatch or hang snatch to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom of the split to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on technique, or perform a hang snatch to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the split or perform a power snatch to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter weight and ensure proper warm-up and mobility work before attempting.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up and mobility exercises before attempting.
Use a spotter or perform in a controlled environment to minimize risk.
Avoid excessive weight until proper form is mastered.
formCues: Keep the bar close to the body throughout the lift.
Drive through the heels and extend the hips explosively.
Maintain a neutral spine and keep the chest up.
Ensure the bar is directly overhead with arms fully extended in the receiving position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the bar to drift away from the body.
Rounding the back during the lift.
Failing to fully extend the hips before pulling under the bar.
Landing with an unstable split stance.

recommendedReps.endurance: Not recommended due to high intensity.

name: Split Squat with Dumbbells
instructions: Position yourself into a staggered stance with the rear foot elevated and front foot forward.
Hold a dumbbell in each hand, letting them hang at the sides. This will be your starting position.
Begin by descending, flexing your knee and hip to lower your body down. Maintain good posture througout the movement. Keep the front knee in line with the foot as you perform the exercise.
At the bottom of the movement, drive through the heel to extend the knee and hip to return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The exercise can exacerbate pain and inflammation in the knee joint due to the load and range of motion involved.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The movement may increase stress on the patellar tendon, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: The elevated rear foot position can challenge balance and stability, increasing the risk of ankle injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe balance disorders: The staggered stance and rear foot elevation require good balance, which may be compromised in individuals with balance disorders.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery may be compromised by the load and movement pattern, especially if the surgery involved the knee, hip, or ankle.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The exercise may increase spinal load and exacerbate symptoms, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The movement can irritate the sciatic nerve, particularly if there is poor posture or excessive forward lean.

modifications.easier: Perform the split squat without dumbbells to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance and stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Keep the torso upright and engage the core to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to a pain-free range and ensure the knee does not travel past the toes.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Hold the dumbbells with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the rear foot is securely positioned to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive forward lean to minimize spinal stress.
Maintain a controlled descent to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back.
Engage the core throughout the movement.
Drive through the heel of the front foot to return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to collapse inward.
Leaning too far forward, placing stress on the lower back.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Split Squats
instructions: Being in a standing position. Jump into a split leg position, with one leg forward and one leg back, flexing the knees and lowering your hips slightly as you do so.
As you descend, immediately reverse direction, standing back up and jumping, reversing the position of your legs. Repeat 5-10 times on each leg.

contraindicationDetails.knee injuries: The dynamic nature of split squats can exacerbate knee pain or instability, especially in cases of ligament tears or severe arthritis.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The jumping motion can increase lumbar spine stress, potentially aggravating existing lower back conditions.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may exacerbate sciatic nerve irritation due to increased lumbar and hip flexion.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee surgery: Post-surgical knees may not tolerate the impact and dynamic movement required in split squats.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The need for balance during the exercise can pose a fall risk for individuals with balance impairments.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: The exercise can place stress on the hip joint, potentially worsening symptoms in those with arthritis.

modifications.easier: Perform static lunges instead of jumping to reduce impact and focus on stability.
modifications.harder: Add dumbbells for increased resistance or perform on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the range of motion and avoid the jumping component.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on maintaining a neutral spine and avoid deep lunges.

safetyNotes: Ensure a proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints.
Avoid excessive forward knee movement beyond the toes to reduce knee stress.
Maintain a controlled landing to minimize joint impact.
formCues: Keep the chest upright and core engaged throughout the movement.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Focus on a smooth and controlled transition between legs.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to collapse inward.
Landing with a stiff leg, increasing joint stress.
Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the back.

name: Squat Jerk
instructions: Standing with the weight racked on the front of the shoulders, begin with the dip. With your feet directly under your hips, flex the knees without moving the hips backward. Go down only slightly, and reverse direction as powerfully as possible. Drive through the heels create as much speed and force as possible, and be sure to move your head out of the way as the bar leaves the shoulders.

At this moment as the feet leave the floor, the feet must be placed into the receiving position as quickly as possible. In the brief moment the feet are not actively driving against the platform, the athlete's effort to push the bar up will drive them down. The feet should move forcefully to just outside the hips, turned out as necessary. Receive the bar with your body in a full squat and the arms fully extended overhead.
Keeping the bar aligned over the front of the heels, your head and chest up, drive throught heels of the feet to move to a standing position. Carefully return the weight to floor.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The squat jerk places significant axial load on the spine, which can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_injuries.explanation: The overhead position requires strong shoulder stability and mobility, which can be compromised in cases of rotator cuff injuries or impingement.

knee_injuries.explanation: The deep squat position can increase stress on the knee joint, potentially aggravating conditions like tendinitis or meniscus tears.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The explosive nature of the movement can spike heart rate and blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: The exercise's intensity and balance requirements are not recommended during pregnancy due to potential risks to both the mother and fetus.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries, especially involving the spine, shoulders, or knees, require avoidance of high-load, dynamic movements like the squat jerk.

neurological_conditions.explanation: Conditions affecting balance or coordination, such as neuropathy, can increase the risk of falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Perform a push press or a power jerk to reduce the complexity and balance requirements.
modifications.harder: Increase the load or perform the movement from a deficit to increase range of motion and difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and perform a split jerk to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat and focus on a power jerk variation.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a push press to avoid the overhead squat position.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up focusing on shoulder, hip, and knee mobility.
Use a spotter or safety bars to prevent injury in case of failure.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the heels and maintain a neutral spine.
Ensure the bar path is vertical and aligned over the midfoot.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to collapse inward during the squat.
Failing to fully extend the arms overhead.
Using excessive weight that leads to poor form.

name: Squat with Bands
instructions: Set up the bands on the sleeves, secured to either band pegs, the rack, or dumbbells so that there is appropriate tension.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wide for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips as much as possible. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Lower bar position necessitates a greater torso lean to keep the bar over the heels. Continue until you break parallel, which is defined as the crease of the hip being in line with the top of the knee.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe, until you have returned to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and potential for spinal compression.

joint_issues.explanation: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis may experience increased joint stress and should modify the exercise or avoid it if pain persists.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: Hypertension and heart disease patients should monitor their blood pressure and avoid Valsalva maneuver during the lift.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid heavy lifting and exercises that require significant balance and core stability.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Post-surgical patients, particularly those recovering from back or knee surgery, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.explanation: Osteoporosis patients should avoid heavy axial loading to prevent fractures. Diabetic individuals should monitor blood sugar levels.

acute_injuries.explanation: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

neurological_conditions.explanation: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form.

modifications.easier: Bodyweight squat or goblet squat with a dumbbell.
modifications.harder: Add more resistance bands or increase barbell weight.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a Smith machine to stabilize the movement and reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform a box squat to limit knee flexion and reduce stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a safety squat bar to minimize shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely attached to prevent snapping.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare joints and muscles.
Avoid locking knees at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Drive through the heels to engage the posterior chain.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward during ascent.
Rounding the back, especially at the bottom of the squat.
Failing to maintain tension in the bands throughout the movement.

name: Squat with Chains
instructions: To set up the chains, begin by looping the leader chain over the sleeves of the bar. The heavy chain should be attached using a snap hook. Adjust the length of the lead chain so that a few links are still on the floor at the top of the movement.

Begin by stepping under the bar and placing it across the back of the shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wide for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings. Keep your head facing forward.

With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips as much as possible. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Lower bar position necessitates a greater torso lean to keep the bar over the heels. Continue until you break parallel, which is defined as the crease of the hip being in line with the top of the knee.

Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe, until you have returned to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the compressive forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should modify the depth or load to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Hypertension or heart disease patients should consult a physician due to increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid heavy squats due to balance changes and increased intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Avoid if recovering from recent surgeries, especially in the lower body or spine, until cleared by a healthcare provider.

osteoporosis.details: High risk of fractures due to bone fragility; alternative exercises with less axial loading are recommended.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase fall risk; modifications or alternative exercises are advised.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight squats or use lighter weights without chains to reduce complexity and load.
modifications.harder: Increase chain weight or use a pause at the bottom of the squat to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a goblet squat or reduce depth to maintain a neutral spine and minimize lumbar stress.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit squat depth and focus on controlled, slow movements to reduce knee strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a safety squat bar to reduce shoulder rotation and stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure chains are properly secured and adjusted to prevent instability.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid lumbar stress.
Use a spotter or safety bars in the rack for added safety.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged to maintain spinal alignment.
Drive through your heels to ensure proper force distribution.
Push your knees out to align with your toes and prevent valgus collapse.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during ascent.
Rounding the lower back at the bottom of the squat.
Leaning too far forward, causing excessive torso flexion.

name: Squat with Plate Movers
instructions: To begin, first set the bar on a rack to just below shoulder level. Position a weight plate on the ground a couple feet back from the rack. Once the bar is loaded, step under it and place the back of your shoulders across it.
Hold on to the bar with both hands and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straighten your torso.
Step away from the rack and adopt a wide stance with the toes slightly pointed out, with one foot on the weight plate. Keep your head up at all times. This will be your starting position.
Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and hips. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees.
Raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heels of your feet as you extend the hips and knees.
At the top of the movement, side step, bringing your feet together on the opposite side of the plate.
Using your inside foot, push the weight plate, sliding it across the floor to where you were just standing.
Place your inside foot on the weight plate, adopting a wide stance for the next repetition.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, spondylolisthesis, or sciatica should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and potential for spinal compression.

knee_joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis, tendinitis, or previous knee surgeries should modify the depth and load to reduce stress on the knee joint.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before performing this exercise due to the potential for increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance and abdominal pressure concerns.

surgical_recovery.details: Individuals recovering from recent surgeries, particularly in the lower body or spine, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

balance_disorders.details: Those with balance issues should perform this exercise with caution or under supervision to prevent falls.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight squats or use a lighter barbell without the plate movement to focus on form and balance.
modifications.harder: Increase the barbell weight or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad to challenge stability.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a Smith machine to provide more support and control during the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the squat depth to a partial squat and focus on keeping the knees aligned with the toes.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely loaded and the rack is stable before starting.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar flexion or extension.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back to maintain a strong upper body posture.
Drive through your heels and keep your knees aligned with your toes.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat.
Leaning too far forward, placing excessive stress on the lower back.
Not maintaining a consistent tempo, leading to loss of control.

name: Squats - With Bands
instructions: To start out, make sure that the exercise band is at an even split between both the left and right side of the body. To do this, use your hands to grab both sides of the band and place both feet in the middle of the band. Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other.

When holding the bands, they should be the same height on each side. You should be using a pronated grip (palms facing forward) and have the handles of the bands next to your face for this exercise. This is the starting position.
Slowly start to bend the knees and lower the legs so that your thighs are parallel to the floor while exhaling.
Use the heel of your feet to push your body up to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High compressive forces on the knee joint during squats can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The exercise involves knee extension, which can increase strain on the patellar tendon.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Improper form or excessive load can increase lumbar spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The exercise may aggravate symptoms due to lumbar flexion and load.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Maintaining stability during the squat can be challenging and risky.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee surgery: Healing tissues may not tolerate the stress of squatting.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The exertion level may be too high for individuals with compromised heart function.

modifications.easier: Perform squats without bands or use a chair for support.
modifications.harder: Increase band resistance or perform single-leg squats with bands.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a lighter resistance band and limit depth to pain-free range.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a more upright torso and engage core muscles to support the spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely anchored under feet to prevent slipping.
Avoid locking knees at the top of the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep feet shoulder-width apart and toes slightly pointed out.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
Drive through the heels to return to the starting position.
Keep knees aligned with toes and avoid letting them cave inward.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to extend beyond toes.
Rounding the back during the descent.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Uneven band tension between sides.

name: Stairmaster
instructions: To begin, step onto the stairmaster and select the desired option from the menu. You can choose a manual setting, or you can select a program to run. Typically, you can enter your age and weight to estimate the amount of calories burned during exercise.

Pump your legs up and down in an established rhythm, driving the pedals down but not all the way to the floor. It is recommended that you maintain your grip on the handles so that you don't fall. The handles can be used to monitor your heart rate to help you stay at an appropriate intensity.

Stairmasters offer convenience, cardiovascular benefits, and usually have less impact than running outside. They are typically much harder than other cardio equipment. A 150 lb person will typically burn over 300 calories in 30 minutes, compared to about 175 calories walking.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The repetitive motion and load on the knee joint can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: The continuous hip flexion and extension may irritate the bursa.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The high cardiovascular demand may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled heart conditions.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding high-impact or repetitive stress on healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The movement and height of the machine can pose a fall risk.

modifications.easier: Reduce the speed and resistance settings to decrease intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed and resistance settings or incorporate interval training.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to reduce stress on the knees.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain an upright posture and avoid leaning forward excessively.

safetyNotes: Always use the handrails for stability, especially when starting or stopping the machine.
Ensure the machine is properly calibrated and functioning before use.
Stay hydrated and take breaks if you feel dizzy or fatigued.
formCues: Maintain an upright posture with a slight forward lean.
Engage your core muscles to support your lower back.
Keep your steps smooth and controlled, avoiding slamming the pedals.
commonMistakes: Leaning heavily on the handrails, which reduces the effectiveness of the workout.
Allowing the knees to lock at the top of the step.
Using excessive speed that compromises form and increases injury risk.

recommendedReps.interval training: 1-2 minutes high intensity followed by 1-2 minutes low intensity

name: Standing Alternating Dumbbell Press
instructions: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand. Raise the dumbbells to your shoulders with your palms facing forward and your elbows pointed out. This will be your starting position.
Extend one arm to press the dumbbell straight up, keeping your off hand in place. Do not lean or jerk the weight during the movement.
After a brief pause, return the weight to the starting position.
Repeat for the opposite side, continuing to alternate between arms.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High overhead movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The pressing motion may aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Overhead movements can increase strain on the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fracture with overhead loading.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead pressing can increase blood pressure, which may be risky for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands and use lighter weights.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm press with a heavier dumbbell to increase core stabilization requirements.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a neutral grip press to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Avoid locking out the elbows at the top of the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Do not use momentum to lift the weights.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the torso.
Press the dumbbell directly upward, not forward or backward.
Keep your head aligned with your spine.
commonMistakes: Leaning back excessively during the press.
Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Failing to control the descent of the dumbbell.

name: Standing Barbell Calf Raise
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the bar on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck).
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. The knees should be kept with a slight bend; never locked. This will be your starting position. Tip: For better range of motion you may also place the ball of your feet on a wooden block but be careful as this option requires more balance and a sturdy block.

Raise your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending at any time. Hold the contracted position by a second before you start to go back down.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering your heels as you bend the ankles until calves are stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.achilles tendinitis: High stress on the Achilles tendon during calf raises can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: The exercise can increase tension on the plantar fascia, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: Weight-bearing exercises can increase joint stress and pain in affected knees.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: The requirement for balance can increase the risk of ankle sprains.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not withstand the load and stress of this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires good balance, posing a risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.severe lower back pain: Supporting a barbell on the back can exacerbate lower back issues.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights or use a Smith machine for added stability.
modifications.harder: Perform single-leg calf raises to increase the challenge and balance requirement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a seated calf raise machine to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid using additional weight.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform the exercise on a stable surface without elevation.

safetyNotes: Always use a squat rack for safety when lifting a barbell.
Ensure the barbell is securely loaded and balanced before beginning.
Avoid locking the knees to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees throughout the movement.
Focus on a controlled ascent and descent to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Allowing the knees to lock during the exercise.
Failing to maintain a straight back and neutral spine.

name: Standing Barbell Press Behind Neck
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for easier pick up of the bar. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Your back should be kept straight while performing this exercise. This will be your starting position.
Elevate the barbell overhead by fully extending your arms while breathing out.
Hold the contraction for a second and lower the barbell back down to the starting position by inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The behind-the-neck position can exacerbate impingement by forcing the shoulder into extreme external rotation.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff, increasing the risk of aggravation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The barbell's position can strain the cervical spine, especially in those with pre-existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to the load on the elbow joint during pressing.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The load on the spine and shoulders can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.thoracic outlet syndrome: The overhead position may compress neurovascular structures, worsening symptoms.

modifications.easier: Seated dumbbell shoulder press to reduce spinal loading and improve control.
modifications.harder: Single-arm standing dumbbell press to increase core stabilization demands.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip dumbbell press to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare shoulder joints and muscles.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back during the press.
Use a spotter or safety pins in the rack for added safety.
formCues: Keep elbows slightly forward to reduce shoulder stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
commonMistakes: Allowing the bar to drift too far behind the head.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Neglecting to engage the core, leading to excessive lumbar extension.

name: Standing Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
instructions: With a dumbbell in one hand and the palm facing your torso, bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Make sure that you keep the head up.

The upper arm should be close to the torso and parallel to the floor while the forearm is pointing towards the floor as the hand holds the weight. Tip: There should be a 90-degree angle between the forearm and the upper arm. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arms stationary, use the triceps to lift the weights as you exhale until the forearms are parallel to the floor and the whole arm is extended. Like many other arm exercises, only the forearm moves.
After a second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbell back to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: This exercise involves shoulder stabilization, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive extension of the elbow can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Stabilizing the shoulder joint during this exercise can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell may increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Any recent surgery involving the shoulder, elbow, or wrist may require avoiding this exercise to prevent strain.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Bending forward can place stress on the spine, potentially aggravating conditions like herniated discs or sciatica.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with back support to reduce the need for core stabilization.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support and use a lighter weight.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Reduce the range of motion or perform triceps pushdowns with a resistance band instead.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid locking the elbow at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the upper arm stationary and close to the torso.
Engage the core to maintain balance and support the lower back.
Exhale as you extend the arm and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the upper arm to move away from the torso, reducing triceps activation.
Rounding the back, which can lead to spinal strain.

name: Standing Bent-Over Two-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
instructions: With a dumbbell in each hand and the palms facing your torso, bend your knees slightly and bring your torso forward, by bending at the waist, while keeping the back straight until it is almost parallel to the floor. Make sure that you keep the head up. The upper arms should be close to the torso and parallel to the floor while the forearms are pointing towards the floor as the hands hold the weights. Tip: There should be a 90-degree angle between the forearms and the upper arm. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arms stationary, use the triceps to lift the weights as you exhale until the forearms are parallel to the floor and the whole arms are extended. Like many other arm exercises, only the forearm moves.
After a second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbells back to their starting position as you inhale.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms and the movement can exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms due to the overhead nature of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension of the elbow can aggravate tendinitis, particularly in the triceps tendon.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required from the shoulder muscles can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The bent-over position can increase stress on the lumbar spine, potentially worsening lower back pain.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward bending position can increase intra-disc pressure, potentially exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (third trimester): The forward-leaning position may be uncomfortable and could affect balance.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with back support to reduce the demand on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Use a single heavier dumbbell held with both hands to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform triceps kickbacks with a lighter weight to minimize shoulder involvement.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a bench to support the chest and reduce strain on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso and prevent rounding of the back.
Exhale during the extension phase and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round, which can lead to lower back strain.
Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Letting the elbows flare out, reducing triceps engagement.

name: Standing Biceps Cable Curl
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a cable curl bar that is attached to a low pulley. Grab the cable bar at shoulder width and keep the elbows close to the torso. The palm of your hands should be facing up (supinated grip). This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the muscle.
Slowly begin to bring the curl bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow can exacerbate tendinitis symptoms. Modifications or alternative exercises may be necessary.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Keeping elbows close to the torso can cause discomfort in individuals with shoulder impingement. Adjusting the range of motion or using lighter weights may help.

carpal tunnel syndrome.explanation: Gripping the bar can aggravate symptoms. Using wrist straps or a neutral grip may alleviate pressure on the median nerve.

severe hypertension.explanation: Isometric contractions and holding breath during exertion can increase blood pressure. Consultation with a healthcare provider is recommended.

safetyNotes: Avoid locking the elbows at the bottom of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid leaning back to lift the weight.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body throughout the movement.
Focus on a slow and controlled descent to maximize muscle engagement.
Exhale during the curl and inhale as you lower the weight.
commonMistakes: Using momentum by swinging the body or leaning back.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing bicep isolation.
Not fully extending the arms, limiting range of motion.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load on the biceps and joints.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm cable curl to increase the challenge and engage core stabilizers.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip attachment to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
