injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize shoulder involvement.

name: Standing Biceps Stretch
instructions: Clasp your hands behind your back with your palms together, straighten arms and then rotate them so your palms face downward.
Raise your arms up and hold until you feel a stretch in your biceps.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms behind the back can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the shoulder structures.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: This stretch can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Extending the arms fully and holding a stretch can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Clasping hands and rotating the wrists can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with a towel between the hands to reduce the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Perform the stretch while leaning forward slightly to increase the stretch intensity.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the stretch with one arm at a time to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow_pain: Keep the elbows slightly bent to reduce tension on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid overstretching to prevent muscle strain.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
Ensure a gradual increase in stretch intensity.
formCues: Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from your ears.
Engage your core to maintain an upright posture.
Breathe deeply and evenly throughout the stretch.
commonMistakes: Overarching the lower back.
Forcing the arms too high, causing shoulder discomfort.
Holding the breath during the stretch.

name: Standing Bradford Press
instructions: Place a loaded bar at shoulder level in a rack. With a pronated grip at shoulder width, begin with the bar racked across the front of your shoulders. This is your starting position.
Initiate the lift by extending the elbows to press the bar overhead. Avoid locking out the elbow as you move the weight behind your head.
Lower the bar down to the back of the head until your elbow forms a right angle.
Lift the bar back over your head by extending the elbows
Lower the bar down to the starting position.
Alternate in this manner until you complete the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The position of the bar behind the head can strain the cervical spine, especially if flexibility is limited.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repeated elbow extension and flexion can aggravate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The load on the spine and shoulders may increase the risk of fractures, particularly in the thoracic region.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding heavy loads and overhead movements to prevent re-injury.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or a dowel to practice the movement pattern without significant load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the barbell or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to engage more stabilizers.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press to reduce spinal loading and allow for more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely loaded and balanced before starting.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid excessive arching of the back, particularly when pressing the bar overhead.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Avoid locking out your elbows at the top of the press.
Move the bar in a controlled manner, focusing on smooth transitions between the front and back positions.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.
Failing to maintain a neutral head position, which can stress the cervical spine.

name: Standing Cable Chest Press
instructions: Position dual pulleys to chest height and select an appropriate weight. Stand a foot or two in front of the cables, holding one in each hand. You can stagger your stance for better stability.
Position the upper arm at a 90 degree angle with the shoulder blades together. This will be your starting position.
Keeping the rest of the body stationary, extend through the elbows to press the handles forward, drawing them together in front of you.
Pause at the top of the motion, and return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Pressing movements can exacerbate impingement by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may increase inflammation and pain in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.chest surgery recovery: Post-surgical tissues may not withstand the stress of pressing movements.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fractures due to the load on the upper body.
contraindicationDetails.acute shoulder or chest injuries: These injuries require rest and rehabilitation before engaging in pressing exercises.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: Strenuous upper body exercises can provoke cardiac events.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Healing tissues are vulnerable to stress and strain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with back support to reduce stability demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Reduce the range of motion, keeping elbows slightly bent throughout.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable pulleys are securely fastened and at the correct height.
Start with a light weight to master the form before increasing the load.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Exhale as you press the handles forward and inhale as you return to the starting position.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.
Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Arching the back excessively during the press.

name: Standing Cable Lift
instructions: Connect a standard handle on a tower, and move the cable to the lowest pulley position.

With your side to the cable, grab the handle with one hand and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm's length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable. Your outstretched arm should be aligned with the cable.
With your feet positioned shoulder width apart, squat down and grab the handle with both hands. Your arms should still be fully extended.
In one motion, pull the handle up and across your body until your arms are in a fully-extended position above your head.
Keep your back straight and your arms close to your body as you pivot your back foot and straighten your legs to get a full range of motion.
Retract your arms and then your body. Return to the neutral position in a slow and controlled manner.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the rotational and axial loading on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with shoulder impingement or knee arthritis should modify the exercise to minimize joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing exercises involving significant core engagement and balance.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid exercises with significant twisting and balance challenges, especially in the second and third trimesters.

osteoporosis.details: Due to the risk of spinal fractures, individuals with osteoporosis should avoid exercises that involve twisting and axial loading.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are any acute injuries such as muscle strains or sprains in the core, shoulders, or lower body.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications to ensure safety and stability during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable machine or perform the exercise on a single leg to challenge balance and core stability further.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise seated on a stability ball to reduce spinal load and improve support.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid overhead extension and focus on the rotational component only.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Avoid deep squats; perform the exercise in a standing position without bending the knees significantly.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is securely anchored and the handle is properly attached.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive spinal flexion or extension.
Control the movement speed to prevent jerking motions that could lead to injury.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Keep your arms close to your body as you lift the handle.
Pivot on your back foot to facilitate the rotational movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the back to round or hyperextend during the lift.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.
Failing to pivot the back foot, leading to unnecessary stress on the knees.

name: Standing Cable Wood Chop
instructions: Connect a standard handle to a tower, and move the cable to the highest pulley position.

With your side to the cable, grab the handle with one hand and step away from the tower. You should be approximately arm's length away from the pulley, with the tension of the weight on the cable. Your outstretched arm should be aligned with the cable.
With your feet positioned shoulder width apart, reach upward with your other hand and grab the handle with both hands. Your arms should still be fully extended.
In one motion, pull the handle down and across your body to your front knee while rotating your torso.
Keep your back and arms straight and core tight while you pivot your back foot and bend your knees to get a full range of motion.
Maintain your stance and straight arms. Return to the neutral position in a slow and controlled manner.
Repeat to failure.
Then, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the rotational forces and potential for spinal compression.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or shoulder impingement should modify the range of motion to avoid exacerbating joint pain.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should perform this exercise at a lower intensity to avoid excessive cardiovascular strain.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid exercises that involve significant twisting and core compression, especially in the second and third trimesters.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from abdominal or spinal surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare professional.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid high-impact or high-torque movements that could increase fracture risk.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if there are any recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the torso or lower limbs.

neurological_conditions.details: Those with balance disorders or neuropathy should perform this exercise with caution and possibly under supervision.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable machine or perform the exercise on a single leg to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Reduce the range of motion and avoid excessive twisting. Focus on engaging the core without full rotation.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the knee bend and ensure proper foot alignment to reduce stress on the knees.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Keep the arms slightly bent to reduce strain on the shoulder joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is securely anchored and the handle is properly attached.
Start with a light weight to master the movement pattern before increasing resistance.
Avoid jerky or uncontrolled movements to minimize the risk of injury.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement to stabilize the spine.
Keep the arms straight but not locked to maintain control.
Pivot the back foot and bend the knees to facilitate a smooth rotational movement.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Failing to pivot the back foot, which can strain the knees and lower back.
Allowing the arms to bend excessively, reducing the effectiveness of the exercise.

name: Standing Calf Raises
instructions: Adjust the padded lever of the calf raise machine to fit your height.

Place your shoulders under the pads provided and position your toes facing forward (or using any of the two other positions described at the beginning of the chapter). The balls of your feet should be secured on top of the calf block with the heels extending off it. Push the lever up by extending your hips and knees until your torso is standing erect. The knees should be kept with a slight bend; never locked. Toes should be facing forward, outwards or inwards as described at the beginning of the chapter. This will be your starting position.

Raise your heels as you breathe out by extending your ankles as high as possible and flexing your calf. Ensure that the knee is kept stationary at all times. There should be no bending at any time. Hold the contracted position by a second before you start to go back down.
Go back slowly to the starting position as you breathe in by lowering your heels as you bend the ankles until calves are stretched.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

Achilles tendinitis.explanation: The exercise places significant stress on the Achilles tendon, potentially exacerbating inflammation and pain.

Plantar fasciitis.explanation: Standing calf raises can increase tension on the plantar fascia, potentially worsening symptoms.

Recent ankle sprain.explanation: The exercise requires stability and strength in the ankle, which may not be present during recovery from a sprain.

Severe osteoarthritis in the ankle.explanation: Weight-bearing exercises can exacerbate joint pain and degeneration in individuals with severe osteoarthritis.

Peripheral neuropathy.explanation: Reduced sensation in the feet may affect balance and increase the risk of injury during the exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform seated calf raises to reduce the load on the ankle and Achilles tendon.
modifications.harder: Perform single-leg standing calf raises to increase difficulty and balance requirements.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a seated calf raise machine to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Ensure a slight bend in the knees to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is adjusted to fit your height to prevent unnecessary strain.
Keep movements controlled to avoid jerking motions that could lead to injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability.
Avoid locking your knees; maintain a slight bend.
Raise your heels as high as possible for full calf contraction.
commonMistakes: Bouncing at the bottom of the movement instead of controlled lowering.
Allowing the knees to lock during the exercise.
Using too much weight, compromising form and increasing injury risk.

name: Standing Concentration Curl
instructions: Taking a dumbbell in your working hand, lean forward. Allow your working arm to hang perpendicular to the ground with the elbow pointing out. This will be your starting position.
Flex the elbow to curl the weight, keeping the upper arm stationary. At the top of the repetition, flex the biceps and pause.
Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation and pain in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Leaning forward may place undue stress on the shoulder joint, potentially worsening impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell may increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is increased with high loads or improper form.
contraindicationDetails.acute wrist or elbow injuries: The exercise may worsen pain or delay healing in the affected joints.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated with the elbow supported on the inner thigh to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a resistance band instead of a dumbbell to reduce joint stress and allow for a more controlled movement.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine to avoid unnecessary strain on the lower back.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weight, as this can lead to injury.
formCues: Keep the upper arm stationary and close to the body.
Flex the bicep fully at the top of the movement and pause briefly.
Lower the weight in a controlled manner.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbow to drift away from the body.
Not fully extending the arm at the bottom of the movement.

name: Standing Dumbbell Calf Raise
instructions: Stand with your torso upright holding two dumbbells in your hands by your sides. Place the ball of the foot on a sturdy and stable wooden board (that is around 2-3 inches tall) while your heels extend off and touch the floor. This will be your starting position.

With the toes pointing either straight (to hit all parts equally), inwards (for emphasis on the outer head) or outwards (for emphasis on the inner head), raise the heels off the floor as you exhale by contracting the calves. Hold the top contraction for a second.
As you inhale, go back to the starting position by slowly lowering the heels.
Repeat for the recommended amount of times.

contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: High risk of further injury due to the need for stable ankle support during the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Moderate risk as the exercise requires good balance, especially when performed on an elevated surface.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle or foot surgery: High risk of re-injury or delayed healing; avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: Moderate risk; can exacerbate symptoms due to the stress on the Achilles tendon.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: Moderate risk; can increase pain and inflammation in the plantar fascia.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High risk of fractures due to the weight-bearing nature of the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.peripheral neuropathy: Moderate risk due to potential lack of proprioception and increased fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without weights or using a stable surface for support.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on one leg to increase the difficulty and balance challenge.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated calf raises to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a leg press machine for calf raises to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Perform seated calf raises to minimize ankle stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the board is stable and secure to prevent slipping.
Do not lock knees; keep them slightly bent to reduce joint stress.
Avoid bouncing at the top of the movement to prevent tendon strain.
formCues: Keep core engaged to maintain balance.
Raise heels slowly and with control.
Hold the top position briefly to maximize muscle contraction.
Lower heels slowly to avoid jerking movements.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of muscle control.
Allowing ankles to roll outward or inward excessively.
Not using a full range of motion.
Holding breath during the exercise.

name: Standing Dumbbell Press
instructions: Standing with your feet shoulder width apart, take a dumbbell in each hand. Raise the dumbbells to head height, the elbows out and about 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Maintaining strict technique with no leg drive or leaning back, extend through the elbow to raise the weights together directly above your head.
Pause, and slowly return the weight to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead motion can exacerbate impingement by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially worsening inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights overhead can strain the cervical spine, especially if posture is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture increases with overhead loading, particularly in the spine.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead lifting can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Standing overhead presses can increase lumbar spine stress, potentially aggravating this condition.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands and lower back strain.
modifications.harder: Use a single arm to perform the press for increased core engagement and unilateral strength.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing overhead exercises.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent compromising form.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Ensure your elbows are slightly in front of your body at the start.
Press the weights directly overhead without arching your back.
commonMistakes: Leaning back excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Using momentum or leg drive to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to flare out too wide, increasing shoulder stress.

name: Standing Dumbbell Reverse Curl
instructions: To begin, stand straight with a dumbbell in each hand using a pronated grip (palms facing down). Your arms should be fully extended while your feet are shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the muscle.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during curls can exacerbate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The pronated grip may increase shoulder stress, potentially aggravating impingement.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping dumbbells can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise can strain the shoulder joint, particularly if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Weight-bearing exercises with improper form can increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Use lighter dumbbells or perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase or add a pause at the top of the curl.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip (hammer curl) to reduce stress on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a resistance band to allow for more natural joint movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure a firm grip on the dumbbells to prevent slipping.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weights; focus on controlled movements.
Keep the wrists in a neutral position to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the curl.
Maintain a straight back and engage the core for stability.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the body.
Bending the wrists excessively during the curl.

name: Standing Dumbbell Straight-Arm Front Delt Raise Above Head
instructions: Hold the dumbbells in front of your thighs, palms facing your thighs.
Keep your arms straight with a slight bend at the elbows but keep them locked. This will be your starting position.
Raise the dumbbells in a semicircular motion to arm's length overhead as you exhale.
Slowly return to the starting position using the same path as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms above the head can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the tendons or bursa in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: This exercise can place additional stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially worsening inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights overhead can strain the neck, particularly in individuals with cervical spine pathologies.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Overhead movements with weights can increase the risk of fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead exercises can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to shoulder height and avoid going overhead.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize neck strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder and neck strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep a slight bend in the elbows to reduce joint stress.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso and prevent arching of the back.
Lift the weights in a controlled manner, avoiding momentum.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights, reducing muscle engagement.
Allowing the back to arch excessively, increasing the risk of injury.
Lifting the weights too quickly, which can lead to poor form and increased injury risk.

name: Standing Dumbbell Triceps Extension
instructions: To begin, stand up with a dumbbell held by both hands. Your feet should be about shoulder width apart from each other. Slowly use both hands to grab the dumbbell and lift it over your head until both arms are fully extended.
The resistance should be resting in the palms of your hands with your thumbs around it. The palm of the hands should be facing up towards the ceiling. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your upper arms close to your head with elbows in and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the dumbbell. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to overhead position which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Moderate risk as the exercise involves repetitive elbow extension which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: High risk because the overhead position can strain the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Low risk but caution is advised due to grip involvement.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: High risk; avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Moderate risk; the standing position requires core stabilization which can stress the spine.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce core stabilization demands.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise on one leg to increase balance and core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a resistance band instead of a dumbbell to reduce load and stress on the shoulder.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit range of motion to avoid full extension and reduce stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure a firm grip on the dumbbell to prevent it from slipping.
Avoid arching the back; engage the core to maintain a neutral spine.
Do not lock the elbows at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the head and pointing forward.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
Move only the forearms; upper arms should remain stationary.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, which reduces triceps engagement.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively during the lift.

name: Standing Dumbbell Upright Row
instructions: Grasp a dumbbell in each hand with a pronated (palms forward) grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The dumbbells should be resting on top of your thighs. Your arms should be extended with a slight bend at the elbows and your back should be straight. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the dumbbells as you exhale. The dumbbells should be close to the body as you move it up and the elbows should drive the motion. Continue to lift them until they nearly touch your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the dumbbells, your elbows should always be higher than your forearms. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the dumbbells back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The upright row can exacerbate impingement due to the elevation and internal rotation of the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding weights close to the chin can strain the neck, aggravating cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and lifting motion can exacerbate tendinitis in the elbow.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with resistance bands instead of dumbbells to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a barbell for increased load and stability challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion to below shoulder height to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated to minimize lower back strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid lifting the dumbbells too high to prevent shoulder impingement.
Ensure a neutral wrist position to avoid undue stress on the wrists.
formCues: Keep elbows higher than wrists throughout the movement.
Maintain a straight back and engaged core.
Lift with controlled motion, avoiding jerking movements.
commonMistakes: Lifting the dumbbells too high, causing shoulder impingement.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the back to round or sway during the lift.

name: Standing Elevated Quad Stretch
instructions: Start by standing with your back about two to three feet away from a bench or step.
Lift one leg behind you and rest your foot on the step,either on your instep or the ball of your foot, whichever you find most comfortable.
Keep your supporting knee slightly bent and avoid letting that knee extend out beyond your toes. Switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High stress on the knee joint can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The position may increase lumbar lordosis and aggravate pain.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Risk of falling due to single-leg stance.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee surgery: Healing tissues may not tolerate the stretch or load.
contraindicationDetails.hip impingement: The position may cause discomfort or pain due to hip flexion.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch lying on your side with a strap around your ankle to gently pull the foot towards the glutes.
modifications.harder: Add a slight forward lean to increase the stretch on the quadriceps and hip flexors.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch lying on your side to reduce lumbar strain.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a lower step or bench to decrease knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench or step is stable to prevent slipping.
Avoid excessive lumbar extension to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep your torso upright and engage your core.
Ensure your supporting knee is slightly bent and aligned with your toes.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the stretch.
commonMistakes: Allowing the supporting knee to lock or hyperextend.
Leaning too far forward or backward, losing balance.
Letting the knee of the supporting leg extend beyond the toes.

name: Standing Front Barbell Raise Over Head
instructions: To begin, stand straight with a barbell in your hands. You should grip the bar with palms facing down and a closer than shoulder width grip apart from each other.
Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. Your elbows should be slightly bent. This is the starting position.
Lift the barbell up until it is directly over your head while exhaling. Make sure to keep your elbows slightly bent when performing each repetition.
Once you feel the contraction, begin to lower the barbell back down to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The overhead motion can exacerbate impingement by narrowing the subacromial space.

rotator cuff injury.explanation: Lifting overhead places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, potentially worsening the injury.

cervical spine issues.explanation: The exercise may strain the neck, especially if form is compromised or if there is pre-existing cervical spine pathology.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: Gripping the barbell can aggravate tendinitis, particularly lateral epicondylitis.

osteoporosis.explanation: The load on the spine during overhead lifting can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.

hypertension.explanation: Overhead lifting can cause a temporary increase in blood pressure; individuals with uncontrolled hypertension should exercise caution.

modifications.easier: Use lighter dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a front raise to shoulder height only, avoiding the overhead position.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing overhead exercises.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent compromising form.
Ensure a stable base by keeping feet shoulder-width apart.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Lift the barbell in a controlled manner, avoiding jerking motions.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the barbell.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.
Failing to keep the elbows slightly bent.

name: Standing Gastrocnemius Calf Stretch
instructions: Place your right heel on a step with your knee extended and lean forward to grab your right toe with your right hand. Your left knee should be slightly bent and your back should be straight.
Support your weight on your left leg and place your left hand on your left thigh.
Pull your right toes toward your knee until you feel a stretch in your calf.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: high - Stretching can exacerbate symptoms and delay healing.
contraindicationDetails.plantar fasciitis: moderate - Stretching may increase pain; modifications needed.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - Risk of falling; exercise should be performed with support.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle sprain: high - Stretching can aggravate the injury and impede recovery.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: moderate - Joint stress may increase pain; modifications needed.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - Forward bending may increase nerve compression; modifications needed.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the heel on the ground instead of a step to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by placing the heel on a higher step or using a resistance band to pull the toes.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch while sitting on a chair to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep the supporting leg more bent to reduce strain on the knee joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing during the stretch to prevent muscle strain.
Ensure the supporting leg is stable to prevent falls.
formCues: Keep your back straight to avoid excessive spinal flexion.
Engage your core to maintain balance.
Pull the toes gently to avoid overstretching.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which can lead to lower back strain.
Locking the supporting knee, increasing joint stress.
Pulling the toes too forcefully, risking muscle strain.

name: Standing Hamstring and Calf Stretch
instructions: Being by looping a belt, band, or rope around one foot. While standing, place that foot forward.
Bend your back leg, while keeping the front one straight. Now raise the toes of your front foot off of the ground and lean forward.
Using the belt, pull on the top of the foot to increase the stretch in the calf. Hold for 10-20 seconds and repeat with the other foot.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs or sciatica should avoid forward bending to prevent exacerbating symptoms.

joint_issues.explanation: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should be cautious with weight distribution and avoid excessive bending.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals should avoid excessive forward bending and maintain balance to prevent falls.

acute_injuries.explanation: Avoid if there is a recent hamstring or calf strain to prevent further injury.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while seated on the ground with the leg extended, using the band to gently pull the toes back.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by leaning further forward and holding the position for up to 30 seconds.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the stretch lying on your back with the leg raised and supported, using the band to pull the toes.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Keep a slight bend in the front knee to reduce stress on the joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing during the stretch to prevent muscle strain.
Ensure the band is secure to prevent slipping.
formCues: Keep the back straight while leaning forward.
Engage the core to maintain balance.
Flex the toes towards the shin to enhance the stretch.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively.
Leaning too far forward, causing loss of balance.
Not keeping the front leg straight.

name: Standing Hip Circles
instructions: Begin standing on one leg, holding to a vertical support.
Raise the unsupported knee to 90 degrees. This will be your starting position.
Open the hip as far as possible, attempting to make a big circle with your knee.
Perform this movement slowly for a number of repetitions, and repeat on the other side.

hip_joint_issues.explanation: Individuals with hip arthritis, impingement, or bursitis may experience discomfort or exacerbation of symptoms due to the rotational movement.

balance_disorders.explanation: Those with balance disorders should avoid this exercise as it requires standing on one leg, increasing the risk of falls.

acute_knee_injuries.explanation: Knee injuries such as sprains or strains may be aggravated by the weight-bearing and rotational aspects of the exercise.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Conditions like herniated discs or sciatica may be exacerbated by the rotational forces and weight-bearing nature of the exercise.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, may need to modify or avoid this exercise due to balance changes and joint laxity.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise while seated on a chair, lifting the knee and making small circles to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise without holding onto a support to increase balance and core engagement.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion and ensure a neutral spine position.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and avoid locking the standing knee to reduce stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the standing leg is slightly bent to avoid hyperextension.
Use a stable support to prevent falls.
Avoid rapid or jerky movements to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to maintain balance.
Move the knee in a controlled, circular motion.
Keep the torso upright and avoid leaning.
commonMistakes: Leaning excessively to one side.
Performing the movement too quickly.
Locking the standing knee.

name: Standing Hip Flexors
instructions: Stand up straight with the spine vertical, the left foot slightly in front of the right.

Bend both knees and lift the back heel off the floor as you press the right hip forward. You can't get a thorough, deep stretch in this position, however, because it's hard to relax the hip flexor and stand on it at the same time. Switch sides.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or sciatica may experience discomfort due to the forward hip position and should modify or avoid this exercise.

joint_issues.details: Those with hip or knee arthritis may find this position uncomfortable and should consider modifications to reduce joint stress.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals may perform this exercise with caution, focusing on balance and avoiding excessive hip extension.

balance_disorders.details: Individuals with significant balance issues should avoid this exercise due to the risk of falls.

recent_lower_limb_surgery.details: Those recovering from recent lower limb surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with support from a wall or chair to aid balance.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Avoid deep knee bends and maintain a more upright posture.

safetyNotes: Ensure a stable surface to prevent slipping.
Avoid locking the knees to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders back.
Engage the core to maintain balance.
Press the hip forward gently without overextending.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to collapse inward.
Overarching the lower back.
Failing to engage the core muscles.

name: Standing Inner-Biceps Curl
instructions: Stand up with a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso. Your legs should be at about shoulder's width apart from each other.
Rotate the palms of the hands so that they are facing inward in a neutral position. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights out while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Your wrist should turn so that when the weights are fully elevated you have supinated grip (palms facing up).
Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. Tip: Keep the forearms aligned with your outer deltoids.
Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to the starting position as your breathe in. Remember to rotate the wrists as you lower the weight in order to switch back to a neutral grip.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during curls can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The supination and lifting motion can aggravate shoulder impingement.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells tightly can increase pressure on the carpal tunnel.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The rotational movement of the forearm can strain the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is heightened with heavy lifting in individuals with severe osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise on an unstable surface, such as a balance pad, to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a hammer curl grip to reduce strain on the elbow joint.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the elbows and shoulders.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to avoid lower back strain.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso and stationary.
Rotate wrists smoothly during the curl to avoid jerky movements.
Engage core muscles to maintain balance and posture.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to lift the weights.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the torso.
Using momentum instead of muscle contraction to lift the weights.

name: Standing Lateral Stretch
instructions: Take a slightly wider than hip distance stance with your knees slightly bent.
Place your right hand on your right hip to support the spine.
Raise your left arm in a vertical line and place your left hand behind your head. Keep it there as you incline your torso to the right.
Keep your weight evenly distributed between both legs (don't lean into your left hip). Switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Inclining the torso laterally can exacerbate disc protrusion, especially in the lumbar region.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Lateral bending may increase pressure on the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: This exercise can increase anterior shear forces on the spine, potentially aggravating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arm overhead may compress the shoulder structures, exacerbating impingement.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead arm positioning can increase blood pressure; caution is advised.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Lateral bending can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires good balance; those with balance issues are at risk of falls.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch seated on a chair to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Hold a light dumbbell in the raised hand to increase the stretch intensity.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with a smaller range of motion and support the lower back with the hand.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep the arm lower, at shoulder height, to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive lateral flexion to prevent spinal strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to protect the lower back.
Do not lock the knees; keep them slightly bent.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Keep the chest open and shoulders relaxed.
Distribute weight evenly on both feet.
commonMistakes: Leaning too far laterally, causing imbalance.
Locking the knees, which can lead to joint strain.
Allowing the torso to rotate instead of bending directly sideways.

name: Standing Leg Curl
instructions: Adjust the machine lever to fit your height and lie with your torso bent at the waist facing forward around 30-45 degrees (since an angled position is more favorable for hamstrings recruitment) with the pad of the lever on the back of your right leg (just a few inches under the calves) and the front of the right leg on top of the machine pad.
Keeping the torso bent forward, ensure your leg is fully stretched and grab the side handles of the machine. Position your toes straight. This will be your starting position.
As you exhale, curl your right leg up as far as possible without lifting the upper leg from the pad. Once you hit the fully contracted position, hold it for a second.
As you inhale, bring the legs back to the initial position. Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Perform the same exercise now for the left leg.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs or lower back pain may experience discomfort due to the forward bending position required. Modifications or alternative exercises should be considered.

knee_joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis, tendinitis, or recent knee surgery should avoid this exercise or perform it with caution, as it places stress on the knee joint.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: While generally safe, individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult with a healthcare provider before performing this exercise.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the later stages, should avoid exercises that require lying prone or excessive bending at the waist.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid performing this exercise if experiencing acute hamstring or calf strains, or any recent lower body trauma.

modifications.easier: Perform seated leg curls to reduce the need for torso stabilization and decrease lower back strain.
modifications.harder: Increase resistance or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a seated leg curl machine to maintain a neutral spine and reduce lower back stress.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion, or perform isometric holds at a comfortable angle.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height to avoid unnecessary strain.
Avoid hyperextending the knee at the starting position.
Maintain a controlled motion to prevent jerking movements that could strain the hamstrings.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Focus on squeezing the hamstrings at the top of the movement.
Avoid lifting the hips off the pad during the curl.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the knee to hyperextend at the starting position.
Lifting the hips or torso off the pad, which reduces effectiveness and increases injury risk.

name: Standing Long Jump
instructions: This drill is best done in sand or other soft landing surface. Ensure that you are able to measure distance. Stand in a partial squat stance with feet shoulder width apart.
Utilizing a big arm swing and a countermovement of the legs, jump forward as far as you can.
Attempt to land with your feet out in front you, reaching as far as possible with your legs.
Measure the distance from your landing point to the starting point and track results.

spinal injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the high impact and potential for exacerbating spinal issues.

joint issues.details: Those with arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis in the knees or ankles should avoid this exercise due to the stress placed on these joints during landing.

cardiovascular conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before attempting high-intensity exercises like the standing long jump.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid high-impact exercises to reduce the risk of falls and abdominal strain.

surgical recovery.details: Recent surgeries involving the lower extremities or spine require clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

chronic conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid high-impact activities that increase fracture risk. Those with diabetes should ensure stable blood glucose levels before engaging in high-intensity exercises.

acute injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

neurological conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls during this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform a standing broad jump onto a soft surface or mat to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the distance of the jump or perform with a weighted vest for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on a smaller jump with controlled landing to minimize spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform a step-forward jump, reducing the jump distance and focusing on soft landings.

safetyNotes: Ensure the landing surface is soft and free of obstacles.
Warm up thoroughly to prepare the muscles and joints for explosive movements.
Wear supportive footwear to absorb impact and provide stability.
formCues: Start with feet shoulder-width apart and knees slightly bent.
Swing arms back and then forward to generate momentum.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the body during the jump.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
commonMistakes: Failing to use arm swing effectively, reducing jump distance.
Landing with stiff legs, increasing joint stress.
Not engaging the core, leading to poor balance and control.

name: Standing Low-Pulley Deltoid Raise
instructions: Start by standing to the right side of a low pulley row. Use your left hand to come across the body and grab a single handle attached to the low pulley with a pronated grip (palms facing down). Rest your arm in front of you. Your right hand should grab the machine for better support and balance.
Make sure that your back is erect and your feet are shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.
Begin to use the left hand and come across your body out until it is elevated to shoulder height while exhaling.
Feel the contraction at the top for a second and begin to slowly lower the handle back down to the original starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and lateral movement may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the tendons or bursa in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The exercise can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Joint stress from the movement may increase pain and inflammation in those with advanced arthritis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The need for stability and posture maintenance can strain the cervical spine, especially in those with existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The isometric contraction and potential for breath-holding can elevate blood pressure, posing a risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slight pause at the top of the movement for added time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder pain, perform the exercise with a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent shoulder strain.
Maintain a neutral spine to protect the lower back.
Do not lock the elbows at the top of the movement to avoid joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability.
Lift the handle in a controlled manner, avoiding any jerking motions.
Ensure your shoulder remains down and away from your ears to prevent neck strain.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulder to elevate towards the ear, causing neck strain.
Arching the back excessively, leading to potential lower back discomfort.

name: Standing Low-Pulley One-Arm Triceps Extension
instructions: Grab a single handle with your left arm next to the low pulley machine. Turn away from the machine keeping the handle to the side of your body with your arm fully extended. Now use both hands to elevate the single handle directly above the head with the palm facing forward. Keep your upper arm completely vertical (perpendicular to the floor) and put your right hand on your left elbow to help keep it steady. This is the starting position.

Keeping your upper arms close to your head (elbows in) and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the single handle. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Repetitive extension under load can aggravate tendinitis, especially in the lateral epicondyle.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The standing position requires core stabilization, which may be challenging for those with acute pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Looking up or maintaining head position can strain the neck, particularly in those with cervical spine problems.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or elbow surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to stress, and this exercise places significant load on these joints.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a higher weight or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full extension, reducing stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached to prevent sudden release.
Avoid hyperextending the elbow at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability.
Ensure your upper arm remains perpendicular to the floor throughout the movement.
Use a controlled motion, avoiding any jerking or swinging.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to flare out, reducing triceps activation.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Neglecting to stabilize the shoulder, leading to excessive movement.

name: Standing Military Press
instructions: Start by placing a barbell that is about chest high on a squat rack. Once you have selected the weights, grab the barbell using a pronated (palms facing forward) grip. Make sure to grip the bar wider than shoulder width apart from each other.
Slightly bend the knees and place the barbell on your collar bone. Lift the barbell up keeping it lying on your chest. Take a step back and position your feet shoulder width apart from each other.

Once you pick up the barbell with the correct grip length, lift the bar up over your head by locking your arms. Hold at about shoulder level and slightly in front of your head. This is your starting position.
Lower the bar down to the collarbone slowly as you inhale.
Lift the bar back up to the starting position as you exhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead pressing motion.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Overhead movements can strain the rotator cuff, delaying recovery.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The overhead position can increase cervical spine compression and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping and pressing can aggravate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to axial loading on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead lifting can increase blood pressure; caution is advised.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural range of motion.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise seated to eliminate leg assistance and increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a seated dumbbell shoulder press with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a back-supported bench to maintain proper spinal alignment.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is properly secured on the squat rack before starting.
Avoid excessive arching of the lower back during the press.
Do not lock the elbows forcefully at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Press the barbell in a straight line over your head.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees for balance.
Keep the elbows slightly in front of the barbell to protect the shoulder joint.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively.
Arching the lower back excessively during the press.
Not maintaining a stable foot position.

name: Standing Olympic Plate Hand Squeeze
instructions: To begin, stand straight while holding a weight plate by the ridge at arm's length in each hand using a neutral grip (palms facing in). You feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. This will be your starting position.
Lower the plates until the fingers are nearly extended but can still hold weights. Inhale as you lower the plates.
Now raise the plates back to the starting position as you exhale by closing your hands.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions prescribed in your program.

carpalTunnelSyndrome.explanation: The gripping action can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the median nerve.

arthritis.explanation: Individuals with arthritis, especially in the hands or wrists, may experience increased pain and inflammation.

recentHandOrWristSurgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding stress on the healing tissues.

neuropathy.explanation: Reduced sensation or motor control can increase the risk of dropping the weight.

acuteShoulderInjuries.explanation: Holding weights at arm's length can strain injured shoulder tissues.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weight plates or perform the exercise seated to reduce load and improve stability.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the plates or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to increase the challenge.

injury_friendly.hand pain: Use a padded grip or towel around the plate to reduce pressure on the hands.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with elbows slightly bent to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a firm grip on the plates to prevent dropping them.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid excessive strain.
Avoid using excessively heavy weights that compromise form.
formCues: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart.
Keep your core engaged to stabilize your body.
Lower the plates slowly and with control.
Exhale as you squeeze and lift the plates back to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using too heavy weights leading to poor form.
Allowing the wrists to bend excessively.
Neglecting to engage the core, resulting in poor posture.

name: Standing One-Arm Cable Curl
instructions: Start out by grabbing single handle next to the low pulley machine. Make sure you are far enough from the machine so that your arm is supporting the weight.

Make sure that your upper arm is stationary, perpendicular to the floor with elbows in and palms facing forward. Your non lifting arm should be grabbing your waist. This will allow you to keep your balance.
Slowly begin to curl the single handle upwards while keeping the upper arm stationary until your forearm touches your bicep while exhaling. Tip: Only the forearm should move.
Hold the contraction position as you squeeze the bicep and then lower the single handle back down to the starting position as you inhale.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms while performing this exercise.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Maintaining a stationary upper arm position may increase stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the handle can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: Isometric contractions and holding breath during exertion can elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Stabilizing the shoulder during the curl can strain an injured rotator cuff.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a neutral grip (hammer curl) to reduce stress on the elbow joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid using momentum to lift the weight.
Ensure the cable is securely attached before starting.
Do not hyperextend the elbow at the bottom of the movement.
formCues: Keep your upper arm stationary and perpendicular to the floor.
Focus on squeezing the bicep at the top of the curl.
Control the weight during both the lifting and lowering phases.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbow to drift forward or backward.
Rushing through the movement without control.

name: Standing One-Arm Dumbbell Curl Over Incline Bench
instructions: Stand on the back side of an incline bench as if you were going to be a spotter for someone. Have a dumbbell in one hand and rest it across the incline bench with a supinated (palms up) grip.

Position your non lifting hand at the corner or side of the incline bench. The chest should be pressed against the top part of the incline and your feet should be pressed against the floor at a wide stance. This is the starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the dumbbell upward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbell is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms while performing this exercise.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the shoulder during the exercise can increase the risk of impingement, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required by the shoulder can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased due to the load on the upper extremities and potential for falls.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated with the arm supported on a preacher bench to reduce stabilization demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline angle of the bench to increase the range of motion and challenge the biceps further.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce strain on the elbow.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with the arm supported on a preacher bench to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weight, focus on controlled movements.
Keep the wrist in a neutral position to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep the chest pressed against the bench to stabilize the torso.
Maintain a slight bend in the knees for balance.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Swinging the dumbbell to gain momentum.
Allowing the elbow to move away from the bench.
Hyperextending the wrist during the curl.

name: Standing One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
instructions: To begin, stand up with a dumbbell held in one hand. Your feet should be about shoulder width apart from each other. Now fully extend the arm with the dumbbell over your head. Tip: The small finger of your hand should be facing the ceiling and the palm of your hand should be facing forward. The dumbbell should be above your head.
This will be your starting position.

Keeping your upper arm close to your head (elbows in) and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearm touch your bicep. Tip: The upper arm should remain stationary and only the forearm should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the dumbbell. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the elbow joint, potentially aggravating tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Overhead movements can strain the rotator cuff, especially if the shoulder is not stable.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Any recent surgical intervention in the shoulder, elbow, or wrist may be compromised by this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The overhead position can strain the neck, particularly if there is pre-existing cervical spine pathology.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce stabilization demands.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise standing on one leg to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a resistance band instead of a dumbbell to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full extension and flexion.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the shoulder and elbow joints.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
Ensure a firm grip on the dumbbell to prevent it from slipping.
formCues: Keep the upper arm close to the head and stationary.
Engage the core to maintain balance and stability.
Lower the dumbbell in a controlled manner to avoid momentum.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbow to flare out, reducing triceps engagement.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Arching the back excessively, leading to potential back strain.

name: Standing Overhead Barbell Triceps Extension
instructions: To begin, stand up holding a barbell or e-z bar using a pronated grip (palms facing forward) with your hands closer than shoulder width apart from each other. Your feet should be about shoulder width apart.
Now elevate the barbell above your head until your arms are fully extended. Keep your elbows in. This will be your starting position.

Keeping your upper arms close to your head and elbows in, perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the barbell. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position can exacerbate shoulder impingement by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The extension movement places stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Holding the barbell in a pronated grip can strain the wrist, especially if there is pre-existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The overhead position may increase blood pressure, posing a risk for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Supporting a load overhead can strain the neck, particularly if there are pre-existing cervical spine conditions.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or switch to dumbbells for better control and reduced load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on one leg to engage more stabilizer muscles.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use resistance bands instead of a barbell to decrease joint stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use an EZ bar to allow for a more natural grip position.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight is manageable to maintain control throughout the movement.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Keep the core engaged to support the lower back and maintain balance.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the head and pointed forward.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid arching the back.
Lower the barbell slowly and with control.
commonMistakes: Flaring the elbows outwards, which can increase shoulder strain.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively, risking injury.

name: Standing Palm-In One-Arm Dumbbell Press
instructions: Start by having a dumbbell in one hand with your arm fully extended to the side using a neutral grip. Use your other arm to hold on to an incline bench to keep your balance.

Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. Now slowly lift the dumbbell up until you create a 90 degree angle with your arm. Note: Your forearm should be perpendicular to the floor. Continue to maintain a neutral grip throughout the entire exercise.
Slowly lift the dumbbell up until your arm is fully extended. This the starting position.
While inhaling lower the weight down until your arm is at a 90 degree angle again.

Feel the contraction for a second and then lift the weight back up towards the starting position while exhaling. Remember to hold on to the incline bench and keep your feet positioned to keep balance during the exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch arms and repeat the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pressing motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: This exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding a weight overhead can strain the neck, especially if there is pre-existing cervical spine pathology.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture increases with weight-bearing exercises, particularly if balance is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead exercises can elevate blood pressure; individuals with uncontrolled hypertension should avoid or modify.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The unilateral nature of the exercise requires good balance, posing a fall risk for those with balance impairments.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands and use a lighter weight.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise standing on one leg to increase core and balance challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid pain, stopping before any discomfort.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure the core is engaged and perform the exercise seated with back support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the dumbbell is not too heavy to maintain control throughout the movement.
Avoid locking the elbow at the top of the press to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your spine.
Press the dumbbell directly overhead, not forward or backward.
Maintain a neutral grip throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the back to arch excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Failing to keep the elbow aligned under the wrist during the press.

name: Standing Palms-In Dumbbell Press
instructions: Start by having a dumbbell in each hand with your arm fully extended to the side using a neutral grip. Your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. Now slowly lift the dumbbells up until you create a 90 degree angle with your arms. Note: Your forearms should be perpendicular to the floor. This the starting position.
Continue to maintain a neutral grip throughout the entire exercise. Slowly lift the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended.
While inhaling lower the weights down until your arm is at a 90 degree angle again.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
