contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk of exacerbating symptoms due to overhead motion. Avoid or significantly modify the exercise.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Overhead pressing can aggravate tendinitis. Consider modifications to reduce shoulder stress.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Overhead loading can increase cervical spine strain. Modify to reduce neck involvement.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to loading and overhead position. Avoid or perform under professional supervision.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Overhead pressing can increase blood pressure. Monitor closely and consider alternatives.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to increase stability and reduce core engagement.
modifications.harder: Use a single-arm press to increase core stabilization demands.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a landmine press to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform seated with back support to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Warm up thoroughly before performing overhead exercises.
Avoid locking out elbows at the top to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
formCues: Engage core to stabilize the spine.
Keep elbows slightly in front of the body to protect the shoulder joint.
Press the dumbbells directly overhead, not forward or backward.
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back excessively.
Allowing elbows to flare out too wide.
Using momentum to lift the weights.

name: Standing Palms-Up Barbell Behind The Back Wrist Curl
instructions: Start by standing straight and holding a barbell behind your glutes at arm's length while using a pronated grip (palms will be facing back away from the glutes) and having your hands shoulder width apart from each other.
You should be looking straight forward while your feet are shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.
While exhaling, slowly elevate the barbell up by curling your wrist in a semi-circular motion towards the ceiling. Note: Your wrist should be the only body part moving for this exercise.
Hold the contraction for a second and lower the barbell back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
When finished, lower the barbell down to the squat rack or the floor by bending the knees. Tip: It is easiest to either pick it up from a squat rack or have a partner hand it to you.

contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: High severity. The repetitive motion and load on the wrist can exacerbate inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate severity. The position and movement may increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis in the wrist: Moderate severity. The exercise may cause discomfort or pain due to joint stress.
contraindicationDetails.recent wrist fracture: High severity. The exercise should be avoided until fully healed and cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High severity. Risk of fracture due to bone fragility.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load on the wrists.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist curls with a resistance band to reduce load and allow for a more controlled range of motion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely gripped to prevent dropping.
Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the wrists.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid unnecessary stress on the back.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body and stationary.
Focus on moving only the wrists in a controlled manner.
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart for stability.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the barbell instead of isolating the wrist movement.
Allowing the elbows to move away from the body.
Using too much weight, leading to improper form.

name: Standing Pelvic Tilt
instructions: Start off with your feet hip-distance apart.
Bend your knees slightly to keep them soft and springy.
You may want to move your pelvis forward and backward and back few times before holding the tailbone forward in this stretch.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The forward and backward movement of the pelvis can exacerbate disc issues by increasing pressure on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The exercise may compress the spinal canal further, leading to increased symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - Pelvic tilting can increase shear forces on the spine, worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The movement might irritate the sciatic nerve; modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - Care should be taken to avoid excessive spinal flexion which can increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - Hormonal changes can affect joint stability; modifications for comfort and safety are advised.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise lying on your back with knees bent to reduce spinal load.
modifications.harder: Add a resistance band around the thighs to increase muscle activation.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated on a stability ball to reduce spinal load and allow for more controlled movement.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure knees are only slightly bent and avoid deep flexion to minimize stress on the knee joint.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive arching or rounding of the lower back.
Perform movements slowly and with control to prevent injury.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Keep your shoulders relaxed and away from the ears.
Focus on tilting the pelvis without moving the upper body.
commonMistakes: Overarching the lower back, leading to potential strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Locking the knees, which can increase stress on the joints.

name: Standing Rope Crunch
instructions: Attach a rope to a high pulley and select an appropriate weight.
Stand with your back to the cable tower. Take the rope with both hands over your shoulders, holding it to your upper chest. This will be your starting position.
Perform the movement by flexing the spine, crunching the weight down as far as you can.
Hold the peak contraction for a moment before returning to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the flexion and load on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis or tendinitis in the shoulders or lower back should proceed with caution and may need modifications.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises involving spinal flexion and abdominal pressure.

osteoporosis.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of vertebral fractures from spinal flexion.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing acute back pain, recent trauma, or muscle strains until fully recovered.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise kneeling on a mat to reduce the load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance and core stability.
modifications.injury_friendly: For back pain, perform standing cable rotations to engage the core without spinal flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight is appropriate to avoid excessive strain on the spine.
Maintain a neutral spine at the start and end of the movement.
Avoid jerking motions to prevent injury.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Keep your elbows close to your head throughout the exercise.
Focus on a controlled movement, emphasizing the contraction of the abdominals.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the rope to pull the head forward excessively.
Arching the back at the top of the movement.

name: Standing Soleus And Achilles Stretch
instructions: Stand with your feet hip-distance apart, one foot slightly in front of the other.
Bend both knees, keeping your back heel on the floor. Switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.Achilles tendinitis: Stretching the Achilles tendon can exacerbate inflammation and pain in individuals with tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.recent ankle sprain: Placing weight on a recently sprained ankle can delay healing and increase the risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Standing on one leg or shifting weight may pose a fall risk for individuals with impaired balance.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Weight-bearing activities can increase joint pain and discomfort in individuals with severe osteoarthritis.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while seated, extending one leg and gently pulling the toes back with a towel.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by leaning forward slightly or placing the front foot on an elevated surface.
modifications.injury_friendly: For knee pain, reduce the bend in the knees and focus on a gentle stretch. For back pain, perform against a wall for support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the back heel remains on the ground to prevent excessive strain on the Achilles tendon.
Avoid bouncing during the stretch to prevent muscle strain.
formCues: Keep both knees bent and aligned over the toes.
Maintain an upright posture with a neutral spine.
Distribute weight evenly between both feet.
commonMistakes: Lifting the back heel off the ground.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward.
Overarching the lower back.

name: Standing Toe Touches
instructions: Stand with some space in front and behind you.
Bend at the waist, keeping your legs straight, until you can relax and let your upper body hang down in front of you. Let your arms and hands hang down naturally. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Bending forward can exacerbate disc protrusion, increasing pain and risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Forward bending may aggravate sciatic nerve irritation, leading to increased pain and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Forward flexion can increase the risk of vertebral fractures due to decreased bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Bending forward may worsen pain and delay recovery in acute lower back conditions.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Standing toe touches require balance, which can be challenging and unsafe for those with balance impairments.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: During later stages, forward bending can be uncomfortable and may increase intra-abdominal pressure.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while seated on a chair, reaching towards your toes.
modifications.harder: Perform the stretch with one leg elevated on a low platform to increase the stretch intensity.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch lying on your back and bringing one knee towards your chest to stretch the hamstrings gently.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Perform the stretch while seated to reduce pressure on the knees.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Do not force the stretch beyond a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Keep your knees slightly bent if you feel tension in the lower back.
Engage your core to support your lower back during the stretch.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
commonMistakes: Locking the knees, which can increase strain on the lower back.
Rounding the back excessively, leading to potential spinal stress.
Holding the breath, which can increase tension and reduce stretch effectiveness.

name: Standing Towel Triceps Extension
instructions: To begin, stand up with both arms fully extended above the head holding one end of a towel with both hands. Your elbows should be in and the arms perpendicular to the floor with the palms facing each other while your feet should be shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.

Now communicate with your partner so that he/she can grip the other side of the towel to apply resistance. Keeping your upper arms close to your head (elbows in) and perpendicular to the floor, lower the resistance in a semicircular motion behind your head until your forearms touch your biceps. Tip: The upper arms should remain stationary and only the forearms should move. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Go back to the starting position by using the triceps to raise the towel. Breathe out as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position may exacerbate symptoms by compressing the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise involves elbow extension, which can aggravate tendinitis due to repetitive strain.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Stabilizing the shoulder joint in an overhead position can stress the rotator cuff muscles.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Holding the arms overhead may increase strain on the cervical spine, potentially worsening conditions like herniated discs or stenosis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated with a shorter range of motion, or use a resistance band instead of a towel for less resistance.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier towel or resistance band, or perform the exercise on one leg to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with elbows slightly forward to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full extension and flexion, reducing strain on the elbow.

safetyNotes: Ensure the towel is securely held to prevent slipping.
Communicate clearly with your partner to manage resistance safely.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the head throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine with core engaged.
Move only the forearms, keeping upper arms stationary.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out, reducing triceps engagement.
Arching the back excessively, leading to potential lower back strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Standing Two-Arm Overhead Throw
instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder width apart holding a medicine ball in both hands. To begin, reach the medicine ball deep behind your head as you bend the knees slightly and lean back.
Violently throw the ball forward, flexing at the hip and using your whole body to complete the movement.
The medicine ball can be thrown to a partner or to a wall, receiving it as it bounces back.

spinal_injuries.explanation: The dynamic nature of the throw and the spinal flexion involved can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: Overhead movements can aggravate impingement symptoms due to the compression of shoulder structures.

rotator_cuff_tendinitis.explanation: The explosive overhead motion can strain the rotator cuff tendons, worsening tendinitis.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The exertion required can elevate heart rate and blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: The balance and core engagement required, along with the risk of abdominal strain, make this exercise unsuitable during pregnancy.

balance_disorders.explanation: The dynamic movement and need for stability can be challenging for individuals with balance issues.

modifications.easier: Perform the throw with a lighter medicine ball or perform a seated overhead throw to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a balance pad.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the throw seated or against a wall to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of knee flexion or perform the exercise seated.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a lighter ball and reduce the range of motion, avoiding full overhead extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or collisions.
Use a medicine ball with a weight appropriate for your strength level to avoid strain.
Maintain control of the ball throughout the movement to prevent injury.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine during the throw.
Keep your elbows slightly bent to reduce stress on the shoulder joints.
Follow through with your arms and body to ensure a smooth motion.
commonMistakes: Using too heavy a medicine ball, leading to compromised form.
Failing to engage the core, resulting in excessive spinal flexion.
Not following through with the arms, which can lead to abrupt stopping and increased joint stress.

name: Star Jump
instructions: Begin in a relaxed stance with your feet shoulder width apart and hold your arms close to the body.
To initiate the move, squat down halfway and explode back up as high as possible. Fully extend your entire body, spreading your legs and arms away from the body.
As you land, bring your limbs back in and absorb your impact through the legs.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, spondylolisthesis, or sciatica should avoid high-impact activities like star jumps due to the risk of exacerbating spinal issues.

joint_issues.details: Those with arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis in the knees or ankles should modify the exercise to reduce impact and joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: People with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid high-intensity exercises that can spike heart rate and blood pressure.

pregnancy_and_postpartum.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid high-impact exercises due to balance and joint stability concerns.

surgical_recovery.details: Individuals recovering from surgeries, particularly in the lower extremities or spine, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Those with osteoporosis should avoid high-impact activities to prevent fractures. Diabetics should monitor blood sugar levels as high-intensity exercises can affect glucose levels.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing any acute sprains, strains, or recent trauma to the lower body.

neurological_conditions.details: Individuals with balance disorders or neuropathy should modify the exercise to reduce fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform a half-star jump by reducing the jump height and limiting the arm and leg spread.
modifications.harder: Add a tuck jump at the peak of the star jump for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a low-impact version by stepping side to side with arm raises instead of jumping.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Reduce the depth of the squat and jump height, or perform a seated arm and leg extension.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the arm movement to shoulder height or perform the exercise without arm movements.

safetyNotes: Ensure a soft landing by bending the knees to absorb impact.
Perform on a shock-absorbent surface to reduce joint stress.
Warm up thoroughly before performing high-impact exercises.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement to maintain balance.
Land softly on the balls of your feet and roll back to the heels.
Keep the chest up and avoid leaning forward excessively.
commonMistakes: Landing stiff-legged, which increases joint stress.
Allowing knees to collapse inward during landing.
Failing to fully extend arms and legs during the jump.

name: Step-up with Knee Raise
instructions: Stand facing a box or bench of an appropriate height with your feet together. This will be your starting position.

Begin the movement by stepping up, putting your left foot on the top of the bench. Extend through the hip and knee of your front leg to stand up on the box. As you stand on the box with your left leg, flex your right knee and hip, bringing your knee as high as you can.
Reverse this motion to step down off the box, and then repeat the sequence on the opposite leg.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis may experience increased pressure on the spine during the step-up motion, especially if balance is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: Knee arthritis or tendinitis may be aggravated by the repeated flexion and extension of the joint. Ankle instability or hip bursitis may also be exacerbated.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: Those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid sudden changes in elevation that may affect blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: During later stages of pregnancy, balance may be compromised, increasing fall risk. The exercise should be modified or avoided as needed.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Recent sprains or strains, especially in the lower body, may be aggravated by this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.neurological_conditions: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls during this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the step-up without the knee raise, focusing on controlled movements and using a lower step height.
modifications.harder: Add weights by holding dumbbells in each hand or increase the step height to challenge balance and strength further.

injury_friendly.knee_pain: Use a lower step height and avoid the knee raise, focusing on slow, controlled movements.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Engage the core throughout the movement and avoid excessive forward lean. Consider performing the exercise near a wall for support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the step or box is stable and can support your weight.
Perform the exercise on a non-slip surface to prevent falls.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to protect the lower back.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core to maintain balance.
Drive through the heel of the stepping foot to activate the glutes.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knee to cave inward during the step-up.
Using momentum instead of muscle control to lift the body.
Failing to engage the core, leading to excessive trunk movement.

name: Step Mill
instructions: To begin, step onto the stepmill and select the desired option from the menu. You can choose a manual setting, or you can select a program to run. Typically, you can enter your age and weight to estimate the amount of calories burned during exercise. Use caution so that you don't trip as you climb the stairs. It is recommended that you maintain your grip on the handles so that you don't fall.

Stepmills offer convenience, cardiovascular benefits, and usually have less impact than running outside while offering a similar rate of calories burned. They are typically much harder than other cardio equipment. A 150 lb person will typically burn over 300 calories in 30 minutes, compared to about 175 calories walking.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The repetitive stepping motion can exacerbate knee joint pain and inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: The continuous hip flexion and extension may irritate the bursa.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: The high cardiovascular demand may be unsafe for individuals with uncontrolled heart conditions.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: The exercise places stress on the lower limbs, which may hinder recovery.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The moving stairs require good balance and coordination, posing a fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The upright posture and repetitive motion can increase lumbar spine compression.

modifications.easier: Use a lower speed setting to reduce intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the speed or add intervals of higher intensity.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce speed and avoid deep stepping to minimize knee joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a neutral spine and avoid leaning forward excessively.

safetyNotes: Always hold onto the handles to prevent falls.
Ensure the machine is properly calibrated and functioning before use.
Start with a warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to support your spine.
Maintain an upright posture without leaning excessively forward.
Step with a controlled motion, avoiding stomping.
commonMistakes: Leaning too far forward, which can strain the back.
Using the handles to support body weight, reducing workout effectiveness.
Stepping too quickly, increasing the risk of tripping.

name: Stiff-Legged Barbell Deadlift
instructions: Grasp a bar using an overhand grip (palms facing down). You may need some wrist wraps if using a significant amount of weight.
Stand with your torso straight and your legs spaced using a shoulder width or narrower stance. The knees should be slightly bent. This is your starting position.

Keeping the knees stationary, lower the barbell to over the top of your feet by bending at the hips while keeping your back straight. Keep moving forward as if you were going to pick something from the floor until you feel a stretch on the hamstrings. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Start bringing your torso up straight again by extending your hips until you are back at the starting position. Exhale as you perform this movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and shear forces.

joint_issues.explanation: Those with knee or hip arthritis should modify the range of motion to avoid joint stress. Tendinitis or bursitis in the lower body may require alternative exercises.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing heavy compound lifts.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve significant intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent surgeries involving the spine, hips, or knees require clearance from a healthcare provider before engaging in this exercise.

chronic_conditions.explanation: Osteoporosis patients should avoid heavy lifting due to fracture risk. Diabetes-related neuropathy may affect balance and proprioception.

acute_injuries.explanation: Avoid this exercise if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower back or lower extremities.

neurological_conditions.explanation: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form, requiring modifications or alternative exercises.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use dumbbells for better control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on a deficit platform to increase the range of motion.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform Romanian deadlifts with a reduced range of motion and lighter weights.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion and focus on hip hinge.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid locking the knees to reduce stress on the joint.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without compromising form.
formCues: Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
Keep the barbell close to the body during the descent and ascent.
Initiate the movement by hinging at the hips, not bending at the waist.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which increases the risk of spinal injury.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.
Allowing the knees to lock or hyperextend.

name: Stiff-Legged Dumbbell Deadlift
instructions: Grasp a couple of dumbbells holding them by your side at arm's length.
Stand with your torso straight and your legs spaced using a shoulder width or narrower stance. The knees should be slightly bent. This is your starting position.

Keeping the knees stationary, lower the dumbbells to over the top of your feet by bending at the waist while keeping your back straight. Keep moving forward as if you were going to pick something from the floor until you feel a stretch on the hamstrings. Exhale as you perform this movement
Start bringing your torso up straight again by extending your hips and waist until you are back at the starting position. Inhale as you perform this movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and shear forces.

joint_issues.explanation: Those with knee or hip arthritis should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress by limiting range of motion or using lighter weights.

pregnancy.explanation: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid this exercise due to balance and core stability challenges.

osteoporosis.explanation: The forward bending motion increases the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.explanation: Avoid if there are any acute strains or sprains in the lower back, hamstrings, or knees.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion or use lighter dumbbells.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on a single leg to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a slight bend in the knees and reduce the range of motion to minimize lower back strain.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the bend and ensure knees are slightly bent to reduce stress.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Do not lock the knees; keep them slightly bent to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Keep your shoulders back and chest up as you lower the weights.
Hinge at the hips, not the lower back.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Locking the knees completely.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.

name: Stiff Leg Barbell Good Morning
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your legs stationary, move your torso forward by bending at the hips while inhaling. Lower your torso until it is parallel with the floor.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by elevating your torso back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The forward bending motion and spinal loading can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The exercise can increase spinal compression and exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - Forward bending and spinal loading can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high - The exercise may aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - Spinal loading increases fracture risk; modifications needed.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: high - Avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - Risk of falling; modifications or alternative exercises recommended.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or a PVC pipe to practice form without significant load.
modifications.harder: Add resistance bands around the shoulders and under the feet to increase tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a resistance band or bodyweight only to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure minimal knee flexion and focus on hip hinge to avoid knee strain.

safetyNotes: Always warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise.
Use a squat rack with safety pins set at an appropriate height to catch the bar if needed.
Avoid rounding the back during the movement to prevent spinal injury.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine by keeping your chest up and shoulders back.
Hinge at the hips, not the waist, to lower your torso.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the descent.
Bending the knees excessively, turning it into a squat.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Stomach Vacuum
instructions: To begin, stand straight with your feet shoulder width apart from each other. Place your hands on your hips. This is the starting position.

Now slowly inhale as much air as possible and then start to exhale as much as possible while bringing your stomach in as much as possible and hold this position. Try to visualize your navel touching your backbone.
One isometric contraction is around 20 seconds. During the 20 second hold, try to breathe normally. Then inhale and bring your stomach back to the starting position.
Once you have practiced this exercise, try to perform this exercise for longer than 20 seconds. Tip: You can work your way up to 40-60 seconds.
Repeat for the recommended amount of sets.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High intra-abdominal pressure can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: May increase spinal compression and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Can increase lumbar instability and pain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Holding breath can elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Abdominal compression may be unsafe, especially in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: Strain on healing tissues can impede recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise lying on your back with knees bent to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise in a seated position with legs extended for increased difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform lying down with a pillow under the knees to support the lumbar spine.

safetyNotes: Avoid holding your breath to prevent spikes in blood pressure.
Stop immediately if you experience pain or discomfort in the lower back or abdomen.
formCues: Keep shoulders relaxed and away from the ears.
Focus on drawing the navel towards the spine without rounding the back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Holding breath excessively, leading to increased blood pressure.
Allowing the shoulders to rise, causing tension in the neck.
Arching the back instead of maintaining a neutral spine.

name: Straight-Arm Dumbbell Pullover
instructions: Place a dumbbell standing up on a flat bench.

Ensuring that the dumbbell stays securely placed at the top of the bench, lie perpendicular to the bench (torso across it as in forming a cross) with only your shoulders lying on the surface. Hips should be below the bench and legs bent with feet firmly on the floor. The head will be off the bench as well.

Grasp the dumbbell with both hands and hold it straight over your chest at arms length. Both palms should be pressing against the underside one of the sides of the dumbbell. This will be your starting position.
Caution: Always ensure that the dumbbell used for this exercise is secure. Using a dumbbell with loose plates can result in the dumbbell falling apart and falling on your face.
While keeping your arms straight, lower the weight slowly in an arc behind your head while breathing in until you feel a stretch on the chest.
At that point, bring the dumbbell back to the starting position using the arc through which the weight was lowered and exhale as you perform this movement.
Hold the weight on the initial position for a second and repeat the motion for the prescribed number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead motion can exacerbate symptoms of impingement by compressing the structures within the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can aggravate existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The position of the head off the bench can strain the cervical spine, especially in individuals with pre-existing conditions.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased due to the position and load on the spine and shoulders.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The position and load can increase intradiscal pressure, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can place additional stress on the lumbar spine, potentially exacerbating symptoms.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a stability ball to reduce the range of motion and support the back.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise with a slight pause at the stretched position.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid discomfort and focus on a lighter weight.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a bench with full back support to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the dumbbell is securely fastened to prevent it from falling apart.
Maintain control of the dumbbell throughout the movement to avoid excessive strain on the shoulders and spine.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to protect the shoulder joints.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on the stretch and contraction of the chest muscles.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to bend excessively, turning the exercise into a triceps extension.
Using momentum to swing the dumbbell, which reduces effectiveness and increases injury risk.
Arching the lower back excessively, which can strain the lumbar spine.

name: Straight-Arm Pulldown
instructions: You will start by grabbing the wide bar from the top pulley of a pulldown machine and using a wider than shoulder-width pronated (palms down) grip. Step backwards two feet or so.

Bend your torso forward at the waist by around 30-degrees with your arms fully extended in front of you and a slight bend at the elbows. If your arms are not fully extended then you need to step a bit more backwards until they are. Once your arms are fully extended and your torso is slightly bent at the waist, tighten the lats and then you are ready to begin.
While keeping the arms straight, pull the bar down by contracting the lats until your hands are next to the side of the thighs. Breathe out as you perform this step.
While keeping the arms straight, go back to the starting position while breathing in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and shoulder movement can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves shoulder stabilization, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: Forward bending and load on the spine may worsen disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric contraction and breath holding can increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or back surgery: The exercise places stress on healing tissues, potentially disrupting recovery.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band anchored at a high point to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase stabilization demands.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip to reduce shoulder joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable attachment is secure before starting.
Avoid excessive forward bending to protect the lower back.
Maintain a controlled movement to prevent jerking.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize your torso.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows throughout the movement.
Focus on contracting the lats to initiate the pull.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull the bar down.
Allowing the shoulders to roll forward.
Hyperextending the elbows at the bottom of the movement.

name: Straight Bar Bench Mid Rows
instructions: Place a loaded barbell on the end of a bench. Standing on the bench behind the bar, take a medium, pronated grip. Stand with your hips back and chest up, maintaining a neutral spine. This will be your starting position.
Row the bar to your torso by retracting the shoulder blades and flexing the elbows. Use a controlled movement with no jerking.
After a brief pause, slowly return the bar to the starting position, ensuring to go all the way down.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity due to the potential for increased intradiscal pressure and spinal flexion under load.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity as the exercise may exacerbate nerve compression due to spinal positioning.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity because of the risk of aggravating vertebral slippage with forward bending.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity as the exercise may increase nerve irritation due to lumbar flexion.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity; requires careful shoulder positioning to avoid exacerbation.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate severity; may require modification to reduce shoulder strain.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Low severity; ensure proper breathing to avoid Valsalva maneuver.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity; avoid heavy loads and ensure proper form to prevent fractures.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a tempo (slow eccentric phase).

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated cable rows with a neutral spine to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a wider grip to decrease shoulder internal rotation and impingement risk.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid jerking movements to prevent injury.
Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Pull the bar towards your torso using your back muscles, not your arms.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Lifting the bar too high, causing shoulder strain.

name: Straight Raises on Incline Bench
instructions: Place a bar on the ground behind the head of an incline bench.
Lay on the bench face down. With a pronated grip, pick the barbell up from the floor, keeping your arms straight. Allow the bar to hang straight down. This will be your starting position.
To begin, raise the barbell out in front of your head while keeping your arms extended.
Return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms overhead can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the narrowing of the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Lying face down can place pressure on the cervical spine, potentially aggravating conditions like herniated discs.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping the barbell and raising it can strain the elbow tendons, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The prone position and load on the spine can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding overhead movements until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or dumbbells to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a barbell to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper bench support and engage core muscles to maintain spinal alignment.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and at an appropriate incline to avoid excessive neck strain.
Start with a light weight to master the form before progressing to heavier loads.
Avoid jerky movements; keep the motion controlled and smooth.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a neutral neck position by looking slightly forward.
Raise the barbell in a controlled manner, avoiding swinging or using momentum.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the neck to hyperextend, causing strain.
Bending the elbows, which shifts the focus away from the shoulders.

name: Stride Jump Crossover
instructions: Stand to the side of a box with your inside foot on top of it, close to the edge.
Begin by swinging the arms upward as you push through the top leg, jumping upward as high as possible. Attempt to drive the opposite knee upward.
Land in the opposite position that you started, on the opposite side of the box. The foot that was initially on the box will now be on the ground, with the opposite foot now on the box.
Repeat the movement, crossing back over to the other side.

knee osteoarthritis.reason: The impact and dynamic nature of the exercise can exacerbate joint pain and inflammation.

acute lower back pain.reason: Jumping and landing forces can increase spinal load and worsen symptoms.

balance disorders.reason: The exercise requires dynamic balance and coordination, posing a fall risk.

recent lower limb surgery.reason: Healing tissues may not withstand the impact and stress of the exercise.

ankle instability.reason: Jumping and landing can increase the risk of ankle sprains.

cardiovascular conditions.reason: The exercise is high-intensity and may not be suitable for individuals with uncontrolled heart conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform step-ups onto the box without jumping to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the height of the box or add a weighted vest for additional resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a lower box and focus on controlled step-ups.
injury_friendly.back pain: Avoid jumping and focus on slow, controlled movements to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the box is stable and on a non-slip surface.
Wear supportive footwear to reduce impact on joints.
Perform a thorough warm-up focusing on dynamic leg and core exercises.
formCues: Engage your core to maintain balance and stability.
Land softly with knees slightly bent to absorb impact.
Drive through the heel of the foot on the box for better power generation.
commonMistakes: Landing with locked knees, increasing joint stress.
Not using arms to aid in momentum and balance.
Allowing the knee to cave inward during landing, risking injury.

name: Sumo Deadlift
instructions: Begin with a bar loaded on the ground. Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip. Relax the shoulders, which in effect lengthens your arms.

Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.
As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.
Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the compressive and shear forces on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Knee arthritis or hip impingement may require modifications to reduce joint stress. Ensure proper form to minimize joint loading.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing heavy compound lifts due to increased cardiovascular demand.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid heavy lifting and exercises that strain the pelvic floor.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, hips, or knees, require full medical clearance before attempting this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis may increase fracture risk; modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower back, hips, or knees.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase fall risk; consider using a lighter weight or alternative exercises.

modifications.easier: Perform the sumo deadlift with a lighter weight or use a kettlebell instead of a barbell to reduce load and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright torso.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit range of motion by performing a partial deadlift from blocks to reduce knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the muscles and joints.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the lift to prevent injury.
Do not hyperextend the back at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep the chest up and shoulders relaxed.
Drive through the heels and spread the floor apart with your feet.
Engage the core to stabilize the spine.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Sumo Deadlift with Bands
instructions: To deadlift with short bands, simply loop them over the bar before you start, and step into them to set up. Ensure that they under the back half of your foot, directly where you are driving into the floor.

Begin with a bar loaded on the ground. Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip.

Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.
As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.
Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis, or shoulder impingement should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity compound lifts.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar to reduce spinal loading and maintain a more upright posture.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on partial deadlifts to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a neutral grip with a trap bar to minimize shoulder strain.

Maintain a neutral spine throughout the lift to avoid spinal injury.
Do not hyperextend the knees or lock them out forcefully.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core before lifting.
Drive through your heels and keep the weight balanced over the midfoot.
Squeeze your glutes at the top of the lift.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Allowing the knees to cave inward.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Not engaging the core, leading to instability.

name: Sumo Deadlift with Chains
instructions: You can attach the chains to the sleeves of the bar, or just drape the middle over the bar so there is a greater weight increase as you lift. Attempt to keep the ends of the chains away from the plates so you don't hit them when you lower the weight.

Begin with a bar loaded on the ground. Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip. Relax the shoulders, which in effect lengthens your arms.

Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.
As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.
Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial load and potential for spinal compression.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or hip impingement should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress, such as using lighter weights or partial range of motion.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing heavy lifting exercises.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the later trimesters, should avoid heavy lifting due to changes in balance and increased risk of injury.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from recent surgeries, particularly in the lower back, hips, or knees, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should use caution due to the risk of fractures from heavy lifting.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back.

neurological_conditions.details: Those with balance disorders or neuropathy should use caution and consider modifications to ensure stability.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a trap bar to reduce strain on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Increase the chain weight or perform the exercise with a deficit by standing on a platform.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar or perform Romanian deadlifts to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion or perform the exercise from blocks to reduce knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure chains are securely attached to avoid shifting during the lift.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent back injury.
Avoid jerking the weight off the ground; initiate the lift smoothly.
formCues: Set feet wide, near the collars.
Grip the bar with arms inside the legs.
Keep chest up and shoulders relaxed.
Drive through the heels and extend hips and knees simultaneously.
Engage core and pull shoulder blades together at the top.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward.
Starting the lift with the hips too high.
Not engaging the core, leading to instability.

name: Superman
instructions: To begin, lie straight and face down on the floor or exercise mat. Your arms should be fully extended in front of you. This is the starting position.

Simultaneously raise your arms, legs, and chest off of the floor and hold this contraction for 2 seconds. Tip: Squeeze your lower back to get the best results from this exercise. Remember to exhale during this movement. Note: When holding the contracted position, you should look like superman when he is flying.
Slowly begin to lower your arms, legs and chest back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions prescribed in your program.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The extension of the spine during the Superman exercise can exacerbate symptoms of a herniated disc by increasing intradiscal pressure.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: This condition involves the forward displacement of a vertebra, and the extension movement can increase stress on the affected area, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Individuals with osteoporosis are at increased risk of vertebral fractures, and the spinal extension involved in this exercise can pose a risk.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires stabilization and protection of the spine, and this exercise may introduce undue stress.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: During pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, lying prone and performing spinal extensions can be uncomfortable and potentially harmful.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise by lifting only the arms or only the legs, not both simultaneously, to reduce the load on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Hold the top position for a longer duration, such as 5 seconds, or add ankle and wrist weights to increase resistance.
modifications.injury_friendly: For those with mild back pain, perform the exercise on an exercise ball to reduce the range of motion and support the spine.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking motions; movements should be slow and controlled.
Do not hyperextend the spine; lift only to the point of comfort.
Ensure the neck remains neutral to avoid strain.
formCues: Engage the core and glutes before lifting.
Keep the head aligned with the spine; do not look up excessively.
Focus on lifting with the back muscles, not the arms or legs.
commonMistakes: Overarching the lower back, leading to potential strain.
Lifting the head too high, causing neck discomfort.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle engagement.

name: Supine Chest Throw
instructions: This drill is great for chest passes when you lack a partner or a wall of sufficient strength. Lay on the ground on your back with your knees bent.
Begin with the ball on your chest, held with both hands on the bottom.
Explode up, extending through the elbow to throw the ball directly above you as high as possible.
Catch the ball with both hands as it comes down.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The explosive nature of the throw can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to excessive shoulder movement.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The rapid extension and catching motion can strain the rotator cuff, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.acute elbow injuries: The extension force required can aggravate elbow injuries such as tendinitis or ligament strains.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of fracture from catching the ball may be increased in individuals with decreased bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Any recent surgical intervention in the shoulder, elbow, or wrist may be compromised by the explosive and catching movements.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter medicine ball or a stability ball to reduce impact.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball to engage more stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a chest press with resistance bands to minimize overhead stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a bench to support the back and reduce strain on the lumbar region.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent injury from a dropped ball.
Use a medicine ball with a non-slip surface to maintain grip.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Exhale as you throw the ball and inhale as you catch it.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid strain.
commonMistakes: Allowing the lower back to arch excessively during the throw.
Catching the ball with stiff arms, increasing joint stress.
Using too heavy a ball, leading to compromised form.

name: Supine One-Arm Overhead Throw
instructions: Lay on the ground on your back with your knees bent. Hold the ball with one hand, extending the arm fully behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement at the shoulder, throwing the ball directly forward of you as you sit up, attempting to go for maximum distance.
The ball can be thrown to a partner or bounced off of a wall.

spinal injuries.details: The dynamic movement and spinal flexion involved can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or sciatica.

shoulder impingement.details: The overhead position and throwing motion may aggravate shoulder impingement.

rotator cuff tendinitis.details: Throwing motion can strain the rotator cuff, worsening tendinitis.

wrist injuries.details: The forceful throw can stress the wrist, particularly if there is a history of injury.

pregnancy.details: Supine position and dynamic movements are generally not recommended, especially in later stages.

osteoporosis.details: Risk of fracture due to dynamic movement and potential impact.

acute injuries.details: Any recent trauma or inflammation should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the throw with both hands to reduce load on a single shoulder and arm.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the medicine ball or perform the exercise on an unstable surface like a BOSU ball.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion and avoid full spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lighter ball and focus on controlled movements without full overhead extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent injury from a misdirected throw.
Use a ball weight appropriate for your strength level to avoid strain.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement to protect your spine.
Keep your throwing arm slightly bent to reduce stress on the elbow joint.
Exhale as you throw the ball to maximize power and control.
commonMistakes: Using too heavy a ball, leading to compromised form.
Not engaging the core, which can lead to lower back strain.
Allowing the head to lift off the ground too early, which can cause neck strain.

name: Supine Two-Arm Overhead Throw
instructions: Lay on the ground on your back with your knees bent.
Hold the ball with both hands, extending the arms fully behind your head. This will be your starting position.
Initiate the movement at the shoulder, throwing the ball directly forward of you as you sit up, attempting to go for maximum distance.
The ball can be thrown to a partner or bounced off of a wall.

spinal injuries.details: The explosive nature of the throw and the sit-up motion can exacerbate spinal issues such as herniated discs or spondylolisthesis.

shoulder impingement.details: The overhead position and throwing motion can aggravate shoulder impingement.

rotator cuff tendinitis.details: The exercise involves dynamic shoulder movement that can strain the rotator cuff.

wrist injuries.details: Catching or throwing the ball can place stress on the wrists, aggravating existing injuries.

pregnancy.details: The supine position and explosive movements are not recommended during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters.

osteoporosis.details: The explosive nature of the exercise may increase the risk of fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the throw, simply raising the ball overhead and performing a controlled sit-up.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier medicine ball or increase the throwing distance by incorporating a partner who stands further away.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion and avoid the explosive throw.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full overhead extension and use a lighter ball.

safetyNotes: Ensure the area is clear of obstacles to prevent tripping or falling.
Use a medicine ball that is appropriate for your strength level to avoid strain.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement to protect your lower back.
Keep your arms straight and aligned with your ears during the overhead position.
Exhale as you throw the ball and sit up.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of core strength to sit up.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively during the throw.
Failing to follow through with the arms, leading to incomplete throws.

name: Suspended Fallout
instructions: Adjust the straps so the handles are at an appropriate height, below waist level.
Begin standing and grasping the handles. Lean into the straps, moving to an incline push-up position. This will be your starting position.
Keeping your arms straight, lean further into the suspension straps, bringing your body closer to the ground, allowing your shoulders to extend, raising your arms up and over your head.
Maintain a neutral spine and keep the rest of your body straight, your shoulders being the only joints allowed to move.
Pause during the peak contraction, and then return to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the risk of exacerbating spinal compression and shear forces.

shoulder_joint_issues.details: Those with shoulder impingement, tendinitis, or rotator cuff injuries should modify or avoid this exercise to prevent aggravation of the shoulder joint.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult with a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise due to the potential for increased blood pressure and heart rate.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify this exercise to avoid excessive strain on the abdominal wall.

surgical_recovery.details: Those recovering from recent abdominal or shoulder surgery should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion or with the straps at a higher angle to decrease the load on the core and shoulders.
modifications.harder: Increase the angle of the body to the floor or add a weight vest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a smaller range of motion and ensure a strong core engagement to minimize lumbar stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid overhead extension and focus on maintaining scapular stability.

formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Keep the arms straight and avoid bending the elbows.
Maintain a straight line from head to heels throughout the exercise.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag, which can increase lumbar strain.
Bending the elbows, reducing the effectiveness of the core engagement.
Overextending the shoulders, which can lead to shoulder strain.

name: Suspended Push-Up
instructions: Anchor your suspension straps securely to the top of a rack or other object.

Leaning into the straps, take a handle in each hand and move into a push-up plank position. You should be as close to parallel to the ground as you can manage with your arms fully extended, maintaining good posture.
Maintaining a straight, rigid torso, descend slowly by allowing the elbows to flex.
Continue until your elbows break 90 degrees, pausing before you extend to return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The suspended push-up can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the overhead and horizontal abduction positions.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: This exercise places significant load on the shoulder joint, potentially aggravating rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The wrist position in a suspended push-up can increase strain on the tendons, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Pressure on the wrist during this exercise can aggravate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.spinal instability: Maintaining a rigid torso is crucial, and those with spinal instability may struggle to do so safely.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical shoulders may not be able to handle the load and range of motion required.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (third trimester): Balance and core stability challenges increase, making this exercise potentially unsafe.

modifications.easier: Perform the push-up with the straps set higher, reducing the angle of inclination.
modifications.harder: Perform the push-up with feet elevated on a bench or stability ball to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit range of motion to avoid deep elbow flexion and use a wider grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps or perform the exercise with fists to minimize wrist extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure the suspension straps are securely anchored before starting.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid excessive elbow flare to protect the shoulders.
formCues: Engage the core to keep the body in a straight line.
Lower the body slowly and with control.
Keep elbows at a 45-degree angle to the body.
commonMistakes: Allowing hips to sag or rise, compromising spinal alignment.
Flaring elbows excessively, increasing shoulder strain.
Rushing the movement, leading to poor control.

name: Suspended Reverse Crunch
instructions: Secure a set of suspension straps with the handles hanging about a foot off of the ground. Move yourself into a pushup plank position facing away from the rack.
Place your feet into the handles. You should maintain a straight posture, not allowing the hips to sag. This will be your starting position.
Begin the movement by flexing the knees and hips, drawing the knees to your torso. As you do so, anteriorly tilt your pelvis, allowing your spine to flex.
At the top of the controlled motion, return to the starting position.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the flexion and load on the lumbar spine.

hip_joint_issues.details: Those with hip impingement or arthritis may experience discomfort due to the hip flexion required.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before attempting due to the isometric hold and potential for increased blood pressure.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals should avoid this exercise, especially in the second and third trimesters, due to the risk of abdominal strain and balance issues.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent abdominal or spinal surgeries require avoidance of this exercise until fully cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid excessive spinal flexion, and those with diabetes should monitor for hypoglycemia due to exertion.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if there are recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower back or hips.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with feet on the ground, drawing knees towards the chest while lying on a mat.
modifications.harder: Add a slow tempo or pause at the top of the movement to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise on a stability ball to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Ensure the suspension straps are securely fastened and can support your body weight.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to prevent excessive lumbar flexion.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Keep the shoulders directly over the wrists.
Avoid letting the hips sag; maintain a straight line from head to heels.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to drop, causing lower back strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Not engaging the core fully, leading to poor form.

name: Suspended Row
instructions: Suspend your straps at around chest height. Take a handle in each hand and lean back. Keep your body erect and your head and chest up. Your arms should be fully extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by flexing the elbow to initiate the movement. Protract your shoulder blades as you do so.
At the completion of the motion pause, and then return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead and pulling motions can exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise involves significant shoulder movement, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The leaning back position may increase spinal load and exacerbate disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can increase lumbar spine stress, potentially worsening the condition.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Grip and wrist positioning can exacerbate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures due to bone fragility may be increased with this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a higher anchor point to reduce the angle of lean, decreasing resistance.
modifications.harder: Lower the anchor point to increase the angle of lean, increasing resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a more upright position to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive shoulder extension.

safetyNotes: Ensure straps are securely anchored to prevent slipping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid jerky movements to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a straight line from head to heels.
Initiate the movement by retracting the shoulder blades.
Keep elbows close to the body during the pull.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to sag, leading to loss of core engagement.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Overextending the shoulders at the end of the pull.

name: Suspended Split Squat
instructions: Suspend your straps so the handles are 18-30 inches from the floor.
Facing away from the setup, place your rear foot into the handle behind you. Keep your head looking forward and your chest up, with your knee slightly bent. This will be your starting position.
Descend by flexing the knee and hips, lowering yourself to the ground. Keep your weight on the heel of your foot and maintain your posture throughout the exercise.
At the bottom of the movement, reverse the motion, extending through the hip and knee to return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High stress on the knee joint during the descent and ascent can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.patellar tendinitis: The exercise places significant load on the quadriceps tendon, potentially aggravating tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The need for core stabilization can increase lumbar spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The suspended position requires good balance, which can be challenging for those with balance issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: The exercise can place undue stress on healing tissues and should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Perform a standard split squat without suspension to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Add dumbbells or a weighted vest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the range of motion and ensure the knee does not travel past the toes.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on engaging the core and maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the suspension straps are securely anchored to prevent slipping.
Maintain control throughout the movement to avoid excessive strain on the knee and hip joints.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back to maintain an upright posture.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso and prevent excessive forward lean.
Focus on pressing through the heel of the front foot during the ascent.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to cave inward, which can increase stress on the knee joint.
Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Not maintaining tension in the core, leading to instability.

name: Svend Press
instructions: Begin in a standing position.

Press two lightweight plates together with your hands. Hold the plates together close to your chest to create an isometric contraction in your chest muscles. Your fingers should be pointed forward. This is your starting position.
Squeeze the plates between your palms and extend your arms directly out in front of you in a controlled motion.
Pause at the top of the motion, and then slowly return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The Svend Press involves shoulder flexion and internal rotation, which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise requires stabilization and movement of the shoulder joint, potentially aggravating rotator cuff issues.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The pressing motion can strain the elbow tendons, worsening tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Holding and pressing the plates may increase pressure on the wrist and exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid exercises that could lead to falls or excessive strain on the bones.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: During pregnancy, especially in later stages, balance and core stability are affected, and exercises requiring standing balance should be performed with caution.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce balance demands.
modifications.harder: Use heavier plates or increase the duration of the isometric hold at the end of the extension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a resistance band to reduce joint strain.
