injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with a towel to reduce grip strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure a firm grip on the plates to prevent them from slipping.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid locking the elbows at the end of the extension to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your shoulders down and back to avoid excessive elevation.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
Move in a slow, controlled manner to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to elevate excessively.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Rushing through the movement without control.

name: T-Bar Row with Handle
instructions: Position a bar into a landmine or in a corner to keep it from moving. Load an appropriate weight onto your end.
Stand over the bar, and position a Double D row handle around the bar next to the collar. Using your hips and legs, rise to a standing position.
Assume a wide stance with your hips back and your chest up. Your arms should be extended. This will be your starting position.
Pull the weight to your upper abdomen by retracting the shoulder blades and flexing the elbows. Do not jerk the weight or cheat during the movement.
After a brief pause, return to the starting position.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. The forward bending and load on the spine can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity. The position may compress the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity. The exercise can increase shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Moderate severity. The exercise may aggravate symptoms due to lumbar flexion.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Moderate severity. The exercise can stress the shoulder joint if not performed with proper form.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. The loaded position can increase fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity. The exercise may strain healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise with a chest-supported row machine to reduce spinal load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a single-arm row to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a chest-supported row machine to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip and ensure proper scapular retraction to reduce shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bar is securely positioned in the landmine or corner to prevent movement.
Avoid jerking the weight to reduce the risk of injury.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Retract your shoulder blades as you pull the weight towards your abdomen.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back, which can increase the risk of spinal injury.
Using momentum to lift the weight instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively, which can strain the shoulders.

name: Tate Press
instructions: Lie down on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand on top of your thighs. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.

By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbells up, clean the dumbbells one arm at a time so that you can hold them in front of you at shoulder width. Note: when holding the dumbbells in front of you, make sure your arms are wider than shoulder width apart from each other using a pronated (palms forward) grip. Allow your elbows to point out. This is your starting position.

Keeping the upper arms stationary, slowly move the dumbbells in and down in a semi circular motion until they touch the upper chest while inhaling. Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times and do not move the upper arms nor rest the dumbbells on the chest.

As you breathe out, move the dumbbells up using your triceps and the same semi-circular motion but in reverse. Attempt to keep the dumbbells together as they move up. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down again slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The Tate Press involves shoulder movement that can exacerbate impingement symptoms due to the position of the elbows and the load on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the elbow joint, which can aggravate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The position and movement of the arms can strain the rotator cuff, especially if there is pre-existing injury.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbells can increase pressure on the wrist, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Any recent surgical intervention in the shoulder, elbow, or wrist area may be compromised by the load and movement of this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased with osteoporosis, especially with the potential for dropping weights or improper form.
contraindicationDetails.severe hypertension: Lying supine and lifting weights can increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with uncontrolled hypertension.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbells or perform the exercise on an incline bench to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on slow, controlled movements to minimize stress on the elbow.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Select an appropriate weight to maintain control throughout the movement.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain stability on the bench.
Focus on moving the dumbbells in a controlled, semi-circular motion.
Keep your elbows pointing out and maintain a wide grip.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the dumbbells to rest on the chest.
Failing to control the descent of the dumbbells.

name: The Straddle
instructions: Begin in a seated, upright position. Start by extending your legs in front of you in a V.
With your hands on the floor, lean forward as far as possible. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward bending motion can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the intervertebral discs.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Leaning forward can aggravate the sciatic nerve, causing increased pain or discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.recent hamstring strain: Stretching the hamstrings too soon after a strain can impede healing and increase the risk of re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: Forward bending can increase the risk of vertebral fractures due to decreased bone density.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: The forward flexion can increase stress on the lumbar spine, potentially worsening pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch while lying on your back with one leg against a wall to control the stretch intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the hold time to 30 seconds and reach further forward with your hands.
modifications.injury_friendly: For lower back pain, perform the stretch with a slight bend in the knees to reduce lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Do not force the stretch beyond a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Keep your back straight as you lean forward.
Engage your core to support the lower back.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively.
Holding the breath during the stretch.
Forcing the stretch beyond a comfortable point.

name: Thigh Abductor
instructions: To begin, sit down on the abductor machine and select a weight you are comfortable with. When your legs are positioned properly, grip the handles on each side. Your entire upper body (from the waist up) should be stationary. This is the starting position.
Slowly press against the machine with your legs to move them away from each other while exhaling.

Feel the contraction for a second and begin to move your legs back to the starting position while breathing in. Note: Remember to keep your upper body stationary to prevent any injuries from occurring.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Moderate to severe arthritis may cause pain during abduction due to joint stress.
contraindicationDetails.hip bursitis: The exercise may exacerbate inflammation in the bursa, leading to increased pain.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The seated position and hip movement can aggravate sciatic nerve pain.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: High severity; avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: In later stages, the seated position may be uncomfortable and increase pelvic pressure.

modifications.easier: Use a lower weight setting and perform partial range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise slowly with a pause at full abduction.

injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure lumbar support is adjusted properly to maintain a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.hip pain: Reduce range of motion and use minimal resistance.

safetyNotes: Ensure the machine is properly adjusted to your height.
Avoid jerking movements to prevent strain on the hip joint.
Do not lock the knees at full abduction to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your back flat against the seat.
Engage your core to stabilize your upper body.
Exhale as you press your legs apart and inhale as you return.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the upper body to sway or move.
Not controlling the movement on the return phase.

name: Thigh Adductor
instructions: To begin, sit down on the adductor machine and select a weight you are comfortable with. When your legs are positioned properly on the leg pads of the machine, grip the handles on each side. Your entire upper body (from the waist up) should be stationary. This is the starting position.
Slowly press against the machine with your legs to move them towards each other while exhaling.

Feel the contraction for a second and begin to move your legs back to the starting position while breathing in. Note: Remember to keep your upper body stationary and avoid fast jerking motions in order to prevent any injuries from occurring.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Moderate to severe arthritis can cause pain and discomfort during adduction movements.
contraindicationDetails.groin strain: Adductor exercises can exacerbate groin strains due to the direct involvement of the adductor muscles.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip surgery: High severity; avoid until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent complications.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High severity; risk of fracture due to bone fragility.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy (third trimester): Moderate severity; avoid due to potential discomfort and balance issues.

modifications.easier: Use a lower weight and increase the range of motion gradually as strength improves.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a back support or cushion to maintain lumbar support and reduce strain.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Ensure proper seat height to avoid excessive knee flexion.

safetyNotes: Always warm up before performing this exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
Avoid locking the knees at the end of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Do not use excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Keep your back firmly against the seat throughout the movement.
Exhale as you bring your legs together and inhale as you return to the starting position.
Move slowly and with control to maximize muscle engagement and minimize injury risk.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to bring the legs together instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the knees to collapse inward or outward excessively.
Leaning forward or backward, which can strain the lower back.

name: Tire Flip
instructions: Begin by gripping the bottom of the tire on the tread, and position your feet back a bit. Your chest should be driving into the tire.
To lift the tire, extend through the hips, knees, and ankles, driving into the tire and up.

As the tire reaches a 45 degree angle, step forward and drive a knee into the tire. As you do so adjust your grip to the upper portion of the tire and push it forward as hard as possible to complete the turn. Repeat as necessary.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The tire flip involves significant spinal loading and flexion, which can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The compression and extension of the spine during the lift can increase symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The forward bending and lifting can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: high - The exercise can aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: moderate - The knee extension and pressure during the lift can increase joint pain.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: moderate - The overhead pushing phase can irritate the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower back surgery: high - The exercise places significant stress on the recovering tissues.
contraindicationDetails.recent knee surgery: high - The pressure and extension required can disrupt healing.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: high - The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance and coordination.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: moderate - The high-impact nature can increase fracture risk, especially in the spine.

modifications.easier: Use a smaller or lighter tire to reduce the load and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the tire or perform the exercise for time rather than reps.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a deadlift with a barbell or kettlebell to reduce spinal flexion.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a sled push instead to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a landmine press to avoid overhead movements.

safetyNotes: Ensure the tire is stable and free from debris before starting.
Warm up thoroughly, focusing on dynamic stretches for the lower body and core.
Avoid jerking movements; maintain a controlled pace.
formCues: Keep your chest close to the tire to maintain leverage.
Drive through your legs, not your back, to lift the tire.
Engage your core throughout the movement to protect your spine.
Adjust your grip as the tire rises to maintain control.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift, increasing spinal stress.
Using arms instead of legs to initiate the lift.
Failing to adjust grip as the tire rises, leading to loss of control.
Not stepping forward as the tire reaches a 45-degree angle.

name: Toe Touchers
instructions: To begin, lie down on the floor or an exercise mat with your back pressed against the floor. Your arms should be lying across your sides with the palms facing down.

Your legs should be touching each other. Slowly elevate your legs up in the air until they are almost perpendicular to the floor with a slight bend at the knees. Your feet should be parallel to the floor.
Move your arms so that they are fully extended at a 45 degree angle from the floor. This is the starting position.
While keeping your lower back pressed against the floor, slowly lift your torso and use your hands to try and touch your toes. Remember to exhale while perform this part of the exercise.
Slowly begin to lower your torso and arms back down to the starting position while inhaling. Remember to keep your arms straight out pointing towards your toes.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity: The flexion of the spine during this exercise can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity: Spinal flexion may increase compression on the spinal canal.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity: The exercise can increase anterior shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity: The movement may aggravate sciatic nerve pain.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High severity: Spinal flexion increases the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity: Supine position may cause discomfort and reduced venous return.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity: The exercise may strain healing tissues.

modifications.easier: Perform a partial crunch by lifting only the shoulders off the ground, keeping the arms by the sides.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight in each hand to increase resistance.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform a standing toe touch with a slight bend in the knees to reduce spinal flexion.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine to avoid excessive lumbar flexion.
Avoid jerking motions to prevent strain on the lower back.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement.
Exhale as you reach towards your toes.
Keep the chin slightly tucked to avoid neck strain.
commonMistakes: Lifting the lower back off the floor.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Holding breath during the exercise.

name: Torso Rotation
instructions: Stand upright holding an exercise ball with both hands. Extend your arms so the ball is straight out in front of you. This will be your starting position.
Rotate your torso to one side, keeping your eyes on the ball as you move. Now, rotate back to the opposite direction. Repeat for 10-20 repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the rotational stress on the spine.

shoulder_instability.details: Those with shoulder impingement or instability should modify the exercise to reduce arm extension or avoid it if pain persists.

balance_disorders.details: Individuals with balance issues should perform this exercise with caution or under supervision to prevent falls.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve significant twisting to prevent abdominal strain.

osteoporosis.details: Due to the risk of vertebral fractures, individuals with osteoporosis should avoid exercises that involve spinal rotation.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated on a chair with feet flat on the ground, reducing the range of motion.
modifications.harder: Hold a medicine ball instead of an exercise ball to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the exercise with a reduced range of motion and avoid twisting beyond a comfortable range.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Keep elbows slightly bent to reduce stress on the shoulder joint.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
Avoid excessive twisting to prevent spinal strain.
Keep movements controlled and avoid jerking motions.
formCues: Engage your core before starting the rotation.
Keep your hips facing forward and rotate only through the torso.
Follow the ball with your eyes to ensure full rotation.
commonMistakes: Allowing the hips to rotate instead of isolating the movement to the torso.
Using momentum rather than controlled muscle engagement.
Overextending the arms, causing shoulder strain.

name: Trail Running/Walking
instructions: Running or hiking on trails will get the blood pumping and heart beating almost immediately. Make sure you have good shoes. While you use the muscles in your calves and buttocks to pull yourself up a hill, the knees, joints and ankles absorb the bulk of the pounding coming back down. Take smaller steps as you walk downhill, keep your knees bent to reduce the impact and slow down to avoid falling.
A 150 lb person can burn over 200 calories for 30 minutes walking uphill, compared to 175 on a flat surface. If running the trail, a 150 lb person can burn well over 500 calories in 30 minutes.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High-impact activities like trail running can exacerbate joint pain and degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.ankle instability: Uneven terrain increases the risk of sprains and further injury.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: High-impact and uneven surfaces can impede recovery and cause complications.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Uneven terrain poses a significant fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.advanced osteoporosis: High-impact activities increase the risk of fractures.
contraindicationDetails.severe cardiovascular conditions: Intense physical exertion can be dangerous without medical clearance.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower limb injuries: Running or walking on trails can worsen injuries due to uneven surfaces and high impact.

modifications.easier: Opt for walking on flat, even trails to reduce impact and difficulty.
modifications.harder: Increase speed or choose steeper, more challenging trails.

injury_friendly.knee pain: Use hiking poles to reduce load on the knees and choose less steep trails.
injury_friendly.back pain: Focus on maintaining a neutral spine and engage core muscles to support the lower back.
injury_friendly.ankle pain: Wear supportive footwear with good ankle support and stick to well-maintained trails.

safetyNotes: Wear appropriate footwear with good grip and support.
Stay hydrated and carry water, especially on longer trails.
Be aware of your surroundings and trail conditions to avoid tripping hazards.
Start with shorter distances and gradually increase intensity and duration.
formCues: Maintain an upright posture with a slight forward lean when running uphill.
Keep your core engaged to support your spine.
Take shorter, controlled steps when descending to reduce impact.
Use your arms for balance and propulsion.
commonMistakes: Overstriding, which can increase impact on joints.
Neglecting to warm up properly before starting.
Ignoring pain or discomfort, which can lead to injury.
Running too fast on technical or unfamiliar trails.

recommendedSets.beginner: Start with 20-30 minutes of trail walking or running.
recommendedSets.intermediate: Aim for 30-45 minutes, incorporating varied terrain.
recommendedSets.advanced: 60 minutes or more, including challenging trails and intervals.

recommendedReps.endurance: Continuous effort for the duration of the session.
recommendedReps.interval training: Alternate between high-intensity running and walking for recovery.

timeEstimate.advanced: 60 minutes or more including warm-up and cool-down.

name: Trap Bar Deadlift
instructions: For this exercise load a trap bar, also known as a hex bar, to an appropriate weight resting on the ground. Stand in the center of the apparatus and grasp both handles.
Lower your hips, look forward with your head and keep your chest up.
Begin the movement by driving through the heels and extend your hips and knees. Avoid rounding your back at all times.
At the completion of the movement, lower the weight back to the ground under control.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The axial loading and spinal flexion involved can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The compression forces can aggravate symptoms of spinal stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise can increase anterior shear forces on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - May worsen symptoms due to nerve compression; modifications needed.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: moderate - Can increase joint stress; modifications or alternative exercises recommended.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: high - Lifting can exacerbate pain and delay recovery.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: high - Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding heavy lifting.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - Requires stable balance; modifications or supervision recommended.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a higher starting position by placing the bar on blocks.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the lift.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine; consider using a belt for support.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion and focus on controlled movements; consider using knee sleeves for support.

safetyNotes: Always warm up thoroughly before performing deadlifts.
Ensure the trap bar is loaded evenly to prevent imbalance.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to avoid injury.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back.
Drive through your heels and engage your core.
Avoid rounding your back; maintain a neutral spine.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Allowing the knees to cave inward.
Lifting with the arms instead of driving through the legs.

name: Tricep Dumbbell Kickback
instructions: Start with a dumbbell in each hand and your palms facing your torso. Keep your back straight with a slight bend in the knees and bend forward at the waist. Your torso should be almost parallel to the floor. Make sure to keep your head up. Your upper arms should be close to your torso and parallel to the floor. Your forearms should be pointed towards the floor as you hold the weights. There should be a 90-degree angle formed between your forearm and upper arm. This is your starting position.
Now, while keeping your upper arms stationary, exhale and use your triceps to lift the weights until the arm is fully extended. Focus on moving the forearm.
After a brief pause at the top contraction, inhale and slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arm during the kickback can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the overhead and backward motion.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension of the elbow can aggravate tendinitis, especially if the weight is too heavy.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required may strain the rotator cuff, especially if not properly warmed up.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping the dumbbell can increase pressure in the carpal tunnel, exacerbating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.recent upper body surgery: Any recent surgery in the shoulder, elbow, or wrist area may be compromised by the load and motion.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Bending forward can increase pressure on the lumbar spine, potentially aggravating lower back pain.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of dumbbells to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Use a heavier dumbbell or perform the exercise with one arm at a time to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise lying on a bench to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on a slower, controlled movement.
injury_friendly.lower back pain: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with back support to reduce lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weights; focus on controlled movements.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your body and stationary.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Exhale as you extend your arms and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Swinging the arms instead of using controlled movements.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the body.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to strain.

name: Tricep Side Stretch
instructions: Bring right arm across your body and over your left shoulder, holding your elbow with your left hand, until you feel a stretch in your tricep. Then repeat for your other arm.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Individuals with shoulder impingement may experience discomfort or pain when the arm is brought across the body. This movement can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Stretching the arm across the body can place stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially aggravating existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Those with severe osteoarthritis in the shoulder joint may experience pain or limited range of motion, making this stretch uncomfortable.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with the arm at a lower angle, closer to the waist, to reduce the intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the stretch by gently pulling the elbow further across the body while maintaining proper form.
modifications.injury_friendly: For shoulder pain, perform the stretch lying on your back with a pillow supporting the arm to reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements during the stretch.
Do not force the arm beyond a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Keep shoulders relaxed and down away from the ears.
Ensure the torso remains upright and does not twist.
commonMistakes: Overstretching the arm beyond comfort, leading to potential strain.
Allowing the shoulder to elevate towards the ear.

name: Triceps Overhead Extension with Rope
instructions: Attach a rope to a low pulley. After selecting an appropriate weight, grasp the rope with both hands and face away from the cable.

Position your hands behind your head with your elbows point straight up. Your elbows should start out flexed, and you can stagger your stance and lean gently away from the machine to create greater stability. This will be your starting position.
To perform the movement, extend through the elbow while keeping the upper arm in position, raising your hands above your head.
Squeeze your triceps at the top of the movement, and slowly lower the weight back to the start position.

shoulder impingement.explanation: Overhead movements can exacerbate shoulder impingement by placing stress on the rotator cuff tendons.

elbow tendinitis.explanation: The exercise involves repetitive elbow extension, which can aggravate tendinitis.

acute lower back pain.explanation: The standing position with potential anterior pelvic tilt can increase lumbar spine stress.

cervical spine issues.explanation: The overhead position may cause strain on the cervical spine, especially if posture is compromised.

recent elbow surgery.explanation: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to stress, and overhead extensions can disrupt healing.

osteoporosis.explanation: The exercise requires stabilization that may pose a risk for individuals with compromised bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise on one arm at a time to increase challenge.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform a triceps pushdown instead to avoid overhead stress.
injury_friendly.elbow_pain: Use a lighter resistance and ensure a thorough warm-up.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached to prevent accidents.
Maintain a neutral spine to avoid lower back strain.
Avoid locking the elbows at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep elbows close to your head throughout the movement.
Engage your core to maintain stability.
Control the movement speed, especially when lowering the weight.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare outwards.
Using momentum to lift the weight.
Arching the lower back excessively.

name: Triceps Pushdown
instructions: Attach a straight or angled bar to a high pulley and grab with an overhand grip (palms facing down) at shoulder width.

Standing upright with the torso straight and a very small inclination forward, bring the upper arms close to your body and perpendicular to the floor. The forearms should be pointing up towards the pulley as they hold the bar. This is your starting position.

Using the triceps, bring the bar down until it touches the front of your thighs and the arms are fully extended perpendicular to the floor. The upper arms should always remain stationary next to your torso and only the forearms should move. Exhale as you perform this movement.
After a second hold at the contracted position, bring the bar slowly up to the starting point. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension of the elbow can exacerbate inflammation and pain in individuals with tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Maintaining a stationary upper arm position may cause discomfort or exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Standing posture and potential forward lean can increase lumbar spine stress.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid exercises that may lead to falls or sudden jerky movements.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding stress on the elbow joint to prevent complications.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band anchored at a high point to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase difficulty and engage stabilizers more.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a rope attachment to allow a more natural wrist and elbow position.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize shoulder involvement.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is properly set up and the weight is appropriate for your level.
Avoid locking the elbows at the bottom of the movement to prevent joint stress.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body and stationary throughout the exercise.
Engage the core to maintain a stable and upright posture.
Control the movement both on the way down and up to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing triceps engagement.
Using momentum or body sway to move the weight.
Not fully extending the arms, which limits the range of motion.

name: Triceps Pushdown - Rope Attachment
instructions: Attach a rope attachment to a high pulley and grab with a neutral grip (palms facing each other).

Standing upright with the torso straight and a very small inclination forward, bring the upper arms close to your body and perpendicular to the floor. The forearms should be pointing up towards the pulley as they hold the rope with the palms facing each other. This is your starting position.

Using the triceps, bring the rope down as you bring each side of the rope to the side of your thighs. At the end of the movement the arms are fully extended and perpendicular to the floor. The upper arms should always remain stationary next to your torso and only the forearms should move. Exhale as you perform this movement.
After holding for a second, at the contracted position, bring the rope slowly up to the starting point. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive extension movement can exacerbate inflammation and pain in the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The exercise requires stabilization of the shoulder, which can aggravate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Standing posture with forward inclination may increase strain on the lumbar spine.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Maintaining head and neck alignment can be challenging, potentially worsening cervical conditions.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow surgery: Post-surgical healing tissues may be stressed by the extension movement.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: High resistance can increase the risk of fractures, particularly in the spine and forearm.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or perform the exercise seated to reduce strain on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase the challenge and engage stabilizer muscles more intensely.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to minimize lumbar strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a shorter range of motion to avoid shoulder discomfort.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use an elastic band instead of a cable to reduce joint stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable is securely attached to avoid accidents.
Do not lock the elbows at the bottom of the movement to prevent joint strain.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body and stationary.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
Exhale while pushing down and inhale while returning to the start position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to push the weight down.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Leaning too far forward, causing back strain.

name: Triceps Pushdown - V-Bar Attachment
instructions: Attach a V-Bar to a high pulley and grab with an overhand grip (palms facing down) at shoulder width.

Standing upright with the torso straight and a very small inclination forward, bring the upper arms close to your body and perpendicular to the floor. The forearms should be pointing up towards the pulley as they hold the bar. The thumbs should be higher than the small finger. This is your starting position.

Using the triceps, bring the bar down until it touches the front of your thighs and the arms are fully extended perpendicular to the floor. The upper arms should always remain stationary next to your torso and only the forearms should move. Exhale as you perform this movement.
After a second hold at the contracted position, bring the V-Bar slowly up to the starting point. Breathe in as you perform this step.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive motion and load on the elbow joint can exacerbate tendinitis symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms and potential for improper form can lead to shoulder impingement.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Standing posture and potential for poor form can increase lumbar strain.
contraindicationDetails.recent elbow surgery: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding stress on the elbow joint.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The standing position and potential for sudden movements can increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to reduce lumbar strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a rope attachment to allow for more natural wrist and shoulder positioning.

safetyNotes: Ensure the cable machine is properly set up and secure.
Avoid locking the elbows at the bottom of the movement to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the body and stationary.
Engage core muscles to maintain stability.
Exhale during the downward phase and inhale as you return to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to push the weight down.
Allowing elbows to flare out.
Leaning too far forward or backward.

name: Triceps Stretch
instructions: Reach your hand behind your head, grasp your elbow and gently pull. Hold for 10 to 20 seconds, then switch sides.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position may exacerbate symptoms by compressing structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The stretch can place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoarthritis: Limited range of motion and joint pain may be aggravated by the stretch.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical protocols often restrict overhead movements to protect healing tissues.
contraindicationDetails.severe cervical spine issues: The position may strain the neck, especially if there is existing cervical spine pathology.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch lying down to reduce the effect of gravity and support the arm.
modifications.harder: Add a gentle side bend to increase the stretch on the triceps and latissimus dorsi.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a towel or strap to gently assist the stretch without forcing the elbow into a painful position.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Support the head with a pillow or perform the stretch seated with back support to minimize neck strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid forcing the stretch if you feel sharp pain or discomfort.
Keep the neck relaxed and avoid excessive tilting or twisting.
formCues: Keep the elbow pointing straight up towards the ceiling.
Engage the core to maintain a neutral spine.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
commonMistakes: Arching the back excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Pulling the elbow too hard, leading to shoulder discomfort.
Holding the breath, which can increase tension.

recommendedReps.flexibility: Hold each stretch for 10 to 20 seconds
recommendedReps.general: Hold each stretch for 15 to 30 seconds

name: Tuck Crunch
instructions: To begin, lie down on the floor or an exercise mat with your back pressed against the floor. Your arms should be lying across your sides with the palms facing down.

Your legs should be crossed by wrapping one ankle around the other. Slowly elevate your legs up in the air until your thighs are perpendicular to the floor with a slight bend at the knees. Note: Your knees and toes should be parallel to the floor as opposed to the thighs.
Move your arms from the floor and cross them so they are resting on your chest. This is the starting position.
While keeping your lower back pressed against the floor, slowly lift your torso. Remember to exhale while perform this part of the exercise.
Slowly begin to lower your torso back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity; spinal flexion can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: High severity; flexion may increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High severity; spinal flexion can worsen vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity; flexion may irritate the sciatic nerve.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity; risk of vertebral fracture with spinal flexion.
contraindicationDetails.recent abdominal surgery: High severity; stress on abdominal muscles can impede healing.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with feet on the ground and knees bent, lifting only the head and shoulders.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight or medicine ball on the chest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a rolled towel under the lower back for support.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Keep feet on the ground and focus on upper body movement only.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking motions to prevent strain on the lower back.
Maintain a neutral neck position to avoid cervical strain.
formCues: Engage the core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you lift your torso and inhale as you lower it.
Keep movements slow and controlled.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the torso instead of engaging the core.
Allowing the lower back to arch off the floor.
Tucking the chin excessively, leading to neck strain.

name: Two-Arm Dumbbell Preacher Curl
instructions: Grab a dumbbell with each arm and place the upper arms on top of the preacher bench or the incline bench. The dumbbell should be held at shoulder length. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbells until your upper arm is extended and the biceps is fully stretched.
As you exhale, use the biceps to curl the weights up until your biceps is fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder height.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High repetition or excessive weight can exacerbate inflammation and pain in the elbow tendons.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms on the preacher bench may cause discomfort or further impingement in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Gripping dumbbells can increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures increases with heavy weights and the stress placed on the bones during this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: Stabilizing the shoulder during the curl can strain the rotator cuff, especially if already injured.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase weight or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip (hammer curl position) to reduce strain on the elbow.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lower incline on the preacher bench to reduce shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the preacher bench is stable and adjusted to the correct height.
Avoid locking the elbows at the bottom of the movement to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep your back straight and core engaged throughout the exercise.
Control the movement, especially when lowering the weights.
Avoid swinging the weights; focus on isolating the biceps.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing bicep isolation.
Bouncing the weights at the bottom of the movement.

name: Two-Arm Kettlebell Clean
instructions: Place two kettlebells between your feet. To get in the starting position, push your butt back and look straight ahead.
Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you raise the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so.
Lower the kettlebells back to the starting position and repeat.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead movement and rotation of the shoulders can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The dynamic lifting and rotation can increase inflammation and pain in the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The load on the shoulders and neck during the lift can aggravate cervical disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The exertion and potential for holding breath can spike blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not tolerate the dynamic load and range of motion required.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: The hip hinge and load can stress the lumbar spine, worsening pain.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The hip and leg extension may irritate the sciatic nerve.

modifications.easier: Perform a single-arm kettlebell clean to reduce the load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform a kettlebell clean and press.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use lighter kettlebells and focus on controlled movements, avoiding full shoulder rotation.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the shoulders and lower back.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement without compromising form.
Avoid locking the knees during the lift to reduce joint stress.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels and extend your hips explosively.
Rotate your wrists smoothly as the kettlebells reach shoulder height.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding your back.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Failing to rotate the wrists properly, causing strain on the wrists and elbows.
Not engaging the core, leading to instability.

name: Two-Arm Kettlebell Jerk
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you swing the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so, so that the palms face forward. Squat down a few inches and reverse the motion rapidly driving both kettlebells overhead. Immediately after the initial push, squat down again and get under the kettlebells. Once the kettlebells are locked out, stand upright to complete the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead motion can exacerbate impingement by compressing the tendons in the shoulder.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The dynamic and overhead nature of the exercise can increase inflammation and pain in the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The load on the shoulders and neck can increase pressure on cervical discs, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: The rapid and explosive movements can cause spikes in blood pressure, posing a risk for those with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which may not be suitable during recovery.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: The squatting motion can put stress on the knee joints, aggravating symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The dynamic nature of the exercise requires good balance and coordination, which may be compromised in these conditions.

modifications.easier: Perform a single-arm kettlebell press to reduce the load and complexity.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise on an unstable surface to challenge balance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform a push press instead, which reduces the overhead component.
injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on strict form to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the depth of the squat or perform the exercise seated to reduce knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up to prepare the shoulders and lower body for dynamic movement.
Use a weight that allows for controlled movement and proper form.
Avoid locking out the elbows forcefully to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels during the squat phase to maximize power.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to avoid unnecessary strain.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat phase.
Failing to engage the core, leading to excessive lumbar extension.

name: Two-Arm Kettlebell Military Press
instructions: Clean two kettlebells to your shoulders. Clean the kettlebells to your shoulders by extending through the legs and hips as you swing the kettlebells towards your shoulders. Rotate your wrists as you do so, so that the palms face forward.

Press the kettlebells up and out. As the kettlebells pass your head, lean into the weights so that the kettlebells are racked behind your head. Make sure to contract your lats, butt, and stomach for added stability.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High risk due to overhead pressing motion which can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: Moderate risk as the exercise involves significant shoulder stabilization and movement.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: High risk due to potential neck strain from holding weights overhead.
contraindicationDetails.uncontrolled hypertension: High risk as overhead pressing can increase blood pressure significantly.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: High risk as the shoulder joint is heavily involved and may not be ready for this load.
contraindicationDetails.lower back pain: Moderate risk due to the need for core stabilization; improper form can exacerbate pain.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: High risk as spinal alignment and core stability are crucial, and overhead pressing can increase lumbar stress.

modifications.easier: Perform a single-arm kettlebell press to reduce load and focus on one side at a time.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise standing on one leg to challenge balance and core stability.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a lighter weight and perform a seated dumbbell press to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated with back support to minimize lumbar stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure proper warm-up, focusing on shoulder and thoracic mobility.
Avoid locking elbows at the top of the press to reduce joint stress.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
formCues: Engage your core and glutes for stability.
Keep your wrists straight and aligned with your forearms.
Press the kettlebells up in a controlled manner, avoiding excessive arching of the lower back.
commonMistakes: Overarching the lower back during the press.
Allowing the elbows to flare out excessively.
Using momentum rather than controlled muscle engagement.

name: Two-Arm Kettlebell Row
instructions: Place two kettlebells in front of your feet. Bend your knees slightly and then push your butt out as much as possible as you bend over to get in the starting position.
Grab both kettlebells and pull them to your stomach, retracting your shoulder blades and flexing the elbows. Keep your back straight. Lower and repeat.

herniated disc.explanation: Bending over and lifting weights can exacerbate disc herniation, increasing the risk of nerve compression.

sciatica.explanation: The forward bending position may aggravate sciatic nerve pain due to increased pressure on the lumbar spine.

shoulder impingement.explanation: The rowing motion may compress the shoulder structures, worsening impingement symptoms.

rotator cuff tendinitis.explanation: Repetitive pulling can strain the rotator cuff, increasing inflammation and pain.

pregnancy.explanation: The forward bending position and weight lifting can be uncomfortable and risky, especially in the later stages.

lumbar stenosis.explanation: Flexion of the lumbar spine can exacerbate symptoms by narrowing the spinal canal further.

osteoporosis.explanation: The bending and lifting motion increases the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with low bone density.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with one kettlebell at a time, using a bench for support to reduce load and improve stability.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the kettlebells or perform the exercise with a pause at the top of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise seated on a bench with back support to minimize spinal loading.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a resistance band instead of kettlebells to reduce joint stress and allow for a more controlled motion.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Keep your elbows close to your body as you row.
Retract your shoulder blades fully at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the lift.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the shoulders to protract excessively at the bottom of the movement.

name: Underhand Cable Pulldowns
instructions: Sit down on a pull-down machine with a wide bar attached to the top pulley. Adjust the knee pad of the machine to fit your height. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the resistance attached to the bar.
Grab the pull-down bar with the palms facing your torso (a supinated grip). Make sure that the hands are placed closer than the shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

As you breathe out, pull the bar down until it touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the fully contracted position and keep the elbows close to your body. The upper torso should remain stationary as your bring the bar to you and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, while breathing in, slowly bring the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead position and movement can exacerbate symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may increase inflammation and pain due to repetitive shoulder movements.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The exercise can increase spinal load and exacerbate symptoms, especially with improper form.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during resistance exercises, can elevate blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or back surgery: The exercise can stress healing tissues and should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce load and control movement.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a single arm to increase difficulty and engage core stabilizers.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip (palms facing each other) to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a supported back or use a seated row machine to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the knee pads are properly adjusted to prevent lifting off the seat.
Avoid using excessive weight to maintain control and proper form.
Do not jerk the bar down; use a smooth, controlled motion.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back throughout the movement.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Focus on pulling with your back muscles, not your arms.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull the bar down.
Allowing the shoulders to roll forward.
Leaning too far back or arching the lower back excessively.

name: Upper Back-Leg Grab
instructions: While seated, bend forward to hug your thighs from underneath with both arms.
Keep your knees together and your legs extended out as you bring your chest down to your knees. You can also stretch your middle back by pulling your back away from your knees as your hugging them.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High severity. Forward bending can exacerbate disc protrusion and increase nerve compression.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: High severity. Stretching in this position may aggravate sciatic nerve irritation.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: High severity. Forward flexion can increase pain and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Moderate severity. Forward bending increases the risk of vertebral fractures.
contraindicationDetails.recent hamstring strain: High severity. Stretching can worsen the injury and delay healing.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Moderate severity. Forward bending may cause discomfort and affect balance, especially in later stages.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with bent knees to reduce tension on the hamstrings.
modifications.harder: Extend the arms further forward to increase the stretch intensity.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch lying on your back with one leg extended and the other bent, using a strap to gently pull the extended leg towards you.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Sit on a chair and extend one leg at a time, reaching towards the toes to reduce pressure on the knees.

safetyNotes: Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Stop immediately if you feel sharp pain or discomfort.
Ensure a gradual and controlled movement into the stretch.
formCues: Keep your back straight as you begin the stretch.
Engage your core to support the lower back.
Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back excessively, which can increase spinal stress.
Locking the knees, which can strain the joints.
Pulling too hard, leading to overstretching.

name: Upper Back Stretch
instructions: Clasp fingers together with your thumbs pointing down, round your shoulders as you reach your hands forward.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Individuals with herniated discs or spinal stenosis should avoid excessive rounding of the back, which may exacerbate symptoms.

shoulder_impingement.explanation: Rounding the shoulders may increase impingement symptoms; modifications or alternative stretches may be necessary.

osteoporosis.explanation: Rounding the spine can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

recent_abdominal_surgery.explanation: Stretching may place undue stress on healing tissues; consult with a healthcare provider before performing.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch seated with support for the lower back to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Incorporate a slight twist at the waist to engage the obliques and deepen the stretch.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform the stretch against a wall to maintain a neutral spine and reduce strain.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Keep the arms lower and avoid excessive rounding to minimize shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive rounding of the spine, especially if you have a history of back issues.
Perform the stretch slowly and avoid any sudden movements.
formCues: Engage your core to support the spine.
Keep your neck in a neutral position, avoiding excessive forward head posture.
Focus on feeling a stretch between the shoulder blades.
commonMistakes: Over-rounding the back, leading to potential strain.
Allowing the head to drop forward excessively, causing neck strain.
Holding the breath during the stretch.

name: Upright Barbell Row
instructions: Grasp a barbell with an overhand grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The bar should be resting on the top of your thighs with your arms extended and a slight bend in your elbows. Your back should also be straight. This will be your starting position.

Now exhale and use the sides of your shoulders to lift the bar, raising your elbows up and to the side. Keep the bar close to your body as you raise it. Continue to lift the bar until it nearly touches your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion, and should always be higher than your forearms. Remember to keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the bar back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
contraindications: wrist pain or carpal tunnel syndrome

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The upright row can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the position of the arms and the elevation of the elbows, which can compress the structures in the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: This exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The upright row can place stress on the neck, potentially aggravating cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and lifting motion can exacerbate tendinitis in the elbow due to repetitive strain.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain or carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip position and lifting motion can increase pressure on the wrists, potentially worsening pain or nerve compression.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural wrist position and reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a wider grip to increase the range of motion and engage the shoulders more intensely.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform lateral raises with light dumbbells to reduce stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist straps or a neutral grip bar to alleviate pressure on the wrists.

safetyNotes: Avoid lifting the barbell above shoulder height to reduce the risk of shoulder impingement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement to protect the lower back.
Use a controlled tempo to prevent jerking movements that can strain the shoulders and wrists.
formCues: Keep elbows higher than wrists throughout the lift.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
Lift the bar close to the body to maintain proper form.
commonMistakes: Lifting the bar too high, causing shoulder impingement.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the wrists to bend excessively, increasing strain.

name: Upright Cable Row
instructions: Grasp a straight bar cable attachment that is attached to a low pulley with a pronated (palms facing your thighs) grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The bar should be resting on top of your thighs. Your arms should be extended with a slight bend at the elbows and your back should be straight. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the cable bar as you exhale. The bar should be close to the body as you move it up. Continue to lift it until it nearly touches your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the bar, your elbows should always be higher than your forearms. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the bar back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The upward motion of the upright cable row can exacerbate shoulder impingement by compressing the structures within the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff, which may worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The exercise requires stabilization of the neck and upper back, which can strain the cervical spine.
contraindicationDetails.acute neck pain: The exercise may exacerbate neck pain due to the engagement of the trapezius and other neck muscles.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and pulling motion can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a resistance band instead of a cable machine to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the cable machine or perform the exercise with a wider grip to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform lateral raises with light dumbbells to reduce shoulder joint stress.
injury_friendly.neck pain: Perform seated rows to engage similar muscles without stressing the neck.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking the weight to prevent shoulder and neck strain.
Keep the movement controlled and within a comfortable range of motion.
formCues: Keep elbows higher than forearms throughout the movement.
Maintain a straight back and engage core muscles for stability.
Exhale while lifting the bar and inhale while lowering it.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to drop below the forearms.
Leaning forward or backward during the lift.

name: Upright Row - With Bands
instructions: To begin, stand on an exercise band so that tension begins at arm's length. Grasp the handles using a pronated (palms facing your thighs) grip that is slightly less than shoulder width. The handles should be resting on top of your thighs. Your arms should be extended with a slight bend at the elbows and your back should be straight. This will be your starting position.

Use your side shoulders to lift the handles as you exhale. The handles should be close to the body as you move them up. Continue to lift the handles until they nearly touches your chin. Tip: Your elbows should drive the motion. As you lift the handles, your elbows should always be higher than your forearms. Also, keep your torso stationary and pause for a second at the top of the movement.
Lower the handles back down slowly to the starting position. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The upright row position can exacerbate shoulder impingement due to the elevation and internal rotation of the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise may place excessive stress on the rotator cuff tendons, potentially aggravating tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The upward pulling motion can strain the neck, especially if form is compromised, which may worsen cervical spine conditions.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The gripping and pulling motion can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis in the elbow.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter resistance band or limit the range of motion to reduce strain.
modifications.harder: Use a thicker resistance band or perform the exercise on one leg to increase core engagement.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the range of motion to below shoulder height and use a lighter band.
injury_friendly.neck_pain: Focus on maintaining a neutral neck position and avoid excessive forward head posture.

safetyNotes: Avoid lifting the bands too high to prevent shoulder impingement.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Do not jerk the bands; use controlled movements.
formCues: Keep elbows higher than wrists throughout the movement.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the torso.
Exhale as you lift, inhale as you lower.
commonMistakes: Lifting the bands too high, causing shoulder strain.
Allowing the wrists to bend excessively.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.

name: Upward Stretch
instructions: Extend both hands straight above your head, palms touching.
Slowly push your hands up and back, keeping your back straight.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Raising the arms overhead can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tear: The upward stretch may place undue stress on the rotator cuff, potentially aggravating a tear.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis: Overhead movements can increase joint stress and discomfort in individuals with severe shoulder arthritis.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical protocols often restrict overhead movements to allow for proper healing.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: Extending the arms overhead can increase cervical spine load, potentially worsening symptoms in individuals with cervical spine pathologies.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with arms bent at the elbows to reduce shoulder joint stress.
modifications.harder: Add a gentle side bend to each side while maintaining the upward stretch to increase the stretch intensity.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform the stretch seated with back support to minimize spinal and shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid hyperextending the lower back during the stretch.
Discontinue the exercise if you experience pain or discomfort in the shoulders or neck.
formCues: Keep your core engaged to maintain a neutral spine.
Ensure your shoulders are relaxed and not elevated towards your ears.
Reach upwards with your fingertips to maximize the stretch.
commonMistakes: Arching the lower back excessively.
Failing to engage the core muscles.
Allowing the shoulders to rise towards the ears.

name: V-Bar Pulldown
instructions: Sit down on a pull-down machine with a V-Bar attached to the top pulley.
Adjust the knee pad of the machine to fit your height. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the resistance attached to the bar.

Grab the V-bar with the palms facing each other (a neutral grip). Stick your chest out and lean yourself back slightly (around 30-degrees) in order to better engage the lats. This will be your starting position.

Using your lats, pull the bar down as you squeeze your shoulder blades. Continue until your chest nearly touches the V-bar. Exhale as you execute this motion. Tip: Keep the torso stationary throughout the movement.
After a second hold on the contracted position, slowly bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the prescribed number of repetitions.

shoulder impingement.details: The overhead pulling motion can exacerbate shoulder impingement symptoms due to compression of the rotator cuff tendons.

rotator cuff tendinitis.details: The exercise may aggravate inflammation in the rotator cuff tendons, especially if performed with improper form or excessive weight.

herniated cervical or lumbar disc.details: The exercise can place undue stress on the spine, potentially worsening disc herniation symptoms.

hypertension.details: The V-Bar Pulldown can increase blood pressure, especially if performed with breath-holding or excessive weight.

recent shoulder or back surgery.details: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to re-injury; this exercise should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.

modifications.easier: Use a resistance band anchored above to perform a similar pulldown motion with less resistance.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase, taking 3-4 seconds to return to the starting position.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a wider grip to reduce stress on the shoulder joint or perform seated rows instead.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise with a supported back using a bench or opt for a seated row to minimize spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the knee pads are properly adjusted to prevent lifting off the seat during the exercise.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your elbows close to your body as you pull down.
Avoid shrugging your shoulders; keep them down and back.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull the bar down.
Leaning too far back, turning the exercise into a row.
Allowing the shoulders to round forward at the top of the movement.

name: V-Bar Pullup
instructions: Start by placing the middle of the V-bar in the middle of the pull-up bar (assuming that the pull-up station you are using does not have neutral grip handles). The V-Bar handles will be facing down so that you can hang from the pull-up bar through the use of the handles.

Once you securely place the V-bar, take a hold of the bar from each side and hang from it. Stick your chest out and lean yourself back slightly in order to better engage the lats. This will be your starting position.

Using your lats, pull your torso up while leaning your head back slightly so that you do not hit yourself with the chin-up bar. Continue until your chest nearly touches the V-bar. Exhale as you execute this motion.
After a second hold on the contracted position, slowly lower your body back to the starting position as you breathe in.
Repeat for the prescribed number of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The overhead pulling motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places stress on the rotator cuff, potentially worsening inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping and pulling can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow, particularly lateral epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The gripping required may increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: Neck positioning during the pull-up can increase cervical spine stress, potentially aggravating disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.thoracic outlet syndrome: Overhead activities can exacerbate symptoms by compressing neurovascular structures.

modifications.easier: Use an assisted pull-up machine or resistance bands to reduce the load.
modifications.harder: Add weight using a dip belt or weighted vest to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform lat pull-downs with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a thicker grip or fat grips to reduce strain on the elbows.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist straps to alleviate pressure on the wrists.

safetyNotes: Ensure the V-bar is securely attached to prevent slipping.
Avoid swinging or kipping to reduce unnecessary joint stress.
Warm up thoroughly before performing the exercise to prepare the muscles and joints.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your body throughout the movement.
Keep your shoulders down and back to prevent excessive elevation.
Pull with your elbows rather than your hands to better engage the lats.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to complete the pull-up.
Failing to fully extend the arms at the bottom of the movement.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up towards the ears.

name: Vertical Swing
instructions: Allow the dumbbell to hang at arms length between your legs, holding it with both hands. Keep your back straight and your head up.
Swing the dumbbell between your legs, flexing at the hips and bending the knees slightly.
Powerfully reverse the motion by extending at the hips, knees, and ankles to propel yourself upward, swinging the dumbell over your head.
As you land, absorb the impact through your legs and draw the dumbbell to your torso before the next repetition.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the dynamic load on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or shoulder arthritis or tendinitis should modify or avoid this exercise to prevent exacerbation of symptoms.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider before performing high-intensity exercises.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid exercises that involve high-impact or overhead movements.
