osteoporosis.details: The risk of fracture due to high-impact forces makes this exercise unsuitable for individuals with osteoporosis.

acute_injuries.details: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or back require avoidance of this exercise until fully healed.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may increase the risk of falls or improper form, necessitating caution or modification.

modifications.easier: Perform the swing with a lighter dumbbell or kettlebell, and limit the range of motion to below shoulder height.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the dumbbell or perform the exercise on one leg to challenge balance and stability.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a lighter weight and focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Reduce the depth of the squat and ensure knees track over toes to minimize joint stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Limit the swing to shoulder height and avoid overhead movements.

safetyNotes: Ensure adequate warm-up before performing this exercise.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
Avoid locking the knees at the top of the movement.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through the hips, not the arms, to initiate the swing.
Land softly and absorb impact through the legs.
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the swing.
Using the arms instead of the hips to generate momentum.
Allowing the knees to cave inward during the squat phase.

name: Walking, Treadmill
instructions: To begin, step onto the treadmill and select the desired option from the menu. Most treadmills have a manual setting, or you can select a program to run. Typically, you can enter your age and weight to estimate the amount of calories burned during exercise. Elevation can be adjusted to change the intensity of the workout.

Treadmills offer convenience, cardiovascular benefits, and usually have less impact than walking outside. When walking, you should move at a moderate to fast pace, not a leisurely one. Being an activity of lower intensity, walking doesn't burn as many calories as some other activities, but still provides great benefit. A 150 lb person will burn about 175 calories walking 4 miles per hour for 30 minutes, compared to 450 calories running twice as fast. Maintain proper posture as you walk, and only hold onto the handles when necessary, such as when dismounting or checking your heart rate.

severe cardiovascular conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should avoid treadmill walking without medical clearance due to potential cardiovascular strain.

acute knee injuries.details: Those with recent knee sprains or strains should modify the exercise to reduce joint stress, possibly by reducing speed and incline.

balance disorders.details: People with significant balance issues should use caution or avoid treadmill walking due to the risk of falls.

severe arthritis.details: Individuals with advanced arthritis may experience discomfort and should consider lower-impact alternatives or modifications.

recent lower limb surgery.details: Post-surgical patients should avoid treadmill walking until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent complications.

modifications.easier: Reduce the speed and incline to decrease intensity.
modifications.harder: Increase the incline or speed to elevate the workout intensity.

injury_friendly.back pain: Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive incline.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a lower incline and speed to minimize knee stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the treadmill is properly calibrated and functioning before use.
Use the safety clip to stop the treadmill in case of an emergency.
Avoid sudden changes in speed or incline to prevent loss of balance.
formCues: Maintain an upright posture with shoulders relaxed.
Engage the core muscles to support the lower back.
Use a natural arm swing and avoid holding onto the handles unless necessary.
commonMistakes: Leaning forward excessively, which can strain the back.
Holding onto the handles continuously, reducing the effectiveness of the workout.
Setting the speed too high, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.

name: Weighted Ball Hyperextension
instructions: To begin, lie down on an exercise ball with your torso pressing against the ball and parallel to the floor. The ball of your feet should be pressed against the floor to help keep you balanced. Place a weighted plate under your chin or behind your neck. This is the starting position.
Slowly raise your torso up by bending at the waist and lower back. Remember to exhale during this movement.
Hold the contraction on your lower back for a second and lower your torso back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions prescribed in your program.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The exercise places significant stress on the lumbar spine, which can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - Hyperextension can increase spinal canal narrowing, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The exercise can increase anterior shear forces on the spine, aggravating the condition.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The exercise may irritate the sciatic nerve; modifications or alternative exercises are recommended.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: high - The exercise involves spinal flexion and extension, increasing fracture risk in individuals with low bone density.
contraindicationDetails.recent spinal surgery: high - Post-surgical patients should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: moderate - Balance and core stability are compromised; alternative exercises are recommended.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: moderate - The exercise requires significant balance and stability, posing a fall risk.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without added weight to focus on form and control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the plate or perform the exercise on a decline bench for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform prone back extensions on a mat without weights to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Ensure feet are firmly planted and consider using a lower platform to reduce knee strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the exercise ball is properly inflated and stable.
Avoid hyperextending the spine beyond a neutral position.
Maintain a slow and controlled movement to prevent injury.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your spine.
Keep your head in line with your spine to avoid neck strain.
Exhale as you lift your torso and inhale as you lower it.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movements.
Hyperextending the back excessively.
Allowing the head to drop forward, causing neck strain.

name: Weighted Ball Side Bend
instructions: To begin, lie down on an exercise ball with your left side of the torso (waist, hips and shoulder) pressed against the ball.

Your feet should be on the floor while your legs are crossed and hanging from the ball. Hold a weighted plate with your right hand directly to the right side of your head. Tip: Make sure the smooth side of the plate is resting against your head.
Place your left arm across your torso so that your palm is on your obliques. There should be a right angle between your left forearm and upper arm. This is the starting position.
Raise the side of your torso up by laterally flexing at the waist while exhaling.
Hold the contraction for a second and slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
Switch sides and repeat the exercise.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the lateral flexion and load on the spine.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The lateral flexion and potential for spinal loading increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The balance required and the position on the ball may be unsafe, especially in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.recent_abdominal_surgery: The exercise places stress on the abdominal region, which may interfere with healing post-surgery.
contraindicationDetails.balance_disorders: The instability of the exercise ball can exacerbate balance issues, increasing the risk of falls.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise without the weighted plate to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the plate or perform the exercise on a less stable surface to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform side bends while standing with a light dumbbell, avoiding excessive lateral flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise without holding a weight, keeping the arm across the chest.

safetyNotes: Ensure the exercise ball is properly inflated and stable.
Avoid excessive lateral flexion to prevent strain on the spine.
Maintain control throughout the movement to prevent falls.
formCues: Keep the core engaged throughout the movement.
Exhale while lifting the torso and inhale while returning to the starting position.
Avoid twisting the torso; focus on pure lateral flexion.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the torso instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the hips to rotate instead of maintaining a stable position.
Holding the breath during the movement, which can increase intra-abdominal pressure.

name: Weighted Bench Dip
instructions: For this exercise you will need to place a bench behind your back and another one in front of you. With the benches perpendicular to your body, hold on to one bench on its edge with the hands close to your body, separated at shoulder width. Your arms should be fully extended.

The legs will be extended forward on top of the other bench. Your legs should be parallel to the floor while your torso is to be perpendicular to the floor. Have your partner place the dumbbell on your lap. Note: This exercise is best performed with a partner as placing the weight on your lap can be challenging and cause injury without assistance. This will be your starting position.

Slowly lower your body as you inhale by bending at the elbows until you lower yourself far enough to where there is an angle slightly smaller than 90 degrees between the upper arm and the forearm. Tip: Keep the elbows as close as possible throughout the movement. Forearms should always be pointing down.
Using your triceps to bring your torso up again, lift yourself back to the starting position while exhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position and movement of the weighted bench dip can exacerbate shoulder impingement by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places significant stress on the shoulder joint, which can aggravate a rotator cuff injury.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The triceps activation and elbow flexion/extension can worsen symptoms of tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The wrist extension required can exacerbate pain in individuals with pre-existing wrist issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or elbow surgery: Post-surgical tissues may not be able to handle the stress of this exercise, risking re-injury.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The wrist position and pressure can increase symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.

modifications.easier: Perform bench dips without additional weight, or use a chair or lower surface for foot support.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the lap or perform the exercise with one leg elevated.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid deep flexion of the shoulder.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use resistance bands instead of weights to reduce joint stress.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Perform the exercise with neutral wrist grips or use wrist wraps for support.

safetyNotes: Ensure the benches are stable and secure before starting the exercise.
Have a partner assist with placing and removing the weight to prevent injury.
Avoid excessive forward lean which can increase shoulder stress.
formCues: Keep elbows close to your body throughout the movement.
Maintain a tall posture with your chest up and shoulders back.
Lower your body slowly and with control, avoiding bouncing at the bottom.
commonMistakes: Allowing elbows to flare out excessively.
Dropping too quickly into the dip, leading to poor control.
Using momentum rather than muscle control to lift back up.

name: Weighted Crunches
instructions: Lie flat on your back with your feet flat on the ground or resting on a bench with your knees bent at a 90 degree angle.
Hold a weight to your chest, or you may hold it extended above your torso. This will be your starting position.
Now, exhale and slowly begin to roll your shoulders off the floor. Your shoulders should come up off the floor about 4 inches while your lower back remains on the floor.
At the top of the movement, flex your abdominals and hold for a brief pause.
Then inhale and slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position.

spinal injuries.explanation: Weighted crunches can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or spinal stenosis due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and spinal flexion.

pregnancy.explanation: Exercises involving supine positions and abdominal pressure are not recommended during pregnancy, especially after the first trimester.

osteoporosis.explanation: The spinal flexion involved in crunches can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

acute abdominal injuries.explanation: Performing crunches with an acute abdominal injury can worsen the condition and delay healing.

modifications.easier: Perform crunches without weights to reduce the load on the spine and core muscles.
modifications.harder: Hold the medicine ball with arms fully extended above the chest to increase the lever arm and challenge the abdominals more.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform partial crunches or isometric holds to minimize spinal flexion and reduce stress on the lower back.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking motions to prevent strain on the neck and back.
Maintain a neutral neck position to avoid cervical strain.
formCues: Engage your core before initiating the movement.
Exhale as you crunch up and inhale as you return to the starting position.
Keep your lower back pressed into the floor throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the shoulders off the ground.
Pulling on the neck with the hands, which can cause strain.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively.

name: Weighted Jump Squat
instructions: Position a lightly loaded barbell across the back of your shoulders. You could also use a weighted vest, sandbag, or other type of resistance for this exercise.
The weight should be light enough that it doesn't slow you down significantly. Your feet should be just outside of shoulder width with your head and chest up. This will be your starting position.

Using a countermovement, squat partially down and immediately reverse your direction to explode off of the ground, extending through your hips, knees, and ankles. Maintain good posture throughout the jump.
As you return to the ground, absorb the impact through your legs.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and explosive movement, which can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.joint_issues: People with knee arthritis, tendinitis, or bursitis may experience increased joint stress during the landing phase, potentially worsening their condition.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: The explosive nature of the exercise can elevate heart rate and blood pressure, posing risks for those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The risk of falls and the need for core stability make this exercise unsuitable during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Recent surgeries, particularly involving the spine, knees, or hips, require avoidance of high-impact activities until fully healed and cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.chronic_conditions: Osteoporosis increases the risk of fractures with high-impact activities. Diabetes with neuropathy may affect balance and proprioception, increasing fall risk.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body should be fully healed before attempting this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.neurological_conditions: Balance disorders or neuropathy can increase the risk of falls and improper landing mechanics.

modifications.easier: Bodyweight jump squats or box jumps without additional weight.
modifications.harder: Increase the barbell weight or perform the exercise on a single leg for added difficulty.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a trap bar or dumbbells to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Perform low-impact plyometric exercises like step-ups or use a leg press machine with controlled speed.

safetyNotes: Ensure the barbell is securely positioned across the shoulders to prevent slipping.
Use a weight that allows for explosive movement without compromising form.
Perform on a non-slip surface to reduce the risk of falls.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Land softly, absorbing impact through the knees and hips.
Maintain a neutral spine during the jump and landing.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, which can lead to poor form and increased injury risk.
Failing to land softly, increasing stress on the joints.
Allowing the knees to cave inward during the jump or landing.

name: Weighted Pull Ups
instructions: Attach a weight to a dip belt and secure it around your waist. Grab the pull-up bar with the palms of your hands facing forward. For a medium grip, your hands should be spaced at shoulder width. Both arms should be extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip.
You'll want to bring your torso back about 30 degrees while creating a curvature in your lower back and sticking your chest out. This will be your starting position.
Now, exhale and pull your torso up until your head is above your hands. Concentrate on squeezing yourshoulder blades back and down as you reach the top contracted position.
After a brief moment at the top contracted position, inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position with your arms extended and your lats fully stretched.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: High shoulder abduction and external rotation can exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The overhead pulling motion can increase inflammation and pain.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping the bar and pulling can strain the elbow tendons.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: Gripping the bar can exacerbate wrist pain, especially if there is existing tendinitis or carpal tunnel syndrome.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The neck may be strained during the exercise, especially if form is compromised.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The axial loading and spinal extension can exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Hyperextension of the lumbar spine can increase vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver can increase blood pressure significantly.
contraindicationDetails.heart disease: The intense effort can place undue stress on the cardiovascular system.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The exercise may not be safe due to balance issues and abdominal strain.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The axial loading and potential for falls increase fracture risk.

modifications.easier: Use a band-assisted pull-up or perform negative pull-ups to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight on the dip belt or perform one-arm weighted pull-ups.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform pull-ups without added weight to reduce spinal load.

safetyNotes: Ensure the dip belt is securely fastened to prevent weight from shifting.
Avoid using excessive weight that compromises form.
Warm up thoroughly before performing weighted pull-ups to prevent injury.
formCues: Engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.
Keep shoulders retracted and depressed throughout the movement.
Avoid swinging or using momentum to complete the pull-up.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to swing up instead of controlled movement.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug or roll forward.
Not fully extending the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Weighted Sissy Squat
instructions: Standing upright, with feet at shoulder width and toes raised, use one hand to hold onto the beams of a squat rack and the opposite arm to hold a plate on top of your chest. This is your starting position.

As you use one arm to hold yourself, bend at the knees and slowly lower your torso toward the ground by bringing your pelvis and knees forward. Inhale as you go down and stop when your upper and lower legs almost create a 90-degree angle. Hold the stretch position for a second.
After your one second hold, use your thigh muscles to bring your torso back up to the starting position. Exhale as you move up.
Repeat for the recommended amount of times.

contraindicationDetails.spinal_injuries: The forward lean and load can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs or sciatica.
contraindicationDetails.knee_joint_issues: The deep knee flexion and load can aggravate arthritis, tendinitis, or previous knee injuries.
contraindicationDetails.cardiovascular_conditions: The strain from holding a weight and the potential for increased blood pressure may not be suitable for individuals with heart disease or hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: The balance and core stability required, along with the load, may not be safe during pregnancy.
contraindicationDetails.surgical_recovery: Individuals recovering from surgeries, especially in the lower body or spine, should avoid this exercise until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.acute_injuries: Recent trauma or sprains in the lower body or core can be exacerbated by this exercise.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight sissy squat without additional weight to reduce load and focus on form.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the plate or use a barbell across the shoulders for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a Smith machine for added stability and reduce the range of motion.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the squat to avoid excessive knee flexion and reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the squat rack or support structure is stable and can support your weight.
Avoid this exercise if you have any knee or back pain.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting this exercise.
formCues: Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a controlled descent and ascent.
Avoid letting the knees collapse inward.
commonMistakes: Leaning too far forward, which can strain the lower back.
Allowing the knees to travel too far past the toes, increasing knee stress.
Using momentum instead of controlled muscle contraction.

name: Weighted Sit-Ups - With Bands
instructions: Start out by strapping the bands around the base of the decline bench. Place the handles towards the inside of the decline bench so that when lying down, you can reach for both of them.

Position your legs through the decline machine until they are secured. Now reach for the exercise bands with both hands. Use a pronated (palms forward) grip to grasp the handles. Position them near your collar bone and rotate your wrist to a neutral grip (palms facing the torso). Note: Your arms should remain stationary throughout the exercise. This is the starting position.

Move your torso upward until your upper body is perpendicular to the floor while exhaling. Hold the contraction for a second and lower your upper body back down to the starting position while inhaling.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.explanation: Weighted sit-ups can exacerbate conditions like herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis due to increased spinal flexion and load.

joint_issues.explanation: Individuals with arthritis or tendinitis, particularly in the lower back or hips, may experience increased discomfort or inflammation.

cardiovascular_conditions.explanation: The exertion involved can elevate blood pressure and heart rate, which may be risky for those with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease.

pregnancy.explanation: Exercises involving significant abdominal pressure and supine positions are generally contraindicated during pregnancy.

surgical_recovery.explanation: Recent abdominal or spinal surgeries require avoidance of exercises that stress the core or spine.

osteoporosis.explanation: The flexion and load can increase the risk of vertebral fractures in individuals with osteoporosis.

safetyNotes: Ensure bands are securely attached to prevent snapping.
Avoid jerking motions to reduce risk of injury.
Maintain a neutral spine to prevent excessive lumbar flexion.
formCues: Engage the core throughout the movement.
Exhale on the upward phase and inhale on the downward phase.
Keep arms stationary and avoid using them to pull yourself up.
commonMistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Arching the back excessively during the upward phase.
Allowing the bands to pull the body back too quickly.

modifications.easier: Perform regular sit-ups without weights or bands to reduce resistance.
modifications.harder: Increase the resistance of the bands or add a weight plate held at the chest.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a stability ball for support and reduce the range of motion to minimize spinal stress.

name: Weighted Squat
instructions: Start by positioning two flat benches shoulder width apart from each other. Stand on top of them and wrap the weighted belt around your waist with the amount of weight you feel comfortable with. Make sure your toes are facing out.
Once you are standing straight up with the weight hanging in between your legs, position your arms so that they are fully extended to the side of your body. This is the starting position.

Begin by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that are perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.

Begin to move the body back up by pushing the floor of the flat bench with the ball of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position. Exhale as you perform this portion of the exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: High compressive forces on the knee joint may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.acute lower back pain: Increased spinal load can worsen pain and impede recovery.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: Standing on benches increases fall risk, requiring stable balance.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: Healing tissues may not tolerate the stress of weighted squats.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: Spinal loading can exacerbate disc issues and cause nerve impingement.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Compression and flexion can irritate the sciatic nerve.

modifications.easier: Perform bodyweight squats on a stable surface without additional weight.
modifications.harder: Increase weight on the belt or perform with a barbell for added resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform squats with a stability ball against a wall to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit depth to a partial squat, ensuring knees do not pass toes.
injury_friendly.balance issues: Perform on the ground rather than elevated surfaces to reduce fall risk.

safetyNotes: Ensure the benches are stable and can support your weight.
Warm up thoroughly before performing weighted squats to prepare muscles and joints.
Avoid locking knees at the top of the movement to maintain muscle tension and joint safety.
formCues: Keep chest up and back straight throughout the movement.
Engage core muscles to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels to activate the posterior chain.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward (valgus collapse).
Leaning forward excessively, causing undue stress on the lower back.
Bouncing at the bottom of the squat, which can strain joints.

name: Wide-Grip Barbell Bench Press
instructions: Lie back on a flat bench with feet firm on the floor. Using a wide, pronated (palms forward) grip that is around 3 inches away from shoulder width (for each hand), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. The bar will be perpendicular to the torso and the floor. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The wide grip can exacerbate impingement by increasing the angle of abduction and external rotation, leading to increased stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places significant load on the shoulder stabilizers, which can aggravate existing rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: Heavy lifting can cause significant increases in blood pressure and heart rate, which may not be safe for individuals with unstable angina.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-operative tissues are vulnerable to stress and strain, and the wide grip can place undue stress on healing structures.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The axial load and potential for falls or dropping the bar pose a high risk of fractures.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The position of the neck during the lift can exacerbate symptoms due to increased cervical spine load.

modifications.easier: Use a Smith machine to provide more stability and control during the lift.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom of the lift to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a narrower grip to reduce shoulder abduction and external rotation, decreasing stress on the shoulder joint.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper bench support and foot placement to maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.

safetyNotes: Always use a spotter when lifting heavy to ensure safety.
Ensure the bar path is controlled and steady to avoid shoulder strain.
Avoid bouncing the bar off the chest to prevent injury.
formCues: Keep feet flat on the floor for stability.
Engage core muscles to maintain a neutral spine.
Lower the bar slowly and with control to the mid-chest.
Exhale as you press the bar back up to the starting position.
commonMistakes: Using too wide of a grip, which can increase shoulder stress.
Arching the back excessively, which can lead to lower back strain.
Failing to lock out elbows at the top of the lift, reducing effectiveness.

name: Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Bench Press
instructions: Lie back on a decline bench with the feet securely locked at the front of the bench. Using a wide, pronated (palms forward) grip that is around 3 inches away from shoulder width (for each hand), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked. The bar will be perpendicular to the torso and the floor. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your lower chest.

After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The wide grip and decline angle can exacerbate impingement by increasing the stress on the shoulder joint.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: The exercise places significant load on the shoulder, which can aggravate existing rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: The exertion and position may increase cardiovascular strain, posing a risk for those with unstable angina.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical shoulders may not tolerate the load and range of motion required for this exercise.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fracture is increased due to the load and position, especially in the spine and ribs.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The decline position can increase intra-abdominal pressure and stress on the lumbar spine.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The decline position may exacerbate anterior slippage of vertebrae.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The decline position may increase blood pressure, posing a risk for those with hypertension.

modifications.easier: Use dumbbells instead of a barbell to allow for a more natural range of motion and less strain on the shoulders.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a pause at the bottom of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Perform the exercise on a flat bench with a narrower grip to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a flat bench to minimize spinal stress and avoid the decline position.

safetyNotes: Ensure the decline bench is securely locked to prevent movement during the exercise.
Use a spotter to assist with lifting and re-racking the barbell.
Avoid excessive arching of the back to prevent spinal strain.
formCues: Keep your feet securely locked at the front of the bench.
Maintain a controlled descent and avoid bouncing the bar off the chest.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Using too wide of a grip, which can increase shoulder strain.
Bouncing the bar off the chest, which can lead to injury.
Failing to lock the arms at the top of the movement, reducing muscle engagement.

name: Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Pullover
instructions: Lie down on a decline bench with both legs securely locked in position. Reach for the barbell behind the head using a pronated grip (palms facing out). Make sure to grab the barbell wider than shoulder width apart for this exercise. Slowly lift the barbell up from the floor by using your arms.
When positioned properly, your arms should be fully extended and perpendicular to the floor. This is the starting position.

Begin by moving the barbell back down in a semicircular motion as if you were going to place it on the floor, but instead, stop when the arms are parallel to the floor. Tip: Keep the arms fully extended at all times. The movement should only happen at the shoulder joint. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.
Now bring the barbell up while exhaling until you are back at the starting position. Remember to keep full control of the barbell at all times.
Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.
When finished with your set, slowly lower the barbell back down until it is level with your head and release it.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The wide grip and overhead motion can exacerbate impingement symptoms by narrowing the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: This exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff, which can worsen existing injuries.
contraindicationDetails.unstable angina: The physical exertion and position may increase cardiovascular strain, posing a risk for those with unstable angina.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder surgery: Post-surgical tissues are vulnerable to stress and strain, which can impede healing.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The risk of fractures is elevated due to the load and position, especially in the thoracic spine.
contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The decline position increases lumbar spine pressure, potentially aggravating disc issues.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The decline angle can increase anterior shear forces on the spine, worsening this condition.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise on a flat bench with a lighter barbell or use dumbbells for better control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slow tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a narrower grip or switch to a flat bench dumbbell pullover to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the exercise on a flat bench and ensure proper core engagement to minimize lumbar strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the decline bench is stable and secure before starting.
Use a spotter if lifting heavy to assist in case of fatigue or loss of control.
Avoid hyperextending the elbows to prevent joint strain.
formCues: Keep the core engaged to stabilize the spine.
Maintain a slight bend in the elbows to protect the joints.
Focus on a controlled motion, especially when lowering the barbell.
commonMistakes: Allowing the elbows to flare excessively, increasing shoulder strain.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Arching the back excessively, leading to potential lumbar strain.

name: Wide-Grip Lat Pulldown
instructions: Sit down on a pull-down machine with a wide bar attached to the top pulley. Make sure that you adjust the knee pad of the machine to fit your height. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the resistance attached to the bar.

Grab the bar with the palms facing forward using the prescribed grip. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than shoulder width. For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out. This is your starting position.

As you breathe out, bring the bar down until it touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work except for holding the bar; therefore do not try to pull down the bar using the forearms.

After a second at the contracted position squeezing your shoulder blades together, slowly raise the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched. Inhale during this portion of the movement.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The wide-grip position can exacerbate shoulder impingement by increasing the risk of pinching the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The overhead pulling motion may aggravate inflammation in the rotator cuff tendons.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical or lumbar disc: The exercise can place stress on the spine, potentially worsening disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: The Valsalva maneuver, often used during lifting, can increase blood pressure.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or back surgery: The exercise places stress on healing tissues and should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: The exercise may pose a risk of vertebral fractures due to spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: The exercise can exacerbate spinal instability, particularly with improper form.

modifications.easier: Use a narrower grip or perform assisted pull-ups to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform pull-ups instead of lat pulldowns.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip attachment to reduce shoulder strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Ensure proper lumbar support and avoid excessive leaning back.

safetyNotes: Ensure the knee pads are adjusted correctly to prevent lifting off the seat.
Avoid using momentum to pull the bar down; focus on muscle contraction.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your chest lifted and shoulders down and back.
Pull the bar to your upper chest, not behind your neck.
Avoid shrugging your shoulders during the pull.
commonMistakes: Using excessive weight leading to poor form.
Pulling the bar behind the neck, increasing shoulder strain.
Leaning back excessively, which can strain the lower back.
Using the forearms to pull instead of the back muscles.

name: Wide-Grip Pulldown Behind The Neck
instructions: Sit down on a pull-down machine with a wide bar attached to the top pulley. Make sure that you adjust the knee pad of the machine to fit your height. These pads will prevent your body from being raised by the resistance attached to the bar.

Grab the bar with the palms facing forward using the prescribed grip. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than your shoulder width. For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso and head forward. Think of an imaginary line from the center of the bar down to the back of your neck. This is your starting position.

As you breathe out, bring the bar down until it touches the back of your neck by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work except for holding the bar; therefore do not try to pull down the bar using the forearms.

After a second on the contracted position squeezing your shoulder blades together, slowly raise the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched. Inhale during this portion of the movement.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.
contraindications: recent shoulder or cervical spine surgery

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The behind-the-neck position can exacerbate impingement by forcing the shoulder into extreme external rotation and abduction.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff tendons, which can worsen inflammation.
contraindicationDetails.cervical spine issues: The position of the neck during this exercise can put undue stress on the cervical vertebrae, potentially aggravating conditions like herniated discs or stenosis.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Holding the breath or straining during this exercise can increase blood pressure, posing risks for individuals with hypertension.
contraindicationDetails.recent shoulder or cervical spine surger: The exercise places stress on the surgical sites, which can impede healing and recovery.

modifications.easier: Perform a wide-grip front lat pulldown instead, which reduces stress on the shoulders and neck.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.
modifications.injury_friendly: Use a resistance band for a similar movement pattern with less load on the joints, or perform seated rows to target similar muscle groups without overhead stress.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the shoulders and neck.
Ensure the movement is controlled and avoid jerking the bar down.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid excessive forward head posture.
formCues: Keep your chest up and shoulders back throughout the movement.
Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Focus on pulling with your back muscles rather than your arms.
Avoid pulling the bar too far down; it should just touch the back of your neck.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to pull the bar down.
Allowing the head to jut forward excessively.
Pulling the bar too far down or behind the neck.
Not engaging the core, leading to excessive arching of the lower back.

name: Wide-Grip Rear Pull-Up
instructions: Grab the pull-up bar with the palms facing forward using a wide grip.

As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar, bring your torso forward and head so that there is an imaginary line from the pull-up bar to the back of your neck. This is your starting position.

Pull your torso up until the bar is near the back of your neck. To do this, draw the shoulders and upper arms down and back while slightly leaning your head forward. Exhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move. The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.
After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.
Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The wide grip and overhead position can exacerbate impingement symptoms by compressing the structures in the subacromial space.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff tendinitis: The exercise places significant stress on the rotator cuff muscles, particularly during the eccentric phase, which can worsen tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: Gripping the bar tightly and the repetitive pulling motion can aggravate tendinitis in the elbow, especially lateral epicondylitis.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The wrist position and grip can increase pressure on the median nerve, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.herniated cervical disc: The neck position and potential for cervical extension during the exercise can increase pressure on cervical discs.
contraindicationDetails.thoracic outlet syndrome: The overhead position can compress the neurovascular bundle, exacerbating symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome.

modifications.easier: Assisted pull-up machine or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Weighted pull-ups by adding a weight belt.

injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a neutral grip pull-up to reduce shoulder stress.
injury_friendly.elbow pain: Perform inverted rows with a neutral grip to minimize elbow strain.
injury_friendly.back pain: Lat pull-downs with a moderate grip to avoid excessive spinal loading.

safetyNotes: Ensure the pull-up bar is secure and can support your weight.
Avoid excessive swinging or kipping to prevent undue stress on the shoulders and spine.
Maintain a controlled motion throughout the exercise to reduce injury risk.
formCues: Engage your core to stabilize your torso.
Keep your shoulders down and back to activate the lats effectively.
Avoid craning your neck forward; keep it in a neutral position.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to complete the pull-up.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up towards the ears.
Failing to fully extend the arms at the bottom of the movement.

name: Wide-Grip Standing Barbell Curl
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright while holding a barbell at the wide outer handle. The palm of your hands should be facing forward. The elbows should be close to the torso. This will be your starting position.
While holding the upper arms stationary, curl the weights forward while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Tip: Only the forearms should move.
Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. Hold the contracted position for a second and squeeze the biceps hard.
Slowly begin to bring the bar back to starting position as your breathe in.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during curling motion can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Wide grip may increase shoulder abduction, potentially aggravating impingement.
contraindicationDetails.wrist pain: The supinated grip can stress the wrist joints, worsening existing pain.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Prolonged wrist flexion and gripping can increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injury: Wide grip can place additional stress on the shoulder joint, affecting the rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.spinal injuries: Standing position requires core stability; those with spinal injuries should avoid or modify.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: Isometric contraction and breath holding can increase blood pressure.

modifications.easier: Use lighter weights or resistance bands to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase or add a pause at the top.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated with back support to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a closer grip to reduce shoulder abduction.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use an EZ curl bar to reduce wrist supination.

safetyNotes: Avoid using momentum to lift the barbell.
Keep a neutral spine to prevent lower back strain.
Ensure a firm grip to prevent the bar from slipping.
formCues: Keep elbows close to the torso throughout the movement.
Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top of the curl.
Lower the barbell slowly to maintain control.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to flare out.
Using too much weight, compromising form.

name: Wide Stance Barbell Squat
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.
Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a wider-than-shoulder-width stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance, and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position.

Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading on the spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should perform with caution and may require modifications to reduce joint stress.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician before performing high-intensity exercises.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should modify or avoid due to balance and intra-abdominal pressure concerns.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery on the lower back, hips, or knees requires complete avoidance until cleared by a healthcare provider.

chronic_conditions.details: Those with osteoporosis should avoid heavy loading due to fracture risk; modifications are necessary.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy may require modifications or supervision to prevent falls.

modifications.easier: Perform a bodyweight squat or use a lighter barbell with a reduced range of motion.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform a pause squat, holding the bottom position for 2-3 seconds.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Use a safety squat bar or perform goblet squats to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit depth to a pain-free range and consider using a box squat to control depth.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a front squat grip or a safety squat bar to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Always use a squat rack with safety bars set at an appropriate height.
Warm up thoroughly before attempting heavy lifts.
Ensure proper footwear with good grip and support.
formCues: Keep your chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Drive through your heels to initiate the upward phase.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding your back.
commonMistakes: Allowing knees to cave inward during the squat.
Leaning too far forward, placing excessive stress on the lower back.
Rising onto the toes instead of keeping weight in the heels.

name: Wide Stance Stiff Legs
instructions: Begin with a barbell loaded on the floor. Adopt a wide stance, and then bend at the hips to grab the bar. Your hips should be as far back as possible, and your legs nearly straight. Keep your back straight, and your head and chest up. This will be your starting position.

Begin the movement be engaging the hips, driving them forward as you allow the arms to hang straight. Continue until you are standing straight up, and then slowly return the weight to the starting position. For successive reps, the weight need not touch the floor.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, spinal stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the significant load on the lumbar spine.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee or hip arthritis should modify the range of motion to avoid exacerbating symptoms.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: People with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a healthcare provider due to the potential for increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance and intra-abdominal pressure concerns.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery in the lower back, hips, or knees requires clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Individuals with osteoporosis should avoid heavy loading and consider alternative exercises to reduce fracture risk.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid this exercise if recovering from recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower back or lower extremities.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with a lighter weight or use dumbbells instead of a barbell to reduce load and improve control.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or add a pause at the bottom of the movement to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform a Romanian deadlift with a reduced range of motion and focus on maintaining a neutral spine.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit the depth of the movement and ensure knees are not locked out to reduce stress on the joint.

safetyNotes: Always warm up thoroughly before performing this exercise.
Avoid rounding the back to prevent spinal injuries.
Do not lock the knees fully to maintain joint safety.
formCues: Keep your back straight and chest up throughout the movement.
Engage your core to stabilize the spine.
Drive through the heels and keep the bar close to your body.
commonMistakes: Rounding the lower back during the lift.
Using too much weight, compromising form.
Not engaging the core, leading to instability.

name: Wind Sprints
instructions: Hang from a pull-up bar using a pronated grip. Your arms and legs should be extended. This will be your starting position.
Begin by quickly raising one knee as high as you can. Do not swing your body or your legs. 3
Immediately reverse the motion, returning that leg to the starting position. Simultaneously raise the opposite knee as high as possible.
Continue alternating between legs until the set is complete.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High spinal flexion and extension forces can exacerbate the condition.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: Hanging and leg movement may increase spinal compression and discomfort.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Spinal instability can be aggravated by the dynamic movement of the legs.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Leg raises may increase nerve compression and pain.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Hanging position can exacerbate shoulder joint compression.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise places stress on the shoulder joint, potentially worsening the injury.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Risk of fracture due to high impact and spinal loading.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Hanging and dynamic leg movement may not be safe due to changes in balance and joint stability.

modifications.easier: Perform lying leg raises on the floor to reduce load and complexity.
modifications.harder: Add ankle weights to increase resistance.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform seated knee raises to reduce spinal load.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Use a captain's chair to eliminate the need for hanging.

safetyNotes: Ensure the pull-up bar is secure and can support your weight.
Avoid swinging your body to prevent excessive spinal motion.
formCues: Engage your core throughout the movement.
Keep your shoulders down and back to stabilize the shoulder girdle.
Move your legs in a controlled manner to avoid momentum.
commonMistakes: Swinging the body to generate momentum.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up towards the ears.
Not engaging the core, leading to excessive lumbar extension.

name: Windmills
instructions: Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides and your legs straight. This will be your starting position.
Lift one leg and quickly cross it over your body, attempting to touch the ground near the opposite hand.
Return to the starting position, and repeat with the opposite leg. Continue to alternate for 10-20 repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: High rotational forces can exacerbate disc herniation, increasing pain and risk of further injury.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: The twisting motion may compress the spinal canal, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: Excessive spinal rotation can increase instability and pain.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: Rotational movements can irritate the sciatic nerve, leading to increased pain.
contraindicationDetails.hip arthritis: Crossing the leg over the body may cause discomfort in those with hip joint degeneration.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: Arm positioning may exacerbate impingement symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: Supine position and twisting can be uncomfortable and potentially harmful, especially in later stages.
contraindicationDetails.osteoporosis: Twisting motions can increase the risk of vertebral fractures.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with bent knees to reduce the range of motion and decrease strain on the lower back.
modifications.harder: Hold a light weight in the hands to increase the challenge on the core and shoulder stability.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform a standing version of the exercise, keeping the movement slow and controlled.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid excessive strain on the knees.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep arms at a lower angle or perform with hands on the chest to reduce shoulder strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid jerking or fast movements to minimize risk of injury.
Maintain control throughout the exercise to protect the spine.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain.
formCues: Engage your core before lifting your leg.
Keep your shoulders flat on the ground.
Move slowly and with control, focusing on the twist coming from the torso.
commonMistakes: Allowing the shoulders to lift off the ground.
Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
Not engaging the core, leading to excessive lumbar strain.

name: World's Greatest Stretch
instructions: This is a three-part stretch. Begin by lunging forward, with your front foot flat on the ground and on the toes of your back foot. With your knees bent, squat down until your knee is almost touching the ground. Keep your torso erect, and hold this position for 10-20 seconds.

Now, place the arm on the same side as your front leg on the ground, with the elbow next to the foot. Your other hand should be placed on the ground, parallel to your lead leg, to help support you during this portion of the stretch.

After 10-20 seconds, place your hands on either side of your front foot. Raise the toes of the front foot off of the ground, and straighten your leg. You may need to reposition your rear leg to do so. Hold for 10-20 seconds, and then repeat the entire sequence for the other side.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: The forward bending and twisting motion may exacerbate symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: The stretch can place pressure on the sciatic nerve, potentially worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.knee injuries: Lunging can stress the knee joint, particularly if there is instability or pain.
contraindicationDetails.hip impingement: Deep lunging can aggravate hip joint issues.
contraindicationDetails.recent hip or knee surgery: Post-surgical recovery may not tolerate the range of motion required.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: The exercise requires stability and balance, which may be compromised.

modifications.easier: Perform the stretch with a shorter lunge and use a chair or wall for support.
modifications.harder: Add a dynamic component by transitioning smoothly between positions without pausing.

injury_friendly.back pain: Perform the stretch with a more upright torso and avoid deep lunging.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Use a pad under the back knee and reduce the depth of the lunge.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Keep hands on the hips instead of reaching to the ground.

safetyNotes: Warm up adequately before performing the stretch.
Avoid bouncing or jerking movements to prevent muscle strain.
Ensure a stable surface to prevent slipping.
formCues: Keep the front knee aligned over the ankle to avoid excessive stress.
Engage the core to maintain balance and support the lower back.
Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
commonMistakes: Allowing the front knee to extend beyond the toes.
Collapsing the chest forward instead of maintaining an upright torso.
Failing to engage the core, leading to instability.

name: Wrist Circles
instructions: Start by standing straight with your feet being shoulder width apart from each other. Elevate your arms to the side of you until they are fully extended and parallel to the floor at a height that is evenly aligned with your shoulders. Tip: Your torso and arms should form the letter "T: Your palms should be facing down. This is the starting position.

Keeping your entire body stationary except for the wrists, begin to rotate both wrists forward in a circular motion. Tip: Pretend that you are trying to draw circles by using your hands as the brush. Breathe normally as you perform this exercise.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Repetitive wrist movements can exacerbate symptoms by increasing pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: Circular wrist movements may aggravate inflammation in the tendons.
contraindicationDetails.recent wrist fracture: Movement can interfere with the healing process and should be avoided until cleared by a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.severe arthritis in the wrist: This exercise may increase pain and inflammation in affected joints.

modifications.easier: Perform wrist circles with elbows bent to reduce the lever arm and decrease strain on the wrists.
modifications.harder: Hold a light dumbbell or resistance band to increase resistance during the wrist circles.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform seated wrist circles with forearms supported on a table to minimize strain.

safetyNotes: Avoid excessive speed to prevent unnecessary strain on the wrist joints.
Stop immediately if you experience pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your shoulders relaxed and avoid shrugging.
Maintain a neutral wrist position without excessive flexion or extension.
Focus on smooth, controlled movements.
commonMistakes: Moving the entire arm instead of isolating the wrist.
Performing the exercise too quickly, leading to loss of control.
Allowing the shoulders to rise or tense up.

name: Wrist Roller
instructions: To begin, stand straight up grabbing a wrist roller using a pronated grip (palms facing down). Your feet should be shoulder width apart.

Slowly lift both arms until they are fully extended and parallel to the floor in front of you. Note: Make sure the rope is not wrapped around the roller. Your entire body should be stationary except for the forearms. This is the starting position.
Rotate one wrist at a time in an upward motion to bring the weight up to the bar by rolling the rope around the roller.
Once the weight has reached the bar, slowly begin to lower the weight back down by rotating the wrist in a downward motion until the weight reaches the starting position.
Repeat for the prescribed amount of repetitions in your program.

carpal_tunnel_syndrome.explanation: This exercise can exacerbate symptoms due to repetitive wrist flexion and extension.

arthritis.explanation: Individuals with arthritis in the wrists or hands may experience increased pain and inflammation.

recent_hand_or_wrist_surgery.explanation: Post-surgical recovery requires avoiding stress on the healing tissues.

neuropathy.explanation: Reduced sensation can increase the risk of injury due to improper grip or excessive load.

tendinitis.explanation: Repetitive wrist movements can aggravate tendinitis in the wrist or forearm.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter weight or a shorter rope to reduce the load on the forearms.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or use a thicker bar to enhance grip challenge.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist curls with a dumbbell or resistance band to control the range of motion and reduce strain.

safetyNotes: Ensure the weight is manageable to avoid excessive strain on the wrists.
Maintain a neutral wrist position to prevent undue stress on the joints.
Avoid using momentum; focus on controlled wrist movements.
formCues: Keep your elbows slightly bent and stationary.
Engage your core to stabilize your upper body.
Focus on smooth, controlled wrist rotations.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form.
Allowing the elbows to move excessively.
Using momentum instead of controlled wrist movements.

name: Wrist Rotations with Straight Bar
instructions: Hold a barbell with both hands and your palms facing down; hands spaced about shoulder width. This will be your starting position.
Alternating between each of your hands, perform the movement by extending the wrist as though you were rolling up a newspaper. Continue alternating back and forth until failure.
Reverse the motion by flexing the wrist, rolling the opposite direction. Continue the alternating motion until failure.

contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: High risk of exacerbating inflammation due to repetitive wrist movements.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: Moderate risk of increased compression on the median nerve during wrist flexion and extension.
contraindicationDetails.arthritis in the wrist: Moderate risk of joint pain and inflammation due to repetitive stress.
contraindicationDetails.recent wrist fracture: High risk of re-injury or delayed healing due to stress on the healing bone.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: High risk of fracture due to compromised bone density.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter barbell or a dowel rod to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight of the barbell or perform the exercise with a thicker bar for grip strength.
modifications.injury_friendly: Perform wrist rotations with a resistance band to reduce joint stress and allow for controlled resistance.

safetyNotes: Avoid using excessive weight to prevent strain on the wrist joints.
Ensure a controlled motion to minimize the risk of injury.
Stop immediately if you experience sharp pain or discomfort.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your body to stabilize the movement.
Maintain a neutral wrist position at the start to avoid excessive strain.
Focus on slow, controlled movements to maximize muscle engagement.
commonMistakes: Using too much weight, leading to poor form and increased injury risk.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, reducing control and stability.
Performing the movement too quickly, which can lead to strain.

name: Yoke Walk
instructions: The yoke is usually done with a yoke apparatus, but is sometimes seen with refrigerators or other heavy objects.
Begin by racking the apparatus across the back of the shoulders. With your head looking forward and back arched, lift the yoke by driving through the heels.

Begin walking as quickly as possible using short, quick steps. You may hold the side posts of the yoke to help steady it and hold it in position. Continue for the given distance as fast as possible, usually 75-100 feet.

contraindicationDetails.herniated disc: high - The axial load and compressive forces on the spine during the yoke walk can exacerbate disc herniation.
contraindicationDetails.spinal stenosis: high - The exercise may increase spinal compression, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.spondylolisthesis: high - The forward and downward forces can aggravate vertebral slippage.
contraindicationDetails.sciatica: moderate - The exercise can increase nerve compression; modifications are necessary.
contraindicationDetails.knee osteoarthritis: moderate - The load and impact on the knees can exacerbate symptoms; modifications are recommended.
contraindicationDetails.balance disorders: high - The dynamic nature and heavy load require good balance, posing a risk of falls.
contraindicationDetails.hypertension: moderate - The heavy load can cause spikes in blood pressure; consult a healthcare provider.
contraindicationDetails.recent lower limb surgery: high - The exercise places significant stress on the lower limbs, requiring full recovery before attempting.
contraindicationDetails.pregnancy: high - The exercise poses a risk due to balance and abdominal pressure concerns.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter yoke or a trap bar to reduce the load and improve balance.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or the distance walked to add difficulty.

injury_friendly.back pain: Use a lighter load and focus on maintaining a neutral spine. Consider a sled drag as an alternative.
injury_friendly.knee pain: Reduce the load and distance, or switch to a sled drag to minimize knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Ensure proper padding on the yoke and reduce load. Consider using a harness to distribute weight differently.

safetyNotes: Ensure the yoke is properly secured and balanced before lifting.
Avoid twisting or leaning excessively during the walk.
Use a spotter if attempting heavy loads or if unsure about balance.
formCues: Keep your head up and eyes forward.
Maintain a neutral spine with a slight arch in the lower back.
Drive through the heels and keep steps short and quick.
Engage the core to stabilize the torso.
commonMistakes: Allowing the yoke to sway side to side.
Taking excessively long steps, which can destabilize the load.
Rounding the back, which increases spinal stress.
Holding the breath, which can increase blood pressure.

name: Zercher Squats
instructions: This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height. The correct height should be anywhere above the waist but below the chest. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, lock your hands together and place the bar on top of your arms in between the forearm and upper arm.
Lift the bar up so that it is resting on top of your forearms. If you are holding the bar properly, it should look as if you have your arms crossed but with a bar running across them.

Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back. This will be your starting position. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).

Begin to lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor). Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.
Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the ball of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

spinal_injuries.details: Individuals with herniated discs, stenosis, or spondylolisthesis should avoid this exercise due to the axial loading and forward lean which can exacerbate spinal issues.

joint_issues.details: Those with knee arthritis or tendinitis should be cautious due to the stress on the knee joint. Proper form and reduced load are essential.

cardiovascular_conditions.details: Individuals with uncontrolled hypertension or heart disease should consult a physician due to the Valsalva maneuver and increased blood pressure during heavy lifting.

pregnancy.details: Pregnant individuals, especially in the second and third trimesters, should avoid this exercise due to balance challenges and intra-abdominal pressure.

surgical_recovery.details: Recent surgery in the lower body or spine requires clearance from a healthcare provider before attempting this exercise.

chronic_conditions.details: Osteoporosis patients should avoid heavy axial loading. Diabetes patients with neuropathy should ensure stable footing and balance.

acute_injuries.details: Avoid if experiencing recent sprains, strains, or trauma to the lower body or spine.

neurological_conditions.details: Balance disorders or neuropathy require modifications or alternative exercises to ensure safety.

modifications.easier: Goblet squats with a dumbbell held at chest level to reduce load and improve balance.
modifications.harder: Zercher squats with added resistance bands around the thighs for increased glute activation.

injury_friendly.back_pain: Perform with a lighter load or use a safety squat bar to reduce spinal loading.
injury_friendly.knee_pain: Limit depth to above parallel and focus on controlled tempo to reduce knee stress.
injury_friendly.shoulder_pain: Use a padded bar or towel to reduce discomfort on the forearms and shoulders.

safetyNotes: Always use a squat rack with safety pins set at an appropriate height.
Ensure proper warm-up and mobility exercises before performing Zercher squats.
Avoid excessive forward lean to minimize spinal stress.
formCues: Keep the chest up and core engaged throughout the movement.
Maintain a neutral spine and avoid rounding the back.
Drive through the heels and midfoot to stand up.
commonMistakes: Allowing the knees to cave inward during the ascent.
Rounding the lower back at the bottom of the squat.
Using excessive weight that compromises form.

name: Zottman Curl
instructions: Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell in each hand being held at arms length. The elbows should be close to the torso.
Make sure the palms of the hands are facing each other. This will be your starting position.

While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out. Only the forearms should move. Your wrist should rotate so that you have a supinated (palms up) grip. Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level.
Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.
Now during the contracted position, rotate your wrist until you now have a pronated (palms facing down) grip with the thumb at a higher position than the pinky.
Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back down using the pronated grip.
As the dumbbells close your thighs, start rotating the wrist so that you go back to a neutral (palms facing your body) grip.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.
