contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: High stress on the elbow joint during the rotation and curl can exacerbate tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The movement can cause further compression of the shoulder structures.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The grip and rotation may increase pressure on the median nerve.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The exercise requires stabilization from the shoulder, which can strain an injured rotator cuff.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The load on the arms and potential for improper form can increase fracture risk.
contraindicationDetails.wrist tendinitis: The rotational component can aggravate wrist tendinitis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise seated to reduce stability demands.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slower tempo to increase time under tension.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Use a lighter weight and limit the range of motion to avoid full extension.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip throughout to reduce shoulder involvement.
injury_friendly.wrist pain: Use wrist wraps for support and avoid excessive rotation.

safetyNotes: Maintain a neutral spine throughout the exercise.
Avoid using momentum to lift the weights.
Ensure a controlled motion during both the lifting and lowering phases.
formCues: Keep your elbows close to your torso.
Rotate your wrists smoothly during the transition from supination to pronation.
Focus on contracting the biceps at the top of the movement.
commonMistakes: Swinging the weights using body momentum.
Not fully rotating the wrists during the movement.
Allowing the elbows to drift away from the torso.

name: Zottman Preacher Curl
instructions: Grab a dumbbell in each hand and place your upper arms on top of the preacher bench or the incline bench. The dumbbells should be held at shoulder height and the elbows should be flexed. Hold the dumbbells with the palms of your hands facing down. This will be your starting position.
As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbells keeping the palms down until your upper arm is extended and your biceps are fully stretched.
Now rotate your wrists once you are at the bottom of the movement so that the palms of the hands are facing up.

As you exhale, use your biceps to curl the weights up until they are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder height. Again, remember that to ensure full contraction you need to bring that small finger higher than the thumb.
Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and rotate your wrists so that the palms are facing down again.
Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.

contraindicationDetails.elbow tendinitis: The repetitive flexion and extension of the elbow can exacerbate symptoms of tendinitis.
contraindicationDetails.shoulder impingement: The position of the arms during the curl can lead to impingement if the shoulder is not stable.
contraindicationDetails.carpal tunnel syndrome: The wrist rotation involved may increase pressure on the median nerve, worsening symptoms.
contraindicationDetails.rotator cuff injuries: The stabilization required by the shoulder joint may aggravate existing rotator cuff injuries.
contraindicationDetails.severe osteoporosis: The load on the arms and potential for improper form can increase fracture risk in individuals with severe osteoporosis.

modifications.easier: Perform the exercise with lighter weights or use a resistance band to reduce load.
modifications.harder: Increase the weight or perform the exercise with a slow eccentric phase to increase difficulty.

injury_friendly.elbow pain: Limit the range of motion to avoid full extension and flexion.
injury_friendly.shoulder pain: Perform the exercise with a neutral grip to reduce shoulder stress.

safetyNotes: Ensure the bench is adjusted to a comfortable height to prevent shoulder strain.
Avoid using excessive weight which can compromise form and increase injury risk.
formCues: Keep your back straight and core engaged to stabilize the body.
Control the movement throughout the entire range of motion.
Rotate the wrists smoothly to avoid jerking motions.
commonMistakes: Using momentum to lift the weights instead of controlled muscle contraction.
Allowing the elbows to flare out, which can reduce bicep engagement.
Neglecting wrist rotation, which is crucial for targeting the biceps effectively.
